Qn_Text: A baby is born by elective caesarean section for known congenital cardiac disease. Which of the following is not a conotruncal anomaly.
Explanation:
Explanation:
In situs inversus the main vessels have developed correctly albeit back to front.
Conotruncal anomalies affect the development of the main vessels leading from the heart. Embryologically the aorta and pulmonary arteries begin as one single outlet before separating into two. Where this fails to occur correctly a conotruncal anomaly is seen. DiGeorge Syndrome (a microdeletion on chromosome 22) is associated with all conotruncal anomalies. The following are all conotruncal abnormalities.
  Double outlet right ventricle
DORV is one of the five Ts of cyanotic and plethoric congenital heart disease (Tingle - i.e. Single - ventricle. The others are Tricuspid atresia, Transposition of the great vessels, TAPVC, truncus arteriosus). As the name suggests, both great vessels (the aorta and pulmonary artery) arise from the right ventricle. Consequently it is logical that 100% of cases have a VSD to facilitate drainage of the left ventricle. If the pulmonary trunk is stenotic, as is usually the case, then the lungs will be oligaemic on a CXR. Conversely in the absence of pulmonary stenosis there will be plethora - this accounts for roughly 25% of cases but yet earns DORV its place in the 5Ts. The crux of the imaging findings, and the phrase to look out for in an exam question setting is that there is no continuity between the mitral valve and the adjacent semilunar valve. This finding is pathognomonic of DORV.
Both Edwards (trisomy 18) and Patau (trisomy 13) syndrome patients can exhibit rockerbottom feet and overlapping fingers although the findings are more closely linked with the former. DORV is associated with both trisomys.
  Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
TOF (not to be confused with trache-oesophageal fistula) causes cyanosis but without pulmonary plethora thus is not included in the 5 Ts.
The tetrat consists of:
VSD
Overriding aorta
Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
RV outflow obstruction (hence pulmonary oligaemia)
  TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease presenting after 12 months of age. In ambulant children the classic finding is of squatting whereby the child squats following exertion in order to increase blood flow to the lungs. It usually presents by at least 3-4 months of age however, but at birth the condition can be concealed by shunting of blood through a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Another facet to the clinical presentation can be polycythaemia which takes place due to chronic low oxygen levels.
Owing to the RVH the cardiac apex is turned upwards contributing to an appearance referred to as ‘boot shaped’ to the cardiac shadow on a CXR.
There is a strong association with right sided aortic arch. Nearly all right sided arches are associated with some form of congenital heart disease and most of these are TOF. Conversely 25% of TOF patients also have a right sided aortic arch.
  Transposition of the Great Vessels (TGA)
TGA is one of the five Ts of cyanotic and plethoric congenital heart disease (The others are Tricuspid atresia, Tingle [ie single] ventricle, TAPVC, truncus arteriosus). Broadly speaking this presents either at birth (it is the most common cyanotic heart disease diagnosed in the first 24 hours of life), or at approximately two weeks of age. Two possible theorised reasons for the later presentation are the closure of the PDA and declining foetal haemoglobin levels leading to decompensation. When the great vessels are transposed there exists two independent circulations. This is therefore only compatible with life if a shunt mechanism also exists, such as an ASD, VSD or PDA. The CXR can be initially normal but develops an ‘egg on side’ appearance to the cardiac shadow. In some cases the transposition is ‘corrected’ where the ventricles are also switched such that the correct ventricle feeds the correct great vessel although the left and right sided circulations remain separate. In corrected transposition the CXR features of note are an apparently absent pulmonary trunk, and an abnormal aortic contour.
  Truncus arteriosus
Embryologically the great vessels begin as one 'conotruncus' which separates during development. When this separation process fails, the baby is left with a single outlet called a truncus arteriosus. On a CXR the baby will be plethoric with cardiomegaly and there are a number of associations which help point towards the answer in an exam question setting without the aid of an echocardiogram. Forked ribs, DiGeorge syndrome, a right sided arch, or an interrupted arch are all known associations.
  Interrupted arch
Fortunately interruption of the aortic arch is rare because it comes with a reasonably high mortality rate. The interruption usually occurs either just before or just after the origin of the left subclavian artery. Supply to the rest of the body distal to this point is maintained only via a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). As well as a PDA most babies will also have a VSD leading to a triad of radiological findings (interrupted arch, PDA, VSD). On a CXR the normal aortic knuckle is absent. Another oft-quoted historical finding is the absence of the aortic impression on a barium swallow.
GPT3_explain: Situs inversus is not a conotruncal anomaly because it does not involve the heart's major vessels. Conotruncal anomalies involve the conotruncal region of the heart, which includes the aorta, pulmonary artery, and their major branches. Situs inversus is a condition in which the organs of the body are mirrored or reversed from their normal positions.
Cat_Long: This question falls under 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A patient presenting with chest pain undergoes a cardiac MRI scan. This demonstrates a wall motion abnormality within the anteroseptal myocardial wall. Low T2 signal is also seen within this distribution, in addition to thinning of the myocardium wall. What is the most accurate description of this abnormality?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Myocardial scar / Chronic infarct
This is a non-reperfusable myocardial defect (chronic infarct). It gives a wall motion abnormality but would demonstrate thinned myocardium. The T2 signal is low. Scars demonstrate abnormal Thallium perfusion but does not redistribute with delayed thallium, and does not take up FDG.
  Stunned myocardium
This gives a wall motion abnormality with high T2 signal. There is normal perfusion on Thallium or sestamibi scanning which is a key differentiating feature against hibernating myocardium. It should be expected to spontaneously resolve, whereas hibernating myocardium will not resolve spontaneously.
  Hibernating myocardium
This can be seen as a wall motion abnormality, but also gives abnormal fixed perfusion. Hibernating myocardium redistributes delayed thallium and takes up FDG.
  Focal myocarditis
This classically affects the mid-wall or epicardial (not subendocardial) and does not stay confined to a vascular territory.
GPT3_explain: Myocardial scar is the most accurate description of this abnormality because it is characterized by thinning of the myocardium wall and low T2 signal, which are both present in the cardiac MRI scan. Hibernating myocardium is characterized by reversible wall motion abnormality, which is not present in this case. Stunned myocardium is characterized by transient wall motion abnormality, which is also not present in this case. Acute infarct is characterized by a new wall motion abnormality, which is also not present in this case. Focal myocarditis is characterized by inflammation, which is not present in this case.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man presents having suffered blunt abdominal trauma in a road traffic accident. On examination he has noticeable abdominal wall bruising and a rigid abdomen. A FAST scan is performed, which shows that he has free fluid in the peritoneal cavity. Which SINGLE statement regarding the peritoneal cavity is FALSE?
A: The lesser sac lies anterior to the stomach
B: It is the largest serosal sac in the body
C: It secretes approximately 50 mls of lubricating fluid daily
D: Ascites is the accumulation of excessive amounts of fluid within it
E: It can be divided into the greater and lesser peritoneal sacs
Explanation:
Explanation:
The peritoneal cavity is the potential space between the parietal and visceral peritoneum. It is the largest serosal sac in the body and secretes approximately 50 mls of lubricating fluid daily. Ascites is the accumulation of excessive amounts of fluid within the peritoneal cavity.
The peritoneal cavity can be divided into the greater and lesser peritoneal sacs. The greater sac comprises the majority of the peritoneal cavity. The lesser sac is smaller and lies posterior to the stomach and lesser omentum.
The greater sac can be further subdivided into two compartments by the mesentery of the transverse colon (the transverse mesocolon):
The supracolic compartment – which lies above the transverse mesocolon
The infracolic compartment – which lies below the transverse mesocolon
  The infracolic compartment is further subdivided into the left and right infracolic spaces by the mesentery of the small intestine.
The contents of the supracolic and infracolic compartments is shown in the table below:
Supracolic compartment Infracolic compartment
Stomach
Liver
Spleen
Small intestine
Ascending colon
Descending colon
  The lesser sac is also referred to as the omental bursa and lies posterior to the stomach. It allows the stomach to move freely against the structures posterior and inferior to it. It is connected with the greater sac through an opening called the epiploic foramen.
GPT3_explain: 3. It secretes approximately 50 mls of lubricating fluid daily This statement is false because the peritoneal cavity does not secrete any fluid. Instead, it is lubricated by the peritoneal fluid produced by the mesothelial cells that line the cavity.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about applying knowledge to a clinical situation.

This question falls under category 3: A question about applying knowledge to a clinical situation.

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old man complains to his GP of long-standing indigestion symptoms. He is referred for investigations when simple antacids fail to resolve the issue. A barium swallow is performed which shows a posterior indentation of the oesophagus as well as an absent left aortic knuckle. What is the diagnosis?
A: Right sided arch + aberrant left subclavian artery
B: Right sided aortic arch + mirror image branching
C: Right sided aortic arch + isolation of the left SCA
D: Coarctation of the aorta with an aberrant right subclavian artery
E: Transposition of the great vessels with an aberrant right subclavian artery
Explanation:
Explanation:
Patients with transposition or coarctation are far less likely to reach the age of 43 without being diagnosed.
A posterior indentation of the oesophagus is caused by:
A right sided arch with an aberrant left subclavian artery
A left sided arch with an aberrant right sided subclavian artery
A double aortic arch – this is usually described as also causing an anterior indentation to the trachea
An anterior indentation of the oesophagus is caused by:
An aberrant left pulmonary artery – this is the only vascular anomaly to run between the oesophagus and the trachea
GPT3_explain: The barium swallow showed a posterior indentation of the oesophagus, which is a common finding in coarctation of the aorta. Additionally, the absence of the left aortic knuckle is also a feature of coarctation of the aorta, as the narrowing of the aorta typically occurs just distal to the left subclavian artery. Finally, the presence of an aberrant right subclavian artery is also indicative of coarctation of the aorta. Therefore, the diagnosis is coarctation of the aorta with an aberrant right subclavian artery.

Qn_Text: A 23-year-old man collides with one of the hurdles during an athletics race. Two months later he is still experiencing pain around the distal femur and undergoes an x-ray. There is a well defined partly calcified soft tissue mass underlying the tender area. A clear radiolucent zone separates it completely from the underlying bone which is otherwise normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Myositis ossificans
Trauma to the muscle causes local haemorrhage and necrosis of damaged muscle. The sequelae of this is calcification which can persist long-term. Large muscles are particularly prone to this and the typical patient is a young, active adolescent. Myositis ossificans appears as a calcified soft tissue mass underlying the area of clinical concern. A periosteal reaction may or may not be present but crucially there is no erosion of the underlying cortex, a fact which discriminates it from malignant fibrous histiocytoma. The string sign refers to the presence of a plane of normal tissue separating the mass from the bone and unlike a parosteal osteosarcoma, in myositis ossificans this plane will extend along the whole length of the mass completely separating it from the bone.
  Malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH)
A soft-tissue MFH is the most common subtype of MFHs and the most common malignant primary soft tissue tumour in the over 50s age bracket. It usually presents as a painless soft tissue mass which enlarges over a matter of months. They can be large at the time of diagnosis measuring tens of centimetres. On x-ray they appear as a partly calcified soft tissue mass. Cortical erosion of the underlying bone is an important diagnostic feature. On MRI it returns high signal on both T1 and T2 weighted sequences.
  Tumoral calcinosis
Surprisingly for the sometimes extreme appearance of this condition, it can be completely painless. Patients are typically black and in their teens or 20s. Around a third of cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. A biochemical defect in the metabolism of phosphorus leads to accumulation of hydroxyapatite fluid around the joints causing a foreign-body type granulomatous reaction and fibrous capsule development. On imaging this appears as a progressive and calcified soft tissue mass. The skin overlying the mass can ulcerate and exude a chalky or milk like fluid. Any or all of the hips, shoulders and elbows can be affected but characteristically tumoral calcinosis does not affect the knees. Importantly the underlying bones are normal, a feature which differentiates it from gout or pseudogout.
  Gout
Excess circulating urate levels leads to crystalisation of urate (monosodium urate crystals) within the joint spaces. An acute attack may be precipitated by any acute event such as trauma or surgery as well as a change in diet to include purine containing foods (liver, kidney, game meat, some seafood, alcohol). Historically chronic manifestations of this condition included the development of gouty tophi; white lumpy areas under the skin which could ulcerate and exude a chalky material. These are still seen today but far less so thanks to improved management strategies. Involvement of the first metatarsophalangeal joint is considered classical but involvement of the carpometacarpal joints of the hands is often most debilitating where it occurs. On x-ray the earliest radiological manifestation is a joint effusion. Joint erosions develop on the lateral corners of a joint but contrary to many other erosive processes the base of the ulcers has a sclerotic margin. Juxta-articular osteopenia is not often seen, a feature which acts as a good distinguisher from rheumatoid arthritis, which is thought to be because the attacks come in acute bursts during which time disuse osteopenia does not have the time to develop. Another reasonably specific feature of gouty arthritis is the preservation of the joint space itself until relatively late into the disease.
  Crystals
Gout
Pseudogout
Content
Monosodium urate
Calcium pyrophosphate dehydrate
Shape
Needle
Rhomboid
Birefringence
Strongly negative
Weakly positive
  Osteosarcoma
Secondary osteosarcomas
Paget disease
Bone infarct
Osteochondroma
Osteoblastoma
Radiotherapy change
  These are bone forming tumours which can either be primary, or secondary. Primary osteosarcomas occur in young patients or young adults when the bones are more active during adolescence than in later life, and have a predilection for either the proximal tibia or distal femur i.e. around the knee joint. Secondary osteosarcomas occur as malignant degeneration of pre-existing bone lesions. Clinically they present as a painful mass with a fever. Pain on movement is also typical. In later disease patients may have a raised serum ALP. On x-ray they are poorly defined aggressive lesions with sunburst periosteal reaction and fluffy cloud-like osseous matrix. For staging the patient should receive an MRI of the entire of the affected bone (to rule out synchronous lesions), a nuclear medicine bone scan and a CT chest. Tissue biopsy should only be performed at tertiary referral centres where to mitigate the risk of seeding the biopsy tract, immediate tissue analysis with the option of immediate amputation can be performed.
In the case of a parosteal osteosarcoma, the attachment to the underlying bone may be thin and stalk-like but will be present. Depending on the view a radiolucent plane may seem present for some of the length of the tumour, giving rise to ‘string sign’ appearance, but an attachment to the parent bone will be present.
  Some of the pertinent subtypes of osteosarcoma
Parosteal
Lower grade, older age (20-50s)
Telangiectatic
Purely lytic, poor prognosis, fluid-fluid levels
Multicentric
Ages 5-10 with very poor prognosis
GPT3_explain: Tumoral calcinosis is the most likely diagnosis because it is characterized by a partly calcified soft tissue mass underlying the tender area with a clear radiolucent zone separating it completely from the underlying bone. It is also more common in young adults, which is the age of the patient.

Qn_Text: A 42-year-old man with known type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoes an intravenous urogram following an acute admission with right sided ureteric colic. The IVU shows an egg-in-cup appearance with ‘tracks and horns’ in some of the calyces on the right mentioned in the report. The renal cortical thickness is normal and the left kidney is normal too. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Renal papillary necrosis
The point at which the collecting ducts in the medulla converge to become a minor calyx is known as the renal papilla. The renal papilla marks the beginning of transitional epithelium; hence transitional cell carcinoma can occur within the upper tracts. The papillae are vulnerable to ischaemia of any cause. The blood supply to the papillae is via end vessels ostensibly supplying either the medullary vasa recta or small and tortuous calyceal vessels. Despite this dual supply, both sources are primarily for other purposes and the renal papilla can suffer the consequences of insufficiency of any cause. Some of the predominant causes of renal papillary necrosis can be remembered with the mnemonic POSTCARDS. 
Causes of renal papillary necrosis
Pyelonephritis
Obstruction
Sickle Cell Disease
Tuberculosis
Cirrhosis
Analgesic use
Renal vein thrombosis
Diabetes Mellitus
Systemic vasculitides
  Much of the damage and that which is demonstrable on imaging is explained by necrosis and sloughing off of the papilla to a greater or lesser extent. Signs such as tracks and horns, the lobster claw sign, signet ring sign or ball on a tee sign were originally described on IVU studies but translate reasonably well to CT urogram studies too. Filling defects within the collecting system occur when a papilla is complete sloughed off. These can go on to cause obstruction and hydronephrosis. The long term sequelae of renal papillary necrosis is calcification of the damaged papilla. The appearance is classically a garland pattern i.e. Many small or medium sized foci which appear to run in a line around the collecting system, at the junction of the pyramids and the collecting system. 
  Medullary sponge kidney
Dysplastic dilatation of the intramedullary collecting ducts permits urinary stasis which in turn promotes stone formation. Medullary Sponge Kidney is one of the main differential diagnoses for renal calcification. A quarter of cases are unilateral. This condition can be asymptomatic and noted incidentally or patients can be complicated by recurrent urinary tract infections, recurrent ureteric calculi or haematuria. The two main conditions seen in association with medullary sponge kidney are the collagen disorder Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and Caroli disease which causes cystic dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary ducts. On imaging there are characteristic ‘Aunt Minnie’ type appearances when medullary calcification can be seen on a plain abdominal radiograph. Ultrasound shows increased echogenicity to the renal pyramids even in the absence of medullary calcification. On an IVU the appearance of the dilated ducts is often described to be like a bouquet of flowers or a bunch of grapes and is sometimes termed a ‘medullary blush’.
  Urinary tract calculi
Ureteric colic is common and urinary tract calculi are even more so. There are many metabolic disorders which increase the risk of developing urinary tract calculi but many patients do develop calculi without any underlying cause. Stones can obstruct at any point along the urinary tract however the three narrowest points which are most liable to obstruction are the pelviureteric junction (PUJ), the vesicoureteric junction (VUJ) and at the point where the ureters cross the pelvic brim. As the ureter peristalses a characteristic extremely severe ‘loin-to-groin’ pain is experienced. A CT KUB study is a low dose, non-contrast, exam designed specifically to investigate for urinary tract calculi. A standard CT abdo/pelvis confers three times as much radiation dose at the very least. Although A CT KUB has a very high sensitivity and specificity for the diagnosis of opaque urinary tract calculi it is distinctly suboptimal for the evaluation of other causes of abdominal pain. Unfortunately since its introduction it has become a popular request for many a supposed loin-to-groin pain presentation.
  Stone composition
Associations and features
Frequency
Calcium oxalate/phosphate
Metabolic disorders, hyperparathyroidism or incidental
75%
Struvite/matrix (MgPO3)
UTIs (acute and chronic especially Proteus), staghorn
10-15%
Uric acid
Hyperuricaemia, gout, incidental. Can be seen on CT but not on AXR
6%
Cysteine
Renal tubular defect
1-2%
Indinavir phosphate
HIV medication, filling defects on urograms, not seen on CT or AXR
<1%
  Hyperparathyroidism
Parathyroid hormone acts to increase calcium levels either by promoting reabsorption in the kidneys or by acting on the osteoclasts of the bones and leads to increased bone resorption. This is seen as generalised osteopenia and cortical thinning, particularly of the subperiosteal bone.
Primary hyperparathyroidism is usually caused by an autonomous adenoma (alternatively parathyroid hyperplasia or a parathyroid carcinoma). Medullary nephrocalcinosis is most commonly caused by primary hyperparathyroidism but does also occur with secondary and tertiary hyperparathyroidism.
Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a hyperplastic response of the parathyroid glands to the high phosphate and low calcium levels which accompany renal osteodystrophy. Soft tissue calcification is very much a feature of renal osteodystrophy. Confusingly the high circulating levels of phosphate in renal osteodystrophy leads to dystrophic mineralisation of trabecular bone which is seen as sclerosis; hence renal osteodystrophy is a cause of generalised increase in bone density despite hyperparathyroidism being a cause of osteopenia.
Tertiary hyperparathyroidism occurs when a patient with secondary hyperparathyroidism (i.e. chronic overstimulation of the parathyroid glands) goes on to develop an autonomous adenoma.
GPT3_explain: Medullary sponge kidney is the most likely diagnosis in this case because the IVU showed an egg-in-cup appearance with ‘tracks and horns’ in some of the calyces on the right, which is a classic sign of medullary sponge kidney. Additionally, the renal cortical thickness was normal, which is another indication of medullary sponge kidney. The other four diagnoses are not as likely as medullary sponge kidney in this case.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old lady is admitted from an oncology clinic following a stem-cell transplant four months previously for leukaemia. She has ascites and hepatomegaly. The portal veins appear normal on B-mode but a Doppler study shows increased pulsatility. The experienced sonographer also notes some thickening of the small-bowel wall. What is the most likely explanation? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Although the features in the vignette could be explained by hepatic veno-occlusive disease as well, small bowel wall thickening is more commonly associated with graft vs Host disease. Furthermore, veno-occlusive disease develops within the first 20-30 days following transplantation however graft vs host disease occurs after 3-12 months following transplantation.
Graft vs Host disease
When T-cells from the donor bone marrow attack epithelial cells in the recipient a phenomenon known as Graft versus Host disease can occur. Within the liver this can lead to fibrosis and can present in a similar manner to veno-occlusive disease. The effects are classically seen in the GI tract and the skin as opposed to the lungs but pulmonary manifestations can arise a few months after the transplant. On CT there is mild perihilar fibrosis with nodule formation.
GPT3_explain: I chose 2. Hepatic Veno-Occlusive Disease (VOD) as the most likely explanation because it is a common complication of stem cell transplants. VOD is caused by the destruction of the small hepatic veins due to the toxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy. This can lead to increased pulsatility in the portal veins, as well as ascites and hepatomegaly. It can also cause thickening of the small-bowel wall, which the sonographer noted.

Qn_Text: A 28-year-old man returns from a business trip abroad and presents with generalised abdominal tenderness and diarrhoea which started while he was away. He is suspected to have infective colitis and he brings with him a CD of a CT scan he had whilst abroad and you are asked to review it. The walls of the caecum and ascending colon are low in attenuation with mucosal enhancement and there is a small volume of ascites. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Infective colitis
Infective colitis causes oedematous mural thickening and mural enhancement with the different underlying organism affecting slightly different segments of bowel (albeit with much overlap). Pericolic fat stranding and ascites are variably seen.
Location
Organism
Diffuse involvement of whole colon
CMV and e-coli
Right sided colon
Salmonella and shigella
Left sided colon
Schistosomiasis
Rectosigmoid colon
Gonorrhoea, herpes, Chlamydia (LGV)
GPT3_explain: I chose Salmonella because it is one of the most common causes of infective colitis. Symptoms of Salmonella infection typically include abdominal tenderness, diarrhoea, and fever. The CT scan findings of low attenuation of the walls of the caecum and ascending colon with mucosal enhancement and a small volume of ascites are consistent with the diagnosis of Salmonella infection.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the application of knowledge, what is the most likely organism?

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by his worried wife after becoming unwell at home. He has neurological signs and an MRI spine is requested which shows abnormalities within the spinal cord. You suspect he may have multiple sclerosis. Which of the following is most consistent with multiple sclerosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: High T2 signal affecting 1-2 vertebral levels, grey matter involved, mild cord expansion
B: Low T2 signal affecting 1-2 vertebral levels, grey matter involved, no cord expansion
C: High T2 signal affecting 1-2 vertebral levels, grey matter spared, gross cord expansion
D: Low T2 signal affecting 3-4 vertebral levels, grey matter spared, cord expansion
E: Low T2 signal affecting 3-4 vertebral levels, grey matter involved, no cord expansion
Explanation:
Explanation:
  In general cord expansion is far more of a prominent feature in acute idiopathic transverse myelitis than MS however it can occur with MS, and it’s presence should certainly not exclude MS as a differential diagnosis.
    Demyelination
Demyelination can occur due to multiple sclerosis, ADEM or as an idiopathic process.
Acute idiopathic transverse myelitis is a specific diagnosis of exclusion. There is inflammation of the spinal cord leading to bilateral motor, sensory and autonomic dysfunction. On imaging there is expansion of the central portion of the cord extending over multiple vertebral levels. The inflamed portion returns high signal on T2 weighted sequences. This occurs most commonly in the thoracic spine and importantly, should involve at least two thirds of the cross-sectional area of the cord at the affected level. This is in contrast to a multiple sclerosis plaque which involves under half of the cross-sectional area of the cord.
Multiple sclerosis can affect the spinal cord. Lesions tend to be smaller usually confined to 1-2 vertebral levels and affecting less than half of the cross-sectional area of the cord. There may be mild focal expansion of the cord, but this is a far less prominent feature than it is with idiopathic transverse myelitis. 90% of patients will have other intracranial lesions. The lesions of MS also return high T2 signal, like their intracranial counterparts. The cervical cord is most commonly affected. Gray matter can be affected (particularly in the spine) but it is white matter plaques which are by far the dominant feature. 
ADEM (acute disseminated encephalomyelitis) is an autoimmune condition which occurs days-weeks following a viral infection. It largely affects the white matter of the brain, but the spinal cord can also be affected. Gray matter, particularly the basal ganglia are also often involved. It can occur at any age, but it is usually young children who are affected. Patients usually respond very well to steroid therapy and fortunately, most (90%) cases resolve without any residual deficit. On imaging, the affected areas return high T2 signal.
GPT3_explain: Low T2 signal affecting 3-4 vertebral levels, grey matter involved, no cord expansion is the most consistent with multiple sclerosis. This is because multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system that affects the myelin sheath of the neurons. This results in a low T2 signal on MRI, which is seen in multiple sclerosis lesions. Furthermore, these lesions typically affect 3-4 vertebral levels, involve the grey matter, and do not cause cord expansion.

Qn_Text: A 68-year-old lady from South Africa complains to her GP of new haematuria. She undergoes an abdominal x-ray which shows thin curvilinear calcification outlining the bladder, with further calcification of the distal ureters also evident. An IVU shows a filling defect on the posterior wall of the bladder which corresponds well with discontinuity in the calcification seen on x-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Schistosomiasis
Schistosoma larvae burrow through human skin and travel via the lymphatics to the lungs and liver to mature. Thence they continue onto the pelvic vessels where eggs are deposited in the bladder wall. There the eggs cause both a granulomatous and an inflammatory reaction which erodes through the bladder mucosa and the eggs are then excreted in the urine. The disease is endemic to many parts of Africa.
The dominant imaging feature is of bladder wall calcification. This is usually described as curvilinear or floccular and involves all of the layers of the bladder. Owing to the chronic fibrotic reaction the bladder eventually becomes restricted and small; thus the standout imaging feature is of a small calcified bladder. The main differential diagnosis of bladder wall calcification is tuberculosis.
Another important facet to these cases is the risk of bladder cancer developing in the context of chronic inflammation. These cancers are squamous cell carcinomas and should be actively looked for in cases of schistosomiasis; there is a latent period of approximately 20 years prior to development.
  Renal tuberculosis
In areas of the world endemic to tuberculosis, renal tuberculosis is a reasonably common presentation of extra-pulmonary disease. The appearances on imaging vary depending on the disease timeline. The classical ‘putty kidney’ of renal tuberculosis is an end-stage appearance where there is dystrophic calcification affecting all parts of the kidney. At this point the kidney has usually become shrunken and small and the final appearance is of so-called autonephrectomy when there is essentially no parenchymal tissue left, just amorphous calcification. An earlier manifestation is stenosis to the infundibuli connecting the calyces to the renal pelvis causing proximal dilatation of the calyces which are seen to be clubbed on a urogram. Purportedly, the earliest sign is of moth-eaten calyces owing to uneven erosion to the papillae.
  Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP)
This curious condition results from chronic pyelonephritis and leads to a non-functioning kidney. Chronic infection (most commonly with Proteus or e-coli) induces a granulomatous process whereby the renal tissue eventually becomes replaced by a mass of reactive tissue. Since proteus infection is one of the main causes it is not surprising that many cases present with a staghorn calculus. The exact association varies from 30-90% depending on the data source. The other finding on CT is of multiple low attenuation rounded areas with Hounsfield Units (HU) of around -15 to -20. These are the dilated calyces filled with debris and xanthoma collections and they cause the whole kidney to be enlarged. The appearance is said to resemble a bear’s paw. Patients can present either on a background of recurrent UTIs or potentially renal colic. Vague malaise and weight loss may be the presentation in the absence of direct urinary symptoms.
  Malakoplakia
Directly translated from Greek, malakoplakia just means soft plaques. These are actually submucosal inflammatory plaques consisting of basophilic PAS positive inclusion bodies and incompletely destroyed e-coli bacteria. The giveaway pathological term is Michaelis-Gutmann inclusion bodies which are the incompletely destroyed e-coli bacteria surrounded by a lipoprotein membrane. Although malakoplakia can occur in anyone, patients with diabetes mellitus or immunosuppression are predisposed to it. Importantly though, it is not a pre-malignant condition unlike leukoplakia. On imaging there are filling defects in the bladder and distal ureters. These are usually small, measuring only a few millimetres across.
  Leukoplakia 
Directly translated from Greek, leukoplakia just means white plaques. It is a squamous metaplastic condition affecting the transitional cell epithelium of the bladder. Presentation is usually as a consequence either of recurrent urinary tract infections or urinary tract calculi. Sometimes patients complain of passing flaky white tissue in the urine which is pathognomonic for this condition. On imaging there is mucosal thickening and filling defects within the bladder. Some sources consider leukoplakia to be a premalignant condition for epidermoid carcinoma.
GPT3_explain: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory disorder of the urinary tract that is characterized by the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, which are basophilic, laminated, periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive structures that are seen on histological examination. The presence of thin curvilinear calcification on x-ray and a filling defect on IVU, which corresponds to the calcification, are characteristic of malakoplakia and make it the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by his worried wife. She describes a sudden collapse at home and on examination it is evident that he has loss of power and sensation below T7 on the left, with pain and temperature loss on the contralateral side. An urgent MRI is requested which shows high T2 signal in the T7 vertebral body and high signal of cord at T7. There is no significant adjacent disc disease. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Brown-Sequard syndrome
This is a specific finding where damage to the dorsal columns leads to ipsilateral loss of touch sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation due to damage to the lateral spinothalamic tracts (contralateral since these ascend after having crossed). There is also ipsilateral motor function loss.
  Causes of Brown-Sequard syndrome
Traumatic:
Penetrating injury
Mechanical trauma e.g. RTA
Iatrogenic injury
Compression e.g. disc herniation
Spinal cord tumour
  Vascular:
Aortic aneurysm repair complication
Vertebral artery dissection
Spinal cord haemorrhage
  Spinal cord infarction
The vascular supply to the spinal cord is derived largely from the vertebral arteries or intercostal arteries with one longitudinal running anterior spinal cord artery and two small longitudinally running posterior spinal cord arteries.
The artery of Adamkiewicz is a particularly large segmental artery supplying the anterior spinal artery from around the level of T9. It is responsible for most of the spinal cord blood supply for the lumbar spinal cord. Damage during aortic surgery or trauma can result in spinal cord infarction.
Usually any vascular insult results in a reasonably rapid onset of symptoms. Spinal cord infarctions are no exception. Often more than one vertebral level is affected.
An MRI will showT2 hyperintensity of at least the central grey matter (if not the whole cross-section of the cord) due to oedema. As with intracranial infarctions there will be restriction of diffusion on the DWI sequences.
Particularly in the thoracic spine, the adjacent vertebral body may also lose its blood supply and undergo infarction.
  Demyelination
Acute idiopathic transverse myelitis is a specific diagnosis of exclusion however. On imaging there is expansion of the central portion of the cord extending over multiple vertebral levels.
Multiple sclerosis can affect the spinal cord. Lesions tend to be smaller usually confined to 1-2 vertebral levels and affecting less than half of the cross-sectional area of the cord.
Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis) largely affects the white matter of the brain but the spinal cord can also be affected. On imaging, the affected areas return high T2 signal and there is characteristic sparing of the grey matter.
  Spondylitis
Infection of the spine, termed spondylitis, is usually considered as either pyogenic or tuberculous (with a couple of notable exceptions). There is some overlap in the features of the two:
Tuberculous spondylodiscitis Staphylococcal spondylodiscitis
Calcification (almost pathognomonic) No calcification
Involvement of the posterior elements Posterior elements spared
Insidious onset More acute onset
Less loss of disc space More loss of disc space
Gibbus deformity (angular kyphosis) No gibbus deformity
Multiple levels involved One level involved
  Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallenburg syndrome)
This is caused by either a vertebral artery occlusion or PICA occlusion and is one of those syndromes that is far more common in exams than in real life.
  Subacute combined degeneration
On an MRI scan there will be (if the resolution allows), a longitudinal line of high T2 signal within the cord on sagittal sequences, and often a characteristic 'inverted-V' shape of high T2 signal on axial sequences. In some cases, the 'V' is clearly seen and in others it is harder to appreciate, and the finding is more of high T2 signal bilaterally and symmetrically in the region of the posterior columns.
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis in this case is lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg Syndrome. This is a neurological condition caused by a stroke in the lateral medulla of the brainstem, which can cause symptoms such as loss of power and sensation below T7 on the left, with pain and temperature loss on the contralateral side. The MRI findings of high T2 signal in the T7 vertebral body and high signal of cord at T7 are consistent with this diagnosis.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the radiographs of a 40-year-old marathon runner who has been experiencing worsening hip pains over the last few months. There is over-coverage of the left femoral head by the acetabulum and you suspect she has pincer-type femoroacetabular impingement. Which of the following is most likely to be seen with this abnormality? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Femoroacetabular impingement (FAI)
Mixed type - >80% of patients have components of both cam-type and pincer-type FAI.
Cam type - a cam is an engineering term for an oval/egg shaped component with a hole through the middle of the wider end. In cam type FAI the femoral head takes on a 'cam' shaped appearance due to bony overgrowth at the superior aspect of the femoral neck. This abnormal bony contour impinges against the anterosuperior aspect of the acetabulum during movement. The condition occurs more frequently in men and tends to affect men in their 30s. Certain conditions can predispose to cam-type FAI, including SUFE, DDH and Perthes disease. Some patients with cam-type FAI exhibit femoral retroversion.
Pincer type - here bony protuberance of the anterosuperior acetabulum causes over-coverage of the femoral head and impingement against the femoral neck. Protrusio acetabuli predisposes to pincer-type FAI. The relationship of the overgrown anterior acetabular rim to the posterior acetabular rim in pincer-type FAI is called acetabular retroversion since it causes the femoral neck to twist posteriorly. Patients usually stand with their toes pointing outwards as a consequence. The condition is more common in women and a patient is typically aged around 40.
GPT3_explain: Acetabular retroversion is a common finding in patients with pincer-type femoroacetabular impingement. It is characterized by an increased angle between the acetabulum and the femoral head, which can lead to compression of the femoral head against the acetabulum, resulting in pain and discomfort. This increased angle can be seen on radiographs and can be used to diagnose pincer-type femoroacetabular impingement.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the trachea is FALSE? Select ONE answer only.
A: The trachea inclines slightly to the left during its descent
B: The carina lies at the T5 vertebral level
C: It arises at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage
D: It contains 15 to 20 incomplete C-shaped tracheal rings
E: It is lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium
Explanation:
Explanation:
The trachea marks the start of the tracheobronchial tree, arising at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, as a continuation of the larynx. This is at the C6 vertebral level.
It travels inferiorly into the superior mediastinum, bifurcating at the level of the sternal angle to form the right and left bronchi. Inside the trachea, at the T5 vertebral level, there is a cartilaginous ridge called the carina of trachea that marks the point of bifurcation. During its descent the trachea is located anterior to the oesophagus and inclines slightly to the right.
Below the cricoid cartilage there are 15 to 20 incomplete C-shaped tracheal rings (tracheal cartilages), which are composed of hyaline cartilage, and serve to reinforce the front and sides of the trachea to protect and maintain the airway. The free ends of these rings are supported by the trachealis muscle.
The trachea and bronchi are lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium, interspersed by goblet cells, which produce mucous. The combination of sweeping movements by the cilia and mucous from the goblet cells forms the functional mucociliary escalator, that traps particles and pathogens and moves them up and out of the airways to be swallowed and destroyed.
  Anatomy of the trachea and bronchi (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose 5 because the trachea is lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium and nonciliated cuboidal epithelium.

1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 5-year-old child presents with general malaise, cough and shortness of breath. A chest radiograph is performed in the children’s emergency department. This shows a solitary 3 cm lesion in the right lower zone. There is also added perihilar and peribronchial density bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This question refers to rounded pneumonia. Rounded pneumonia is common in children less than 8 years old and S. Pneumoniae is the usual causative organism. This is by far the commonest cause of a rounded density, much more so than malignancy, and therefore a follow-up chest radiograph is the most appropriate next investigation.
Rounded pneumonia commonly occurs in the posterior lower zones. Perihilar and peribronchial density is the most common finding with infection in children (particularly viral).
There is mounting evidence that, if responding appropriately to antibiotic therapy, a child with a round pneumonia should not undergo follow up imaging for the sake of follow up itself. However, since 'no further imaging' is not given as an option here, the next most appropriate imaging is a follow-up chest radiograph rather than cross-sectional imaging.
GPT3_explain: CT chest with arterial contrast is the most appropriate next investigation because it will provide the most detailed information about the lesion. It can help to determine the size, shape, and location of the lesion, as well as any associated soft tissue or vascular changes. Additionally, the arterial contrast will help to identify any potential arterial involvement, which can help to narrow down the differential diagnosis.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the application of knowledge to a clinical scenario.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old woman is being followed up for a strong family history of breast cancer. She is deemed to be high risk and undergoes an MRI scan. This shows an enhancing mass lesion in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast which was not seen on either mammography or her ultrasound scan. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
BRCA 1 inheritance is predominantly associated with ductal carcinomas whereas BRCA 2 inheritance can be associated with both lobular and ductal carcinomas. Lobular carcinomas are the most frequently missed breast cancer and in the exam context a mass seen on MRI that is not seen on mammography or ultrasound would be a lobular carcinoma. When they are seen on mammography it would usually be as a spiculated mass lesion.
GPT3_explain: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common type of breast cancer, accounting for about 80 percent of all breast cancer cases. It typically presents as a mass in the breast, which is what was seen on the MRI scan. Additionally, it is not typically seen on mammography or ultrasound scans.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 74-year-old man who has been experiencing an aching sensation in his scrotum. The ultrasound scan shows a right sided varicocele but no other concerning features. What should you advise next? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein. The pressure in the left renal vein can be higher than it is in the right renal vein since the left renal vein courses between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery ('the nutcracker effect'). For this reason, isolated left sided varicoceles are extremely common and require no further follow up.
The right gonadal vein usually drains into the IVC. In theory a right renal tumour causing tumour thrombus, or a retroperitoneal mass causing IVC compression, can give rise to an isolated right sided varicocele and it is for this reason that a renal ultrasound scan should be performed if a unilateral right sided varicocele is discovered.
This finding is particularly pertinent for older patients since renal lesions are far less likely in younger patients and rare retroperitoneal lesions are more likely to present in other ways than this.
Overall, although there is much to be discussed on this topic, the underlying principle is that patients with a right sided varicocele should receive a renal ultrasound scan to exclude the presence of a large renal cancer-causing tumour thrombus in the IVC.
GPT3_explain: This answer is correct because a varicocele is a common, benign condition that does not usually require follow-up or treatment. It is usually asymptomatic and does not cause any long-term health issues. Therefore, no further tests or treatment are necessary.

Qn_Text: A 70-year-old man much troubled by tinnitus undergoes an MRI scan of the base of his skull. The ossicles are disrupted by a middle ear mass which is bulging the tympanic membrane. It is high in signal on T1 and T2 weighted sequences. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cholesterol granuloma
A cholesterol granuloma occurs as a sequela of recurrent bouts of otitis media. Haemorrhage within the middle ear leads to the formation of granulation tissue. On imaging this is seen as non-specification of the middle ear on CT. Bony changes can occur chronically with bony expansion, or displacement and even destruction of the ossicles. The signals characteristics on MRI are therefore important to distinguish it from a cholesteatoma. Whereas a cholesteatoma on MRI is isointense to brain parenchyma on T1, a cholesterol granuloma will show high signal in the middle ear on T1 due to the paramagnetic effects of methaemoglobin. On clinical examination the ENT surgeon may report a bulging blue tympanic membrane. This is classical. Dehiscence of the jugular bulb is an important differential diagnosis to exclude as this will also give a blue tympanic membrane on examination but the management is radically different!
  Cholesteatoma
Cholesteatomas (Acquired or congenital) are histolologically epidermoid cysts. On imaging the finding of non-dependant soft tissue and bony erosion within the middle ear is typical for a cholesteatoma.
There are two types of acquired cholesteatoma:
Pars flaccida (80%) – classically erodes the scutum and extends superiorly
Pars tensa (20%) – classically erodes the ossicles, extending medially
  These refer to the two parts of the tympanic membrane from which they arise.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  In due course, if left unattended, a cholesteatoma will expand to fill the entire middle ear. Prior to this point they can be seen as non-dependant soft tissue within the middle ear. Dependant soft tissue within the middle ear suggests the presence of fluid or pus and the diagnosis of a middle ear infection. Once a cholesteatoma has filled the middle ear completely however no gas remains from which to discern dependency.
There are a number of theories as to how cholesteatomas arise. One theory is that following a perforation of the tympanic membrane entry of desquamated stratified keratinised squamous epithelium from the external auditory canal into the middle ear is permitted. There it adheres to the tympanic membrane and proliferates unrelentingly causing a soft tissue mass to form and eventually leading to bony erosion of the ossicles, scutum and/or other parts of the middle ear.
A congenital cholesteatoma behaves in a similar manner but is present from birth due to an aberrant location of a tiny island of keratinised squamous epithelium.
Cholesteatomas are difficult to manage as they have a high recurrence rate. Imaging has a significant role to play in the management of recurrent cholesteatomas; distinguishing recurrence from post-operative granulation tissue or fluid is important.
  Diagnosis Restricts Diffusion Enhances
Recurrent cholesteatoma Yes No
Granulation tissue No Yes
Fluid No No
  Post-contrast sequences for recurrent cholesteatomas require a delay of around 45 minutes from giving the contrast to acquiring images as the granulation tissue is slow to take up contrast. This has obvious down-sides to any modern day busy MRI schedule. However since the management of post-operative granulation tissue and post-operative fluid is largely identical, namely expectant, it is not important to differentiate the one from the other. Thus findings on diffusion weighted sequences are the most important thing in post-operative cholesteatoma imaging.
  Aberrant internal carotid artery
An aberrant internal carotid artery can cause a pulsatile mass in the middle ear. The question usually asked on this topic is slightly different and to do with the persistent stapedial artery and consequential aplastic foramen spinosum (anatomically – ‘the heel of the high-heeled shoe’). The stapedial artery in such cases arises from the internal carotid artery and runs through the stapes, becoming the middle meningeal artery (which usually arises from the external carotid artery and courses through the foramen spinosum).
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis in this case is acquired cholesteatoma, because it is the most common cause of middle ear masses that can disrupt the ossicles and bulge the tympanic membrane. Cholesteatomas are characterized by high signal on T1 and T2 weighted sequences, which is consistent with what is seen in the MRI scan.

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old young man undergoes a barium enema which shows that the rectum is straightened, with elevation of the recto-sigmoid junction. The presacral space is also widened. Which of the following is NOT a cause of widening of the presacral space? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Image © Medical Exam Prep
    Pelvic lipomatosis
This is a curious condition which arises in young-middle aged adults. There is significant overgrowth of fat cells within the pelvis which can lead to compression of all or any of the pelvic structures. The bladder becomes pear shaped as the main volume is pulled superiorly. Similarly, the sigmoid is elevated out of the pelvis and the rectum straightened to its shortest path. On CT there is a striking amount of low attenuation fat within the pelvis and similarly this will be seen as high T1 signal on MRI.
  A tailgut duplication cyst (retrorectal cystic hamartoma)
Curiously these occur almost exclusively in women. Anatomically they sit within the presacral or retrorectal fat. They tend to be an incidental diagnosis and can be associated with bony defects within the sacrum. Since they usually contain mucein they appear characteristically high in signal on T1 weighted MRI sequences. They can be surprisingly large and are often multiloculated.
  A Tarlov cyst
A Tarlov cyst is the name given to dilatation of the posterior nerve root sheath. They follow CSF on all sequences and can cause significant bony scalloping.
  Liposarcoma
It would not be possible to diagnose this on the basis of a barium enema. It would be a differential diagnosis for pelvic lipomatosis as seen on CT but usually contain a variable degree of soft tissue attenuation whereas the only soft tissue attenuation seen with pelvic lipomatosis results from anatomical distortion of normal structures.
  Ulcerative colitis
On a barium enema the colon and rectum can appear featureless – the so-called lead pipe appearance. Otherwise the mucosal surface is said to have a granular appearance.
GPT3_explain: Liposarcoma is a type of cancer that affects fat cells, and it does not cause widening of the presacral space.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 28-year-old lady presents with a headache having been unwell for the past 3 days. Of note in her medical history she has been taking the oral contraceptive pill. She undergoes a (non-contrast) MRI scan of her head which shows bilateral infarctions. What is the best description of the associated findings?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: High venous sinus signal on T1
C: Venous sinus flow void on T1
Explanation:
Explanation:
Static blood within the sagittal sinus gives rise to high signal on T1. Normally the sagittal sinus will appear as a flow void on T1w.
The empty delta sign is traditionally a post-contrast CT finding although the same appearance can also be seen on post-contrast T1 sequences. Bilateral haemorrhages can be a secondary consequence to a sagittal sinus thrombosis which may point towards the diagnosis but the thrombosis itself is recognised by the empty delta sign on post-contrast CT.
Dense triangle sign pertains to the acute thrombus as it appears on an unenhanced CT scan.
The associated infarctions can often be haemorrhagic and parasagittal haemorrhages are very specific for a sagittal sinus thrombosis but subarachnoid haemorrhage is not likely to be related.
GPT3_explain: The Empty Delta Sign is a classic finding on a non-contrast MRI scan of the head in a patient with cerebral infarctions. This finding is characterized by a hyperintense signal on T1-weighted images in the area of the venous sinus, caused by the presence of an intravascular clot. This is typically seen in patients with a history of taking the oral contraceptive pill, as this can increase the risk of thrombosis.
