Qn_Text: A 30-year-old man is reviewed in the breast clinic following the development of gynaecomastia. He is on no medications which might provoke this and denies the use of any performance-enhancing steroids. A testicular ultrasound is performed which shows a mass in the left testicle. Which of the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
For a patient to develop gynaecomastia as a consequence of testicular cancer the tumour must be oestrogenic. Sex cord stromal tumours can produce oestrogen and present in this way, as can germ cell tumours. The classical tumour to be linked with gynaecomastia as an index presentation is the sex cord tumour Leydig cell tumours since around a third of cases present as gynaecomastia. That being said, when tumour incidence is accounted for, technically more patients who present with gynaecomastia will actually have a germ cell tumour of either a seminomatous or non-seminomatous variety. If germ cell tumours are therefore pitched against sex cord tumours in a question the exact wording of the question is crucial. Certainly Leydig cell tumours (Sex cord tumours) are more closely linked with gynaecomastia but there are undeniably fewer of them.
  Tumour
% presentation with gynaecomastia
% of all testicular tumours
% of all testicular tumours presenting with gynaecomastia
Sex cord - Leydig cell
30
1-3
<9
Sex cord - Sertoli cell
3
<1
<1
Germ cell - Seminoma
5
25
12.5
Germ cell - Non-seminomatous
5
25
12.5
  Sex cord stromal tumours
These account in total for only around 10% of testicular tumours but have some interesting characteristics.
Leydig cell tumours - classically these cause hormone imbalance and can present as gynaecomastia. Around a third of patients will present in this way. Most of these tumours are actually benign. There are two peaks in age prevalance at 5-10years and 20-30years
Sertoli cell tumours - These are much less common, less likely to produce hormones and therefore gynaecomastia but can be associated with syndromes such as Peutz-Jegher syndrome, or the Carney complex. They classically arise in young boys but are by no means rare at all any age.
  Carney Triad
Carney complex
Pulmonary chondromas
Atrial myxoma
Gastric leiomyosarcoma (GIST)
Facial/buccal pigmentation
Extra-adrenal paraganglioma
Sertoli tumour of the testis
  Pituitary adenoma
  Germ cell tumours
Germ cell tumours are divided into seminomas and non-seminomatous varieties. They are very common and comprise almost half of all testicular tumours. They can often be found incidentally or subsequent to any trauma which might cause the patient to self-examine and discover a testicular lump. Alternatively they can present as a vague dull scrotal aching sensation with no lump.
Lymphatic drainage is to the retroperitoneum. Para-aortic lymph nodes are therefore regional. Involvement of the internal, external and common iliac nodes however, is considered non-regional. Only if there has been previous scrotal or inguinal surgery disrupting tissue planes are inguinal or external iliac artery nodes considered regional.
They typically are found in patients in their 40s. Testicular tumours can be diagnosed with a strong pre-test probability based solely on age as detailed in the table below. On ultrasound there will be an intratesticular low reflectivity well-defined mass. Colour doppler flow can be seen within the mass.
  Age at diagnosis
Tumour
10s
Yolk sac tumour or teratoma
20s + 30s
Choriocarcinoma
30s
Embryonal cell carcinoma
40s
Seminoma
GPT3_explain: Leydig cell tumours are the most common type of testicular tumour in men over 30 years old. They usually cause gynaecomastia, which is why this is the likely diagnosis in this case. Additionally, they are not associated with the use of performance-enhancing steroids, which the patient has denied using.

Qn_Text: A 42-year-old man becomes dyspnoeic two days after an RTA in which he suffered multiple fractures. On examination he is febrile, cyanosed and confused. There are petechial haemorrhages on his chest and abdomen but his CXR is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Radiologically the CXR can be normal initially. On CT there are usually features suggestive of ARDS with widespread ground glass opacities. Petechial haemorrhages are not seen with straightforward pulmonary emboli.
GPT3_explain: Fat embolism is the most likely diagnosis in this case because the patient is displaying symptoms of dyspnea, cyanosis, confusion, and petechial hemorrhages, which are all common signs and symptoms of fat embolism syndrome. Additionally, the patient has recently suffered multiple fractures, which can lead to fat embolism. The patient's CXR being normal further supports the diagnosis of fat embolism, as fat emboli are not visible on CXR.

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old man undergoes lumbar spine radiographs three weeks after slipping and falling on an icy pavement. He has been suffering from lumbar back pain since the fall. The x-rays show mild anterolisthesis of L5 on S1 with normal spinous process alignment. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Spondylolysis
Anterolisthesis of L5 over S1 with normal spinous process alignment is typical for bilateral pars defects, also known as spondylolysis. The pars is the junction of the spinous lamina, pedicle and facet. A bony defect in the pars interarticularis allows separation of the spinous process from the rest of the vertebra, which slips forwards. Patients can be asymptomatic from this or may develop worsening anterolisthesis with consequential nerve root impingement.
On an x-ray the outline of a 'scottie dog' is said to be formed by the posterior elements of the spine. If there is a lucent linear defect in the neck of the scottie dog, a pars defect is present.
GPT3_explain: I chose 1. Degenerative changes as the most likely diagnosis because the x-rays show mild anterolisthesis of L5 on S1, which is a degenerative condition caused by wear and tear on the discs and joints of the spine. This is a common cause of lower back pain, especially in individuals of advanced age, and is likely a result of the fall in this case.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes an abdominal ultrasound scan as part of work up for infertility. There is left sided hydronephrosis. She undergoes a CT KUB which shows no stones. Which of the following would be best to manage this patient?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The MAG3 scan will show whether the kidney is truly functionally obstructed.
  MAG3
Dynamic scan. Images every 2 mins for approximately 20 mins
MAG3 is a compound which has a high renal extraction rate and can be labelled with Tc99m. It provides an overview of the renal plasma flow. A normal unobstructed kidney shows an initial increase in activity over 2 minutes as the tracer reaches the kidney followed by a slow decline in activity over around 20 minutes as it is filtered. An obstructed system will show a similar initial increase, but activity will then not decline. Furosemide can be given to maximise the opportunity to show flow distal to the kidney. MAG3 is a safe agent to use in patients with renal failure.
  Captopril (an ACEi) can be given to diagnose renal artery stenosis as a cause of hypertension since the activity in a patient with renal artery stenosis will decline following administration of Captopril whereas a normal kidney will retain activity.
Post-micturition images at 20 minutes can help to show the presence of residual bladder volume.
  DTPA – differential agent
Dynamic scan. Images at 1.5 second intervals for the first 30 seconds then less at 5 min intervals for 30 mins
Since DTPA is cleared only via the glomeruli it can be used to measure GFR. In a normal kidney the activity level peaks sharply followed by a decline which is initially rapid and then tapers off. As GFR worsens firstly the initial rapid decline becomes more gradual and with increasingly poor disease the initial peak then becomes diminished too. Ironically for a study used to measure GFR, DTPA is not a good agent for patients with renal failure; it can only be cleared via the glomeruli therefore if there is no glomerular filtration the agent will persist and lead to a high dose. Studies need higher doses than MAG3.
  DMSA – morphology and structure
Static scan. Image once at 2 hours.
DMSA is an excellent agent for evaluating the renal cortex. It is used a lot in the paediatric setting in the investigation of scars following pyelonephritis.
GPT3_explain: Technetium-99m DMSA is the best choice to manage this patient because it is a radiopharmaceutical used to evaluate renal function and detect renal parenchymal abnormalities. It can be used to assess the degree of hydronephrosis, detect renal scarring, and evaluate the cause of hydronephrosis. It is also useful in detecting renal stones, which was ruled out by the CT KUB.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical management, what is the best way to manage this patient?

Qn_Text: Which of the following would be an absolute contraindication to uterine fibroid embolisation? Select one answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Uterine fibroid embolisation (UFE)
  Contraindications to UFE
Pelvic infection
History of pelvic radiation
Connective tissue disease
Asymptomatic fibroids
Pregnancy
Pedunculated fibroids
  In the world of interventional radiology, uterine fibroid embolisation is gaining momentum. The uterine artery arises from the internal iliac artery whereas the ovarian artery arises directly from the aorta and has a corkscrew appearance on angiography. Anastomoses between the two arteries or the two sides exist in approximately 20% of patients. Patients should be counselled for the risk of ovarian dysfunction subsequent to the procedure and patients over the age of 45 are at particular risk. Pedunculated fibroids are said to be poor candidates for embolisation owing to their propensity to detach however the literature is slightly contradictory on this topic.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a dominant fibroid of 20 cm is too large to be treated with uterine fibroid embolisation. Uterine fibroid embolisation is generally reserved for smaller fibroids, typically those measuring less than 10 cm. A dominant fibroid of 20 cm is too large to be treated with this procedure, and so it would be an absolute contraindication.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 76-year-old man with type 2 diabetes is suffering from a non-healing ulcer to his left heel. He undergoes a CT angiogram to establish the extent of his vasculopathy. What are the most likely findings?
B: A chronic occlusion to the left superficial femoral artery
C: An acute occlusion to the left popliteal artery
Explanation:
Explanation:
While lower limb angiography is usually the preserve of the vascular radiologist a basic grounding in CT angiography is essential for the general radiologist.
The arteries of a diabetic typically become small and calcified. In the lower leg the normal three vessel run-off can be reduced to two or even single vessel run-off causing arterial supply problems downstream.
Another aspect which could be asked, would be the best method of imaging the vessels of a patient with an eGFR precluding the use of nephrotoxic contrast agents. In such settings diagnostic images can be acquired with CO2 angiography.
GPT3_explain: The most likely findings from a CT angiogram in a 76-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and a non-healing ulcer to his left heel would be 2, 3, and 4. Small and calcified peripheral vessels (1) can occur in patients with diabetes, but are not necessarily the most likely findings in this case. Multiple venous collaterals (5) are also not likely to be seen on a CT angiogram. The most likely findings would be a chronic occlusion to the left superficial femoral artery (2), an acute occlusion to the left popliteal artery (3), and extensive bilateral aorto-iliac disease (4). These findings would indicate that the patient has significant peripheral vascular disease, which is common in patients with diabetes.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 63-year-old lady develops progressive abdominal distension accompanied by vague abdominal pains. An ultrasound shows a 20cm complex ovarian mass and her ca-125 level is found to be markedly elevated. She undergoes a CT scan for staging and widespread disease is discovered. Which of the following is least likely to be secondary to metastatic ovarian cancer?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Bony involvement in metastatic ovarian cancer is actually relatively uncommon with only around 2% of patients being affected.
Ovarian cancer can spread in a multitude of ways:
  Spread of ovarian cancer
Direct extension
Sigmoid mesocolon, broad ligament, fallopian tubes
Intraperitoneal seeding and implantation
Omental caking, peritoneal space
Lymphatic spread
External iliac, obturator nodes
Haematogenous
Liver, lung, adrenal glands, pleural effusion
  Bowel obstruction is relatively common cause of morbidity and mortality with disseminated ovarian cancer.
  Ovarian cancer
There are a number of different types of ovarian carcinoma and the final diagnosis will be a histological one. On imaging the features can be varied.
  Subtypes
Frequency and age
Malignant epithelial tumours (Serous, mucinous, endometroid, clear cell)
85%   60s -70s
Malignant germ cell tumours (Teratoma, dysgerminaoma, choricarcinoma, mixed)
7%   <30 years
Metastases
<10%
Sex cord stromal tumours
~5%
  A number of factors increase the risk of developing ovarian cancer in an individual. Anything which increases the number of ovulatory cycles a woman undergoes in her lifetime will increase the risk of ovarian cancer (early menarche, late menopause, nulliparity), and vice versa (multiparity, breastfeeding, oral contraceptive pill use). A family history of related cancers also increase the risk.
  Presenting symptoms may be quite vague with abdominal pains, constipation or urinary frequency being the only complaints if any from the patient. Consequently many tumours have already spread beyond the ovary by the time of diagnosis. Initial investigation is often with ultrasound. Although ovarian cancers can have a variety of imaging appearances, solid or papillary components to a cystic mass are strongly indicative of malignancy. Predominantly solid masses with some small cystic components are also likely to be malignant but completely perfectly solid lesions are actually more likely to be benign. Ovarian fibromas and fibrothecomas are both benign lesions which can be seen as solid masses however despite this, without prior imaging for comparison a solid ovarian lesion is malignant until proven otherwise.
  Ovarian cysts
The incidental finding of a simple (non-haemorrhagic) ovarian cyst in day to day cross-sectional reporting is a relatively common occurrence. In deciding on a subsequent management plan both age and the size of the cyst should be taken into account as well as the presence of any internal haemorrhage, thus:
  Age
Diameter
Plan
Reproductive age
<3cm
Normal finding, no follow up
3-5cm
Almost certainly benign, no follow up
5-7cm
Almost certainly benign but risk of torsion. Follow up with ultrasound either at 2-6 months if uncertainty of findings, or at 6-12 months. 
>7cm
Difficult to fully evaluate on ultrasound, suggest MRI
Haemorrhagic, >5cm
Follow up ultrasound or MRI in 6 weeks (different part of the menstrual cycle)
Post-menopausal
<1cm
No follow up
1-3 cm
Describe but no follow up needed.
3-5 cm
Follow up with ultrasound either at 3-6 months if uncertainty of findings, or at 6-12 months. 
Haemorrhagic, any size
Follow up ultrasound or MRI in 6 weeks
  In summary if a cyst is above 7cm in diameter an MRI is warranted even though the likelihood of benignity is still extremely high.
GPT3_explain: Metastatic ovarian cancer is most likely to spread to organs in the abdominal cavity such as the intestines, liver, and peritoneum. It is much less likely to spread to the pleura, which is the lining of the lungs. Therefore, left pleural effusion is the least likely to be secondary to metastatic ovarian cancer.
Cat_Long: This question would fall under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: 80-year-old man is found to have a mass involving the corpus callosum. Broadly speaking the mass is low on T1 and high on T2. There is evidence of central necrosis and T2 changes in periventricular regions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is a defined differential for ‘lesions which cross the corpus callosum’: GBM, lymphoma, infarction, trauma, radiation, metastases, MS. Although not well described here the ‘T2 changes’ could be oedema relating to the mass.
PML (progressive multifocal leucoencephalopathy) is an HIV related condition caused by the JC virus which is classically described as having asymmetrical high T2 signal but there isn’t anything else in the question which points to this.
Gliomatosis cerebri is a horrible tumour seen as generalised high T2 signal involving at least three lobes but is usually found in younger patients than this.
An anaplastic astrocytoma is a main player in the differential diagnosis for ‘lesions which cross the corpus callosum’ but is more prevalent in younger or middle aged patients.
Thus the answer for this question comes down to lymphoma or GBM. Both can be low on T1 and high on T2 but central necrosis is a classical finding in GBM and there is often significant oedema.
GPT3_explain: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most aggressive form of brain cancer and is characterized by a high T2 signal on imaging with central necrosis and T2 changes in the periventricular regions. GBM is often found in elderly patients, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man has a CT scan of his pelvis following a motorbiking accident. There are no findings of major trauma but there is a 10cm mass in the pelvis sitting just superior to the bladder.  It is smooth in outline and homogenous in density showing slightly more contrast enhancement than the adjacent psoas muscles. The vessels supplying it course upwards into the abdomen and out of the field of view. Which of the following would be the best way of confirming the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Splenic variants
Rarely (<1% of patients) the spleen can migrate from its usual position and end up virtually anywhere else within the abdominal cavity. This is of no clinical consequence unless the consequently long and tortuous vessels supplying it become compromised by torsion or the patient undergoes abdominal surgery. On imaging the wandered spleen should exhibit the usual characteristics of a normally positioned spleen but if there is any doubt as to the diagnosis confirmation with a 99mTc-sulphur-colloid scan can be sought.
Accessory spleens or splenunculi are relatively common (30% of patients) and can usually be found close to the splenic hilum or tail of the pancreas. They follow the spleen on all modalities and should not be mistaken for intra-abdominal lymph nodes.
Polysplenia is a condition which arises as part of left-sided isomerism (also known as heterotaxy). In Left-sided isomerism all of the features which would usually be found on the left side of the body are found on both, or right sided features are found on the left side (such as the liver). Vice versa is true for right-sided isomerism. Right-sided isomerism usually presents earlier on due to the greater complexity of associated cardiac abnormalities.
Heterotaxy syndrome
Left-sided isomerism
Right-sided isomerism
Bilateral bilobed lungs
Bilateral trilobed lungs
Polysplenism
Asplenia
Left sided liver
Large central liver
GPT3_explain: MRI is the best way to confirm the diagnosis because it provides the most detailed images of the mass and its relationship to the surrounding structures. MRI can also show the size and shape of the mass, as well as the vessels supplying it, which is important for determining the exact nature of the mass. Additionally, MRI can show any changes in the tissue that may indicate malignancy, and can also help to identify any other possible lesions in the area.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 74-year-old man undergoes a lumbar spine x-ray which shows dense sclerosis to the L4 vertebra. The vertebral body height is preserved, and the discs appear unaffected. Which of the following is NOT a likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is NOT a likely diagnosis.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  The ivory vertebra sign denotes dense sclerosis of a solitary vertebra without any change in its size or shape.
  Ivory vertebra differential diagnosis
Paediatric Adult
Lymphoma
Osteosarcoma
Osteoblastoma
Metastatic Ewing sarcoma
Metastatic medulloblastoma
Paget disease
Tuberculous spondylitis
Haemangioma
Prostate/ breast metastatic cancer
GPT3_explain: Prostate cancer metastasis is not a likely diagnosis because the x-ray does not show any evidence of metastatic disease. The x-ray shows dense sclerosis to the L4 vertebra, which can be indicative of Paget disease, hyperparathyroidism, leukaemia, or lymphoma.

Qn_Text: A 78-year-old man undergoes an MRI after a routine asymptomatic screening ear exam shows an intact blue tympanic membrane. The scan shows a middle ear mass which is homogeneously high on T1 and T2. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
A cholesterol granuloma should be at the top of the list when a blue tympanic membrane is mentioned. The features described in the question are classical for a cholesterol granuloma – the other notable feature not provided is the absence of pulsatile tinnitus which helps distinguish it from a glomus tympanicum. A cholesterol granuloma contains both cholesterol crystals and blood products (hence is bright on T1) whereas a cholesteatoma is isointense to brain parenchyma on T1 and can apparently be seen clinically as a whitish mass behind the tympanic membrane.
An aberrant internal carotid artery can cause a pulsatile mass in the middle ear. The question usually asked on this topic is slightly different and to do with the persistent stapedial artery and consequential aplastic foramen spinosum (anatomically – ‘the heel of the high-heeled shoe’). The stapedial artery in such cases arises from the internal carotid artery and runs through the stapes, becoming the middle meningeal artery (which usually arises from the external carotid artery and courses through the foramen spinosum).
Haemangiomas of the middle ear have been described but are largely confined to case reports in the literature.
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis for a homogeneously high middle ear mass on T1 and T2 MRI is a glomus tumour. Glomus tumours are benign vascular tumors that typically appear as a homogeneously high signal intensity on T1 and T2 MRI. They are most commonly found in the middle ear and can cause hearing loss, facial nerve palsy, and vertigo.

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old lady is referred for an ultrasound to investigate raised ALT and AST. She admits to enjoying one small glass of wine per week. On ultrasound, the liver is diffusely increased in reflectivity with a coarse echotexture but a smooth capsular margin. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note the question asks for the answer which is NOT a risk factor.
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease can be divided into non-alcoholic fatty liver (NAFL) where there are no features of hepatic inflammation, and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) where features of hepatic inflammation are present. The following are the most common associations with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease:
Diabetes
Hypothyroidism
Central obesity
Dyslipidaemia
Wilson's disease
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because haemachromatosis is a condition caused by iron overload, and is not a risk factor for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge to a clinical situation.

3. A question about the application of knowledge to a clinical situation.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old lady undergoes an ultrasound as part of assessment for a new lump in her right breast. The ultrasound shows a 1.5 cm hypoechoic mass with hyperechoic margins and a lobulated contour. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
A mucinous carcinoma is a subtype of infiltrating/invasive ductal carcinoma. The ultrasound findings are those of many other suspicious lesions too however mucinous carcinoma is the only one which would fit best. Differentiating this from a different type of carcinoma would be difficult.
A phyllodes tumour would usually appear as a lobulated round hypoechoic mass with ill-defined borders and a posterior acoustic enhancement.
A fibroadenoma would be typically in a younger patient in their 20-30s. These are largely hypoechoic with a range of additional features but can have an echogenic halo.
A galactocoele would appear cystic on ultrasound.
A breast abscess clinical manifestations notwithstanding, would also appear cystic on ultrasound.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2, Fibroadenoma, because it is the most likely diagnosis based on the ultrasound findings. Fibroadenomas are typically well-defined, hypoechoic masses with hyperechoic margins and a lobulated contour, which are characteristics of the mass described in the question. They are also the most common benign breast tumors in women, making them the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old lady presents with right upper quadrant pain. A CT demonstrates a mass with inwards retraction of the liver capsule. What is the LEAST likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note the question asks for the LEAST likely answer.
Retraction of the liver capsule signifies the presence of fibrosis.
  Differential diagnosis for hepatic capsular retraction:
Cholangiocarcinoma
Fibrolamella HCC
Metastases (breast, lung, carcinoid, colorectal)
IgG4 related disease
Iatrogenic/ post-traumatic
Cirrhosis
  Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH)
These lesions typically occur in women in late middle age. They are not caused by oral contraceptive use however they do enlarge in response to hormone stimulation. They are composed of hyperplastic hepatocytes and are thought to arise when a small underlying congenital vascular malformation means that an area of the liver receives a better blood supply and therefore grows better, thus they lack a true capsule but can outgrow their blood supply resulting in the classical central fibrous scar which is present in around half of cases. On imaging they do demonstrate mass effect, displacing adjacent vessels, have marked arterial enhancement which fits in with their supposed aetiology. The central scar enhances only on delayed sequences. On MRI they tend to return high signal on T2 weighted sequences. Their appearance on contrast enhanced ultrasound is interesting; the central scar enhances very early in the arterial phase, branching out in a spoke-wheel type of appearance. During the main arterial phase, the lesions enhance strongly before becoming isoechoic in the portal venous phase.
GPT3_explain: I chose Fibrolamellar HCC as the least likely diagnosis because it is an uncommon form of liver cancer that typically affects young adults and adolescents, whereas the patient in this case is 54 years old. Additionally, it is a type of cancer that is not typically associated with inwards retraction of the liver capsule. Colorectal metastasis, cholangiocarcinoma, and breast cancer metastasis are all more likely diagnoses in this case given the patient's age and the imaging findings.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old lady suspected to have multiple sclerosis following an episode 2 years ago of optic neuritis now presents with paraesthesia. She undergoes an MRI scan. Where it the new lesion likely to be?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Basal ganglia lesions will likely lead to movement or coordination issues, or spasms.
Lesions of the thalami may be purely sensory or lead to ataxia. This is arguably an alternative answer however the callosoeptal interface is far more classical for multiple sclerosis.
Virchow-Robin spaces are dilated fluid filled spaces surrounding perforating vessels and are a differential diagnosis for multiple sclerosis however will suppress on FLAIR sequences.
  Multiple sclerosis
The imaging characteristics of multiple sclerosis should definitely be learnt, as much for real life radiology as for the exams. This is an idiopathic demyelinating disease with oedematous perivascular inflammation in the acute stage progressing to demyelination with proliferation of the astroglia in the chronic phase. There are oblong elliptical plaques of high T2 signal at the callososeptal interface.
Other highly testable features:
Involvement of the middle cerebellar peduncle is specific to multiple sclerosis when attempting to differentiate it from small vessel ischaemic changes
Lesions can cross the midline
Axial T2 sequences are better than FLAIR for posterior fossa lesions
Acute lesions can enhance with contrast, classically in an ‘incomplete ring’
Thalamic involvement is rare and suggests the possibility of ADEM instead
GPT3_explain: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei located at the base of the brain, and they are responsible for controlling voluntary movement, as well as the regulation of emotions and cognition. Multiple sclerosis can cause inflammation of the white matter in the brain, which can lead to lesions in the basal ganglia. Paraesthesia, or abnormal sensations such as tingling or numbness, is a common symptom of MS, and can be caused by lesions in the basal ganglia. Therefore, an MRI scan is likely to reveal a new lesion in the basal ganglia in this patient.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about management, what is the best treatment?

This question would fall under Category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 3-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the GP with headaches and intermittent ataxia. She is referred to the paediatricians at her local hospital and subsequently undergoes a CT scan and a sedated MRI scan. This shows a hypointense mass in the region of the fourth ventricle on T1 which has a heterogenous signal intensity on T2. There is homogeneous enhancement with a hypointense rim on the post-gadolinium sequences. Although it appears hyperdense, no calcification is seen on CT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Medulloblastomas are the most common posterior fossa tumours in children and the imaging features here are characteristic. The distinguishing feature from an ependymoma is the hypointense rim on the post-contrast sequences. Cavernous angiomas are also described as having a hypointense rim but this would be on the T2 sequences as opposed to the post contrast T1 sequences and the other features given are not applicable. On CT medulloblastomas are usually (90%) slightly higher in attenuation than the adjacent parenchyma; they are highly cellular tumours and appear very dense.
GPT3_explain: Ependymoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common brain tumor in this age group. It typically presents with headaches, ataxia, and seizures, and is usually located in the fourth ventricle. The imaging findings of a hypointense mass on T1 and heterogenous signal intensity on T2, with homogeneous enhancement and a hypointense rim on post-gadolinium sequences, are consistent with ependymoma.

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old man complaining of chest pain undergoes a CT chest that shows a cardiac carcinoid. What are the most likely features that will be seen?
C: Prolapse of a soft tissue density mass through the mitral valve
Explanation:
Explanation:
The spectrum of cardiac carcinoid disease encompasses the physical plaque deposits of metastatic disease as well as the valve damage caused by secretion of vasoactive substances from the tumour load. Classically the right side of the heart is most affected because most of the primary lesions, as well as hepatic metastases, secrete into the right-sided circulation.
Prolapse of a soft tissue density mass through the mitral valve is a classic description for a myxoma however this feature is seen on Ultrasound predominantly, as well as potentially on cardiac MRI.
A low attenuation mass without calcification is probably describing a lipoma.
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 1, 3, 4, 5. Cardiac carcinoid tumors are typically associated with left heart dilatation, prolapse of a soft tissue density mass through the mitral valve, low attenuation mass without calcification, right heart dilatation, and biatrial dilatation. These features can be seen on a CT chest and are the most likely features of a cardiac carcinoid.

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old patient undergoes a CT venogram for suspected venous sinus thrombosis. The reporting registrar sees a structure draining the superficial middle vein into the transverse sinus. What normal venous structure is she describing?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Vein of Labbe
Large draining vein connecting the transverse sinus and the superficial middle vein.
  Vein of Trolard
Usually smaller than the vein of Labbe. Connects the superficial middle vein and sagittal sinus. A larger vein of Labbe is associated with a smaller vein of Trolard and vice versa.
  Basal vein of Rosenthal
This deep vein passes lateral to the midbrain and eventually drains into the vein of Galen.
  Vein of Galen
The confluence of the internal cerebral veins results in the vein of Galen.
  Straight sinus
Drains the inferior sagittal sinus into (usually) the confluence of sinuses.
GPT3_explain: The Vein of Trolard is a normal venous structure that drains the superficial middle cerebral vein into the transverse sinus. This is the most likely structure that the reporting registrar is describing, as it is the only one that fits the description given.

Qn_Text: A 5-year-old girl who has suffered repeated chest infections undergoes a CT scan of her chest after an abnormality is detected on her CXR. There is a large multi-cystic mass in the right hemithorax containing air-fluid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) – also known as Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM)
Although often an antenatal diagnosis, CPAM should be considered in the investigation of a neonatal respiratory distress. Milder cases can present later when the child develops a LRTI and decompensates. On investigation a cystic mass is discovered. The size of the cysts denotes the type with Type I accounting for half of cases and comprising a smaller number of larger (>20mm) cysts. Type III is more sponge-like with cysts measuring only a couple of mm and Type II is between the two. Where cysts are larger, air-fluid levels may be seen. The malformation can exert a mass effect, causing both hypoplasia of the remainder of the ipsilateral lung as well as contralateral mediastinal shift.
  Swyer-James syndrome
In this condition, normal development of the infant lung is impeded by bronchiolitis (viral or mycoplasma) at an early age, with superadded acute airspace destruction. Consequently the affected lobe is small and lucent on the CXR due to air trapping. It is a differential diagnosis for a unilateral lucent hemithorax, along with a pneumothorax, very large pulmonary emboli and causes of decreased chest wall musculature such as Poland syndrome or, historically, polio. In an an exam situation Swyer-James syndrome is usually given as a teenage or young adult patient with a history of recurrent LRTIs. Air trapping, and bronchiectasis can also be described.
  Bronchopulmonary foregut malformations:
CPAM
Sequestration
Duplication cysts (bronchogenic, neuroenteric, enteric)
  Pulmonary sequestration
There are two types of pulmonary sequestration and two features which unite them. A segment of lung firstly, which derives its arterial blood supply from the systemic circulation and secondly, has no communication with the bronchial tree is termed pulmonary sequestration. It is a congenital abnormality and usually affects the left lower lobe with a smaller percentage affecting the right lower lobe.
Intralobar sequestration – This is more common (75%) but less severe. The affected segment does not have its own pleura and drains, like normal, via the pulmonary veins. Presents as recurrent pneumonias and is seen on a CXR as cysts with fluid levels. Some are associated with other congenital abnormalities but a larger proportion develop in isolation.
Extralobar sequestration – This is less common (25%) and more severe with around half of patients suffering from other additional congenital anomalies. Venous drainage is via the systemic circulation and patients present in childhood either with respiratory distress due to shunting of blood or with symptoms attributed to the associated congenital anomalies (e.g. diaphragmatic hernia). The segment has its own pleura and therefore collateral air drift via the pores of Kohn cannot occur. The lack of aeration helps differentiate it from intralobar sequestration. Seen on a CXR as an opacity adjacent to the heart, abutting the diaphragm.
  Bronchogenic cysts
Unless particularly large, or infected, they are usually an incidental finding. Since they are a malformation of the bronchial tree they are lined with respiratory epithelium and hence fluid filled. They do not however communicate with the bronchial tree and therefore do not usually contain air. On CT they will be seen as a unilocular cyst with HU of water or slightly higher owing to the high protein content of water. Approximately half of cases are adjacent to the carina.
GPT3_explain: Intralobar sequestration is the most likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old girl with a large multi-cystic mass in the right hemithorax containing air-fluid levels. Intralobar sequestration is a congenital anomaly in which a segment of the lung is separated from the normal pulmonary circulation and is supplied by its own systemic arterial blood supply. It is usually characterized by a large cystic mass that contains air-fluid levels, which is consistent with the findings of the CT scan.

Qn_Text: A 68-year-old woman undergoes a CT scan of her adrenal glands for an incidental lesion picked up on a CT colonogram. The lesion is situated in the lateral limb of the left adrenal gland and is 2cm in diameter. It measures 20HU on the unenhanced sequence, 75HU on the portal venous phase and 38HU on the delayed sequences. You may use a calculator. What is the relative washout of this lesion?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Figures have been rounded to the nearest whole number.
Absolute washout = (75-38)/(75-20) = 67%
Relative washout = (75-38)/75 = 49%
    This lesion is a benign adrenal adenoma. In many centres, if the lesion measures less than 10HU on the unenhanced sequence then the study will be terminated at that point.
  Adrenal washout
Washout characteristics of adrenal nodules help confirm or refute a diagnosis of an adrenal adenoma. The absolute washout takes into account the initial uptake of contrast whereas the relative washout calculation is based only on how well contrast washes out of a nodule.
The underpinning principle is that vasculature within malignant lesions is more permeable than in benign lesions. This allows contrast to diffuse out of the lesion during the portal venous phase and the contrast is then slower to wash out during the delayed phase than it would be for benign lesions. Thus the higher/faster washout characteristics (either absolute or relative) the more suggestive it is that a lesion is benign.
    Adrenal adenoma
These present a diagnostic challenge if only to rule out a malignant adrenal mass. Once the diagnosis is confirmed they can then be left alone and do not require any further imaging. The majority are obvious on CT and obviously adenomas. Owing to their high fat content most adenomas show low Hounsfield units (HU) an HU <18 on an unenhanced study has a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 100%.
In cases where the fat content is insufficient to make the diagnosis an adrenal protocol CT can be performed. This compares the HU on an unenhanced scan, a portal venous phase scan and a 15 minute delayed phase scan. From these values the absolute washout can be calculated by comparing the difference between the two contrast studies with the amount of contrast taken up in the first place (i.e. the difference between the portal venous phase and the unenhanced phase). The relative washout is calculated by comparing the difference between the two contrast studies to just the portal venous phase (i.e. it is relative to the portal venous phase).
An alternative diagnostic strategy which, but for demand management, is better for patients as far as dose preservation is concerned, is an MRI scan. The fat content of adrenal adenomas shows up well as signal loss on out-of-phase imaging and gives a chemical shift artefact in the frequency encoding direction on both gradient echo and spin echo sequences.  On gradient echo sequences due to the chemical shift a black line appears in all directions and is termed the India Ink effect or etching artefact.
  Diagnostic of adrenal adenoma:
At least 60% absolute washout
At least 40% relative washout
<18 HU (100% specific)
<37 HU on a delayed scan
India ink effect on GE MRI
Chemical shift on GE and SE MRI
GPT3_explain: The relative washout of this lesion is calculated by subtracting the HU on the delayed sequence (38 HU) from the HU on the portal venous phase (75 HU), and then dividing that result by the HU on the unenhanced sequence (20 HU). This calculation yields a relative washout of 73%, which is the correct answer.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the HRCT of a 64-year-old man. He has been experiencing recurrent tachycardia, but this is well controlled on regular medication. The CT shows a number of findings and you suspect he may have a drug-related lung condition. Which of the following is LEAST likely to be seen? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely option.
  Amiodarone therapy
Amiodarone is an anti-arrhythmic drug which contains iodine (am-IOD-arone). Consequently, as it accumulates in the liver, it can cause significant increase in density to the liver on a CT scan.
Around 10% of patients taking Amiodarone can develop lung disease from it. These patients are usually older than 60 and have been taking Amiodarone for around 2-6 months. On an HRCT scan ground glass opacities, reticulations and areas of consolidation can be seen. The constellation of lung changes seen represent a kind of non-specific interstitial pneumonitis as well as an organising pneumonia type of pattern (NSIP and COP).
Around half of patients can develop pleural effusions.
GPT3_explain: Pleural effusions are not typically seen in drug-related lung conditions. They are more likely to be seen in conditions such as pneumonia, congestive heart failure, or lung cancer. Therefore, the correct answer is 3. Pleural effusions.

Qn_Text: A 14-year-old boy with recurrent seizures and a port-wine stain on his face undergoes a CT head scan. Where on the scan would you expect calcification to be?
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are a limited number of mainstream phakomatoses (NF1, NF2, Sturge-Weber, von Hippel-Lindau, and Tuberous sclerosis) and they all have fairly well definable features.
Largely speaking the other phakomatoses are all autosomal dominant in inheritance. Sturge-Weber syndrome arises from a sporadic mutation.
Sturge-Weber Syndrome
Gyral cortical calcification and leptomeningeal enhancement are classical features of this condition and the two entities are often (confusingly, misleadingly) used interchangably.
For complete precision it should be noted that the gyriform calcification in Sturge-Weber Syndrome is a sequela of cortical atrophy (caused by venous ischaemia secondary to the presence of a pial angioma). The leptomeningeal enhancement on the other hand is due to the vascular nature of the pial angioma.
Thus, in the answers given above, technically none are correct but the option of leptomeningeal comes closest and should therefore be selected.
GPT3_explain: Calcification can be seen on a CT head scan in the dural layer. The dura mater is a dense connective tissue layer that covers the brain and spinal cord and is composed of collagen and elastin fibers. Calcifications in this layer can be indicative of a number of conditions, including trauma, infection, and vascular malformations. In the case of a port-wine stain, calcifications can be seen in the dural layer and can be indicative of a vascular malformation.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a CT of a 72-year-old man who has an acquired cholesteatoma. Which of the following is correct? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: The Prussak space is found behind the superior part of the tympanic membrane
B: The stapes is situated in the epitympanum
C: The head of the malleus is situated in the mesotympanum
D: The incus is connected to the tympanic membrane
E: The stapes is connected to the round window of the cochlea
Explanation:
Explanation:
The anatomy of the middle ear is complex but important and contains a number of specific anatomical terms.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  The epitympanum, also known as the attic, is the superior portion above the highest point of the tympanic membrane. It contains the head of the malleus and the short crus of the incus (These give the appearance of an ice-cream cone on an axial CT).
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  The Prussak space is found within the epitympanum and is a tiny space at the top of the tympanic membrane, just behind the scutum. Its clinical relevance is that it is the usual origin for pars flaccida cholesteatomas.
The aditus ad antrum connects the epitympanum to the mastoid antrum and thence the mastoid air cells.
The tegmen mastoidium (tegmen means roof) is the point at which the mastoid air cells meet the temporal lobe of the brain.
The tegmen tympani is the point at which the upper most extent of the epitympanum reaches the temporal lobe of the brain.
    Image © Medical Exam Prep
  The mesotympanum is the space posterior to the tympanic membrane and contains the body of the incus, the manubrium (connected to the tympanic membrane) and the anterior process of the malleus and the stapes. The stapes is connected to the incus as well as the oval window of the cochlea. There is also a round window placed more inferiorly which bulges to allow compression waves transmitted from the stapes to the oval window to travel through the cochlea.
The hypotympanum is a far less significant space than either the epitympanum or the mesotympanum. It begins at the inferior most extent of the tympanic membrane. The Eustachian tube opens into the hypotympanum anteriorly.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3 because the head of the malleus is situated in the mesotympanum. The mesotympanum is the middle ear cavity located between the tympanic membrane and the ossicular chain. The ossicular chain is composed of the malleus, incus, and stapes, which are all connected to the tympanic membrane. The stapes is situated in the epitympanum, which is the space between the tympanic membrane and the oval window of the cochlea. The Prussak space is found behind the superior part of the tympanic membrane and the stapes is connected to the round window of the cochlea.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old lady attends A+E having recently arrived back from a holiday in Jamaica. She has abdominal pain and her liver function tests are deranged. An ultrasound scan shows hepatomegaly and the liver is diffusely low in reflectivity. A portal vein Doppler study is normal and there is no ascites. What is the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Viral hepatitis
The imaging findings of hepatitis are non-specific and include hepatomegaly, decreased echogenicity, periportal oedema, and gallbladder wall thickening. The ‘starry sky’ appearance is used to describe a liver which has a number of bright echogenic dots on a background of diffuse low reflectivity and this has traditionally been associated with hepatitis however both the sensitivity and specificity of this sign are low.
  Hepatic venous outflow obstruction
There are three separate syndromes which all overlap both in terms of their clinical and radiological features. They are, however, separate entities, caused by subtly different processes.
Passive hepatic congestion – this arises due to a cardiac problem such as right sided heart failure of any cause or constrictive pericarditis. Tender hepatomegaly is common and on imaging the hepatic veins and IVC are notably enlarged.
Budd-Chiari syndrome – the pathology here is within the hepatic veins with thrombosis or other non-thrombotic obstruction (e.g. extrinsic compression). Acutely there is abdominal pain, ascites and hepatomegaly. The presence or absence of caudate lobe hypertrophy can help distinguish between a chronic process or an acute one where this has not had sufficient time to develop.
Hepatic veno-occlusive disease – fibrosis of the tiny venules can develop following a stem-cell transplant, and by pyrrolizidine alkaloids found in Jamaican bush teas. Clinically patients present with weight gain due to fluid retention, hepatomegaly and jaundice.
  Passive hepatic congestion
Budd-Chiari syndrome
Hepatic veno-occlusive disease
Hepatomegaly, ascites and nutmeg liver
Yes
Yes
Yes
USS: Dilated IVC/hepatic veins
Yes
No
No
Doppler: Portal veins
Increased pulsatility
May be reversed flow
Increased pulsatility or reversed flow
CT: hepatic veins
Dilated
Might not be visible
Normal
MRI
-
Comma-shaped collateral vessels – spiders web (chronic feature, also visible on doppler)
-
  All three cause hepatomegaly and ascites, although fluid overload in general is a particular feature of hepatic veno-occlusive disease. On CT all three can give a ‘nutmeg’ appearance to the liver when, on early phase imaging, contrast has yet to homogenise throughout the liver and consequently there is a mottled appearance which rather resembles the cut surface of a nutmeg. On delayed phase imaging the liver becomes more homogeneous. The flip-flop sign is particularly associated with Budd-Chiari syndrome with strong central and limited peripheral enhancement on early phases followed by early central washout with retained peripheral enhancement on delayed images.
  Budd-Chiari syndrome
The haemodynamics of the liver, as being different from any other organ, can give rise to some interesting pathology. In Budd-Chiari syndrome venous obstruction causes flow reversal in the portal venous system to drain the liver. Acutely this presents as a triad of abdominal pain, ascites and hepatomegaly. In many acute cases the liver function tests have not had sufficient time to become deranged. The caudate lobe usually drains directly into the IVC so may not be affected by the underlying cause of obstruction to the other hepatic veins. Consequently it is able to shoulder more of the usual burden of the liver and becomes hypertrophied. In the acute setting this has not had time to manifest and the caudate lobe will be of a normal size.
Some of the many causes of Budd-Chiari syndrome
Thrombosis of the hepatic veins
Platelets (thrombocytosis)
Pill (OCP)
Pregnancy (hypercoagulable state)
Polycythaemia rubra vera
Non-thrombotic causes
Mechanical compression by a tumour
Right atrial myxoma
Constrictive pericarditis
  On CT the enhancement pattern is described as being ‘flip-flop’, with strong central and limited peripheral enhancement on early phases followed by early central washout with retained peripheral enhancement on delayed images. Alternatively the whole liver may appear mottled with a ‘nutmeg’ type pattern due to the venous congestion. On Doppler ultrasound or MRI the hepatic veins will show a reduction in calibre or not be seen at all and on Doppler insonation the hepatic veins may show little or no flow. Flow in the portal venous system, on the other hand, may be reversed. In chronic cases a veritable spiders-web of small collateral vessels can be seen on angiography; they can also be seen on MRI and are described as having a comma-shape.
  Passive hepatic congestion
This is similar to chronic Budd-Chiari syndrome, but whereas Budd-Chiari syndrome arises due to hepatic outflow obstruction, in heart failure leading to hepatic congestion there is no mechanical obstruction. In contrast to acute thrombotic Budd-Chiari syndrome there is distension of the hepatic veins and IVC, a feature which distinguishes it from hepatic veno-occlusive disease as well. Other signs of heart failure, such as pleural effusions and ascites may be present concurrently.
  Hepatic veno-occlusive disease
The outcome of hepatic veno-occlusive disease is similar to that of Budd-Chiari syndrome but the mechanism is different. Hepatic congestion develops as a consequence of fibrosis to the venules within the liver. This can occur secondary to chemotherapy or bone marrow transplantation and also bizarrely due to pyrrolizidine alkaloids which are found in Jamaican bush teas. On imaging there is overlap with the features of Budd-Chiari syndrome but crucially the hepatic veins should appear normal; it is the smaller venules which cause the problem and these are not seen on ultrasound or CT.
  Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
This can be difficult to distinguish from PSC however whereas PSC can involve both intra and extrahepatic ducts, PBC only involves the intrahepatic ducts. It is an autoimmune condition and, like many other autoimmune conditions, patients are typically women in their middle ages. Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are present in the vast majority of patients. On imaging, the secondary cirrhotic effects are most pertinent with caudate lobe hypertrophy and left lobar atrophy. The periportal halo sign as seen on MRI is reasonably specific and relates to fluid accumulation around the portal triad.
GPT3_explain: Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) is an autoimmune chronic liver disease that is characterized by the destruction of the small bile ducts in the liver. It is more commonly seen in women and usually presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, and elevated liver function tests. Ultrasound findings of hepatomegaly and diffusely low reflectivity of the liver are commonly seen in PBC. A portal vein Doppler study is typically normal in PBC, and there is usually no ascites. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is Primary biliary cirrhosis.

Qn_Text: You are reporting a lower limb angiogram for a patient with claudication. Which SINGLE statement regarding the dorsalis pedis artery is true?
A: It supplies the tarsal bones and the dorsal aspects of the metatarsals
B: The pulse can be felt lateral to the extensor digitorum longus tendon
C: It is a continuation of the posterior tibial artery
D: It anastomoses with the medial plantar artery to form the deep plantar arch
E: It enters the sole of the foot through the tarsal tunnel
Explanation:
Explanation:
The dorsalis pedis artery arises at the anterior aspect of the ankle joint as a continuation of the anterior tibial artery. It passes over the dorsal aspect of the tarsal bones before moving inferiorly towards the sole of the foot. It then anastomoses with the lateral plantar artery to form the deep plantar arch.
The dorsalis pedis artery supplies the tarsal bones and the dorsal aspects of the metatarsals. Via the deep plantar arch, it also contributes to the supply of the toes.
The pulse of the dorsalis pedis artery can be easily palpated lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon and medial to the extensor digitorum longus tendon, on the dorsal surface of the foot. The pulse is situated distal to the dorsal most prominence of the navicular bone, which serves as a reliable landmark for palpation.
GPT3_explain: I chose this statement because it is true. The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the top of the foot, lateral to the extensor digitorum longus tendon, and it can be palpated to feel the pulse.
Cat_Long: This question falls under the category of basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 49-year-old woman presents with right upper quadrant pain and undergoes ultrasound for suspected gallstones. No gallstones are identified, but within the liver multiple low reflectivity tubular structures are seen emanating from the hilum. They each have a central dot. The radiologist identifies these structures as grossly dilated bile ducts and suggests Caroli disease. Which of the following is NOT a recognised complication of Caroli disease? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Caroli disease is also type 5 in the Todani classification. It is associated with polycystic kidney disease and medullary sponge kidney. The key feature is the ‘central dot sign’ which reflects a portal vein surrounded by dilated bile ducts. The following complications are the most commonly recognised:
Liver cirrhosis
Intraductal stones
Cholangitis
Cholangiocarcinoma
  Biliary cystadenocarcinoma is not associated with Caroli disease.
GPT3_explain: Biliary cystadenocarcinoma is not a recognized complication of Caroli disease. The other four options are all known complications of Caroli disease.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about diagnosis, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 16-year-old, on holiday with some friends, and known to have cystic fibrosis, is taken to A+E by her friends after developing severe abdominal pain over the last two days. While waiting to be seen in A+E she also begins vomiting. An abdominal radiograph shows a bubbly area in the right lower quadrant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS)
The description of a bubbly area on an abdominal radiograph is more usually linked to meconium ileus. DIOS is also referred to as a meconium ileus equivalent as these two conditions are similar. In patients with cystic fibrosis the thicker-than-normal intestinal mucus, increase in transit time and pancreatic insufficiency all conspire to cause faecal impaction. This often occurs in early adolescence when parental control wears thin and concordance with medical management (in particular pancreatic enzyme replacement) of their cystic fibrosis can become an issue. Patients develop colicky right lower quadrant pain and tenderness when faecal matter obstructs around the terminal ileum. On x-ray this can sometimes be seen as a bubbly area close to where the caecum might be expected to be.
  Fibrosing colonopathy
By contrast this condition is caused by pancreatic enzyme replacement. High dose lipase treatment leads to progressive stricturing of the colonic submucosa. Modern preparations of enzyme supplementation have reduced the incidence of this disease.
GPT3_explain: Appendicitis is the most likely diagnosis in this case due to the presence of severe abdominal pain and vomiting, as well as the presence of a bubbly area in the right lower quadrant on the abdominal radiograph. Appendicitis is one of the most common causes of abdominal pain in children and can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.

Qn_Text: A 23-year-old lady is being investigated for recurrent urinary tract infections. She is found to have a staghorn calculus in her left kidney measuring 3cm in length. Isotope studies show the right kidney to be functioning normally but there is a 25% difference in function between her left and right kidneys.  What is the most appropriate management?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL)
This is a very safe procedure with low mortality and morbidity statistics which has been developed to retrieve large renal calculi measuring 2cm in diameter or larger. It also works well for smaller recurrent cysteine stones where other avenues of management are proving insufficient.
A calyx in the lower pole is usually targeted for entry, the better to reduce the risk of creating a pneumothorax. The stone can be fragmented via ultrasonic, pneumatic or laser implements under direct vision via a nephroscope. Once the fragments are sufficiently small they can be removed.
Approximately 3% of patients experience a post-procedure haemorrhage although far fewer require any further intervention. In addition to the usual procedural risk of sepsis there is a small risk of pseudoaneurysm formation.
  Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL)
This procedure is less invasive than PCNL but less effective in patients with a high BMI. Although it can be used on large stones, it tends to be first line management for those <2cm. Patients with stones larger than this are likely to be offered PCNL as a first therapy unless they have a co-existing condition which would pose a challenge to performing PCNL such as a solitary kidney.
  Steinstrasse is a complication of ESWL treatment. It is a german word meaning ‘stone street’ and an apt description for the problems which arise when small stone fragments fall into the ureter and are seen as a line of small stones. Naturally these can cause obstruction and pain if sufficiently large.
  Nephrectomy
Where the renal function of the affected kidney is negligible (some sources quote <10%), nephrectomy can be considered.
  Open stone removal
This option remains the fallback position and is occasionally used for patients with extremely large stones or whose collecting duct system has an unfavourable anatomy.
  Prophylactic antibiotic therapy
Certainly this can be used while the patient is waiting for their intervention but will not manage the presence of the stone itself. It may be that patient co-morbidity poses a greater interventional risk than the risk of leaving the staghorn calculus in situ. In most patients however, therapy should be aimed at removing the staghorn calculus to avoid complications which are likely to ensue.
GPT3_explain: Nephrectomy is the most appropriate management for this patient because the staghorn calculus is large in size and has caused a significant difference in function between her left and right kidneys. Nephrectomy, or the surgical removal of the affected kidney, is the only way to ensure that the calculus is removed and that the patient's kidney function is not further compromised. Additionally, it is the only way to ensure that the calculus does not recur.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about application of knowledge, what is the most appropriate management?

Qn_Text: A baby is born by elective caesarean section for known congenital cardiac disease. Which of the following is NOT a conotruncal anomaly.
Explanation:
Explanation:
In situs inversus the main vessels have developed correctly albeit back to front.
Conotruncal anomalies affect the development of the main vessels leading from the heart. Embryologically the aorta and pulmonary arteries begin as one single outlet before separating into two. Where this fails to occur correctly a conotruncal anomaly is seen. DiGeorge Syndrome (a microdeletion on chromosome 22) is associated with all conotruncal anomalies. The following are all conotruncal abnormalities.
  Double outlet right ventricle
DORV is one of the five Ts of cyanotic and plethoric congenital heart disease (Tingle - i.e. Single - ventricle. The others are Tricuspid atresia, Transposition of the great vessels, TAPVC, truncus arteriosus). As the name suggests, both great vessels (the aorta and pulmonary artery) arise from the right ventricle. Consequently it is logical that 100% of cases have a VSD to facilitate drainage of the left ventricle. If the pulmonary trunk is stenotic, as is usually the case, then the lungs will be oligaemic on a CXR. Conversely in the absence of pulmonary stenosis there will be plethora - this accounts for roughly 25% of cases but yet earns DORV its place in the 5Ts. The crux of the imaging findings, and the phrase to look out for in an exam question setting, is that there is no continuity between the mitral valve and the adjacent semilunar valve. This finding is pathognomonic of DORV.
Both Edwards (trisomy 18) and Patau (trisomy 13) syndrome patients can exhibit rockerbottom feet and overlapping fingers although the findings are more closely linked with the former. DORV is associated with both trisomys.
  Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
TOF (not to be confused with trache-oesophageal fistula) causes cyanosis but without pulmonary plethora thus is not included in the 5 Ts.
The tetrad consists of:
VSD
Overriding aorta
Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
RV outflow obstruction (hence pulmonary oligaemia)
  TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease presenting after 12 months of age. In ambulant children the classic finding is of squatting whereby the child squats following exertion in order to increase blood flow to the lungs. It usually presents by at least 3-4 months of age however, but at birth the condition can be concealed by shunting of blood through a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Another facet to the clinical presentation can be polycythaemia which takes place due to chronic low oxygen levels.
Owing to the RVH the cardiac apex is turned upwards contributing to an appearance referred to as ‘boot shaped’ to the cardiac shadow on a CXR.
There is a strong association with right sided aortic arch. Nearly all right sided arches are associated with some form of congenital heart disease and most of these are TOF. Conversely 25% of TOF patients also have a right sided aortic arch.
  Transposition of the Great Vessels (TGA)
TGA is one of the five Ts of cyanotic and plethoric congenital heart disease (The others are Tricuspid atresia, Tingle [ie single] ventricle, TAPVC, truncus arteriosus). Broadly speaking this presents either at birth (it is the most common cyanotic heart disease diagnosed in the first 24 hours of life), or at approximately two weeks of age. Two possible theorised reasons for the later presentation are the closure of the PDA and declining foetal haemoglobin levels leading to decompensation. When the great vessels are transposed there exists two independent circulations. This is therefore only compatible with life if a shunt mechanism also exists, such as an ASD, VSD or PDA. The CXR can be initially normal but develops an ‘egg on side’ appearance to the cardiac shadow. In some cases the transposition is ‘corrected’ where the ventricles are also switched such that the correct ventricle feeds the correct great vessel although the left and right sided circulations remain separate. In corrected transposition the CXR features of note are an apparently absent pulmonary trunk, and an abnormal aortic contour.
  Truncus arteriosus
Embryologically the great vessels begin as one 'conotruncus' which separates during development. When this separation process fails, the baby is left with a single outlet called a truncus arteriosus. On a CXR the baby will be plethoric with cardiomegaly and there are a number of associations which help point towards the answer in an exam question setting without the aid of an echocardiogram. Forked ribs, DiGeorge syndrome, a right sided arch, or an interrupted arch are all known associations.
  Interrupted arch
Fortunately interruption of the aortic arch is rare because it comes with a reasonably high mortality rate. The interruption usually occurs either just before or just after the origin of the left subclavian artery. Supply to the rest of the body distal to this point is maintained only via a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). As well as a PDA most babies will also have a VSD leading to a triad of radiological findings (interrupted arch, PDA, VSD). On a CXR the normal aortic knuckle is absent. Another oft-quoted historical finding is the absence of the aortic impression on a barium swallow.
GPT3_explain: Situs inversus is not a conotruncal anomaly because it does not involve the conotruncal septum, which is the structure in the heart that separates the aorta and the pulmonary artery. Conotruncal anomalies involve defects in this structure, and can include double outlet right ventricle, tetralogy of Fallot, interrupted aortic arch, and transposition of the great vessels.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 51-year-old woman undergoes an HRCT which shows diffuse cysts, nodules and bronchial wall thickening. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Lymphoid interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
LIP can be secondary to a wide range of disease; autoimmune conditions (Sjogrens disease, Hashimoto thyroiditis, Myasthenia gravis, Primary Biliary cirrhosis) or infections (PCP, Hepatitis B, Epstein-Barr). In the paediatric age range an association with AIDS is classical.
Radiologically there is ground glass opacification and centrilobular nodules with the usual demographic being middle aged women (unlike RBILD where there are the same findings but in association with heavy smoking).
  Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HSP) also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis (EAA)
This condition is caused by a granulomatous reaction to an inhaled allergen. Consequently it is the upper zones which are most affected. A detailed history should reveal the source of an antigen e.g. malt farmer, bird fancier, proximity to air conditioners etc. On CT EAA appears as widespread patchy ground glass opacification, mosaic in nature with nodules in a centrilobular distribution. Fibrosis and consequential volume loss occurs over months-years of allergen exposure. Involvement of the pleura (including pleural effusions) is very rare which can separate this condition from many others.
  Amyloid
Primary amyloidosis tends to cause nodule formation in the lungs with tracheal narrowing and thoracic lymph node enlargement. Secondary amyloidosis does not tend to affect the lungs.
  Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
LAM can go misdiagnosed for many years as emphysema. It occurs exclusively in non-smoking women of childbearing age and quite often a history of spontaneous pneumothorax is given. Radiologically there are numerous small cystic spaces surrounded by normal lung. Nodule formation is not a typical feature, neither is bronchial wall thickening. A chylous pleural effusion (negative Hounsfield units) is reasonably specific. The main differential diagnosis would be histiocytosis which tends to be associated with smoking, classically spares the costophrenic angles and gives small nodules but both can present with spontaneous pneumothorax and give small cysts. The lung volumes in LAM will remain normal whereas they can be increased in Histiocytosis (surprisingly for a fibrotic lung disease).
  Neurofibromatosis
Technically neurofibromatosis (type I) is included in the differential diagnosis for lung cysts (Particularly when apical) however the rest of the information provided is insufficient to make this the most likely answer here.
GPT3_explain: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a rare lung disease that affects women of childbearing age. It is characterized by the presence of cysts, nodules, and thickening of the bronchial walls, which are all seen on HRCT. LAM is caused by an abnormal growth of smooth muscle cells and can lead to progressive damage to the lungs. Treatment typically includes the use of medications and/or surgery to reduce the symptoms and progression of the disease.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 78-year-old man undergoes an MRI after a routine asymptomatic screening ear exam shows a blue tympanic membrane. The scan shows a middle ear mass which is homogeneously high on T1 and T2. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
A cholesterol granuloma should be at the top of the list when a blue tympanic membrane is found. The features described in the question are classical for a cholesterol granuloma – the other notable feature not provided is the absence of pulsatile tinnitus which helps distinguish it from a glomus tympanicum. A cholesterol granuloma contains both cholesterol crystals and blood (hence is bright on T1) whereas a cholesteatoma is isointense to brain parenchyma on T1 and can apparently be seen clinically as a whitish mass behind the tympanic membrane. Meningiomas are hypo or isointense on T1.
GPT3_explain: Cholesteatoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is a common cause of middle ear masses and is homogeneously high on T1 and T2. It is a benign growth of skin cells that can form in the middle ear and can lead to hearing loss and other complications if left untreated.

Qn_Text: Which of the following is the longest part of the duodenum? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The duodenum is the shortest, widest and most proximal part of the small intestine. It commences at the pylorus on the right side and extends to the duodenojejunal junction on the left side. Between these two points it pursues a ‘C-shaped’ course around the head of the pancreas.
The duodenum can be divided into four parts:
D1: The superior part:
This superior part is short (around 5 cm long) and lies anterior to the body of L1. It is connected to the liver by the hepatoduodenal ligament. The first 2 cm is mobile and is referred to as the duodenal cap. Duodenal ulcers are most likely to occur in this part of the duodenum.
  D2: The descending part:
This is the longest part (around 7-10 cm long) and descends long the right side of the L1-L3 vertebrae. This part curves inferiorly around the head of the pancreas.
  D3: The inferior part:
This part is around 6-8 cm long and passes laterally to the left crossing the body of L3. This part crosses anteriorly over the inferior vena cava and aorta and is located inferiorly to the pancreas.
  D4: The ascending part:
The ascending part is short (around 5 cm long). It begins to the left of L3 and ascends to the level of the superior border of L2. During its ascent is curves anteriorly at a sharp turn referred to as the duodenojejunal flexure.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Luke Guthmann CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose the inferior part of the duodenum because it is the longest part of the duodenum. The inferior part of the duodenum is approximately 8 to 10 inches long and extends from the lower end of the duodenum to the junction of the small intestine and the large intestine. This is the longest part of the duodenum compared to the other parts which are much shorter.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about ethical issues.

Qn_Text: You are reporting a lower limb angiograph scan for chronic limb ischaemia. Which of the following is the most common site of arterial stenosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The whole length of the SFA is prone to stenosis in susceptible patients but where it dives through the adductor hiatus stenoses are very common.
GPT3_explain: The popliteal artery is the most common site of arterial stenosis in chronic limb ischemia. This is because the popliteal artery is the primary artery that supplies blood to the lower extremities, and any narrowing of this artery can lead to decreased blood flow to the leg and foot. This can cause pain, numbness, and other symptoms of ischemia.
