Qn_Text: You are reporting a CT scan on a baby who had a renal mass discovered on ultrasound. The CT shows it to be a well-defined mass. You suspect this to be a mesoblastic nephroma. Which of the following features would support this diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
A: No involvement of the renal pelvis
Explanation:
Explanation:
Mesoblastic nephroma
This is the most common solid mass in a neonate and 90% of them are diagnosed within the first year of life. Presentation is usually as an abdominal mass. On ultrasound there will be a large hypoechoic renal mass which cannot clearly be separated from the normal renal parenchyma. Cystic spaces can be present due to necrosis. Pertinent negative imaging features of note are the lack of invasion into the collecting system and lack of venous invasion, the latter in particular helps to differentiate it from a Wilms tumour. Both mesoblastic nephroma and nephroblastomatosis show less enhancement post-contrast than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma. Nephroblastomatosis consists of cystic spaces whereas a mesoblastic nephroma is a solid mass which may or may not have cystic spaces.
  Renal masses by age
Neonate:
Multicystic dysplastic kidney (second most common neonatal renal mass)
Mesoblastic nephroma (most common SOLID neonatal renal mass)
Nephroblastomatosis (can be a precursor to Wilms tumour)
  Pre-school:
Multilocular cystic nephroma (affects boys, slightly younger than Wilms)
Wilms tumour (most common SOLID mass of childhood)
Lymphoma (can affect teenagers and adults as well)
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because mesoblastic nephroma is a type of neoplasm that is typically seen in infants and is characterized by a well-defined mass that does not involve the renal pelvis. Avid enhancement, age >1 year, cystic spaces, and calcification are not necessarily indicative of a mesoblastic nephroma.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: Haemorrhoids are caused by a communication between the superior rectal vein and which other veins? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The hepatic portal vein is the major vein of the hepatic portal venous system and carries blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver.
The hepatic portal venous system communicates with the systemic venous system in the following locations:
Oesophageal veins
Para-umbiical veins
Retroperitoneal veins
Rectal veins
When blood flow through the portal system is obstructed, for example due to cirrhosis, thrombosis or the presence of a tumour, pressure rises within the portal system. In these circumstances, portal hypertension develops (a portal venous pressure of >10 mmHg) and these anatomoses become congested and form venous dilatations.
An overview of the main porto-systemic anastomoses and their associated clinical conditions is given in the table below:
  Portal circulation Systemic circulation Clinical condition
Left gastric vein Azygous vein Oesophageal varices
Para-umbilical veins Inferior epigastric vein Caput medusae
Superior rectal vein Middle and inferior rectal veins Haemorrhoids
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the middle and inferior rectal veins are the veins that are most commonly involved in the formation of haemorrhoids. They are connected to the superior rectal vein, which can cause increased pressure in the veins and lead to haemorrhoids.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 58-year-old man presents with a two year history of a painless palpable swelling in his left parotid. USS shows it to be mobile and superficial to the facial nerve. On MRI there is a septated well defined mass in the parotid tail with low intensity on T1 and high intensity on T2. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is a classic description for a Warthin tumour. A squamous cell carcinoma in this location would be a metastatic deposit from a scalp SCC and would be unlikely not to progress in the time frame given. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a relentlessly growing oral tumour although a small percentage arise from the parotid gland. In the parotid it would usually be painful due to invasion of the facial nerve; this tumour is notorious for perineural spread. Both the lymphomas mentioned would be unlikely to demonstrate stability over two years, in addition to the parotid being unlikely primary sites.
GPT3_explain: Warthin tumour is the most likely diagnosis as it is a common benign tumor of the parotid gland that typically presents with a painless, palpable swelling in the parotid gland. It is usually well-defined and septated on MRI, with low intensity on T1 and high intensity on T2.

Qn_Text: A 41-year-old lady attends her GP surgery with a constellation of symptoms. They have all been developing over the last year but she has been putting off attending. After a thorough history and examination her GP finds that she has a symmetrical arthritis affecting the metacarpophalangeal joints, a dry mouth, and abdominal distension. She is referred for an urgent ultrasound scan which shows scattered dilated intraheptic ducts and hypertrophy of the caudate lobe. The common bile duct measures 5 mm in diameter. What is the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
This can be difficult to distinguish from PSC however whereas PSC can involve both intra and extrahepatic ducts, PBC only involves the intrahepatic ducts. It is an autoimmune condition and, like many other autoimmune conditions, patients are typically women in their middle ages. Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are present in the vast majority of patients. On imaging, the secondary cirrhotic effects are most pertinent with caudate lobe hypertrophy and left lobar atrophy. The periportal halo sign as seen on MRI is reasonably specific and relates to fluid accumulation around the portal triad. Associations with rheumatoid arthritis, Sjogrens disease, Hashimoto thyroiditis or CREST are all common.
  Hepatic venous outflow obstruction
There are three separate syndromes which all overlap both in terms of their clinical and radiological features. They are, however, separate entities, caused by subtly different processes.
Passive hepatic congestion – this arises due to a cardiac problem such as right sided heart failure of any cause or constrictive pericarditis. Tender hepatomegaly is common and on imaging the hepatic veins and IVC are notably enlarged.
Budd-Chiari syndrome – the pathology here is within the hepatic veins with thrombosis or other non-thrombotic obstruction (e.g. extrinsic compression). Acutely there is abdominal pain, ascites and hepatomegaly. The presence or absence of caudate lobe hypertrophy can help distinguish between a chronic process or an acute one where this has not had sufficient time to develop.
Hepatic veno-occlusive disease – fibrosis of the tiny venules can develop following a stem-cell transplant, and by pyrrolizidine alkaloids found in Jamaican bush teas. Clinically patients present with weight gain due to fluid retention, hepatomegaly and jaundice.
  Passive hepatic congestion
Budd-Chiari syndrome
Hepatic veno-occlusive disease
Hepatomegaly, ascites and nutmeg liver
Yes
Yes
Yes
USS: Dilated IVC/hepatic veins
Yes
No
No
Doppler: Portal veins
Increased pulsatility
May be reversed flow
Increased pulsatility or reversed flow
CT: hepatic veins
Dilated
Might not be visible
Normal
MRI
-
Comma-shaped collateral vessels – spiders web (chronic feature, also visible on doppler)
-
  All three cause hepatomegaly and ascites, although fluid overload in general is a particular feature of hepatic veno-occlusive disease. On CT all three can give a ‘nutmeg’ appearance to the liver when, on early phase imaging, contrast has yet to homogenise throughout the liver and consequently there is a mottled appearance which rather resembles the cut surface of a nutmeg. On delayed phase imaging the liver becomes more homogeneous. The flip-flop sign is particularly associated with Budd-Chiari syndrome with strong central and limited peripheral enhancement on early phases followed by early central washout with retained peripheral enhancement on delayed images.
  Budd-Chiari syndrome
The haemodynamics of the liver, as being different from any other organ, can give rise to some interesting pathology. In Budd-Chiari syndrome venous obstruction causes flow reversal in the portal venous system to drain the liver. Acutely this presents as a triad of abdominal pain, ascites and hepatomegaly. In many acute cases the liver function tests have not had sufficient time to become deranged. The caudate lobe usually drains directly into the IVC so may not be affected by the underlying cause of obstruction to the other hepatic veins. Consequently it is able to shoulder more of the usual burden of the liver and becomes hypertrophied. In the acute setting this has not had time to manifest and the caudate lobe will be of a normal size.
Some of the many causes of Budd-Chiari syndrome
Thrombosis of the hepatic veins
Platelets (thrombocytosis)
Pill (OCP)
Pregnancy (hypercoagulable state)
Polycythaemia rubra vera
Non-thrombotic causes
Mechanical compression by a tumour
Right atrial myxoma
Constrictive pericarditis
  On CT the enhancement pattern is described as being ‘flip-flop’, with strong central and limited peripheral enhancement on early phases followed by early central washout with retained peripheral enhancement on delayed images. Alternatively the whole liver may appear mottled with a ‘nutmeg’ type pattern due to the venous congestion. On Doppler ultrasound or MRI the hepatic veins will show a reduction in calibre or not be seen at all and on Doppler insonation the hepatic veins may show little or no flow. Flow in the portal venous system, on the other hand, may be reversed. In chronic cases a veritable spiders-web of small collateral vessels can be seen on angiography; they can also be seen on MRI and are described as having a comma-shape.
  Passive hepatic congestion
This is similar to chronic Budd-Chiari syndrome, but whereas Budd-Chiari syndrome arises due to hepatic outflow obstruction, in heart failure leading to hepatic congestion there is no mechanical obstruction. In contrast to acute thrombotic Budd-Chiari syndrome there is distension of the hepatic veins and IVC, a feature which distinguishes it from hepatic veno-occlusive disease as well. Other signs of heart failure, such as pleural effusions and ascites may be present concurrently.
  Hepatic veno-occlusive disease
The outcome of hepatic veno-occlusive disease is similar to that of Budd-Chiari syndrome but the mechanism is different. Hepatic congestion develops as a consequence of fibrosis to the venules within the liver. This can occur secondary to chemotherapy or bone marrow transplantation and also bizarrely due to pyrrolizidine alkaloids which are found in Jamaican bush teas. On imaging there is overlap with the features of Budd-Chiari syndrome but crucially the hepatic veins should appear normal; it is the smaller venules which cause the problem and these are not seen on ultrasound or CT.
  Viral hepatitis
The imaging findings of hepatitis are non-specific and include hepatomegaly, decreased echogenicity, periportal oedema, and gallbladder wall thickening. The ‘starry sky’ appearance is used to describe a liver which has a number of bright echogenic dots on a background of diffuse low reflectivity and this has traditionally been associated with hepatitis however both the sensitivity and specificity of this sign are low.
GPT3_explain: Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the liver. The characteristic symptoms include symmetrical arthritis affecting the metacarpophalangeal joints, dry mouth, and abdominal distension. The ultrasound scan findings of scattered dilated intraheptic ducts and hypertrophy of the caudate lobe along with the common bile duct measuring 5 mm in diameter are all consistent with a diagnosis of PBC.

Qn_Text: A 9-day-old baby boy who was born prematurely is found to have bubbly and curvilinear areas in the right lower quadrant on abdominal x-ray.   What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Of the neonatal causes of bowel obstruction, the age at presentation and level of obstruction can point heavily towards the diagnosis.
  Level of obstruction
Age at presentation
NEC
All/any
<10 days
Meconium ileus
Caecum/terminal ileum
<48hrs
Meconium plug
Splenic flexure
<48hrs
Hirschsprung disease
Sigmoid colon
<6 weeks
  Necrotising enterocolitis
This is the most common gastrointestinal emergency for premature babies. It results from an immature immune system being unable to cope with mucosal ulceration. Almost all cases occur before the baby reaches 10 days old. Pneumatosis intestinalis (intramural gas) is the hallmark of the condition on abdominal radiography and appears as curvilinear or bubbly areas. Branching gas within the liver, indicative of portal venous gas can also occur but is not as serious a finding as it would be for an adult. Surgery is definitely indicated however, if there is evidence of perforation and for this reason patients should undergo a horizontal beam x-ray. If performed decubitus the left side should be down in order to better visualise air against the contour of the liver. On an over-table view the ‘football’ sign, where a large collection of gas rises centrally, is seen if there is sufficient free gas within the abdomen.
  Meconium ileus
This condition is strongly associated with cystic fibrosis but not with prematurity. The thicker-than-normal intestinal mucus, increase in transit time and pancreatic insufficiency all conspire to cause impaction of meconium leading to small bowel obstruction in neonates. It should be suspected if the baby does not pass meconium within the first 2 days of life. On an abdominal radiograph there will be no air-fluid levels since no fluid is present but multiple gas filled dilated loops of small bowel will be seen. The meconium can sometimes be seen as a bubbly area in the right lower quadrant where it has impacted within the terminal ileum.
  Meconium plug
Whereas meconium ileus leads to small bowl obstruction, meconium plug syndrome leads to large bowel obstruction due to functional immaturity of the colon. This will also present within the first two days of life with a failure to pass meconium. Some literature associates this condition with babies born to diabetic mothers and around a quater of patients have cystic fibrosis. The condition can be treated with a water-soluble contrast enema.
  Meconium peritonitis
When there is antenatal bowel perforation the result is a chemical peritonitis as opposed to a purulent one since the bowel is as yet unpopulated by the usual flora of life after birth. The result is calcification scattered around the abdomen. If the perforation spontaneously heals itself then the prognosis is excellent and the finding of abdominal calcification may be purely incidental.
  Hirschsprung disease
There is a congenital absence of parasympathetic ganglia in the muscular and submucosal layers of a segment of colon, usually the sigmoid colon. The affected segment is unable to relax to pass meconium and patients therefore present with failure to pass meconium or sometimes within the first six weeks of life with severe constipation with overflow diarrhoea. Classically on a barium enema there is an inverted cone shape formed between the normal and abnormal bowel segments and the diagnosis should be confirmed using a suction biopsy below this transition point. Another feature seen on a barium enema is a result of abnormally coordinated contractions of the affected segment which appears as so-called ‘persistent corrugation’.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2, Necrotising enterocolitis, because bubbly and curvilinear areas on an abdominal x-ray are consistent with the presence of air within the intestinal wall, which is a common symptom of necrotising enterocolitis. This condition is a serious complication of prematurity, and is more common in premature babies than in full-term babies.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reporting the CT scan of an industrial worker. There are calcified pleural plaques and you suspect the patient may have asbestosis. Which of the following would support a diagnosis of asbestosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
When calcified pleural plaques are seen bilaterally it is virtually pathognomonic of prior asbestos exposure. Of all asbestos related pleural plaques around 85% are calcified. Involvement of the mediastinal pleura should raise the possibility of mesothelioma but involvement of the costophrenic angles should raise the possibility of an alternative diagnosis as these are usually spared in asbestos related plaque disease. Sparing can occur in other pathologies too and should not be taken as an absolute sign of asbestosis, merely that involvement of the costophrenic angles suggests an alternative diagnosis. Unilateral pleural plaques can be caused by any previous insult such as surgery or an empyema although the most common cause is still asbestos related lung disease.
  Mediastinal lymph node calcification
This can be seen in a number of conditions:
Tuberculosis
Histoplasmosis
Amyloidosis (rare)
Metastases: papillary/medullary thyroid cancer, osteosarcoma, mucinous adenocarcinoma
  Specifically egg-shell calcification
Silicosis and coal workers pneumoconiosis
Sarcoidosis
Treated lymphoma
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because continuous pleural plaques are a common sign of asbestosis. The plaques are typically visible on a CT scan and are particularly common in those who have been exposed to asbestos. The presence of continuous pleural plaques is a strong indication that the patient has been exposed to asbestos and is likely suffering from asbestosis.
Cat_Long: This question falls under 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 14-year-old boy with recurrent seizures since birth and a port wine stain on his face undergoes an MRI. There is gyriform low signal on T2 with leptomeningeal enhancement and ipsilateral enlargement of the choroid plexus. Which feature of Sturge-Weber-Dimitri syndrome would explain the MRI findings?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is one of those irritating questions where as you are reading the information provided you should be thinking of Sturge-Weber syndrome (technically Sturge-Weber-Dimitri syndrome) and then the question writers tell you that that is what it is and ask you something else about it. With the exception of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome, the other answers are all features of Sturge-Weber syndrome, but not ones which explain the particular MRI findings that have been described. Buphthalmos is enlargement of the globe. Largely speaking the other phakomatoses are all autosomal dominant in inheritance. Sturge-Weber syndrome arises from a sporadic mutation.
GPT3_explain: Leptomeningeal angiomatosis is a common feature of Sturge-Weber-Dimitri syndrome. It is characterized by the presence of a diffuse, gyriform low signal on T2 MRI with leptomeningeal enhancement and ipsilateral enlargement of the choroid plexus. These findings are consistent with the clinical presentation of the patient and explain the MRI findings seen.

3. A question involving application of knowledge to a clinical scenario.

Qn_Text: An 8-year-old girl is tackled during a football training session and is unable to weight-bear. An x-ray in A+E shows a medial malleolar fracture but also a distal tibial lesion thought to be fibrous dysplasia. Which of the following is NOT part of the spectrum of fibrous dysplasia? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is NOT related to fibrous dysplasia.
  This patient has McCune-Albright syndrome
Fibrous dysplasia
This tends to be a condition of childhood-adolescence. It is otherwise rarely seen in patients older than 30. It is a benign condition caused by abnormal osteoblasts and leading to focal replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue. Most cases are monostotic but polyostotic cases occur around 20% of the time. Virtually any bone can be affected although the long bones tend to be more frequently affected in the polyostotic form. That said, fibrous dysplasia is also a typical differential diagnosis for a rib or skull lesion.
Classically the appearances on x-ray or CT is described as 'ground glass' in matrix, and situated within the centre of the bone (i.e. medullary), but often causing bony expansion. Since the bone is abnormal there is an increased risk of fractures but unless there is an acute injury there should not be a periosteal reaction.
On a nuclear medicine bone scan the lesions tend to show increased uptake and this is therefore rarely useful in diagnosing this condition.
Aside from pathological fractures, the condition can also occasionally be complicated by secondary degeneration which would be to osteosarcoma and should be suspected if the patient complains of pain and the growth of a soft tissue mass. This occurs more frequently in patients who have previously been exposed to radiation.
There are a number of eponymous or descriptive terms associated with fibrous dysplasia:
Shepherds crook deformity - coxa varus deformity of the proximal femur. This is usually used to describe the effect of fibrous dysplasia on the proximal femur with chronic bowing and remodelling secondary to microfractures, but the same appearance can occur with conditions such as Paget disease or osteogenesis imperfecta, for the same reasons.
Protrusio acetabuli - fibrous dysplasia is one of a number of things which can cause protrusion of the femoral head into the pelvis due to remodelling of the acetabulum.
Leontiasis ossea - facial involvement causing a specific appearance said to resemble that of a lion. Owing to canal stenosis caused by bony expansion patients can exhibit cranial nerve palsies.
Cherubism - facial (maxilla and mandible) involvement causes a specific appearance said to resemble that of a cherub. Owing to canal stenosis caused by bony expansion patients can exhibit cranial nerve palsies. Cherubism is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.
McCune-Albright syndrome - this almost always only affects girls and consists of a triad of cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (or other endocrine pathology), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia. The cafe-au-lait pigmentation is often on the back and can commonly be seen to respect the midline.
Mazabraud syndrome - this is a very rare condition. Patients present with polyostotic fibrous dysplasia and soft tissue tumours and are at increased risk of malignant degeneration to osteosarcoma.
  Hand-Schüller-Christian Disease is a type of histiocytosis.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Shepherds Crook deformity because it is not part of the spectrum of fibrous dysplasia. Fibrous dysplasia is a benign bone disorder characterized by the replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue. The other four conditions listed are all part of the spectrum of fibrous dysplasia. Leontiasis Ossea is a rare disorder characterized by a painful enlargement of the bones of the face and skull. Hand-Schüller-Christian Disease is a rare form of lymphoma that affects the bones and skin. Cherubism is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the enlargement of the lower jaw and facial bones. McCune-Albright syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of multiple bone lesions.

3. A question about the application of knowledge, what is the best treatment?

This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old man involved in a severe road traffic accident is brought to A+E. He undergoes a trauma CT scan which shows a complex pelvic fracture with a large pelvic haematoma. The scan shows a large contrast blush around the right obturator artery tracking towards the haematoma. The patient becomes unstable after the scan. What should the next management step be?
Explanation:
Explanation:
A retrograde urethrogram can be performed if there is concern regarding a possible urethral or bladder injury. For optimum results this should be achieved prior to IV contrast however can still be performed after a CT scan if necessary. It is, however, somewhat futile in the case of an unstable patient with a large pelvic haematoma and will go no way towards halting further blood loss.
Target artery embolisation via endovascular techniques can be hugely successful in such cases and is associated with a far lower morbidity and mortality than surgical exploration. Pelvic fractures are associated with a high risk of vascular injury. Catheter angiography is the gold standard for identifying a bleeding point although the scan results in this case suggest a target vessel even prior to catheter angiography. Endovascular embolisation can be extremely successful in achieving haemostasis for arterial bleeding but is not useful where the haematoma is thought to derive from the bony fractures.
GPT3_explain: Target artery embolisation is the best management step for this patient because it will help to stop the bleeding from the obturator artery and reduce the size of the pelvic haematoma. Embolisation involves the injection of a substance (such as a coil or glue) into the artery to block it and stop the flow of blood. This can be done under ultrasound guidance and is a minimally invasive procedure that can be performed quickly and effectively. This will help stabilize the patient and allow them to receive the necessary treatment for their fracture.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical decision making, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: A 50-year-old lady presents with a worst ever headache and has equivocal findings for a subarachnoid haemorrhage on CT scan two days later. She is unable to tolerate a lumbar puncture. What would be the next best test to confirm the diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The diagnostic pathway to investigate for intracranial aneurysms following a subarachnoid haemorrhage is:
CT angiogram
Invasive angiogram
Second invasive angiogram after approx 10 days.
Although in this patient’s case the diagnosis of a subarachnoid haemorrhage has not been fully established, the presence of an aneurysm must be excluded.
Bear in mind that the correct answer may change if the wording of the questions is different. For example a DSA invasive angiogram would be the gold standard investigation for an aneurysm but is not usually done first; a CTA is therefore the next best test in the first instance.  Similarly an MRI scan would be the next best test to confirm the diagnosis of a subarachnoid haemorrhage but does not have a sufficiently low false negative rate to exclude an aneurysm. In the answers provided here, with the exception of the unenhanced CT, only angiographic options are available and hence this is not the correct answer.
GPT3_explain: MRA is the next best test to confirm a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage because it provides detailed images of the brain and its blood vessels, which can help identify the exact location of the hemorrhage. Additionally, MRA does not require a lumbar puncture, which the patient is unable to tolerate.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about prognosis, what is the likely outcome?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing an x-ray of a 23-year-old woman. There is fragmentation and sclerosis of the head of the lunate. No overlying soft tissue swelling is present. What is the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Kienbock disease is avascular necrosis of the lunate and usually occurs either in young men or in middle aged women. There is an association with negative ulnar variance where the ulna is shorter than it should be and the stresses on the wrist are therefore altered. That being said, most patients with negative ulnar variance do not have Kienbock disease.
Of the Eponymous avascular necroses, in general any bone can be affected at any age however there are distinct trends for many of them. Some of the prominent conditions are listed below:
  Eponym
Bone
Age
Kohler
Navicular
4-6 yrs
Panner
Capitellum
5-10 yrs
Sever
Calcaneum
Young children
Frieberg
Metatarsal head (usually 2nd)
Teenage women
Scheuermann
Vertebral apophyses
Children, teenagers
Blount
Proximal medial tibial epiphysis
Infants, juveniles and adolescents
Kienbock
Lunate
Young men or middle aged women
Ahlback
Medial femoral condyle (i.e. SONK)
Women >55
Preiser
Scaphoid
Any age
GPT3_explain: Kienbock disease is a condition that affects the lunate bone in the wrist. It is characterized by fragmentation and sclerosis of the head of the lunate, which is what is seen in the x-ray of the 23-year-old woman. Overlying soft tissue swelling is not present, which further supports the diagnosis of Kienbock disease.

Qn_Text: Which of the following structures empties urine into the renal pelvis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The parenchyma of the kidney is divided into two major structures:
The outer renal cortex and;
The inner renal medulla
  The renal cortex extends into the medulla and divides it into triangular shaped areas referred to as the renal pyramids. Each renal pyramid combines with the renal cortex above it to form a renal lobe. Between the renal pyramids are projections of renal cortex referred to as the renal columns.
The functional unit of the kidney is the nephron. These are responsible for the production of urine and span the cortex and medulla. The initial filtering portion of the nephron is the renal corpuscle, which is located in the cortex. This is followed by the renal tubule that extends into the renal pyramids. Within the renal cortex lies the medullary ray, which is a collection of renal tubules that drains into a single collecting duct.
At the apex of each renal pyramid is the renal papilla. This empties urine into the minor calyx. Several minor calices combine to form a major calyx. Urine drains from the minor calices into the major calyx and the empties into the funnel-shaped renal pelvis. Urine then drains from the renal pelvis into the ureter.
  Image adapted from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Holly Fischer CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose 5. Major calyx because the major calyx is the structure that empties urine into the renal pelvis. The major calyx is a funnel-shaped structure that is located at the end of the renal papilla and is responsible for collecting and transporting urine from the renal tubules to the renal pelvis.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 53-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of occipital headache. A CT of her head demonstrates hydrocephalus, subarachnoid haemorrhage and a frontal lobe (gyrus rectus) haematoma. What is the most likely site for the responsible aneurysm?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
An anterior choroidal artery is a tiny branch of the internal carotid artery which runs posteriorly and accounts for 4% of aneurysms.
The pericallosal artery is the distal continuation of the anterior cerebral artery, coursing superiorly over the corpus callosum.
Aneurysms at branch points such as at the anterior communicating artery have a much higher risk of rupture.
GPT3_explain: The anterior communicating artery is the most likely site for the responsible aneurysm in this case because it is the most common site for an aneurysm in cases of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The anterior communicating artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery and it is located at the base of the brain where the two anterior cerebral arteries meet. It is the most common site for aneurysms due to its location, which is a region of high pressure and turbulence.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment?

This question falls under question 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old woman complaining of blurred vision is referred for an MRI scan by her neurologist. This shows T2 and FLAIR hyperintensities in the corpus callosum orientated perpendicularly to the lateral ventricles. One of the lesions shows restriction of diffusion and enhancement with contrast. The rest do not. What is the most likely explanation?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Multiple sclerosis
This is an idiopathic demyelinating disease with oedematous perivascular inflammation in the acute stage progressing to demyelination with proliferation of the astroglia in the chronic phase. There are oblong elliptical plaques of high T2 signal at the callososeptal interface.
Other highly testable features:
Involvement of the middle cerebral peduncle is specific to multiple sclerosis when attempting to differentiate it from small vessel ischaemic changes
Lesions can cross the midline
Axial T2 sequences are better than FLAIR for posterior fossa lesions
Acute lesions can enhance with contrast, classically in an ‘incomplete ring’
Thalamic involvement is rare and suggests the possibility of ADEM instead
Cryptococcus
This is an opportunistic yeast-like fungus which therefore requires a degree of immunocompromise, typically AIDS. The cryptococcomas are non-enhancing low density lesions in the basal ganglia. These show as high signal on T2 sequences. A granulomatous meningitis can also occur. They can be differentiated from VR spaces on FLAIR where VR spaces will suppress (being CSF in content) whereas the mucoid cryptococcomas will not.
  Astrocytoma
Multifocal astrocytomas would not be impossible but are statistically unlikely.
  Antiphospholipid syndrome
Antiphospholipid syndrome is technically a differential diagnosis to the findings of multiple sclerosis on MRI however is largely only included for the sake of completeness.
  Hurler syndrome
This unpleasant disease is a mucopolysaccharidosis and like most others is autosomal recessive in inheritance. It affects very young children and is usually fatal within the first 12 months of life. Prominent perivascular spaces are seen on MRI brain, hence its inclusion here as a theoretical differential diagnosis.
GPT3_explain: I chose this because multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common cause of demyelination in the corpus callosum, which is the area that was shown to have hyperintensities on the MRI scan. The fact that one of the lesions showed restriction of diffusion and enhancement with contrast is consistent with the diagnosis of MS.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the appendix is true?
A: It contains a large quantity of lymphoid tissue
B: It is attached to the anterio-lateral end of the caecum
D: Its tip is most commonly located in the retro-ileal position
E: McBurney’s point corresponds with the most common position of the tip of the appendix
Explanation:
Explanation:
The appendix is a narrow, worm-shaped, blind-ended tube that is attached to the posteromedial end of the caecum. It has a short triangular mesentery called the mesoappendix that suspends it from the mesentery of the terminal ileum.
It contains a large quantity of lymphoid tissue but serves no important function in humans. The position of the free-end of the appendix is highly variable. There are five main locations at which it can be found, the two commonest being the retrocaecal and subcaecal positions.
The distribution of positions is as follows:
Ascending retrocaecal (64%)
Subcaecal (32%)
Transverse retrocaecal (2%)
Ascending preileal (1%)
Ascending retroileal (0.5%)
    Distribution of the position of the appendix tip (from An Atlas of Anatomy by John Charles Grant)
  Appendicitis is acute inflammation of the appendix and is one of the most common causes of the acute abdomen. It is typically a disease of children and young adults with a peak incidence in the 2nd to 3rd decades of life.
The classical presentation of appendicitis is with poorly localized periumbilical pain (referred pain from the visceral peritoneum). Within a day or two this pain typically localizes to McBurney’s point (pain from parietal peritoneum). There is usually associated fever, anorexia and nausea.
McBurney’s point is defined as being the point that lies one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. It roughly corresponds with the most common position of the attachment of the base of the appendix to the caecum.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Steven Fruitsmaak CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because it is the only statement that is true. The appendix is attached to the anterio-lateral end of the caecum, but does have a mesentery. Its tip is usually located in the retro-ileal position, but can be in other positions. It does contain a large quantity of lymphoid tissue, which is why it is considered part of the immune system. McBurney's point does not correspond with the most common position of the tip of the appendix.
Cat_Long: This question falls under Basic Factual Recall.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old lady presents with right flank pain. She denies any history of trauma. She undergoes a CT scan which demonstrates a 5 cm fat-dense lesion within the right kidney. The radiologist also notes an 8mm tubular structure in the right flank with surrounding fat stranding. Which of the following would be the most accurate description of this clinical presentation? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
This patient has appendicitis and an incidental large AML. Following treatment for her acute presentation she should receive counselling for the risk of AML rupture and be offered prophylactic embolisation.
Wunderlich syndrome
Spontaneous haemorrhage/rupture is a known complication of AMLs and is termed Wunderlich syndrome. Patients with AMLs larger than 4cm are at particularly increased risk of this. Wunderlich syndrome can occur in the context of Tuberous Sclerosis or in a patient with an isolated large AML. Although Wunderlich syndrome is most commonly caused by an underlying AML, it can also be seen with renal cell carcinoma or vascular malformations.
Tuberous sclerosis
This condition would explain the presence of a fat containing renal lesion (if it wasn't simply a sporadic finding) but has no relation to the dilated and inflamed appendix. Not all patients with tuberous sclerosis have AMLs and not all of those with AMLs have large enough ones to rupture, and not all of those with large AMLs experience Wunderlich syndrome.
Majewski Syndrome
This is a variant of short-rib polydactyly syndrome with no renal associations.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Wunderlich Syndrome because it is a condition that is characterized by an abnormally large, fat-dense lesion in the kidney and an 8mm tubular structure in the flank with surrounding fat stranding. The other options are not associated with this type of presentation.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about a clinical scenario, what is the most accurate description?

3. A question about a clinical scenario, what is the most accurate description?

Qn_Text: A 77-year-old man is undergoing pre-operative assessment prior to a routine TURP procedure for some troublesome lower urinary tract symptoms. When his PSA is found to be markedly elevated he undergoes an MRI scan for further investigation. A 12mm tumour is seen in the left peripheral zone. It returns low signal on the T2 weighted sequences, with some very low signal on the ADC sequence too. What is the PSA density most likely to be? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The PSA is usually considered elevated when levels exceed 4ng/L. A number of things can artificially elevate the PSA and in many cases of an incidental elevated PSA once these have been excluded the PSA returns to normal. Patients should be counselled to avoid activities which could lead to an elevated PSA for at least 48hrs prior to the test.
  False positive PSA False negative PSA
'Stradle' activities (bike riding, horse riding etc.) Aspirin
Ejaculation NSAIDs
Urinary tract infection  
Prostatitis  
Digital rectal examination  
Benign prostatic hyperplasia  
  The PSA density is calculated by taking the PSA and dividing it by the volume of the prostate. The volume is calculated as: Height x Length x Depth x π/6 (the volume of an ellipsoid). It accounts for the increase in size of the prostate which occurs in many men with increasing age and allows a far more comparable indication of the likelihood of malignancy. 0.1 is considered a normal PSA density value. Prostate cancers are usually seen in those with a prostate density of >0.1ng/ml/cc.
If a radiologist is reviewing a scan for a patient with a PSA density >0.1 and is unable to identify a prostatic malignancy then either they should review the scan more closely, or the PSA value could be repeated following appropriate instructions to the patient regarding cessation of PSA elevating activities prior to the test.
GPT3_explain: The PSA density is the ratio of the PSA level to the size of the prostate gland. In this case, the PSA level is markedly elevated and the size of the tumor is 12mm. Therefore, the PSA density is likely to be 0.04.

Qn_Text: A 14-year-old boy is found to have a lucent bone lesion in his right ilium. It is permeative, has an associated periosteal reaction and there is an associated soft tissue component measuring 15cm in depth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Ewing sarcoma
This is an aggressive cancer which affects children. The age distribution peaks at 15 years and initial presentation is with pain and a mass but blood tests will often show a high white cell count and a raised ESR. For this reason it can sometimes be misdiagnosed as infection. X-ray findings are of an aggressive lytic lesion with a lamellated periosteal reaction seen in around half cases (sunburst/spiculated periosteal reactions can be seen in a fifth of cases). The moth-eaten, permeative bony destruction seen on x-ray is a late finding. Any bone can be affected but 60% of cases involve a long bone, in particular the femur. On MRI, if not on x-ray, a large soft-tissue component can usually be seen. About a third of cases have metastatic disease at presentation and in these patients anaemia is a common finding.
  Osteosarcoma
These are bone forming tumours which can either be primary, or secondary. Primary osteosarcomas occur in young patients or young adults when the bones are more active during adolescence than in later life, and have a predilection for either the proximal tibia or distal femur i.e. around the knee joint. Secondary osteosarcomas occur as malignant degeneration of pre-existing bone lesions. Clinically they present as a painful mass with a fever. Pain on movement is also typical. In later disease patients may have a raised serum ALP. On x-ray they are poorly defined aggressive lesions with sunburst periosteal reaction and fluffy cloud-like osseous matrix. For staging the patient should receive an MRI of the entire of the affected bone (to rule out synchronous lesions), a nuclear medicine bone scan and a CT chest. Tissue biopsy should only be performed at tertiary referral centres where to mitigate the risk of seeding the biopsy tract, immediate tissue analysis with the option of immediate amputation can be performed.
  Some of the pertinent subtypes of osteosarcoma
 Parosteal
 Lower grade, older age (20-50s)
 Telangiectatic
 Purely lytic, poor prognosis, fluid-fluid levels
 Multicentric
 Ages 5-10 with very poor prognosis
  Chondroblastoma
Largely speaking these tumours only arise in epiphyses or epiphyseal equivalent bones (such as the patella) and are therefore confined, in-terms of age, to children or adolescents. They can present in a fairly indolent fashion with pain, swelling and tenderness preceding diagnosis by weeks, if not months. They typically occur in the long bones, around two thirds are found in the leg and half are found around the knee. On x-ray they appear as a lucent, lobulated lesion with a thin sclerotic margin. Surrounding oedema, if present, can be surprisingly florid, even leading to an overestimation of the extent of the underlying lesion. Calcification associated with the lesion does occur but is better appreciated with CT.
  Histiocytosis (aka Langerhans cell histiocytosis - LCH)
There are three separate forms of this disease:
Eosinophilic granuloma (70%) – a limited version confined to the skeleton in children or young adults. Clinically presents as fever, raised WCC and ESR with painful bony lesions. In the skull these have a typical ‘beveled edge’ or ‘hole within a hole’ appearance or can be seen as a ‘button sequestrum’. In the spine it is one of the main causes of vertebra plana.
Hand-Schüller-Christian Disease (20%) – classically a triad of destructive bony lesions, diabetes insipidus and exophthalmos. In a quarter of these patients the lungs are involved with cyst formation and spontaneous pneumothoraces possible. Nodule formation, fibrosis and honeycombing is also seen.
Letterer-Siwe Disease (10%) – a fulminant multi-organ variant affecting very young infants
There is a strong association with smoking for patients who develop pulmonary features of LCH. Heavy smoking causes an accumulation of Langerhans cells and hence, as with other inspiration-related lung diseases, there is a predilection for the upper zones. The Langerhans cells can collect with other cells and become small granulomas seen as small lung nodules. Despite being a type of fibrotic lung disease the lung volumes can be increased.  Small lung cysts form and there is a risk of spontaneous pneumothorax. In the MCQ world there is sparing of the costophrenic angles.
GPT3_explain: I chose Ewing sarcoma because it is the most common type of bone tumor in adolescents, and it typically involves the long bones of the body, such as the ilium. It is also characterized by a permeative, lucent bone lesion with an associated periosteal reaction and a soft tissue component.

Qn_Text: You are performing an FNA for a patient with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. The histology is reported as squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is the LEAST likely primary source?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Men
Firstly prostate cancer is nearly always adenocarcinoma not squamous cell carcinoma and secondly regional nodes in the context of prostate cancer would be internal and external iliac nodes. Inguinal nodes are therefore less likely to be from prostate cancer; these would be considered as non-regional metastatic disease.
When not adenocarcinomatous in origin, prostate cancer can (rarely) be transitional cell, sarcoma, lymphoma or adenoid cystic cancer.
Inguinal lymph node involvement would be considered regional disease for anal cancers in both sexes as well as penile and scrotal skin cancers in men and vulval or vaginal cancers in women.
Scrotal skin cancers are usually squamous cell in origin and spread via the lymphatics, initially to the inguinal nodes. Of note involvement of the inguinal nodes may be contralateral to the site of the index tumour since both sets of inguinal nodes drain the whole scrotal sac. Testicular tumours however, will only spread to the inguinal region as regional disease if the patient has undergone previous inguinal or scrotal surgery. In the absence of prior intervention the inguinal region is considered as a non-regional area for testicular tumours.
  Proportion of squamous cell carcinomas
Penile cancer
  >90%
Anal cancer
Scrotal skin cancer
Cervical cancer
Vulval cancer
Vaginal cancer
>80%
Bladder cancer
<10%
Prostate cancer
<1%
Testicular cancer
<1% (can be a site of metastatic SCC though)
  Women
Cervical cancer is predominantly squamous cell in origin and spreads initially via the obturator nodes and thence to the internal or external iliac nodes. The lymphatic spread of vaginal cancer depends to an extent on its exact location. Cancers situated in the upper two thirds of the vagina behaves in a similar way to cervical cancer (Obturater, internal and external iliac nodes) but those in the lower third do spread first to the inguinal or femoral nodes as local disease as do vulval cancers.
  Prostate cancer
The vast majority of cancers of the prostate are adenocarcinomas and the risk of developing prostate cancer increases with age to such an extent that by the age of 80 approximately 80% of men will have some neoplastic foci within the prostate although these may be completely occult and never manifest clinically.  Where the disease does advance it becomes one of the top three most common causes of death from cancer in men alongside lung cancer and colorectal cancer. Serum Prostatic Specific Antigen (PSA) levels have been used in prostate cancer screening since the 1990s.
MRI is crucial to provide accurate staging but is also gaining in momentum on its way to becoming a screening tool in its own right.
The majority of prostate cancers arise from the peripheral zone and causes the normally high T2 signal to become low signal. Additionally the cancer should show restriction in diffusion (ie high signal on DWI, correspondingly low on ADC). It is important to view the T1 images as well in order to exclude the possibility of haemorrhage which can sometimes look like a prostate cancer. The precise appearance of a haemorrhage changes depending on the timeframe.
GPT3_explain: Anal cancer is the least likely primary source for a squamous cell carcinoma in an enlarged inguinal lymph node because squamous cell carcinoma is most commonly associated with cancers of the skin, head, neck, and other organs, but not typically anal cancer.
Cat_Long: This question would fall under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A baby boy born at term is brought back to hospital three weeks later by his worried parents. They describe bilious vomiting and on examination the baby has abdominal distension. An abdominal radiograph is performed which shows multiple dilated loops of bowel. A barium enema shows the distal sigmoid colon to be of normal calibre but the proximal colon to be very dilated with an inverted cone shape between the two. Given the likely diagnosis, what would be the best way of confirming this?
E: Cellular swab at the transition point
Explanation:
Explanation:
Hirschsprung disease
There is a congenital absence of parasympathetic ganglia in the muscular and submucosal layers of a segment of colon, usually the sigmoid colon. The affected segment is unable to relax to pass meconium and patients therefore present with failure to pass meconium or sometimes within the first six weeks of life with severe constipation with overflow diarrhoea. Classically on a barium enema there is an inverted cone shape formed between the normal and abnormal bowel segments and the diagnosis should be confirmed using a suction biopsy below this transition point. Another feature seen on a barium enema is a result of abnormally coordinated contractions of the affected segment which appears as so-called ‘persistent corrugation’.
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because laparoscopic biopsy is the most accurate and reliable method for confirming the diagnosis. It allows for the direct visualization of the transition point, which is the key area of interest in this scenario. The laparoscopic biopsy can provide a sample of tissue from the transition point to be examined for any abnormalities, which will provide the most accurate diagnosis.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical management, what is the best way of confirming the diagnosis?

Qn_Text: In a teaching session you are presented with an MRI scan which shows low T1 signal in the liver. There is signal gain on the out of phase images. The consultant taking the session refuses to provide you with any details of the patient’s history or presenting complaint. Which of the following would best fit with these findings?
Explanation:
Explanation:
It is more usual to talk about haemochromatosis as causing signal drop out on the in-phase images or to talk about fatty lesions in terms of signal drop out on the out-of-phase images. The absence of signal drop-out on the out of phase images serves only to prove that there is no fatty component to the area being described.
  Haemochromatosis
The primary version of this disease can be inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. Excess dietary iron is absorbed and this accumulates in all tissues of the body leading to various different problems.
Secondary haemochromatosis can arise if patients receive numerous blood transfusions without sufficient chelation to mitigate against the iron overload.
Cirrhosis – the presence of the excess iron in the liver leads to unusual signal properties on an MRI scan. Iron is paramagnetic and causes spin dephasing. T2* and T2 sequences are particularly vulnerable to this effect but lower than expected signal will be seen on all sequences. Importantly the signal from the spleen and bone marrow should be normal. By contrast they will be involved in cases of transfusional siderosis.
Generalised osteoporosis
Hook like osteophytes on the radial aspect of the metacarpal heads – these are highly characteristic
Chondrocalcinosis, particularly affecting the knees
Insulin dependent diabetes
Congestive cardiomyopathy
Skin pigmentation
  Wilson disease
Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, this disease results from an excess of copper within the body due to the inability of the liver to excrete it. It can present in childhood with cirrhosis but later presentations are more likely to be due to the neuropsychiatric manifestations. Clinically adolescent or adult patients develop tremor and dysarthria due to copper deposition in the lentiform nucleus. The classic diagnostic feature is Kayser-Fleischer pigment rings in the eyes. Radiologically the following features can be seen:
Hepatic manifestations: The liver appears normal on MRI since fatty infiltration effectively cancels out the paramagnetic effects of copper
Musculoskeletal manifestations: Generalised osteoporosis, subarticular cysts, chondrocalcinosis and arthropathy which can mimic CPPD
CNS manifestations: White matter atrophy and T2 hyperintensities predominantly affecting the basal ganglia and thalami. T1 signal is also high in these areas, differentiating it from many of the other basal ganglia disorders. There is a classical feature of ‘sparing of the red nucleus’ leading to an appearance known as the giant panda sign at the level of the pons.
  Focal steatosis also known as focal fatty infiltration
The liver plays a small role in fat storage and subtle variation in blood supply and drainage between different areas can lead to variations in the amount of fat in those areas. Focal fatty change is very common and has a geographic appearance on all imaging modalities, with a lack of mass effect (i.e. preservation of the vascular architecture). It can occur anywhere within the liver but is classically found adjacent to the falciform ligament (i.e. segments II, III and IV). Fat-identifying sequences on MRI can be very useful to cinch the diagnosis with signal drop out on out-of-phase images. Focal fatty sparing on the other hand appears as the inverse of this and on CT will be seen as isoattenuation on a background of a diffusely hypoattenuating liver. On ultrasound the liver will be diffusely hyperechoic when compared to the right kidney, and the spared area will be hypoechoic.
  Amiodarone therapy
Amiodarone is an anti-arrhythmic drug which contains iodine (am-IOD-arone). Consequently, as it accumulates in the liver, it can cause significant increase in density to the liver on a CT scan.
GPT3_explain: The presence of low T1 signal in the liver on MRI scan and signal gain on the out of phase images is indicative of diffuse steatosis. Diffuse steatosis is a condition in which fat accumulates in the liver cells, leading to a decrease in the T1 signal. The signal gain on the out of phase images is caused by the fat protons being in different phases of the RF pulse.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the interpretation of imaging results.

Qn_Text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a painless lump near the angle of the jaw. Ultrasound scan shows a thin-walled unilocular 3cm cyst just posterior to the left submandibular gland and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The thyroid and salivary glands appear normal on the scan. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is the classic description for a second branchial cleft cyst being between the submandibular gland and the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  A first branchial cleft cyst is situated in the periparotid region.
A third branchial cleft cyst is situated at the base of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
A cystic hygroma are usually (but not exclusively) multilocular and are situated in the posterior triangle of the neck.
A thyroglossal duct cyst is usually midline or close to midline.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a second branchial cleft cyst is the most likely diagnosis for a painless lump near the angle of the jaw that is thin-walled and unilocular, as seen on the ultrasound scan. This type of cyst is typically located posterior to the left submandibular gland and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which is consistent with the findings of the scan.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the x-ray of a 38-year-old man's lumbar spine. There are concavities to the anterior surface of the vertebral bodies affecting L3 and L4. Which of the following is NOT a likely cause of this finding? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is NOT a cause.
  Anterior vertebral scalloping
There are a number of specific differential diagnoses which can lead to this finding. In each case the image should be interrogated carefully to look for further clues as to the underlying diagnosis. Scalloping is a chronic process whereby mechanical pressure on the bone causes remodelling.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Lymphadenopathy as the answer because lymphadenopathy is not a likely cause of the concavities to the anterior surface of the vertebral bodies affecting L3 and L4. Lymphadenopathy is an enlargement of the lymph nodes due to an infection or other medical condition, and would not cause the concavities observed in the x-ray.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 36-year-old man with an extensive smoking history presents with mild dyspnoea and a cough. He undergoes a CT scan which shows scattered patchy ground glass opacities in the upper lobes as well as centrilobular nodules and apical emphysematous changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is much overlap in the features of the various different fibrotic lung diseases.
Therefore, look for specific features which are most strongly associated with the different conditions.
  Respiratory Bronchiolitis Interstitial Lung disease (RBILD)
This condition is heavily associated with smoking and can be seen as centrilobular nodules with ground glass opacification – therefore, look for this trio of findings. Appearances are often very similar to desquamative interstitial pneumonia. Patients can be relatively young.
  Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HSP) also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis (EAA)
This condition is caused by a granulomatous reaction to an inhaled allergen. Consequently it is the upper zones which are most affected. A detailed history should reveal the source of an antigen e.g. malt farmer, bird fancier, proximity to air conditioners etc. On CT EAA appears as widespread patchy ground glass opacification, mosaic in nature with nodules in a centrilobular distribution. Fibrosis and consequential volume loss occurs over months-years of allergen exposure. Involvement of the pleura (including pleural effusions) is very rare which can separate this condition from many others.
  Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)
IPF (Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis) can only be diagnosed in the absence of a precipitating condition such as asbestosis, rheumatoid arthritis, or drug toxicity. Where such exists, the condition is termed UIP (Usual interstitial pneumonia). CFA (Cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis) is a historic term for the same thing. IPF is not a true differential diagnosis for cysts since the low attenuation areas seen on CT are not true cysts (no epithelial lining is present). The macrocystic honeycombing seen is merely the consequence of the fibrotic process underlying the condition. Another clue to the diagnosis of IPF lies in the distribution; there is an apicobasilar gradient with honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis affecting the lung bases and fading away superiorly.
  Histiocytosis (also known as Langerhans cell histiocytosis - LCH)
There are three separate forms of this disease:
Eosinophilic granuloma (70%) – a limited version confined to the skeleton in children or young adults. Clinically presents as fever, raised WCC and ESR with painful bony lesions. In the skull these have a typical ‘beveled edge’ or ‘hole within a hole’ appearance or can be seen as a ‘button sequestrum’. In the spine it is one of the main causes of vertebra plana.
Hand-Schüller-Christian Disease (20%) – classically a triad of destructive bony lesions, diabetes insipidus and exophthalmos. In a quarter of these patients the lungs are involved with cyst formation and spontaneous pneumothoraces possible. Nodule formation, fibrosis and honeycombing is also seen.
Letterer-Siwe Disease (10%) – a fulminant multi-organ variant affecting very young infants
  Desquamative interstitial Pneumonia - DIP
It is very difficult to distinguish DIP from RBILD; a biopsy is usually required. DIP is however, far rarer than RBILD. There is a strong association with heavy cigarette smoking. On CT it is seen as diffuse ground glass opacification (GGO) which can have a peripheral or lower lobe predominance.
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis is Subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP). This is because the CT scan findings are consistent with the characteristic findings of HP, which include patchy ground glass opacities in the upper lobes, centrilobular nodules, and apical emphysematous changes. HP is an inflammatory condition of the lungs caused by an allergic reaction to inhaled substances, such as dust, mold, or other substances. It is often seen in people with a history of smoking, which is the case in this patient.
Cat_Long: This question falls under the category of clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 6-week-old girl is referred to the hospital by the health visitor for failure to progress. She undergoes an x-ray which shows a large mass in the right upper quadrant. An ultrasound scan reveals a complex poorly-defined 10cm mass in the right lobe of the liver which contains multiple vascular channels. Which additional feature would make you consider a haemangioendothelioma the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Haemangioendothelioma
These are benign lesions which can cause elevation of the serum AFP and endothelial growth factor but the vast majority occur in babies under the age of 6 months. Around half of cases are associated with the presence of a cutaneous haemangioma. They are large vascular tumours and on imaging behave as might be expected of a haemangioma with peripheral enhancement with gradual filling in on CT and flow voids on MRI. Calcifications can be seen with these lesions but they are finer, more granular calcifications; not coarse. Owing to their size they often cause significant right to left shunting of blood resulting in congestive heart failure. Thrombocytopaenia also occurs due to platelet trapping (known as the Kasabach-Merritt sequence). N.B. these lesions should not be confused with epithelioid haemangioendotheliomas which occur in adults.
    Hepatic masses in children © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2 because presence of calcification is a common feature of haemangioendotheliomas. Calcification is often seen in these tumors, and its presence can help to differentiate them from other liver masses.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the HMPAO images from a patient who presented to his GP with a gradual decline in memory. Involvement of which of the following regions of the brain is INCORRECTLY matched to its diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
D: Sparing of hippocampi - Lewy body dementia
E: Precuneus and cingulate gyrus – Alzheimer’s disease
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which region is INCORRECTLY matched.
  Functional imaging in dementia
Tc99m-HMPAO SPECT and 18F-FDG PET produce very similar patterns when used to image patients with cognitive decline however the latter is considered to have a greater sensitivity and specificity and is therefore preferred.
Two structures bear particular importance in the imaging of dementia; the precuneus and the cingulate gyrus. Both are best appreciated on sagittal views.
Precuneus: The precuneus is located on the medial surface of each hemisphere, in the posterior parietal lobe. It has functions in motor planning, working memory and also connections to the visual pathways.
        The cingulate gyrus: The cinculate gyrus is also located on the medial side of each hemisphere and runs anteroposteriorly just above the corpus callosum. The cingulate gyrus has complex functions to do with learning, emotional response and memory.
        Alzheimer's disease
The radiological findings of this well-known disease are diffuse sulcal and ventricular enlargement. There is a disproportionate effect to the anterior temporal lobes, hippocampi and sylvian fissures with sparing of the sensorimotor and visual cortices, thalami and cerebellum. Functional studies (Tc-HMPAO SPECT or F-18 FDG PET) show reduced uptake in the precuneus, posterior cingulate gyrus, frontal and temporoparietal lobes but with characteristic sparing of the sensorimotor cortex and basal ganglia bilaterally. Importantly there is also sparing of the occipital lobes, which helps differentiate it from Lewy body dementia where the occipital lobes are involved. Other differences between the two conditions are seen with specific dopamine transporter agent imaging techniques
  Lewy body dementia
There is a generalised decrease in cerebral volume (sparing the hippocampi). Temporo-parietal hypoperfusion on HMPAO Tc99m SPECT scanning is indicative of Lewy body dementia. Involvement of the occipital cortex, which is typically spared in Alzheimer’s disease, sets the two apart from one another on PET studies. The cingulate island sign has also been ascribed to Lewy body dementia, where there is preservation of metabolism in the mid-posterior cingulate gyrus. If present, this is said to be specific for Lewy body dementia.
GPT3_explain: The occipital lobes are not typically associated with Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the loss of neurons and the formation of plaques and tangles in the hippocampus, frontal lobes, precuneus, and cingulate gyrus. Lewy body dementia is associated with the sparing of the hippocampus.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 69-year-old lady receiving palliative care for advanced breast cancer complains of worsening shortness of breath. Her CXR shows new reticular shadowing in the left lower lobe. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Lymphangitis carcinomatosis is easy to recognize on a scan but can be described in a number of different ways on paper. It occurs when tumour cells, spread via the lymphatics, accumulate in the connective tissues of the lung, in particular the interlobular septa. The classical description is as a smooth thick reticular polygonal network.
A mnemonic for the likely cancers is: Certain Cancers Spread By Plugging The Lymphatics (this is not an exclusive list). Of these Breast accounts for just over half of cases and gastric cancer accounts for most of the remainder.
Cervix
Colon
Stomach
Breast
Pancreas
Thyroid
Larynx (or lung – bronchogenic)
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because lower respiratory tract infections are the most common cause of worsening shortness of breath in a patient receiving palliative care for advanced breast cancer. In addition, the presence of new reticular shadowing in the left lower lobe on the CXR is consistent with an infection in this area.

Qn_Text: You are performing a transvaginal ultrasound scan on a 32-year-old woman who is being investigated for abnormal bleeding. The left ovary is enlarged and there are multiple small hypoechoic rounded regions around the edge of it. You are unable to visualise the right ovary due to artefact from bowel gas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
D: Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary
Explanation:
Explanation:
Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
PCOS affects around 5% of women and patients experience a broad spectrum of issues with it ranging from being completely asymptomatic through to infertility and other important gynaecological problems.
The typical patient with PCOS is overweight with impaired glucose tolerance. High blood pressure and high lipid levels may be found on blood tests and excess circulating androgen levels cause an increase in the LH to FSH ratio as well as explaining the other physical complaints of many patients such as acne and hirsutism. It should be noted that a diagnosis of PCOS should not be made on the basis of imaging findings.
Patients with PCOS often (but not always) show ovarian enlargement, each with a volume in excess of 15cm3.  There are ususally multiple small cysts within the ovaries; those which give the syndrome its name. These are the developing follicles caused by aberrations in hormone levels. They usually appear around the edge of the ovary, in a subcapsular location, as anechoic rounded cystic structures and there are typically around 5-10 per ovary at any one time but can be many more in number than this. The appearance is sometimes described as looking like a string of pearls. It should be noted however that this appearance can also be seen in otherwise normal women too.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Schomynv CC0
  Endometrial hyperplasia occurs due to high oestrogen levels and patients are at increased risk of endometrial carcinoma. When it does occur, endometrial carcinoma may arise at a younger age than the normal population (<40 years).
GPT3_explain: Retained products of conception are usually indicated by an enlarged ovary with multiple small hypoechoic rounded regions around the edge. The inability to visualize the right ovary due to artefact from bowel gas is also indicative of a retained product of conception.

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old man complains to his GP of severe odynophagia. You are asked to perform a barium swallow to aid diagnosis. The oesophagus is abnormal and you suspect the patient may have Barrett oesophagitis. The presence of which of the following would support your diagnosis?
A: A reticular mucosal pattern to the distal oesophagus
B: Irregular longitudinal plaques in the upper half of the oesophagus
C: A solitary large ulcer in the distal oesophagus
D: Multiple small ulcers each surrounded by a radiolucent halo
E: An ulcer in the mid oesophagus at the aortic impression
Explanation:
Explanation:
Barrett oesophagus
Metaplasia of the usual squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium as a result of reflux is termed Barrett oesophagus and predisposes the patient to developing adenocarcinoma. It affects the distal oesophagus adjacent to the gastro-oesophageal junction. Long strictures can develop and on a barium swallow the mucosa appears to have a reticular pattern. Tertiary contractions may also be seen.
  Oesophagitis
Inflammation of the oesophagus usually presents with severe pain on swallowing (odynophagia). There are many different aetiologies but there are a few features which can help separate the differential diagnoses on imaging.
Aetiology
Features
Candidiasis
Immunocompromised patients (including long term steroid therapy)
Upper half of the oesophagus
Irregular, longitudinal plaques with normal mucosa in between
Fulminant candidiasis
Patients with AIDs
Shaggy outline from a pseudomembrane of joined-together plaques
Herpes simplex
Immunocompromised patients
Flu-like symptoms
Multiple small ulcers, each may have a halo of oedema
CMV / HIV oesophagitis
One large ulcer
These two are indistinguishable from one another by appearance
Caustic
Ingestion of corrosive substance
Affects middle and lower thirds
Progression from oedema to ulceration to scarring over days
Barrett oesophagitis
Columnar metaplasia of distal oesophagus in response to reflux
Long strictures
Reticular mucosal pattern
Drug-induced
Ulcers at sites of extrinsic compression in the mid oesophagus
Patients taking medication without enough water immediately prior to going to bed
Idiopathic eosinophilic oesophagitis
History of atopy usually present
Specific ring-like indentations to the oesophagus
  Glycogen acanthosis
This condition is caused by benign age-related squamous hyperplasia but, based on its imaging features, a differential diagnosis for candidiasis. On a barium swallow there will be small rounded white plaques in a random distribution, predominantly affecting the middle and upper oesophagus. Patients are typically middle aged or elderly.
  Intramural pseudodiverticulosis
This is a feature of candidal oesophagitis. Tiny diverticulae are found scattered along the length of the oesophagus and on a barium swallow the appearance can be quite impressive! Like most candidal infections oesophagitis is most common in patients with suppressed immunity including patients with diabetes, on steroids, or chemotherapy.
GPT3_explain: I chose 1, 3, and 5 because they are all symptoms that are associated with Barrett oesophagitis. Irregular longitudinal plaques in the upper half of the oesophagus, multiple small ulcers each surrounded by a radiolucent halo, and an ulcer in the mid oesophagus at the aortic impression are all indicative of the condition.
