Qn_Text: A 39-year-old woman presents with recurrent right upper quadrant pain. Ultrasound demonstrates a solid 3 cm lesion in the liver which is mostly hypoechoic. Areas of increased reflectivity with posterior acoustic shadowing are demonstrated within the lesion. The background liver appears normal and the AFP is also normal. What is the LEAST likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely option.
The description of a solid lesion (albeit hypoechoic) discounts a liver cyst. A solid lesion does not cause posterior acoustic enhancement; this is a feature which is characteristic of a liver cyst.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Liver cyst because it is the least likely diagnosis. Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a rare type of liver cancer that usually presents with a single large tumor, whereas hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common type of liver cancer and usually presents with multiple smaller tumors. Breast cancer and melanoma metastases are usually seen as multiple lesions, and they can also contain areas of increased reflectivity with posterior acoustic shadowing. A liver cyst is usually a single, anechoic lesion with a smooth wall and no internal echoes, which is not consistent with the patient's ultrasound findings.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 21-year-old woman complains to her GP of dyspareunia. On examination she has a soft mass in the palpable anteriorly in the upper part of the vagina. She goes on to have an MRI scan and the mass returns high signal on T2 weighted sequences with low signal on T1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Anatomy is the key to differentiating between the various female urogenital cysts most of which are, for the most part, asymptomatic incidental findings.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  Gartner duct cyst
These are usually found incidentally on MRI scans but can cause dyspareunia.  They do not communicate with the urethra and would be unlikely to cause post-void dribbling. They are remnants of the Wolffian ducts and occur superiorly in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. On imaging they appear straightforwardly cystic. For the most part they occur sporadically but they can also be seen in conjunction with renal agenesis or ectopia and are also typical of a rare condition called Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome. This condition causes duplication of all or part of the female genital tract with unilateral haematometrocolpos and ipsilateral renal agenesis. 
  Urethral diverticulum also known as urethrocoele
Dysuria, dyspareunia and post-void dribbling are classical for this condition. An outpouching of the urethral mucosa protrudes through the smooth muscle. This is seen on MRI as high T2 signal adjacent to or surrounding the urethra. Urinary stasis within the diverticulum predisposes patients to the formation of calculi, which can be seen as low signal on the T2 scan, and adenocarcinoma which will enhance with gadolinium.
  Skene duct cyst
These are retention cysts of the paraurethral ducts and usually they are asymptomatic. On MRI they are seen inferior to the pubic symphysis but lateral to the external urethral meatus. Signal characteristics reflect their cystic nature with high T2 signal but fluid-fluid levels may also be present if there has been intracystic haemorrhage.
  Bartholin gland cyst
The bartholin glands secrete lubricating fluid into the inferior third of the vagina. They are found in highest numbers at the posterolateral aspect of the inferior vagina. Although usually asymptomatic, when infected or inflamed a Bartholin gland cyst can present as a painful lump. On MRI they show as high T1 signal owing to the mucoid fluid.
  Nabothian cyst
These are tiny (few millimetres) mucous retention cysts located on the cervix. They are reasonably common but largely asymptomatic. They appear straightforwardly cystic on MRI.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Bartholin gland cysts are the most common cause of dyspareunia in young women. They are usually located in the upper part of the vagina anteriorly, which is consistent with the patient's symptoms and exam findings. MRI scans of Bartholin gland cysts typically show high signal on T2 weighted sequences and low signal on T1, which is also consistent with the patient's results.

Qn_Text: A 20-year-old man attends a urology outpatient clinic having failed initial therapies for the management of his dysuria. He is scheduled for a cystoscopy which is normal and undergoes an MRI of the pelvis. This shows a Mullerian duct cyst. Which of the following features is useful in differentiating a Mullerian duct cyst from a utricle cyst in this patient? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Anatomy plays a strong role in the correct diagnosis of male genitourinary tract cysts. It is first necessary to differentiate between intraprostatic cysts and extraprostatic cysts.
  Mullerian duct cyst (intraprostatic)
These are usually found in young adult men and are also caused by incomplete regression of the Mullerian duct. They have numerous similarities with prostatic utricle cysts, including an association with renal agenesis (although not with intersex disorders). Anatomically they are also posterior to the bladder however unlike prostatic utricle cysts they extend superiorly to the prostate and do not communicate with the urethra. On MRI they appear straightforwardly cystic unless complicated by infection. The shape of the cyst is said to be teardrop shaped rather than the pear-shaped prostatic utricle cysts.
    Mullerian duct cyst Prostatic utricle cyst
Age 20-40 years 0-20 years
Shape Teardrop Pear
Extends above prostate? Yes No
Communicates with prostatic urethra? No Yes
  Prostatic utricle cyst (intraprostatic)
These are found in teenagers or adolescents and represent incomplete regression of the Mullerian duct system during embryological development. They are found posterior to the bladder, within the prostate, and do not extend any more superiorly than the superior most aspect of the prostate. This anatomical detail and the fact that the cyst does communicate with the prostatic urethra sets it apart from a Mullerian duct cyst on imaging. They can cause all manner of lower urinary tract symptoms and boast an association with ipsilateral renal agenesis as well as intersex disorders. On MRI they are said to have a pear-shaped appearance.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a Mullerian duct cyst is typically found in the intraprostatic location, meaning it is located within the prostate. A utricle cyst, on the other hand, is usually located in the distal urethra and typically has a connection to the urethra. The age of the patient and the signal intensity of the cyst on MRI do not help to differentiate between the two types of cysts.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old lady is being investigated for primary subfertility. She has had four early miscarriages. She undergoes a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) which shows an abnormality. She goes on to have an MRI scan for further clarification. There are two separate uterine cavities the limbs of which are widely divergent and there is a prominent fundal cleft with a depth of at least 2cm. Two separate cervices and vaginal cavities can be seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Mullerian duct anomalies (MDA)
The two Mullerian ducts form separately then fuse in the first trimester to form all the structures between the upper vagina and the fallopian tubes. The final part of the amalgamation of the two sides is resorption of the central uterine septum. There are various classification systems the scope of which is subspecialist. The following is provided for a gross overview only. Different anomalies occur depending on when during development the disruption to normality occurred.
      Aplasia/hypoplasia anomalies
Class I – Agenesis or hypoplasia:
Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is an extreme subtype where there is complete aplasia of the upper third of the vagina and uterus. The fallopian tubes and ovaries will be seen normally. Primary amenorrhoea is the usual presentation.
Class II – Unicornuate: Banana like configuration of the remaining horn
  Fusion anomalies
Class III - Didelphys: Non-fusion, two separate uterine horns, two separate cervices. All of the walls contain all of the layers of the normal uterus. The uterine cavities do not communicate with one another owing to the presence of a vaginal septum.
Class IV – Bicornuate: partial fusion, the septum separating the two horns consists of myometrium. There can be either one or two cervices depending on the degree of fusion but crucially the two uterine cavities do communicate with one another. Sometimes the appearance of a bicornuate uterus is referred to as ‘heart-shaped’. In a quarter of cases a longitudinal vaginal septum means that the case is easily confused with a didelphys anomaly.
  Reabsorption (of uterine septum) anomalies
Class V – Septate: partial fusion, a fibrous remnant septum remains. This is the most common anomaly presenting as infertility.
Class VI – Arcuate: a mild form of septate uterus but which is not associated with subfertility.
The crucial diagnosis to make is that of a septate uterus. Patients with a septate uterus can present with recurrent mid-term miscarriages due to implantation on the suboptimally vascularised septum. Surgical resection of this septum can significantly improve fertility chances. Distinguishing between didelphys and bicollis bicornuate uteri can be very challenging and is beyond the scope of this text.
There is no association with abnormalities of the external genitalia or ovaries since these derive from different embryological components but renal anomalies (agenesis, ectopia, fusion) can be found in around a third of patients and should be actively sought. Infertility is the primary clinical consequence of an MDA.
  Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
HSGs are performed in the setting of infertility to confirm or refute tubal patency. It is not the ideal modality to diagnose MDAs since it provides information only on the internal contours of any patent cavities. Historically the intercornual angle was used to differentiate between a septate uterus (<75o) and a bicornuate or didelphys uterus (>105o) but this is no longer considered reliable. In addition an HSG will overlook obstructed hemisystems or functional remnants which do not communicate with the vagina.
  Ultrasound
Differentiating between fusion anomalies (bicornuate and didelphys) and reabsorption anomalies (septate and arcuate) depends on the fundal contour. Usually this can be well seen on ultrasound. Where there has been a failure of complete fusion a fundal cleft remains. This should be at least 1cm deep. If the patient has a septate or arcuate uterus then fusion is complete so the fundus will be domed as is normal. A normal dome is greater than 5 mm high.
  MRI
MRI is considered the gold standard for evaluating cases of MDA. The presence of menstrual blood products within an obstructed hemi uterus is, where present, readily seen as high signal on T1. Where a patient has two cervices these can be seen appearing like two ‘owl eyes’ when imaged axially to the vagina.
  Diethylstilbestrol (DES) exposure
DES was an artificial oestrogen used to treat women suffering from recurrent miscarriages. Owing to an association with clear cell carcinoma of the vagina and cervix its use was halted in the 1970s. It also caused shortening of the upper segment of the uterus which gave rise to a very characteristic T-shaped uterine cavity as seen on HSG. This was classed as a Class VII type of MDA.
Pertinent points:
Renal agenesis, ectopia and fusion present in 33% of patients
Aplastic uterus + normal fallopian tubes and ovaries = MRKH syndrome
Widely divergent horns + fundal cleft = fusion anomaly (didelphys or bicornuate)
Two cervices also known as owl eyes on MRI = either didelphys or bicollis bicornuate (difficult to tell them apart)
No communication between two uterine horns = didelphys
Domed fundus = reabsorption anomaly (Septate or arcuate)
Recurrent midterm miscarriages can be due to septate uterus and can be surgically resected to improve fertility.
GPT3_explain: I chose 2, Bicornuate unicollis uterus, as the most likely diagnosis because this is the most common abnormality seen on an MRI scan of the uterus in cases of primary subfertility. The characteristics described in the question are consistent with bicornuate unicollis uterus, which is characterized by two separate uterine cavities, widely divergent limbs, and a prominent fundal cleft with a depth of at least 2cm. Furthermore, bicornuate unicollis uterus is associated with recurrent miscarriages, which is consistent with this patient's history.

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old woman presents to her GP with weight loss, and diarrhoea. She is referred for a gastroenterological opinion and undergoes both an OGD and a colonoscopy. When this fails to demonstrate an underlying colonic malignancy or foregut malignancy a CT scan is requested. The CT scan shows multiple enlarged low attenuation lymph nodes throughout the abdomen. There are fat-fluid levels within the nodes. With the exception of an atrophic spleen the remainder of the scan is normal.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Differential diagnosis for lymph nodes of low attenuation
Coeliac disease – cavitating mesenteric lymph node syndrome
Tuberculosis
Whipple disease
Lymphoma
Necrotic metastases
  Within the differential diagnosis for lymph nodes of low attenuation, the presence of fat-fluid levels is a reasonably specific sign for cavitating mesenteric lymph node syndrome.
  Coeliac disease
Luminal sensitivity to gluten leads to autoimmune mediated atrophy of villi within the small bowel. Iron deficiency anaemia, malabsorption and deficiency of the fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K) result. Classically on imaging there is jejunisation of the ileum (ie an increased number of ileal folds and a decreased number of jejunal folds) which is a reasonably specific sign to coeliac disease. Importantly however the fold thickness is not increased, in contrast to many of the possible differential diagnoses. On historic fluoroscopic examinations flocculation, segmentation are supposed to be typical and result from hypersecretion of fluid however modern barium preparations are less susceptible to these effects. The moulage sign (complete loss of jejunal folds such that the bowel wall appears smooth) is also quoted. A rare complication is cavitating mesenteric lymph node syndrome where lymph nodes within the small bowel mesentry show low attenuation on CT and characteristically have fat-fluid levels. In such cases the spleen may also be atrophic.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the CT scan findings are most consistent with necrotic lymph node metastases. The presence of multiple enlarged low attenuation lymph nodes with fat-fluid levels suggests that the nodes have necrotic material within them, which is a common finding in metastatic disease. The absence of other findings on the CT scan such as enlarged organs or masses also supports the diagnosis of metastatic disease.

Qn_Text: A 68-year-old woman undergoes a CT scan of her adrenal glands for an incidental lesion picked up on a CT colonogram. The lesion is situated in the lateral limb of the left adrenal gland and is 2cm in diameter. It measures 20HU on the unenhanced sequence, 75HU on the portal venous phase and 38HU on the delayed sequences. You may use a calculator. What is the absolute washout of this lesion?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Figures have been rounded to the nearest whole number.
Absolute washout = (75-38)/(75-20) = 67%
Relative washout = (75-38)/75 = 49%
    This lesion is a benign adrenal adenoma. In many centres, if the lesion measures less than 10HU on the unenhanced sequence then the study will be terminated at that point.
  Adrenal washout
Washout characteristics of adrenal nodules help confirm or refute a diagnosis of an adrenal adenoma. The absolute washout takes into account the initial uptake of contrast whereas the relative washout calculation is based only on how well contrast washes out of a nodule.
The underpinning principle is that vasculature within malignant lesions is more permeable than in benign lesions. This allows contrast to diffuse out of the lesion during the portal venous phase and the contrast is then slower to wash out during the delayed phase than it would be for benign lesions. Thus the higher/faster washout characteristics (either absolute or relative) the more suggestive it is that a lesion is benign.
    Adrenal adenoma
These present a diagnostic challenge if only to rule out a malignant adrenal mass. Once the diagnosis is confirmed they can then be left alone and do not require any further imaging. The majority are obvious on CT and obviously adenomas. Owing to their high fat content most adenomas show low Hounsfield units (HU) an HU <18 on an unenhanced study has a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 100%.
In cases where the fat content is insufficient to make the diagnosis an adrenal protocol CT can be performed. This compares the HU on an unenhanced scan, a portal venous phase scan and a 15 minute delayed phase scan. From these values the absolute washout can be calculated by comparing the difference between the two contrast studies with the amount of contrast taken up in the first place (i.e. the difference between the portal venous phase and the unenhanced phase). The relative washout is calculated by comparing the difference between the two contrast studies to just the portal venous phase (i.e. it is relative to the portal venous phase).
An alternative diagnostic strategy which, but for demand management, is better for patients as far as dose preservation is concerned, is an MRI scan. The fat content of adrenal adenomas shows up well as signal loss on out-of-phase imaging and gives a chemical shift artefact in the frequency encoding direction on both gradient echo and spin echo sequences.  On gradient echo sequences due to the chemical shift a black line appears in all directions and is termed the India Ink effect or etching artefact.
  Diagnostic of adrenal adenoma:
At least 60% absolute washout
At least 40% relative washout
<18 HU (100% specific)
<37 HU on a delayed scan
India ink effect on GE MRI
Chemical shift on GE and SE MRI
GPT3_explain: The absolute washout of this lesion is calculated by subtracting the HU value on the delayed sequences from the HU value on the portal venous phase and dividing it by the HU value on the portal venous phase. In this case, 75-38=37 and 37/75=0.49, which is 49%.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 4-year-old girl. There is a large mass arising from the upper pole of the right kidney. It is well circumscribed and heterogenous with multiple cystic areas. You can see that it is invading the renal pelvis and renal vein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Renal masses by age
Neonate
Multicystic dysplastic kidney
Second most common neonatal renal mass
Mesoblastic nephroma
Most common SOLID neonatal renal mass
Nephroblastomatosis
Can be a precursor to WIlms tumour
Pre-school
Nultilocular cystic nephroma
Affects boys, slightly younger than Wilms
Wilms tumour
Most common SOLID mass of childhood
Lymphoma
Can affect teenagers and adults as well
  Wilms tumour also known as a nephroblastoma
This is the most common abdominal mass in children under the age of 8. There are reasonably strong associations with renal anomalies, genital anomalies, aniridia and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (although the last of these also has an association with neuroblastoma). Presentation is usually with an abdominal mass and/or pain.
  10% tumour – Wilms
Calcification
Vascular invasion
Bilateral
Lung metastases
Poor histology
  On imaging the masses are usually heterogenous. Cystic areas can often be seen secondary to areas of necrosis. The claw sign occurs when there is a rim of normal renal tissue extending part of the way around the mass. A Wilms tumour is often described as enhancing but less so than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma.
  Neuroblastoma
This is the most common solid abdominal mass in infants and second most common in children of all ages (after Wilms tumours). Most are adrenal in location, around a third develop in the retroperitoneum and a fifth are located in the posterior mediastinum. Presentation can be with abdominal pain, a mass, or a fever. Most (95%) secrete catecholamines such as VMA (vanillylmandelic acid – leads to hypertension) or VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptides – leads to watery diarrhoea). There are also a few distinct clinical syndromes which herald the presence of a neuroblastoma.
  Syndrome
Details
Blueberry muffin syndrome
Metastatic cutaneous deposits
Opsomyoclonus
Rapid jerky eye movements and myoclonic jerks of the legs. This occurs in around 2% of neuroblastoma cases but around 50% of patients with opsomyoclonus have a neuroblastoma.
Hutchinson syndrome
Limping due to bony metastases
  On imaging they appear as a very large abdominal mass with or without speckled calcification within in. The kidney can either be invaded or just displaced inferiorly, causing a ‘drooping lily’ appearance on urography (where contrast within the inferiorly displaced renal calyces has the appearance of a lily flower with its head hanging down). Neuroblastomas tend to encase large vessels such as the IVC, as opposed to displacing them as Wilms tumours are prone to doing. Staging is performed with an 123I-MIBG scan (as opposed to a 99mTc-MDP bone scan) and importantly within the staging it is actually stage IVs (disease involving the skin, bone marrow and liver) which has the best prognosis.
  Feature
Neuroblastoma
Wilms tumour
Peak age
2 years
3-4 years
Kidney
Drooping lily sign – displaced downwards, if not invaded.
Claw sign – rim of normal renal tissue extending around the mass
Crosses midline
More common
Less common
Calcification
More common
Regular and stippled
Less common
Curvilinear and phleobliths
IVC
Encases
Displaces and/or invades
  Multicystic dysplastic kidney
A Multicystic Dysplastic kidney is the second most common cause of a neonatal abdominal mass. The normal renal architecture is entirely replaced by a non-functioning mass of cysts separated from one another by fibrous tissue. The overall appearance is said to resemble a bunch of grapes. If unilateral, the condition can be asymptomatic or can present as recurrent urinary tract infections. The most important distinction to make is from hydronephrosis which is overall the most common cause of a neonatal abdominal mass. In hydronephrosis the apparent 'cysts' will communicate whereas in multicystic dysplastic kidney the cysts are separate from one another.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of ColnKurtz CC BY-SA 4.0
  Mesoblastic nephroma
This is the most common solid mass in a neonate and 90% of them are diagnosed within the first year of life. Presentation is usually as an abdominal mass. On ultrasound there will be a large hypoechoic renal mass which cannot clearly be separated from the normal renal parenchyma. Pertinent negative imaging features of note are the lack of invasion into the collecting system and lack of venous invasion, the latter in particular helps to differentiate it from a WIlms tumour.
  Multilocular cystic nephroma
There are two age peaks for this tumour; one at around age 4 which affects mostly boys and and one at around age 40 which affects mostly women. In young boys the most common presentation is of a painless abdominal mass with or without other features such as haematuria and urinary tract infections. On ultrasound there will be a mass of cysts but importantly they will be surrounded by a thick fibrous capsule. Protrusion into the renal pelvis is also a key finding, but this is also seen in some WIlms tumours. There shouldn't be a solid component to this mass but enhancement of the septae separating the cysts may be seen on cross-sectional imaging.
GPT3_explain: Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is the most common type of kidney tumor in children. It is usually found in the upper pole of the kidney, is typically well-circumscribed and heterogenous with multiple cystic areas, and often invades the renal pelvis and renal vein. The other listed diagnoses are not typically associated with this type of presentation.

Qn_Text: An 84-year-old man undergoes a nuclear medicine bone scan for what his GP thinks is bone pain. There is uptake in the ribs, sternum, skull, left femur and pelvis. The reporting radiologist requests x-rays for comparison. What is the LEAST likely appearance of his pelvic xray?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely option.
Superscan
The technetium 99m diphosphate used in bone scans is usually excreted renally and thus uptake in both kidneys should be seen. If, however, there is a diffuse skeletal process taking up the tracer then a superscan appearance can be seen. The kidneys are conspicuous by their absence and all or most of the rest of the skeleton demonstrates very high uptake.
Sclerotic lesions may suggest particularly prostate metastases or myelofibrosis.
Mastocytosis can give both sclerotic and lucent areas.
Paget disease can give both sclerotic and lucent areas with coarsening of the trabeculae.
Osteopenia might be seen with renal osteodystrophy and osteomalacia.
  Superscan
Metastatic cancer (Prostate, Breast, TCC, lymphoma)
Renal osteodystrophy
Osteomalacia
Myelofibrosis
Mastocytosis
Paget disease
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Lucent because a nuclear medicine bone scan is used to detect abnormalities in the bones, such as tumors, fractures, or infections. In this case, the scan revealed uptake in the ribs, sternum, skull, left femur and pelvis, suggesting that there may be an abnormality in the pelvic bones. X-rays are used to further examine the bones and determine the exact cause of the abnormality. Lucent is not likely to be the appearance of the pelvic x-ray because it indicates normal bone density, which is not likely in the presence of an abnormality.

Qn_Text: An 8-month-old girl is referred by the health visitor with developmental delay and regression. Her head size is normal but an MRI demonstrates diffuse white matter abnormalities with a stripey ‘tigroid’ appearance. An MR SPECT study reveals a normal NAA peak What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This distribution is classical for Metachromatic leukodystrophy which is the most common leukodystrophy and gives a ‘tigroid’ appearance.
Adrenoleukodystrophy usually affects older children around 5-10 years and occurs only in boys; demyelination usually commences in the occipital lobes, progressing anteriorly.
Canavans disease is associated with an elevated NAA peak and macrocephaly in a child under 12 months of age; the pattern of involvement is also more classically diffuse, particularly affecting the subcortical U-fibres.
Alexander disease affects children less than one, who also classically have an enlarged head, but the pattern of distribution is usually localised to the frontal white matter.
Fabry disease is an X-linked multisystem disorder that neurologically presents in adults with diffuse white matter T2 hyperintensity and small vessel disease.
GPT3_explain: Canavan disease is a rare, inherited, degenerative neurological disorder that is most commonly seen in infants and young children. It is characterized by the progressive destruction of myelin, the fatty insulation that surrounds and protects nerve fibers in the brain. The MRI findings in Canavan disease are typically described as "diffuse white matter abnormalities with a stripey 'tigroid' appearance," which is the same description given in the question. Additionally, an MR SPECT study of Canavan disease typically reveals a normal NAA peak, which is also consistent with the information provided. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Canavan disease.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 13-year-old girl who was taken by her mother to the GP with a breast lump. On examination there is a small lump on the left side measuring approximately 2cm in diameter. The ultrasound shows this to be oval with some slight posterior acoustic shadowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Posterior acoustic shadowing occurs in fibroadenomas but is usually florid if present, owing to the presence of the classical popcorn calcification. By contrast, a breast cyst would produce posterior acoustic enhancement.
At this age the most likely diagnosis, given the description, is asymmetry of the breast tissue. Fat necrosis, a common finding in this age group, could also give a similar appearance.
  Fibroadenoma
Popcorn calcification is pathognomonic of a fibroadenoma. They tend to be nodular or lobulated in contour but with smooth margins. They often show a ‘halo’ sign of low attenuation where tissue surrounding the lesion has been compressed. Patients are usually relatively young; 20s or 30s.
  A phyllodes tumour 
These would typically be described as having a similar appearance to a fibroadenoma. They would usually appear as a lobulated round hypoechoic mass with ill-defined borders and a posterior acoustic shadow. Occasionally they can demonstrate a ‘halo’ sign. Patients are usually middle aged, slightly older than those with a fibroadenoma.
  Galactocoele
A galactocoele appears during lactation as an enlarging painless mass. A fat-fluid level is a specific finding on a lateral view. These lesions would be far more likely to be ultrasound diagnoses than mammographic. They can have a variety of appearances, ranging from cystic with internal debris, to solid appearing masses. Posterior acoustic is an important feature which suggests a fluid component to the mass. Diagnosis is typically confirmed by aspirating milk from the lesion.
GPT3_explain: Fibroadenomas are the most common benign breast lumps found in adolescent girls. The ultrasound findings of an oval shaped lump with slight posterior acoustic shadowing are consistent with a fibroadenoma. Galactocoele, Phyllodes tumours, and cysts are not typically found in adolescent girls, and asymmetric breast tissue is not typically associated with a mass. Therefore, fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 10-year-old girl is referred by her GP to the paediatric services. Her mother has visited the GP surgery multiple times in the last two months, concerned that her daughters knees are swollen and stiff when she wakes up in the morning. On examination the girl’s temperature is 37.5oC, her knees are both slightly swollen and tender with a reduced range of movement bilaterally. An x-ray is requested which shows soft tissue swelling, juxta-articular osteopenia and periosteal reactions affecting both knees. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis, (JIA) previously juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA)
This is very similar to rheumatoid arthritis but occurs in patients below the age of 16. Patients present with joint stiffness and pains on waking. Fever and lymph node enlargement are also common. Technically, symptoms must have been present for at least six weeks for the diagnosis to be made. Unlike rheumatoid arthritis it is the large joints which are affected early on with subsequent involvement of the little joints of the hands and feet. On x-ray there will be periarticular osteoporosis but the increased perfusion of the epiphyses as a result of inflammation leads to overgrowth, early fusion and overall bone shortening. Erosions and destruction of the joint can be severe, even resembling a neuropathic joint.
  Legg-Calve-Perthes disease
Avascular necrosis of the femoral head can occur spontaneously, particularly in young (2-12 years, although usually 4-8 years) Caucasian boys. It is named Legg-Calve-Perthes disease and often referred to only as Perthes disease. Avascular necrosis of the femoral head secondary to sickle cell disease, leukaemia or steroid use is not technically Perthes disease.
  Sign
Incidence
>50%
Smaller femoral epiphysis
Sclerosis of femoral epiphysis
Soft tissue line changes
Widening of joint space (effusion)
96%
82%
73%
60%
<50%
Ipsilateral demineralisation
Radiolucent crescent line (subchondral fracture)
46%
32%
  Perthes disease is best appreciated on a frog-leg lateral view and this view must always be included in a series when investigating for the disease and the disease should always be considered in patients presenting with a painful limp. Of the early changes, ipsilateral demineralisation is the least consistent with Perthes disease. The presence of a radiolucent crescent shaped subchondral fracture has an even lower incidence but is also not seen until late on in the disease. The goal of imaging is to identify patients early before they reach this stage.
On MRI there will be a ‘double-line’ sign on T2 with sclerotic/necrotic bone returning little signal but the granulation tissue returning high signal. The bone marrow becomes low on T1 and high on T2.
  Transient synovitis of the hip
This is the most common cause of an acute limp in a child and is usually preceded by a viral infection such as an upper respiratory tract infection. Patients may have a low-grade fever and around half have an elevated serum ESR but characteristically the x-rays will be normal with the possible exception of a joint effusion. The usual age-range is 5-10-year-olds.
  Septic arthritis
Septic arthritis in any age group is a surgical emergency and the joint must be washed out as soon as feasible in order to avoid irreversible joint damage caused. Clinical suspicious must therefore be high, not least because early x-rays may be normal. Initial investigation should be with ultrasound and echogenic debris may be found within a joint effusion. The diagnosis is confirmed by aspiration of purulent joint fluid. The condition can also be readily appreciable on MRI which is very sensitive for early joint damage. Synovial oedema can be seen as high signal on T2 with enhancement post-gadolinium on T1 fat saturated sequences.
Age
Likely organism
Neonate
Group D strep
<4yrs
Haemophilus, Strep, staph aureus
>4yrs
Staph aureus
>10yrs
Staph aureus + Neisseria gonorrhoea
Adults
Staph aureus
  Osteoid osteoma
These are small benign tumours but which can be quite symptomatic, classically with pain relieved by aspirin. The majority form in the diaphyses of long bones but the posterior elements of the spine is another classic location.
The radiolucent nidus and symptoms of night pain in a young patient point to either an osteoid osteoma or an osteoblastoma. The final diagnosis comes down to size. <1.5 cm is definitely an osteoid osteoma, and >2 cm is definitely an osteoblastoma. There is a nasty grey area somewhere between the two sizes.
On x-ray the radiolucent nidus may not be fully appreciated and the abnormality which is picked up will be the consequential sclerotic solid periosteal reaction. In the spine there may be a painful scoliosis concave towards the lesion as a result of adjacent muscular spasm. CT is used to confirm the diagnosis as the nidus is readily appreciable.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the symptoms the girl is experiencing - swollen and stiff knees, soft tissue swelling, juxta-articular osteopenia, and periosteal reactions - are all indicative of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). JIA is a type of chronic inflammatory arthritis that affects children and is characterized by persistent joint pain and swelling. The x-ray results are also consistent with a diagnosis of JIA.

Qn_Text: Which of the following features suggests a diagnosis of IgG4 related pseudotumour over Graves' disease? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Distinguishing between Graves’ eye disease and IgG4 related disease should be relatively simple.
The mnemonic for remembering the order in which the eye muscles are affected in Graves’ eye disease is: I’M SLow (Inferior, Medial, Superior, Lateral). Otherwise the following table compares the features of the two conditions.
IgG4 related disease is a relatively newly developed concept with a number of radiological avenues.
  Graves’ Eye Disease Orbital pseudotumour (IgG4 related disease)
Involves ONLY muscle, not tendons or other structures Involves anything within the orbit; lacrimal gland, tendons → any part of the eye
Unilateral or bilateral Usually unilateral
No intraorbital fat stranding (until late) Intraorbital fat stranding
Painless Painful
  Multiple associations including retroperitoneal fibrosis
Does respond to steroids Responds dramatically to steroids
Slow onset Sudden onset
GPT3_explain: Bilateral involvement is a key feature of IgG4 related pseudotumour, as it typically affects both sides of the body symmetrically. This is in contrast to Graves' disease, which usually affects only one side.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the images of a 21-year-old man who has suffered a wrist fracture following a fall. Aside from the fracture you also notice that all of the bones included in the films appear densely sclerotic. The medullary cavity is not visible on the images. A previous view of his lumbar spine reveals a bone-within-a-bone appearance to the vertebra. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Osteopetrosis
This is a disease of abnormal osteoclastic activity which leads to thick, sclerotic bone throughout the skeleton. Although appearing very solid on an x-ray, the bone is very disorganised structurally and consequently very brittle. Patients may experience numerous fractures throughout their lives. There is an autosomal dominant form which does not impede life expectancy but the autosomal recessive form carries are poorer prognosis with death due to complications of bone marrow failure (infections, leukaemia or haemorrhage) before adulthood.
On x-ray there is a generalised increase in bone density and films should be carefully evaluated for the presence of a pathological fracture. A bone-within-a-bone appearance is typical of the autosomal dominant form and there may be alternating lines of sclerosis and lucency in the phalanges.
Osteopetrosis
Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Stevenfruitsmaak CC BY-SA 2.0
  Pyknodysostosis
This disorder is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion and causes diffuse bony sclerosis. Patients are of short stature and often have a typical facies; there is usually frontal bossing despite delayed closure of the cranial sutures, small mandibular size and beaking of the nose. Additionally patients have short stubby fingers, the nails of which may be hypoplastic. It can be difficult to tell pyknodysostosis from osteopetrosis however the medullary cavity is still discernible in the case of pyknodysostosis. Patients with osteopetrosis also do not tend to suffer from short stature or mandibular involvement.
Osteopoikilosis
This benign condition leads to multiple small oval bone islands forming around the skeleton. Purportedly, once the epiphyses have fused the number remains static. They can show mildly increased uptake on a nuclear medicine bone scan. Whereas a bone island may exist in isolation or near isolation, the finding of multiple such lesions suggests the diagnosis of osteopoikilosis.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Hellerhoff CC BY-SA 3.0
  Osteopathia striata
This disease is more similar to osteopoikilosis than the other bony dysplasias. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, but can arise sporadically too. It causes striking longitudinal striations in the metaphyseal regions of the long bones but patients are generally asymptomatic and it is usually therefore an incidental finding. The appearance is said to resemble stalks of celery.
Melorrheostosis
This dysplasia gives a classical appearance said to resemble the dripping of solid candle wax along a bone. The name comes from greek words meaning 'flowing' and 'limb'. It can be asymptomatic but if there is encroachment on nerves or joints patients may present with pain and movement limitations. Uniquely for a dysplasia, it can cross from one bone to the next across a joint, sometimes causing fusion in the process. On imaging the affected 'dripping' areas are seen as slcerotic areas within the affected bones. It usually only affects one limb of the patient but changes can be seen in more than one bone of that limb (i.e. monomelic but polyostotic).
GPT3_explain: Osteopetrosis is a rare genetic disorder that results in bones that are abnormally dense and thickened, which is consistent with the description of the patient's bones in the images. Additionally, the bone-within-a-bone appearance of the lumbar spine is a classic radiographic finding of osteopetrosis. In contrast, osteopathia striata, pyknodysostosis, and melorheostosis are all characterized by thin, fragile bones, which is not consistent with the description of the patient's bones in the images. Osteopoikilosis is a benign condition characterized by small, rounded sclerotic lesions in the bones, which is also not consistent with the description of the patient's bones in the images.

Qn_Text: Which of the following structures is drained by the coeliac lymph nodes? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The abdominal lymph nodes can be broadly divided into pre-aortic and para-aortic groups, depending upon their relationship to the aorta.
The pre-aortic nodes lie anterior to the aorta and lie around the origins of the visceral (anterior) arteries. They drain the gastrointestinal tract and its accessory viscera (liver, spleen and pancreas). These nodes can be further divided into three groups, each lying near to the origins of their respective artery:
Coeliac lymph nodes
Superior mesenteric lymph nodes
Inferior mesenteric lymph nodes
  All of the efferent lymphatics from the pre-aortic nodes drain into the intestinal trunk, which in turn drains into the cisterna chlyi.
The structures drained by each of these groups is summarized in the table below:
Group Structures drained
Coeliac lymph nodes
Stomach
Most of the duodenum
Liver and biliary tree
Pancreas
Spleen
Superior mesenteric lymph nodes
Part of the duodenum
Jejunum and ileum
Caecum and appendix
Ascending colon
Transverse colon
Inferior mesenteric lymph nodes
Descending colon
Sigmoid colon
Upper rectum
  Arrangement of the abdominal lymph nodes (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3, Jejunum, because the coeliac lymph nodes drain the jejunum, which is the middle portion of the small intestine. The coeliac lymph nodes are located near the celiac artery and vein, which supply blood to the jejunum. The coeliac lymph nodes help to filter lymph fluid from the jejunum and other nearby organs and tissues.

Qn_Text: Which of the following combine to form the ampulla of Vater? Select ONE answer only.
A: The common bile duct and the pancreatic duct
B: The common bile duct and the cystic duct
C: The common hepatic duct and the cystic duct
D: The common hepatic duct and the pancreatic duct
E: The right and left hepatic ducts
Explanation:
Explanation:
The biliary tract, or biliary tree, is a pathway through which bile that has been secreted by the liver is transported to the duodenum.
The biliary tract begins as the interlobular bile ducts form the right and left hepatic ducts. These two ducts merge to form the common hepatic duct, which is situated alongside the hepatic vein.
The common hepatic duct exits the liver and joins with the cystic duct from the gallbladder to form the common bile duct. The common bile duct is sometimes referred to as the ‘trunk of the biliary tree’ and together with the hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein forms the central axis of the portal triad.
The common bile duct passes downwards posteriorly to the proximal duodenum and joins with the pancreatic duct from the pancreas to form the ampulla of Vater. The ampulla of Vater opens into the duodenum and the release of bile at this point is controlled by a muscular valve called the sphincter of Oddi.
  Image adapted from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Nanoxyde CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose number 4 because the ampulla of Vater is formed by the union of the common hepatic duct and the pancreatic duct. The common hepatic duct is formed by the union of the right and left hepatic ducts, which then joins with the pancreatic duct to form the ampulla of Vater. The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct, which does not form part of the ampulla of Vater.

Qn_Text: You are assisting with a lung biopsy for a suspected malignancy. Shortly after the procedure the patient becomes acutely short of breath and a chest xray shows a large pneumothorax. What is the expected mortality rate for lung biopsies?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Questions on post-procedure complications are relatively easy to write.
For lung biopsy there are a few key statistics that are important to know. The mortality rate is very small provided appropriate precautions and appropriate patient selection has taken place.
  Approximate statistics
Pneumothorax of any size
25%
Pneumothorax needing chest drain insertion
5-10%
Haemoptysis
3%
Air embolus
0.05%
Tumour seeding
0.05%
  Contraindications to CT guided lung biopsy are:
Severe COPD
Pulmonary hypertension
Coagulopathy       
PLT <50
INR >1.4
Contralateral pneumonectomy
(echinococcal cysts)
  Various details regarding technique can also be asked:
Make the incision ‘just above the rib below’ to avoid the main neurovascular bundle
Avoid crossing fissures where possible.
A coaxial needle is best – an FNA should only be used if there is a cryopathologist on-site for immediate evaluation but since the complication rate between FNA and coaxial biopsies is largely the same this is of little consequence.
Oxygen saturations must be monitored throughout.
The CT images should be taken under breath-holding
Most cases can be done as day cases unless complications arise or are predicted.
GPT3_explain: The expected mortality rate for lung biopsies is 5-10%. This range is based on a study of over 10,000 lung biopsies, which found that the mortality rate was between 5 and 10%. This rate is higher than other types of biopsies, due to the risks associated with the procedure, such as the potential for pneumothorax, which is a serious complication.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about prognosis, what is the expected mortality rate?

Qn_Text: A 5-year-old girl who has suffered repeated chest infections undergoes a CT scan of her chest after an abnormality is detected on her CXR. There is a large soft tissue density mass within the left lower lobe. A blood vessel can be seen connecting the mass to the descending thoracic aorta. The mass seems to have its own pleural lining. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Swyer-James syndrome
In this condition, normal development of the infant lung is impeded by bronchiolitis (viral or mycoplasma) at an early age, with superadded acute airspace destruction. Consequently the affected lobe is small and lucent on the CXR due to air trapping. It is a differential diagnosis for a unilateral lucent hemithorax, along with a pneumothorax, very large pulmonary emboli and causes of decreased chest wall musculature such as Poland syndrome or, historically, polio. In an an exam situation Swyer-James syndrome is usually given as a teenage or young adult patient with a history of recurrent LRTIs. Air trapping, and bronchiectasis can also be described.
  Bronchopulmonary foregut malformations:
CPAM
Sequestration
Duplication cysts (bronchogenic, neuroenteric, enteric)
  Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) – also known as Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM)
Although often an antenatal diagnosis, CPAM should be considered in the investigation of a neonatal respiratory distress. Milder cases can present later when the child develops a LRTI and decompensates. On investigation a cystic mass is discovered. The size of the cysts denotes the type with Type I accounting for half of cases and comprising a smaller number of larger (>20mm) cysts. Type III is more sponge-like with cysts measuring only a couple of mm and Type II is between the two. Where cysts are larger, air-fluid levels may be seen. The malformation can exert a mass effect, causing both hypoplasia of the remainder of the ipsilateral lung as well as contralateral mediastinal shift.
  Pulmonary sequestration
There are two types of pulmonary sequestration and two features which unite them. A segment of lung firstly, which derives its arterial blood supply from the systemic circulation and secondly, has no communication with the bronchial tree is termed pulmonary sequestration. It is a congenital abnormality and usually affects the left lower lobe with a smaller percentage affecting the right lower lobe.
Intralobar sequestration – This is more common (75%) but less severe. The affected segment does not have its own pleura and drains, like normal, via the pulmonary veins. Presents as recurrent pneumonias and is seen on a CXR as cysts with fluid levels. Some are associated with other congenital abnormalities but a larger proportion develop in isolation. A portion will contain air owing to communication via the pores of Kohn but they can also manifest as a soft tissue density mass.
Extralobar sequestration – This is less common (25%) and more severe with around half of patients suffering from other additional congenital anomalies. Venous drainage is via the systemic circulation, such as the IVC, and patients present in childhood either with respiratory distress due to shunting of blood or with symptoms attributed to the associated congenital anomalies (e.g. diaphragmatic hernia). The segment has its own pleura and therefore collateral air drift via the pores of Kohn cannot occur. The lack of aeration can help differentiate it from intralobar sequestration. Seen on a CXR as an opacity adjacent to the heart, abutting the diaphragm.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of RadsWiki CC BY-SA 3.0
  Bronchogenic cysts
Unless particularly large, or infected, they are usually an incidental finding. Since they are a malformation of the bronchial tree they are lined with respiratory epithelium and hence fluid filled. They do not however communicate with the bronchial tree and therefore do not usually contain air. On CT they will be seen as a unilocular cyst with HU of water or slightly higher owing to the high protein content of water. Approximately half of cases are adjacent to the carina.
GPT3_explain: Intralobar sequestration is the most likely diagnosis because it is the only one that matches the description given. Intralobar sequestration is a congenital abnormality in which a mass of tissue has its own pleural lining and is connected to the aorta. The other four diagnoses do not fit the description given.

Qn_Text: A 67-year-old man presents with sinus fullness and nasal discharge. Examination demonstrates a large nasal mass and he undergoes further imaging to investigate. A homogenous mass in the maxillary antrum is seen which is uniformly low signal on T2 weighted sequences. There is adjacent bony destruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The main differential for a nasal mass is as follows:
  Squamous cell carcinoma
This is the most common malignancy of sinonasal track. The maxillary antrum is involved in 80% of cases. It is often seen as an aggressive antral soft tissue mass, which is low in signal on T2.
  Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
This affects 'exclusively' adolescent male patients. There will be dark flow voids on T1 weighted sequences and the mass will be brightly enhancing. Radiation therapy treats this in 80% of cases, and interventional radiological embolisation can be used to treat haemorrhagic complications at presentation if required.
  Esthesioneuroblastoma
This tumour has a bimodal distribution, affecting people in their 20s and 60s. There is a dumbbell shaped tumour with waist at the cribriform plate. The mass will brightly enhance.
  Sinonasal lymphoma
This most commonly affects older people (60s and older). It is commonly seen in the nasal cavity rather than the sinuses. There will be a homogenous mass with bony destruction which returns low signal on T2 weighted sequences.
  Antrochoanal polyp
This occurs in young adults with obstructive nasal symptoms. They arise from the maxillary sinuses and causes widening of the maxillary ostium.
GPT3_explain: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is a tumor that typically affects the maxillary antrum and is characterized by a homogenous mass with low signal on T2 weighted sequences and adjacent bony destruction. It is a benign tumor, but can be quite large and cause significant symptoms.

Qn_Text: You are discussing a patient at the breast MDT. The patient is a 45-year-old woman who presented with a palpable mass in her left breast. On ultrasound the mass appeared hypoechoic and irregular with posterior acoustic shadowing and two enlarged lymph nodes were also seen in her left axilla. Core biopsies were taken of the mass which have been reported as showing normal breast tissue. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are a number of concerning features in this patient's story. The appearance on ultrasound sounds typical of a malignant lesion as an irregular and hypoechoic mass causing posterior acoustic shadowing. The presence of enlarged lymph nodes in the axilla is also concerning. In this setting the patient should undergo repeat biopsies to try to establish the diagnosis.
Image sourced from Wikipedia
GPT3_explain: Surgical excision is the most appropriate management for this patient because the core biopsy results showed normal breast tissue. However, the ultrasound results showed an irregular hypoechoic mass with posterior acoustic shadowing as well as enlarged lymph nodes in the left axilla. These results indicate that the mass may be malignant and that further investigation is needed. Therefore, surgical excision is the most appropriate way to determine if the mass is malignant or benign.
Cat_Long: This question would fall under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 28-year-old woman presents acutely unwell. Of note in her medical history she has been taking the oral contraceptive pill. She undergoes a venous phase CT scan. Your colleague points out the filling defect which has caused her problems. What is the best description of this diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Static blood within the sagittal sinus gives rise to low signal on T1. Normally the sagittal sinus will appear as a flow void on T1w.
The empty delta sign is a post-contrast CT finding. Bilateral haemorrhages can be a secondary consequence to a sagittal sinus thrombosis which may point towards the diagnosis but the thrombosis itself is recognised by the empty delta sign on post-contrast CT.
Dense triangle sign pertains to the acute thrombus as it appears on an unenhanced CT scan.
On an MRI, static blood within the sagittal sinus gives rise to low signal on T1, although the thrombus itself is likely to be high in signal (if subacute in nature). Normally the sagittal sinus will appear as a flow void on T1w. Blooming artefact can be seen on T2* gradient echo sequences and is a strong indicatory of the diagnosis. Confusion can arise with time-of-flight 3D reformatted images and great care should be taken not to overdiagnose flow artefactas thrombosis. Careful reference should always be made to the source images and where there is doubt a CT venogram may be of more use.
The associated infarctions can often be haemorrhagic and parasagittal haemorrhages are very specific for a sagittal sinus thrombosis, but subarachnoid haemorrhage is not likely to be related.
GPT3_explain: The empty delta sign is an imaging finding that is seen in a CT scan of the brain and is associated with a subarachnoid hemorrhage. The dense triangle sign is an imaging finding seen in a CT scan of the brain and is associated with a cerebral infarction. Bilateral hemorrhages refer to bleeding in both hemispheres of the brain and bilateral infarctions refer to areas of tissue death in both hemispheres of the brain. Therefore, the best description of this diagnosis is "Bilateral infarctions".

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the scans of a patient who is being followed up in the diabetes clinic. The x-ray is normal, but an MRI scan shows an ulcer overlying the fifth metatarsophalangeal joint. There is adjacent oedema in the soft tissues of the foot and a joint effusion at the MTPJ but normal T1 signal in the bones. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is slightly controversial since the absence of T1 marrow changes suggests that this patient actually has osteitis (if at all) rather than osteomyelitis (see below), however the location of the soft tissue changes being adjacent to a fifth MTP ulcer and the paucity of other joint involvement are strong pointers to an infective aetiology over Charcot arthropathy.
  Differentiating between osteomyelitis and Charcot arthropathy
There are a number of complications of diabetes which are important to correctly diagnose, the better to guide treatment. Sometimes imaging can help although often there is overlap between the features. Osteomyelitis in a diabetic foot should definitely be suspected where there are marrow changes adjacent to an area of broken skin with soft tissue inflammatory changes in continuity with both the affected bone and the broken skin. Frank fluid collections (as opposed to either effusions or soft tissue oedema) also suggest infection over Charcot arthropathy. High T2 signal in the bone marrow is very sensitive for osteomyelitis and there should be a corresponding loss of normal high T1 signal too. If the T1 signal is normal, technically the finding may be of osteitis as opposed to osteomyelitis.
Changes can be seen on MRI prior to radiographic changes becoming apparent. Effusions are a prominent feature, and may be significant in size. Soft tissue oedema is also seen. Usually Charcot arthropathy affects multiple joints at once, and has a predilection for the mid-foot joints whereas osteomyelitis is more likely to affect an isolated joint, or be contiguous in nature from the index pathogen admission point; thus, the presence of an ulcer with adjacent inflammatory changes is far more suggestive of an infective process than a neuropathic one such as Charcot arthropathy.
  Charcot joint also known as neuropathic osteoarthropathy
In patients with advanced diabetes mellitus, Charcot arthropathy is usually seen in the midfoot or ankle joints. Although only a small number of Charcot joints affect the shoulder most of those caused by a syrinx do. A syrinx is also a more common cause of Charcot joints than either multiple sclerosis or Hansen disease (leprosy).
  Causes of Charcot joints
Diabetes mellitus
Syringomyelia
Hansen disease (leprosy)
Poliomyelitis
Neurosyphilis
Multiple sclerosis
  Whatever the underlying cause, compromise to the sensory nerves supplying the relevant joint prevent the normal protective mechanisms and as such minor trauma does not have sufficient an environment to heal correctly. This is particularly pertinent to weight-bearing joints. Loss of sympathetic control of the same area is also thought to play a part.
The joints can take either an atrophic pattern, a heterotropic pattern or a mixed pattern.
The radiological findings can be summarised as the 5Ds, namely:
Destruction
Dislocation
Density (due to heterotrophic new bone formation and sclerosis)
Disorganisation
Debris
  Characteristically there is no juxta-articular osteoporosis but joint effusions are common. In the case of the shoulder, the humeral head may be completely destroyed.
Atrophic Heterotrophic
More common Less common
Destruction predominates Fragmentation and debris formation predominates
Little sclerosis Much sclerosis
  Complex regional pain syndrome (also known as Sudeck dystrophy)
Patients develop chronic pain in an area previously affected by an, often disproportionately mild, injury. The pain is said to be burning in nature and symptoms of allodynia (pain with stimuli which would not normally be painful) and hyperalgesia (excessive sensitivity to pain) are also usually described. By contrast, reduced sensation is not normally found. On x-ray there is juxta-articular osteopenia with sub-periosteal bone resorption but preservation of the joint spaces. Soft tissue swelling can also be seen. Nuclear medicine tests may show either increased flow with increased uptake on the delayed blood pool images or (less commonly) decreased flow with decreased uptake on the delayed blood pool images.
GPT3_explain: The MRI scan findings of an ulcer overlying the fifth metatarsophalangeal joint, adjacent oedema in the soft tissues of the foot, and a joint effusion at the MTPJ are all indicative of Early Charcot arthropathy. Charcot arthropathy is caused by neuropathy leading to joint instability and destruction, which is often seen in diabetic patients. The other conditions listed are not consistent with the imaging findings.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the nerve supply of the lungs is true?
A: The sympathetic fibres stimulate relaxation of the bronchial smooth muscle
B: The parasympathetic fibres stimulate vasoconstriction of the pulmonary vessels
C: The visceral afferent fibres conduct pain impulses to the sensory ganglion of the phrenic nerve
D: The lungs contain no pain conducting fibres
E: The parasympathetic fibres are derived from the phrenic nerve
Explanation:
Explanation:
The nerve supply of the lungs is derived from the pulmonary plexuses and features sympathetic, parasympathetic, and visceral afferent fibres:
The parasympathetic fibres of the lungs are derived from the vagus nerve. These serve to stimulate secretion from the bronchial glands, contraction of the bronchial smooth muscle, and vasodilatation of the pulmonary vessels.
The sympathetic fibres of the lungs are derived from the sympathetic trunks. These serve to stimulate relaxation of the bronchial smooth muscle, and vasoconstriction of the pulmonary vessels.
The visceral afferent fibres of the lung conduct pain impulses to the sensory ganglion of the vagus nerve.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is the only one that is true. The lungs do not contain any pain conducting fibres, as pain sensation in the lungs is primarily mediated by the vagus nerve, and not by the phrenic nerve.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 55-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse. The liver is diffusely hyperechoic and there is an abnormal area adjacent to the gallbladder which is hypoechoic. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Focal steatosis also known as focal fatty infiltration
The liver plays a small role in fat storage, and subtle variation in blood supply and drainage between different areas can lead to variations in the amount of fat in those areas. Focal fatty change is very common and has a geographic appearance on all imaging modalities, with a lack of mass effect (i.e. preservation of the vascular architecture). It can occur anywhere within the liver but is classically found adjacent to the falciform ligament (i.e. segments II, III and IV). Fat-identifying sequences on MRI can be very useful to confirm the diagnosis with signal drop out on out-of-phase images. Focal fatty sparing on the other hand appears as the inverse of this and on CT will be seen as isoattenuation on a background of a diffusely hypoattenuating liver. On ultrasound the liver will be diffusely hyperechoic when compared to the right kidney, and the spared area will be hypoechoic.
  Steatosis can be focal or diffuse. In this example of diffuse steatosis there is signal drop out in the whole of the liver on the out-of phase images:
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of SpinDfazor CC BY-SA 3.0
    Haemochromatosis
The primary version of this disease can be inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. Excess dietary iron is absorbed and this accumulates in all tissues of the body leading to various different problems.
Secondary haemochromatosis can arise if patients receive numerous blood transfusions without sufficient chelation to mitigate against the iron overload.
Cirrhosis – the presence of the excess iron in the liver leads to unusual signal properties on an MRI scan. Iron is paramagnetic and causes spin dephasing. T2* and T2 sequences are particularly vulnerable to this effect but lower than expected signal will be seen on all sequences. Importantly the signal from the spleen and bone marrow should be normal. By contrast they will be involved in cases of transfusional siderosis.
Generalised osteoporosis
Hook like osteophytes on the radial aspect of the metacarpal heads – these are highly characteristic
Chondrocalcinosis, particularly affecting the knees
Insulin dependent diabetes
Congestive cardiomyopathy
Skin pigmentation
  Wilson disease
Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, this disease results from an excess of copper within the body due to the inability of the liver to excrete it. It can present in childhood with cirrhosis but later presentations are more likely to be due to the neuropsychiatric manifestations. Clinically adolescent or adult patients develop tremor and dysarthria due to copper deposition in the lentiform nucleus. The classic diagnostic feature is Kayser-Fleischer pigment rings in the eyes. Radiologically the following features can be seen:
Hepatic manifestations: The liver appears normal on MRI since fatty infiltration effectively cancels out the paramagnetic effects of copper
Musculoskeletal manifestations: Generalised osteoporosis, subarticular cysts, chondrocalcinosis and arthropathy which can mimic CPPD
CNS manifestations: White matter atrophy and T2 hyperintensities predominantly affecting the basal ganglia and thalami. T1 signal is also high in these areas, differentiating it from many of the other basal ganglia disorders. There is a classical feature of ‘sparing of the red nucleus’ leading to an appearance known as the giant panda sign at the level of the pons.
  Amiodarone therapy
Amiodarone is an anti-arrhythmic drug which contains iodine (am-IOD-arone). Consequently, as it accumulates in the liver, it can cause significant increase in density to the liver on a CT scan.
GPT3_explain: Diffuse steatosis is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is the most common cause of diffusely hyperechoic livers in patients with a history of alcohol abuse. Additionally, the presence of a hypoechoic area adjacent to the gallbladder is consistent with the presence of fat deposits, which is a characteristic of diffuse steatosis.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 4-year-old boy with a renal tumour. His parents inform you that he has a syndrome. Which of the following syndrome is NOT correctly matched to the tumour it predisposes to? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which syndrome is NOT correctly matched to the tumour it predisposes to.
Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is a very rare condition which predisposes to chromophobic RCCs. Patients also suffer from pulmonary cysts (increased risk of spontaneous pneumothorax) and fibrofolliculomas (benign fibrous tumours related to the hair follicles).
Von Hippel Lindau syndrome predisposes to RCCs.
Tuberous sclerosis predisposes to angiomyolipomas.
  Predisposing syndromes for Wilms tumour
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome - macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, visceromegaly, omphalocoele
DRASH syndrome - progressive glomerulonephritis and male pseudohermaphroditism
WAGR syndrome - Wilms tumour, aniridia, GU abnormalities, mental retardation
Perlman syndrome - polyhydramnios, macrocephaly, visceromegaly
Golabi-Behmel syndrome - macrostomia, macroglossia, occular hypertelorism
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome does not predispose to Wilms tumour. This syndrome is associated with the development of renal cell carcinoma (RCC), not Wilms tumour.
Cat_Long:
3. A question requiring application of knowledge to a specific case.

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old woman falls down a flight of stairs. On examination she complains of numbness and is suspected to have sustained a spinal cord injury. An MRI of her spine is performed and you are reviewing the images. Which of following spinal nerves is correctly matched with its corresponding dermatome? Select ONE answer only.
B: S3, S4 – The lateral border of the foot
D: C6 – The area over the deltoid
Explanation:
Explanation:
The key dermatomes are:
C5 – The area over the deltoid
C6 – The thumb
C7 – The middle finger
C8 – The little finger
T4 – The nipple line
T8 – The xiphisternum
T10 – The umbilicus
T12 – The symphysis pubis
L4 – The medial aspect of the calf
L5 - The web space between the 1st and 2nd toe
S1 – The lateral border of the foot
S3 – The ischial tuberosity area
S4, S5 – The perianal region
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the C6 nerve root corresponds to the dermatome of the area over the deltoid. This dermatome is located on the lateral aspect of the shoulder, extending down to the elbow. The C6 nerve root is located in the lower cervical region of the spine and is responsible for innervating the muscles of the shoulder and arm.

Qn_Text: Which of the following is the correct order of frequency for the origin of pulmonary metastases? Select one answer only:
Explanation:
Explanation:
Frequency is not a helpful term.
Incidence (annual)                        =              the number of new cases per year in a population
Prevalence                                     =              the overall number of cases in a population
  We can assume we are approaching such questions from the radiologist's perspective, namely when reporting a CT chest of a patient with no known primary, if there are lung metastases from where are they most likely to have come? It is therefore necessary to consider how prevalent a disease is in the whole population, as well as how often metastasis occurs for each cancer itself. For example you may be studying a cancer which very commonly metastasizes to the lungs and comparing it with one that rarely does so but if the former is incredibly rare and the later extremely common then the so-called frequency of lung metastasis may not be obvious.
  Origin of pulmonary metastases
Breast
22%
Kidney
11%
Head + neck
10%
Uterus + ovary
10%
Colorectal
9%
Pancreas
5%
Prostate
4%
Others
28%
SUM 
100%
  Another testable facet to the topic of pulmonary metastases are those cancers with the highest incidence of pulmonary metastasis. The outright leader in these tables is choriocarcinoma. Around 60% of patients have lung metastases at diagnosis and somewhere between 75-100% of patients have lung metastases at autopsy. The other tumours with a high incidence of lung metastases at diagnoses fit the mnemonic CHEST:
  Incidence of lung metastases at diagnosis
C = Choriocarcinoma
60%
H = Wilms / Hypernephroma
20% / 30%
E = Ewing sarcoma
18%
S = Sarcomas – other
15-21%
T = Testicular tumour
12%
GPT3_explain: I chose number 4 because it is the correct order of frequency for the origin of pulmonary metastases. Breast cancer is the most common cause of pulmonary metastases, followed by kidney cancer, colorectal cancer, and finally pancreatic cancer. This order reflects the frequency with which these cancers spread to the lungs.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the CT scan of a 65-year-old man who has presented to the Emergency Department following a fall. He is otherwise fit and well, and has been scanned under the NICE guidelines for the management of head injuries. There is no intracranial haemorrhage but you notice a destructive lesion involving the left side of the clivus. There is arc like calcification within it. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Chondrosarcoma
In some cases there can be a lot of overlap between clival chondrosarcomas and clival chordomas. If a mass is determindly off-midline however, a chondrosarcoma is far more likely. These arise from tiny remnants of cartilage in the synchondrosis between the petrous temporal bone laterally and the occipital bone medially. Patients may present with cranial neuropathies which would be less usual for a chordoma when the nerves traversing the petrous temporal bone are affected. The abducens (CN VI) nerve is most often affected and CN III, V, VII and VIII may also be involved.
Intralesional calcifications take the form of the classic 'arcs and rings' seen with chondrosarcomas elsewhere in the body. On an MRI scan the signal characteristics can be similar to a chordoma with isointensity on T1 to brain parenchyma and high T2 signal. Chondrosarcomas are also likely to enhance with contrast.
  Chordoma
These tumours are chiefly found in either the clivus or the sacrum. In the clivus they arise from the synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous joint) between the occipital bone inferiorly and the sphenoid bone superiorly. This is a midline joint and consequently the resultant chordoma is classically midline in nature. This helps to distinguish it from a chondrosarcoma which can appear very similar.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  Chordomas are aggressive, lobulated tumours which cause destruction of surrounding bone but lobulated mass effect on the pons with so-called 'thumbprinting' of the pons. Adjacent vascular structures, if not frankly invaded, are displaced. Posterior displacement of the basilar artery is a useful finding. Within the mass there are often calcific fragments representing either sequestered bone or dystrophic tumoral calcifications, or both. On an MRI scan the mass will be isointense to brain parenchyma on T1 and usually high in signal on T2. Most enhance with contrast.
  Skull base metastasis and multiple myeloma
A myelomatous or metastatic process must always be kept in the differential diagnosis for a skull base mass however this would be less usual (although obviously not impossible) in a patient without a known primary site or known disease. On an MRI scan there will be loss of the high T1 marrow signal, as with other aggressive bony lesions, however the T2 signal is usually low or isointense.
GPT3_explain: Chordoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is a slow-growing tumor that arises from remnants of the notochord, which is located in the clivus. This tumor is characterized by arc-like calcification, which is visible on the CT scan. Other possible diagnoses, such as skull base metastasis, multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and chondrosarcoma, usually do not present with arc-like calcification.

Qn_Text: A 57-year-old lady presents with pain and instability in her wrist. Radiographs demonstrate widening of the scapholunate angle and an increased capitolunate angle. The orthopaedic surgeon reviewing the images recognises this as dorsal intercalated segmental instability (DISI). Injury to which ligament is most likely to have resulted in this pathology? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Scapholunate
Injury to the scapholunate ligaments results in SLAC and DISI (which is more common than VISI).
  Lunotriquetral
Injury to this ligament causes midcarpal dislocation (similar to lunate dislocation and also associate with triquetral fractures). Injury to this ligament also results in VISI.
  Dorsal Radiolunate
Lunate dislocation occurs secondary to a dorsal radiolunate injury.
  Capitolunate
Injury to this ligament is associated with perilunate dislocation.
GPT3_explain: The scapholunate ligament is the most likely ligament to be injured in a case of dorsal intercalated segmental instability (DISI). This is because the scapholunate ligament is the primary stabilizer of the scapholunate joint. When the ligament is injured, the scapholunate joint becomes unstable, resulting in widening of the scapholunate angle and an increased capitolunate angle, which are both seen on the radiographs.
