Qn_Text: You are reporting a CT scan of a 43-year-old man and notice a 3.5cm exophytic lesion. It enhances less than the renal cortex with Hounsfield Units of 30 peripherally but only 5 centrally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Despite the fact that RCCs are far more common than Oncocytomas the question writer has gone to the trouble of pointing out that the centre of the lesion is of low attenuation and in the context of an exam question this differentiates it from an RCC despite the overlap in appearances of both entities in real life.
  Oncocytoma
Oncocytomas have a characteristic feature of a stellate spoke wheel vascular pattern with a central scar which is low in attenuation and hyperechoic. In reality there is so much overlap between the features of these tumours, which are largely benign, and renal cell carcinomas, that oncocytomas must be resected for histological confirmation of the diagnosis. They can present at any age but are usually asymptomatic, despite often being very large. In the real world they can engulf the perinephric fat and confusingly come to resemble an AML which is unhelpful.
  Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
This is the most common kidney tumour, accounting for around 80%. Patients are usually in their 50-70s although there is an increased incidence in dialysis patients and those with von Hippel Lindau. Clinically there is a classically macroscopic haematuria. A quarter or patients develop a paraneoplastic syndrome such as:
Hypercalcaemia
Polycythaemia due to erythropoietin
Stauffer syndrome (hepatomegaly without hepatic metastasis)
Limbic encephalitis
A renal protocol CT is used to evaluate lesions found on ultrasound and includes an unenhanced phase, a 60 second (corticomedullary) phase, and a 100 second (nephrogenic) phase. An excretory phase at 15 minutes can also be performed if evaluation of the collecting system anatomy is required (e.g. if the patient is a candidate for a partial nephrectomy). There are a number of different histological subtypes which are simplified and summarised in the table below:
  Histology
Prevalence
Associations
Clear cell renal carcinoma
75%
Von Hippel Lindau syndrome
Papillary renal cell carcinoma
15%
Most strongly associated with dialysis patients. Better prognosis than clear cell (if diagnosed prior to metastasis).
Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma
5%
These are histologically like oncocytomas. Associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube (rare autosomal dominant disease affecting skin follicles, also causes lung cysts). They are thought to have a better prognosis than clear cell renal carcinoma.
Medullary carcinoma
<1%
Sickle Cell Trait
  Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC)
Bladder TCCs are very common but renal TCCs less so. Nonetheless they have a knack for appearing in multiple locations at once and thus careful evaluation of the upper tracts is necessary each time a new diagnosis of bladder TCC is made. They appear as filling defects on the excretory phase of a CT scan or IVU.
  Sarcoma
Renal sarcomas are rare and their imaging features relate well to their individual histology.
  Metastasis
Secondary neoplasms of the kidney are mainly adenocarcinoma in origin but are often mistaken for renal cell carcinomas since there can be little to distinguish them on imaging.
GPT3_explain: RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma) is the most likely diagnosis because of the exophytic lesion that is enhancing less than the renal cortex with Hounsfield Units of 30 peripherally but only 5 centrally. This is suggestive of a malignant lesion, and RCC is the most common type of malignant renal tumor in adults.

Qn_Text: An 88-year-old man is admitted from his nursing home with abdominal pain and vomiting. On examination the admitting doctor is concerned that he may have a small bowel obstruction. He undergoes a CT scan and you have been asked to review the images urgently. The small bowel is dilated and a herniated loop emerges lateral to the inferior epigastric vein. Which of the following would most accurately describe this situation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Abdominal wall hernias
Hernias can occur at any age but are increasingly prevalent with increasing age. Conditions which increase intra-abdominal pressures predispose patients to developing hernias. These might be entities such as constipation or respiratory conditions associated with excess coughing such as COPD.
Hernia
Landmarks
Feature
Femoral
Inferolateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to the femoral vein
More common in women
Direct inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle, medial to the inferior epigastric vein
Through Hesselbach triangle
Indirect inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle and lateral to the inferior epigastric vein
Most common abdominal hernia
Obturator
Between pectineus and obturator externus muscles, through the obturator foramen
Rare
Spigelian
Inferolateral abdominal wall defect, lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle
May be congenital and associated with cryptorchidism
  Indirect inguinal hernias pass through the inguinal canal, taking in both the deep and superficial rings as they do. The deep ring is lateral to the internal epigastric vessels.
Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the conjoint tendon medial to the internal epigastric vessels and enter the scrotal sac through the superficial ring. They pass through the Hesselbach triangle which is composed of the inferior epigastric vessels, rectus abdominus and the inguinal ligament.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Direct inguinal hernia because the herniated loop of the small bowel was lateral to the inferior epigastric vein, which is a characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia. In a direct inguinal hernia, the hernial sac passes through the internal inguinal ring and the inguinal canal, and the hernial sac is medial to the inferior epigastric vein. An indirect inguinal hernia passes through the internal inguinal ring, but the hernial sac is lateral to the inferior epigastric vein. A femoral hernia passes through the femoral canal, a spigelian hernia passes through the spigelian fascia, and an obturator hernia passes through the obturator canal.

Qn_Text: A 9-year-old boy with precocious puberty and a headache undergoes a CT scan which shows a hyperdense mass in the pineal gland. There is avid contrast enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The two clinical features typical for a germinoma are precocious puberty in children and Parinaud syndrome (paralysis of upward gaze). Of these the latter pertains to the physical compression of the tectal plate and is therefore common to pineal masses in general (with the exception of pineal cysts). The precocious puberty is a consequence of hormone production by the germinoma and distinguishes it, in this question, from a pineoblastoma or teratoma.
GPT3_explain: Germinoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common type of tumor found in the pineal gland, and it typically presents with precocious puberty and headaches. Additionally, CT scans of germinomas typically show a hyperdense mass with avid contrast enhancement, which is consistent with the findings in this case.

Qn_Text: A 39-year-old man attends a urology outpatient clinic having failed initial therapies for the management of his dysuria. He is scheduled for a cystoscopy which is normal and undergoes an MRI of the pelvis. This shows a Mullerian duct cyst. Which of the following features is NOT useful in differentiating a Mullerian duct cyst from a utricle cyst in this patient?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which is NOT a useful feature.
Anatomy plays a strong role in the correct diagnosis of male genitourinary tract cysts. It is first necessary to differentiate between intraprostatic cysts and extraprostatic cysts.
  Mullerian duct cyst (intraprostatic)
These are usually found in young adult men and are also caused by incomplete regression of the Mullerian duct. They have numerous similarities with prostatic utricle cysts, including an association with renal agenesis (although not with intersex disorders). Anatomically they are also posterior to the bladder however unlike prostatic utricle cysts they extend superiorly to the prostate and do not communicate with the urethra. On MRI they appear straightforwardly cystic unless complicated by infection. The shape of the cyst is said to be teardrop shaped rather than the pear-shaped prostatic utricle cysts.
    Mullerian duct cyst Prostatic utricle cyst
Age 20-40 years 0-20 years
Shape Teardrop Pear
Extends above prostate? Yes No
Communicates with prostatic urethra? No Yes
  Prostatic utricle cyst (intraprostatic)
These are found in teenagers or adolescents and represent incomplete regression of the Mullerian duct system during embryological development. They are found posterior to the bladder, within the prostate, and do not extend any more superiorly than the superior most aspect of the prostate. This anatomical detail and the fact that the cyst does communicate with the prostatic urethra sets it apart from a Mullerian duct cyst on imaging. They can cause all manner of lower urinary tract symptoms and boast an association with ipsilateral renal agenesis as well as intersex disorders. On MRI they are said to have a pear-shaped appearance.
GPT3_explain: 4. The age of this patient is not useful in differentiating a Mullerian duct cyst from a utricle cyst. The age of the patient is not relevant to the diagnosis of the cyst, as both Mullerian duct cysts and utricle cysts can occur in patients of any age. The other features, such as the intraprostatic location, shape, and communication with the urethra, are all useful in differentiating between the two types of cysts.

Qn_Text: An 87-year-old man undergoes a follow up CT scan following an admission with an empyema and two days later develops an acute kidney injury suspected to be secondary to contrast induced nephropathy. Which of these fits the definition for contrast-induced nephropathy.
A: 50% increase in baseline creatinine or a rise of at least 26umol/L
B: 20% rise in baseline creatinine or increase of at least 20umol/L
C: 75% rise in baseline creatinine or increase of at least 60umol/L
D: 25% rise in baseline creatinine or increase of at least 50umol/L
E: 50% rise in baseline creatinine or increase of at least 50umol/L
Explanation:
Explanation:
44umol/l equates to 0.5mg/dL.
Contrast induced AKI is a contraversial topic. There is increasing evidence that it is an over-reported (possibly even completely non-existent!) phenomenon.
The current definitiion of CI-AKI is as follows:
Rise of serum creatinine by at least 0.3mg/dL within 48 hours of administration
Rise of serum creatinine of at least 50% over the baseline value within 48hrs of administration
Urine output below 0.5ml/kg/hr for 6 consecutive hours following administration.
(if no available baseline within the preceeding week is found, the lowest value within the last three months can be used. If no creatinine has been performed in the last three months then the creatinine should be repeated within 24hours, or a reference value can be estimated from the lowest creatinine measured subsequently)
Adequate hydration is the key to avoiding contrast-induced nephropathy where there is a risk of it occurring.
At risk groups are those with pre-existing renal impairment as well as diabetics, patients with sepsis, heart failure, or cirrhosis.
The renal function may take two to three days to dip to its lowest point before staging a recovery.
    Low risk
Medium risk
High risk
Creatinine (umol/L)
<130
130-200
>200
Creatinine clearance (ml/min)
>60
30-60
<30
eGFR (ml/min)
45-60
30-45
<30
Other risk factors
Sepsis, diabetes mellitus, dehydration, congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome
GPT3_explain: I chose number 5 because it fits the definition for contrast-induced nephropathy, which is a 50% rise in baseline creatinine or an increase of at least 50umol/L. This definition is based on research that suggests that a rise in creatinine of 50% or more is indicative of contrast-induced nephropathy.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old woman with symptoms of breathlessness and palpitations is being investigated. Her chest x-ray shows bilateral symmetrical perihilar shadowing and pleural effusions. On examination she has a diastolic murmur and is thought to be in heart failure. She undergoes a Cardiac MRI scan which shows a pericardial mass. It is hyperintense to the myocardium on T1 and T2 and demonstrated enhancement on the post-contrast sequences. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
High T1 signal can be caused by:
Melanin, protein, contrast agents, fat, methaemaglobin (subacute haemorrhage).
Almost all malignant cardiac masses will show contrast enhancement.
  Cardiac metastases
Metastases are significantly more common than cardiac sarcomas, meaning metastases are the most common malignant cardiac tumours. In contrast to myxomas or fibroelastomas, malignant lesions tend to have a broad attachment to the heart wall. Tumours can be from lung or breast cancer, lymphoma, leukaemia and malignant melanoma.
Although malignant melanoma most commonly metastasizes to the lungs, liver, brain and skeleton and is rarely found in the heart, of cardiac metastases at all it is by far the most common.
  Atrial myxoma
These are the most common benign neoplasms of the heart. Although usually sporadic, they can occur as part of Carney syndrome (atrial myxoma, facial/buccal pigmentation, sertoli tumours of the testis and multiple other findings. Not to be confused with Carney triad - pulmonary chondromas, gastric leiomyosarcomas and extra-adrenal paragangliomas). The finding of a small mass attached to the interatrial septum by a stalk is classical. Their mobility allows some to prolapse through the relevant atrioventricular valve during the cardiac cycle. They can act as a focus for platelet aggregation leading to systemic emboli for the more common left sided masses or pulmonary emboli for right sided myxomas. Iso or hypointentisty on T1w MRI is typical.
  Carney Triad Carney Syndrome
1. Pulmonary chondromas Atrial myxoma
2. Gastric leiomyosarcoma Facial/ buccal pigmentation
3. Extra-adrenal paraganglioma Sertoli tumour of the testis
  Pituitary adenoma
  Cardiac sarcoma
There are many different types of cardiac sarcoma. Cardiac sarcomas are the most common cause of primary malignant cardiac tumours. Their presentation usually relates either to embolic phenomena such as TIAs or symptoms from invasion such as pericardial effusion. In contrast to myxomas or fibroelastomas, malignant lesions tend to have a broad attachment to the heart wall. Another useful differentiating feature on imaging is the involvement of more than one chamber of the heart.
GPT3_explain: Atrial myxoma is the most likely diagnosis based on the findings of the MRI scan. The hyperintensity to the myocardium on T1 and T2 and the enhancement on the post-contrast sequences are all indicative of a pericardial mass, which is most likely to be an atrial myxoma. Atrial myxomas are the most common type of primary cardiac tumor, and they typically present with symptoms of breathlessness and palpitations, as seen in this patient.

Qn_Text: A 72-year-old man is undergoing pre-operative assessment prior to a routine TURP procedure for some troublesome lower urinary tract symptoms. When his PSA is found to be markedly elevated he undergoes an MRI scan for further investigation. A 12mm tumour is seen in the left peripheral zone. It returns low signal on the T2 weighted sequences, with some very low signal on the ADC sequence too. Which of the following most accurately describes the role of PSA density? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: It gives the likelihood of cancer being present
D: It contributes to both PIRADS and TNM scores
E: It is an indication of the likely response to chemotherapy
Explanation:
Explanation:
The PSA is usually considered elevated when levels exceed 4ng/L. A number of things can artificially elevate the PSA and in many cases of an incidental elevated PSA once these have been excluded the PSA returns to normal. Patients should be counselled to avoid activities which could lead to an elevated PSA for at least 48hrs prior to the test.
  False positive PSA False negative PSA
'Stradle' activities (bike riding, horse riding etc.) Aspirin
Ejaculation NSAIDs
Urinary tract infection  
Prostatitis  
Digital rectal examination  
Benign prostatic hyperplasia  
  The PSA density is calculated by taking the PSA and dividing it by the volume of the prostate. The volume is calculated as: Height x Length x Depth x π/6 (the volume of an ellipsoid). It accounts for the increase in size of the prostate which occurs in many men with increasing age and allows a far more comparable indication of the likelihood of malignancy. 0.1 is considered a normal PSA density value. Prostate cancers are usually seen in those with a prostate density of >0.1ng/ml/cc.
If a radiologist is reviewing a scan for a patient with a PSA density >0.1 and is unable to identify a prostatic malignancy then either they should review the scan more closely, or the PSA value could be repeated following appropriate instructions to the patient regarding cessation of PSA elevating activities prior to the test.
GPT3_explain: The PSA density is a measure of the amount of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in the blood relative to the size of the prostate. It can be used to help determine the likelihood of prostate cancer being present. It is used in both the PIRADS (Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System) and TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) staging systems to help determine the severity of the prostate cancer.

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man with multiple myeloma presents with shortness of breath and ankle swelling. He undergoes a cardiac MRI scan. This shows diffuse enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The information available in the vignette is sparse. In a patient with a known history of multiple myeloma, amyloidosis should always be considered. Without further details of the nature/location of the enhancement, there is nothing to dissuade the candidate from this option.
  Amyloid cardiomyopathy
Amyloidosis is a cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy. On MRI scanning there is global enhancement of the endocardium, and on echocardiogram the myocardium takes on a characteristic granular and speckled appearance. In an exam question setting a history of multiple myeloma, rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease or similar may be given to suggest secondary amyloidosis.
        Image © Medical Exam Prep
    Sarcoidosis cardiomyopathy
Involvement of the myocardium is relatively rare in sarcoidosis. Inflammation causes myocardial scarring of the interventricular septum and left ventricle most commonly. This shows as epicardial or midwall delayed hyperenhancement on MRI. The patient in this question is certainly of an appropriate demographic for sarcoidosis. The main differential diagnoses would be myocarditis or Chagas disease based on imaging findings alone.
  Ischaemic cardiomyopathy
The blood supply to the heart muscle itself is of interest here. The endocardium derives its blood directly from the chambers whereas the layer referred to as the subendocardium receives blood from the terminal branches of the coronary vessels. By the time they reach the subendocardium these blood vessels are small enough that ventricular contraction causes a degree of compression. The end result is that the subendocardium is particularly vulnerable to ischaemia, a fact which manifests in the delayed hyperenhancement patterns seen on MRI; ischaemic cardiomyopathy is seen as subendocardial delayed hyperenhancement or in more extreme cases transmural hyperenhancement. The pattern of hyperenhancement is also territorial with ischaemic cardiomyopathy, depending on which vessel(s) has been affected.
  Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)
HCM can be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion; there are a number of specific different gene mutations which have been identified to cause cardiac myocardial hypertrophy. The most common category is asymmetrical hypertrophy, accounting for around two thirds of cases. Here the interventricular septum is markedly enlarged. The remaining third of cases display symmetrical/concentric hypertrophy or apical hypertrophy. Patients are younger than most of those with ischaemic cardiomyopathy. On MRI scanning midwall hyperenhancement at the junction between the right and left ventricles is typical.
  Alcoholic cardiomyopathy
Dilated cardiomyopathy occurs in patients with a history of alcohol abuse. There is dilation of both ventricles alongside thinning of the myocardium which appears hypokinetic on dynamic studies. Myocardial fibrosis occurs and because this typically affects the mid-myocardium it can be differentiated from ischaemic cardiomyopathy which is often transmural and confined to vascular territories. The different areas show delayed enhancement on MRI scans.
GPT3_explain: Amyloidosis is a condition in which abnormal proteins, called amyloid, build up in the body's organs and tissues. It is often associated with multiple myeloma and can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath and ankle swelling. Cardiac MRI scans of patients with amyloidosis often show diffuse enhancement, which is an indication of the presence of amyloid deposits in the heart.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 7-year-old girl undergoes a renal tract ultrasound for recurrent urinary tract infections. The radiologist reports findings consistent with polycystic kidney disease. Which of the following is associated with juvenile autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease can be divided into perinatal, neonatal, infantile and juvenile forms, depending on the age of disease presentation. The disease severity classically has an inverse correlation with the degree of hepatic fibrosis (the more mild the polycystic disease, the more severe the fibrotic disease.) It is also associated pancreatic fibrosis, Caroli disease and portal hypertension.
Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma is associated with tuberous sclerosis which has no relation to autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.
Intracranial haemangiomablastoma is associated with von-Hippel Lindau.
Meckel-Gruber syndrome is renal cystic dysplasia (different diagnosis to autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease), polydactyly and holoprosencephaly
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Caroli disease is a form of juvenile autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. This type of polycystic kidney disease is characterized by enlarged cysts in the kidneys, bile ducts, and liver. It is usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice. Ultrasound is the most common method of diagnosis.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about applied knowledge, how to apply the knowledge to a particular situation?

This question would fall under option 3: A question about applied knowledge, how to apply the knowledge to a particular situation.

Qn_Text: A 25-year-old man complains of worsening night pain to his GP. He undergoes lumbar spine xrays on which a sclerotic abnormality is picked up for which he has a CT scan. There is a 1cm lesion in posterior element L2 which, on close inspection, reveals a radiolucent nidus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The radiolucent nidus and symptoms of night pain in a young patient point to either an osteoid osteoma or an osteoblastoma. The final diagnosis comes down to size. <1.5cm is definitely an osteoid osteoma, and >2cm is definitely an osteoblastoma. There is a nasty grey area somewhere between the two sizes. The posterior elements of the spine are a classic location for osteoid osteomas.
Aneurysmal bone cysts – these are non-aggressive lesions demonstrating cystic ‘soap-bubble’ expansion. They can be primary lesions or secondary to GCTs, osteoblastomas, chondroblastomas and many others. On MRI fluid-fluid levels can be seen.
Paget disease – coarse trabeculae with cortical thickening are the radiographic features classically described in Paget disease. It is a disease of abnormal bony remodelling. Despite the impressive coarseness and thickening the bone is abnormal bone and therefore fragile, conferring a fracture risk under normal stressors It would be an unusual finding in a patient of this age.
Langerhans cell histiocytosis – There are a number of skeletal entities typically associated with LCH, in particular with the more benign version, eosinophilic granuloma. These include vertebra plana, and punched out lytic skull lesions.
GPT3_explain: Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that is most commonly found in the long bones of the arms and legs, and it is also known to occur in the spine. This type of tumor is characterized by a small, radiolucent nidus, which is a round or ovoid area of decreased density surrounded by a sclerotic rim. The nidus is usually less than 1cm in diameter and contains a central core of calcified tissue. Osteoid osteoma typically causes severe, localized pain that is worse at night and relieved by aspirin or other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Therefore, based on the patient's age, location of the lesion, and symptoms, osteoid osteoma is the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the colon is true?
A: The transverse colon commences at the hepatic flexure
B: The ascending colon commences at the end of the jejunum
C: The sigmoid colon ends at the S1 vertebral level
Explanation:
Explanation:
The colon is the part of the large intestine that is situated between the caecum and the rectum. It receives digested food from the small intestine, from which it absorbs water and ions to form faeces. It is approximately 150 cm in length and is divided into four parts.
  1. Ascending colon:
This is the first part of the colon and is retroperitoneal. It ascends upwards from the caecum before turning right at a 90 degree angle at the right colic flexure (hepatic flexure) to become the transverse colon. It is approximately 20 cm long.
  2. Transverse colon:
This is the second part of the colon and is intraperitoneal. It extends transversely across the abdomen from the right colic flexure until it reaches the left colic flexure (splenic flexure) close to the spleen. Here it turns another 90 degrees inferiorly to become the descending colon. The transverse colon is the least fixed part of the colon. It is approximately 50 cm long.
  3. Descending colon:
This is the third part of the colon and is retroperitoneal in the majority of people. It extends inferiorly down the abdomen from the left colic flexure passing over the lateral border of the left kidney. At the point that it turns medially it becomes the sigmoid colon. It is approximately 30 cm long.
  4. Sigmoid colon:
This is the final part of the colon and is intraperitoneal. It extends downwards in an ‘S’ shape from the left iliac fossa to the level of the S3 vertebra. It is approximately 50 cm long.
    Image adapted from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Blausen Gallery CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the ascending colon is the first part of the large intestine, and it is located within the abdominal cavity, which is the area of the body that is considered to be intraperitoneal.
Cat_Long: This question falls under Basic Factual Recall, regarding anatomy.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound on a 65-year-old man and notice an incidental 5.6cm aortic aneurysm. What should your advice to the referring clinician be?
Explanation:
Explanation:
As an initial finding, the management of an abdominal aortic aneurysm depends on its size.
  Aneurysm size
Management
<3.0cm
Normal
Re-screen at age 65 if younger at time of imaging
3.0 – 4.4cm
Small
Repeat USS in 12 months time
4.5 – 5.4cm
Medium
Repeat USS in 3 months time
>5.5cm
Large
Vascular referral (and CT aortogram if a surgical candidate)
  The national screening program currently screens men aged 65 using ultrasound. The risk age group is men aged 65-80 and anyone with a family history of a first degree relative with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
Thus men older than 65, women with a family history and men younger than 65 with a family history are all also screened outside of the national screening programme if they are referred by a GP. Aneurysms are also picked up incidentally during abdominal scanning for any other reason, on USS and non-USS modalities.
GPT3_explain: CT aortogram in 6 months time is the correct choice because it is important to monitor the aneurysm closely to assess any changes in size or shape. A CT aortogram provides a detailed image of the aorta and can detect any changes that may have occurred in the aneurysm since the ultrasound. If the aneurysm is found to be growing or changing shape, the patient may need to be referred for further treatment.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best course of treatment?

This question falls under 3. A question about clinical management, what is the best course of treatment?

Qn_Text: A 58-year-old man with multiple myeloma presents with progressive dyspnoea and peripheral oedema undergoes a cardiac MRI scan. This shows global endocardial delayed hyperenhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Sarcoidosis cardiomyopathy
Involvement of the myocardium is relatively rare in sarcoidosis. Inflammation causes myocardial scarring of the interventricular septum and left ventricle most commonly. This shows as epicardial or midwall delayed hyperenhancement on MRI. 
  Ischaemic cardiomyopathy 
The blood supply to the heart muscle itself is of interest here. The endocardium derives its blood directly from the chambers whereas the layer referred to as the subendocardium receives blood from the terminal branches of the coronary vessels. By the time they reach the subendocardium these blood vessels are small enough that ventricular contraction causes a degree of compression. The end result is that the subendocardium is particularly vulnerable to ischaemia, a fact which manifests in the delayed hyperenhancement patterns seen on MRI; ischaemic cardiomyopathy is seen as subendocardial delayed hyperenhancement or in more extreme cases transmural hyperenhancement. The pattern of hyperenhancement is also territorial with ischaemic cardiomyopathy, depending on which vessel(s) has been affected.
  Amyloid cardiomyopathy 
Amyloidosis is a cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy. On MRI scanning there is global enhancement of the endocardium, and on echocardiogram the myocardium takes on a characteristic granular and speckled appearance. In an exam question setting a history of multiple myeloma, rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease or similar may be given to suggest secondary amyloidosis.
  Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)
HCM can be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion; there are a number of specific different gene mutations which have been identified to cause cardiac myocardial hypertrophy. The most common category is asymmetrical hypertrophy, accounting for around two thirds of cases. Here the interventricular septum is markedly enlarged. The remaining third of cases display symmetrical/concentric hypertrophy or apical hypertrophy. Patients are younger than most of those with ischaemic cardiomyopathy. On MRI scanning midwall hyperenhancement at the junction between the right and left ventricles is typical.
  Alcoholic cardiomyopathy 
Dilated cardiomyopathy occurs in patients with a history of alcohol abuse. There is dilation of both ventricles alongside thinning of the myocardium which appears hypokinetic on dynamic studies. Myocardial fibrosis occurs and because this typically affects the mid-myocardium it can be differentiated from ischaemic cardiomyopathy which is often transmural and confined to vascular territories. The different areas show delayed enhancement on MRI scans.
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis based on the cardiac MRI scan showing global endocardial delayed hyperenhancement is dilated cardiomyopathy. This type of cardiomyopathy is characterized by an enlargement of the heart chambers and a decrease in the heart's ability to pump blood. It is often caused by conditions such as coronary artery disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, and other heart diseases, but can also be caused by certain types of cancer, including multiple myeloma.

Qn_Text: A 15-year-old boy is studying for some science exams. While attempting to recall the bones in the arm he notices a subcutaneous fusiform mass on his forearm which is not present in the diagram in his book. His GP refers him for an ultrasound scan which shows the mass to bear a similar echogenicity to muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are many different minor accessory muscle possibilities at the wrist/forearm. The mass described has a similar reflectivity to muscle.
  Muscular hernia
Muscular hernias are more often seen in the lower limbs than the upper limbs. They can be diagnosed with ultrasound when a lump of muscle can be seen protruding through a defect in the containing fascia. Clinically a patient with a lump which disappears when the underlying muscle is tensed should raise the suspicion of a muscular hernia.
  Ganglion cyst
These are fluid-filled masses associated with musculoskeletal structures. They are most recognisable in the wrist. Due to pressure effects on locally adjacent nerves they can be associated with numbness. On imaging they behave as would be expected for cystic masses however owing to a variable protein content of the gelatinous content they can return high signal on T1 weighted MRI sequences.
  Giant Cell Tumour also known as osteoclastoma
These are benign bony tumours arising from within bone. They can cause bony expansion from within but not bony scalloping from without. Since they always occur in the mature skeleton they are seldom found in children or adolescent patients although the peak age group is still young; 30s. Typically they occur around the knee but can be found anywhere in the skeleton. They are seen on x-ray as expansile lytic lesions with the words ‘soap bubble’ often used to describe them in literature. On MRI they usually return low signal on both T1 and T2, in contrast to many of the potential differential diagnoses which would otherwise return high signal on one or the other.
  Four criteria of GCT (according to Clyde A. Helms)
After epiphyseal closure
Abuts articular surface
Well defined, non-sclerotic margin
Eccentric location
  Rhabdomyosarcoma
These are often aggressive lesions which can be found anywhere in the body. Although histologically they are formed of skeletal muscle derivation, they do not have to be in continuity with normal skeletal muscle. They tend to appear low in reflectivity on ultrasound. On MRI they follow muscle on T1 weighted sequences, but enhance avidly with gadolinium.
GPT3_explain: I chose this because a ganglion cyst is the most common type of subcutaneous mass found in the arm. It is a benign, fluid-filled cyst that is usually associated with a joint or tendon sheath. Ultrasound scans can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 2-week-old baby is brought in by his parents to the GP. They complain that their son cannot seem to keep anything down. The baby is found to be still losing weight and is referred urgently to the paediatricians. A barium meal is arranged and this shows a ‘double bubble’ sign with proximal duodenal dilatation and concentric luminal narrowing of the D2 segment. You notice a single palmar crease and classical Brushfield spots while examining the baby. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Annular pancreas
When the head and uncinate process of the pancreas (ventral pancreas) fail to migrate satisfactorily during embryological development they can fuse with the rest of the pancreas and encircle the duodenum. Around half of patients are diagnosed in childhood although the condition can remain asymptomatic and be picked up incidentally. In the neonatal period symptoms fit with duodenal obstruction and the classic ‘double bubble’ can be seen on fluoroscopy where contrast media can flow through the pylorus into the D1 segment of the duodenum but no further. Most cases are associated with other congential abnormalities such as trache-oesophageal fistula, malrotation or atresia of the duodenum or oesophagus and Down syndrome (i.e. single palmar crease, Brushfield spots) is also an associated syndrome.
GPT3_explain: Pyloric stenosis is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation of the baby. The double bubble sign on the barium meal is the classic sign of pyloric stenosis and is indicative of an obstruction at the pylorus. The single palmar crease and Brushfield spots are also associated with pyloric stenosis, further confirming the diagnosis.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 63-year-old man undergoes ultrasound to investigate deranged liver function tests. This demonstrates a smooth liver contour and normal echotexture but dilated hepatic veins and pulsatile flow in the portal vein. What is the most likely cause of these ultrasound findings? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The most common causes of portal venous pulsatility are right sided heart failure, tricuspid regurgitation and cirrhosis. Reversed flow is specific for portal hypertension. Absent flow is seen with thrombosis, tumour invasion. Stagnant flow is seen with severe portal hypertension.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2, Budd-Chiari syndrome, as the most likely cause of these ultrasound findings because it is characterized by the obstruction of the hepatic veins, resulting in dilated hepatic veins and pulsatile flow in the portal vein. This obstruction can be caused by a variety of factors, including thrombosis, tumors, or congenital malformations.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge to a clinical scenario.

2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 66-year-old man undergoes a CT scan of his adrenal glands for an incidental lesion picked up on a CT colonogram. The lesion is situated in the lateral limb of the left adrenal gland and is 2cm in diameter. It measures 21HU on the unenhanced sequence, 65HU on the portal venous phase and 50HU on the delayed sequences. You may use a calculator. What is the absolute washout of this lesion?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Figures have been rounded to the nearest whole number.
Absolute washout = (65-50)/(65-21) = 34%
Relative washout = (65-50)/65 = 23%
    This lesion is non-adenomatous and the patient should be referred for PET/CT or resection depending on the clinical scenario. In many centres, if the lesion measures less than 10HU on the unenhanced sequence then the study will be terminated at that point.
  Adrenal washout
Washout characteristics of adrenal nodules help confirm or refute a diagnosis of an adrenal adenoma. The absolute washout takes into account the initial uptake of contrast whereas the relative washout calculation is based only on how well contrast washes out of a nodule.
The underpinning principle is that vasculature within malignant lesions is more permeable than in benign lesions. This allows contrast to diffuse out of the lesion during the portal venous phase and the contrast is then slower to wash out during the delayed phase than it would be for benign lesions. Thus the higher/faster washout characteristics (either absolute or relative) the more suggestive it is that a lesion is benign.
GPT3_explain: The absolute washout of this lesion is calculated by subtracting the attenuation values of the delayed sequences from the attenuation values of the portal venous phase and then dividing by the attenuation value of the portal venous phase. In this case, the calculation is (65-50)/65 = 0.23 or 23%. Since washout is the opposite of this, the absolute washout of the lesion is (1-0.23) or 0.77 or 77%. Since washout is expressed as a percentage, the absolute washout of the lesion is 77% or 34%.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about interpreting images or other data. 

This question falls under option 3: A question about interpreting images or other data.

Qn_Text: A patient with troubling lower urinary tract symptoms is found to have a markedly raised PSA, but normal digital rectal examination of the prostate. Which of the following protocols is optimally concise but would enable full staging of a malignant lesion? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Axial, sagittal and coronal T2, axial T1, diffusion weighted imaging, axial dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
B: Axial, sagittal and coronal T1, axial T2, diffusion weighted imaging, axial dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
C: Axial and coronal T2, axial T1, sagittal FLAIR, diffusion weighted imaging, axial and coronal dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
D: Axial T1, coronal FLAIR, diffusion weighted imaging, axial, sagittal and coronal dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
E: Axial, sagittal and coronal T1, axial T2, diffusion weighted imaging
Explanation:
Explanation:
Three plane T2 imaging is common practice and enables full assessment of the peripheral zone of the prostate, particularly examining for extra-capsular extension, bladder base or seminal vesical invasion. T2 is also the most important sequence for lesions in the transitional zone.
Diffusion weighted imaging is essential for PIRADS calculation and is the first sequence that should be used to evaluate lesions in the peripheral zone. Axial dynamic contrast enhanced imaging (after non-contrast axial T1) is then essential to differentiate between between PIRADS 3 and 4 lesions.
The T1 weighted sequences are also useful to check for the presence of any haemorrhagic foci although since most patients now undergo their MRI scan prior to any biopsies being taken this has become far less important.
Interestingly the ADC map is more sensitive for carcinoma of the prostate (in the peripheral zone) than the DWI sequences. A finding of focal low signal on the ADC map may be seen in the absence of a corresponding high DWI focus. In the transitional zone however, the T2 sequences are more sensitive.

3. A question about clinical decision making, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: From the following, select the correct combination of ossification centre and the age at which it should be visible on a radiograph. Select one answer only.
B: Head of the radius at 5-7 years
Explanation:
Explanation:
The mnemonic CRITOL(or CRITOE) can be used to remember the order of appearance of the ossification centres at the elbow. This is usually most useful in confirming the presence of an avulsion fracture of the internal epicondyle; if the internal epicondyle is not visible but the trochlea is, then the internal epicondyle must be avulsed. The usual age brackets at which they form is given below but it is easier to remember them as 1,3,5,7,9 and 11 years respectively.
  1 year              (1)                  C = Capitellum also known as capitulum
3-5 years         (3)                  R = Radial head
5-7 years         (5)                  I = Internal / Medial epicondyle
5-7 years         (7)                  T = Trochlea
7-10 years       (9)                  O = Olecranon
11 years          (11)               L = External / Lateral epicondyle
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the head of the radius usually ossifies before the trochlea, capitulum, and epicondyles. The capitulum is the first of the four structures to ossify, usually appearing in the 3-5 year age range. The head of the radius usually appears in the 5-7 year age range, the trochlea in the 9-10 year age range, and the epicondyles in the 7-10 year age range.
Cat_Long: This question would fall under option 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: An 11-year-old previously healthy girl presents to a minor injuries unit with a 4 day history of headache, lethargy, malaise and sinus congestion. She suffers a seizure whilst being transferred from the minor injuries unit to the local paediatric centre. She undergoes a CT head scan which shows among other things a soft tissue density lesion overlying the supraorbital region of the frontal bone. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Pott puffy tumour
During an acute sinusitis there is bony erosion and subperiosteal abscess formation. Extracranially this causes forehead swelling, hence the name of this entity. Additionally there can also be the usual intracranial extension as a complication of frontal sinusitis, hence the presentation with seizures.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Pott Puffy Tumour because it is the most likely explanation for the soft tissue density lesion overlying the supraorbital region of the frontal bone. Pott Puffy Tumour is a rare, benign, intraosseous lesion of the frontal bone, which is most commonly found in children and adolescents. It is characterized by a soft tissue density lesion, which can cause headaches, lethargy, malaise, and sinus congestion. The seizure that the patient experienced is likely due to increased intracranial pressure caused by the lesion.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about a patient's presentation, history and examination.
