Qn_Text: A 22-year-old passenger in an RTA is discharged home after no major injuries are found. One week later she develops a painful left eye swelling and double vision with a third cranial nerve palsy. Angiography demonstrates early opacification of the left superior ophthalmic vein and a vascular blush. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is the classic presentation for a carotico cavernous fistula.
Moyamoya disease is progressive occlusion/arteritis of the distal ICA causing the formation of a large network of tiny collateral vessels seen on angiogram as a ‘puff of smoke’. It is predominantly found in children or young adults.
CADASIL (Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy). The typical patient is a youngish adult (30-50s) with recurrent TIAs/strokes, and/or psychiatric symptoms such as depression, psychosis. The classical area affected is the anterior temporal lobes and external capsules.
GPT3_explain: Carotico cavernous fistula (CCF) is the most likely explanation because it is a direct connection between the carotid artery and the cavernous sinus, which can cause a painful eye swelling and double vision with a third cranial nerve palsy. Angiography is the best diagnostic tool for CCF, as it can demonstrate early opacification of the left superior ophthalmic vein and a vascular blush.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about medical ethics.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old male patient complains to his GP about ongoing dysphagia. He has recently recovered from two separate lower respiratory tract infections and his GP is concerned about an oesophageal pathology. A barium swallow is arranged which demonstrates prominence of the crocopharyngeal muscle and a focal midoesophageal stricture with no associated shouldering. There is proximal dilatation and delayed clearance of barium. He undergoes a CT scan. There is a focal thickening of mid-oesophagus and some coarse calcification within it. What is the most likely aetiology of this stricture?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Oesophageal leiomyoma
Leiomyomas are said to be the only oesophageal lesions which can calcify. Generally, the absence of any shouldering of a stricture is a benign feature. Leiomyomas tend to arise in relatively young patients and are more common in the mid or distal thirds of the oesophagus. Ulceration is a very uncommon feature.
  Oesophageal carcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the oesophagus predominantly affects the middle and lower thirds of the oesophagus. Adenocarcinoma arises in the lower third, mostly in areas of Barrett oesophagus, and accounts for most oesophageal cancers in the developed world. Both histological types are more commonly found in the lower part of the oesophagus than the upper part, but that being said, if a cancer is found in the upper third of the oesophagus, it is most likely to be squamous cell in origin. Some patients develop symptoms of dysphagia and retrosternal pain but sadly many tumours remain occult until they are at an advanced stage. This is in-part due to the fact that there is no serosal layer protecting the oesophagus and as such cancers can progress rapidly. Patients found to have Barrett oesophagus (metaplasia of the usual squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium) are screened frequently for adenocarcinoma. Importantly in the staging criteria, the only nodes which contribute to nodal staging are the immediately local ones to the cancer. Any involved lymph nodes of the cervical chains or coeliac region are considered as metastatic disease. It is therefore important to review these areas on a staging scan with particular attention.
  Achalasia
This is a motility disorder which causes a failure of relaxation of the gastro-oesophageal junction (GOJ) and disorganisation of oesophageal peristalsis. Ingested material (including barium during fluoroscopy) is held up at the GOJ in a column. On a barium study the column has a classical bird-beak tapering point at the inferior-most end where it reaches the GOJ. There is often then sudden emptying of the oesophagus due to eventual pressure on the GOJ exceeding its strength. Oesophageal contractions may be absent or may be non-peristaltic. On a CXR an air-fluid level may be seen behind the heart.
  Aberrant right subclavian artery
This common anomaly occurs when instead of being the first major branch of the aorta (technically the first branches are the coronary arteries), the right subclavian artery arises distal to the left subclavian artery. It then has to swerve back around to reach the right side and in doing so usually runs posterior to the oesophagus, which can be seen on a barium study as a smooth indentation. In some cases it can exert sufficient pressure on the oesophagus to cause dysphagia which is termed dysphagia lusoria.
An aberrant left pulmonary artery is the ‘only’ vascular anomaly to run between the oesophagus and the trachea. There are cases of aberrancy of the right pulmonary artery in the literature however these patients tend to die in infancy.
An anterior indentation of the oesophagus is caused by:
An aberrant left pulmonary artery
A posterior indentation of the oesophagus is caused by:
A right sided arch with an aberrant left subclavian artery
A left sided arch with an aberrant right sided subclavian artery
A double aortic arch – this is usually described as also causing an anterior indentation to the trachea
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Barrett oesophagus is a condition that is characterized by the presence of a focal mid-oesophageal stricture, proximal dilatation, and delayed clearance of barium. Additionally, the CT scan revealed a focal thickening of the mid-oesophagus and some coarse calcification, which are both common findings in patients with Barrett oesophagus.

Qn_Text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents after they notice acute severe scrotal swelling, worse on the left side. The doctor in the department is worried he may have a testicular torsion but arranges an urgent ultrasound scan and review by the surgical team. The ultrasound scan shows a hypervascular and thickened scrotal wall with normal vascularity in the left testis and epididymis. There is a small left sided hydrocoele. The right testicle is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Acute idiopathic scrotal wall oedema syndrome
This occurs mostly in children under the age of 10 but can occur in adults too and is an important differential diagnosis for acute scrotal pain. It is thought to be a kind of localised hypersensitivity reaction. Scrotal swelling is typical but accompanying pain may or may not be present. Features are usually fairly typical on ultrasound with unilateral scrotal wall oedema (can be bilateral in 10%) and hypervascularity. Reactive hydrocoeles may be present, as with most scrotal pathology. Importantly, the condition requires no surgical input and can be managed conservatively with NSAIDs, avoiding an unnecessary surgery/anaesthetic for the patient when correctly diagnosed.
  Testicular torsion
Acute testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and in the prepubertal age bracket torsion is more common than infection as a cause of testicular pain. Even 180o of torsion can result in reduced blood flow, however complete ischemia is usually only seen in cases of >720degrees of torsion. Time is of essence; as early as three hours there will be some irreversibility within the testicle. Ideally the diagnosis should be made clinically and the patient taken straight to theatre without need for an ultrasound diagnosis. When an ultrasound is performed, either in the emergent setting or in cases of a misdiagnosis of epidiymo-orchitis the testicle can appear normal in echotexture, especially within the first 6 hours, thus a normal scrotal ultrasound does not rule torsion out. Diffuse hypoechogenicity is seen beyond this and heterogeneity suggests necrosis. Scrotal skin oedema occurs and is usually readily visible on ultrasound. With the advent of colour Doppler further information can be gleaned. Reduced signal in the spermatic cord and reduced testicular flow are both signs of torsion. Since venous occlusion occurs prior to arterial occlusion, apparently normal blood flow on colour Doppler does not exclude torsion.
  Bell-clapper deformity
This is the most common cause of testicular torsion. When the tunica vaginalis inserts high onto the spermatic cord, the testis is left hanging in a lateral position and takes on an appearance mimicking the central part of a bell, known as the clapper. In this position the testicle is more vulnerable to twisting on its axis with compromise to the blood flow leading to ischaemia.
  Epididymo-orchitis
Infection of the epididymis with concomitant infection of the testis is called epididymo-orchitis; it is seen most commonly in young adolescents with Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea accounting for most cases in this age range. In older patients E-coli and proteus are more likely to be responsible. Ultrasound is useful only in excluding testicular torsion as a cause of the pain (although a normal scrotal ultrasound does not exclude torsion), and investigating the possibility of abscess formation in cases refractory to antibiotic therapy. On ultrasound a reactive hydrocoele is often present and epididymal enlargement occurs. Colour Doppler flow can be used to demonstrate hyperaemia within the testicle and epididymis as would be expected for an infective process.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because Idiopathic scrotal wall oedema syndrome is the most likely diagnosis based on the description of the ultrasound scan. The scan showed a hypervascular and thickened scrotal wall with normal vascularity in the left testis and epididymis, indicating that the swelling was due to an increase in the size of the scrotal wall, rather than a torsion of the testicle or an infection in the epididymis. Additionally, the presence of a small left sided hydrocoele suggests that the swelling was due to an accumulation of fluid in the scrotum, which is a common symptom of idiopathic scrotal wall oedema syndrome.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a baby boy. There is splenomegaly and the splenic vein is tortuous. You notice tortuous vessels around the hepatic hilum. The hepatic and portal veins are patent but the hepatic artery shows a resistive index of 0.9. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Budd-Chiari syndrome is unusual in children and babies but can occur. It can be caused by haematological problems leading to thrombotic occlusion or as a result of a congenital membrane in the inferior vena cava distal to the liver, in which case the hepatic veins may appear patent.
  Budd-Chiari syndrome
The haemodynamics of the liver are different from any other organ, and can give rise to some interesting pathology. In Budd-Chiari syndrome venous obstruction causes flow reversal in the portal venous system to drain the liver. Acutely this presents as a triad of abdominal pain, ascites and hepatomegaly. In many acute cases the liver function tests have not had sufficient time to become deranged. The caudate lobe usually drains directly into the IVC so may not be affected by the underlying cause of obstruction to the other hepatic veins. Consequently it is able to shoulder more of the usual burden of the liver and becomes hypertrophied. In the acute setting this has not had time to manifest and the caudate lobe will be of a normal size.
  Some of the many causes of Budd-Chiari syndrome:
Thrombosis of the hepatic veins:
Platelets (thrombocytosis)
Pill (OCP)
Pregnancy (hypercoagulable state)
Polycythaemia rubra vera
Non-thrombotic causes:
Mechanical compression by a tumour
Right atrial myxoma
Constrictive pericarditis
  On CT the enhancement pattern is described as being ‘flip-flop’, with strong central and limited peripheral enhancement on early phases followed by early central washout with retained peripheral enhancement on delayed images. Alternatively the whole liver may appear mottled with a ‘nutmeg’ type pattern due to the venous congestion. On Doppler ultrasound or MRI the hepatic veins will show a reduction in calibre or not be seen at all and on Doppler insonation the hepatic veins may show little or no flow. Flow in the portal venous system, on the other hand, may be reversed. In chronic cases a veritable spiders-web of small collateral vessels can be seen on angiography; they can also be seen on MRI and are described as having a comma-shape.
GPT3_explain: The presence of splenomegaly, a tortuous splenic vein, tortuous vessels around the hepatic hilum, and a resistive index of 0.9 in the hepatic artery are all suggestive of Budd-Chiari syndrome, a condition in which occlusion of the hepatic veins leads to congestion and enlargement of the liver and spleen. This is the most likely diagnosis based on the given information.

Qn_Text: A 6-month-old baby girl presents in visibly severe discomfort with abdominal distention. She undergoes ultrasound which demonstrates a ‘pseudokidney’ appearance and intestinal intussusception is diagnosed. What is the most common type of intussusception?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Intussusception usually affects infants between the ages of 3 months and 3 years. The ileocolic type is the most common, followed by ileo-ileocolic. It is important to consider lead points: HSP (Henoch-Schonlein Purpura), Meckel’s diverticulum and duplication cysts are all possibilities. Another important facet to this condition is the management of intussusception. Reduction using a fluoroscopic-guided air enema (rather than barium) reduces the risk of faecal peritonitis and is the preferred management. The risk of perforation with this method is thought to be around 0.5%. Free air on plain film and clinical peritonitis are contraindications to pneumatic reduction by air enema.
GPT3_explain: Ileocolic intussusception is the most common type of intussusception, accounting for over 80% of cases. It occurs when the ileum (the last part of the small intestine) invaginates into the cecum (the first part of the large intestine), resulting in a blockage of the intestine.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the management of a clinical situation.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 22-year-old passenger involved in a road traffic collision. She makes an uneventful recovery but a week later complains of painful left eye swelling and a third nerve palsy. A CT head shows a prominent superior ophthalmic vein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is the classic presentation for a carotico cavernous fistula.
Moyamoya disease is progressive occlusion/arteritis of the distal ICA causing the formation of a large network of tiny collateral vessels seen on angiogram as a ‘puff of smoke’. It is predominantly found in children or young adults.
CADASIL (Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy). The typical patient is a youngish adult (30-50s) with recurrent TIAs/strokes, and/or psychiatric symptoms such as depression, psychosis. The classical area affected is the anterior temporal lobes and external capsules.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 1, Thyroid Eye Disease, as the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common cause of painful swelling and third nerve palsy in the left eye. The presence of a prominent superior ophthalmic vein on the CT scan is also consistent with this diagnosis. Other causes of this presentation, such as CADASIL, Orbital pseudotumour, Moyamoya disease, and Carotico cavernous fistula, are much less common and therefore less likely to be the cause.

Qn_Text: What is the name given to the line seen on a CXR formed by the interface of the parietal and visceral pleura anteromedially? Select one answer only:
Explanation:
Explanation:
The azygo-oesophageal recess is formed by the interface of the right lung and the mediastinal reflection of the azygos vein.
The anterior junctional line is formed by the meeting of the parietal and visceral pleura anteromedially.
The posterior junctional line is formed by the meeting of the pleural surfaces of the upper lobes behind the oesophagus.
The right paratracheal line is formed by the right wall of the trachea against the right lung.
The right paraspinal stripe is formed by the meeting of the right lung against the posterior mediastinal soft tissue.
GPT3_explain: The anterior junctional line is the name given to the line seen on a CXR formed by the interface of the parietal and visceral pleura anteromedially. This line is located at the junction of the anterior chest wall and the mediastinum, and is formed by the parietal and visceral pleurae of the lungs. It is a useful landmark for identifying the position of the lungs and the mediastinum on a CXR.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the interpretation of a radiographic image.

3. A question about the interpretation of a radiographic image.

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old man is investigated for blood mixed in with his stools. Sigmoidoscopy identifies a low rectal polyp with features suspicious for malignancy. It is completely excised and sent for histopathological assessment. At the local MDT, the pathologist reveals the histological diagnosis to be squamous cell carcinoma. What is the likely underlying diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
98% of rectal tumours are adenocarcinomas. If the diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma, HPV is usually the underlying diagnosis.
Cowden’s disease
Causes multiple hamartomas in the large and small bowel (and elsewhere in the body). Also associated with breast cancer.
Hereditary non-polyposis rectal cancer
Also known as Lynch syndrome; it is several times more common than FAP. Associated with colorectal cancer, but also multiple other malignancies such as ovarian, endometrial and urinary tract tumours.
Turcot syndrome
Intestinal polyps and glioblastoma are the key features of this syndrome.
McKittrick-Wheelock Syndrome
Villous adenoma causing hypochloremic hypokalaemia and hyponatraemia due to mucous diarrhoea. Usually affects old women.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2 because hereditary non-polyposis rectal cancer (HNPCC) is the most likely underlying diagnosis for a squamous cell carcinoma in the rectum. HNPCC is an inherited condition that increases the risk of developing colorectal cancer. The risk of developing a squamous cell carcinoma in the rectum is significantly higher in individuals with HNPCC than in the general population.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man suffers a knee injury while on a skiing holiday. He visits a local hospital and has x-rays taken of his knee. No fracture is found. Once back home he undergoes an MRI scan when the pain fails to resolve. The scan shows a tear of the medial collateral ligament and a sprain to the anterior cruciate ligament. High STIR signal is seen in the lateral femoral condyle and lateral tibial plateau too. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Bony contusions
Bruising to the bone can be detected around 2 days following an injury but may not resolve for many months thereafter. With regards knee injuries, it is often possible to discern the mechanism of injury from the pattern of bruising seen. The contusions follow fluid on MRI scans i.e. low in signal on T1 and high on T2 (and STIR). STIR is used to suppress the fat of the bone marrow thereby making the fluid stand out more.
  Clip injury and pivot shift injury
These two injuries are very similar. Both involve valgus stress on a flexed knee (such as a tackle to the knee during sports). A pivot shift injury also requires external rotation of the tibia. The three main structures most at risk during these injuries are:
Anterior cruciate ligament (especially in a pivot shift injury)
Medial collateral ligament (especially in a clip injury)
Medial meniscus (remember that the medial meniscus is attached to the medial collateral ligament)
If all three are present together it is referred to as the O’Donoghue triad. Since O’Donoghue defined this triad however, it has been discovered that lateral meniscal tears are actually more common with this type of injury than medial meniscus ones.
Bony contusions occur at the side of impact because the proximal tibia and distal femur impact on one another thus:
Lateral tibial plateau (posterolateral in pivot shift injury)
Lateral femoral condyle
  Transient lateral patella dislocation injury
When the patella dislocates laterally, its medial facet can impact onto the anterolateral corner of the lateral femoral condyle. Both areas become damaged and contusions can be seen on MRI. Often though, the patella reduces spontaneously and thus the exact mechanism of injury must be inferred from the imaging findings.
Joint effusion
Osteochondral injuries to the anterolateral femoral condyle and medial patella facet
Sprain or disruption to the medial retinaculum
  Hyperextension injury
These occur often following excessively forceful kicking. There will be bony contusions at the anterior aspect of the tibial plateau and femoral condyles. Either of the anterior or posterior cruciate ligaments may also be involved.
  Dashboard injury
As the name would suggest, this injury is usually stained by impact of the knee against the dashboard of a car during a road traffic incident. Force applied to the anterior aspect of the tibia when the knee is flexed leads to:
Osteochondral injury or fracture to the anterior aspect of the tibia
Posterior cruciate ligament rupture/sprain
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis in this case is a hyperextension injury. This is because the MRI scan showed a tear of the medial collateral ligament and a sprain to the anterior cruciate ligament, as well as high STIR signal in the lateral femoral condyle and lateral tibial plateau. All of these findings are consistent with a hyperextension injury, which is an injury that occurs when the knee is bent backwards beyond its normal range of motion.

Qn_Text: A 9-month-old boy undergoes an MRI scan for investigation of severe developmental delay. The scan demonstrates basal ganglia calcification with hydrocephalus. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The presence of hydrocephalus is key in this question, which should steer you away from the most common TORCH (CMV) and towards toxoplasmosis. The key features of the TORCH infections are below:
  Toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasmosis is a reasonable suggestion if there is hydrocephalus with the calcifications. Toxoplasmosis is the second most common TORCH infection after CMV.
  CMV
This is by far the most common TORCH infection (almost twice as common as all the others put together). Periventricular calcification is the most common finding. It is also commonly associated with polymicrogyria.
  HSV
Haemorrhagic infarction is a prominent feature of HSV, with subsequent encephalomalacia. It is usually HSV-2 rather than HSV-1.
  Rubella
Focal high signal in the white matter is the most common finding.
  HIV
Frontal predominant atrophy is the main feature with basal ganglia calcification.
GPT3_explain: Toxoplasmosis is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common cause of basal ganglia calcification and hydrocephalus in young children. It is caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, which is often acquired through contact with cat feces.

Qn_Text: A gentleman is seen in a neurology outpatient clinic with complaints of progressive memory loss and some movement problems. He subsequently undergoes an MRI scan of his brain. You suspect he may have a neurodegenerative condition. Which SINGLE one of the following findings is correctly matched to its condition?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Sparing of the hippocampi - Lewy body dementia
C: Disproportionate involvement of the hippocampi - Parkinson's disease
D: Blurring of structures in the midbrain - Alzheimer's disease
Explanation:
Explanation:
  Lewy body dementia
A core clinical feature to this dementia is the fluctuant nature of the symptoms. Parkinsonian features can also develop although these are usually subsequent to the memory decline. Visual hallucinations are also a feature. Radiologically there is a generalised decrease in cerebral volume (sparing the hippocampi). Temporo-parietal hypoperfusion on HMPAO Tc99m SPECT scanning is indicative of Lewy body dementia. Involvement of the occipital cortex, which is typically spared in Alzheimer's disease, sets the two apart from one another on PET studies. The cingulate island sign has also been ascribed to Lewy body dementia, where there is preservation of metabolism in the mid-posterior cingulate gyrus. If present, this is said to be specific for Lewy body dementia.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
    Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
There are three types of this prion transmitted disease; the one linked to the BSE (bovine spongiform encephalopathy) epidemic of the late 1980s and 1990s, a rare familial variant, and finally a sporadic version which accounts for the vast majority of the cases. Clinically there is a rapidly progressive dementia with ataxia and myoclonus which should be the give-away feature even before imaging features are discussed. On MRI, the reported finding is of high T2/FLAIR signal in the basal ganglia bilaterally and symmetrically (particularly the putamen). The pulvinar sign is often described in association with cJD which describes high FLAIR signal in the pulvinar thalamic nuclei (called the hockey stick sign). Strangely the signal changes are a rare cause of restriction of diffusion, seen as bright areas on DWI. Important negatives for this condition are the lack of enhancement with contrast and the lack of white matter involvement (since the white matter is protected by its myelin sheath).
  Huntington disease
There are relatively few radiological manifestations of Huntington disease. The usual one described is atrophy of the heads of the caudate nuclei with consequential prominence of the adjacent lateral ventricle frontal horns with a ‘box’ like appearance. Various studies have been done to quantify the extent of this atrophy.
  Alzheimer's disease
The radiological findings of this well known disease are diffuse sulcal and ventricular enlargement. There is a disproportionate effect to the anterior temporal lobes, hippocampi and sylvian fissures with sparing of the sensorimotor and visual cortices, thalami and cerebellum.
  Parkinson's disease
Generalised cerebral atrophy occurs with Parkinson's disease but is a highly non-specific feature. There are, however, radiological findings in the midbrain which although subtle, are far more specific. Parkinson's disease occurs when there is neuronal loss in the substantia nigra, specifically the pars compacta of the substantia nigra. On a T2 weighted MRI image this appears as blurring of the intermediate signal intensity line which separates the two adjacent low intensity structures (these are the pars reticulata of the substantia nigra and the red nucleus).
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the hockey stick sign on an MRI scan is a characteristic finding of Huntington disease. It is a sign of atrophy of the caudate nuclei and is seen in up to 90% of patients with Huntington disease.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A patient has been referred for an ultrasound scan with a probable rotator cuff tear following a recent fall. Which of the following muscles is LEAST likely to be damaged in this case? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The rotator cuff muscles are a group of four muscles that originate from the scapula and attach to the humeral head. Acting together these muscles act to hold the humeral head in the glenoid fossa, stabilizing the shoulder joint.
The rotator cuff comprises the following four muscles:
Supraspinatus
Infraspinatus
Subscapularis
Teres minor
  Anatomy of the shoulder showing teres minor, infraspinatus and supraspinatus (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: The supraspinatus is the least likely muscle to be damaged in this case because it is located at the top of the shoulder and is not usually involved in falls. The other muscles, such as the subscapularis, teres major, teres minor and infraspinatus, are all located in the lower part of the shoulder and are more likely to be affected by a fall.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: An 88-year-old man is admitted from his nursing home with abdominal pain and vomiting. On examination the admitting doctor is concerned that he may have a small bowel obstruction. He undergoes a CT scan and you have been asked to review the images urgently. The small bowel is dilated and a herniated loop emerges between the pectineus and obturator externus muscles. Which of the following would most accurately describe this situation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Abdominal wall hernias
Hernias can occur at any age but are increasingly prevalent with increasing age. Conditions which increase intra-abdominal pressures predispose patients to developing hernias. These might be entities such as constipation or respiratory conditions associated with excess coughing such as COPD.
Hernia
Landmarks
Feature
Femoral
Inferolateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to the femoral vein
More common in women
Direct inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle, medial to the inferior epigastric vein
Through Hesselbach triangle
Indirect inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle and lateral to the inferior epigastric vein
Most common abdominal hernia
Obturator
Between pectineus and obturator externus muscles, through the obturator foramen
Rare
Spigelian
Inferolateral abdominal wall defect, lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle
May be congenital and associated with cryptorchidism
  Indirect inguinal hernias pass through the inguinal canal, taking in both the deep and superficial rings as they do. The deep ring is lateral to the internal epigastric vessels.
Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the conjoint tendon medial to the internal epigastric vessels and enter the scrotal sac through the superficial ring. They pass through the Hesselbach triangle which is composed of the inferior epigastric vessels, rectus abdominus and the inguinal ligament.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Indirect inguinal hernia because this is the type of hernia that occurs when a loop of the small bowel protrudes through the internal inguinal ring and emerges between the pectineus and obturator externus muscles. This is the most common type of hernia, and it is usually seen in elderly men.

Qn_Text: A 48-year-old woman comes to your interventional department for drainage of a diverticular abscess. 10mls of 1% lignocaine is infiltrated and allowed to take effect but the patient continues to complain of pain. 5mls more of 1% lignocaine is infiltrated. How much more lignocaine can safely be given assuming the patient is of average weight? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The maximum dose of lignocaine is 3mg/kg.
The average weight of an adult is 70kg for men and 65kg for women giving doses of 210mg or 195mg respectively (i.e. around 200mg).
This relates to 19.5ml of 1% total or 9.75ml of 2%. She has already had 15ml of 1% so there is 4.5ml of 1% left available to give.
GPT3_explain: The maximum safe dose of lignocaine is 4 mg/kg of body weight. Since the patient has already received 15mls of 1% lignocaine, they have already reached their maximum safe dose and no more lignocaine should be given.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment?

3. A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment?

Qn_Text: A 52-year-old man presents to his GP with epigastric pain and weight loss. He has been taking a proton pump inhibitor for the last 6 months but says this is no longer helping. He is referred for a barium meal which shows multiple ulcers within the stomach and duodenum. The stomach is distended and the gastric folds are markedly thickened. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is a consequence of excess gastrin circulation, usually from a gastrinoma within the pancreas. There is marked hypersecretion of gastric acid which predisposes the patient to ulcer formation since the normal gastric mucosal coating becomes overwhelmed. Patients may also experience diarrhoea but hypoproteinaemia is not a feature. On a barium study, as well as gastric ulcers, there may be rugal enlargement and dilution of barium by the large volume of acid. Ulcers may be present at unusual locations such as the duodenal bulb and around the ligament of Treitz.
  Menetrier disease
A triad of gastric glandular hypertrophy, achlorhydia and hypoproteinaemia makes up this condition. The rugal folds become enlarged and bizarre in configuration; often said to more closely resemble the convolutions of the cerebral cortex than the usual parallel orientation of normal gastric folds. Within the stomach there is hypersecretion of mucus and albumin (hence hypoalbuminaemia) and this prevents the barium from coating the mucosal surface effectively. The antrum is said to be spared although in reality it is involved in around half of cases but where it is spared it serves as an important discriminatory against gastric lymphoma which often does involve the antrum, as well as coming with associated splenomegaly. In contrast to scirrhous carcinoma the stomach’s ability to distend is retained.
  Gastric lymphoma
Within the context of lymphomas of the gastro-intestinal tract, gastric lymphoma is the most common site. The infiltrative form can give pronounced thickening of the gastric wall but the stomach’s ability to distend is usually preserved. On a barium study rugal thickening may be evident but the degree of gastric wall thickening is unlikely to be evident. There is no particularly predisposed part of the stomach but typically more than half of the stomach wall area is affected, including antral involvement in most cases. Hypersecretion and hypoalbuminaemia are not features of this condition but associated splenomegaly is likely.
  Gastric carcinoma
There is a subtype of gastric carcinoma called scirrhous carcinoma where instead of forming a solitary large mass the cancer infiltrates the entire gastric wall causing thickening and shrinkage of the stomach as well as compromising its ability to distend. The term scirrhous comes from the Greek word for hard and relates to the fibrous indistensible change to the stomach wall. The stomach becomes leathery and aperistaltic with appearances said to resemble an old leather drinking bottle; this appearance on a barium study is given the term linitis plastica.
  Eosinophilic gastroenteritis
This is a relapsing, remitting condition caused by eosinophilic infiltration of the wall of the stomach. The small bowel can also be affected and when it is, there may be accompanying hypoproteinaemia. Involvement of the stomach however, brings ‘only’ abdominal pain, diarrhoea and weight loss. Patients often have a concurrent history of allergies, either to food stuffs or other antigens. Within the stomach the condition is usually confined only to the antrum and there may be rugal enlargement, polyps and ulcers present.
GPT3_explain: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a rare disorder characterized by the development of multiple peptic ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. It is caused by an overproduction of gastrin, a hormone that stimulates the production of stomach acid. The overproduction of gastrin leads to an increased acid production, which can cause the formation of ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. The barium meal in this case shows multiple ulcers in the stomach and duodenum, as well as a distended stomach and thickened gastric folds, which are all consistent with ZES. Therefore, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old with a history of malignant melanoma presents complains of a constant headache. He has also developed facial pain over the left side of his jaw and chin. A CT scan of his head demonstrates multiple destructive calvarial and skull base lesions. Given his symptoms, which skull base foramen is most likely to be involved by a metastatic deposit?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
These symptoms suggest involvement of V3, the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve which is responsible for sensation of the lower portion of the face, over the jaw and chin.
Below are the foramen and their relevant associated transmitted nerve:
Foramen ovale - mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve
Foramen rotundum - maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve
Foramen spinosum - no major nerve, middle meningeal artery
Superior orbital fissure - CN III, IV, V1, VI.
Hypoglossal canal - hypoglossal nerve
GPT3_explain: I chose Foramen ovale because it is the most likely foramen to be involved by a metastatic deposit in this case. The foramen ovale is located in the middle cranial fossa and is the largest of the three foramina of the middle cranial fossa. It is the only foramen in the middle cranial fossa that allows for direct communication between the middle and posterior cranial fossae. Since the patient is presenting with facial pain and destructive calvarial and skull base lesions, it is likely that the metastatic deposit is located in the middle cranial fossa and is causing pressure on the foramen ovale.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about problem-solving, how to solve a problem or how to manage a clinical situation?

This question falls under Category 3: A question about problem-solving, how to solve a problem or how to manage a clinical situation.

Qn_Text: A 63-year-old man undergoes at CT for investigation of abdominal discomfort. This demonstrates a 4 cm exophytic mass arising from the fourth part of the duodenum. There is evidence of central necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Gastrointestinal stromal tumour
Classically exophytic tumours which occur most frequently in the stomach but which can also arise in the proximal small bowel. Central necrosis is a key feature. The presence of metastases is a common feature at presentation (50%).
Small bowel adenocarcinoma
Usually found in the duodenum as focal circumference small bowel wall thicekning. Coeliac disease is a risk factor.
Lymphoma
Can have a variety of appearances, including exophytic, but it is usually infiltrative. This would be the second differential for the description in the question. Usually non-Hodgkins rathear than Hodgkins. Rarely obstruct even if large.
Carcinoid
Usually found in terminal ileum or appendix. Common features are a fibrotic, desmoplastic reaction with calcification.
GPT3_explain: Adenocarcinoma is the most likely diagnosis because of the exophytic nature of the mass, the presence of central necrosis, and the location of the mass in the fourth part of the duodenum. Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of malignant tumor that can occur in the duodenum.

Qn_Text: An 11-year-old boy has a mass in his right cerebellopontine angle. CT shows a lobulated homogeneous mass with CSF density. MRI shows low T1 signal and high T2 signal. There is restriction on diffusion weighted imaging and hyperintensity on FLAIR sequences. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are a few key features to cerebellopontine angle masses which help distinguish them from one another. In this particular question the combination of CSF density on CT with hyperintensity on FLAIR gives the game away. This is classic for an epidermoid cyst. Additionally, restricted diffusion is specific for an epidermoid cyst. A choroid plexus cyst is not a CP angle mass.
  For the usual differential diagnosis for CP angle masses the pertinent features are summarised in the table below. Where an asterisk has been used denotes a reasonably specific defining feature which can be used to pinpoint the diagnosis.
    Schwannoma (80-90%)
Meningioma (10-20%)
Epidermoid (5%)
Epicentre
IAC
Dura
CPA
CT density
Iso
Hyper or iso
Hypo
Calcification
*None
*Frequent
Occasional
IAC
*Wide
Normal or wide
Normal
T2 signal
Hyper
50% iso
Hyper
Enhancement
++
++
*None
Description
-
-
Lobulated
GPT3_explain: Schwannomas are the most common type of tumor found in the cerebellopontine angle in children. The imaging findings described (lobulated homogeneous mass with CSF density, low T1 signal and high T2 signal, restriction on diffusion weighted imaging, and hyperintensity on FLAIR sequences) are all consistent with a diagnosis of schwannoma.

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man undergoes a left pneumonectomy for lung cancer. He recovers well post-operatively and is reviewed in clinic shortly after discharge at two weeks post operation. Which of the following CXR appearances, if not seen pre-operatively, would not be expected at this time?
B: Complete opacification of the left hemithorax
C: An air fluid level in the left hemithorax at approximately two thirds of the way up the chest
Explanation:
Explanation:
Overall post-pneumonectomy changes are features of volume loss with fluid accumulation in the affected hemithorax.
As the now empty hemithorax gradually fills with fluid an air-fluid level is to be expected. This should reach approximately half-way up the chest on a CXR by day 4 or day 5 and should reach at least 66%, if not 100%, of the height of the chest on a CXR after a fortnight. Ipsilateral mediastinal shift also usually takes place owing to the volume loss although this is not an absolute finding; Some patients will have no mediastinal shift. Diaphragmatic elevation would be an expected finding, diaphragmatic flattening would not.
Post-operative complications of a pneumonectomy include:
5-10% bronchopulmonary fistula
Contralateral tracheal shift
Reduction in height of the fluid level on sequential films
5% ARDS
5% Pulmonary oedema
<5% empyema
Post-pneumonectomy syndrome
This occurs when hyperexpansion of the remaining lung displaces the heart, with rotation of the heart in an anticlockwise fashion along its long axis.
This develops in the first year and usually affects young adults or children. Patients develop exertional dyspnoea or recurrent infections
GPT3_explain: Diaphragmatic flattening would not be expected at this time because the diaphragm is still intact and functioning. The other four options would all be expected after a pneumonectomy, as the left lung is removed, resulting in complete opacification of the left hemithorax, an air fluid level in the left hemithorax, and a mediastinal shift to the left.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man with back pain is seen by an orthopaedic surgeon who requests x-rays. The x-rays show a number of findings which lead you to suspect he has ochronosis. Which SINGLE ONE of the following is a feature of ochronosis?
B: Rat bite erosions to the hands
Explanation:
Explanation:
Alkaptonuria (also known as ochronosis)
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is caused by excessive circulating levels of homogentisic acid (HGA) when the enzyme which would usually degrade it is deficient. HGA has an affinity for collagen and accumulates in the connective tissues throughout the body. In visible light HGA has a blackish colour and thus the disease can be diagnosed in infancy when a baby’s nappies are stained black by the presence of HGA in the urine. By the time patients reach their 20s pigmentation may be visible in their skin, particularly the ears. This is initially a dark yellow colour (hence the term ochronosis, from ‘Ochre’ in Greek meaning a dark yellow colour) but can progress to blue-grey and black.
In imaging chondrocalcinosis is the most prominent feature, with calcification and destruction of the intervertebral discs. Premature osteoarthritic changes to the hands, feet, shoulders, hips and knees will also develop as the collagen deteriorates. Deposition in the heart and kidneys too leads to cardiac and renal failure.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Hook like osteophytes because this is a common feature of ochronosis. Ochronosis is a rare inherited disorder caused by an enzyme deficiency which leads to the accumulation of a substance called homogentisic acid in the body. This substance can cause the formation of hook-like osteophytes in the spine and other bones.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old man complains to his GP of pain in both wrists. On examination his GP notices a salmon-pink patch of skin on his forearm. There is some silver coloured scale overlying the patch. Bilateral x-rays of the wrist are requested which show soft tissue swelling to the second and third digits with marginal erosions and periosteal new bone formation. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Psoriatic arthropathy
Around a fifth of patients with psoriasis develop arthropathy and it is also possible to suffer from psoriatic arthropathy in the absence of the typical psoriatic cutaneous plaques.
Importantly, on x-ray there are findings of both erosive changes in addition to productive changes with periosteal new bone formation. The combination of the two contrives to leave a ‘pencil-in-cup’ appearance. The joints can appear fluffy due to the exuberance of new bone formation.
The differential diagnosis for periosteal reactions in the presence of an arthropathy is relatively narrow and very specific:
Psoriatic arthropathy
Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
Reiter syndrome
Infective arthritis
  Although often classified as a distal arthropathy, preferring the DIPs to the MCPs, psoriatic arthropathy does also affect the spine and SI joints frequently. ‘Sausage digits’ is a term used to describe the diffuse soft tissue swelling which can affect the fingers and toes. Osteoporosis does occur but is a feature of later disease.
GPT3_explain: Rheumatoid arthritis is the most likely diagnosis because the symptoms (pain in both wrists) and findings (salmon-pink patch of skin on the forearm with silver colored scale, soft tissue swelling to the second and third digits, marginal erosions, and periosteal new bone formation) are all characteristic of this condition. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder which causes inflammation of the joints and can lead to joint destruction and deformity.

Qn_Text: A 49-year-old man with painless discharge and hearing loss undergoes a CT scan which shows a soft tissue mass in the middle ear. Erosion of which structure would be LEAST supportive of a diagnosis of cholesteatoma?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Certainly the ossicles, lateral semicircular canal (Known by some as the Clint Eastwood sign) and lateral epitympanic wall (ie scutum) are often involved. Of the ossicles, the long process, lenticular process of the incus and the head of the stapes are commonly involved. The tegmen tympani is the roof of the middle ear and is also often involved. It can be seen superior to the ‘ice cream cone’ on coronal images. The tegmen mastoidium is the roof of the mastoid and is seen laterally to the tegmen tympani. The facial nerve canal is closely associated with the middle ear structures but the cochlear aqueduct runs medially from the cochlear and is therefore less likely to be affected by a cholesteatoma.
There are two types of acquired cholesteatoma:
                Pars flaccid – classically erodes the scutum
                Pars tensa – classically erodes the ossicles
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a cholesteatoma is a type of skin growth that often grows behind the eardrum and can cause erosion of the surrounding structures. The scutum is a thin bone located in the middle ear that separates the tympanic cavity from the mastoid antrum, and it is not typically affected by cholesteatomas.
Cat_Long: This question falls under the category of clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man is involved in a high-speed road traffic accident. He sustains a significant head injury and a CT head is performed. This shows intracranial blood within the fissures at the vertex, crossing suture lines, but which does not cross the midline. Which of the following would best explain these findings? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Blood being present within the fissures suggests subarachnoid origin.
  The learning point here is how a haemorrhage deals with the sutures. Extradural (aka epidural) haematomas do cross the midline but do not cross suture lines as this is where the dura is attached to the skull. Subdural haematomas on the other hand do not cross the midline but do extend along the falx, dipping down and affecting both sides of the falx cerebri on the coronal views for example. Combined haematomas (ie extradural and subdural) are possible but on balance the question seems to imply that it is one haematoma rather than two with separate properties for each.
A subarachnoid haemorrhage can be seen as high density on CT within the small fissures on the surface of the brain, as well as into the larger fissures such as the interhemispheric fissure. Obviously very small subarachnoid haemorrhages can be very hard to spot on CT scans and a high index of suspicion is required.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because a subdural haematoma is the most likely explanation for the CT findings of intracranial blood within the fissures at the vertex, crossing suture lines, but which does not cross the midline. Subdural haematomas are caused by head trauma and are characterized by collections of blood between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane. They can range in severity from small collections of blood to large collections that can cause significant brain compression.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about understanding a clinical scenario.

Explanation:
Explanation:

Section of colon Anterior relations Posterior relations
Ascending colon
Anterior abdominal wall
Small intestine

Quadratus lumborum
Iliacus
Right kidney
Iliohypogastric nerve
Ilioinguinal nerve
Transverse colon

Greater omentum
Duodenum
Jejunum
Ileum
Head of pancreas
Descending colon
Anterior abdominal wall
Small intestine

Left kidney
Iliohypogastric nerve
Ilioinguinal nerve

Urinary bladder
Uterus (females)
Upper vagina (females)

GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Iliohypogastric nerve because it is located in front of the descending colon. The iliohypogastric nerve is a sensory nerve that originates in the lumbar plexus and supplies sensation to the skin of the lower abdomen. It runs along the iliac crest and passes in front of the descending colon.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 78-year-old lady falls while walking her dog and a fractured neck of femur is suspected. She has a history of stage III node negative breast cancer dating back 15 years. The pelvic x-ray shows multiple small sclerotic foci in the pelvic girdle and both femora, which are subsequently found to have slightly increased uptake on a bone scan. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
  Osteopoikilosis
This benign condition leads to multiple small oval bone islands forming around the skeleton. It usually looks absolutely characteristic and review of old films would confirm the diagnosis, however it has been (deliberately) poorly described in the question.  Frustrating though this may be, it is reflective of the nature of some of the questions in the exam.
Purportedly, once the epiphyses have fused the number remains static. They can (albeit rarely, such that many sources say ‘never’ happens) show mildly increased uptake on a nuclear medicine bone scan. Whereas a bone island may exist in isolation or near isolation, the finding of multiple such lesions suggests the diagnosis of osteopoikilosis.
  Since osteopoikilosis is a condition consisting of multiple bone islands, the answer option of 'bone islands' is also technically correct. Given the choice (arguably unfair though it may be) between these two options, osteopoikilosis is a more specific entity and deemed to be correct in this case.
GPT3_explain: Metastases is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common cause of sclerotic foci in the pelvic girdle and femora, and because the patient has a history of cancer. Bone islands, multiple myeloma, osteopoikilosis, and stress fracture are all less likely diagnoses in this case.

Qn_Text: A 5-day-old baby boy is referred to the Emergency Department by the health visitor, who is concerned about his breathing. He is cyanosed and requires prompt intubation on arrival. A radiograph shows a normal heart size but bilateral air-space opacities. The pulmonary vasculature appears normal. Which of the following cardiac conditions is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR)
Anomalous pulmonary venous return can be partial or total. In the latter, the oxygenated blood returning from the lungs fails to drain into the left side of the heart but reaches the right side of the heart by other avenues. Such babies are dependent on a right-to-left shunt (usually an ASD). TAPVR is not a duct-dependant condition (which usually present around day 4-5 when the duct closes) but can also present in the very early neonatal period with unstable cyanosis.
Most patients with this condition return the oxygenated blood from the lungs to the right side of the heart via either the brachiocephalic veins or the coronary sinus. Excessive pressures on the lungs cause pulmonary plethora and, if not picked up antenatally or neonatally, can compensate for the initial few weeks and months. Owing to the prominence of the supracardiac vasculature, the appearance on a chest radiograph is said to resemble a snowman.
In the case of infradiaphragmatic TAPVR, the venous return from the lungs is via the portal vein or IVC. As the anomalous pulmonary vein passes through the diaphragm (at the oesophageal hiatus) it becomes compressed, leading to an acute presentation in the early neonatal period with pulmonary oedema. The heart size is usually normal and the patient may not have developed plethora by the time of presentation. Of importance to note, some patients with infradiaphragmatic TAPVR may benefit from prostaglandin therapy helping to maintain the ductus venosus in the abdomen. Depending on the exact anatomy of the anomalous venous drainage, the ductus venosus may be critical for circulation in a small number of these patients.
      Congenital Cyanotic Heart Disease © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: Pulmonary atresia with a VSD is the most likely diagnosis because the radiograph shows bilateral air-space opacities and a normal heart size. Additionally, the pulmonary vasculature appears normal, which indicates that the pulmonary arteries and veins are intact. Pulmonary atresia with a VSD is a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary valve is closed and there is a ventricular septal defect (VSD) between the two ventricles. This allows blood to flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, but not to the pulmonary artery. As a result, the lungs are not perfused and the baby becomes cyanosed.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the MRI brain of a patient with known Alzheimer’s disease. Which of the following is NOT part of the limbic system? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is NOT part of the limbic system.
  The limbic system
The limbic system is a complex network of connections between a number of important different regions of the brain. It has roles in emotion, learning, memory, affective disorders and some dementias to name but a few.
  Components of the limbic system:
Cortical structures
The olfactory cortex
Parahippocampal gyrus
Hippocampus
Cingulate gyrus
Subcallosal gyrus
  Subcortical structures
Amygdala
Septum pellucidum
Hypothalamus
Anterior thalamic nuclei
Mamillary bodies
  Two structures bear particular importance in the imaging of dementia; the precuneus and the cingulate gyrus. Both are best appreciated on sagittal views.
Precuneus: The precuneus is located on the medial surface of each hemisphere, in the posterior parietal lobe. It has functions in motor planning, working memory and also connections to the visual pathways.
The cingulate gyrus: The cinculate gyrus is also located on the medial side of each hemisphere and runs anteroposteriorly just above the corpus callosum. The cingulate gyrus has complex functions to do with learning, emotional response and memory.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Thalamus because the thalamus is not part of the limbic system. The limbic system is a group of interconnected structures in the brain that are responsible for emotion, memory, motivation, and other functions. It includes the hippocampus, amygdala, cingulate gyrus, and precuneus.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge, what is the best course of action?

1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: Which of the following structures passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening? Select ONE answer only.
A: Branches of the right phrenic nerve
Explanation:
Explanation:
The diaphragm has three main openings:
The caval opening: passes through the central tendon
The oesophageal hiatus: situated in the posterior part of the diaphragm, to the left of the central tendon through the muscular sling of the right crus
The aortic hiatus: situated in the posterior part of the diaphragm, between the left and right crus
  The main openings in the diaphragm and their contents are shown in the table below:
  Opening
Vertebral level
Contents
Caval opening
T8
Inferior vena cava
Branches of right phrenic nerve
Oesophageal hiatus
T10
Oesophagus
Anterior vagal trunk
Posterior vagal trunk
Oesophageal branches of left gastric vessels
Aortic hiatus
T12
Aorta
Azygous veins
Thoracic duct
        Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of OpenStax College CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: The azygous veins are the only structure listed that passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening. The vagal trunks, thoracic duct, and branches of the right phrenic nerve do not pass through the diaphragm via the caval opening. The oesophagus does not pass through the diaphragm at all.

3. A question about a procedure, what is the correct technique?

Qn_Text: A 13-year-old boy presents with acute abdominal pain. He has a fever and marked nausea. He is tender in the right iliac fossa. You suspect a diagnosis of acute appendicitis. What is the commonest position of the tip of the appendix? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The appendix is a narrow, worm-shaped, blind-ended tube that is attached to the posteromedial end of the caecum. It has a short triangular mesentery called the mesoappendix that suspends it from the mesentery of the terminal ileum.
It contains a large quantity of lymphoid tissue but serves no important function in humans. The position of the free-end of the appendix is highly variable. There are five main locations at which it can be found, the two commonest being the retrocaecal and subcaecal positions.
The distribution of positions is as follows:
Ascending retrocaecal (64%)
Subcaecal (32%)
Transverse retrocaecal (2%)
Ascending preileal (1%)
Ascending retroileal (0.5%)
    Distribution of the position of the appendix tip (from An Atlas of Anatomy by John Charles Grant)
GPT3_explain: The ascending retrocaecal position of the appendix is the most common position, accounting for approximately 60-70% of cases. This position is characterized by the appendix being located in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, behind the cecum, and extending towards the right iliac fossa. This position is associated with the typical presentation of acute appendicitis, which includes fever, abdominal pain, and marked nausea.
