Qn_Text: A 70-year-old man undergoes an MRI scan of the base of his skull. He has previously undergone surgery for a left sided cholesteatoma and the surgeon is concerned there may be a recurrence. Within the surgical cavity on the left there is a mass which does not enhance on the post-contrast sequences. On the DWI sequences there is no restriction of diffusion. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Otitis media causes fluid signal to be seen within the middle ear or middle ear cavity following a cholesteatoma resection.
Cholesteatomas are difficult to manage as they have a high recurrence rate. Imaging has a significant role to play in the management of recurrent cholesteatomas; distinguishing recurrence from post-operative granulation tissue or fluid is important.
  Diagnosis Restricts Diffusion Enhances
Recurrent cholesteatoma Yes No
Granulation tissue No Yes
Fluid No No
  Post-contrast sequences for recurrent cholesteatomas require a delay of around 45 minutes from giving the contrast to acquiring images as the granulation tissue is slow to take up contrast. This has obvious down-sides to any modern day busy MRI schedule. However since the management of post-operative granulation tissue and post-operative fluid is largely identical, namely expectant, it is not important to differentiate the one from the other. Thus findings on diffusion weighted sequences are the most important thing in post-operative cholesteatoma imaging.
  Cholesteatoma
Cholesteatomas (Acquired or congenital) are histolologically epidermoid cysts. On imaging the finding of non-dependant soft tissue and bony erosion within the middle ear is typical for a cholesteatoma.
There are two types of acquired cholesteatoma:
Pars flaccida (80%) – classically erodes the scutum and extends superiorly
Pars tensa (20%) – classically erodes the ossicles, extending medially
  These refer to the two parts of the tympanic membrane from which they arise.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  In due course, if left unattended, a cholesteatoma will expand to fill the entire middle ear. Prior to this point they can be seen as non-dependant soft tissue within the middle ear. Dependant soft tissue within the middle ear suggests the presence of fluid or pus and the diagnosis of a middle ear infection. Once a cholesteatoma has filled the middle ear completely however no gas remains from which to discern dependency.
There are a number of theories as to how cholesteatomas arise. One theory is that following a perforation of the tympanic membrane entry of desquamated stratified keratinised squamous epithelium from the external auditory canal into the middle ear is permitted. There it adheres to the tympanic membrane and proliferates unrelentingly causing a soft tissue mass to form and eventually leading to bony erosion of the ossicles, scutum and/or other parts of the middle ear.
A congenital cholesteatoma behaves in a similar manner but is present from birth due to an aberrant location of a tiny island of keratinised squamous epithelium.
  Cholesterol granuloma
A cholesterol granuloma occurs as a sequela of recurrent bouts of otitis media. Haemorrhage within the middle ear leads to the formation of granulation tissue. On imaging this is seen as non-specification of the middle ear on CT. Bony changes can occur chronically with bony expansion, or displacement and even destruction of the ossicles. The signals characteristics on MRI are therefore important to distinguish it from a cholesteatoma. Whereas a cholesteatoma on MRI is isointense to brain parenchyma on T1, a cholesterol granuloma will show high signal in the middle ear on T1 due to the paramagnetic effects of methaemoglobin. On clinical examination the ENT surgeon may report a bulging blue tympanic membrane. This is classical. Dehiscence of the jugular bulb is an important differential diagnosis to exclude as this will also give a blue tympanic membrane on examination but the management is radically different!
  Aberrant internal carotid artery
An aberrant internal carotid artery can cause a pulsatile mass in the middle ear. The question usually asked on this topic is slightly different and to do with the persistent stapedial artery and consequential aplastic foramen spinosum (anatomically – ‘the heel of the high-heeled shoe’). The stapedial artery in such cases arises from the internal carotid artery and runs through the stapes, becoming the middle meningeal artery (which usually arises from the external carotid artery and courses through the foramen spinosum).
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis based on the given information is recurrent cholesteatoma. This is because the mass does not enhance on post-contrast sequences and there is no restriction of diffusion on DWI sequences. These two characteristics are consistent with recurrent cholesteatoma, which is a benign growth that can occur in the middle ear cavity after surgery. Other diagnoses, such as otitis media, aberrant internal carotid artery, granulation tissue, and glomus tumour, do not typically present with these characteristics.

Qn_Text: A 20-year-old man who has been experiencing symptoms of tiredness and malaise for the last 6 months presents to his GP. His GP requests some basic blood tests and among other abnormalities these show that his kidney function is very poor. On examination there are enlarged axillary lymph nodes and hepatosplenomegaly is evident. He undergoes an ultrasound scan which also shows both his kidneys to be enlarged and echogenic. Which of the following best explains the appearances of the kidneys?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The vignette suggests that the patient has lymphoma however the ultrasound appearances of renal lymphoma do not fit with those provided. Of the other options provided, both HIV (where patients are at greater risk of developing lymphoma) and amyloidosis (occuring secondary to lymphoma) could give the ultrasound appearances described however HIV nephropathy although associated renal parenchymal hyperechogenicity, is unlikely to be the presenting feature of the HIV infection.
  Renal amyloidosis
Amyloidosis can be either primary or secondary and Hodgkin lymphoma can be a cause of secondary amyloidosis. Renal amyloidosis usually presents as nephrotic syndrome (proteinuria, hypoalbuminaemia, hyperlipidaemia). Imaging features can be relatively classical, causing bilateral renal enlargement and increased echogenicity. The combination of these two features should make you think of amyloidosis. Most renal pathology causes reduced echogenicity so amyloidosis stands almost alone in this respect. Nephrocalcinosis is the obvious other textbook cause of increased echogenicity and the differential diagnosis is longer in the paediatric age range. 
  HIV
Patients with HIV are more at risk of developing lymphoma so the scenario would also fit in that respect. HIV nephropathy tends to arise in patients with a low CD4 cell count and is not a usual de novo presentation of the virus. HIV nephropathy cannot be diagnosed by ultrasound alone, and a renal biopsy should be performed for confirmation however the kidneys of a patient affected by HIV nephropathy can be enlarged and the renal parenchyma can become more echogenic than usual. The sinus fat, however, becomes oedematous and therefore hypoechoic.
  Renal lymphoma
Renal lymphoma may be seen as an incidental finding or in the context of a pre-existing non-Hodgkin lymphoma study. Involvement of the kidneys can be either via haematogenous spread or direct extension from retroperitoneal lymph nodes. The appearances on CT tend to fall into one of a few different categories despite there being little difference in the type of lymphoma.
By far the most common pattern is that of multiple bilateral masses. The masses tend to enhance poorly with contrast and are therefore seen as low attenuation against the normal renal parenchyma.A large solitary mass mimicking a renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is another type of renal lymphoma presentation. These will usually be more homogenous in appearance than an RCC although there is much overlap in appearances of the two.
Contiguous retroperitoneal extension can appear quite drastic on a CT scan. Often associated with bulky lymph nodes in the retroperitoneum there is a homogeneous soft-tissue mass encasing the renal vessels which can usually still be seen running through the mass even when it is significantly large.
Perirenal disease is odd in so far as it can leave the renal parenchyma itself relatively unharmed. It appears as low attenuation surrounding the kidney at may at first casual glance, be mistaken for a urinoma.
Infiltrative disease can be a subtle finding when there is bilateral renal enlargement. The key finding is that although enlarged, the kidneys retain their ‘reniform’ shape. Infiltrative lymphoma is the most likely of the above to cause a decline in renal function. Usually kidneys infiltrated with lymphoma would appear hypoechoic, not echogenic.
  Leukaemia
Leukaemia type
Age
Prognosis
Radiology
Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (ALL)
  0-4yrs
Good for <14yrs, worse with increasing age thereafter
Xray - Periosteal reaction and permeative destruction
  MRI - Hypointense bone marrow on T1 due to replacement of fatty marrow + hepatosplenomegaly
  CNS - Cerebral haemorrhage, dural sinus thrombosis and leukaemic meningitis
Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (AML)
  >85yrs
OK for <14yrs, worse with increasing age thereafter
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)
  >85yrs
Approx 70-75% 5yr survival
Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia (CML)
  >85yrs
Approx 70-75% 5yr survival
  Castleman disease
This disease causes significant lymph node enlargement either in one compartment or, often when associated with HIV infection, in multiple different locations at once. The typical age range tends to be 30s-40s for unicentric disease or 40s-50s for multicentric disease. Most often it is discussed as a cause of isolated mediastinal lymph node enlargement but it can also affect the abdomen. When multicentric, hepatosplenomegaly is often a feature. On CT an enhancing rim to the lymph nodes is seen, indicative of the vascular capsule surrounding the nodes. Renal involvement is rare.
GPT3_explain: I chose lymphoma because lymphoma is a type of cancer that can cause enlarged lymph nodes and hepatosplenomegaly, as well as enlarged and echogenic kidneys on ultrasound scans. It can also cause symptoms of tiredness and malaise, which the patient has been experiencing for the last 6 months.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about practical application, how to apply a procedure or a treatment?

This question falls under Category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old woman is seen in A+E after falling on her outstretched hand. The lateral wrist radiograph clearly shows a bony fragment at the dorsum of the hand. A fracture of which bone is most likely?
Explanation:
Explanation:
A bony fragment at the dorsum of the wrist is likely to be either from the triquetrum or the hamate. The latter will lie more superiorly and is far less common than a triquetrum fracture. Of the carpal bones, the scaphoid is most frequently fractured, followed by the triquetrum.
GPT3_explain: I chose Triquetrum because it is the bone located at the dorsum of the hand. It is a small, triangular bone located between the hamate and lunate bones in the wrist. It is one of the eight carpal bones in the wrist joint and is the most commonly fractured carpal bone.

Qn_Text: A 67-year-old overweight man presents with lower back pain. On examination he has weakness of ankle dorsiflexion, eversion and inversion as well as weakness of hip abduction. His GP thinks he may have a problem with an intervertebral disc protrusion. At which level is this most likely to be?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is a straightforward anatomy question. In the cervical spine the nerve roots exit above their named vertebral body; thus at the level of C4/5 it is the C5 which will be exiting. This is unlike the lumbar spine where the nerve root exits below its named vertebral body and is explained by the presence of 8 cervical nerve roots with only 7 cervical vertebra.
There is also the concept of the exiting nerve root and the descending nerve root. This applies in particular to disc bulges/protrusions/extrusions and is more pertinent in the lumbar spine. The exiting nerve root at a given level will be one less than the descending nerve root. (ie at L2/3 the exiting nerve will be L2 and the descending nerve will be L3). Central disc pathology affects the descending nerve whereas paramedian or foraminal disc pathology may affect the exiting nerve.
  Level
Exiting nerve root
Descending nerve root
Muscles, reflexes and sensation of exiting root
L1/2
L1
L2
Iliopsoas and hip adductors, anterior thigh sensation
L2/3
L2
L3
Iliopsoas and hip adductors, medial thigh and knee sensation
L3/4
L3
L4
Quadriceps, patella reflex, sensation over knee and shin
L4/5
L4
L5
Dorsiflexion of the foot, ankle eversion, sensation to medial calf
L5/S1
L5
S1
Hip extension, extension of the big toe, ankle inversion, ankle reflex, sensation to sole of foot
    Image © Medical Exam Prep
  In this question the clinical information suggests involvement of both the L4 and L5 nerves. The level at which both of these could be affected by the same disc is L4/L5.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the L4/L5 intervertebral disc is the most common site for a disc protrusion due to the increased load placed on this disc from the weight of the upper body. Additionally, the patient's symptoms of lower back pain and weakness of ankle dorsiflexion, eversion, and inversion, as well as weakness of hip abduction are all consistent with a disc protrusion at the L4/L5 level.

Qn_Text: A 60-year-old man undergoes ultrasound for investigation of bilateral testicular lumps. Ultrasound reveals bilateral poorly defined areas of low echogenicity suspected to be metastases. Which of the following is the most likely primary malignancy? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
A mass in the testes of patient older than 50 is more likely to be a secondary tumour than a germ cell tumour. Prostate (35%) is the most common tumour to metastasize to the testicle, followed by lung, then melanoma, colon and renal.
GPT3_explain: Multifocal germ cell tumours are the most likely primary malignancy in this case because they are the most common type of malignancy to spread to the testes. These tumours are often found in young men and are associated with a high risk of metastasis. Ultrasound findings of bilateral poorly defined areas of low echogenicity are highly suggestive of metastatic disease, and in this case, the most likely primary malignancy would be a multifocal germ cell tumour.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a long history of temporal lobe epilepsy. An MRI scan of the brain reveals atrophy as well as high signal of the left hippocampus on T2-weighted and FLAIR images. The boy’s parents report that he used to suffer from prolonged febrile convulsions in childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Mesial temporal sclerosis
This is a specific pattern of hippocampal neuronal loss with associated gliosis and atrophy. On MRI there is high T2 signal which is best seen on coronal sequences. Refractory epilepsy is a classical history.
  Limbic encephalitis
The limbic system comprises the olfactory tract, temporal lobes, cingulated gyrus and insular cortex. Limbic encephalitis has either a paraneoplastic aetiology or an autoimmune one. Involvement of the mesial temporal lobes is classical. In the case of a paraneoplastic syndrome the classical cause is a lung tumor, specifically bronchial small cell lung cancer. Of the other options provided breast cancer has also been found to be associated with limbic encephalitis but is far less classical. Other possible options would have been thymic and testicular cancers. Psychotic features are prevalent and serve well to distinguish limbic encephalitis from HSV encephalitis although there is often overlap in the literature. Limbic encephalitis will show no haemorrhage which can also differentiate it from HSV encephalitis.
  Herpes simplex encephalitis
HSV encephalitis in immunocompetent individuals usually gives a classical appearance of high T2 signal particularly affecting the temporal and frontal lobes but also with a predilection for the rest of the limbic system too. It would however have a more acute history than that provided. Presentation as seizures would not be unusual though. Cytotoxic oedema can cause a degree of mass effect and also restriction of diffusion on DWI. There is a classical feature to separate it from Japanese encephalitis which is sparing of the basal ganglia.
One of the main differential diagnoses for HSV encephalitis would be a low grade glioma.
  Low grade glioma (of the hippocampus)
Low grade tumours can be readily missed on imaging, particularly non-related imaging (ie as an incidental finding on an MRI IAMs). There is often little or no mass effect and may be no appreciable contrast enhancement. T2 hyperintensity is a factor of peri-lesional oedema which may also be absent. The border between these tumours and normal cerebral tissue can be radiologically invisible. An association with localised cerebral atrophy is not a feature though, making it an unlikely choice for this question.
  Hashimoto encephalopathy
This is a very rare condition relating to hashimoto thyroiditis. MRI studies of the patients whose case reports are described in the literature have shown high T2 signal to the frontal and temporal lobes but there is little else here to commend this as a viable answer.
GPT3_explain: Mesial temporal sclerosis is the most likely diagnosis in this case, as it is a common cause of temporal lobe epilepsy and is associated with a history of prolonged febrile convulsions. MRI scans of the brain in patients with mesial temporal sclerosis typically show atrophy of the hippocampus and high signal intensity on T2-weighted and FLAIR images.

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old man collapses while playing golf. On arrival at the Emergency Department the blood pressure in his arms is found to be different. He is thought to have suffered a stroke and undergoes carotid Doppler study. The sonographer believes he may have subclavian steal syndrome. Which of the following findings regarding subclavian steal syndrome is INCORRECT? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: There is a filling defect in the subclavian vein
B: The most common cause is atherosclerosis
D: It can be caused by Takayasu aortitis
E: There is flow reversal in a vertebral artery unilaterally
Explanation:
Explanation:
Subclavian steal syndrome occurs when blood supplying the arm (usually the left arm) travels via the ipsilateral vertebral artery in order to bypass a proximal obstruction of the subclavian artery. The distal subclavian artery ‘steals’ blood from the vertebral artery circulation. This gives rise to two different categories of symptoms:
Arm - weaker pulses, numbness, paraesthesia, fingertip necrosis
Brain - syncope, ischaemic symptoms
The most likely cause of subclavian steal would be atherosclerosis. Takayasu aortitis and aortic dissections can also cause subclavian steal but would not be at the top of a differential list without further prompts from the history.
GPT3_explain: Subclavian steal syndrome presents with symptoms of cerebral hypoperfusion, such as dizziness, lightheadedness, and syncope. It is caused by a narrowing or occlusion of the subclavian artery, which leads to a decrease in blood flow to the subclavian vein, resulting in a reversal of flow in the vertebral artery. The most common cause is atherosclerosis, but it can also be caused by Takayasu aortitis. There may be a filling defect in the subclavian vein, which can be seen on Doppler ultrasound.

Qn_Text: Which of the following features if noted on a CT abdominal angiogram is most likely to render an abdominal aortic aneurysm unsuitable for endovascular repair? Select one answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
For the most part it will be the vascular surgeons or interventional radiologists themselves who decide on a case-by-case basis whether they themselves are prepared to attempt endovascular repair of a given aneurysm. Broadly speaking however, there are a number of criteria which the surgeon or interventionalist would be wise to abide by:
Distance to the renal arteries – 10mm used to be the absolute minimum landing zone distance required but many of the grafts would required a minimum of 15mm. If the landing zone is less than 10mm a fenestrated graft must be used to preserve the patency of the renal arteries.
Angle of the neck – this is measured one of two ways in the literature. Consequently there are two different values for an acceptable angle. A purely straight aneurysm would have a neck angle of either 180o or 0o in each of the different measuring systems. Thus the acceptable neck cut-off values are 120o or 60o in each case.
Angle of the common iliac artery – fortunately this is easier to remember. Iliac arteries at 90o or worse are significantly harder to stent. Further consideration is usually given to the overall tortuosity of the iliac arteries but this relates to endovascular access as opposed to stent deployment.
Common iliac artery (CIA) length – Ideally the CIA should be longer than 20mm to accommodate the stents used. Shorter lengths may require landing in the external iliac artery with deliberate occlusion of the internal iliac artery and reliance on pelvic collaterals.
Common iliac artery diameter – Stents are difficult to place where the diameter of the CIA is less than 7mm.
GPT3_explain: Answer: 1. 20mm infrarenal neck. The infrarenal neck is the portion of the aorta between the renal arteries and the aneurysm, and an infrarenal neck of 20mm or less is generally considered too wide for endovascular repair.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a CT scan of a 48-year-old man who presented with acute severe abdominal pain radiating through to his back. The CT shows a dilated pancreatic duct and sausage shaped pancreas. What is the next step in the management of this patient? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
IgG4 related diseases are one of Radiology’s newest entities. They comprise a constellation of fibrotic conditions affecting virtually every part of the body, mediated by a subclass of Immunoglobulin called IgG4. Where one condition exists others may also be present. The more common of these include:
Autoimmune pancreatitis (most common manifestation)
Orbital pseudotumour
Fibrosing mediastinitis
Riedel thyroiditis
Sclerosing mesenteritis
Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  Specific to sclerosing mesenteritis is the ‘fat-halo’ sign (fat-ring sign) where there is misty mesenteric soft tissue density fat stranding but the fat immediately adjacent to the mesenteric vessels is spared.
Serum IgG4 levels are usually (but not always) elevated in patients with IgG4 related disease, and this should be the first test performed. Patients can respond extremely well to corticosteroid therapy.
  Autoimmune pancreatitis
The main role of imaging is to exclude malignant pathology. The typical appearance is of a diffusely enlarged 'sausage-shaped' pancreas. Enhancement may be slightly delayed owing to the degree of fibrotic change and on duct-imaging (ERCP, MRCP), benign strictures of the pancreatic ducts may be appreciated. The duct-penetrating sign is used to differentiate these from malignant strictures; if the duct traverses an area of concern then malignancy is unlikely. In a malignant stricture the duct will be occluded. The pancreatic duct is usually narrowed although some mild upstream dilatation may be present as a result of stricturing. Biopsy and pathological confirmation of the diagnosis can be helpful if deemed necessary but the combination of typical CT findings, elevated serum IgG4 levels and response to corticosteroids is often sufficient. Ca19-9 levels may also be elevated and so do not help differentiated the condition from the presence of a neoplastic lesion.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. EUS because it is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. EUS (endoscopic ultrasound) is a minimally invasive procedure that can provide detailed imaging of the pancreas and surrounding organs. This can help to accurately diagnose the cause of the patient's symptoms and provide information on the severity of the condition. EUS can also help to determine the best course of treatment.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the bronchi is true?
A: The tertiary bronchi supply the bronchopulmonary segments
B: The left main bronchus passes superior to the arch of the aorta
C: The right main bronchus is longer than the left main bronchus
D: The left main bronchus is more vertical than the right main bronchus
E: There are two secondary bronchi on the right
Explanation:
Explanation:
The left main bronchus is thinner but longer than the right. It is typically 5 cm long and enters the left lung opposite the 6th thoracic vertebra. It passes beneath the arch of the aorta and crosses in front of the oesophagus, the thoracic duct and the descending aorta.
The right main bronchus is wider, shorter and more vertical than the left. It is typically 2.5 cm long and enters the right lung opposite the 5th thoracic vertebra.
The carina is a cartilaginous ridge within the trachea that runs antero-posteriorly between the right and left bronchi at the site of the tracheal bifurcation. It lies approximately at the level of the sternal angle.
  The trachea and bronchi (from Gray's Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose 3 because it is the only statement that is true. The right main bronchus is actually longer than the left main bronchus and it is more horizontal than the left main bronchus. There are three secondary bronchi, two on the right and one on the left. The tertiary bronchi supply the bronchopulmonary segments.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: An 88-year-old man with a long history of COPD is admitted complaining of acute severe abdominal pain. While waiting to be clerked he begins vomiting and the admitting doctor suspects that he may have a small bowel obstruction. He undergoes a CT scan which shows multiple dilated loops of small bowel and an indirect inguinal hernia. Which of the following would most accurately describe the radiological findings of this situation?
A: Herniated loop of bowel passing superolateral to the pubic tubercle
B: Herniated loop of bowel passing through the Hesselbach triangle
C: Herniated loop of bowel passing medial to the inferior epigastric vein
D: Herniated loop of bowel passing between pectineus and obturator externus muscles
E: Herniated loop of bowel passing lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle
Explanation:
Explanation:
Abdominal wall hernias
Hernias can occur at any age but are increasingly prevalent with increasing age. Conditions which increase intra-abdominal pressures predispose patients to developing hernias. These might be entities such as constipation or respiratory conditions associated with excess coughing such as COPD.
Hernia
Landmarks
Feature
Femoral
Inferolateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to the femoral vein
More common in women
Direct inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle, medial to the inferior epigastric vein
Through Hesselbach triangle
Indirect inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle and lateral to the inferior epigastric vein
Most common abdominal hernia
Obturator
Between pectineus and obturator externus muscles, through the obturator foramen
Rare
Spigelian
Inferolateral abdominal wall defect, lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle
May be congenital and associated with cryptorchidism
  Indirect inguinal hernias pass through the inguinal canal, taking in both the deep and superficial rings as they do. The deep ring is lateral to the internal epigastric vessels.
Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the conjoint tendon medial to the internal epigastric vessels and enter the scrotal sac through the superficial ring. They pass through the Hesselbach triangle which is composed of the inferior epigastric vessels, rectus abdominus and the inguinal ligament.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the inferior epigastric vein is located in the inguinal region, which is where the hernia was found. This is the most likely location for a herniation of the small bowel to pass through, as it is the weakest point in the abdominal wall.

Qn_Text: A 10-year-old girl undergoes a trauma CT scan following an RTC. Among other things, the CT shows a lucent lesion in the mandible. Which of the following is NOT a likely differential diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which option is NOT a likely differential diagnosis.
  Brown tumours are a feature of hyperparathyroidism which is highly unlikely in a patient of this age.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
    An ameloblastoma (aka adamantinoma) is classically described as having a soap-bubble appearance with cortical destruction. Ameloblastomas also erode the overlying teeth, a feature which is almost unique to lucent jaw lesions. They are more usually multilocular and show fluid-fluid levels on MRI. Although painless, they are locally aggressive.
  An odontogenic keratocyst is a unilocular lucent lesion which demonstrates a smooth border. They can be indistinguishable from dentigerous cysts given that they are often associated with an unerupted tooth. They also have an association with Gorlin syndrome (BCCs).
  A dentigerous cyst (aka follicular cyst) develops around the crown of an unerupted tooth. They are typically painless however.
  Osteonecrosis of the jaw. This condition can be caused by bisphosphonate use or monoclonal antibody therapy. Clinically the bone of the jaw is exposed and radiologically there are aggressive bony features such as permeative destruction with periosteal reactions.
  An odontoma is usually a small lucent lesion between the roots of the teeth. It can cause resorption of adjacent teeth however the description given is much more classical for an ameloblastoma.
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 5. Periodontal cysts are not a likely differential diagnosis for a lucent lesion in the mandible. Periodontal cysts are typically found in the soft tissues surrounding the teeth, not in the bone. The other four options are all possible differential diagnoses for a lucent lesion in the mandible.

Qn_Text: A 27-year-old man presents to A+E with severe left sided scrotal pain. He has just returned home from a holiday abroad and this has been worsening over the last three days. He also reports dysuria and urinary frequency and a mid-stream urine specimen shows cloudy urine. You are asked to perform an ultrasound scan which shows enlargement of both the epididymis and testis when compared to the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Epididymo-orchitis
Infection of the epididymis with concomitant infection of the testis is called epididymo-orchitis; it is seen most commonly in young adolescents with Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea accounting for most cases in this age range. In older patients E-coli and proteus are more likely to be responsible. Ultrasound is useful only in excluding testicular torsion as a cause of the pain (although a normal scrotal ultrasound does not exclude torsion), and investigating the possibility of abscess formation in cases refractory to antibiotic therapy. On ultrasound a reactive hydrocoele is often present and epididymal enlargement occurs. Colour Doppler flow can be used to demonstrate hyperaemia within the testicle and epididymis as would be expected for an infective process. Historically nuclear medicine scanning was used to confirm the diagnosis with findings of increased activity in the epididymis being expected owing to the hyperaemia.
  Testicular torsion
Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency with salvage rates dropping sharply beyond the first six hours. A normal ultrasound scan does not exclude testicular torsion, particularly if performed within the first six hours. Acute unilateral pain beginning at night is a typical history and the peak age range is in either newborn boys or young adolescents (13-16 years). Ultrasound features, if present, are as follows:
Hypoechoic compared to the normal side (after 6 hours)
Heterogenous if there is ischaemic necrosis present (after 24 hours)
Enlarged (after 8 hours)
Absent Doppler signal (incomplete torsion can show flow)
Twisting of the spermatic cord with spiralling vessels
  Missed torsion
Where ultrasound features of heterogeneous testis with increased peri testicular flow but absent testicular flow are found in a patient with symptoms lasting longer than 24 hours, a missed torsion can be diagnosed.
  Chronic torsion
Beyond around 10 days the testicle becomes small and homogeneously hypoechoic with an enlarged and echogenic epididymis.
  Reversed torsion also known as torsion-detorsion sequence
Increased blood flow within the testicle is either caused by infection or reversed torsion (a testicular tumour can also show increased blood flow).
GPT3_explain: Epididymo-orchitis is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms and the ultrasound findings. Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention to prevent permanent damage to the testicle. Symptoms of testicular torsion include severe pain, swelling, and discoloration of the scrotum. However, in this case, the patient has had the symptoms for three days and the ultrasound findings indicate enlargement of both the epididymis and testis, which is more consistent with epididymo-orchitis.

Qn_Text: A 31-year-old lady who is 25 weeks pregnant with her first pregnancy presents with an aching leg, shortness of breath and tachycardia. Full blood count and renal function tests are normal. A chest x-ray is also normal. The admitting team suspect she may have a pulmonary embolism. Which of the following is the best test to perform next? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
A pregnant patient suspected to have a pulmonary embolus should undergo a chest x-ray to look for alternative causes of shortness of breath such as a lower respiratory tract infection, pleural effusions or a pneumothorax. In the event that they go on to have a VQ scan a chest radiograph is required for comparison.
Thereafter the patient should undergo bilateral lower limb venous dopplers if they have signs or symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. Around a third of pregnant patients who develop pulmonary emboli will have a deep vein thrombosis and for these patients treatment can be started on the basis of their DVT diagnosis without the need for further imaging. If the patient has no signs or symptoms of a DVT, they should proceed to a VQ scan or a CTPA.
The patient should be counselled that there is a small increase in the absolute risk of the foetus developing a childhood cancer following a maternal VQ scan but also that the absolute risk of maternal breast cancer is reduced compared to a CTPA.
  CTPA
CTPA imaging confers a lower dose to the foetus than V/Q scanning, although this effect is diminished in the third trimester as the gravid uterus becomes closer to the field of view.
Unfortunately however, CTPA confers a far greater dose to the breast tissue of the mothers at a time when the tissue is more radiosensitive than it would otherwise be in a non-pregnant woman.
A secondary consideration is the use of iodinated contrast. Iodine crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid. Babies of mothers who have received iodinated contrast during pregnancy should be tested during their first week of life for thyroid suppression although there is little evidence in literature to suggest that many if any infants have developed hypothyroidism following maternal intravenous iodine exposure.
Technical factors to performing a CTPA scan in pregnant patients, if required, are also important to consider. Hyperdynamic circulation can render usual triggering bolus mechanisms suboptimal and raise the possibility of a non-diagnostic study.
  V/Q or Q only scanning
V/Q scanning confers a far lower breast dose to the mother but the dose to the foetus, particularly when small, can be greater owing to tracer accumulation within the solid organs of the mother. The mother should be encouraged to adequately hydrate and void frequently in the subsequent hours/days following a scan.
Many institutes choose to perform perfusion scanning only in pregnant women on the understanding that if the perfusion scan is normal then there is no need to go on to perform the ventilation study. The perfusion scan can also be performed at half the usual dose to further reduce the foetal-dose. Naturally doing so comes with the trade-off of lower sensitivity and specificity.
  Gadolinium in pregnancy
Gadolinium also crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetus into the amniotic fluid. The chelated form of gadolinium in itself poses no risk to the foetus however the free form of gadolinium is teratogenic and the longer the foetus is exposed to the chelated gadolinium administered for the scan, the greater the risk of each molecule of gadolinium becoming dissociated from its chelate. For this reason therefore, gadolinium should only be administered in a patient known to be pregnant, if there is likely to be significant diagnostic benefit from the resultant images.
  Considerations during lactation
Less than 1% of injected iodine or gadolinium is excreted into breast milk and less than 1% of this is then absorbed by the baby's intestinal tract. Although these amounts are considered acceptably low as to not necessitate any breast-feeding cessation advice many families are understandably over-cautious. It is accepted that contrast agents are undetectable in blood 24hours after administration and so any mother wishing to 'pump-and-dump' despite the negligible risks need not do so for longer than a day. Care should, however, be given to counsel the family that it is possible for inadvertent weaning to occur even after short intervals and this should be factored in to any decision made by the family.
Following a nuclear medicine study the risks to the baby are two-fold; firstly from tracer excretion into the breast milk, but also through proximity to the mother during breast-feeding. Recommendations for breast-feeding interruption vary depending on the half-life of the tracer used. For perfusion imaging using technetium (half-life 6 hours) breast milk should be expressed for the first 24 hours following the scan. In theory, it need not be discarded but can safely be bottle-fed to the baby after these 24 hours have elapsed, however in practice many patients none-the-less choose to discard it.
Most tracers simply require adherence to a washout time but of note, the precautions following administration of Gallium-67 based tracers (most commonly used for pyrexia of unknown origin) are much more limiting and, practically speaking, unfortunately lead to complete cessation of breastfeeding. The half-life of Ga-67 is approximately 78 hours. Breastfeeding should, if time allows, be stopped for 2-4 weeks prior to the scan to allow the breast tissue to become less radiosensitive while the tracer circulates within the mother. Where this is an unacceptably long delay for the clinical state of the patient the study can be performed straight away anyway but in either case, milk should also be discarded for at least a further two weeks following the study. Clearly a disruption to breast-feeding of such a long time is far from ideal, even assuming that a patient who is sufficiently unwell as to need a PUO study is able to continue breast-feeding at all, and is likely to lead to complete cessation of breast-feeding. There are other ways to image PUO using Tc99m labelled white blood cells which can be considered.
GPT3_explain: A ventilation/ perfusion scan is the best test to perform next in this case because it is the most reliable and accurate test for diagnosing a pulmonary embolism. The scan can detect blockages in the lungs caused by blood clots, which is the suspected diagnosis in this case. It is also a non-invasive procedure, which is important when dealing with a pregnant patient.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound of a 3 week old baby’s spine. At which vertebral level does the spinal cord terminate in neonates? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The spinal cord terminates at L1/2 in adults and L3 in infants. By 2 months of age, a baby's cord should sit in the same position as an adults; between L1-L2. The subarachnoid space ends at S2 in adults and also lies lower in infants.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the spinal cord generally terminates at the L4 vertebral level in neonates. This is because the lumbar vertebrae are still developing and the spine is still relatively short at this age.

Qn_Text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of lower back pain. She has also noticed pain in her left sternoclavicular joint. She undergoes x-rays of her shoulder which shows that the joint space is well preserved but there is bony expansion and ankylosis. A subsequent MRI scan is reported as showing new bone formation with oedema and synovitis at the sternoclavicular joint. There is no discernible collection. She goes on to have a nuclear medicine scan which shows uptake in both sternoclavicular joints. Old x-rays of her pelvis show left sided sclerosis of the sacroiliac joint. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
SAPHO (Synovitis, acne, palmoplantar pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteitis)
This disease is thought to be a variant of psoriatic arthropathy. The cutaneous manifestations may not be apparent at diagnosis (like psoriatic arthropathy) but hyperostosis and osteolysis and ankylosis of the sternocleidomastoid joint is absolutely typical. On a nuclear medicine bone scan, bilateral uptake in the sternoclavicular joints and manubrium is called a ‘bull’s head’ sign. About a third of patients also have spinal disease with paravertebral ossifications and osteosclerosis. Unilateral sacroiliitis may also occur. Appearances can be quite striking on CT. In the knees, ankles and small joints of the hands there may be inflammation of the joints with juxta-articular osteoporosis.
GPT3_explain: I chose answer 2 because the symptoms and imaging results are most consistent with SAPHO (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, and osteitis) syndrome. SAPHO syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by chronic inflammation of the joints and bones. It is most commonly seen in the sternoclavicular joint, as well as the sacroiliac joint, which is what the patient's x-rays showed. It can also cause bone formation and ankylosis, which the patient's MRI scan showed. The nuclear medicine scan further confirmed the presence of SAPHO syndrome.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old woman presents with neck discomfort with pain and weakness in her arms and hands. She undergoes an MRI of her cervical spine for further assessment. The C7/T1 vertebral disc is seen to extrude posteriorly and effaces the exiting nerve root. Which nerve root is most likely to be affected? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
In the cervical spine the nerve roots exit at the spinal cord without needing to traverse (as in the lumbar spine). The exiting nerve root takes the name of the vertebra BELOW the affected disc. A disc protrusion at C3/4 will affect the C4 nerve root. This allows for the extra nerve root at C8 before reaching the thoracic spine.
In the thoracic spine the affected level takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level. In the lumbar spine the exiting nerve root is usually compressed in the neural foramen, whereas the traversing nerve root is compressed usually in the lateral recess. Far lateral bulges affect the exiting nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level). Paracentral bulges affect the traversing nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body BELOW that level).
GPT3_explain: The C7/T1 vertebral disc is seen to extrude posteriorly and efface the exiting nerve root. This means that the disc is pressing on the nerve root as it exits the spine. Since the disc is located between the C7 and T1 vertebrae, the nerve root that is most likely affected is the C7 nerve root.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a CT scan of the temporal bone from an ENT outpatient clinic. The vestibular aqueduct is very small. What is the most likely consequence?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Meniere disease is an idiopathic condition of the inner ear structures giving rise to symptoms principally of vertigo and tinnitus. Radiologically the vestibular aqueduct is seen to be either small or not visible.
Pendred syndrome – this is an inherited cause of sensorineural hearing loss. It is associated with a large vestibular aqueduct.
Mondini syndrome – this is a specific malformation of the cochlea where there are only 1.5 turns instead of 2.5. It is associated with a large vestibular aqueduct.
Cochlear hypoplasia – some cochlear hypoplasias can be associated with large vestibular aqueducts.
Tullio phenomenon – this refers to vertigo and nystagmus induced by loud noises. It is caused by superior semicircular canal dehiscence.
GPT3_explain: Pendred Syndrome is a genetic disorder that is characterized by a small vestibular aqueduct. It is associated with hearing loss and is the most likely consequence of a small vestibular aqueduct seen on a CT scan.

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by his worried wife. She describes a sudden collapse at home and on examination it is evident that he has loss of power and sensation below T7 on the left, with pain and temperature loss on the contralateral side. An urgent MRI is requested which shows high T2 signal in the T7 vertebral body and high signal of cord at T7. There is no significant adjacent disc disease. Which ONE of the following is NOT a cause of Brown-Sequard syndrome?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord
Explanation:
Explanation:
Brown-Sequard syndrome
This is a specific finding where damage to to one side of the spinal cord causes ipsilateral loss of touch sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation due to damage to the lateral spinothalamic tracts (contralateral since these ascend after having crossed). There is also ipsilateral motor function loss.
  Causes of Brown-Sequard syndrome
Traumatic:
Penetrating injury
Mechanical trauma e.g. RTA
Iatrogenic injury
Compression e.g. disc herniation
Spinal cord tumour
  Vascular:
Aortic aneurysm repair complication
Vertebral artery dissection
Spinal cord haemorrhage
  Spinal cord infarction
The vascular supply to the spinal cord is derived largely from the vertebral arteries or intercostal arteries with one longitudinal running anterior spinal cord artery and two small longitudinally running posterior spinal cord arteries.
The artery of Adamkiewicz is a particularly large segmental artery supplying the anterior spinal artery from around the level of T9. It is responsible for most of the spinal cord blood supply for the lumbar spinal cord. Damage during aortic surgery or trauma can result in spinal cord infarction.
Usually any vascular insult results in a reasonably rapid onset of symptoms. Spinal cord infarctions are no exception. Often more than one vertebral level is affected.
An MRI will showT2 hyperintensity of at least the central grey matter (if not the whole cross-section of the cord) due to oedema. As with intracranial infarctions there will be restriction of diffusion on the DWI sequences.
Particularly in the thoracic spine, the adjacent vertebral body may also lose its blood supply and undergo infarction.
  Subacute combined degeneration
This is a curious condition which can be subtle to detect. A deficiency of vitamin B12 (usually caused by malabsorption) leads to degeneration within the dorsal columns of the cord. The dorsal columns carry nerves responsible for position and vibration sense and as such patients present with loss of these senses as well as sensory ataxia (balance significantly deteriorates when the patient’s eyes are shut thereby excluding visual stabilisation as opposed to sensory stabilisation), and hyperreflexia.
On an MRI scan there will be (if the resolution allows), a longitudinal line of high T2 signal within the cord on sagittal sequences, and often a characteristic 'inverted-V' shape of high T2 signal on axial sequences. In some cases, the 'V' is clearly seen and in others it is harder to appreciate, and the finding is more of high T2 signal bilaterally and symmetrically in the region of the posterior columns.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Poly-trauma as the answer because Brown-Sequard Syndrome is caused by an injury to one side of the spinal cord, resulting in a loss of sensation on the contralateral side and a loss of power on the ipsilateral side. Poly-trauma is an injury involving multiple parts of the body, and is not typically associated with Brown-Sequard Syndrome.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 4-year-old boy who has recently been found to have a large abdominal mass. It is displacing the kidney inferiorly and encasing the aorta. Which of the following would help differentiate a neuroblastoma from a Wilms tumour?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Both tumours can displace the kidney although this feature is more closely associated with neuroblastomas. Similarly both tumours can present with lung metastases but they are far more common with Wilms tumours. Wilms tumours can show heterogeneity which may be mistaken for renal cysts but otherwise neither are particularly associated with them. It is perfectly possible for neither tumour to show renal vein invasion.
This leaves encasement of the aorta which is a feature strongly associated with neuroblastoma.
  Neuroblastoma
This is the most common solid abdominal mass in infants and second most common in children of all ages (after Wilms tumours). Most are adrenal in location, around a third develop in the retroperitoneum and a fifth are located in the posterior mediastinum. Presentation can be with abdominal pain, a mass, or a fever. Most (95%) secrete catecholamines such as VMA (vanillylmandelic acid – leads to hypertension) or VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptides – leads to watery diarrhoea). There are also a few distinct clinical syndromes which herald the presence of a neuroblastoma.
  Syndrome
Details
Blueberry muffin syndrome
Metastatic cutaneous deposits
Opsomyoclonus
Rapid jerky eye movements and myoclonic jerks of the legs. This occurs in around 2% of neuroblastoma cases but around 50% of patients with opsomyoclonus have a neuroblastoma.
Hutchinson syndrome
Limping due to bony metastases
  On imaging they appear as a very large abdominal mass with or without speckled calcification within in. The kidney can either be invaded or just displaced inferiorly, causing a ‘drooping lily’ appearance on urography (where contrast within the inferiorly displaced renal calyces has the appearance of a lily flower with its head hanging down). Neuroblastomas tend to encase large vessels such as the IVC, as opposed to displacing them as Wilms tumours are prone to doing. Staging is performed with an 123I-MIBG scan (as opposed to a 99mTc-MDP bone scan) and importantly within the staging it is actually stage IVs (disease involving the skin, bone marrow and liver) which has the best prognosis.
  Wilms tumour also known as a nephroblastoma
This is the most common abdominal mass in children under the age of 8. There are reasonably strong associations with renal anomalies, genital anomalies, aniridia and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (although the last of these also has an association with neuroblastoma). Presentation is usually with an abdominal mass and/or pain.

GPT3_explain: Wilms tumor is a type of kidney cancer that usually affects young children. It is usually located in the kidney, but can also spread to other organs. Neuroblastoma, on the other hand, is a cancer of the nervous system that commonly originates in the adrenal glands. It can also spread to other organs, including the kidney. Encasement of the aorta is a common feature of neuroblastoma, but not of Wilms tumor. Therefore, the presence of encasement of the aorta can help differentiate a neuroblastoma from a Wilms tumor.

Qn_Text: An 80-year-old man is undergoing pre-operative assessment prior to a routine TURP procedure for some troublesome lower urinary tract symptoms. When his PSA is found to be markedly elevated he undergoes an MRI scan for further investigation. Which of the following regarding prostate cancer in the transitional zone is FALSE? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: A negative trans-rectal biopsy is reassuring
B: A non-circumscribed low T2 lesion is most likely to be cancer
D: Can be masked by BPH changes
E: Around 30% of prostate cancers occur in the transitional zone
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is FALSE.
Transitional zone cancers are less common than peripheral zone cancers but do occur and account for around 30% of prostate cancers. They are often harder to detect clinically due to their central location, and can be occult on imaging owing to overlap and confusion, in particular in patients with benign prostatic hypertrophy since it is the transitional zone which is involved in BPH. BPH leads to a heterogenous and enlarged appearance to the transitional zone which can obscure smaller lesions. On the plus side however, they are more often organ-confined since their central location effectively cushions them from capsular breach for longer. Their central location within the prostate cancer does however mean that trans-rectal biopsies may be falsely reassuring if negative, having missed the lesion due to lesion-depth within the prostate. Clinicians should have a low threshold for repeat-biopsies.
Peripheral zone
The highest grade of suspicion for malignancy in the peripheral zone is indicated by the presence of marked restricted diffusion (focal high b-value and corresponding low ADC signal), with a PIRADS 5 lesion being one that is greater than 1.5 cm. PIRADS 3 lesions will show some restricted diffusion but this is far less (subjective analysis) than for PIRADS 4 lesions. Dynamic contrast enhancement is used for assessment of peripheral zone lesions only - differentiating between lesions which show only limited restricted diffusion. If there is dynamic contrast enhancement with a type 3 washout curve, the lesion becomes a PIRADS 4 lesion despite the only limited restriction in diffusion.
Transitional zone
The highest grade of suspicion for transitional zone lesions is reserved for moderate T2 lesion which is lenticular or non-circumscribed and moderately T2 hypointense (PIRADS 5 >1.5 cm).
Three plane T2 imaging is common practice and enables full assessment of the peripheral zone of the prostate, particularly examining for extra-capsular extension, bladder base or seminal vesical invasion. T2 is also the most important sequence for lesions in the transitional zone.
The T1 weighted sequences are also useful to check for the presence of any haemorrhagic foci although since most patients now undergo their MRI scan prior to any biopsies being taken this has become far less important.
Interestingly the ADC map is more sensitive for carcinoma of the prostate (in the peripheral zone) than the DWI sequences. A finding of focal low signal on the ADC map may be seen in the absence of a corresponding high DWI focus. In the transitional zone however, the T2 sequences are more sensitive.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Are usually organ-confined at presentation because prostate cancer in the transitional zone is not usually organ-confined at presentation. It is more likely to be locally advanced or metastatic, and can spread to other organs.

Qn_Text: Which of the following is NOT a cause of eggshell calcification of thoracic lymph nodes? Select one answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Eggshell calcification 
When the outer rim of a lymph node becomes calcified it is seen on CT as eggshell calcification. There is a relatively specific differential diagnosis for diseases which can manifest in this way. 
Fibrosing mediastinitis
Amyloidosis
Pneumoconioses - silicosis and coal workers only. Not seen in most others.
Sarcoidosis 
Scleroderma 
Treated lymphoma (ie post radiotherapy)
TB
Histoplasmosis
GPT3_explain: Talcosilicosis is not a cause of eggshell calcification of thoracic lymph nodes because it is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of talc and silica dust, and does not affect the lymph nodes. Eggshell calcification of thoracic lymph nodes is caused by conditions such as asbestosis, coal workers pneumoconiosis, sarcoidosis, and tuberculosis.

Qn_Text: A 70-year-old male smoker with a history of COPD develops worsening breathlessness, peripheral oedema, chest pain and palpitations. Pulmonary artery catheterisation is performed and he has pulmonary artery hypertension. Which SINGLE statement regarding the pulmonary arteries is true?
A: The pulmonary trunk is located anteriorly and medially to the right atrium
B: The right pulmonary artery divides into three arteries that supply the three lobes of the right lung
C: The right pulmonary artery is thinner and shorter than the left
D: They receive oxygenated blood from the lungs, and deliver it to the left atrium
E: The pulmonary trunk always lies posterior to the ascending aorta
Explanation:
Explanation:
The pulmonary arteries receive deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle and deliver it to the lungs.
The pulmonary arteries begin as the short and wide pulmonary trunk at the base of the right ventricle. It is separated from the right ventricle by the pulmonary valve and is located anteriorly and medially to the right atrium.
The ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk twist around each other, with the aorta initially lying posterior to the pulmonary trunk, before twisting to the right and lying anteriorly to it.
The pulmonary trunk divides into the left and right pulmonary arteries. The left pulmonary artery supplies blood to the left lung and further divides into two separate arteries to supply each lobe of the lung. The right pulmonary artery is thicker and longer than the left and supplies blood to the right lung. It also bifurcates into two arteries, despite providing a blood supply to three lobes.
  Anatomical image from Grey's Anatomy showing the left lung on the LEFT and the right lung on the RIGHT
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is the only statement that accurately describes the pulmonary arteries. The pulmonary arteries receive oxygenated blood from the lungs and deliver it to the left atrium of the heart. The right pulmonary artery divides into three arteries that supply the three lobes of the right lung, and the left pulmonary artery divides into two arteries that supply the two lobes of the left lung. The pulmonary trunk is located anteriorly and medially to the right atrium, and the pulmonary trunk usually lies posterior to the ascending aorta, but this is not always the case.

Qn_Text: A 23-year-old goalkeeper injures her thumb during a football match. The radiograph demonstrates an avulsion fracture of the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Which fracture is described? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Gamekeeper’s thumb
This is an avulsion fracture of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb associated with ulnar collateral ligament disruption.
Bennett fracture
This is a non-comminuted fracture which requires operative fixation due to the action of Abductor Pollicis Longus causing dorsolateral dislocation.
Rolando fracture
This descrives a comminuted fracture through the base of the thumb.
Guyon
Guyon’s canal transmits the ulnar nerve which can be injured in a Hamate hook fracture.
Stener lesion
A Stener lesion occurs when the Adductor tendon gets caught around the ulnar collateral ligament following a Game-keeper’s thumb injury. It is best appreciated on ultrasound (by an experienced MSK radiologist). This requires surgery.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a Gamekeeper's fracture is an avulsion fracture of the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, which is what was described in the question. This type of fracture occurs when the thumb is forced backwards, away from the hand, often during a sporting activity.

Qn_Text: A 10-year-old boy with a history of impaired hearing has an erosive soft tissue mass in the middle ear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Normally acquired cholesteatomas have an age association of >40years or so and therefore you could be forgiven for thinking the answer was a congenital cholesteatoma. However these tend to present in younger children (a few months old to 5yrs) so this patient does not fit particularly well into either category. Congenital cholesteatomas are less destructive than the acquired form but can cause bony remodelling. Cholesteatomas are histologically epidermoid cysts. This is also therefore 'correct' however the answer option of acquired cholesteatoma is more specific to the vignette and is therefore more correct.
Cholesterol granulomas are cystic structures with imaging features that belie their contents, namely cholesterol and blood. Hence they tend to show high signal on both T1 and t2. They tend not to be erosive/aggressive when located in the middle ear although this is a feature which is seen when they are situated in the petrous apex.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because acquired cholesteatoma is the most common type of erosive soft tissue mass found in the middle ear in patients with a history of impaired hearing. It is a noncancerous growth of skin cells that can form in the middle ear and can cause hearing loss, dizziness, and facial nerve paralysis.

Qn_Text: A 76-year-old farmer is undergoing a cardiac MRI for investigation of dyspnoeic symptoms. There is nodular pericardial thickening which shows high signal on T1 and low on T2 associated with a small pericardial effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
MRI is seldom used in the world of pulmonary radiology. Nonetheless the physics is the same throughout the body in that there are a limited number of entities which show high signal on T1.
These are the 4Ms and the 3Fs, thus:
Melanin
Methaemoglobin (subacute haemorrhage)
Mineralisation (manganese, copper)
Magnevist (gadolinium contrast agents)
Fluid – proteinaceous (N.B posterior pituitary stores anti-diuretic hormone and is therefore bright)
Fat
Flow – slow
Arguably renal cell carcinoma metastases could cause high T1 signal since they can show haemorrhage however the clinical information in the question alludes to the patient having occupational exposure to sunlight predisposing him to melanoma formation.
GPT3_explain: Mycobacterium Avium Intracellulare is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common cause of nodular pericardial thickening with high signal on T1 and low on T2 associated with a small pericardial effusion. This type of infection is more common in elderly patients, such as the farmer in the case, and is usually caused by inhaling airborne particles from a contaminated environment.

Qn_Text: A 39-year-old man complains to his GP of a lump in his scrotum. He is referred for an ultrasound scan which shows that there is a hypoechoic multilocular lesion at the head of the epididymis. On close inspection, there is echogenic moving material within. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Spermatocoele
A spermatocoele is a focal dilatation of a duct within the head of the epididymis. Since they contain protein debris and spermatozoa, low level echoes can be seen floating within them differentiating them from epididymal cysts. They are essentially an incidental asymptotic finding. 
  Epididymal cyst
A cystic structure within the epididymis is most commonly a simple cyst. They can present as palpable masses or be found incidentally. On ultrasound they behave as you might expect from a cyst, with posterior acoustic enhancement of an anechoic round structure. The main differential diagnosis is a spermatocoele which, unlike a simple cyst, usually contains echogenic material. The latter is usually only found in the epididymal head. 
  Rete testis ectasia
This is a relatively common finding in men around the age of 60. It is asymptomatic and therefore incidental. The rete testis is the name given to the tubules which collect spermatozoa from the seminiferous tubules and deliver them to the extra-testicular ducts. The normal rete testis is too small to appreciate with ultrasound but when, through age, the distal portion becomes stenosed, there is buildup of fluid within the rete testis. This is then seen as tubular branching anechoic structures within the testis.
  Tunica albuginea cyst
The tunica albuginea is a fibrous layer covering the testicle. On ultrasound it appears as the thin echogenic line surrounding the testicle. When cysts form here they are usually palpable as small well-defined lumps a few millimetres in diameter. Appearances on ultrasound usually conform to those expected from any straightforward cyst i.e. An sharply defined anechoic structure with acoustic enhancement posteriorly. They can be uni or multilocular and although they can exert mass effect on the underlying testicle they do not affect the testicular tissue beyond this. They are most commonly located at the anterosuperior or superolateral aspect of the testicle.
  Intratesticular cyst
These are not readily palpable and therefore are seen only as incidental findings. They demonstrate the usual characteristics of any cyst on ultrasound but are located within the testicle itself. They are inconsequential but for their distinction from cystic teratomas. The latter will have solid enhancing components on an MRI scan. Provided, however, there is no ambiguity on ultrasound, no further follow up would be needed for a straightforward intratesticular cyst.
  Seminoma
Germ cell tumours are divided into seminomas and non-seminomatous varieties. They are very common and comprise almost half of all testicular tumours. They can often be found incidentally or subsequent to any trauma which might cause the patient to self-examine and discover a testicular lump. Alternatively they can present as a vague dull scrotal aching sensation with no lump.
Lymphatic drainage is to the retroperitoneum. Para-aortic lymph nodes are therefore regional. Involvement of the internal, external and common iliac nodes however, is considered non-regional. Only if there has been previous scrotal or inguinal surgery disrupting tissue planes are inguinal or external iliac artery nodes considered regional.
They typically are found in patients in their 40s. Testicular tumours can be diagnosed with a strong pre-test probability based solely on age as detailed in the table below. On ultrasound there will be an intratesticular low reflectivity well-defined mass. Colour doppler flow can be seen within the mass.
  Age at diagnosis
Tumour
10s
Yolk sac tumour or teratoma
20s + 30s
Choriocarcinoma
30s
Embryonal cell carcinoma
40s
Seminoma
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because a spermatocoele is a fluid-filled cystic structure within the testes that is often seen on ultrasound scans. It is usually located at the head of the epididymis and is characterized by a hypoechoic multilocular lesion with echogenic moving material within. This is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

Qn_Text: A 76-year-old man presents with Vernet syndrome. He undergoes an urgent MRI scan of his head which shows an irregular mass causing significant bony erosion, and extending into the middle ear. There is low signal on T1 and high signal on T2 with marked enhancement post-contrast. There are both flow voids and foci of hyperintensity within the mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Vernet syndrome is the name for a collection of symptoms caused by pathology at the jugular foramen and consequentially affecting cranial nerves IX, X and XI ie. Loss of taste to the posterior third of the tongue, vocal cord paralysis, dysphasia, weakness of sternocleidomastoid and trapezius.
There is a differential diagnosis for such pathology the identification of which will depend on the further imaging features provided. This question could easily be asked in a way to point to any of the other diagnoses provided.
A jugular foramen metastasis will be destructive and infiltrating with possible enlargement or pathological enhancement of the nerve roots and obliteration of normal fat planes. No particular history of a primary malignancy has been offered though.
A paraganglioma (or glomus jugulare tumour) is the most common cause of Vernet syndrome. This will cause infiltration of the connective tissue planes following the path of least resistance. There can be a moth eaten pattern of temporal bone destruction with associated ossicular destruction and consequential hearing loss. A so-called ‘salt and pepper’ appearance is classical.
A neural sheath tumour (ie a schwannoma or neurofibroma) will cause smooth scalloping of the adjacent bone.
A meningioma will have classical meningioma features (Extra-axial mass appearing isodense on CT with avid enhancement post-contrast, variable signal characteristics on MRI with avid enhancement post-contrast). Bony hyperostosis may be seen.
A PNET in this area would more usually present as a progressive bulbar palsy and appears as a destructive mass causing irregular bony destruction.
GPT3_explain: Paragangliomas are typically seen on MRI as irregular masses with bony erosion, low signal on T1, high signal on T2, and marked enhancement post-contrast. They can also have both flow voids and foci of hyperintensity within the mass. These characteristics are consistent with the findings of the MRI scan in this patient, making paraganglioma the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a trauma CT scan for a 36-year-old patient following a multi-vehicle accident. There is an obvious pelvic fracture with active haemorrhage from an internal iliac vein tributary. How should this best be managed? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the vignette describes a venous bleeding point.
Arterial bleeding from pelvic fractures
Pelvic fractures in the context of trauma are a cause of significant morbidity and mortality. Life threatening haemorrhage may be caused by arterial bleeding or other sources such as the fractured bones themselves, and the pelvic venous structures. External fixation is one of the few means of managing acute haemorrhage in the pre-hospital setting however for arterial bleeding it is far less effective at tamponading ongoing haemorrhage. It remains the treatment of choice for bone bleeding or venous bleeding.
Catheter angiography and embolisation is the most effective method to control arterial haemorrhage. If the patient is haemodynamically unstable due to an arterial pelvic haemorrhage, catheter embolisation still provides the best hope for managing the patient successfully. Even if the patient has abdominal injuries which are likely to necessitate open abdominal trauma surgery, studies have shown that arterial pelvic bleeding should still be controlled via catheter embolisation prior to their open surgery.
GPT3_explain: The best way to manage this injury is to perform an angiogram and embolisation. An angiogram is an imaging procedure that uses a contrast dye to visualize the blood vessels and identify any blockages or areas of active bleeding. Embolisation is a minimally invasive procedure that involves injecting a material into the blood vessels to stop the flow of blood. This is the most effective way to stop the active haemorrhage from the iliac vein tributary. Pelvic binders and laparoscopic surgery are not effective for this type of injury. Laparotomy is a more invasive procedure and should only be used as a last resort.

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old man being staged for his lung cancer arrives for an FDG exam. Which of the following is NOT a reason the scan should be delayed or re-scheduled? Select ONE answer only.
B: His last dose of insulin was one hours previously
C: He had a black coffee that morning
D: He went to the gym the previous afternoon
E: He has fasted for less than 4 hours
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is NOT a reason to delay or reschedule the scan.
FDG imaging relies on glucose uptake being increased in tissues of interest which are more metabolically active than non-target tissues. Hence the patient must be fasted such that the FDG given is taken up rapidly enough to produce an image.
FDG is renally excreted. Patients with a poor renal function are at risk of enduring a higher dose than those with a normal renal function. However, assuming the dose is correctly adjusted down there is no reason such patients cannot undergo PET/CT scanning.
Insulin treatment does not preclude imaging, and indeed helps reduce the extracellular glucose concentration thereby improving the quality of scans acquired later. There should be at least a 4-hour gap between the last insulin dose and the FDG tracer dose time.
The literature on fasting varies and different organizations have suggested slightly different fasting windows. The most conservative of these is 6 hours.
Caffeine, alcohol and nicotine must be avoided for at least 12 hours prior to the scan.
Exercise should be avoided for 24, if not 48 hours prior to the scan.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3 because drinking a black coffee that morning would interfere with the accuracy of the FDG exam, as it can cause an increase in glucose levels. It is important that the patient be fasting for at least 4 hours before the exam for the results to be accurate.

Qn_Text: At which vertebral level does the abdominal aorta bifurcate? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The bifurcation of the abdominal aortaoccurs at the L4 vertebral level.
GPT3_explain: The abdominal aorta bifurcates at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra, which is T12. This is the point at which the aorta divides into the two common iliac arteries, which supply blood to the lower body.
