Qn_Text: A 37-year-old lady is undergoing investigations for primary infertility. She has attended for a hysterosalpingogram. Which of the following is a contraindication to performing the hystersalpingogram?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
HSGs are performed in the setting of infertility to confirm or refute tubal patency. It is not the ideal modality to diagnose MDAs since it provides information only on the internal contours of any patent cavities. Historically the intercornual angle was used to differentiate between a septate uterus (<75o) and a bicornuate or didelphys uterus (>105o) but this is no longer considered reliable. In addition an HSG will overlook obstructed hemisystems or functional remnants which do not communicate with the vagina.
Active pelvic inflammation, contrast allergy and pregnancy are all contraindications to performing a hysterosalpingogram.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of jemsweb CC BY-SA 2.0
  Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
This is a coverall term applied to ascending infection of the genital tract. It encompasses endometriosis, salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, and tubo-ovarian abscesses. Chlamydia and gonorrhoea account of most of the cases and the disease is most prevalent in sexually active young people. Imaging features are those secondary to inflammation with increased vascularity to the endometrium and small volume ascites. Inflammation is also seen on MRI as avid enhancement post contrast. Pelvic inflammatory disease can be complicated by a condition called Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome where there is perihepatitis secondary to PID.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2 because pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an infection of the reproductive organs, and it can cause inflammation and scarring of the fallopian tubes, which can interfere with the passage of the dye used in the hysterosalpingogram. This can make it difficult to interpret the results of the test, so it is a contraindication to performing the test.
Cat_Long: This question falls under Basic Factual Recall, regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 4-year-old boy who has recently been found to have multiple pulmonary metastases from an unknown primary source. There is a well circumscribed heterogeneous mass arising from the left kidney. Which of the following would help differentiate a Wilms tumour from a neuroblastoma?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Both tumours can displace the kidney although this feature is more closely associated with neuroblastomas. Wilms tumours can show heterogeneity which may be mistaken for renal cysts but otherwise neither are particularly associated with them. It is perfectly possible for neither tumour to show renal vein invasion.
Encasement of the aorta which is a feature strongly associated with neuroblastoma.
This leaves curvilinear calcification. Although more commonly seen with neuroblastomas, both tumours can show calcification. The morphology differs between the two however with curvilinear calcification being a feature of Wilms tumours.
  Wilms tumour also known as a nephroblastoma
This is the most common abdominal mass in children under the age of 8. There are reasonably strong associations with renal anomalies, genital anomalies, aniridia and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (although the last of these also has an association with neuroblastoma). Presentation is usually with an abdominal mass and/or pain.
  10% tumour – Wilms
Calcification
Vascular invasion
Bilateral
Lung metastases
Poor histology
  On imaging the masses are usually heterogenous. Cystic areas can often be seen secondary to areas of necrosis. The claw sign occurs when there is a rim of normal renal tissue extending part of the way around the mass. A Wilms tumour is often described as enhancing but less so than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma.
  Feature
Neuroblastoma
Wilms tumour
Peak age
2 years
3-4 years
Kidney
Drooping lily sign – displaced downwards, if not invaded.
Claw sign – rim of normal renal tissue extending around the mass
Crosses midline
More common
Less common
Calcification
More common
Regular and stippled
Less common
Curvilinear and phleobliths
IVC
Encases
Displaces and/or invades
  Neuroblastoma
This is the most common solid abdominal mass in infants and second most common in children of all ages (after Wilms tumours). Most are adrenal in location, around a third develop in the retroperitoneum and a fifth are located in the posterior mediastinum. Presentation can be with abdominal pain, a mass, or a fever. Most (95%) secrete catecholamines such as VMA (vanillylmandelic acid – leads to hypertension) or VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptides – leads to watery diarrhoea). There are also a few distinct clinical syndromes which herald the presence of a neuroblastoma.
  Syndrome
Details
Blueberry muffin syndrome
Metastatic cutaneous deposits
Opsomyoclonus
Rapid jerky eye movements and myoclonic jerks of the legs. This occurs in around 2% of neuroblastoma cases but around 50% of patients with opsomyoclonus have a neuroblastoma.
Hutchinson syndrome
Limping due to bony metastases
  On imaging they appear as a very large abdominal mass with or without speckled calcification within in. The kidney can either be invaded or just displaced inferiorly, causing a ‘drooping lily’ appearance on urography (where contrast within the inferiorly displaced renal calyces has the appearance of a lily flower with its head hanging down). Neuroblastomas tend to encase large vessels such as the IVC, as opposed to displacing them as Wilms tumours are prone to doing. Staging is performed with an 123I-MIBG scan (as opposed to a 99mTc-MDP bone scan) and importantly within the staging it is actually stage IVs (disease involving the skin, bone marrow and liver) which has the best prognosis.
GPT3_explain: Wilms tumours are encapsulated and tend to displace the kidney, have no renal vein invasion, and can have curvilinear calcification, while neuroblastomas are infiltrative and can encase the aorta.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 75-year-old woman taking warfarin for AF falls and sustains a head injury. She undergoes a CT scan which shows an intraparenchymal haemorrhage. She is managed conservatively and later undergoes an MRI scan for follow up. Regarding the signal intensity of the blood, which of the following is correctly matched to the likely findings? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Bright on T1 and dark on T2 = Early subacute
B: Dark on T1 and isointense on T2 = Chronic
C: Dark on T1 and dark on T2 = Hyperacute
D: Isointense on T1 and bright on T2 = Acute
E: Bright on T1 and isointense on T2 = Late Subacute
Explanation:
Explanation:
This question is to do with the imaging characteristics of blood within the brain. We can think of the intracranial space as a closed box as far as oxygen tensions go which means that blood degrades in a predictable fashion and therefore has predictable appearances on T1 and T2 according to the changes in the haemoglobin molecule. There are a few different methods to help remember the changes in appearance, one of which is the table below:
  Time-frame Haemoglobin T1 T2 Mnemonic
Hyperacute (hours)   Iso Bright - IBBY
Acute (0-2 days) Intracellular deoxyHb Dark / Iso Dark - IDDY
Early subacute (3-7 days) Intracellular metHb Bright Dark - BIDDY
Late subacute (8-30 days) Extracellular metHb Bright Bright - BABY
Chronic (> 30 days) Intracellular haemosiderin Dark Dark rim - DODO
  In real life and for the 2b exam the important distinction is around the subacute stages.
In that case, by and large, if it is bright on T1 it is subacute and T2 then decides if it is early or late subacute. The timeframes given are also important and can form the basis of 2a exam questions.
  Of the other answers provided therefore:
Bright on T1 and dark on T2 = Early subacute
Dark on T1 and bright on T2 = Chronic
Dark on T1 and dark on T2 = Acute
Isointense on T1 and bright on T2 = Hyperacute
Bright on T1 and bright on T2 = Late subacute
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because on MRI scans, blood appears isointense on T1 and bright on T2 in acute bleeds. This is because in acute bleeds, the blood is fresh and has a high amount of water content, which makes it appear bright on T2.

Qn_Text: A physician colleague requests your opinion on a chest radiograph of an elderly plumber with a 30-pack year history of smoking. He presented to his GP with a cough which had been bothering him for the last few months. You colleague has been unable to see anything wrong on the film, but you notice an abnormal concavity to the pulmonary bay. Which of the following is LEAST likely to affect the pulmonary bay? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the answer LEAST likely option.
  The aortopulmonary space (less often called the pulmonary bay)
This is an important area of consideration on a chest radiograph responsible for an unusually high number of missed diagnoses. The space is created by the outlines of the aortic arch as it arches backwards over the left main pulmonary artery. Loss of the normal contour of this region on the frontal chest radiograph suggests one of a number of important pathologies:
Lymph node enlargement
Acquired vascular anomalies - aortic aneurysms or pulmonary artery atresia/hypertrophy
Congenital anomalies - Tetralogy of Fallot
Nerve sheath tumour
    Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Mikael Häggström CC BY-SA 3.0
    Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Mikael Häggström and Nevit Dilmen CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: Nerve sheath tumours are not likely to affect the pulmonary bay because they are usually found in the peripheral nerves, such as the brachial plexus or sciatic nerve. They are not typically found in the lungs or pulmonary bay.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge, how to apply knowledge to a situation.

3. A question about the application of knowledge, how to apply knowledge to a situation.

Qn_Text: A 50- year-old man suffers an anterior dislocation of the shoulder. He visits his local A+E department where the joint is successfully reduced. Which of the following is the most likely abnormality demonstrated on the plain films following reduction?
A: Indentation of the posterior humeral head with a fracture at the inferior glenoid
B: Indentation of the anterior humeral head with a fracture at the inferior glenoid
C: Indentation of the anterior humeral head alone
D: Avulsion of the lesser tuberosity alone
E: Indentation of the posterior humeral head and avulsion of the lesser tuberosity
Explanation:
Explanation:
Anterior dislocation (95%)
The integrity of the shoulder joint is weakest when at extreme abduction and external rotation.
When the humeral head dislocates anteriorly with respect to the glenoid, the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the inferior glenoid and both can suffer. The damage to the humeral head is known as a Hill-Sachs lesion and the inferior glenoid fracture is called a Bankart lesion.
  Posterior dislocation (5%)
At extreme abduction with internal rotation the humeral head is forced posteriorly and can dislocate. The usual scenario is in the context of a seizure or alternatively when a patient has been electrocuted. The AP x-ray can seem normal to the untrained eye. If the humerus remains internally rotated, the greater tuberosity rotates to a more anterior position and its characteristic outline is lost, leading to the so-called ‘light-bulb’ sign of a posterior dislocation. To establish the relationship between the humeral head and the glenoid, a Y-view, where the glenoid is viewed head-on, is often performed but an axillary view, where the beam travels through the axilla, is said to be even more useful. Avulsion fractures of the lesser tuberosity (where the subscapularis muscle attaches) are commonly seen in association with posterior dislocations.
A bony defect on the anteromedial surface of the humeral head is known as reverse Hill-Sachs lesion. Similarly a tear to the posterior glenoid labrum is called a reverse Bankart lesion.
  Inferior dislocation (<1%) – Also known as Luxatio erecta
The patient presents with their arm held over their head. X-rays will show the humeral head displaced downwards and caught underneath the glenoid.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is the most likely abnormality demonstrated on plain films following reduction of an anterior shoulder dislocation. This is because the anterior humeral head is often forced out of the glenoid fossa during the dislocation, resulting in an indentation of the anterior humeral head. This indentation can be seen on the plain films following reduction of the shoulder joint.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge to a given clinical scenario.

This question falls under category 3: A question about the application of knowledge to a given clinical scenario.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 27-year-old lady. She has presented with severe abdominal pain and is on day 7 of her menstrual cycle. You suspect she may have ovarian torsion. Which of the following regarding this diagnosis is correct? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Torsion is more common during early pregnancy
B: The most common cause of ovarian torsion is a dermoid cyst
C: The diagnosis is excluded by the presence of doppler flow in the ovary
D: The ovary will be smaller than normal
E: Small fluid pockets seen around the edge of the ovary suggest an alternative diagnosis
Explanation:
Explanation:
Ovarian torsion
At least half of all ovarian torsion is caused by a lead point (i.e. an ovarian mass). Most cases are due to a corpus luteum cyst or follicular cyst with a dermoid cyst being the next most common cause. Torsion is also more common during early pregnancy than in non-pregnant patients. On ultrasound the ovary itself will be enlarged (>4cm in length), and heterogenously echogenic. In the periphery of the ovary, small fluid-filled follicles may be appreciated. On doppler ultrasound scan, twisting of the ovarian pedicle is a useful sign but actual flow within the ovary itself does not exclude torsion since it is venous flow which is lost first.
Symptoms may resolve spontaneously with de-torsion but otherwise laparoscopy is indicated to de-tort the ovary and remove any lead point. If the ovary is infarcted at the time of surgery this will also be resected.
  Mature teratoma
(Immature) teratomas and dermoid cysts (mature teratomas) have very similar imaging characteristics despite their histological differences. Teratomas are the most common ovarian neoplasm but are slow growing and usually benign. By contrast immature teratomas are malignant. The presence of fat is a strong indicator for a mature teratoma with the combination of fat, fluid and calcification being highly specific. On MRI the fat will show the usual signal drop-out on fat saturated sequences. Calcification will show as low signal on T2. Although benign, mature teratomas can be complicated by torsion or rupture. Malignant degeneration if it does occur, is to squamous cell carcinoma most commonly.
Mature teratomas can have a variety of appearances on ultrasound scan depending on their internal composition. Posterior acoustic shadowing suggests the presence of calcification.
  The corpus luteum
The corpus luteum consists of the remnant of a ruptured ovarian follicle following ovulation. It produces oestrogen and progesterone to sustain a pregnancy following fertilisation. On ultrasound it is seen as a thick-walled cyst with peripheral vascularity on colour Doppler flow. This 'ring of fire' appearance can be confused with an ectopic pregnancy.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the presence of doppler flow in the ovary is an important indication that ovarian torsion is not present. Doppler flow is an indication of blood flow to the ovary, which is necessary for the health of the ovary and would be absent in the case of ovarian torsion.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 7-year-old boy with known metastatic neuroblastoma and with a recent history of sinusitis presents acutely with focal neurology and confusion. On MRI scanning he is found to have a ring enhancing lesion with marked vasogenic oedema. Which of the following will help establish the diagnosis of a metastasis over that of an abscess for this patient?
D: The histopathology of the known primary
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is a mnemonic for ring enhancing lesions. MAGIC DR (Metastasis, abscess, glioma, infarction, contusion, demyelination, radiation necrosis). Largely however the differential diagnosis is between a metastasis and an abscess.
An abscess tends to show a thin smooth rim of enhancement whereas mitotic lesions often have a thick, irregular margin. These patterns are not exact but can be taken as good evidence to support/refute either diagnosis. Obviously correlation should be made with the presence or absence of markers of infection which have been deliberately omitted from the vignette.
The central liquefied portion of an abscess characteristically shows restriction in diffusion due to the high viscosity of the pus. However, some cerebral metastases, specifically those from a neuroblastoma, can also show some restriction in diffusion owing to the highly cellular nature of the lesions. Unfortunately, while the difference between the two should be obvious when reviewing images, the question does not elaborate as to the extent of the restriction in diffusion. Certainly if there is no restriction in diffusion then an abscess can confidently be ruled out.

Qn_Text: A 28-year-old woman that is 30-weeks pregnant is seen with pain, numbness and tingling in her left hand. You are reviewing her MRI scan and suspect that she has a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. Which SINGLE statement regarding the carpal tunnel is FALSE?
A: The tendon of flexor carpi radialis passes through the tunnel
B: The carpal arch forms the floor
C: The tendon of flexor pollicis longus is surrounded by its own synovial sheath
D: The ulnar artery and ulnar nerve pass superficial to the tunnel
E: It contains a total of nine flexor tendons
Explanation:
Explanation:
The carpal tunnel is a passageway on the palmar side of the wrist that connects the forearm to the middle compartment of the deep plane of the hand.
The carpal tunnel is formed by two layers, the carpal arch and the flexor retinaculum:
1. The carpal arch forms the floor of the carpal tunnel. It is concave on the palmar side and is formed laterally by the scaphoid and trapezium tubercles and medially by the hook of the hamate and the pisiform bones.
2. The flexor retinaculum forms the roof of the carpal tunnel. It is a strong, fibrous band that covers the carpal bones on the palmar side of the hand near the wrist. It is attached medially to the pisiform bone and the hook of the hamate bone. Laterally it attaches to the tubercle of the scaphoid bone, and to the medial part of the trapezium bone.
The carpal tunnel contains a total of nine flexor tendons (but not the muscles themselves), surrounded by a synovial sheath, and the median nerve. The tendons contained within the carpal tunnel are:
Flexor digitorum profundus (four tendons)
Flexor digitorum superficialis (four tendons)
Flexor pollicis longus (one tendon)
  The eight tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus and superficialis are surrounded by a single synovial sheath, whereas the tendon of flexor pollicis longus is surrounded by its own synovial sheath. These sheaths allow free movement of the tendons
The tendon of flexor carpi radialis does not pass through the carpal tunnel, but is instead located within the flexor retinaculum itself.
The ulnar artery and ulnar nerve pass superficial to the flexor retinaculum and the carpal tunnel, passing through the ulnar tunnel.
Carpal tunnel syndrome is an entrapment neuropathy of the median nerve. It causes weakness and parasthesia in the distribution of the median nerve. The muscles innervated by the median nerve can be remembered using the mnemonic ‘LOAF’:
L – lateral two lumbricals
O – Opponens pollicis
A – Abductor pollicis
F – Flexor pollicis brevis
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of OpenStax College CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 5. It contains a total of nine flexor tendons. This statement is false because the carpal tunnel contains a total of eight flexor tendons, not nine. The tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis, flexor digitorum profundus, flexor pollicis longus, flexor carpi radialis, and palmaris longus all pass through the carpal tunnel.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the application of knowledge, in this case, the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Qn_Text: As part of a teaching session you are shown the images of a barium swallow examination. There are numerous linear ulcers affecting the middle and lower thirds of the oesophagus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Oesophagitis
Inflammation of the oesophagus usually presents with severe pain on swallowing (odynophagia). There are many different aetiologies but there are a few features which can help separate the differential diagnoses on imaging.
Aetiology
Features
Candidiasis
Immunocompromised patients (including long term steroid therapy)
Upper half of the oesophagus
Irregular, longitudinal plaques with normal mucosa in between
Fulminant candidiasis
Patients with AIDs
Shaggy outline from a pseudomembrane of joined-together plaques
Herpes simplex
Immunocompromised patients
Flu-like symptoms
Multiple small ulcers, each may have a halo of oedema
CMV / HIV oesophagitis
One large ulcer
These two are indistinguishable from one another by appearance
Caustic
Ingestion of corrosive substance
Affects middle and lower thirds
Progression from oedema to ulceration to scarring over days
Barrett oesophagitis
Squamous metaplasia of distal oesophagus in response to reflux
Long strictures
Reticular mucosal pattern
Drug-induced
Ulcers at sites of extrinsic compression in the mid oesophagus
Patients taking medication without enough water immediately prior to going to bed
Idiopathic eosinophilic oesophagitis
History of atopy usually present
Specific ring-like indentations to the oesophagus
  Glycogen acanthosis
This condition is caused by benign age-related squamous hyperplasia but, based on its imaging features, a differential diagnosis for candidiasis. On a barium swallow there will be small rounded white plaques in a random distribution, predominantly affecting the middle and upper oesophagus. Patients are typically middle aged or elderly.
  Intramural pseudodiverticulosis
This is a feature of candidal oesophagitis. Tiny diverticulae are found scattered along the length of the oesophagus and on a barium swallow the appearance can be quite impressive! Like most candidal infections oesophagitis is most common in patients with suppressed immunity including patients with diabetes, on steroids, or chemotherapy.
GPT3_explain: Caustic oesophagitis is the most likely diagnosis due to the presence of numerous linear ulcers affecting the middle and lower thirds of the oesophagus. These linear ulcers are typically seen in caustic oesophagitis, as they are caused by the corrosive action of an ingested caustic substance (e.g. lye, bleach, etc.). Other causes of oesophagitis, such as CMV, drug-induced, and Candida albicans, are less likely to cause linear ulcers. Intramural pseudodiverticulosis is a condition characterized by outpouchings of the oesophageal wall, and is not associated with linear ulcers.

Qn_Text: A 28-year-old woman presents acutely unwell. Of note in her medical history she has been taking the oral contraceptive pill. She undergoes a CT scan which shows high density of the superior sagittal sinus. An MRI is requested for follow-up. Which of the following is a pitfall of sagittal sinus thrombosis imaging? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
B: Empty delta sign on post contrast CT
C: Dense triangle sign on unenhanced CT
E: High intensity in the sinus on T1
Explanation:
Explanation:
The empty delta sign is a post-contrast CT finding. Bilateral haemorrhages can be a secondary consequence to a sagittal sinus thrombosis which may point towards the diagnosis but the thrombosis itself is recognised by the empty delta sign on post-contrast CT.
Dense triangle sign pertains to the acute thrombus as it appears on an unenhanced CT scan.
On an MRI, static blood within the sagittal sinus gives rise to low signal on T1, although the thrombus itself is likely to be high in signal (if subacute in nature). Normally the sagittal sinus will appear as a flow void on T1w. Blooming artefact can be seen on T2* gradient echo sequences and is a strong indicatory of the diagnosis. Confusion can arise with time-of-flight 3D reformatted images and great care should be taken not to overdiagnose flow artefactas thrombosis. Careful reference should always be made to the source images and where there is doubt a CT venogram may be of more use.
The associated infarctions can often be haemorrhagic and parasagittal haemorrhages are very specific for a sagittal sinus thrombosis, but subarachnoid haemorrhage is not likely to be related.
GPT3_explain: The dense triangle sign is a pitfall of sagittal sinus thrombosis imaging because it is an artifactual finding that can appear on unenhanced CT scans and can be mistaken for a thrombus. This sign is caused by the overlap of the edges of the transverse sinus and the sigmoid sinus, creating an appearance of a triangle. This sign should not be mistaken for an actual thrombus, which would show up as a high-density area on CT or a high-intensity area on MRI.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment option?

This question falls under category 3: A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment option?

Qn_Text: An 85-year-old man is found to have lymphangitis carcinomatosis. What is the most likely description of the nodules that have been seen as part of this condition?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This question is challenging because when describing the CT findings in lymphangitis carcinomatosis it is usually the interstitial and fissural thickening which are of greatest significance. However, nodules can and do occur and when they do they are most commonly found in the subpleural location.
----------------
Lung nodules seen on CT take one of three different patterns:
Perilymphatic nodules
Peribronchiolar, perivascular, subpleural and close to the fissures
Lymphangitis carcinomatosis, sarcoidosis, pneumoconioses
Centrilobular nodules
Found in the centre of the secondary pulmonary lobule, with subpleural sparing
Infections, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, vasculitis
Random
Miliary disease, metastatic disease, langerhans cell histiocytosis
Subpleural nodules are associated with the secondary pulmonary lobule and nodules here represent a perilymphatic distribution such as would be expected with lymphangitis carcinomatosis. They can also be seen in usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) or idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
Fissural nodules are usually isolated and feature heavily in the lung MDT with follow up CT scans arranged according to the British Thoracic Society guidelines. Fissural thickening is associated with lymphangitis carcinomatosis, this can be smooth or nodular thickening but the nodularity is as part of the overall thickening rather than as discrete nodules.
Perihilar is a term usually used to refer to either cardiogenic or non-cardiogenic in origin. A perihilar distribution of airspace shadowing is also a classical description for Pneumocystis Carinii Pneumonia (PCP).
Peribronchial is a term usually coupled with cuffing and refers to opacification surrounding the larger airways which may be resultant from either oedema or bronchial inflammation (e.g asthma).
Intrapleural is not a classic descriptor for pulmonary pathology. Disease affecting the periphery of the chest are classified as either extrapleural or pleural meaning they either don’t or do affect the pleura.
Lymphangitis carcinomatosis is easy to recognize on a scan but can be described in a number of different ways on paper. It occurs when tumour cells, spread via the lymphatics, accumulate in the connective tissues of the lung, in particular the interlobular septa. The classical description is as a smooth thick reticular polygonal network.
A mnemonic for the likely cancers is: Certain Cancers Spread By Plugging The Lymphatics (this is not an exclusive list). Of these Breast accounts for just over half of cases and gastric cancer accounts for most of the remainder.
Cervix
Colon
Stomach
Breast
Pancreas
Thyroid
Larynx (or lung – bronchogenic)
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Fissural because lymphangitis carcinomatosis is a condition in which cancer cells spread through the lymphatic system, leading to the formation of nodules in the walls of the airways. Fissural nodules are small, round nodules that form in the fissures (small crevices) between the air sacs of the lungs.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 61-year-old lady with a fever, weight loss and night sweats undergoes a CXR which shows a widened mediastinum. A subsequent CT shows a lobulated 8cm anterior mediastinal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The ‘5Ts’ of anterior mediastinal masses are a useful aide memoire:
Thymoma
Thyroid tumours
Teratoma
Thoracic aorta
Terrible lymphoma
  Hodgkin lymphoma
Hodgkin lymphoma has two age peaks in prevalence, one in the late 20s and one in the late 70s. It can present at any age however. If a histological finding of Reed-Sternberg cells (binucleate white cells) is given there can be no other diagnosis. Hodgkin lymphoma tends to cause anterior mediastinal masses whereas Non-hodgkin lymphoma tends to cause posterior mediastinal masses. Hodgkin lymphoma nodal involvement spreads contiguously from one region to the next. This makes the staging very easy to remember.
Stage I = one nodal group involved
Stage II = two or more nodal groups involved on the same side of the diaphragm
Stage III = nodal groups on either side of the diaphragm
Stage IV = involvement of non-lymphatic structures (e.g. bone or lung)
  Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL)
NHL is 4 times more prevalent than Hodgkin lymphoma. Thoracic lymph node enlargement is common and classically affects the posterior mediastinum. Unlike Hodgkin lymphoma, NHL demonstrates non-contiguous spread and thus the whole neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis should be included in staging imaging.
The following table summarises some of the imaging features separating the two diagnoses:
    Hodgkin lymphoma
Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
Mediastinal nodes
Anterior
Posterior
Spread
Contiguous
Non-contiguous
Predominantly
Thorax
Abdomen
→ Abdominal involvement
Approx 4%
>50%
→ Thoracic involvement
Approx 85%
Approx 50%
  Malignant thymoma
These tumours spread by invading the mediastinum and encasing the lung with pleural thickening. Vascular invasion is also seen. The collateral features described fit better with Hodgkin lymphoma; for an association with myasthenia gravis there would more usually be weakness and fatigue symptoms with lid lag and diplopia also commonly described. The presence of any pleural deposits would be a good feature to suggest a malignant thymoma over some of the other possible options.
  Malignant germ cell tumour
These include seminomas and non-seminomatous (embryonal, yolk sac, choriocarcinoma, mixed cell type) tumours. Generally speaking they affect young adults and an elevated hCG, LDH, or alpha fetoprotein is usually present. The presence of effusions suggests local pleural invasion and may well be seen. Although the presence or absence of calcification is not featured in this question, the lack of calcification is in-keeping with seminomatous tumours.
  Lipoma
Lipomas are usually easily distinguished by their fat content, giving negative Hounsfield units. No Hounsfield units have been provided here but the remainder of the clinical information provided would not be explained by a lipoma.
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis in this case is Malignant Thymoma because it is the most common type of anterior mediastinal mass in adults, especially in those over the age of 40. Additionally, the presence of fever, weight loss, and night sweats are all symptoms commonly associated with malignant thymoma.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old man presents to his GP with a cough. He undergoes a CXR which shows a 3cm paraspinal mass. On a subsequent CT scan this is shown to be a smooth mass lesion with a dumbbell shape situated in the left paravertebral region. There is expansion of the adjacent neural foramen and the mass extends into the spinal canal. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Dumbbell protrusion of a spinal mass through the neural foramina is a classic description for a neurofibroma. The slow growth of this lesion means there is bony remodeling around it rather than invasion. Neurogenic tumours are the most common cause of a posterior mediastinal mass.
A bronchogenic carcinoma – this would be more likely to invade bone as opposed to remodel it
Lymphoma – this is unlikely to be as isolated a finding as a solitary 3cm mass
Extramedullary haematopoiesis – this would usually also be expected to be multi-level
Marfan syndrome – this is associated with dural ectasia which can in turn also be seen in neurofibromatosis. Dural ectasia causes posterior vertebral body scalloping though, not unilateral dumbbell expansion of the foramina.
Other possible posterior mediastinal masses would be:
Thoracic aortic aneurysm
Ewing sarcoma – aggressive
Lymphoma – multi-level
Paraspinal abscess – unlikely to cause bony remodeling
GPT3_explain: Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder that is characterized by the development of tumors along the nerves of the body. The presence of a 3cm paraspinal mass with a dumbbell shape and extending into the spinal canal is indicative of neurofibromatosis. The expansion of the adjacent neural foramen is also indicative of neurofibromatosis.

Qn_Text: A 52-year-old man visits his GP concerned regarding some recent weight loss. He also describes some vague abdominal pains and is feels his skin has become darker. On examination his GP notes enlarged lymph nodes in his groins and neck. He undergoes a small bowel follow through which is reported as showing sand-like micronodularity of the small bowel. The radiologist reports the bowel to be of normal calibre throughout. Which of the following would best fit with these findings?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Fold thickness
Much is made on barium examinations, of the thickness of the folds and whether there is any nodularity. Such features can be helpful in teasing apart the possible diagnoses in similar cases.
Coeliac disease – dilatation without increase in fold thickness
Scleroderma – dilatation without loss of valvulae conniventes, prolonged transit time
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome – dilatation of the proximal small bowel due to hypersecretion
Small bowel lymphoma – fold thickening and lymph node enlargement
Mastocytosis – nodular fold thickening with sclerotic bone lesions
Crohn disease – nodular fold thickening
Whipple disease – thickened folds (+/- microndularity) without dilatation, with normal transit time
  Whipple disease also known as intestinal lipodystrophy
Infection with Tropheryma whipplei causes a migratory arthralgia with jejunal fold thickening leading to malabsorption and is known as Whipple disease. Skin hyperpigmentation is often described and peripheral lymph nodes may be enlarged. Micronodularity does occur on the thickened folds but crucially there is little or no small bowel dilatation and a normal transit time. Obstruction of the lymphatics leads to low density lymph nodes appearing on CT. PAS positive macrophages confirm the infection.
  Differential diagnosis for lymph nodes of low attenuation
Coeliac disease – cavitating mesenteric lymph node syndrome
Tuberculosis
Whipple disease
Lymphoma
Necrotic metastases
  Small bowel lymphoma
Malignancies of the small bowel are rare but lymphoma is the most common of these. Coeliac disease, infection with H. Pylori and AIDs both predispose patients to developing small bowel lymphoma. Perhaps surprisingly patients do not present with obstruction even when the tumour burden is large, similarly neoplastic perforation is not common. Instead patients present with insidious symptoms or haemorrhage. On imaging there is (sometimes extensive) thickening of the bowel wall, often with associated lymph node enlargement.
  Mastocytosis
Mast cells store histamine (among other things). Where they exist in excess the resultant symptoms fit with excess histamine release. Patients complain of nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, hypotension, flushing and abdominal pain. Asthma-type symptoms can also occur. On imaging hepatosplenomegaly and lymph node enlargement are common. The walls of the small bowel become thickened and malabsorption occurs too. Mastocytosis is also a cause of bony sclerosis.
  Causes of bony sclerosis
Metabolic
Hyperthyroidism
Hyperparathyroidism
Congenital
Pyknodysostosis
Osteopetrosis
Malignant
Lymphoma
Leukaemia
Haematological
Sickle cell disease
Myelofibrosis
Mastocytosis
Other
Fluorosis
Paget disease
  Eosinophilic enteropathy
This is a rare condition caused by infiltration of eosinophils into the wall of the small bowel. Patients often suffer from food allergies and experience multiple attacks of abdominal pain, diarrhoea and vomiting in a relapsing/remitting pattern. Blood eosinophil levels are usually raised. On imaging the folds of the small bowel can appear thickened.
  Scleroderma
Scleroderma is a multi-system connective tissue disease leading to fibrosis and loss of smooth muscle. In the gastrointestinal system this leads to the hidebound sign (similar but different to stacked coin sign which is seen in intramural haematoma where the folds are thickened) where, despite being dilated in calibre, the small bowel still retains the valvulae conniventes which would otherwise be effaced. This is thought to result from fibrosis of the longitudinal layer causing foreshortening along the long axis. In the small bowel there can also be the formation of square-shaped broad-based sacculations (true-diverticulae because they involve all layers of the bowel wall) on the mesenteric border of the bowel is seen owing to uneven atrophy of the smooth muscle there. A prolonged transit time would be ususal. Pseudosacculations (wide-mouthed diverticulae) are found in the colon but this time on the antimesenteric border. (The *only* anti-mesenteric diverticulum of the small bowel is a Meckel's diverticulum.)
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Lymphoma because the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are suggestive of a lymphoproliferative disorder. Enlarged lymph nodes in the neck and groin are a common symptom of lymphoma, as is weight loss and darkening skin. Additionally, the small bowel follow through showed sand-like micronodularity, which is a common finding in lymphoma. These findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of lymphoma.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about application of knowledge to a clinical scenario.

This question falls under category 3: A question about application of knowledge to a clinical scenario.

Qn_Text: A fair-haired 6-year-old boy undergoes a CT chest for further investigation of recurrent chest infections. This demonstrates upper lobe predominant bronchiectasis. The heart is in the expected position. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cystic Fibrosis
This is causes bronchiectasis but predominantly affects the upper lobes. Presentation, if not before this point, is with recurrent chest infections. Otherwise it can present in the neonatal period with a meconium plug causing meconium ileus. (Meconium plug syndrome is very similar insofar as their is large bowel obstruction by meconium but relates to a pathologically small left colon instead and usually resolves with no long term sequela). In both cases Adults often suffer from subfertility, pancreatitis and malabsorption.
  Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia
This predominantly causes bronchiectasis in the middle and lower lobes. Only 50% have Kartagener’s syndrome (A triad of situs inversus, sinusitis and bronchiectasis), hence the normal heart position in the question. Affected men are infertile, and women are subfertile.
  ABPA
This is generally only seen in asthmatics and is characterised by central bronchiectasis particularly in the mid-zones and sometimes upper zones. Centrilobular nodules are also a feature.
  Aspiration
This classically causes lower lobar bronchiectasis, but not in this demographic without mention of risk factors for aspiration in the history.
  Middle Lobe Syndrome
This affects the middle lobe or lingula. Chronic atelectasis arises secondary to airway obstruction from any one of a multitude of different causes (some benign, some malignant) and associated bronchiectasis can develop. Other areas are not usually affected.
GPT3_explain: Cystic Fibrosis is the most likely underlying diagnosis for a 6-year-old boy with upper lobe predominant bronchiectasis, as this is one of the most common causes of this condition. Cystic Fibrosis is caused by a genetic mutation which leads to abnormal mucus production and accumulation in the lungs, resulting in recurrent chest infections, bronchiectasis, and other respiratory issues.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the trachea is true? Select ONE answer only.
A: The C-shaped tracheal rings are composed of hyaline cartilage
B: It bifurcates at the T3 vertebral level
C: It is located posterior to the oesphagus during its descent
D: It arises at the lower border of the thyroid cartilage
E: It is lined by squamous epithelium
Explanation:
Explanation:
The trachea marks the start of the tracheobronchial tree, arising at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, as a continuation of the larynx. This is at the C6 vertebral level.
It travels inferiorly into the superior mediastinum, bifurcating at the level of the sternal angle to form the right and left bronchi. Inside the trachea, at the T5 vertebral level, there is a cartilaginous ridge called the carina of trachea that marks the point of bifurcation. During its descent the trachea is located anterior to the oesophagus and inclines slightly to the right.
Below the cricoid cartilage there are 15 to 20 incomplete C-shaped tracheal rings (tracheal cartilages), which are composed of hyaline cartilage, and serve to reinforce the front and sides of the trachea to protect and maintain the airway. The free ends of these rings are supported by the trachealis muscle.
The trachea and bronchi are lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium, interspersed by goblet cells, which produce mucous. The combination of sweeping movements by the cilia and mucous from the goblet cells forms the functional mucociliary escalator, that traps particles and pathogens and moves them up and out of the airways to be swallowed and destroyed.
  Anatomy of the trachea and bronchi (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2 because the trachea is composed of C-shaped rings of hyaline cartilage, which provide structural support and allow the trachea to expand and contract during breathing.

Qn_Text: Which of the following structures passes through the diaphragm at the vertebral level of T10? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The diaphragm has three main openings:
The caval opening: passes through the central tendon
The oesophageal hiatus: situated in the posterior part of the diaphragm, to the left of the central tendon through the muscular sling of the right crus
The aortic hiatus: situated in the posterior part of the diaphragm, between the left and right crus
  The main openings in the diaphragm and their contents are shown in the table below:
  Opening
Vertebral level
Contents
Caval opening
T8
Inferior vena cava
Branches of right phrenic nerve
Oesophageal hiatus
T10
Oesophagus
Anterior vagal trunk
Posterior vagal trunk
Oesophageal branches of left gastric vessels
Aortic hiatus
T12
Aorta
Azygous veins
Thoracic duct
        Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of OpenStax College CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: The inferior vena cava is a large vein that passes through the diaphragm at the vertebral level of T10. It carries deoxygenated blood from the lower body to the right atrium of the heart.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old athlete complains of calf claudication. On Doppler ultrasound there is popliteal stenosis. You suspect he has cystic adventitial degeneration. Which of the following is the LEAST likely finding on MRI in this case? Select ONE answer only.
A: Low T1, low T2 in the popliteal artery wall
B: Low T1, high T2 in the popliteal artery wall
C: High T1, high T2 in the popliteal artery wall
D: Intermediate T1, high T2 in the popliteal artery wall
E: Intermediate T1, intermediate T2 in the popliteal artery wall
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely option.
  Cystic adventitial degeneration
On MRI scanning, mucous cysts can be seen in the wall of the popliteal artery. These, like most cysts, show high T2 signal and the T1 signal can be variable depending on the quantity of mucin present. This disease has a strong male preponderance and particularly affects the popliteal artery. On MRI the signal can be variable on T1 depending on the protein content of the cyst but returns a high signal on T2.
GPT3_explain: Cystic adventitial degeneration is a type of degenerative arterial disease that affects the walls of the popliteal artery. It is characterized by cystic dilatation of the adventitia, which is the outermost layer of the artery wall. On MRI, cystic adventitial degeneration typically shows low T1, low T2, and intermediate T1 and T2 signal intensity in the popliteal artery wall. Therefore, the least likely finding on MRI in this case would be high T1, high T2 in the popliteal artery wall.

Qn_Text: A 59-year-old lady undergoes an MRI of her spine. Six months previously she had received radiotherapy to lumbar spine as part of management of breast carcinoma. Which of the following is the most likely appearance of the bone marrow?
A: Very high on T1, isointense on T2
B: High on T1, isointense on T2
C: High on T1, high on T2
D: Low on T1, low on T2
E: Isointense on T1, low on T2
Explanation:
Explanation:
Favours osteoporosis
Favours metastases
Retropulsed bony fragments
Convex posterior cortex
Fluid adjacent to the fractured end plates
Associated soft tissue masses
Multiple compression fractures
Other metastases without compression fractures
Sparing of the marrow signal
Marrow signal abnormalities
  Involvement of the posterior elements of the spine
    Bone marrow on MRI
  T1 T2
Normal bone marrow
High (fatty) Intermediate
Post-Radiotherapy
Very high and homogenous Intermediate (initially high due to oedema)
Haemangioma
High High
Abnormal bone (metastases, myeloma, regeneration)
Low but enhances with Gadolinium High (fluid)
Blastic metastases (prostate, breast, TCC) and myelofibrosis
Low Low
  Metastases
Normally metastatic deposits in the spine lead to low T1 signal and high T2 signal. There should be no signal drop out on fat saturated sequences in contrast to marrow reconversion where although red marrow will experience far less signal dropout than yellow marrow, there will still be some loss in signal owing to the fat content of both types of marrow.
Sclerotic or blastic metastases return little signal on either T1 or T2 weighted sequences. These include prostate, breast or TCC metastases among others.
Breast cancer can cause lytic or sclerotic metastases or a mixed picture.
Lytic metastases are more likely than sclerotic metastases to enhance with contrast. Similarly on DWI imaging, whereas lytic metastases will usually appear hyperintense, sclerotic metastases return little signal since they contain little water.
If there is a diffuse abnormality of the bone marrow it can be difficult to identify but normal bone marrow should not be lower in signal intensity than the muscle on T1 weighted sequences.
GPT3_explain: The most likely appearance of the bone marrow after radiotherapy is very high on T1, isointense on T2. This is because radiotherapy can cause bone marrow edema, which is characterized by high signal intensity on T1-weighted images and isointense signal on T2-weighted images.

Qn_Text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the Emergency Department by her parents. She has severe abdominal tenderness and distension. Ultrasound demonstrates an ileocolic intussusception. She is brought round to the radiology department for an attempt at reduction by fluoroscopically guided air enema. Your assistant suggests you remove the grid before beginning the procedure. Which of the following regarding grids is correct? Select ONE answer only.
A: Use of a grid increases the dose to the patient
B: Grids are not necessary for paediatric patients
C: Grids help reduce the effect of patient motion
D: Use of a grid increases dose to the operator
E: Without the grid there is no need to wear lead aprons
Explanation:
Explanation:
Grids
An anti-scatter grid is useful for patients heavier than around 20kg (about age 4-5) when scatter from within the patient reduces the image quality but, especially for patients smaller than this, the grid only serves to increase the patient dose (by only allowing direct photons through, a greater number of photons must be supplied to create the resultant image). Without any numbers or calculations to perform it is difficult to compare the effects of grid removal and field of view however in this patient the grid should definitely not be used as the patient is too small.
  Magnification and FOV
Image magnification can be achieved either via geometric or electronic means. Geometric magnification reduces patient dose by moving the patient further away from the radiation source however the further the patient is from the source, the greater the blurring effect of any patient (or bowel, or respiratory) motion. Electronic magnification is also called changing the field of view (think of this like zooming) and increasing the FOV does reduce the dose, but at the expense of image sharpness. The dose saving can be significant owing to the inverse square law.
  Collimation
Collimating the x-ray beam involves using lead shielding to concentrate the x-ray beam onto the target area (think of this like cropping). It is important to avoid irradiating tissue which is not required for diagnosis but also reduces operator dose by reducing scatter from the irradiated patient. This may be challenging in a paediatric intussusception scan as it relies on the patient lying still within the target area.
  Continuous vs pulsed
Continuous fluoroscopy mode (as opposed to pulsed fluoroscopy) involves, as the name suggests, imaging continuously as opposed to taking an image at pulsed intervals which involves far less dose. Moving objects are also better imaged with pulsed mode as there can be significant blurring when using continuous fluoroscopy.
GPT3_explain: I chose answer 1 because the use of a grid increases the dose to the patient. Grids are used to reduce scatter radiation and improve contrast, but they also increase the dose to the patient by blocking some of the x-rays. This is especially important to consider when dealing with pediatric patients, who are more sensitive to radiation exposure.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical decision-making, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: An 84-year-old lady is admitted to the Emergency Department after developing shortness of breath. The doctor reviewing her is concerned she may have a pulmonary embolus. There is no history of lung disease and a chest radiograph has been reported as normal. The patient has an eGFR of 25. Which of the following would be best to manage this patient? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
VQ (ventilation perfusion) scan
VQ scans are useful to risk stratify the diagnosis of pulmonary emboli in patients who have a contrast allergy or are at increased risk of contrast induced nephropathy. The chest x-ray must be normal however, to consider a VQ scan.
In pregnancy or lactation, VQ scanning also confers a far lower breast dose to the mother but the dose to the foetus, particularly when small, can be greater owing to tracer accumulation within the solid organs of the mother. The mother should be encouraged to adequately hydrate and void frequently in the subsequent hours/days following a scan.
Many institutes choose to perform perfusion scanning only in pregnant women on the understanding that if the perfusion scan is normal then there is no need to go on to perform the ventilation study. The perfusion scan can also be performed at half the usual dose to further reduce the foetal dose. Naturally doing so comes with the trade-off of lower sensitivity and specificity.
GPT3_explain: V/Q scan is the best option for managing this patient as it is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect pulmonary embolism. It involves the injection of a radioactive tracer that is taken up by the lungs and can detect any blockages or areas of decreased blood flow. V/Q scans are also less expensive than other imaging techniques, making them a more cost-effective option for this patient. Additionally, given the patient's age and renal function, the risks associated with CTPA and angiography would be too high.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical judgement, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a chest radiograph of a patient admitted from the respiratory clinic with an infective exacerbation of bronchiectasis. The field of view is wide and you can see dark streaks of air following the contour of the wall of the colon at the splenic flexure. The clinical information provided suggests that the patient is otherwise well. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis
There are a variety of terms used in a variety of contexts in the literature, often with overlap in intended usage. The term pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis is used to describe the presence of multiple gas-filled cysts within the wall of the 'intestines' (either small bowel or large bowel or both. To specify solely colonic involvement the correct term is Pneumatosis Cystoides Coli). It is a form of pneumatosis coli but whereas the latter has more sinister connotations, usually ischaemia, patients with pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis may be completely asymptomatic. In around 15% of patients no cause is identified (i.e. idiopathic) but it is also thought to be akin to gastric emphysema arising in patients with long-term respiratory conditions causing excessive coughing. 
    Differential diagnosis for intramural gas
  Ch = Chronic respiratory condition
I = Ischaemia
P = Post-traumatic
S = Scleroderma or steroids
  Swyer-James syndrome
In this condition, normal development of the infant lung is impeded by bronchiolitis (viral or mycoplasma) at an early age, with superadded acute airspace destruction. Consequently the affected lobe is small and lucent on the CXR due to air trapping. It is a differential diagnosis for a unilateral lucent hemithorax, along with a pneumothorax, very large pulmonary emboli and causes of decreased chest wall musculature such as Poland syndrome or, historically, polio. In an an exam situation Swyer-James syndrome is usually given as a teenage or young adult patient with a history of recurrent LRTIs. Air trapping, and bronchiectasis can also be described.
  Volvulus
In various areas of the abdomen it is possible for parts of the bowel to twist on themselves causing compromise to their own vascular supply and leading to a closed loop obstruction. This is termed a volvulus. The two most common locations are at redundant loops of sigmoid colon and the caecum but the transverse colon can also volve, as can the entire small bowel and the stomach. The following signs are mainly described with respect to sigmoid volvulus but there is some cross-over to the other types too.
Coffee-bean sign: two opposing dilated loops with a distinct midline crease
Three-line sign: the two outer walls of the loops and the central line
Bird-of-prey sign: on a barium enema, the beak-like outline of the most superior extent that the barium reaches before the volvulus
Whirl sign: on CT, the twisted mesenteric vessels at the centre of the torsion
Sigmoid volvulus is often associated wtih elderly patients who have chronic constipation but patients with any age can develop sigmoid redundancy thereby making them prone to a sigmoid volvulus. Pregnancy and institutionalisation are also risk factors.
In cases of caecal volvulus the haustral markings are preserved even when there is significant dilatation however in the sigmoid colon the haustra can flatten out under endo-tension. This is a specific sign for a sigmoid volvulus.
Chiliaditi sign is seen on a chest x-ray where the transverse colon rises up to sit under the right hemidiaphragm, between it and the liver. It is a mimic for subdiaphragmatic gas.
Sigmoid
Caecal
Older patients
Younger patients (20-40s)
70% of cases
20% of cases
Ahaustral
Haustral
Loops converge to the left pelvis
Loops convervge to the right lower quadrant or left upper quadrant
GPT3_explain: Pneumatosis coli is a condition in which gas-filled cysts form in the wall of the large intestine. It is typically seen in patients with an infective exacerbation of bronchiectasis, and the radiograph shows dark streaks of air following the contour of the wall of the colon at the splenic flexure, which is consistent with this diagnosis.
Cat_Long: This question falls under the category of clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing an MRI scan of a 30-year-old man’s spine. At which vertebral level does the spinal cord terminate in adults? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The spinal cord terminates at L1/2 in adults and L3 in infants. The subarachnoid space ends at S2 in adults and also lies lower in infants.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the spinal cord typically terminates at the L5/S1 vertebral level in adults. This is the lowest level of the lumbar spine, and it is where the spinal cord meets the sacrum, which is a triangular bone at the base of the spine.

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old presents with progressive shortness of breath which has become more severe over the last few days. On examination, there is a pansystolic murmur. A chest radiograph is performed which demonstrates splaying of the carina with a double border of the right heart. There is also isolated right upper lobe pulmonary oedema. The patient then undergoes echocardiogram. What is the most likely finding?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Mitral regurgitation
Chronic regurgitation causes left atrial enlargement with splaying of the carina and a double right heart border. It is also the only valvular pathology associated with isolated right upper lobe pulmonary oedema.
  Aortic stenosis
This can be congenital or acquired. Dilation of ascending aorta is seen due to a jet from the stenosis. Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy is occasionally a feature.
  Aortic regurgitation
This is usually secondary to bacterial endocarditis, Marfan’s, bicuspid aortic valve or aortic root dilatation (due to hypertension).
  Mitral stenosis
The most common cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic heart disease. It can cause left atrial dilatation, but is not associated with right upper lobe pulmonary oedema.
  Tricuspid atresia
This occurs with right ventricular hypoplasia (and often ASD or PFO) as part of a congenital abnormality. It can also be associated with asplenia.
GPT3_explain: Aortic stenosis is the most likely finding on an echocardiogram in this case. This is because the patient has a pansystolic murmur, which is a symptom of aortic stenosis. Additionally, the chest radiograph demonstrates splaying of the carina with a double border of the right heart, which is a sign of aortic stenosis. Therefore, aortic stenosis is the most likely diagnosis.

3. A question about medical management of a patient.

Qn_Text: A 4-month-old baby is reviewed in the paediatric clinic following concerns regarding his head. A flat, widened skull shape with ‘harlequin eye’ and premature closure of the coronal sutures describes which of the following craniosynostosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The most common suture to undergo premature closure is the Sagittal suture which gives Dolichocephaly/ scaphcephaly (long and skinny). Closure of the metopic suture gives a pointed forehead known as Trigonocephaly. Coronal suture closure is known as brachycephaly which also gives a ‘harlequin eye’ appearance. Unilateral (plagiocephaly) and bilateral (turricephaly) lambdoid premature suture closure have also been described.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Scaphocephaly because it is the only craniosynostosis that is characterized by a flat, widened skull shape with ‘harlequin eye’ and premature closure of the coronal sutures. Brachycephaly is characterized by a wide skull shape with premature closure of the lambdoid sutures. Turricephaly is characterized by a tall, pointed skull shape with premature closure of the sagittal suture. Plagiocephaly is characterized by an asymmetrical skull shape with flattening of one side of the head. Trigonocephaly is characterized by a triangular skull shape with premature closure of the metopic suture.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical decision making, what is the best treatment option?
