Qn_Text: A 45-year-old lady presents to A+E with left sided loin to groin pain and undergoes an abdominal x-ray as part of investigations into a suspected diagnosis of ureteric colic. On the x-ray there is calcification in the right iliac fossa. She undergoes an MRI and the calcification relates to an ovarian lesion which returns high signal on both T1 and T2 with areas of low T2 signal seen at the peripheries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Mature teratoma
Teratomas and dermoid cysts have very similar imaging characteristics despite their histological differences. Teratomas are the most common ovarian neoplasm but are slow growing and usually benign. By contrast immature teratomas are malignant. The presence of fat is a strong indicator for a mature teratoma with the combination of fat, fluid and calcification being highly specific. On MRI the fat will show the usual signal drop-out on gradient echo sequences. Calcification will show as low signal on T2. Although benign, mature teratomas can be complicated by torsion or rupture. Malignant degeneration if it does occur, is to squamous cell carcinoma most commonly.
  Mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ovary
Although these are typically multilocular on imaging the diagnosis can often only be suggested, with confirmation coming from histological specimens. The imaging characteristics can vary depending on the mucein content of the tumour. Thick mucein returns high signal on T1 and can appear denser than soft tissue on CT. Mucinous adenocarcinomas of the ovary can be ginormous when they present.
  Ectopic pregnancy 
Vaginal bleeding is very common in early pregnancy but vaginal bleeding with pain or pain without vaginal bleeding definitely call for an ectopic pregnancy to be excluded. Factors which increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy include:
Previous ectopic 
IVF conception
Previous surgery to the Fallopian tubes
PID
  Since most present around 7-8 weeks gestation it is usual that the woman will not yet have had the first routine ultrasound scan, or in many cases, may not yet be aware of the pregnancy at all. Serial serum beta HCGs usually fail to double in the usual 48hours for ectopic pregnancies. The exact level of beta HCG helps guide the sonographer as to what they can expect to find. An ectopic pregnancy is most commonly located within one or other Fallopian tube. Ultrasound will fail to show an intrauterine pregnancy and the ectopic pregnancy can often be seen as a cystic mass elsewhere. The classic ‘ring of fire’ sign refers to the peripheral colour Doppler flow seen on an ectopic pregnancy although this can also be seen on a normal corpus luteal cyst.
  Germ Cell tumour
Ovarian germ cell tumours include teratomas, yolk sac tumours, choriocarcinomas and mixed germ cell tumours. Ovarian embryonal carcinoma and dysgerminomas are also germ cell tumours although they are far less common. Germ cell tumours make up approximately a quarter of all ovarian tumours and tend to affect young adults or children although can occur at any age. Besides pregnancy and gestational trophoblastic disease, beta HCG can also be raised ovarian embryonal carcinoma and dysgerminoma. Embryonal carcinoma can also cause elevation of AFP levels although this would be more classically associated with a Leydig-Sertoli tumour. Embryonal carcinoma can cause menstrual irregularity and any torting ovarian tumour can lead to the acute presentation described. Thick septa as a finding in ovarian masses is strongly linked to malignancy of any nature.
  Krukenberg tumours 
A Kruckenberg tumour is a metastatic deposit from stomach cancer which causes ovarian masses. These are often bilateral and can be mistaken for primary malignancies. The histology is of a mucin producing 'signet-ring' cell cancer of which most derive from the stomach but colorectal, breast, lung, and pancreatic versions can also cause Kruckenberg tumours. On all modalities the tumours have a complex part-cystic, part-solid appearance.
GPT3_explain: Mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ovary is the most likely diagnosis based on the imaging findings. The presence of calcification in the right iliac fossa, high signal on T1 and T2 with areas of low T2 signal seen at the peripheries are highly suggestive of this diagnosis. Other possible diagnoses such as ectopic pregnancy, dermoid, germ cell tumour, and Kruckenberg tumour are less likely based on these findings.

Qn_Text: A 14 -year-old girl confides in her mother that her periods have stopped. She denies being pregnant. Her GP requests an ultrasound and this shows an ovarian lesion. Blood tests done concurrently show an elevated AFP but the βHCG is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The top two answers for this question are a Leydig-Sertoli tumour and a Yolk sac tumour however only the former produces oestrogen and progesterone which would cause the amenorrhoea described in the vignette. Furthermore, although there is overlap, Leydig-Sertoli tumours tend to affect a slightly younger population than Yolk sac tumours. Yolk sac tumours are typically very aggressive, and usually very large at presentation. Presentation with a Yolk sac tumour is usually with a pelvic mass and associated symptoms.
  Leydig-Sertoli tumour
Most patients with a Leydig-Sertoli tumour are in their early teens. Normal Leydig and Sertoli cells are found in the testes and produce testosterone and oestrogen respectively, among other hormones. Leydig-Sertoli tumours often produce one or both hormones in excess leading to virilisation and amenorrhoea, although some patients may experience no hormonal manifestations. AFP is often elevated. They are solid, fibrous tumours which can show cystic elements where haemorrhage or necrosis has taken place. Owing to their fibrous nature they usually return low signal on MRI, with/without high signal foci related to the cystic areas.
  Granulosa cell tumours
These oestrogen producing tumours can affect women of any age. The excess oestrogen causes irregular or post menopausal bleeding. They tend to be large and multicystic with thick septations and a sponge-like appearance. Importantly they can be differentiated from epithelial ovarian tumours (e.g. Mucinous cystanedomas) by their lack of a feature described as intracystic papillary projections.
  Corpus luteal cyst
The corpus luteum comprises the remnant of an ovarian follicle post ovulation. Without fertilisation the normal corpus luteum will involute spontaneously within 2 weeks but occasionally they can persist even in the absence of fertilisation and be seen as a corpus luteum cyst. Ultrasound characteristics depend slightly on the age of the cyst and the presence or absence of haemorrhage within it but a small (<3 cm) thick walled, rounded, cystic structure with peripheral vascularity (the so-called ‘ring of fire’) would be classical. A repeat ultrasound scan after 6 weeks (to ensure a different part of the menstrual cycle) is usually recommended.
  Yolk sac tumour
These unpleasant germ cell tumours affect adolescents and can be quite large at presentation. A raised serum AFP is common. They are usually solid with or without cystic areas. Since they can arise from an ovarian dermoid sometimes fat signal can also be seen in association with these tumours.
  Mature teratoma
Teratomas and dermoid cysts have very similar imaging characteristics despite their histological differences. Teratomas are the most common ovarian neoplasm but are slow growing and usually benign. By contrast immature teratomas are malignant. The presence of fat is a strong indicator for a mature teratoma with the combination of fat, fluid and calcification being highly specific. On MRI the fat will show the usual signal drop-out on gradient echo sequences. Calcification will show as low signal on T2. Although benign, mature teratomas can be complicated by torsion or rupture. Malignant degeneration if it does occur, is to squamous cell carcinoma most commonly.
GPT3_explain: Granulosa cell tumours are the most likely diagnosis in this case due to the elevated AFP and normal βHCG. Elevated AFP can be indicative of a granulosa cell tumour, which is a type of ovarian tumour that can cause amenorrhea (absence of periods) in adolescents. The ultrasound would be able to confirm the presence of a lesion in the ovary, and the normal βHCG indicates that the girl is not pregnant.

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old woman presents with back discomfort with pain and weakness in her legs. She undergoes an MRI of her lumbar spine for further assessment. The L3/4 disc is seen to extrude paracentrally and compress a nerve root. Which nerve root is most likely to be affected? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
In the cervical spine the nerve roots exit at the spinal cord without needing to traverse (as in the lumbar spine). The exiting nerve root takes the name of the vertebra BELOW the affected disc. A disc protrusion at C3/4 will affect the C4 nerve root. This allows for the extra nerve root at C8 before reaching the thoracic spine. In the thoracic spine the affected level takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level.
In the lumbar spine the exiting nerve root is usually compressed in the neural foramen, whereas the traversing nerve root is compressed usually in the lateral recess. Far lateral bulges affect the exiting nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level). Paracentral bulges affect the traversing nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body BELOW that level).
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: L4 is the nerve root most likely to be affected because it is the nerve root that is compressed by the extruded disc at the L3/4 level. The L3 and L2 nerve roots would be affected by the disc at the L3/4 level, but the L4 nerve root would be the most affected due to the direct compression.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about application of knowledge, what is the best treatment for this patient?

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the details of a patient with a known syndrome manifesting as a facial rash, a history of seizures and a known splenic adenoma. What is the other associated finding with this syndrome?
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are a limited number of mainstream phakomatoses (NF1, NF2, Sturge-Weber, von Hippel-Lindau, and Tuberous sclerosis) and they all have fairly well definable features. Tuberous sclerosis has a triad of facial angiofibromas, seizures and mental retardation. Giant cell astrocytomas are found in some patients.
 Bilateral schwannomas
NF2
Optic gliomas NF1 (NB this can be asked as a question differentiating an optic nerve glioma from a meningioma, one being suggestive of NF1 and the latter pointing towards NF2).
Angioma vHL or Sturge-Weber
Haemangioblastoma
vHL
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because bilateral schwannomas are one of the most common associated findings with the syndrome manifesting as a facial rash, a history of seizures, and a known splenic adenoma. Bilateral schwannomas are benign tumors of the Schwann cells, which are cells that form the myelin sheath around nerve fibers. These tumors can affect the cranial nerves, resulting in hearing loss, facial weakness, and other neurological symptoms.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 20-month-old baby boy whose parents are concerned that his stomach has become very large. There is a large mass in the left retroperitoneal space. You suspect he may have a neuroblastoma. Which of the following features is NOT in-keeping with this diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which feature is NOT in-keeping with the diagnosis.
  Feature Neuroblastoma Wilms tumour
Peak age 2 years 3-4 years
Kidney Drooping lily sign – displaced downwards, if not invaded Claw sign – rim of normal renal tissue extending around the mass
Crosses midline More common Less common
Calcification
More common
Regular and stippled
Less common
Curvilinear and phleobliths
IVC Encases Displaces and/or invades
  Neuroblastoma
This is the most common solid abdominal mass in infants and second most common in children of all ages (after Wilms tumours). Most are adrenal in location, around a third develop in the retroperitoneum and a fifth are located in the posterior mediastinum. Presentation can be with abdominal pain, a mass, or a fever. Most (95%) secrete catecholamines such as VMA (vanillylmandelic acid – leads to hypertension) or VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptides – leads to watery diarrhoea). There are also a few distinct clinical syndromes which herald the presence of a neuroblastoma.
  Syndrome Details
Blueberry muffin syndrome Metastatic cutaneous deposits
Opsomyoclonus Rapid jerky eye movements and myoclonic jerks of the legs. This occurs in around 2% of neuroblastoma cases but around 50% of patients with opsomyoclonus have a neuroblastoma.
Hutchinson syndrome Limping due to bony metastases
  On imaging, neuroblastomas appear as a very large abdominal mass with or without speckled calcification within in. The kidney can either be invaded or just displaced inferiorly, causing a ‘drooping lily’ appearance on urography (where contrast within the inferiorly displaced renal calyces has the appearance of a lily flower with its head hanging down). Neuroblastomas tend to encase large vessels such as the IVC, as opposed to displacing them as Wilms tumours are prone to doing. Staging is performed with an 123I-MIBG scan (as opposed to a 99mTc-MDP bone scan) and importantly within the staging it is actually stage IVs (disease involving the skin, bone marrow and liver) which has the best prognosis.
GPT3_explain: Neuroblastomas typically do not encase the inferior vena cava (IVC), which is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower body to the heart. Other features associated with neuroblastomas include curvilinear calcification, the drooping lily sign, and secretion of catecholamines.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about diagnostic decision-making and interpretation of findings.

3. A question about diagnostic decision-making and interpretation of findings.

Qn_Text: A 72-year-old man has leg weakness and incontinence some weeks after undergoing a discectomy. On MRI there is clumping of the nerves in the cauda equina posteriorly. What is the diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Arachnoiditis
The giveaway feature here is ‘clumping of the nerve roots’. At other times this may be describes as ‘empty thecal sac sign’ where the nerve roots are so adherent to the posterior aspect of the space that they become next to invisible. Arachnoiditis can occur secondary to surgery, meningitis, subarachnoid haemorrhage, myelography and can also be idiopathic in origin.
  Disc sequestration
This is the term used to describe the finding when a part of the disc material has completely separated itself from its parent disc and is seen free within the canal.
  Post-op fibrosis
MRI scans are often performed to look for post-op fibrosis or scar tissue and to differentiate it from recurrent disc pathology. The important imaging feature in such cases is enhancement Scar tissue will show enhancement with contrast whereas disc material will not.
  CSF leak
Although this would be a valid concern post-operatively the usual presentation is of positional headaches and most of the time there is nothing to see on imaging.
GPT3_explain: Disc sequestration is a condition in which a fragment of a herniated intervertebral disc becomes completely separated from the rest of the disc, resulting in a localized area of nerve compression. In this case, the MRI findings of clumping of the nerves in the cauda equina posteriorly suggest that a fragment of the disc has become separated from the rest of the disc, resulting in compression of the nerves and causing the patient's symptoms of leg weakness and incontinence.

Qn_Text: A 48-year-old man is suspected to have a TFCC tear to his left wrist. He is scheduled to have an MRI arthrogram to delineate this further. Where should the contrast be injected? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The TFCC - the triangular fibrocartilage complex
There are five components to the TFCC.
TFC - triangular fibrocartilage
Dorsal and volar radioulnar ligaments
Ulnolunate and ulnotriquetral ligaments
Meniscus
Extensor carpi ulnaris tendon
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Elatmani s CC BY-SA 3.0
  Leakage of contrast from the radiocarpal compartment into the distal radioulnar compartment confirms the presence of a tear.
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 3. The volar approach to the ulnatriquetral compartment is the most direct and effective way to inject contrast for imaging of the TFCC. This approach allows for direct visualization of the TFCC, allowing for accurate assessment of any tears or other abnormalities.

Qn_Text: A 3-week-old boy is reviewed in clinic. He has been diagnosed with heterotaxy in utero, following a finding of TAPVR on an antenatal scan. Which of the following would help distinguish between left and right sided isomerism? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Heterotaxy
There are two main forms of this congenital disorder:
Left sided isomerism (polysplenia)
Things that would usually be found on the left side are duplicated on the right side too. The most consistent features are the abnormalities of the spleen and IVC. The other features are commonly associated, but variably seen. The prognosis is slightly better than for asplenia syndrome as there is a lower association with congenital heart disease. There is still 75% mortality by age 5 though.
Spleen - multiple little spleens
IVC - interrupted IVC with azygos or hemiazygos continuation
Lung lobes - two on either side
Liver - situated centrally in the abdomen
Bowel - malrotation
Pancreas - truncated
Heart - ASD, VSD, PAPVR (less severe congenital heart disease)
  Right sided isomerism (asplenia)
Things that would normally be found on the right side are duplicated on the left side too. Strong association with severe congenital heart disease means the condition has a mortality rate of 80% by age 1. Beyond that, the most consistent feature is the absence of the spleen. Once again, the other features are commonly associated, but variably demonstrated.
Heart - TAPVR and other anomalies (Almost 100% have severe cyanotic congenital heart disease)
Spleen - absent
Lung lobes - three on either side (specific finding)
Liver - normal position (can be midline or malpositioned)
Bowel - malrotation
IVC - on same side as aorta (usually the right)
Kidneys - associated with horseshoe kidney
GPT3_explain: Cardiac anomalies can help distinguish between left and right sided isomerism because the heart is the most commonly affected organ in heterotaxy. Depending on the type of isomerism, the position of the heart and its associated structures, such as the great vessels, can be different. For example, in left isomerism, the left atrium is usually hypoplastic and the right atrium is usually larger. In right isomerism, the right atrium is usually hypoplastic and the left atrium is usually larger.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing an MRI scan of a 45-year-old woman's brain. There is a left conal lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The differential diagnosis for orbital pathology is heavily anatomically based. Having said that, rhabdomyosarcomas typically occur in childhood.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  Globe lesions are situated within the eyeball itself.
Retinoblastoma
Melanoma
Retinal detachment
Outside the globe there are three conditions which are included in all of the other orbital compartments namely sarcoidosis, pseudotumours and lymphoproliferative lesions.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  Lymphoproliferative disorders include leukaemias, lymphomas, and less aggressive collections of lymphoid tissue. The term is used particularly in head and neck radiology where histological diagnosis of such entities is key. Some masses on a CT scan can have a 'typical' appearance for a lymphoma but are actually only benign lymphoid hyperplastic tissue and thus the term lymphoproliferative disorder covers both entities accurately.
IgG4 related diseases are one of Radiology’s newest entities. They comprise a constellation of fibrotic conditions affecting virtually every part of the body, mediated by a subclass of Immunoglobulin called IgG4. Where one condition exists others may also be present. The more common of these include:
Orbital pseudotumour
Fibrosing mediastinitis
Reidel thyroiditis
Autoimmune pancreatitis
Sclerosing mesenteritis
Retroperitoneal fibrosis
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because optic nerve meningiomas are the most common type of tumor found in this location. They are usually benign, slow-growing tumors that can cause vision loss and other neurological symptoms. They can be treated with surgery, radiation therapy, or medications.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man with back pain is seen by an orthopaedic surgeon who requests x-rays. The x-rays show a number of findings which lead you to suspect he has ochronosis. Which of the following is NOT a feature of ochronosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is NOT a feature.
  Alkaptonuria (also known as ochronosis)
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is caused by excessive circulating levels of homogentisic acid (HGA) when the enzyme which would usually degrade it is deficient. HGA has an affinity for collagen and accumulates in the connective tissues throughout the body. In visible light HGA has a blackish colour and thus the disease can be diagnosed in infancy when a baby’s nappies are stained black by the presence of HGA in the urine. By the time patients reach their 20s pigmentation may be visible in their skin, particularly the ears. This is initially a dark yellow colour (hence the term ochronosis, from ‘Ochre’ in Greek meaning a dark yellow colour) but can progress to blue-grey and black.
In imaging chondrocalcinosis is the most prominent feature, with calcification and destruction of the intervertebral discs. Premature osteoarthritic changes to the hands, feet, shoulders, hips and knees will also develop as the collagen deteriorates. Deposition in the heart and kidneys too leads to cardiac and renal failure.
GPT3_explain: Renal failure is not a feature of ochronosis. Ochronosis is a metabolic disorder that is caused by an abnormality in the metabolism of the amino acid, homogentisic acid. It is characterized by the deposition of homogentisic acid in the connective tissues of the body, leading to the formation of ochronotic pigment, which is a yellowish-brown pigment. The clinical features of ochronosis include joint pain, stiffness, and deformities, as well as discoloration of the skin, eyes, and teeth. Hook-like osteophytes, osteoarthritis to hands, and disc calcification are all features of ochronosis.

Qn_Text: Which of the following regarding benign intracranial hypertension and sagittal sinus thrombosis is correct? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Papilloedema can be seen in both conditions
B: Prominent temporal horns occur due to increased CSF absorption in sagittal sinus thrombosis
C: Bilateral haemorrhages in sagittal sinus thrombosis occur as a result of arterial infarction
D: Empty sella syndrome is a feature of sagittal sinus thrombosis
E: Ventricular bleeds are commonly seen in benign intracranial hypertension
Explanation:
Explanation:
Benign intracranial hypertension - (idiopathic intracranial hypertension)
This condition can easily be overlooked but causes significant morbidity for patients if undiagnosed. Increased intracranial pressure of the CSF on the surrounding brain causes:
Flattening of the posterior aspect of the globe
Tortuosity of the optic nerves
Empty sella syndrome (or partially so)
Small, 'Pinched' lateral ventricles (slit-like appearance is a relatively rare, poor sign to rely on).
  Sagittal sinus thrombosis
In sagittal sinus thrombosis the development of cerebral oedema secondary to infarction can compress the lateral ventricles, a finding in approximately a third of cases.
In contrast to this, prominent temporal horns, suggestive of developing hydrocephalus can be seen in sagittal sinus thrombosis due to decreased CSF absorption.
Ventricular bleeds might be seen in sagittal sinus thrombosis in the neonatal age group.
Bilateral haemorrhages in the context of sagittal sinus thrombosis are caused by venous infarction.
Papilloedema can be seen with both sagittal sinus thrombosis and idiopathic intracranial hypertension but is not an imaging feature.
GPT3_explain: Bilateral haemorrhages in sagittal sinus thrombosis occur as a result of arterial infarction. This is because when the sinus is thrombosed, the venous drainage from the brain is blocked, leading to increased pressure in the venous system and rupture of the arterial walls. This can lead to haemorrhages in the brain, which can be seen on imaging.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 73-year-old man presents with a left homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely cause for this?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory infarction
B: Branch retinal artery occlusion in the left eye
C: Left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory infarction
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are two facets to the question; the first is in knowing that a homonymous hemianopia suggests a problem in the contralateral optic tract and the second is in knowing the arterial supply to the optic tracts.
A left branch retinal artery occlusion would give a left sided hemianopia or quadrantanopia.
A left PCA infarction might cause a right homonymous hemianopia.
Meningiomas are usually slow growing and incidentally discovered. This would be a very unusual presentation of a meningioma.
GPT3_explain: The most likely cause for a left homonymous hemianopia is a left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory infarction. This is because the left PCA territory is responsible for supplying the left occipital lobe, which is the area of the brain responsible for vision on the left side of the visual field. A stroke or infarction in this area can cause a homonymous hemianopia, which is a loss of vision on the left side of the visual field.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: What is the best sequence on MRI for differentiating an epidermoid cyst from an arachnoid cyst? Select one answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are a few key features to cerebellopontine angle masses which help distinguish them from one another. An arachnoid cyst will follow CSF on all sequences whereas an epidermoid will restrict diffusion.
GPT3_explain: SWI is the best sequence on MRI for differentiating an epidermoid cyst from an arachnoid cyst because it can provide a good contrast between the two types of cysts. SWI can detect cysts that are not visible on other sequences, such as T1 and T2, and can also provide a better assessment of the cyst’s size and shape. Additionally, SWI can provide a better evaluation of the cyst’s contents, which can be helpful in distinguishing between an epidermoid cyst and an arachnoid cyst.

This question falls under category 3: A question about clinical decision making, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: Which of the following is NOT an atypical feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis? Select one option only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
This question has asked a double negative. ‘Not an atypical feature’. Aspergillomas, pneumothoraces, normal central bronchi and empyemas would all be atypical for ABPA.
Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is part of the spectrum of lung diseases caused by the fungus Aspergillus. How the fungus affects the patient depends on their underlying immune status.
Severely immunocompromised patients                        → Invasive aspergillosis
Mildly immunocompromised patients                            → semi-invasive aspergillosis
Normal patients                                                                   → non-invasive aspergillosis (such as colonization of a pre-existing cyst or cavity)
Hypersensitive patients (Cystic fibrosis or asthmatics) → Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
ABPA causes a ‘migratory pneumonitis’, typically affecting the upper lobes. Parenchymal changes are fleeting; appearing in one area of the lung one week and a different area the next. The ‘finger in glove’ sign can often be seen, where mucus plugging of a bronchus allows the distal airway to fill with secretions giving rise to a ‘V’ or Y’ shaped shadow on a CXR or CT. Central bronchiectasis is a prominent feature and maybe indicated by the phrase ‘ring shadows’ in a description. The peripheral bronchi are classically spared. Cavity formation is seen in the later stages of the disease although aspergillomas are not typical (these occur in patients with a normal immune system). The typical patient will be young, with a history of either asthma or cystic fibrosis or ‘chronic lung disease’, symptoms of malaise, headache and intermittent chest pains, and an eosinophilia on their full blood count.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3 because a normal central bronchi is not an atypical feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to the fungus Aspergillus, which can cause inflammation and obstruction of the airways, as well as the formation of a fungus ball (aspergilloma) in the airways and/or cavities in the lungs. Pneumothorax, empyema, and cavities are all atypical features of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man presents for an ultrasound scan with a left testicular lump. The ultrasound scan demonstrates hypoechoic masses in the left and right testicles. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Lymphoma and leukaemia
Testicular lymphoma is uncommon but important. In men over the age of 60 it is the most common testicular malignancy and in men of any age it is the most common bilateral testicular malignancy (although it is not always bilateral). On ultrasound it appears either as a diffusely hypoechoic and enlarged testicle or as multiple hypoechoic masses.
Testicular leukaemia has very similar appearances to lymphoma and may be difficult to differentiate from it.
Teratomas, yolk sac tumours, embryonal cell tumours and choriocarcinomas all fall into the category of non-seminomatous germ cell tumours. Of these, embryonal cell tumours make up the vast majority.
Teratoma
This is the second most common tumour in boys under 5. aFP is usually normal. Under ultrasound it appears as a heterogenous complex mass.
Yolk sac tumour
This makes up 80% of childhood testicular tumours. They can often present as testicular enlargement without a focal mass. These metastasize to the lung which is the most common site of recurrent disease.
Embryonal cell tumour
This is the second most common testicular tumour. It is the most aggressive of all testicular tumours with visceral metastases common and a 5 year survival of 30%.
Choriocarcinoma
This is a rare tumour affecting 20-30-year-olds with rapid metastases to lung, liver, GI tract, brain. They often causes haemorrhage in both primary and metastatic lesions. They cause gynaecomastia in 10% of patients due to raised serum hCG.
In reality, tumours are often mixed histological types in around 35% cases. Testicular tumours can also be diagnosed with a strong pre-test probability based solely on age as detailed in the table below. The role of the radiologist however does not need to be as complex as suggesting the final histological diagnosis. Establishing the presence of a testicular mass is sufficient. Patients should then be referred on to the urology MDT. On ultrasound there will be an intratesticular low reflectivity well-defined mass. Colour doppler flow can be seen within the mass.
  Age at diagnosis Tumour
10s Yolk sac tumour or teratoma
20s and 30s Choriocarcinoma
30s Embryonal cell carcinoma
40s Seminoma
      Testicular tumours © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose Teratoma because it is the most common type of testicular tumor in adults, and it is characterized by the presence of hypoechoic masses in both testicles. Teratomas are usually benign, so they are the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Qn_Text: An incidental finding on a trauma CT of the chest is a mass lesion in the left upper lobe of the lung, containing both calcification and fat density. What further management should you suggest?
B: Low dose non-contrast CT chest in 3 months
C: Low dose non-contrast CT chest in 6 months
D: CT chest with contrast in 3 months
E: CT chest with contrast in 6 months
Explanation:
Explanation:
With the presence of fat density the diagnosis of hamartoma can be made and consequently no follow up is required.
Fat within a thoracic mass is diagnostic of a hamartoma but is only seen in approximately half of cases. In contradistinction to carcinoid tumours, hamartomas tend to be peripherally located whereas carcinoid tumours are often more central. Exceptions to both are reasonably frequent however. Calcification, especially popcorn calcification, is also very classical for hamartomas if present. Cavitation is not a feature often associated with them, but it can be found occasionally. Hamartomas form part of Carney triad (pulmonary chondromas, gastric leiomyosarcomas and extra-adrenal paragangliomas). NB this is different from Carney complex (atrial myxoma, facial/buccal pigmentation, sertoli tumours of the testis and multiple other findings).
  Carney Triad
Carney Complex
Pulmonary chondromas
Atrial myxoma
Gastric leiomyosarcoma (GIST)
Facial/buccal pigmentation
Extra-adrenal paraganglioma
Sertoli tumour of the testis
  Pituitary adenoma
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because a mass lesion containing both calcification and fat density is often indicative of a malignant tumor. Further imaging with contrast is necessary to better characterize the lesion and determine if it is benign or malignant. Low dose non-contrast CT chest imaging is useful for follow-up after a diagnosis has been made, but it is not sufficient to diagnose the lesion in the first instance.

Qn_Text: A 57-year-old has a CT scan which shows a 4 cm lesion arising from the lower pole of the right kidney. It is partly cystic, partly solid with elements of enhancement. What is the Bosniak classification?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Type V does not exist as part of the Bosniak classification and is therefore incorrect.
Bosniak classification
The Bosniak classification of renal cysts is based on their CT or MRI features and provides a guide to follow up based on the likelihood of malignancy. The following table simplifies the classification.
  Bosniak Classification
Malignancy
Findings
Follow up
I
~0%
Simple cyst
None
II
~0%
Thin curvilinear calcification
Hyperdense cyst <3cm
None
IIF
5%
Thin septa
Mural or septal enhancement (visible but not measurable)
Nodular calcification
Hyperdense cyst >3cm
6 months
Then yearly for 5 years
III
50%
Thick septa
Mural enhancement (measurable)
Coarse calcification
Irregular margin
Smooth mural thickening
Surgical resection via MDT
IV
>90%
Large cystic/necrotic area
Irregular mural thickening
Solid enhancing structures
Surgical resection via MDT
GPT3_explain: The Bosniak classification is a system used to classify renal cystic masses based on the features seen on CT scans. The Bosniak classification has four levels, ranging from I to IV. Level III cystic masses are those that are partly cystic and partly solid, with elements of enhancement. Therefore, the lesion described in the question would be classified as a Bosniak III.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old man complains of feeling a lump at the back of his throat and discomfort on swallowing. He is reviewed by an ENT surgeon and on examination a mass is seen at the base of the tongue. An MRI scan reveals this to be a mass within the left lingual tonsil and a biopsy leads to a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following best describes the location of this mass?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Although situated at the base of the tongue, the lingual tonsils are described as being within the oropharynx.
The oropharynx is divided from the hypopharynx at the level of the valleculae. These are recesses at the base of the epiglottis. They are well demonstrated on fluoroscopic swallow studies where a tiny volume of contrast material can collect.
  The boundaries of the oropharynx, hypopharynx and nasopharynx are shown in the following diagram:
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: The lingual tonsil is located in the hypopharynx, which is the lower part of the pharynx that is located behind the mouth and the nasal cavity. The hypopharynx is also known as the "throat" and includes the base of the tongue, the epiglottis, and the side walls of the pharynx.

Qn_Text: You are performing a barium swallow on a 65-year-old man with progressive dysphagia. The barium swallow shows a stricture in the distal oesophagus with shouldering of the barium proximally. What is the most likely aetiology of this stricture?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Oesophageal carcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the oesophagus predominantly affects the middle and lower thirds of the oesophagus and accounts for around 60% of oesophageal malignancies. Adenocarcinoma arises in the lower third, mostly in areas of Barrett oesophagus, and accounts for most of the remaining 40%. Some patients develop symptoms of dysphagia and retrosternal pain but sadly many tumours remain occult until they are at an advanced stage. This is in-part due to the fact that there is no serosal layer protecting the oesophagus and as such cancers can progress rapidly. Patients found to have Barrett oesophagus (metaplasia of the usual squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium) are screened frequently for adenocarcinoma. Importantly in the staging criteria, the only nodes which contribute to nodal staging are the immediately local ones to the cancer. Any involved lymph nodes of the cervical chains or coeliac region are considered as metastatic disease. It is therefore important to review these areas on a staging scan with particular attention.
  Achalasia
This is a motility disorder which causes a failure of relaxation of the gastro-oesophageal junction (GOJ) and disorganisation of oesophageal peristalsis. Ingested material (including barium during fluoroscopy) is held up at the GOJ in a column. On a barium study the column has a classical bird-beak tapering point at the inferior-most end where it reaches the GOJ. There is often then sudden emptying of the oesophagus due to eventual pressure on the GOJ exceeding its strength. Oesophageal contractions may be absent or may be non-peristaltic. On a CXR an air-fluid level may be seen behind the heart.
  Oesophageal leiomyoma
Leiomyomas are said to be the only oesophageal lesions which can calcify. Generally, the absence of any shouldering of a stricture is a benign feature. Leiomyomas tend to arise in relatively young patients and are more common in the mid or distal thirds of the oesophagus. Ulceration is a very uncommon feature.
  Aberrant right subclavian artery
This common anomaly occurs when instead of being the first major branch of the aorta (technically the first branches are the coronary arteries), the right subclavian artery arises distal to the left subclavian artery. It then has to swerve back around to reach the right side and in doing so usually runs posterior to the oesophagus, which can be seen on a barium study as a smooth indentation. In some cases it can exert sufficient pressure on the oesophagus to cause dysphagia which is termed dysphagia lusoria.
An aberrant left pulmonary artery is the ‘only’ vascular anomaly to run between the oesophagus and the trachea. There are cases of aberrancy of the right pulmonary artery in the literature however these patients tend to die in infancy.
An anterior indentation of the oesophagus is caused by:
An aberrant left pulmonary artery
A posterior indentation of the oesophagus is caused by:
A right sided arch with an aberrant left subclavian artery
A left sided arch with an aberrant right sided subclavian artery
A double aortic arch – this is usually described as also causing an anterior indentation to the trachea
GPT3_explain: The most likely aetiology of this stricture is squamous cell carcinoma, as it is the most common cause of oesophageal strictures in adults. Other possible causes of oesophageal strictures, such as achalasia, Barrett's oesophagus, leiomyoma, and aberrant right subclavian artery, are much less common.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge, such as the management of a particular condition.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 73-year-old lady with severe COPD and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with right upper quadrant pain, and fevers. Her respiratory rate is 23 breaths per minute, her heart rate is 118 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is recorded as 90/50mmHg. She is admitted to the intensive care unit and undergoes an abdominal ultrasound scan. This demonstrates a distended gallbladder with a thick wall and an internal membrane. There are also several small stones. Although her blood pressure has improved since admission, her heart rate and respiratory rate remain high. What is the most appropriate management?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Usual management of straightforward acute calculous cholecystitis involves fluids, antibiotics and pain relief. A laparoscopic cholecystectomy should be performed within three days but in patients who are sufficiently unstable a percutaneous cholecystostomy should be performed.
  Gangrenous cholecystitis
Necrosis to the gallbladder wall can complicated around a quarter of cases of cholecystitis but is more usually seen in elderly patients, those with diabetes or those who may be immunocompromised. Once identified, these patients should undergo urgent decompression via cholecystostomy to allow the necrotic material to drain. Ultrasound features suggesting the presence of gangrenous cholecystitis include:
Asymmetrical wall thickening
Ulcerations of focal defects in the gall bladder wall
Sloughed mucosa lining appearing as an intraluminal membrane
Pericholecystic fluid collections
  Cholecystitis
When a gallstone becomes lodged in the neck of the gallbladder, chemical irritation from the trapped bile leads to inflammation of the gallbladder. Sometimes this can be felt by the patient as shoulder pain since irritation of the gallbladder is felt via C3, 4 and 5 the dermatomes of which cover the shoulder. Mostly, however, patients complain of right upper quadrant pain. With an accurate history this should be distinguishable from the pain caused by biliary colic, the latter being intermittent in nature and lasting less than six hours per episode.
On ultrasound the earliest signs will be of gallstones in the presence of a sonographic Murphy sign. Clinically Murphy sign is maximal tenderness when palpating over the gallbladder and the addition of ultrasound allows for greater specificity in this regard. The presence of pericholecystic fluid and increasing thickness of the gallbladder wall (>3mm) are also common findings, but come slightly later on. With CT similar findings can be seen with the addition of enhancement of the adjacent liver due to reactive hyperaemia. The presence of gallstones can be easily masked on CT since they are often of equal density to the bile.
Nuclear medicine tests would not usually be part of the index management of cholecystitis however can be used to determine cytic duct patency. Non-visualisation of the gallbladder at four hours following injection of 99mTc-HIDA is reported to be 99% specific in the diagnosis of cholecystitis. Acalculous cholecystitis can also occur, often in the setting of an already unwell patient on ITU. It will present as generic sepsis and it is usually down to the clinical team to retain a high index of suspicioun. It is thought to be a consequence of low blood flow in the cystic artery.
Emphysematous cholecystitis signifies a gas-producing organism such as Clostridium or E-coli. Appearances are striking on imaging with ring-down or reverberation artefacts on ultrasound and mural gas seen on CT. Patients are typically (but not exclusively) diabetic or suffering from a debilitating condition. Unfortunately the mortality rate is significantly higher than for non-emphysematous cholecystitis.
Mirizzi syndrome can present as cholecystitis and occurs when the common hepatic duct is obstructed by the mechanical pressure of a stone within the cystic duct. It follows that patients whose cystic duct happens to insert low in the course of the common hepatic duct are predisposed to this condition.
GPT3_explain: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most appropriate management for this patient. This procedure is minimally invasive and can be performed with minimal risk to the patient. It is also the most effective way to remove the gallstones, which are causing the patient's symptoms. Additionally, it can be performed quickly and with minimal disruption to the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular systems.

Qn_Text: A patient presents with a markedly raised PSA, but normal digital rectal examination of the prostate. Which of the following protocols is optimally concise but would enable full staging of a malignant lesion? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Axial, sagittal and coronal T2, axial T1, diffusion weighted imaging, axial dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
B: Axial, sagittal and coronal T1, axial T2, diffusion weighted imaging, axial dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
C: Axial and coronal T2, axial T1, sagittal FLAIR, diffusion weighted imaging, axial and coronal dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
D: Axial T1, coronal FLAIR, diffusion weighted imaging, axial, sagittal and coronal dynamic contrast enhanced imaging
E: Axial, sagittal and coronal T1, axial T2, diffusion weighted imaging
Explanation:
Explanation:
Three plane T2 imaging is common practice and enables full assessment of the peripheral zone of the prostate, particularly examining for extra-capsular extension, bladder base or seminal vesical invasion. T2 is also the most important sequence for lesions in the transitional zone.
Diffusion weighted imaging is essential for PIRADS calculation and is the first sequence that should be used to evaluate lesions in the peripheral zone. Axial dynamic contrast enhanced imaging (after non-contrast axial T1) is then essential to differentiate between between PIRADS 3 and 4 lesions.
The T1 weighted sequences are also useful to check for the presence of any haemorrhagic foci although since most patients now undergo their MRI scan prior to any biopsies being taken this has become far less important.
Interestingly the ADC map is more sensitive for carcinoma of the prostate (in the peripheral zone) than the DWI sequences. A finding of focal low signal on the ADC map may be seen in the absence of a corresponding high DWI focus. In the transitional zone however, the T2 sequences are more sensitive.
GPT3_explain: This protocol is the most concise and would enable full staging of a malignant lesion. It includes the necessary imaging modalities to evaluate the size, extent, and location of the lesion, as well as the presence of any metastases. The axial T2 sequence is the most sensitive for detecting prostate tumors, while the axial T1 and diffusion weighted imaging sequences are used to assess the tumor's characteristics and to differentiate it from benign lesions. The dynamic contrast enhanced imaging is used to assess the tumor's vascularity and to help determine the aggressiveness of the tumor.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man suffers a low speed road traffic collision and complains subsequently of a headache. He is found to have nausea, dysarthria and hemiataxia. A vertebral artery dissection is suspected. What would be the best sequence on MRI to detect this?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
A post-traumatic vertebral artery dissection classically presents as a third nerve palsy and cerebellar signs. The ‘sickle sign’ or ‘fried egg’ sign refers to the appearance of T1 fat saturated sequences where a slice transverse through the vessel shows hyperintensity in a crescenteric or circumferential shape to the wall of the affected vessel. Unlike large vessel dissections the anatomy here is usually too small to see a dissection flap.
GPT3_explain: The correct sequence for MRI to detect a vertebral artery dissection is 3, 4, 5. This sequence is designed to maximize the visibility of the vertebral artery and any potential dissection. Time of Flight (TOF) imaging is not optimal for detecting a vertebral artery dissection, as it is not able to provide detailed images of the vessel walls. 2D/3D gadolinium enhanced imaging is used to enhance the visibility of the vessel walls and any potential dissections. T2 fat saturated imaging is used to detect any signal changes in the vessel wall, which may be indicative of a dissection. T1 fat saturated post contrast imaging is used to further enhance the visibility of any signal changes in the vessel wall. T1 fat saturated imaging is used to provide better contrast between the vessel wall and the surrounding tissue.

Qn_Text: A 29-year-old man sprains his right ankle playing football and attends the Emergency Department. An x-ray of the right ankle is performed. There is no evidence of a fracture but the lateral view does demonstrate a well defined radiolucent lesion with a faint sclerotic margin in the calcaneus. The lesion has some calcification centrally. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Intraosseous lipoma
These benign lesions can present with pain but around a third of cases are diagnosed incidentally. The classic location for them is the calcaneum but they do occur all around the body. On x-ray they appear as a lucent bone lesion with a thin cortex and no periosteal reaction. Some show dystrophic calcifications. On MRI signal characteristics follow fat with high signal on T1 and signal loss on fat suppression sequences. The presence of granulation tissue can give high signal and calcifications, if present, will return low signal. On CT the fat within the lesion will show low/negative Hounsfield units.
  Enchondroma
As the name suggests, this is a cartilage forming tumour showing ground-glass matrix and ring or arc calcifications (as with all cartilage forming tumours). Patients are typically young (10-30 years) and the lesions are typically found in the hands (although they can form anywhere in the body. In the hands they are unusual to be found in the terminal phalanges). They are thought to derive from ongoing growth of small foci of cartilage which have become displaced from the growth plate. They can expand the cortex but, unless presenting as a fracture, should be painless and therefore are often an incidental diagnosis. Although they are benign tumours, malignant degeneration to a chondrosarcoma can occur.
  Unicameral bone cyst also known as simple bone cyst
These benign, asymptomatic lesions are almost always found in children in the metaphyseal region of long bones. They can, however, present with pain from a fracture, in which case the ‘fallen fragment’ sign is almost pathognomonic. This occurs when a small piece of the thin cortex overlying the lesion breaks off and is seen dependant within the cyst. Otherwise on x-ray they appear as a lucent bone lesion with a narrow zone of transition, no periosteal reaction and no soft tissue component. Since they are fluid-filled they return high signal on T2 weighted MRI sequences.
  Causes of bone infarction:
Sickle cell disease
Excess corticosteroid
Pancreatitis
Caisson disease ‘The Bends’
Gaucher disease
Leukemia/lymphoma
  Medullary osteonecrosis can be secondary to anything leading to vascular compromise and has the propensity to lead to severe loss or architecture and loss of function, not to mention pain, to the patient. It is an important diagnosis to make. On plain film the finding is usually of a lucent area with a sclerotic serpiginous border of granulation tissue. On MRI this serpiginous border returns low signal on T1 and a ‘double-line’ sign on T2 (high signal of granulation tissue surrounded by low signal of sclerosis). Strangely enough, centrally within the infarction the signal retains the characteristics of normal fatty marrow.
GPT3_explain: Unicameral bone cysts are well-defined radiolucent lesions that are typically seen in the calcaneus. They are typically filled with fluid, have a faint sclerotic margin, and often have some central calcification. The other options are not likely to be seen in the calcaneus and do not match the description of the lesion. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is a unicameral bone cyst.

Qn_Text: A 29-year-old teacher presents to A+E with acute lower abdominal and pelvic pain. She is found to have a raised white cell count and other inflammatory markers are also elevated. She is admitted for further investigations and undergoes an MRI scan. This shows an intramural fibroid which returns low signal on T1 and high signal on T2 with a complex internal structure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Aside from the fact that myxoid degeneration is more common than cystic degeneration, two features set these two apart. Fibroids which have undergone myxoid degeneration but appear cystic tend to have a very complex 'cystic type' structure, as opposed to a simpler internal structure. Furthermore, if there are foci of very high T2 signal this suggests myxoid degeneration.
  Uterine fibroids also known as Leiomyomas
‘Leio’ means smooth in Latin and ‘myo’ means muscle. An ‘oma’ is a lump. Uterine fibroids therefore are smooth muscle lumps by literal translation. They are extremely common and can cause no problems at all however some women do experience significant problems attributable to their fibroids. Fibroids are usually described according to their location, namely subserosal, submucosal, intramural, pedunculated or cervical. On MRI they appear as low signal (compared to the myometrium) on T2 weighted sequences. They grow and shrink in response to the presence or absence of oestrogen. Thus they can get bigger during pregnancy and tend to involute during the course of the menopause.
Fibroids are complicated by degeneration which occurs when the mass outgrows its own blood supply. This takes place in one of four ways:
Hyaline degeneration – this is the most common form, accounting for over half of cases. Proteinaceous material collects in the extracellular space. Calcification (typically described as popcorn calcification) can occur and is sometimes visible on plain films. Appearances on MRI are similar to non-degenerate fibroids with low signal on T2.
Myxoid degeneration – These fibroids are easily confused with cystic degeneration owing to their high T2 signal. The focal areas of very high T2 signal are set against a backdrop of low T2 signal where the gelatinous material has not reached. Where they appear cystic, the complex nature of the cysts suggests myxoid degeneration over cystic degeneration.
Cystic degeneration – Although this type of degeneration is uncommon it gives classical MRI appearances of high T2 signal.
Red degeneration (aka carneous degeneration) – This entity is related to pregnancy or use of the oral contraceptive pill, but can occur without either. It is essentially haemorrhagic necrosis and can present acutely as abdominal pain. MRI characteristics vary depending on the degradation of blood within the fibroid. Peripheral high T2 signal is often described.
  Uterine fibroid embolisation contraindications:
Pelvic infection
History of pelvic radiation
Connective tissue disease
Asymptomatic fibroids
Pregnancy
Pedunculated fibroids
  In the world of interventional radiology, uterine fibroid embolisation is gaining momentum. The uterine artery arises from the internal iliac artery whereas the ovarian artery arises directly from the aorta and has a corkscrew appearance on angiography. Anastomoses between the two arteries or the two sides exist in approximately 20% of patients. Patients should be counselled for the risk of ovarian dysfunction subsequent to the procedure and patients over the age of 45 are at particular risk. Pedunculated fibroids are said to be poor candidates for embolisation owing to their propensity to detach however the literature is slightly contradictory on this topic.
GPT3_explain: Red degeneration is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is characterized by a intramural fibroid that has a low signal on T1 and high signal on T2 with a complex internal structure. This type of degeneration is caused by a sudden increase in the blood supply to the fibroid, usually due to trauma or hormonal changes. It is the most common type of degeneration seen in fibroids.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the lesser curvature of the stomach is true?
A: The angular notch is situated two-thirds of the way along it
B: It is longer than the greater curvature
C: The greater omentum arises from it
E: It forms the lateral border of the stomach
Explanation:
Explanation:
The stomach is a J-shaped digestive organ that lies in the superior aspect of the abdomen between the oesphagus and the duodenum.
It has four main regions:
The cardia – which is around the opening of the oesophagus
The fundus – which is the dilated superior portion lying beneath the left dome of the diaphragm
The body – which is the large central position lying between the fundus and the pylorus
The pylorus – which is the lower portion that facilitates the emptying of its contents into the duodenum
  The medial and lateral borders of the stomach are curved, forming the greater and lesser curvatures of the stomach:
The greater curvature – forms the longer, convex, lateral border of the stomach. The greater omentum arises from it.
The lesser curvature – forms the shorter, concave, medial border of the stomach. The lesser omentum arises from it.
  There is a sharp indentation two-thirds of the way along the lesser curvature called the angular notch. This point marks the junction of the body and the pylorus.
Food boluses enter the stomach via the lower oesophageal sphincter. Once within the stomach protein digesting enzymes, such as pepsin, are released. Hydrochloric acid within the stomach provides a suitably acidic pH for these enzymes to work and also serves to kills bacteria. The food boluses are churned up by peristaltic contractions of the wall and converted into chyme. The passage of chyme into the duodenum is controlled by the pyloric sphincter, which lies between the pylorus and the duodenum.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 4 because it is the only statement that is true regarding the lesser curvature of the stomach. The lesser curvature of the stomach is convex in shape, while the greater curvature is concave. The lesser curvature is shorter than the greater curvature, the greater omentum does not arise from it, and the angular notch is not situated two-thirds of the way along it.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: You are performing a scrotal ultrasound for a 60-year-old man who presented to his GP having noticed a swelling above his left testicle. You suspect he may have a tunica albuginea cyst. What are the most likely findings on ultrasound? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Multiseptate cystic mass with thin echogenic line running over the top and around the rest of the testicle
B: Solid mass with thin echogenic line running over the top and around the rest of the testicle
C: Solid cystic mass with no internal echoes
D: Multiseptate cystic mass with no internal echoes
E: Multiseptate cystic mass with internal echoes
Explanation:
Explanation:
Spermatocoele
A spermatocoele is a focal dilatation of a duct within the head of the epididymis. Since they contain protein debris and spermatozoa, low level echoes can be seen floating within them differentiating them from epididymal cysts. They are essentially an incidental asymptotic finding. They can be unilocular or multiseptate, and measure a few millimetres or a few centimetres in diameter.
  Epididymal cyst
A cystic structure within the epididymis is most commonly a simple cyst. They can present as palpable masses or be found incidentally. On ultrasound they behave as you might expect from a cyst, with posterior acoustic enhancement of an anechoic round structure. The main differential diagnosis is a spermatocoele which, unlike a simple cyst, usually contains echogenic material. The latter is usually only found in the epididymal head.
  Tunica albuginea cyst
The tunica albuginea is a fibrous layer covering the testicle. On ultrasound it appears as the thin echogenic line surrounding the testicle. When cysts form here they are usually palpable as small well-defined lumps a few millimetres in diameter. Appearances on ultrasound usually conform to those expected from any straightforward cyst, i.e. a sharply defined anechoic structure with acoustic enhancement posteriorly. They can be uni or multilocular and although they can exert mass effect on the underlying testicle they do not affect the testicular tissue beyond this. They are most commonly located at the anterosuperior or superolateral aspect of the testicle.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3 because a tunica albuginea cyst is a multiseptate cystic mass with a thin echogenic line running over the top and around the rest of the testicle. This is the most likely finding on an ultrasound for this type of cyst.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about problem solving, what should be done next?
