Qn_Text: A 5-year-old girl is admitted via the Emergency Department with lower abdominal pain and a fever. Her admitting notes reveal that she has tenderness in the right iliac fossa, and a working diagnosis of acute appendicitis has been made. It is noted that she refuses to flex the thigh at the hip and that if her thigh is passively extended, her abdominal pain significantly worsens. She has been referred for an ultrasound scan. What is the most likely position of the appendix in this patient? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
This patient is demonstrating the psoas sign, a medical sign that indicates that there is irritation of the iliopsoas group of hip flexors in the abdomen.
The psoas sign can be elicited by passively extending the thigh of a patient lying on their side with the knees extended, or by asking the patient to actively flex the thigh at the hip. If this results in abdominal pain or the movements are resisted because of pain then there is a positive ‘psoas sign’.
The pain occurs because the psoas muscle borders the peritoneal cavity. Stretching or contraction of the muscles will therefore cause friction against the nearby inflamed tissues. It is strongly suggestive that the appendix is retrocaecal in position.
GPT3_explain: The most likely position of the appendix in this patient is ascending preileal. This is due to the fact that the patient has tenderness in the right iliac fossa, which is a common symptom of appendicitis. Additionally, the patient's abdominal pain worsens when her thigh is passively extended, which is another sign of appendicitis in the ascending preileal position. This is supported by the fact that the patient has been referred for an ultrasound scan, which is the most common imaging modality used to diagnose appendicitis.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge, such as interpreting a scan or test result?

This question falls under category 3: A question about the application of knowledge, such as interpreting a scan or test result.

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old woman is seen in A+E after falling on her outstretched hand. The lateral wrist radiograph clearly shows a bony fragment at the dorsum of the hand. A fracture of which bone is most likely? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
A bony fragment at the dorsum of the wrist is likely to be either from the triquetrum or the hamate. Triquetrum is not provided as a potential choice in this question, so the correct answer has to be hamate. On a radiograph, hamate will lie more superiorly and is far less common than a triquetrum fracture. Of the carpal bones, the scaphoid is most frequently fractured, followed by the triquetrum.
GPT3_explain: The scaphoid is the most likely bone to be fractured in this scenario. This is because the scaphoid is located at the base of the thumb, which is the area where the patient fell on her outstretched hand. The scaphoid is a small, fragile bone that is particularly vulnerable to fractures due to its location and the fact that it is surrounded by a relatively thin layer of soft tissue.

Qn_Text: A 6-week-old girl is referred to the hospital by the health visitor for failure to progress. She undergoes an x-ray which shows cardiomegaly and a large mass in the right upper quadrant. An ultrasound scan reveals a complex poorly-defined 10cm mass in the right lobe of the liver which contains multiple vascular channels. A subsequent CT shows fine granular calcifications within it. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Paediatric liver lesions with a raised AFP
Lesion
Usual age
Features
Infantile haemangioendothelioma
<6m (NB AFP can be normally elevated in this age range)
Heart failure, low platelets. Vascular lesion, fine granular calcifications.
Hepatoblastoma
6m-3y
Coarse calcification, rim enhancement.
HCC
>5y
Central scar which can calcify
  Infantile haemangioendothelioma
These are benign lesions of which the vast majority occur in babies under the age of 6 months. Serum AFP levels can be elevated in normal babies upto the age of 6 months and occasionally these lesions can cause an elevation in serum AFP, as such the presence of a raised AFP is not particularly specific. Around half of cases are associated with the presence of a cutaneous haemangioma. They are large vascular tumours and on imaging behave as might be expected of a haemangioma with low echogenicity on ultrasound, peripheral enhancement with gradual filling in on CT and flow voids on MRI. Calcifications can be seen with these lesions but they are finer, more granular calcifications; not coarse. Owing to their size they often cause significant right to left shunting of blood resulting in congestive heart failure. Thrombocytopaenia due to platelet trapping (known as the Kasabach-Merritt sequence). N.B. these lesions should not be confused with epithelioid haemangioendotheliomas which occur in adults.
  Hepatoblastoma
Most hepatoblastomas are found in children under the age of 3 but they can occur at any point in childhood. They are the third most common abdominal tumour in children. Presentation is typically with an abdominal mass and weight loss and the serum AFP is often markedly elevated. Some may produce hormones and thereby precocious puberty but this is rare. Coarse calcification is seen in around a third of cases. On ultrasound the mass will be large and heterogenous. On CT they appear as a predominantly low attenuation mass seeming to consist of multiple confluent nodules. Often the rim of the mass enhances well on CT. On MRI they are, for the most part, high in signal on T2 weighted sequences but can show low intensity fibrous bands running through them.
  Wilms tumour also known as a nephroblastoma
This is the most common abdominal mass in children under the age of 8. There are reasonably strong associations with renal anomalies, genital anomalies, aniridia and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (although the last of these also has an association with neuroblastoma). Presentation is usually with an abdominal mass and/or pain.
10% tumour – Wilms
Calcification
Vascular invasion
Bilateral
Lung metastases
Poor histology
  On imaging the masses are usually heterogenous. Cystic areas can often be seen secondary to areas of necrosis. The claw sign occurs when there is a rim of normal renal tissue extending part of the way around the mass. A Wilms tumour is often described as enhancing but less so than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma.
  Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) also known as Hepatoma
There is a peak in the incidence of HCCs in the paediatric age range at around age 13. The central scar of an HCC is a specific feature which can help separate it from potential differential diagnoses. Although calcification of this central scar is seen in around a quarter of cases there tends to be less calcification in HCCs than there would be in a hepatoblastoma.
Although metastases are the most common cause of malignant hepatic lesions, hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary hepatic malignancy. It usually arises on a background of cirrhosis of any cause. Patients with any of the hepatitis viruses, alcoholic cirrhosis, haemochromatosis, and Wilson disease are all at risk. Carcinogens such as thorotrast and aflatoxin also predispose to HCC formation. Serum alpha fetoprotein levels are often raised, in contrast with cholangiocarcinomas which are one of the main differential diagnoses.
On imaging HCCs can have a variety of appearances. A large irregular mass with satellite nodules is the most common finding but a diffuse infiltrative version can also occur. Since HCCs derive their blood supply from the hepatic artery they show arterial enhancement on CT with washout on later phases. On ultrasound HCCs tend to be hyperechoic when compared to the rest of the liver and on MRI they show variable signal intensity on both T1 and T2 but arterial enhancement with venous washout can again be seen once Gadolinium has been given.
  Hepatic abscess
Liver abscesses can occur in children, for much the same reasons as they arise in adults, although they are far more common in adults. Pyogenic abscesses result from bacteria accessing the liver via the biliary tree, septicaemia, direct spread, trauma or during a liver procedure. Patients are usually in their 60s. Amoebic abscesses occur in slightly younger patients (40s) and tend to result from spread of amoebae from the colon via the portal venous system. On ultrasound they appear as a hypoechoic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement. Internal debris may be apparent. On CT they are usually low in attenuation with rim enhancement. MRI signal characteristics are dependent on the protein content of the pus but usually abscesses return little T1 signal and, owing to their fluid nature, return high signal on T2 weighted sequences. It is said that amoebic abscesses are usually found to be contiguous with the liver capsule.
GPT3_explain: I chose Hepatoblastoma as the most likely diagnosis because the x-ray, ultrasound, and CT scans all showed signs of a large mass located in the right lobe of the liver. Furthermore, the CT scan revealed fine granular calcifications within the mass, which is a common feature of hepatoblastoma.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man presents to A&E with acute severe left loin to groin pain. Renal function tests are normal but a CT KUB study shows a normal right kidney and a left sided 5mm proximal ureteric calculus with Hounsfield Units of 850. There is only minimal hydronephrosis. What should you advise? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
B: An ultrasound to evaluate the hydronephrosis
Explanation:
Explanation:
Given the patient has one functioning kidney, minimal ipsilateral hydronephrosis and a 5mm stone which should pass spontaneously, a further ultrasound is superfluous. Likewise stenting or a nephrostomy at this stage is not necessary.
In recent years patients with ureteric colic have been imaged with CT KUB which is a low-dose, non-contrast CT scan through the abdomen and pelvis. Urinary tract calculi can be detected on this with significant accuracy however if the patient's symptoms are not caused by renal tract calculi then the scan is a very poor substitute for a normal CT abdomen and pelvis with a far lower sensitivity and specificity for other abdominal pathologies. A negative scan can be falsely reassuring for the clinical teams caring for the patient.
CT KUB studies are also used to follow up patients with known urinary tract calculi following an acute admission however many stones are sufficiently dense as to be plainly visible on abdominal radiographs, and even on the scout views of the CT KUB performed at the time of presentation. As a rough guide, stones which have Hounsfield Units greater than 700 ought to be visible on an abdominal radiograph and this should be considered for follow up in place of a CT KUB.
GPT3_explain: A retrograde ureteric stent is the best treatment option for a patient with a left sided 5mm proximal ureteric calculus. This type of stent is inserted through the urethra and passed up the ureter to the calculus. It is used to help relieve the pressure caused by the blockage and to allow the stone to pass more easily. The stent also helps to reduce the risk of further damage to the ureter or kidney due to the blockage. The stent also helps to reduce the risk of infection, as it prevents urine from backing up into the kidney.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about management, what is the best treatment option?

3. A question about management, what is the best treatment option?

Qn_Text: A baby born at full term to a diabetic mother is brought back to hospital 36 hours later. There were no immediate complications following birth but the parents are concerned that the baby has not yet passed his first stool and now has a very rounded abdomen. An abdominal radiograph shows the transverse colon to be full of meconium but with no gas in the descending colon or rectum. The baby undergoes a water soluble enema which causes passage of the meconium and the baby is eventually discharged in full health. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Of the neonatal causes of bowel obstruction, the age at presentation and level of obstruction can point heavily towards the diagnosis.
  Level of obstruction
Age at presentation
NEC
All/any
<10 days
Meconium ileus
Caecum/terminal ileum
<48hrs
Meconium plug
Splenic flexure
<48hrs
Hirschsprung disease
Sigmoid colon
<6 weeks
  Meconium plug
Whereas meconium ileus leads to small bowl obstruction, meconium plug syndrome leads to large bowel obstruction due to functional immaturity of the colon. This will also present within the first two days of life with a failure to pass meconium. Some literature associates this condition with babies born to diabetic mothers and around a quater of patients have cystic fibrosis. The condition can be treated with a water-soluble contrast enema.
  Necrotising enterocolitis
This is the most common gastrointestinal emergency for premature babies. It results from an immature immune system being unable to cope with mucosal ulceration. Almost all cases occur before the baby reaches 10 days old. Pneumatosis intestinalis (intramural gas) is the hallmark of the condition on abdominal radiography and appears as curvilinear or bubbly areas. Branching gas within the liver, indicative of portal venous gas can also occur but is not as serious a finding as it would be for an adult. Surgery is definitely indicated however, if there is evidence of perforation and for this reason patients should undergo a horizontal beam x-ray. If performed decubitus the left side should be down in order to better visualise air against the contour of the liver. On an over-table view the ‘football’ sign, where a large collection of gas rises centrally, is seen if there is sufficient free gas within the abdomen.
  Meconium ileus
This condition is strongly associated with cystic fibrosis but not with prematurity. The thicker-than-normal intestinal mucus, increase in transit time and pancreatic insufficiency all conspire to cause impaction of meconium leading to small bowel obstruction in neonates. It should be suspected if the baby does not pass meconium within the first 2 days of life. On an abdominal radiograph there will be no air-fluid levels since no fluid is present but multiple gas filled dilated loops of small bowel will be seen. The meconium can sometimes be seen as a bubbly area in the right lower quadrant where it has impacted within the terminal ileum.
  Meconium peritonitis
When there is antenatal bowel perforation the result is a chemical peritonitis as opposed to a purulent one since the bowel is as yet unpopulated by the usual flora of life after birth. The result is calcification scattered around the abdomen. If the perforation spontaneously heals itself then the prognosis is excellent and the finding of abdominal calcification may be purely incidental.
  Hirschsprung disease
There is a congenital absence of parasympathetic ganglia in the muscular and submucosal layers of a segment of colon, usually the sigmoid colon. The affected segment is unable to relax to pass meconium and patients therefore present with failure to pass meconium or sometimes within the first six weeks of life with severe constipation with overflow diarrhoea. Classically on a barium enema there is an inverted cone shape formed between the normal and abnormal bowel segments and the diagnosis should be confirmed using a suction biopsy below this transition point. Another feature seen on a barium enema is a result of abnormally coordinated contractions of the affected segment which appears as so-called ‘persistent corrugation’.
GPT3_explain: Meconium plug is the most likely diagnosis because the baby had a full transverse colon full of meconium, with no gas in the descending colon or rectum. This indicates that the meconium was blocking the baby's intestines, preventing the passage of gas and leading to the rounded abdomen. The water soluble enema caused the passage of the meconium, which then relieved the blockage and allowed the baby to be discharged in full health.

Qn_Text: A 24-year-old rugby player twists his knee in a tackle and suffers a meniscal tear. You are asked to review his MRI scan. Which SINGLE statement regarding the menisci of the knee is true?
A: Both menisci are attached at both ends to the intercondylar area of the tibia
B: The lateral meniscus is larger than the medial meniscus
C: The lateral meniscus is attached to the lateral collateral ligament
D: The lateral meniscus is attached to the joint capsule
E: They act to increase friction between the femur and tibia
Explanation:
Explanation:
The menisci of the knee are two pads of fibrocartilaginous tissue, which have two main functions:
They deepen the articular surface of the tibia and increase stability of the knee joint
To disperse friction between the femur and tibia, acting as ‘shock absorbers’
  Both menisci are C shaped and are attached at both ends to the intercondylar area of the tibia.
The medial meniscus is also fixed to the medial collateral ligament and the joint capsule. As a consequence of this injuries to the medial collateral ligament are often accompanied by a tear of the medial meniscus. The lateral meniscus is smaller and does not have any extra attachments, rendering it fairly mobile.
  The head of the tibia from above, showing the menisci and ligament attachments (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because it is a fact that both the medial and lateral menisci are attached at both ends to the intercondylar area of the tibia. This attachment is important because it helps to stabilize the knee joint, and it also helps to absorb shock and reduce friction between the femur and tibia.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about problem solving, how to treat the patient?

Qn_Text: A 3-month-old baby boy is brought in with progressive cyanosis and respiratory distress. His CXR shows a reduced number of lung markings in the periphery of a hyperinflated left upper lobe with flattening of the hemidiaphragms, and deviation of mediastinum to the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Congenital lobar overinflation (previously congenital lobar emphysema)
This condition is thought to be caused by underdevelopment of bronchial cartilage in the affected lobe(s). Consequently the bronchus is unable to remain patent during expiration leading to significant air trapping. It is usually the left upper lobe which is affected but approximately 40% of cases involve the left upper lobe; the right middle or the right upper lobes are affected in a further 55% of cases. There is a reasonable male preponderance of approximately 3:1.
On a CXR there is hyperlucency of the affected lobe and often mass effect on the mediastinum leading to contralateral mediastinal shift and thereby respiratory distress.
  Pulmonary interstitial emphysema (PIE)
As the name would suggest, this disease is diagnosed when there is air within the interstitial tissues of the lungs. It is caused by alveolar rupture due to the barotrauma of mechanical ventilation or positive airway pressure. It can be associated with hyaline membrane disease and is prevalent in infants of a low birth weight. Complications such as pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum can be severe and acutely life threatening. Radiographically there is hyperinflation and lucencies in either a cystic pattern or streaks emanating from the hila and following the direction of the bronchi/bronchioles. It is treated with high frequency oscillation ventilation which is less traumatic to the lungs.
  Swyer-James syndrome
In this condition, normal development of the infant lung is impeded by bronchiolitis (viral or mycoplasma) at an early age, with superadded acute airspace destruction. Consequently the affected lobe is small and lucent on the CXR due to air trapping. It is a differential diagnosis for a unilateral lucent hemithorax, along with a pneumothorax, very large pulmonary emboli and causes of decreased chest wall musculature such as Poland syndrome or, historically, polio. In an an exam situation Swyer-James syndrome is usually given as a teenage or young adult patient with a history of recurrent LRTIs. Air trapping, and bronchiectasis can also be described.
  Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) – also known as Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM)
Although often an antenatal diagnosis, CPAM should be considered in the investigation of a neonatal respiratory distress. Milder cases can present later when the child develops a LRTI and decompensates. On investigation a cystic mass is discovered. The size of the cysts denotes the type with Type I accounting for half of cases and comprising a smaller number of larger (>20mm) cysts. Type III is more sponge-like with cysts measuring only a couple of mm and Type II is between the two. Where cysts are larger, air-fluid levels may be seen. The malformation can exert a mass effect, causing both hypoplasia of the remainder of the ipsilateral lung as well as contralateral mediastinal shift.
  Tension pneumothorax
This must be ruled out for any patient presenting with acute respiratory distress. The presence of lung markings, even if scarce, ought to rule this out although the difference between ‘scarce’ and ‘absent’ is undoubtedly easier to interpret on a real CXR as opposed to a wooly description of one.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the CXR findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM). CPAM is a congenital anomaly where the lungs are underdeveloped and the airways are blocked or narrowed, leading to respiratory distress and cyanosis. The hyperinflation of the left upper lobe and flattening of the hemidiaphragms are a common finding in CPAM.

Qn_Text: A 60-year-old man with progressive bilateral leg weakness presents to his GP. He is referred for an urgent MRI which shows multiple tortuous tubes with signal voids on the posterior aspect of the cauda equina on both T1 and T2. Subtle bumps along the surface of the cord are seen and the conus appears expanded with high signal on T2. Which of the following will help differentiate between an AVM and an AVF?
A: The presence or absence of a clear nidus
C: Venous drainage in the arterial phase during angiography
Explanation:
Explanation:
Subarachnoid haemorrhage is actually reasonably rare in AVF although it can happen. A history of trauma would point towards the lesion being an AVF and is therefore a potentially viable answer for this question too however on balance the presence or absence of a nidus is more definitive. Logically, although a history of trauma may be given and can be seen to be related in population demographic terms, this is less certain for individual cases whereas a nidus is an unequivocal finding.
GPT3_explain: The presence or absence of subarachnoid blood, as seen on MRI, is one of the key features used to differentiate between an arteriovenous malformation (AVM) and an arteriovenous fistula (AVF). Subarachnoid blood is seen in AVMs, but not in AVFs. Venous drainage in the arterial phase of angiography is also a key feature used to differentiate between an AVM and an AVF. In AVMs, there is no venous drainage in the arterial phase, while in AVFs, there is visible venous drainage in the arterial phase. The presence or absence of a clear nidus and the age of the patient are not reliable indicators for distinguishing between an AVM and an AVF. A history of trauma is also not a reliable indicator for distinguishing between an AVM and an AVF.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 31-year-old lady who is 25 weeks pregnant with her first pregnancy presents with shortness of breath and tachycardia. Full blood count and renal function tests are normal. The admitting team suspect she may have a pulmonary embolism. Which of the following is the best initial test? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
A pregnant patient suspected to have a pulmonary embolus should undergo a chest x-ray to look for alternative causes of shortness of breath such as a lower respiratory tract infection, pleural effusions or a pneumothorax. In the event that they go on to have a VQ scan a chest radiograph is required for comparison.
Thereafter the patient should undergo bilateral lower limb venous dopplers if they have signs or symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. Around a third of pregnant patients who develop pulmonary emboli will have a deep vein thrombosis and for these patients treatment can be started on the basis of their DVT diagnosis without the need for further imaging. If the patient has no signs or symptoms of a DVT, they should proceed to a VQ scan or a CTPA.
The patient should be counselled that there is a small increase in the absolute risk of the foetus developing a childhood cancer following a maternal VQ scan but also that the absolute risk of maternal breast cancer is reduced compared to a CTPA.
  CTPA
CTPA imaging confers a lower dose to the foetus than V/Q scanning, although this effect is diminished in the third trimester as the gravid uterus becomes closer to the field of view.
Unfortunately however, CTPA confers a far greater dose to the breast tissue of the mothers at a time when the tissue is more radiosensitive than it would otherwise be in a non-pregnant woman.
A secondary consideration is the use of iodinated contrast. Iodine crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid. Babies of mothers who have received iodinated contrast during pregnancy should be tested during their first week of life for thyroid suppression although there is little evidence in literature to suggest that many if any infants have developed hypothyroidism following maternal intravenous iodine exposure.
Technical factors to performing a CTPA scan in pregnant patients, if required, are also important to consider. Hyperdynamic circulation can render usual triggering bolus mechanisms suboptimal and raise the possibility of a non-diagnostic study.
  V/Q or Q only scanning
V/Q scanning confers a far lower breast dose to the mother but the dose to the foetus, particularly when small, can be greater owing to tracer accumulation within the solid organs of the mother. The mother should be encouraged to adequately hydrate and void frequently in the subsequent hours/days following a scan.
Many institutes choose to perform perfusion scanning only in pregnant women on the understanding that if the perfusion scan is normal then there is no need to go on to perform the ventilation study. The perfusion scan can also be performed at half the usual dose to further reduce the foetal-dose. Naturally doing so comes with the trade-off of lower sensitivity and specificity.
  Gadolinium in pregnancy
Gadolinium also crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetus into the amniotic fluid. The chelated form of gadolinium in itself poses no risk to the foetus however the free form of gadolinium is teratogenic and the longer the foetus is exposed to the chelated gadolinium administered for the scan, the greater the risk of each molecule of gadolinium becoming dissociated from its chelate. For this reason therefore, gadolinium should only be administered in a patient known to be pregnant, if there is likely to be significant diagnostic benefit from the resultant images.
  Considerations during lactation
Less than 1% of injected iodine or gadolinium is excreted into breast milk and less than 1% of this is then absorbed by the baby's intestinal tract. Although these amounts are considered acceptably low as to not necessitate any breast-feeding cessation advice many families are understandably over-cautious. It is accepted that contrast agents are undetectable in blood 24hours after administration and so any mother wishing to 'pump-and-dump' despite the negligible risks need not do so for longer than a day. Care should, however, be given to counsel the family that it is possible for inadvertent weaning to occur even after short intervals and this should be factored in to any decision made by the family.
Following a nuclear medicine study the risks to the baby are two-fold; firstly from tracer excretion into the breast milk, but also through proximity to the mother during breast-feeding. Recommendations for breast-feeding interruption vary depending on the half-life of the tracer used. For perfusion imaging using technetium (half-life 6 hours) breast milk should be expressed for the first 24 hours following the scan. In theory, it need not be discarded but can safely be bottle-fed to the baby after these 24 hours have elapsed, however in practice many patients none-the-less choose to discard it.
Most tracers simply require adherence to a washout time but of note, the precautions following administration of Gallium-67 based tracers (most commonly used for pyrexia of unknown origin) are much more limiting and, practically speaking, unfortunately lead to complete cessation of breastfeeding. The half-life of Ga-67 is approximately 78 hours. Breastfeeding should, if time allows, be stopped for 2-4 weeks prior to the scan to allow the breast tissue to become less radiosensitive while the tracer circulates within the mother. Where this is an unacceptably long delay for the clinical state of the patient the study can be performed straight away anyway but in either case, milk should also be discarded for at least a further two weeks following the study. Clearly a disruption to breast-feeding of such a long time is far from ideal, even assuming that a patient who is sufficiently unwell as to need a PUO study is able to continue breast-feeding at all, and is likely to lead to complete cessation of breast-feeding. There are other ways to image PUO using Tc99m labelled white blood cells which can be considered.
GPT3_explain: A CT pulmonary angiogram is the best initial test for a suspected pulmonary embolism because it is the most sensitive and specific imaging test for this condition. It can detect emboli in the lungs and provide detailed information on the size and location of the clot. It is also the fastest and most reliable way to get an accurate diagnosis and determine the best treatment plan.

3. A question about clinical management, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man presents with an acute left third cranial nerve palsy and a headache. A CT scan shows subarachnoid haemorrhage. Most of the blood is concentrated around the quadrigeminal cistern. Regarding the subarachnoid cisterns, which of the following is correct? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: The ambient cistern is posterolateral to the midbrain
B: The quadrigeminal cistern is anterior to the midbrain
C: The interpeduncular cistern is posterior to the midbrain
D: The quadrigeminal cistern is lateral to the cerebellum
E: The ambient cistern is lateral to the cerebellum
Explanation:
Explanation:
The quadrigeminal cistern sits behind the midbrain, just above the cerebellum. The ambient cistern run around the posterolateral aspect of the midbrain on either side joining to the interpeduncular cistern and is essentially an extension of the quadrigeminal cistern.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: The interpeduncular cistern is located posterior to the midbrain and is one of the most important subarachnoid cisterns. It is located between the two cerebral peduncles of the midbrain and contains the basilar artery, the posterior cerebral arteries, and the posterior communicating arteries. This is important because the interpeduncular cistern is the most common site for aneurysms and thus the most common cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The quadrigeminal cistern is anterior to the midbrain and is located between the two colliculi of the midbrain. It contains the superior cerebellar arteries and the anterior choroidal artery. The ambient cistern is located posterolateral to the midbrain and contains the posterior choroidal artery and the posterior cerebral artery. The ambient cistern is also lateral to the cerebellum.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a CT chest in a patient with known chronic pulmonary emboli. Which of these are you LEAST likely to see?
Explanation:
Explanation:
CTEPH (Chronic Thromboembolic Pulmonary Hypertension) 
When acute pulmonary emboli fail to resolve there is a danger that their presence will lead to elevated pulmonary arterial pressures i.e CTEPH. The symptoms and radiological signs of CTEPH pertain either to the thrombi or the pulmonary hypertension. Filling defects on CTPA can be expected. Differentiating chronic from acute pulmonary emboli is not an exact science but chronic PEs can display features such as luminal eccentricity (build up of thrombus along the walls of the pulmonary arteries as opposed to central filling defects within the lumen) and calcification. Webs and bands are also features of chronicity - thin, threadlike fibrous structures attached at either end to the vessel wall but free-floating in their mid-portions. Features of the consequent pulmonary hypertension include enlargement of the main pulmonary arteries with stenosis of the peripheral arteries giving rise to a tapered appearance. Right ventricular enlargement and hypertrophy should also be looked for. The bronchial arteries derive from the aorta and thus provide a welcome opportunity for collateralisation thereby maintaining blood flow to lung segments where thrombus is chronically occluding the pulmonary artery.
GPT3_explain: I chose this because thickening of the interventricular septum is not a common finding in patients with chronic pulmonary emboli. Pulmonary artery stenosis, bronchial arterial hypertrophy, and pulmonary artery dilatation are all common findings in patients with chronic pulmonary emboli, while webs may be seen in some cases.
Cat_Long: This question would fall under basic factual recall.

Qn_Text: Above the dentate line lymphatic drainage of the anal canal is to which of the following? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The dentate line (pectinate line) is a line that divides the upper two-thirds and the lower third of the anal canal. It represents the line of division between the embryonic hindgut-proctoderm junction.
Above the dentate line the anal canal lymphatic drainage is to the internal iliac lymph nodes.
Below the dentate line the anal canal lymphatic drainage is to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.
GPT3_explain: The lymphatic drainage of the anal canal above the dentate line is to the internal iliac lymph nodes. This is because the anal canal is part of the pelvic cavity, and the internal iliac lymph nodes are located in the pelvic cavity. The other options are not correct because the external iliac lymph nodes, superficial inguinal lymph nodes, deep inguinal lymph nodes, and retroperitoneal lymph nodes are all located outside of the pelvic cavity.

3. A question about the application of a concept or theory.

Qn_Text: A 12-year-old boy undergoes a contrast enhanced CT chest for further investigation of an anterior mediastinal mass which was found on a chest radiograph. The mass is large with a lobulated outline, but with no invasion of adjacent structures. Calcification is seen within the mass, but no fat or areas of haemorrhage are identified. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The key to this question is the presence of calcification in the mass. Calcification in non-treated lymphoma is extremely rare.
  Germ Cell Tumour
This often causes a large anterior mediastinal mass. It can be subdivided into Teratoma (usually cystic with fat and calcification), seminoma (bulky and lobulated) and Non-seminomatous Germ Cell Tumour (haemorrhage and necrosis).
  Lymphoma
This is the most common anterior mediastinal mass in children. It may be difficult to differentiate a lymphoma from normal thymus, particularly in a patient younger than 10 years of age. Associated lymphadenopathy (i.e. cervical) can be the key to distinguishing the two pathologies. Calcification is rare prior to any treatment but can be a feature of lymphoma which has been treated.
  Duplication cyst
These are very rarely found in the anterior mediastinum, usually being posterior mediastinal (neuroenteric) or middle mediastinal (bronchogenic, enteric).
  Askin Tumour
These heterogenous tumours are part of the Ewing Sarcoma spectrum. Patients are often in their early teens. Askin tumours displace rather than invade adjacent mediastinal structures although rib destruction is common and is a fact which can help distinguish it from a pleuropulmonary blastoma which is another cause of a large mediastinal mass, albeit usually found in babies under the age of 2, but which does not cause rib destruction.
GPT3_explain: Lymphoma is the most likely diagnosis for this 12-year-old boy based on the CT scan findings. The large lobulated mass, the presence of calcification, and the absence of fat or areas of haemorrhage are all characteristic of lymphoma. Additionally, the anterior mediastinal location of the mass is consistent with lymphoma as well.

Qn_Text: Pertaining to Iodine MIBG scanning: Normal uptake is seen in which of the following options?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
MIBG is short for metaiodobenzylguanidine and can be used labelled with either I-123 (a gamma emitter) or I-131 (emits both beta and gamma). It is taken up by catecholamine-producing cells of the adrenal medulla and is therefore useful in the detection of phaeochromocytomas as well as paragangliomas elsewhere. It does not cross the blood brain barrier and should therefore not be seen in the brain. It is not taken up by bone.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 4 because Iodine MIBG scanning is used to detect and diagnose certain types of cancer, and it is known to have a normal uptake in the liver, bone, and salivary glands. It is not known to have a normal uptake in the other organs listed in the other options.

3. A question about a specific treatment or management plan.

Qn_Text: A 16-year-old girl presents with confusion. She has a CT scan and then an MRI scan which show multiple low attenuation lesions. These demonstrate ring enhancement on the post-contrast sequences. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is a mnemonic for ring enhancing lesions. MAGIC DR (Metastasis, abscess, glioma, infarction, contusion, demyelination, radiation necrosis). Largely however the differential diagnosis is between a metastasis and an abscess. In this case there are multiple ring enhancing lesions.
The most likely alternative diagnosis would be multiple sclerosis in this case although this would be unlikely to present as confusion. The enhancement seen with acute lesions is classically described as being an incomplete ring.
Neurocysticercosis and tuberculosis would be unlikely without any further indication from the history. Lymphoma as an index diagnosis is more often seen as a solitary large lesion although multiple lesions are not impossible.
GPT3_explain: Neurocysticercosis is the most likely diagnosis in this case because the CT and MRI scans demonstrate low attenuation lesions with ring enhancement on the post-contrast sequences. This is a classic sign of neurocysticercosis, which is an infection of the brain caused by a tapeworm. It is most common in areas where sanitation is poor.

Qn_Text: A 7mm peripherally lesion suspected to be a pulmonary hamartoma is being reviewed in the lung MDT. Which of the following is most convincing for a pulmonary hamartoma?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Fat within a thoracic mass is diagnostic of a hamartoma but is only seen in approximately half of cases. In contradistinction to carcinoid tumours, hamartomas tend to be peripherally located whereas carcinoid tumours are often more central. Exceptions to both are reasonably frequent however. Calcification, especially popcorn calcification, is also very classical for hamartomas if present. Cavitation is not a feature often associated with them, but it can be found occasionally. Hamartomas are very similar to the chondromas which form part of the Carney triad (pulmonary chondromas, gastric leiomyosarcomas and extra-adrenal paragangliomas). NB this is different from Carney syndrome (atrial myxoma, facial/buccal pigmentation, sertoli tumours of the testis and multiple other findings).
  Carney Triad
Carney syndrome
Pulmonary chondromas
Atrial myxoma
Gastric leiomyosarcoma (GIST)
Facial/buccal pigmentation
Extra-adrenal paraganglioma
Sertoli tumour of the testis
  Pituitary adenoma
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a pulmonary hamartoma is typically found in the periphery of the lung, and is usually a small, well-circumscribed nodule. It is usually seen as a round or oval lesion with a fat-like density on imaging. A peripheral location is therefore the most convincing sign of a pulmonary hamartoma.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old man, known to be HIV positive, presents with odynophagia. You are asked to perform a barium swallow to aid diagnosis and this demonstrates several small diamond shaped ulcers each with a rim of radiolucency around them. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Oesophagitis
Inflammation of the oesophagus usually presents with severe pain on swallowing (odynophagia). There are many different aetiologies but there are a few features which can help separate the differential diagnoses on imaging.
  Aetiology
Features
Candidiasis
 Immunocompromised patients
 Upper half of the oesophagus
 Irregular, longitudinal plaques with normal mucosa in between
Fulminant candidiasis
Patients with AIDs
Shaggy outline from a pseudomembrane of joined-together plaques
Herpes simplex
 Immunocompromised patients
 Flu-like symptoms
 Multiple small ulcers, each may have a halo of oedema
CMV / HIV oesophagitis
One large ulcer
These two are indistinguishable from one another by appearance
Caustic
 Ingestion of corrosive substance
 Affects middle and lower thirds
 Progression from oedema to ulceration to scarring over days
Barrett's oesophagitis
Columnar metaplasia of distal oesophagus in response to reflux
Long strictures
Reticular mucosal pattern
Drug-induced
Ulcers at sites of extrinsic compression in the mid oesophagus
Patients taking medication without enough water immediately prior to going to bed
Idiopathic eosinophilic oesophagitis
History of atopy usually present
Specific ring-like indentations to the oesophagus
  Glycogen acanthosis
This condition is caused by benign age-related squamous hyperplasia but, based on its imaging features, a differential diagnosis for candidiasis. On a barium swallow there will be small rounded white plaques in a random distribution, predominantly affecting the middle and upper oesophagus. Patients are typically middle aged or elderly.
GPT3_explain: Herpes simplex oesophagitis is the most likely diagnosis based on the findings of the barium swallow. The diamond-shaped ulcers with a rim of radiolucency around them are characteristic of this condition. Additionally, the patient's HIV status increases the likelihood of this diagnosis as HIV-positive individuals are more prone to infection with the herpes simplex virus.

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old woman falls down a flight of stairs. On examination she complains of numbness and is suspected to have sustained a spinal cord injury. An MRI of her spine is performed and you are reviewing the images. Which of following spinal nerves is correctly matched with its corresponding dermatome? Select ONE answer only.
D: C6 – The area over the deltoid
E: L4 – The lateral aspect of the calf
Explanation:
Explanation:
The key dermatomes are:
C5 – The area over the deltoid
C6 – The thumb
C7 – The middle finger
C8 – The little finger
T4 – The nipple line
T8 – The xiphisternum
T10 – The umbilicus
T12 – The symphysis pubis
L4 – The medial aspect of the calf
L5 - The web space between the 1st and 2nd toe
S1 – The lateral border of the foot
S3 – The ischial tuberosity area
S4, S5 – The perianal region
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the C6 dermatome is located over the deltoid muscle, which is located on the shoulder. The C6 spinal nerve provides innervation to the deltoid muscle, so it is the correct answer for this question.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge, how to apply knowledge to a clinical situation?

This question falls under category 3: A question about the application of knowledge, how to apply knowledge to a clinical situation.

Qn_Text: A 72-year-old lady, who is otherwise fit and well, complains to her GP of knee pain. She reports having twisted her knee some four years previously. At that time x-rays were reported as normal but new films now show flattening of the medial condyle and a subchondral radiolucent focus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Subchondral insufficiency fractures of the knee (SIFK). (Previously known as spontaneous osteonecrosis of the knee (SONK))
Women over the age of 55 is the typical demographic for SIFK but it does also occur in men. It is the adult equivalent to osteochondritis dessicans of the knee. Typically the medial condyle is affected and often there is an associated meniscal tear. On x-ray the appearances are of medial femoral condyle flattening with or without a subchondral radiolucent area. On MRI bone marrow oedema can be seen (high signal on STIR sequences).
  Terminology
Osteonecrosis
Bone death
Bone infarct
Medullary osteonecrosis
Avascular necrosis
Subchondral osteonecrosis
  Milwaukee Shoulder
This is an association of osteoarthritic changes with a complete rotator cuff tear. On aspiration of the joint fluid both hydroxyapatite and calcium pyrophosphate dehydrate (CPPD) crystals can be found. It tends to affect elderly women following a trauma and presents as a rapidly progressing arthritis. Imaging features are those of advanced osteoarthritis.
  Psoriatic arthropathy
Around a fifth of patients with psoriasis develop arthropathy and it is also possible to suffer from psoriatic arthropathy in the absence of the typical psoriatic cutaneous plaques.
Importantly, on x-ray there are findings of both erosive changes in addition to productive changes with periosteal new bone formation. The combination of the two contrives to leave a ‘pencil-in-cup’ appearance. The joints can appear fluffy due to the exuberance of new bone formation. The differential diagnosis for periosteal reactions in the presence of an arthropathy is relatively narrow and very specific (see table).
  Periosteal reaction + arthropathy
Psoriatic arthropathy
Juvenile Rheumatoid arthritis
Reiter syndrome
Infective arthropathy
  Although often classified as a distal arthropathy, preferring the DIPs to the MCPs, psoriatic arthropathy does also affect the spine and SI joints frequently. ‘Sausage digits’ is a term used to describe the diffuse soft tissue swelling which can affect the fingers and toes. Osteoporosis does occur but is a feature of later disease.
  Dislocation-relocation injury (more correctly called a transient lateral patella dislocation injury)
When the patella dislocates laterally, its medial facet can impact onto the anterolateral corner of the lateral femoral condyle. Both areas become damaged and contusions can be seen on MRI. Often though, the patella reduces spontaneously and thus the exact mechanism of injury must be inferred from the imaging findings.
Joint effusion
Osteochondral injuries to the anterolateral femoral condyle and medial patella facet
Sprain or disruption to the medial retinaculum
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because the patient's history of knee pain and the presence of a subchondral radiolucent focus on x-rays are both common signs of SONK. SONK is a condition in which the bone in the knee joint dies due to a lack of blood supply. It is more common in older adults and can be caused by previous injury or trauma.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man suffers a knee injury while on a heavily activity based holiday. He undergoes x-rays at a local hospital which show no fractures. On returning home he is referred to an orthopaedic surgeon by his GP when his pain fails to resolve. An MRI is arranged which shows high signal on STIR sequences at the anterior aspect of the tibia. There is also a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Bony contusions
Bruising to the bone can be detected around 2 days following an injury but may not resolve for many months thereafter. With regards knee injuries, it is often possible to discern the mechanism of injury from the pattern of bruising seen. The contusions follow fluid on MRI scans i.e. low in signal on T1 and high on T2 (and STIR). STIR is used to suppress the fat of the bone marrow thereby making the fluid stand out more.
  Hyperextension injury
These occur often following excessively forceful kicking. There will be bony contusions at the anterior aspect of the tibial plateau and femoral condyles. Either of the anterior or posterior cruciate ligaments may also be involved.
  Transient lateral patella dislocation injury
When the patella dislocates laterally, its medial facet can impact onto the anterolateral corner of the lateral femoral condyle. Both areas become damaged and contusions can be seen on MRI. Often though, the patella reduces spontaneously and thus the exact mechanism of injury must be inferred from the imaging findings.
Joint effusion
Osteochondral injuries to the anterolateral femoral condyle and medial patella facet
Sprain or disruption to the medial retinaculum
  Clip injury and pivot shift injury
These two injuries are very similar. Both involve valgus stress on a flexed knee (such as a tackle to the knee during sports). A pivot shift injury also requires external rotation of the tibia. The three main structures most at risk during these injuries are:
Anterior cruciate ligament (especially in a pivot shift injury)
Medial collateral ligament (especially in a clip injury)
Medial meniscus (remember that the medial meniscus is attached to the medial collateral ligament)
If all three are present together it is referred to as the O’Donoghue triad. Since O’Donoghue defined this triad however, it has been discovered that lateral meniscal tears are actually more common with this type of injury than medial meniscus ones.
Bony contusions occur at the side of impact because the proximal tibia and distal femur impact on one another thus:
Lateral tibial plateau (posterolateral in pivot shift injury)
Lateral femoral condyle
  Dashboard injury
As the name would suggest, this injury is usually stained by impact of the knee against the dashboard of a car during a road traffic incident. Force applied to the anterior aspect of the tibia when the knee is flexed leads to:
Osteochondral injury or fracture to the anterior aspect of the tibia
Posterior cruciate ligament rupture/sprain
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a clip injury is a common cause of an ACL tear, which is what the MRI showed. A clip injury occurs when the knee is bent and then quickly straightened, which can cause the ACL to tear. This is a common injury that can occur during a heavily activity-based holiday, such as sports or hiking.

Qn_Text: A 25-year-old lady undergoes an MRI scan of her hip. In the edge of the image there is a 2cm lesion on the posterolateral aspect of the vaginal introitus, below the pelvic diaphragm, which returns high signal on T2 and low signal on T1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Anatomy is the key to differentiating between the various female urogenital cysts most of which are, for the most part, asymptomatic incidental findings.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  Bartholin gland cyst
The bartholin glands secrete lubricating fluid into the inferior third of the vagina. They are found in highest numbers at the posterolateral aspect of the inferior vagina. Although usually asymptomatic, when infected or inflamed a Bartholin gland cyst can present as a painful lump. On MRI the T1 characteristics vary depending on the mucoid content but usually they return low signal on T1 and high signal on T2.
  Gartner duct cyst
These are usually found incidentally on MRI scans but can cause dyspareunia.  They do not communicate with the urethra and would be unlikely to cause post-void dribbling. They are remnants of the Wolffian ducts and occur superiorly in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. On imaging they appear straightforwardly cystic. For the most part they occur sporadically but they can also be seen in conjunction with renal agenesis or ectopia and are also typical of a rare condition called Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome. This condition causes duplication of all or part of the female genital tract with unilateral haematometrocolpos and ipsilateral renal agenesis. 
  Urethral diverticulum also known as urethrocoele
Dysuria, dyspareunia and post-void dribbling are classical for this condition. An outpouching of the urethral mucosa protrudes through the smooth muscle. This is seen on MRI as high T2 signal adjacent to or surrounding the urethra. Urinary stasis within the diverticulum predisposes patients to the formation of calculi, which can be seen as low signal on the T2 scan, and adenocarcinoma which will enhance with gadolinium.
  Skene duct cyst
These are retention cysts of the paraurethral ducts and usually they are asymptomatic. On MRI they are seen inferior to the pubic symphysis but lateral to the external urethral meatus. Signal characteristics reflect their cystic nature with high T2 signal but fluid-fluid levels may also be present if there has been intracystic haemorrhage.
  Nabothian cyst
These are tiny (few millimetres) mucous retention cysts located on the cervix. They are reasonably common but largely asymptomatic. They appear straightforwardly cystic on MRI.
GPT3_explain: Skene duct cysts are the most common type of cysts seen in the edge of the vaginal introitus. They are fluid-filled cysts that form due to a blockage of the Skene ducts, which are the ducts that connect the glands in the vulva to the urethra. They typically appear as small, round lesions that return high signal on T2 and low signal on T1, which is consistent with the description of the lesion seen in the MRI scan. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Skene duct cyst.

Qn_Text: A 76-year-old man is admitted with stroke. His wife said his symptoms started exactly 2 hours ago. Thrombolysis is being considered. What is the first line of investigation?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
A large role of acute imaging in stroke is to rule out haemorrhage, and acute haemorrhage is better seen on CT than on MRI.
MRI + DWI has a 20-30% false negative rate within the first 24 hours of symptoms. The only other answer which may be given could be CT perfusion which is often performed in stroke centres. An infarction will obviously cause an increase in the (mean transit time) MTT and is the most sensitive parameter for detecting a stroke. The cerebral blood volume map is used to determine reversibility as it will be severely reduced in frank ischaemia but may be normal or increased in the potentially salvageable penumbra. If there is only a modest reduction in cerebral blood volume but a marked loss of cerebral blood flow this would also indicate potential reversibility.
GPT3_explain: CTA is the first line of investigation for a stroke patient because it is the most efficient and reliable way to identify the location and size of the clot, which is necessary for administering thrombolysis. CTA can also provide information about the patient's blood vessels, which can help determine the cause of the stroke and guide treatment.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical reasoning, what is the best management plan?

This question falls under 3. A question about clinical reasoning, what is the best management plan?

Qn_Text: The right and left hepatic ducts combine to form which of the following? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The biliary tract, or biliary tree, is a pathway through which bile that has been secreted by the liver is transported to the duodenum.
The biliary tract begins as the interlobular bile ducts form the right and left hepatic ducts. These two ducts merge to form the common hepatic duct, which is situated alongside the hepatic vein.
The common hepatic duct exits the liver and joins with the cystic duct from the gallbladder to form the common bile duct. The common bile duct is sometimes referred to as the ‘trunk of the biliary tree’ and together with the hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein forms the central axis of the portal triad.
The common bile duct passes downwards posteriorly to the proximal duodenum and joins with the pancreatic duct from the pancreas to form the ampulla of Vater. The ampulla of Vater opens into the duodenum and the release of bile at this point is controlled by a muscular valve called the sphincter of Oddi.
  Image adapted from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Nanoxyde CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2, Common bile duct, because the right and left hepatic ducts combine to form the common bile duct. The common bile duct carries bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine. The common hepatic duct is a branch of the common bile duct, and the pancreatic duct and cystic duct are separate ducts that carry digestive enzymes and bile, respectively. The ampulla of Vater is the junction between the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old lady is being investigated for atypical chest pains which she has been experiencing for the last two months. She is worried as she has a strong family history of heart problems. She undergoes a 24-hour ECG which is normal, but an exercise ECG shows some lateral T-wave inversion. She undergoes a Dobutamine stress MRI. Which of the following is a reason the scan should be terminated? Select ONE answer only.
A: The patient asks for the scan to be terminated
B: Increase in heart rate to 50% x 200-age
D: Fall in systolic blood pressure by 20mmHg
Explanation:
Explanation:
Dobutamine stress MRI has been shown to be more sensitive and specific for cardiac disease than a dobutamine stress echocardiogram. It is a sympathomimetic so works by inducing the heart to beat both faster and stronger. By increasing the stress on the whole heart, hitherto compensated areas are unmasked. The drug is given at increasing doses ever 3 minutes until any of:
The heart rate has reached the target of (85% x (200-age))
New wall motion abnormality is seen
Blood pressure rises above 240/120mmHg
Systolic blood pressure falls by 40mmHg
The patient develops persistent arrhythmias
The patient becomes too symptomatic to continue the scan
  Aside from the usual contra-indications to performing the MRI in the first place, specific contra-indications to performing a dobutamine stress MRI include:
Hypertension >220/120mmHg
Unstable angina
Aortic stenosis (severe)
Uncontrolled atrial fibrillation
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Congestive heart failure
GPT3_explain: The patient asking for the scan to be terminated is a valid reason to terminate the scan. The patient's comfort and safety is the top priority, and if they are feeling uncomfortable or anxious during the scan, it should be stopped.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical judgement, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old man presents with odynophagia. You are asked to perform a barium swallow to aid diagnosis and this demonstrates a very large ulcer in the mid-oesophagus measuring 6cm in length. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Oesophagitis
Inflammation of the oesophagus usually presents with severe pain on swallowing (odynophagia). There are many different aetiologies but there are a few features which can help separate the differential diagnoses on imaging.
Aetiology
Features
Candidiasis
Immunocompromised patients
Upper half of the oesophagus
Irregular, longitudinal plaques with normal mucosa in between
Fulminant candidiasis
Patients with AIDs
Shaggy outline from a pseudomembrane of joined-together plaques
Herpes simplex
Immunocompromised patients
Flu-like symptoms
Multiple small ulcers, each may have a halo of oedema
CMV / HIV oesophagitis
One large ulcer
These two are indistinguishable from one another by appearance
Caustic
Ingestion of corrosive substance
Affects middle and lower thirds
Progression from oedema to ulceration to scarring over days
Barrett oesophagitis
Columnar metaplasia of distal oesophagus in response to reflux
Long strictures
Reticular mucosal pattern
Drug-induced
Ulcers at sites of extrinsic compression in the mid oesophagus
Patients taking medication without enough water immediately prior to going to bed
Idiopathic eosinophilic oesophagitis
History of atopy usually present
Specific ring-like indentations to the oesophagus
  Glycogen acanthosis
This condition is caused by benign age-related squamous hyperplasia but, based on its imaging features, a differential diagnosis for candidiasis. On a barium swallow there will be small rounded white plaques in a random distribution, predominantly affecting the middle and upper oesophagus. Patients are typically middle aged or elderly.
GPT3_explain: Barrett oesophagitis is a type of chronic inflammation of the oesophagus caused by acid reflux. It is characterized by large ulcers that can measure up to 6 cm in length. Other types of oesophagitis, such as Candida albicans oesophagitis, Glycogen acanthosis, Herpes simplex oesophagitis, and HIV oesophagitis, typically do not cause large ulcers that measure 6 cm in length.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 3-year-old girl is reviewed by the paediatricians having been admitted with a lower respiratory tract infection. This is her third similar admission and other less severe episodes have been treated in the community. Testing for cystic fibrosis is negative. The consultant on-call suspects a diagnosis of trache-oesophageal fistula and passes an NG tube. You have been asked to review the x-ray. If the diagnosis is correct, what is the most likely appearance of the NG tube which will be seen on an x-ray?
A: NG tube at T8 level with gas in the bowel
B: NG tube in the right main bronchus with no gas in the bowel
C: NG tube in right main bronchus with gas in the bowel
D: NG tube at T8 level with no gas in the bowel
E: NG tube high in the midline with gas in the bowel
Explanation:
Explanation:
In questions on TOF, the age of the patient is important. A 3-year-old child with TOF is likely to have presented with recurrent LRTIs and a type E or type H TOF. In this instance the NG tube might reach T8 (it would still be abnormally placed if it only reaches T8 but that may be procedural as opposed to pathological). On the other hand a neonate presenting with difficulty in feeding due to a TOF will have a type A or C TOF and in these cases the NG tube would not reach T8.
  Trache-oesophageal fistula (TOF)
The most common type of TOF involves a blind ending proximal oesophagus with the distal oesophagus connecting to the trachea. This accounts for around 80% of cases and patients present at an early stage with difficulty feeding. Since the distal oesophagus is connected to the trachea, gas does reach the bowel.
In all likelihood if the NG tube has reached T8 then the oesophagus is normally developed although it may still have a fistulous connection to the trachea. This type of TOF presents later with recurrent pneumonias due to aspirated fluids. An NG tube within the oesophagus at T8 is still malpositioned; the tip should be below the diaphragm. The NG tube should be advanced and the x-ray repeated if this were the case.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Lewis Spitz CC BY-SA 2.0
  A baby with Type C TOF - the NG tube is at the level of T1 but there is gas in the bowel distally. 
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Lewis Spitz CC BY-SA 2.0
GPT3_explain: This is the most likely appearance of the NG tube on an x-ray if the diagnosis of trache-oesophageal fistula is correct. The NG tube is typically placed in the right main bronchus in order to bypass the fistula and ensure that the tube is not aspirated. The presence of gas in the bowel indicates that the tube is properly placed and that the fistula is present.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical decision-making, what is the best course of action? 4. A question about interpreting results, what will the x-ray show?

Qn_Text: A 36-year-old woman presents with abdominal pains and, more recently, bloody diarrhoea. She is reviewed in A&E and due her degree of tenderness undergoes a CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast. While reviewing the scan you suspect she may have an inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following features would favour a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis over one of Crohn disease?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Thickening of the ileocaecal valve, fistula formation and skip lesions are all features more closely associated with Crohn disease. In ulcerative colitis the rectum is usually affected and the colitis progresses proximally from there. Circumferential wall thickening is better associated with ulcerative colitis which affects the mucosa and submucosa, than Crohn disease which can be patchy and causes transmural inflammation. It is, however, possible to see circumferential wall thickening in the context of Crohn disease too but of the above features it is the most indicative of a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.
  Ulcerative colitis
Whereas Crohns disease causes discontinuous transmural inflammation in ulcerative colitis it is a continuous segment of bowel which is affected beginning at the rectum and progressing proximally. Additionally, it is only the mucosa and submucosa which are affected. Patients present with symptoms of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhoea and experience relapses and periods of remission with the disease. In general, the small bowel is spared with the exception of the terminal ileum which can be affected in a so-called ‘backwash ileitis’ manner. On imaging colonic mucosal hyperenhancement can sometimes be seen, along with mucosal oedema (so-called thumbprinting). On fluoroscopic studies pseudopolyps can be seen – these are actually islands of normal mucosa or granulation tissue surrounded on all sides by inflammation. In the chronic phase the colon may become narrower, smooth and featureless as the haustral markings are lost. This is described as a lead-pipe appearance.
  Crohn disease
Crohn disease is characterised by discontinuous (skip lesions) transmural non-caseating granulomatous inflammation. By contrast, ulcerative colitis is characterised by continuous mucosal inflammation. Crohn disease is usually diagnosed in adolescence or young adulthood and patients present with non-specific abdominal pains, diarrhoea, weight loss and anaemia. Crohn disease can affect any part of the entire length of the gastrointestinal tract, in contrast to ulcerative colitis which affects only the colon, but owing to the high concentration of lymphoid tissue in the terminal ileum the vast majority of patients will have terminal ileal involvement, in particular thickening of the iliocaecal valve. Aphthous ulceration is common and on endoscopy a cobblestone appearance to the mucosa can be seen where the thickened and oedematous wall is broken up by deep longitudinal fissures. Deep ‘rosethorn’ ulcers can be seen on fluoroscopic studies.  Strictures and fistulae characterise the chronic sequelae of this disease.
Conditions associated with Crohn disease
Erythema nodosum
Gallstones
Oxalate ureteric calculi
Sclerosing cholangitis
Cholangiocarcinoma
Small bowel carcinoma
GPT3_explain: Skip lesions are a common feature of Crohn disease, but not of ulcerative colitis. They are areas of normal bowel sandwiched between two areas of inflamed or ulcerated tissue, and can be seen on imaging studies. The other features mentioned are more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old man with hearing loss presents to his GP. He is referred for an ENT opinion and the ENT surgeon suggests an MRI scan. This shows a cerebellopontine angle mass which is well defined with low signal on T1, high signal on T2. On the FLAIR sequences it cannot be seen and there is low signal (i.e. no restriction) on DWI.   What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are a few key features to cerebellopontine angle masses which help distinguish them from one another. In this particular question the arachnoid cyst is the red herring that proves the rule – although not classically a CP angle tumour, they can occur anywhere and should be easily identified since they follow CSF signals on all modalities and sequences, thus there is high T2 signal, not seen on FLAIR, and no restriction on DWI. A choroid plexus cyst is not a CP angle mass.
Epidermoid cysts restrict diffusion. This is thought to be due to the linear configuration of keratin fibres seen at a microscopic level giving them a higher level of anisotropy than adjacent white matter.
For the usual differential diagnosis for CP angle masses the pertinent features are summarised in the table below. Where an asterisk has been used denotes a reasonably specific defining feature which can be used to pinpoint the diagnosis.
    Schwannoma (80-90%)
Meningioma (10-20%)
Epidermoid (5%)
Epicentre
IAC
Dura
CPA
CT density
Iso
Hyper or iso
Hypo
Calcification
*None
*Frequent
Occasional
IAC
*Wide
Normal or wide
Normal
T2 signal
Hyper
50% iso
Hyper
Enhancement
++
++
*None
Description
-
-
Lobulated
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis is Acoustic neuroma because of the MRI scan findings. The cerebellopontine angle mass is well defined with low signal on T1 and high signal on T2. On the FLAIR sequences it cannot be seen and there is low signal (i.e. no restriction) on DWI. These findings are consistent with an Acoustic neuroma.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old lady is admitted to A&E two weeks following a stem-cell transplant for leukaemia. She has ascites and hepatomegaly. The portal veins appear normal on B-mode but a Doppler study shows increased pulsatility. What is the most likely explanation? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Veno-occlusive disease develops within the first 20-30 days following transplantation however graft vs host disease occurs after 3-12 months following transplantation.
Graft vs Host disease
When T-cells from the donor bone marrow attack epithelial cells in the recipient a phenomenon known as Graft versus Host disease can occur. Within the liver this can lead to fibrosis and can present in a similar manner to veno-occlusive dsease. The effects are classically seen in the GI tract and the skin as opposed to the lungs but pulmonary manifestations can arise a few months after the transplant. On CT there is mild perihilar fibrosis with nodule formation.
Hepatic venous outflow obstruction
There are three separate syndromes which all overlap both in terms of their clinical and radiological features. They are, however, separate entities, caused by subtly different processes.
Passive hepatic congestion – this arises due to a cardiac problem such as right sided heart failure of any cause or constrictive pericarditis. Tender hepatomegaly is common and on imaging the hepatic veins and IVC are notably enlarged.
Budd-Chiari syndrome – the pathology here is within the hepatic veins with thrombosis or other non-thrombotic obstruction (e.g. extrinsic compression). Acutely there is abdominal pain, ascites and hepatomegaly. The presence or absence of caudate lobe hypertrophy can help distinguish between a chronic process or an acute one where this has not had sufficient time to develop.
Hepatic veno-occlusive disease – fibrosis of the tiny venules can develop following a stem-cell transplant, and by pyrrolizidine alkaloids found in Jamaican bush teas. Clinically patients present with weight gain due to fluid retention, hepatomegaly and jaundice.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because hepatic veno-occlusive disease is a common complication of stem cell transplantation, and it is characterized by increased pulsatility in the portal veins. Symptoms of this condition can include ascites and hepatomegaly, which are both present in this patient.

Explanation:
Explanation:
The anatomical relations of each part of the colon are shown in the table below:
Section of colon Anterior relations Posterior relations
Ascending colon

Small intestine

Urinary bladder

Upper vagina (females)
Rectum

GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the greater omentum is a sheet of fat that is attached to the posterior surface of the descending colon. It is located between the stomach and the transverse colon.
