Qn_Text: A 63-year-old man is having a cardiac MRI for investigation of exertional dyspnoea. The radiographer explains to you that the images are degraded by patient motion. How is this likely to have affected the image?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Physics questions should be covered in the FRCR part 1 but every so often one can crop up. Fortunately they are far more clinical than the physics exam, covering problems that a radiologist might face on real scans.
Field inhomogeneities would contribute to inhomogeneous fat suppression
Ghosting in the phase encoding direction occurs either due to patient motion or pulsation of large vessels.
Poorly positioned coiled would cause an overall reduction in signal acquired
The india ink phenomenon is caused by chemical shift artifact
GPT3_explain: I would choose 1 and 2. Ghosting in the frequency-encoding direction and ghosting in the phase-encoding direction are both likely to be affected by patient motion. This is because patient motion can result in misalignment of the signal and cause artifacts in the images. Field inhomogeneities, poorly positioned coils, and India ink phenomenon are all less likely to be affected by patient motion.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge, how to interpret the results of a test?

This question falls under 3. A question about the application of knowledge, how to interpret the results of a test.

Qn_Text: A 58-year-old man undergoes a cystoscopy for investigation of a urinary tract malignancy following presentation with haematuria. He is found to have a primary adenocarcinoma of the bladder. Which of the following is the LEAST common site of this malignancy? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely answer.
Adenocarcinoma of the bladder
Certain areas within the bladder show an increased prevalence of adenocarcinoma - in particular, the bladder base, urethrocoeles (not technically bladder), and any urachal remnants found in the midline. Urachal remnant carcinomas account for around 30% of adenocarcinomas of the bladder. Carcinomas of the prostate are most commonly adenocarcinoma and although usually it is readily possible to differentiate between a prostatic malignancy and a bladder tumour on MRI, there may be advanced invasive cases where the line is more blurred. It is important clinically to differentiate between secondary adenocarcinomas which have metastasized from elsewhere and primary adenocarcinomas as the treatment is obviously very different. This is a histological diagnosis however, not radiological. Secondary adenocarcinomas are more common than primary adenocarcinomas.
For the most part, imaging is not able to distinguish between the different cell types with any degree of reliability; the diagnosis is histological.
Other bladder cancers:
Cell type Percentage
Transitional cell carcinoma >90-95
Squamous cell carcinoma 2-15 (strong geographical variation)
Adenocarcinoma (primary) <2
Sarcoma <2
  Transitional cell carcinoma
Transitional carcinoma makes up around 95% of urinary tract cancers in the UK. The vast majority affect the bladder. The renal pelvis is the second most commonly affected site. The ureter is the least common site of malignancy. The lower third is affected in around 75% of cases, followed by the middle third. The proximal third is affected in only around 3% or ureteric malignancies. Bladder diverticulae, if present, pose an increased risk of tumour development due to urinary stasis within them. These also show invasive features at an earlier stage owing to the paucity of protective muscle surrounding them.
Smokers are at vastly increased risk of developing TCC due to the prolonged contact of carcinogens excreted in urine with the bladder wall.
Squamous cell carcinoma
Both SCC and adenocarcinomas of the bladder are linked to entities which cause chronic bladder irritation such as long term catheters, bladder stones and chronic urinary tract infection. In developing countries, infection with schistosomiasis strongly skews the prevalence data as it is known to cause squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
Urethral diverticulum (urethrocoele)
Dysuria, dyspareunia and post-void dribbling are classical for this condition. An outpouching of the urethral mucosa protrudes through the smooth muscle. This is seen on MRI as high T2 signal adjacent to or surrounding the urethra. Urinary stasis within the diverticulum predisposes patients to the formation of calculi, which can be seen as low signal on the T2 scan, and adenocarcinoma which will enhance with gadolinium.
Urachal cyst (extraprostatic)
The urachus is a fibrous remnant of a thin canal connecting the bladder to the umbilicus. Ordinarily it is almost imperceptible however there are four distinct anomalies which can persist into adulthood and cause symptoms.
Patency – a fistula between the bladder and the umbilicus. There is leakage of urine from the umbilicus present from birth.
Sinus – blind dilatation of the urachus at the umbilical end.
Diverticulum – communication with the dome of the bladder
Cyst – dilatation in the lower third which does not communicate with either end. These are asymptomatic unless or until the cyst becomes infected or ruptures.
  Malignancy arising from the urachas, unlike most bladder cancer, tends to be adenocarcinoma. In young patients sarcomas are also seen.
MRI bladder
Imaging the bladder with MRI is a balancing act between sufficient distension to achieve adequate sensitivity rates without the images being compromised by motion due to the discomfort of having a full bladder for the duration of the scan.
On T2 the detrusor muscle returns low signal but the continuity of this layer will be disrupted if there is invasion.
The T1 images are more useful for evaluating lymph node involvement and any bony metastases.
Post-contrast images are of limited use in bladder cancer imaging. Some literature does support their use since the tumours tend to enhance early, whereas the muscle layer undergoes only delayed enhancement but since the bladder mucosa and submucosa also enhance in the early phase the appearances can be confusing to the untrained eye.
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because the urachal cyst is the least common site for a primary adenocarcinoma of the bladder. This is because the urachal cyst is a rare congenital anomaly that is formed by the remnant of the urachus, which is a tube that connects the bladder to the umbilicus during fetal development. This anomaly is usually asymptomatic, and thus is not usually detected. As such, it is much less likely to be the site of a primary adenocarcinoma of the bladder than other more commonly encountered sites such as the trigone, ureteric orifice, bladder diverticulum, and urachal diverticulum.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about applying knowledge to a scenario.

This question falls under category 3: A question about applying knowledge to a scenario.

Qn_Text: A young patient is found to have bilateral vestibular schwannomas. Which of the following additional findings would also be indicative of neurofibromatosis type 2?
E: Dysplasia to the greater wing of sphenoid
Explanation:
Explanation:
NF1 (Neurofibromatosis type 1) is the ‘peripheral’ version. There are plenty of cerebral features described however NF2 (Neurofibromatosis type 2) is almost exclusively cerebral and is therefore by comparison the ‘central’ version. The usual mnemonic for NF2 is MISME (Multiple Inherited Schwannomas, Meningiomas, Ependymomas). Although the classical schwannoma seen is that involving cranial nerve VIII, they can be found on other cranial nerves. (Theoretically this would not include the optic and olfactory nerves, since they are usually stated not to have Schwann cells however there have been some case reports of anterior cranial fossa schwannomas; the aetiology of these schwannomas is not clearly understood yet.)  Of the other options provided cafe-au-lait spots are the only overlapping feature, although they are more commonly found in NF1 than NF2. The skeletal features are limited to NF1.
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 2, 3, and 4. Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of noncancerous tumors on the nerves of the body, including the vestibular schwannomas that were found in the patient. Other common signs of NF2 include optic nerve gliomas, neurofibromas, cafe au lait spots, and dysplasia to the greater wing of sphenoid. Meningiomas are not typically associated with NF2.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing an MRI scan in the urology MDT. The patient is a 67-year-old man who was found to have a bladder cancer when he underwent cystoscopy following symptoms of painless haematuria. The MRI shows enlarged lymph nodes Involvement of which of the following groups of lymph nodes would be considered as regional disease?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
C: Inguinal, external iliac and common iliac nodes
Explanation:
Explanation:
The most important lymph node groups in the context of a pelvic malignancy are the internal, external and common iliac nodes, the inguinal, perivisceral and para-aortic nodes. It is important to recognise the distinction between what is considered as a regional lymph node for a given organ, and what would be non-regional. Involvement of non-regional lymph nodes is taken as metastatic disease which has huge implications on subsequent patient management.
For bladder cancer, both the internal and external iliac nodes are considered as regional disease. Recently the common iliac nodes have also been reclassifiied as regional disease. These would confer N3 staging.
  Bladder cancer
Imaging the bladder with MRI is a balancing act between sufficient distension to achieve adequate sensitivity rates without the images being compromised by motion due to the discomfort of having a full bladder for the duration of the scan.
On T2 the detrusor muscle returns low signal but the continuity of this layer will be disrupted if there is invasion.
The T1 images are more useful for evaluating lymph node involvement and any bony metastases.
Post-contrast images are of limited use in bladder cancer imaging. Some literature does support their use since the tumours tend to enhance early, whereas the muscle layer undergoes only delayed enhancement but since the bladder mucosa and submucosa also enhance in the early phase the appearances can be confusing to the untrained eye.
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 2. Inguinal, external iliac and common iliac nodes. This is because these nodes are considered to be part of the regional lymph node groups for bladder cancer, which include the inguinal, external iliac, common iliac, and para-aortic nodes. Enlargement of any of these nodes would be considered as regional disease.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reporting a CTPA scan which has filling defects bilaterally in the pulmonary arteries. Which of the following would favour a diagnosis of acute emboli over chronic emboli?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Enlargement of the pulmonary arteries can be seen when there is severe right heart strain but an enlarged main pulmonary artery is more associated with chronic pulmonary emboli leading to pulmonary hypertension.
Contrast within the hepatic veins is seen when there is tricuspid regurgitation and can be seen in both acute and chronic pulmonary emboli.
The polo mint sign is seen when the CT slice is at 90o to the direction of flow in a given pulmonary artery.
The railway track sign is seen when the CT slice is in line with the direction of flow.
Eccentricity of the thrombus is more suggestive of a chronic pulmonary embolus. Acute emboli sit within the lumen of the artery and where they touch the wall of the artery will subtend an acute angle, whereas chronic emboli flatten against the walls of the artery in a crescenteric shape and thereby subtend an obtuse angle.
Bronchial artery collaterals form in the setting of chronic pulmonary emboli.
  Acute pulmonary emboli
Filling defects within the pulmonary arteries can be seen on any post-contrast CT scans but a dedicated CT pulmonary angiogram has a higher sensitivity in this regard. The polo mint and railtrack signs are given as signs of acute pulmonary emboli. Acute emboli also sit within the lumen of the pulmonaries and therefore subtend an acute angle with the wall. When the clot load is haemodynamically significant features of right heart strain can be seen. These include bowing of the interventricular septum, right ventricular enlargement (the right ventricle should not be larger than the left ventricle). Dilatation of the main pulmonary artery (the main pulmonary artery should not be larger than the aorta). There are various features which can help determine the chronicity of an embolus or emboli. These are summarised in the table below:
  Acute
Chronic
Tricuspid regurgitation – contrast in hepatic veins
Acute angles
Obtuse angles
Railway track sign
Bronchial artery collaterals
Polo mint sign
Webs and bands
  CTEPH (Chronic Thromboembolic Pulmonary Hypertension) 
When acute pulmonary emboli fail to resolve there is a danger that their presence will lead to elevated pulmonary arterial pressures i.e CTEPH. The symptoms and radiological signs of CTEPH pertain either to the thrombi or the pulmonary hypertension. Filling defects on CTPA can be expected. Differentiating chronic from acute pulmonary emboli is not an exact science but chronic PEs can display features such as luminal eccentricity (build up of thrombus along the walls of the pulmonary arteries as opposed to central filling defects within the lumen) and calcification. Webs and bands are also features of chronicity - thin, threadlike fibrous structures attached at either end to the vessel wall but free-floating in their mid-portions. Features of the consequent pulmonary hypertension include enlargement of the main pulmonary arteries with stenosis of the peripheral arteries giving rise to a tapered appearance. Right ventricular enlargement and hypertrophy should also be looked for. The bronchial arteries derive from the aorta and thus provide a welcome opportunity for collateralisation thereby maintaining blood flow to lung segments where thrombus is chronically occluding the pulmonary artery.
Acute pulmonary emboli © Medical Exam Prep
  Pulmonary emboli angles © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: Eccentric mural thrombus is more suggestive of acute emboli, as it indicates the presence of fresh thrombi within the pulmonary arteries. Chronic emboli, on the other hand, would be more likely to present with a central mural thrombus.
Cat_Long: This question falls under Category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: Which of the following features is NOT usually used in the context of a paraganglioma? Select one answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Paragangliomas can be found in the body under a number of guises. All are histologically identical and encompass carotid body tumours, phaeochromocytomas, and glomus tumours. They demonstrate similar and characteristic imaging features throughout the body.
Pulsatile tinnitus is a feature of a Glomus Tympanicum.
Splaying of the carotid arteries is a feature of carotid body tumours.
Flow voids or the classic ‘salt and pepper’ description applies to all paragangliomas.
Avid contrast enhancement is also seen since these tumours are highly vascular in nature.
Polycythaemia should be associated with haemangioblastomas as a consequence of erythropoietin production.
GPT3_explain: Polycythaemia is a condition in which there is an abnormally high number of red blood cells in the blood. This is not usually associated with paragangliomas, which are tumors that develop in the paraganglia, a network of cells located near the major blood vessels in the body. The other features listed are commonly seen in the context of paragangliomas.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: In a teaching session you are presented with an MRI scan which shows low T2 signal in the spleen. The consultant taking the session refuses to provide you with any details of the patient’s history or presenting complaint. Which of the following is NOT a possible explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the answer which is NOT a likely option
  Amiodarone therapy
Amiodarone is an anti-arrhythmic drug which contains iodine (am-IOD-arone). Consequently, as it accumulates in the liver, it can cause significant increase in density on CT. The MRI signal is unaffected.
  Haemochromatosis
The primary version of this disease can be inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. Excess dietary iron is absorbed and this accumulates in all tissues of the body leading to various different problems.
Secondary haemochromatosis can arise if patients receive numerous blood transfusions without sufficient chelation to mitigate against the iron overload.
Cirrhosis – the presence of the excess iron in the liver leads to unusual signal properties on an MRI scan. Iron is paramagnetic and causes spin dephasing. T2* and T2 sequences are particularly vulnerable to this effect but lower than expected signal will be seen on all sequences. Importantly the signal from the spleen and bone marrow should be normal. By contrast they will be involved in cases of transfusional siderosis.
Generalised osteoporosis
Hook like osteophytes on the radial aspect of the metacarpal heads – these are highly characteristic
Chondrocalcinosis, particularly affecting the knees
Insulin dependent diabetes
Congestive cardiomyopathy
Skin pigmentation
  Sickle cell disease, spherocytosis and heart valves
The signal from the spleen may be affected by haemosiderin deposition due to haemolysis within the spleen but the liver is unlikely to be affected.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. MRI safe prosthetic heart valve as the incorrect answer because a low T2 signal in the spleen is not typically associated with a prosthetic heart valve. Prosthetic heart valves are made of metal and can cause artifacts on an MRI scan, but they would not cause a low T2 signal in the spleen.

3. A question about the application of knowledge, what is the best treatment for the patient?

This question falls under the category of clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 46-year-old woman undergoes a pelvic MRI to investigate suspected endometrial cancer. Several pelvic sidewall nodes are rounded but measure under 1cm in short axis. Which feature on MRI can be suggestive of metastatic nodal involvement? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Normal lymph nodes restrict diffusion and the DWI sequences are very useful in identifying lymph nodes however they do not accuarely specify whether a lymph node is involved or not. 
Features concerning for metastatic involvement are:
Size - 
Shape - rounded as opposed to oblong
Irregular margins
Morphology - lack of a hilum
Enhancement
GPT3_explain: T2 shine through is a feature that can be suggestive of metastatic nodal involvement on MRI. This is because it is associated with increased cellularity and increased water content within the nodes, which can be indicative of metastatic involvement.

Qn_Text: A 16-year-old male undergoes an x-ray of his right knee which shows scalloping of the distal femoral metadiaphyseal region. An MRI shows a tumour situated in the vastus medialis. There is heterogenous T1 and T2 signal centrally and a low signal rim surrounding the mass. On the gradient echo sequence the low signal rim becomes even darker. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Haemophilic arthropathy
The larger joints are most at risk for this disease, and the knee is particularly classical. On an x-ray there may only be a joint effusion in early disease but erosions and subchondral cysts develop. In particular there may be widening of the intercondylar notch (for which there is a differential diagnosis of: JIA/RA, Psoriatic arthropathy, TB and haemophilia) due to pannus formation. Also classical is epiphyseal overgrowth secondary to hyperaemia. On an MRI there may well be nodular deposits on the synovium however the presence of blood degradation products renders these very low in signal on all sequences with blooming artefact present on gradient echo sequences or similar. If a haemarthrosis is present, the signal of the fluid will change depending on the chronicity of the event.
A haemophilic pseudotumour occurs in around 1-2% of patients with haemophilia. The presence of blood degradation products leads to a wide variety of intralesional signal patterns. The lesions are usually surrounded by a low signal haemosiderin rim though. Lesions can arise within bone (intra-osseous) or in soft tissues (usually muscular). Growth and pressure effects on adjacent bone can cause scalloping.
PVNS - Pigmented villonodular synovitis
The classic joint to be affected by PVNS is the knee but it can also occur at other large joints. Usually only one joint is affected in each patient. On x-ray the only sign may be a joint effusion. Large subchondral cysts can also be seen. On MRI however, the appearances are characteristic. Haemorrhagic proliferation of the synovium in a frond-like fashion gives rise to the classic low signal 'feathery' sea-anemone-like finding. On susceptibility weighted sequences there is blooming artefact owing to the presence of haemosiderin. Patients are usually middle-aged and treatment is with synovectomy although there is a high rate of recurrence. If the patient is male, the usual differential diagnosis for PVNS is of haemophilic arthropathy owing to the presence of blood products there too. PVNS appears as a differential diagnosis for subarticular lucent bone lesions due to the formation of large subchondral cysts.
Lipoma arborescens
This condition can affect children or adults and is thought to be a reaction to chronic inflammation of the synovium leading to extensive fatty infiltration of the synovium. It is almost always the knee which is affected. Plain radiographs will show only an effusion, which may be large, but on MRI there is frond-like or nodular synovial proliferation which returns fat-signal according to the different sequences used. The signal should be high on T1 and T2 but suppress on fat-saturated sequences. Post-contrast the synovium itself will enhance. Treatment is by synovectomy.
SAPHO (Synovitis, acne, palmoplantar pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteitis)
This disease is thought to be a variant of psoriatic arthropathy. The cutaneous manifestations may not be apparent at diagnosis (like psoriatic arthropathy) but hyperostosis and osteolysis and ankylosis of the sternoclavicular joint is absolutely typical. On a nuclear medicine bone scan, bilateral uptake in the sternoclavicular joints and manubrium is called a ‘bull’s head’ sign. About a third of patients also have spinal disease with paravertebral ossifications and osteosclerosis. Unilateral sacroiliitis may also occur. Appearances can be quite striking on CT. In the knees, ankles and small joints of the hands there may be inflammation of the joints with juxta-articular osteoporosis.
Osteosarcoma
These are bone forming tumours which can either be primary, or secondary. Primary osteosarcomas occur in young patients or young adults when the bones are more active during adolescence than in later life, and have a predilection for either the proximal tibia or distal femur i.e. around the knee joint. Secondary osteosarcomas occur as malignant degeneration of pre-existing bone lesions. Clinically they present as a painful mass with a fever. Pain on movement is also typical. In later disease patients may have a raised serum ALP. On x-ray they are poorly defined aggressive lesions with sunburst periosteal reaction and fluffy cloud-like osseous matrix. For staging the patient should receive an MRI of the entire of the affected bone (to rule out synchronous lesions), a nuclear medicine bone scan and a CT chest. Tissue biopsy should only be performed at tertiary referral centres where to mitigate the risk of seeding the biopsy tract, immediate tissue analysis with the option of immediate amputation can be performed.
Secondary osteosarcomas:
Paget disease
Bone infarct
Osteochondroma
Osteoblastoma
Radiotherapy change
  In the case of a parosteal osteosarcoma, the attachment to the underlying bone may be thin and stalk-like but will be present. Depending on the view a radiolucent plane may seem present for some of the length of the tumour, giving rise to ‘string sign’ appearance, but an attachment to the parent bone will be present.
GPT3_explain: SAPHO is the most likely diagnosis because the MRI findings are consistent with the diagnosis. The scalloped distal femoral metadiaphyseal region is a common finding in SAPHO, and the MRI findings of a heterogenous T1 and T2 signal centrally, with a low signal rim surrounding the mass, and the gradient echo sequence showing an even darker low signal rim are all characteristic of SAPHO.

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old man with known HIV presents with neurological deterioration. He undergoes imaging which shows lesions in the frontal lobes. These are shown to be hypometabolic. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cryptococcus
This is an opportunistic yeast-like fungus which therefore requires a degree of immunocompromise, typically AIDS. The cryptococcomas are non-enhancing low density lesions in the basal ganglia. These show as high signal on T2 sequences. A granulomatous meningitis can also occur. They can be differentiated from VR spaces on FLAIR where VR spaces will suppress (being CSF in content) whereas the mucoid cryptococcomas will not.
    Toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasmosis is a more common finding in AIDS patients than lymphoma is, by a large margin. On MRI it is seen as multiple ring enhancing lesions, which can show haemorrhage particularly following treatment. One of the stronger differentiators between toxoplasmosis and lymphoma is the SPECT findings. This is sometimes termed ‘hypometabolic’ meaning the lesions do not demonstrate SPECT uptake. The table below gives some general features of the two conditions. There is however considerable overlap in the imaging features despite these broad trends.
    Toxoplasmosis
Lymphoma
Number of lesions
Multiple lesions
Single lesion (can be multiple)
Predilection/involvement of
Basal ganglia
Corpus callosum
DWI
Range of appearances
Restricts
Thallium SPECT
Negative
Avid
MRS choline
Decreased
Increased
MR perfusion
Decreased rCBV
Increased rCBV
  Lymphoma
A ring solitary ring enhancing lesion in the context of an AIDS patient should raise lymphoma as a strong possibility. Multiple lesions can and do occur however, making the distinction from toxoplasmosis challenging. Lymphoma is also part of the differential diagnosis for lesions that cross the corpus callosum and this can be a feature that separates it from toxoplasmosis, although is not a feature of exclusion. Similarly if haemorrhage has been seen associated with the lesion this is more a feature of toxoplasmosis but absence of haemorrhage does not exclude toxoplasmosis.
  HIV encephalopathy
Separating HIV encephalitis from PML can challenging in real life. HIV encephalitis causes bilateral symmetrical white matter changes, seen as high T2 signal (The T1 sequences can be normal). There is also sparing of the subcortical U-fibres.
  Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)
This is a JC virus mediated phenomenon which causes asymmetrical patchy white matter changes. These can be bilateral. The testable feature is involvement of the cortical U-fibres which separates it from HIV encephalopathy where the U-fibres are spared.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because HIV encephalopathy is a common neurological complication of HIV infection. It is characterized by hypometabolic lesions in the frontal lobes and can lead to neurological deterioration. Other conditions may present with similar symptoms, but HIV encephalopathy is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the kidneys is true?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: The right kidney lies slightly lower than the left kidney
B: The hila lie at the T12 vertebral level
C: The adrenal glands lie posterior to the kidneys
D: The subcostal nerves lie anterior to the kidneys
E: The right kidney lies posterior to the jejunum
Explanation:
Explanation:
The kidneys are two retroperitoneal organs that lie on the posterior abdominal wall. They are responsible for electrolyte and fluid balance and also for the filtration and excretion of waste products from the blood.
Each kidney lies on its respective side of the vertebral column between the T12 and L3 vertebral levels. The right kidney lies slightly lower than the left because of the presence of the large right lobe of the liver. The kidney moves during respiration, one particular study noted that the maximal vertical motion of the superior pole of the kidney from its end-expiratory to its end-inspiratory position is around 40 mm.
At the concave medial margin of each kidney is a vertical cleft called the renal hilum. This is the point where the renal artery and vein enter and exit the kidney respectively. The hila of the kidney lie approximately in the transpyloric plane at the L1 vertebral level.
The principal relations of each kidney are shown in the table below:
    Left kidney Right kidney
Anterior relations
Left adrenal gland
Spleen
Stomach
Pancreas
Left colic flexure
Jejunum
Right adrenal gland
Liver
Duodenum
Right colic flexure
Posterior relations
Diaphragm
11thand 12th ribs
Psoas major
Quadratus lumborum
Transversus abdominis
Subcostal nerve
Iliohypogastric nerve
Ilioinguinal nerve
Diaphragm
12th rib
Psoas major
Quadratus lumborum
Transversus abdominis
Subcostal nerve
Iliohypogastric nerve
Ilioinguinal nerve
  The kidneys and their main relations (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is the only one that accurately describes the anatomical position of the kidneys. The kidneys are located in the retroperitoneal space and lie at the level of the T12 vertebrae. The right kidney is slightly lower than the left kidney due to the presence of the liver on the right side of the body.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 20-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain. Four months previously she suffered a ruptured appendix. A CT scan now shows a complex mass in the right iliac fossa adjacent to a thickened caecal pole. There is a sinus tract to the groin which is discharging pus. Within the pelvis the mass appears to be infiltrating the right psoas muscle. A sample from the groin sinus sent by the GP three days previously has grown actinomycosis. Which of the following is LEAST indicative of actinomycosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the feature LEAST suggestive of actinomycosis.
Actinomycosis
The bacterium actinomyces israelii produces proteases which allows it to cross structures which would otherwise present a barrier to spread of infection. Within the abdominal cavity actinomycosis leads to abscess formation, and fistula development. It is usual for the patient to have previously suffered a ruptured appendix or to be using an IUCD, or other similar entities. In the case of an IUCD, tuboovarian abscesses can form and spread locally to involve the psoas. Extrinsic ureteric compression leads to hydronephrosis.
GPT3_explain: IUCD in situ is not indicative of actinomycosis because it is not a symptom of the disease. Actinomycosis is an infectious disease caused by bacteria, and the symptoms include sinus tract formation, complex mass formation, caecal pole thickening, and psoas involvement.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about a patient's history and presentation.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are performing a trans-vaginal ultrasound scan on a lady who presented to her GP with vague abdominal pains and constipation worsening over the last few months. In the left adnexal region there is a solid lesion measuring 5cm with colour doppler flow seen within. There is no ascites, and no acoustic shadow. According to the IOTA rules, how should this lesion be classified?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
IOTA rules (International Ovarian Tumour Analysis)
In comparison to many other cancers, ovarian cancer has a relatively poor prognosis, partly on account of the vague nature of symptoms leading to presentation but also due to the limitations of diagnosis by ultrasound (often the first line of investigation for patients who end up being diagnosed with ovarian cancer).
The IOTA rules were designed to standardise ultrasound findings in ovarian lesions.
Two sets of rules were drawn up; M-rules and B-rules (indicating malignant and benign characteristics respectively). The rules have been designed to be as simple as possible, for general use by anyone capable of performing transabdominal or transvaginal imaging of the ovaries.
  Malignant = One or more M-rule, no B-rules
Benign = One or more B-rules, no M-rules
Indeterminate = everything else
  B-rules
M-rules
B1 = Unilocular cyst
M1 = Solid, irregular mass
B2 = <7mm solid component
M2 = Ascites
B3 = Acoustic shadow 
M3 = >3 papillary structures
B4 = Multilocular cyst <10cm
M4 = Multilocular solid mass >10cm
B5 = No blood flow
M5 = Blood flow
    Ovarian cancer
There are a number of different types of ovarian carcinoma and the final diagnosis will be a histological one. On imaging the features can be varied.
Subtypes Frequency and Age
Malignant epithelial tumours (Serous, mucinous, endometroid, clear cell) 85% (60s -70s)
Malignant germ cell tumours (Teratoma, dysgerminoma, choriocarcinoma, mixed) 7% (<30 years)
Metastases <10%
Sex cord stromal tumours ~5%
  A number of factors increase the risk of developing ovarian cancer in an individual. Anything which increases the number of ovulatory cycles a woman undergoes in her lifetime will increase the risk of ovarian cancer (early menarche, late menopause, nulliparity), and vice versa (multiparity, breastfeeding, oral contraceptive pill use). A family history of related cancers also increases the risk.
Presenting symptoms may be quite vague with abdominal pains, constipation or urinary frequency being the only complaints if any from the patient. Consequently, many tumours have already spread beyond the ovary by the time of diagnosis. Initial investigation is often with ultrasound. Although ovarian cancers can have a variety of imaging appearances, solid or papillary components to a cystic mass are strongly indicative of malignancy. Predominantly solid masses with some small cystic components are also likely to be malignant but completely perfectly solid lesions are actually more likely to be benign. Ovarian fibromas and fibrothecomas are both benign lesions which can be seen as solid masses however despite this, without prior imaging for comparison a solid ovarian lesion is malignant until proven otherwise.
Ovarian cancer can spread in a multitude of ways:
Direct extension Sigmoid mesocolon, broad ligament, fallopian tubes
Intraperitoneal seeding and implantation Omental caking, peritoneal space
Lymphatic spread External iliac, obturator nodes
Haematogenous Liver, lung, adrenal glands, pleural effusion
  Bowel obstruction is relatively common with disseminated ovarian cancer however it is usually large bowel obstruction. Small bowel obstruction is far less common.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the IOTA rules state that lesions with a size of 5cm or greater should be classified as indeterminate. The presence of color Doppler flow within the lesion is not sufficient to determine whether the lesion is benign or malignant. Therefore, the only option is to classify it as indeterminate.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the chest radiograph of an elderly plumber with a 30 pack year history of smoking. He presented to his GP with a cough which had been bothering him for the last few months. There is an opacity in the right lower zone. You suggest he should have an urgent CT scan. Which of the following makes lung cancer a more likely diagnosis than round atelectasis? Select ONE answer only.
A: It is not associated with pleural plaques
B: There are air bronchograms within it
D: The lesion has a curvilinear shape
Explanation:
Explanation:
Both lung cancer and round atelectasis show enhancement post contrast.
A lack of association with pleural plaques would make this lesion even more suspicious for lung cancer than if they were present when the possibility of round atelectasis is more likely. Having said that, even in the presence of pleural plaques, of course a lung cancer would still need to be excluded.
  Round atelectasis
Round atelectasis occurs most commonly as part of the spectrum of asbestos related findings but does have other lesser aetiologies. It is also referred to as ‘infolded lung’ which better describes the appearances seen on CT. On CT there is a rounded mass-like region adjacent to the pleural surface. A comet tail sign is seen coming from the mass where the bronchovascular structures supplying the affected part of the lung are pulled into the centre of it thus there is a linear opacity curving outwards from the mass and pointing towards the hilum. The pleura adjacent to the mass is often thickened and if the mass is sufficiently large, features of volume loss can be seen in the ipsilateral hemithorax. Owing to the association with asbestos the patient may well show other features of exposure such as pleural plaque disease.
  Pleural plaques
When calcified pleural plaques are seen bilaterally it is virtually pathognomonic of prior asbestos exposure. Of all asbestos related pleural plaques around 85% are calcified. Involvement of the mediastinum should raise the possibility of mesothelioma but involvement of the costophrenic angles should raise the possibility of an alternative diagnosis as these are usually spared in asbestos related plaque disease. Unilateral pleural plaques can be caused by any previous insult such as surgery or an empyema although the most common cause is still asbestos related lung disease.
GPT3_explain: Air bronchograms are seen in lung cancer but not in round atelectasis. Air bronchograms are seen when the airways within a lesion are visible on imaging, indicating that the lesion is partially obstructing the airway. This is a sign of a more advanced lesion, which is more likely to be cancerous than round atelectasis.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 67-year-old man develops a swollen, tender, pulsatile mass in his right groin two days after a diagnostic cardiac angiogram. He undergoes an ultrasound which demonstrates a 2.5cm pseudoaneurysm of the profunda femoris artery. What is the most appropriate next management?
B: Conservative management with repeat USS in 48hrs
Explanation:
Explanation:
Approximately 1-2% of cardiac catheterizations are complicated by femoral pseudoaneurysm formation. An iatrogenic pseudoaneurysm forms when there is contained leakage of blood from a vessel puncture site. The sac of blood communicates with the lumen and continuous flow within the pseudoaneurysm prevents clot formation. Pseudoaneurysms pose a significant risk of rupture with potentially catastrophic consequences if they do. Risk factors for pseudoaneurysm formation include:
Patient related
Anticoagulation
Haemodialysis
Calcified arteries
Obesity
Procedural
Low puncture sites (SFA or profunda femoris)
Suboptimal post-procedure pressure
Some aneurysms do spontaneously thrombose. Ultrasound follow up is not completely unreasonable as a management technique where further intervention is relatively or absolutely contra-indicated, and with appropriate patient counselling regarding risks.
Small pseudoaneurysms (<2cm diameter) can usually be managed non-invasively with manual compression. The goal of manual compression is to occlude the neck of the pseudoaneurysm. This causes stasis within the sac and facilitates clotting. USS is a useful adjunct to compression.
Larger pseudoaneurysms are often amenable to occlusion via ultrasound guided thrombin injection. The average size for pseudoaneurysms amenable to thrombin injection is around 3cm diameter. Larger pseudoaneuryms can be managed with thrombin but It is only safe to perform this if manual compression during the injection is able to satisfactorily occlude the neck of the aneurysm to prevent thrombin embolising distally. Thrombin injection can be used even for patients undergoing anticoagulation with heparin or warfarin and even for higher pseudoaneurysms of the groin region, above the inguinal ligament.
For pseudoaneurysms not amenable to either of these two management strategies surgical ligation would be the next option. Endovascular stenting is not usually performed for femoral pseudoaneurysms owing to the risk of kink formation within the stent on hip flexion. Endovascular coiling is also unsuitable for femoral pseudoaneurysms as the femoral artery is an inexpendable vessel; coiling it would risk leg ischaemia.
GPT3_explain: US guided thrombin injection is the most appropriate next management for a patient with a pseudoaneurysm of the profunda femoris artery. This is because US guided thrombin injection is a minimally invasive procedure which can be used to effectively seal the aneurysm, reducing the risk of rupture and bleeding. This procedure is also less invasive than surgical ligation and is less likely to cause complications than manual compression under US guidance. Additionally, it is more effective than conservative management with repeat USS in 48 hours, as it can immediately address the aneurysm and reduce the risk of rupture.

Qn_Text: A 20-year-old man attends a urology outpatient clinic having failed initial therapies for the management of his dysuria. He is scheduled for a cystoscopy which is normal and undergoes an MRI of the pelvis. This shows a pear shaped cystic lesion posterior to the bladder. A distinct communication with the urethra is present. On the scout images the left kidney is notably absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Anatomy plays a strong role in the correct diagnosis of male genitourinary tract cysts. It is first necessary to differentiate between intraprostatic cysts and extraprostatic cysts.
  Prostatic utricle cyst (intraprostatic)
These are found in teenagers or adolescents and represent incomplete regression of the Mullerian duct system during embryological development. They are found posterior to the bladder, within the prostate, and do not extend any more superiorly than the superior most aspect of the prostate. This anatomical detail and the fact that the cyst does communicate with the prostatic urethra sets it apart from a Mullerian duct cyst on imaging. They can cause all manner of lower urinary tract symptoms and boast an association with ipsilateral renal agenesis as well as intersex disorders. On MRI they are said to have a pear shaped appearance.
  Mullerian duct cyst (intraprostatic)
These are usually found in young adult men and are also caused by incomplete regression of the Mullerian duct. They have numerous similarities with prostatic utricle cysts, although the latter is associated with other congenital anomalies whereas Mullerian duct cysts are, classically, not. Anatomically they are also posterior to the bladder however unlike prostatic utricle cysts they extend superiorly to the prostate and do not communicate with the urethra. On MRI they appear straightforwardly cystic unless complicated by infection. The shape of the cyst is said to be teardrop shaped rather than the pear shaped prostatic utricle cysts.
  Mullerian duct cyst
Prostatic utricle cyst
Age
20-40
0-20
Shape
Teardrop
Pear
Extends above prostate
Yes
No
Communicates with prostatic urethra
No
Yes
  Seminal vesicle cyst (extraprostatic)
Seminal vesicle cysts form due to stenosis or atresia of the ejaculatory ducts and can be post-infective in nature or congenital. They tend to present in adolescence due to the increase in secretions around this time. Acquired cysts are seen later on in life. The signal characteristics on MRI are variable depending on the presence or absence of haemorrhage. Anatomically it should be easy to pinpoint their location as relating to the seminal vesicles, namely posterior to the bladder and superior to the prostate. Congenital seminal vesicle cysts are associated with renal anomalies and adult polycystic kidney disease.
  Urachal cyst (extraprostatic)
The urachus is a fibrous remnant of a thin canal connecting the bladder to the umbilicus. Ordinarily it is almost imperceptible however there are four distinct anomalies which can persist into adulthood and cause symptoms.
Patency – a fistula between the bladder and the umbilicus. There is leakage of urine from the umbilicus present from birth.
Sinus – blind dilatation of the urachus at the umbilical end.
Diverticulum – communication with the dome of the bladder
Cyst – dilatation in the lower third which does not communicate with either end. These are asymptomatic unless or until the cyst becomes infected or ruptures.
Malignancy arising from the urachas, unlike most bladder cancer, tends to be adenocarcinoma. In young patients sarcomas are also seen.
  Cystic prostate cancer
Carcinoma of the prostate does not usually present as a cystic mass but the presence of haemorrhage within a cystic mass should raise the possibility of malignancy. Most prostate cancer arises from the peripheral zone and is seen as low T2 signal with restriction of diffusion. Cystic prostate cancer will return high signal on T2. The main differential diagnosis is a prostatic abscess.
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis is Urachal Cyst. This is because the MRI showed a pear-shaped cystic lesion posterior to the bladder with a distinct communication with the urethra. Additionally, the left kidney was notably absent. These symptoms are consistent with an Urachal Cyst, which is a cyst that forms from the remnants of the urachus, a tube that connects the bladder to the umbilicus in a developing fetus.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on the neck of a patient with a known head and neck cancer. There is an abnormal lymph node by the internal jugular vein. It is inferior to the hyoid bone but superior to the vocal cords. At what level is the node?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Lymph node levels of the neck are best learnt by studying a colourful diagram of the lateral view of the neck.
Essentially the boundaries are the hyoid bone, the cricoid cartilage, the anterior and posterior borders of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. If you can remember those, and the rough pattern you should be able to work out which level is being described in the exam.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3, II, because the node is inferior to the hyoid bone, which is located at the level of the second cervical vertebra (C2). Therefore, the node is at the level of the second cervical vertebra (C2), or level II.

Qn_Text: A 24-year-old patient presents with chest pain on a Saturday morning. He had spent the previous evening celebrating some exam results with his friends. He has been vomiting but is now feeling short of breath. Your A+E colleagues suspect Boerhaave syndrome. What is the most likely early radiological finding?
A: Left sided pleural effusion on CXR
B: Right sided distal oesophageal leak on gastrograffin swallow
Explanation:
Explanation:
Boerhaave syndrome
Benign oesophageal rupture can occur during foreceful vomiting and causes sudden chest pain. Most occur along the left hand wall of the oesophagus and hence initially the most common finding is a left sided pleural effusion. Fluid escapes into the pleural cavity and although aspiration may have occurred during the vomiting, consolidation develops later on, if at all. Tertiary contractions refer to non-propulsive oesophageal contractions and are a feature of achalasia. If Boerhaave syndrome is suspected the patient should not receive oral barium since it can raise a fibrotic process in the pleura. Water soluble contrast media such as gastrograffin should be used instead.
Importantly, the patients risk of aspiration must also be taken into account. If the patient has an unsafe swallow, gastrograffin should not be used as it can lead to pulmonary oedema if it enters the lungs. In such cases, low osmolar agents such as Gastromiro or Omnipaque should be used instead of Gastrograffin.
GPT3_explain: Tertiary contractions on gastrograffin swallow are the most likely early radiological finding in Boerhaave syndrome. This is because Boerhaave syndrome is a type of spontaneous esophageal rupture, and tertiary contractions are a sign of esophageal rupture on a gastrograffin swallow. They are characterized by multiple, irregular esophageal contractions that occur in the distal esophagus.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about a clinical scenario and diagnosis.

This question falls under category 3: A question about a clinical scenario and diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old lady presents with sudden onset right flank pain and bruising which occurred whilst at rest. She denies any history of trauma. Observations carried out in the Emergency department suggest haemodynamic compromise and she is rushed to the CT scanner. The CT scan demonstrates a large right sided perinephric haematoma. A 5 cm fat-dense lesion is also seen within the right kidney. Which of the following syndromes is the most accurate description of this clinical presentation? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Wunderlich syndrome
Spontaneous haemorrhage/rupture is a known complication of AMLs and is termed Wunderlich syndrome. Patients with AMLs larger than 4cm are at particularly increased risk of this. Wunderlich syndrome can occur in the context of Tuberous Sclerosis or in a patient with an isolated large AML. Although Wunderlich syndrome ismost commonly caused by an underlying AML, it can also be seen with renal cell carcinoma or vascular malformations.
Tuberous sclerosis
This condition would explain the presence of a fat containing renal lesion (AML) which is the underlying cause of the haematoma in this case, however it does not describe the main presentation of spontaneous haemorrhage. Not all patients with tuberous sclerosis have AMLs and not all of those with AMLs have large enough ones to rupture, and not all of those with large AMLs experience Wunderlich syndrome. In this question, arguably Tuberous Sclerosis is also a correct answer but in the setting of retroperitoneal haemorrhage, Wunderlich is a more correct/accurate answer.
Majewski Syndrome
This is a variant of short-rib polydactyly syndrome with no renal associations.
GPT3_explain: I chose 2 because Wunderlich Syndrome is a condition that is characterized by the sudden onset of right flank pain and bruising which occurs without any history of trauma. It is also associated with a large perinephric haematoma and a fat-dense lesion within the kidney, which are both present in this case.
Cat_Long:
3. A question requiring application of knowledge to a clinical situation.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the chest radiograph of a young adult who presented to the Emergency Department with worsening shortness of breath. He has had multiple previous admissions for a longstanding diagnosis of asthma for which he is poorly compliant with his medication. What is the LEAST likely finding on the chest radiograph? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely finding.
Complications of asthma
There is little information to go on in the vignette. The question is primarily to do with the complications of asthma.
Air trapping is a well known phenomenon in asthma and is seen as flattening of the hemi diaphragms and hypertransradiancy.
Superadded infection can complicate any respiratory condition and asthma is no exception.
ABPA is a known complication of asthma
Pneumothoraces and pneumomediastinum can complicate asthma although the incidence is actually not vastly higher than that in the general population.
  Hypersensitivity pneumonitis classically mimics asthma on a chest radiograph. In a known asthmatic this would therefore be an unusual finding compared to the common complications listed above.
GPT3_explain: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an inflammatory lung condition that is caused by an allergic reaction to inhaled particles. It is not typically associated with asthma, which is why it is the least likely finding on the chest radiograph.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: Which of the following most accurately describes a Tarlov cyst? Select one answer only.
A: Simple cystic structure closely related to the exiting S2 nerve root. Widened sacral foramina with bony scalloping
B: Ballooning of the dural sac resulting in posterior vertebral scalloping and herniation into the nerve root sleeves
C: Uncomplicated cystic formation connected to the facet joint containing synovial fluid
D: Neural tube defect with protrusion of membranes through bony defect in vertebral column
E: Hyperdense on CT causing vertebral body scalloping, dumbbell widening of the neural exit foramina
Explanation:
Explanation:
A Tarlov cyst
A tarlov cyst is the name given to dilatation of the posterior nerve root sheath. They follow CSF on all sequences and can cause significant bony scalloping.
  A synovial cyst – ‘Uncomplicated cystic formation connected to the facet joint containing synovial fluid’
Synovial cysts relate to the joint rather than the nerve. They tend to be seen in cases where the facet joints are already degenerate.
  Dural ectasia – ‘Ballooning of the dural sac resulting in posterior vertebral scalloping and herniation into the nerve root sleeves’
This is an interesting alternative diagnosis however usually occurs over more than one vertebral level. It can be associated with tarlov cysts.
  Nerve sheath tumour – ‘Hyperdense on CT causing vertebral body scalloping, dumbbell widening of the neural exit foramina’.  For example: a schwannoma.
  Meningocoele – ‘Neural tube defect with protrusion of membranes through bony defect in vertebral column’
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it accurately describes a Tarlov cyst. A Tarlov cyst is a simple cystic formation that is closely related to the exiting S2 nerve root. It is characterized by widened sacral foramina and bony scalloping.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the MRI scan of a 37-year-old lady who has a constellation of symptoms for which she is under review by neurology. Recently she has noticed a deterioration in her vision. Which of the following would be the best sequence to examine for optic atrophy? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Optic atrophy is difficult to pick up on an MRI scan unless you are specifically looking for it. On a T2 weighted coronal sequence (particularly a CISS, heavily T2 weighted sequence) scrolling through the optic nerves you may be able to appreciate that there is too much CSF surrounding the optic nerve, particularly if it is a unilateral finding.
GPT3_explain: I chose Sagittal T2 as the best sequence to examine for optic atrophy because this type of scan will provide the most detailed view of the optic nerve. The sagittal plane is the most perpendicular to the optic nerve, allowing for a more accurate evaluation of the nerve's size and shape. Additionally, the T2-weighted images will provide the highest contrast between the nerve and surrounding tissue, which is important for detecting signs of optic atrophy.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about application of knowledge, what is the best sequence to examine for optic atrophy?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the cervical spine x-rays of a 30-year-old man. There is fusion of C5/6 and in the corner of the film you notice the left scapula is small and elevated above the clavicle. Which of the following is commonly associated with this condition? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Klippel-Feil syndrome
Klippel-Feil syndrome is predominantly a segmentation anomaly which arises during foetal development and leads to cervical fusion of two or more vertebral bodies. C2-3 are most commonly involved, accounting for around half of cases. Thereafter C5-6 accounts for a further third and the remainder are made up from fusions at other levels. There are a multitude of associated features, the predominant ones of which include:
GU abnormalities (of which a third have unilateral renal agenesis) (66%)
Scoliosis > 20 degrees (50%)
Sprengel shoulder (33%)
Deafness (sensorineural) (33%)
Cervial ribs (20%)
  Yet further features of this condition, all present in under 20% of cases include:
Odontoid dysplasia
Hemivertebrae / butterfly vertebrae
Syringomyelia / diastomatomyelia
Ear anomalies (microtia, deformed ossicles etc)
Congenital heart disease (ASD or coarctation)
  Sprengel shoulder
This condition can occur in isolation as well as part of Klippel-Feil syndrome. It is (like Klippel-Feil syndrome) also often associated with renal anomalies. Sprengel shoulder is a congenital abnormality where the scapula (usually, but not exclusively, unilateral) is attached to the cervical vertebra either by a fibrous or osseous connection, and therefore fails to descend into the normal position. The result is elevation and medial rotation of the scapula, which is usually hypoplastic. The condition can be readily appreciated on a plain film although cross-sectional imaging is useful to plan surgical correction if required. If present, the osseous connection between the scapula and the spine is termed an omovertebral bar.
Holt-Oram syndrome
This syndrome is associated with numerous skeletal and cardiac malformations. It is usually evident either antenatally or in the early neonatal period. Cardiac manifestations include either ASD or VSD, tetralogy of Fallot and coarctation. Perhaps most strikingly the condition is often associated with radial ray hypoplasia often meaning the absence of one or both thumbs. An x-ray may show absence or hypoplasia of one or both radii.
GPT3_explain: Holt-Oram syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the development of the heart and arms. It is characterized by abnormalities of the upper limbs, including a small and elevated left scapula, fusion of the C5/6 vertebrae, and underdevelopment of the radius bone. This is why it is the correct answer for this question.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about problem solving, what is the solution to the problem?

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 13-year-old boy presents with epistaxis which is found to be caused by a mass lesion. Which of the following is the area most likely to be affected on imaging?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is the classic description of a juvenile angiofibroma, if the demographic hasn’t already given the answer away. They are vascular tumours arising from the soft tissues in and around the sphenopalatine fossa, classically causing erosion of the medial pterygoid plate and interventionalists have a significant role to play in their management. Other testable points are that they are supplied by the internal maxillary artery, and are seen on MRI as flow voids on T2w.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Ethmoid sinus because epistaxis is a common symptom of a mass lesion in the ethmoid sinus. The ethmoid sinus is located between the eyes and the nasal cavity and is lined with mucous membranes. These membranes can become inflamed or infected, leading to bleeding from the nose. Imaging is typically used to diagnose a mass lesion in the ethmoid sinus, so this is the area most likely to be affected.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about interpretation of imaging results.

This question falls under category 3: A question about interpretation of imaging results.

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old man presents with a painful palpable lump on the sole of his foot. Ultrasound demonstrates a 3cm well-defined, fusiform hyporeflective area arising from the plantar fascia. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is the classical description of a plantar fibroma. On MRI they are characteristically iso/ slightly low in signal on both T1 and T2 weighted sequences compared with normal muscle signal, and show variable contrast enhancement.
A foreign body would be a small echogenic structure. Melanoma metastasis would be unlikely to cause a fusiform swelling and metastasis to the plantar fascia would be unlikely. Osteochondroma and osteophytes would also be hyperechoic due to the bone/ soft tissue interface.
GPT3_explain: Plantar fibromas are the most common cause of a painful palpable lump on the sole of the foot. They are benign fibrous tumors that arise from the plantar fascia and typically appear as well-defined, fusiform hyporeflective areas on ultrasound.

Qn_Text: A prostate MRI is performed for suspected prostate malignancy. The peripheral zone returns uniform high T2 signal. The reporting radiologist suspects there may be malignancy within the transitional zone. Which of the following MRI features indicates the highest level of suspicious for a malignancy in the transitional zone? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Lenticular focus of moderate T2 hypointensity
B: Avid early enhancement with rapid lesion washout
C: Focal high b-value and corresponding low ADC signal
D: Focal low b-value and corresponding high ADC signal
Explanation:
Explanation:
The assessment of peripheral zone and central zone lesions is very different in PIRADS assessment.
Peripheral zone
Dynamic contrast enhancement is used for assessment of peripheral zone lesions only - differentiating between PIRADS 3 and 4 lesions. The highest grade of suspicion for malignancy in the peripheral zone is indicated by the presence of restricted diffusion (focal high b-value and corresponding low ADC signal), with a PIRADS 5 lesion being one that is greater than 1.5 cm.
Transitional zone
The highest grade of suspicion for transitional zone lesions is reserved for moderate T2 lesion which is lenticular or non-circumscribed and moderately T2 hypointense (PIRADS 5 >1.5 cm).
GPT3_explain: The low b-value and corresponding high ADC signal are indicative of prostate malignancy in the transitional zone. This is because malignant lesions typically have a higher water content than benign lesions, resulting in a higher ADC signal. The higher ADC signal is associated with the lower b-value, which is a measure of the strength of the magnetic field.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the interpretation of an image.

3. A question about the interpretation of an image.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old gentleman undergoes an abdominal ultrasound for suspected gallstones due to upper abdominal discomfort. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse. The liver demonstrates a smooth contour and normal echotexture, but a 3 cm focal hypoechoic lesion is identified in the right lobe of the liver. On MRI, this demonstrates early arterial enhancement and washout faster than normal liver parenchyma. The reporting radiologist identifies this as a likely Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC). What is the most likely underlying liver condition? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Usually it is the development of cirrhosis from any cause, which predisposes patients to developing Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC). HCC development in a non-cirrhotic liver is classically seen, however, in Hepatitis B positive individuals. Only a few cases of Hepatitis C related HCC have been described in a non-cirrhotic liver. The other conditions are far less commonly associated with the development of cirrhosis, tending to resolve or respond to therapy.
GPT3_explain: Hepatitis C is the most likely underlying liver condition in this case because it is a known risk factor for Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC). Intravenous drug abuse is a common way of contracting Hepatitis C, and it is the most common risk factor for HCC. Other potential causes of HCC, such as Hepatitis A, B, and Epstein-Barr Virus, are less likely in this case due to the patient's history of intravenous drug abuse. Autoimmune hepatitis is also unlikely in this case due to the presence of a focal hypoechoic lesion on ultrasound and early arterial enhancement on MRI, which are both suggestive of HCC.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the interpretation of medical images.

2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to A+E by her parents. She has severe abdominal tenderness and distension. Ultrasound demonstrates an ileocolic intussusception. Which of the following is a contraindication to performing intussusception reduction?
A: Free abdominal gas on plain film
C: Lack of bowel vascularity on colour doppler
D: Intussusception length of greater than 3 cm
Explanation:
Explanation:
Intussusception usually affects infants between the ages of 3 months and 3 years. The Ileocolic type is the most common, followed by ileo-ileocolic. It is important to consider lead points: HSP, Meckel’s diverticulum and duplication cysts are all possibilities.
Another important facet to this condition is the management of intussusception. Reduction using a fluoroscopic-guided air enema (rather than barium) reduces the risk of faecal peritonitis and is the preferred management. The risk of perforation with this method is thought to be around 0.5%. Free air on plain film and clinical peritonitis are contraindications to pneumatic reduction by air enema.
Although long intussusceptions, lack of bowel wall vascularity and an extended duration of symptoms are not favourable features (being associated with greater complication rates and poorer success rates of pneumatic reduction), they are not contra-indications; perforation is the only absolute contraindication here.
GPT3_explain: I chose 5. Symptom duration greater than 12 hours because intussusception reduction is contraindicated if the duration of the symptoms is greater than 12 hours, as the risk of ischemia and necrosis increases with time. It is important to reduce the intussusception as soon as possible to reduce the risk of complications.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical decision-making.

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old man presents with ataxia and cough headaches. His symptoms increase in severity over three weeks. He stopped smoking five years ago and uses alcohol in moderation. On examination, he has left sided cerebellar signs. Routine biochemical and haematological examinations are normal. A CT scan of the brain shows a solitary 3cm intra-axial rim enhancing mass in the left cerebellar hemisphere. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
In the adult population the most common aetiology of a solitary brain mass is metastatic disease.
GPT3_explain: Cerebellar haemangioblastoma is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms and the findings on the CT scan. The CT scan shows a solitary, rim-enhancing mass in the left cerebellar hemisphere, which is characteristic of a haemangioblastoma. Additionally, the patient's symptoms of ataxia and cough headaches are also consistent with this diagnosis.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 4-year-old boy whose parents are concerned that his stomach has become very large. There is a large mass in the left retroperitoneal space. It is heterogeneous in echotexture. The boy goes onto have a CT scan which shows displacement of the IVC and curvilinear calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Wilms tumour also known as a nephroblastoma
This is the most common abdominal mass in children under the age of 8. There are reasonably strong associations with renal anomalies, genital anomalies, aniridia and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (although the last of these also has an association with neuroblastoma). Presentation is usually with an abdominal mass and/or pain.
  10% tumour – Wilms
Calcification
Vascular invasion
Bilateral
Lung metastases
Poor histology
  On imaging the masses are usually heterogenous. Cystic areas can often be seen secondary to areas of necrosis. The claw sign occurs when there is a rim of normal renal tissue extending part of the way around the mass. A Wilms tumour is often described as enhancing but less so than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma.
  Feature
Neuroblastoma
Wilms tumour
Peak age
2 years
3-4 years
Kidney
Drooping lily sign – displaced downwards, if not invaded.
Claw sign – rim of normal renal tissue extending around the mass
Crosses midline
More common
Less common
Calcification
More common
Regular and stippled
Less common
Curvilinear and phleobliths
IVC
Encases
Displaces and/or invades
  Neuroblastoma
This is the most common solid abdominal mass in infants and second most common in children of all ages (after Wilms tumours). Most are adrenal in location, around a third develop in the retroperitoneum and a fifth are located in the posterior mediastinum. Presentation can be with abdominal pain, a mass, or a fever. Most (95%) secrete catecholamines such as VMA (vanillylmandelic acid – leads to hypertension) or VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptides – leads to watery diarrhoea). There are also a few distinct clinical syndromes which herald the presence of a neuroblastoma.
  Syndrome
Details
Blueberry muffin syndrome
Metastatic cutaneous deposits
Opsomyoclonus
Rapid jerky eye movements and myoclonic jerks of the legs. This occurs in around 2% of neuroblastoma cases but around 50% of patients with opsomyoclonus have a neuroblastoma.
Hutchinson syndrome
Limping due to bony metastases
  On imaging they appear as a very large abdominal mass with or without speckled calcification within in. The kidney can either be invaded or just displaced inferiorly, causing a ‘drooping lily’ appearance on urography (where contrast within the inferiorly displaced renal calyces has the appearance of a lily flower with its head hanging down). Neuroblastomas tend to encase large vessels such as the IVC, as opposed to displacing them as Wilms tumours are prone to doing. Staging is performed with an 123I-MIBG scan (as opposed to a 99mTc-MDP bone scan) and importantly within the staging it is actually stage IVs (disease involving the skin, bone marrow and liver) which has the best prognosis.
  Rhabdomyosarcoma
These aggressive lesions are the most common pelvic tumour for children under the age of 15 although they can be found anywhere in the body. Although histologically they are formed of skeletal muscle derivation, they do not have to be in continuity with normal skeletal muscle. They tend to appear low in reflectivity on ultrasound. On MRI they follow muscle on T1 weighted sequences, but enhance avidly with gadolinium.  They usually show invasive features and have a high propensity for metastatic spread.
  Burkitt lymphoma
The non-endemic form of Burkitt lymphoma comprises around a third of paediatric non-Hodgkin lymphoma cases. Most cases present as an abdominal mass or bowel obstruction due to the attachment of the mass to bowe. Owing to a rapid doubling time the original mass can be extremely large at the time of diagnosis. Often nodal disease is notably absent.
  Mature teratoma
Teratomas and dermoid cysts have very similar imaging characteristics despite their histological differences. Teratomas are are slow growing and usually benign. By contrast immature teratomas are malignant. The presence of fat is a strong indicator for a mature teratoma with the combination of fat, fluid and calcification being highly specific. On MRI the fat will show the usual signal dropout on gradient echo sequences. Calcification will show as low signal on T2. Malignant degeneration if it does occur, is to squamous cell carcinoma most commonly.
GPT3_explain: Wilms tumour is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common malignant abdominal tumour in children and the ultrasound scan findings are consistent with this diagnosis. The large mass in the left retroperitoneal space is heterogeneous in echotexture, and the CT scan shows displacement of the IVC and curvilinear calcification, which are both characteristic of Wilms tumour.

Qn_Text: What are the components of the Phemister triad? Select one answer only.
A: Juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, gradual reduction of the joint space
B: Marginal sclerosis, chondrocalcinosis, rapid joint space narrowing
C: Diffuse osteoporosis, effusion, gradual joint space narrowing
D: Diffuse sclerosis, marginal erosions, gradual reduction of the joint space
E: Juxta-articular osteoporosis, chondrocalcinosis, gradual reduction of the joint space
Explanation:
Explanation:
Tuberculous spondylitis also known as Pott disease
Around half of patients have no pulmonary disease and spondylitis accounts for around 5% of all infections with tuberculosis. The L1 vertebral body is the most commonly affected level but usually more than one levels is affected. Within the vertebral body it is the anterior aspect which is affected first. This is thought to be due to the subligamentous spread of the bacterium, under the anterior longitudinal ligament. The disc height is usually preserved until relatively late on in the disease which can make the condition very difficult to detect on x-ray since neither periosteal reactions nor reactive sclerosis are likely to be seen either. Calcification to the disc is common though, and virtually pathognomonic when present.
  Phemister triad
Of articular tuberculosis it is the spine which is most commonly affected however the hips and knees can also be affected. The Phemister triad describes three classical features of tuberculous arthropathy which are common to all the joints affected:
Juxta-articular osteoporosis
Marginal erosions
Gradual reduction of the joint space
Differentiating tuberculous spondylitis from pyogenic spondylitis is crucial and there are a number of features which can help.
  Tuberculous discitis
Staphylococcal discitis
Calcification (almost pathognomonic)
No calcification
Involvement of the posterior elements
Posterior elements spared
Insidious onset
More acute onset
Less loss of disc space
More loss of disc space
Gibbus deformity (angular kyphosis)
No gibbus deformity
Multiple levels involved
One level involved
GPT3_explain: I chose number 5 because it is the correct answer. The Phemister triad consists of juxta-articular osteoporosis, chondrocalcinosis, and gradual reduction of the joint space. These three components are essential for the diagnosis of osteoarthritis according to the Phemister triad.

Qn_Text: A 61-year-old man undergoes prostate MRI for further investigation of suspected prostate cancer. Which of the following MRI features indicates the highest level of suspicion for a malignancy in the peripheral zone? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Focal high b-value and corresponding low ADC signal
B: Focal low b-value and corresponding high ADC signal
C: Avid early enhancement with rapid lesion washout
Explanation:
Explanation:
The assessment of peripheral zone and central zone lesions is very different in PIRADS assessment.
Peripheral zone
Dynamic contrast enhancement is used for assessment of peripheral zone lesions only - differentiating between PIRADS 3 and 4 lesions. The highest grade of suspicion for malignancy in the peripheral zone is indicated by the presence of restricted diffusion (focal high b-value and corresponding low ADC signal), with a PIRADS 5 lesion being one that is greater than 1.5 cm.
Transitional zone
The highest grade of suspicion for transitional zone lesions is reserved for moderate T2 lesion which is lenticular or non-circumscribed and moderately T2 hypointense (PIRADS 5 >1.5 cm).
GPT3_explain: The low b-value and corresponding high ADC signal indicate a high level of suspicion for a malignancy in the peripheral zone because it suggests the presence of a highly cellular area. This is because a low b-value corresponds to a higher signal intensity, and a high ADC signal suggests a high degree of cellularity. This is a strong indicator of malignancy, as malignant tumors are typically more cellular than benign tumors.
