Qn_Text: You are reviewing the chest radiograph of a baby boy born recently. He has developed hypoxia and required admission to the neonatal unit. Which of the following diagnoses is correctly associated with the likely findings on x-ray? Select ONE answer only.
A: Meconium aspiration - coarse lung markings, hyperinflation
B: Hyaline membrane disease - granular, hyperinflated lungs
C: Transient tachypnoea of the newborn - deep sulcus sign
D: Neonatal pneumonia - prominent hila markings, effusions
Explanation:
Explanation:
Neonatal Respiratory Distress © Medical Exam Prep
    Of the five main respiratory conditions of the neonate the differential diagnosis can be narrowed based on gestational age. The presence of hyperinflation can also be useful but may not always be present where feasible so should not be used as an absolute discriminator. If present, it is useful.
  Meconium aspiration
Meconium is sticky and causes a chemical pneumonitis in the lungs, seen as patchy consolidation. In addition, small globules of meconium entering bronchi and bronchioles of a decreasing calibre act as a ball-valve mechanism and lead to air trapping; thus the lung volumes of a baby with meconium aspiration may be increased. Air bronchograms are notably absent. The typical baby in a meconium aspiration situation is post-term.
  Transient tachypnoea of the newborn (TTN)
The classical patient for TTN would be a term baby born by caesarean section to a diabetic mother. During normal vaginal delivery the compression of the baby as it descends the birth canal acts to squeeze fluid out from its lungs. This mechanism is all but absent during a caesarean section. Consequently, these babies are born with an excess of retained fluid. The CXR of an affected baby will show bilateral symmetrical air space opacification with air bronchograms, fluid in the fissures and pleural effusions. This peaks in severity at 24hrs but resolves by three days.
  Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD) also known as surfactant deficient disease (SDD)
It is to reduce the likelihood of this disease developing that a woman in pre-term labour will be offered a steroid injection. The steroids help the neonatal lungs to develop faster and increase the likelihood of their being able to produce surfactant once delivered. Where there is surfactant deficiency the alveoli collapse. The CXR will show a granular opacification throughout both lungs which progresses to bilateral ground glass opacification with air bronchograms. If exogenous surfactant is given to the baby there may be asymmetrical improvement in the appearances depending on how much reaches each lung. Of note HMD does not cause pleural effusions. Finally a normal CXR at 6hrs post delivery excludes HMD.
  Neonatal pneumothorax
Usually chest radiographs are performed with the baby lying down. The free gas in the pneumothorax rises to the superior part of the baby and therefore the classical apical contour seen in adult pneumothoraces, is lost. Instead unilateral hyperlucency may be seen and any pleural line should be regarded with extreme suspicion. A deep sulcus sign occurs when the gas collects at the anteroinferior aspect of the thoracic cavity, outlining the costophrenic angle sharply at its most inferior extent. The morbidity and mortality relating to undiagnosed neonatal pneumothorax is such that if there is any doubt further views such as a cross table lateral or a lateral decubitus view should be performed without delay.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because neonatal pneumonia is the most likely diagnosis for a baby with hypoxia who has been admitted to the neonatal unit. On the chest radiograph, the findings of neonatal pneumonia would include prominent hila markings, which are enlarged lymph nodes, and effusions, which are fluid-filled spaces in the lungs. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of neonatal pneumonia.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: The superior pancreaticoduodenal artery is a branch of which of the following arteries? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The arterial supply to duodenum is from the pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
The superior pancreaticoduodenal artery is a branch of the gastroduodenal artery (which in turn arises from the common hepatic artery of the coeliac trunk). It supplies the duodenum proximal to the entry of the bile duct (i.e. the section derived from the embryonic foregut).
The inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (which arises from the anterior surface of the aorta). It supplies the duodenum distal to the entry of the bile duct (i.e. the part derived from the embryonic midgut).
  The branches of the coeliac trunk showing the pancreaticoduodenal arteries (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2, Superior mesenteric artery, because it is the most common source of the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery. This artery branches off the superior mesenteric artery, which is a major artery that originates from the abdominal aorta and provides blood supply to the small intestine, pancreas, and other organs in the abdomen.

3. A question about problem solving, how can a problem be solved?

1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old office clerk presents with pains in both knees. There is no history of trauma. X-rays show bilateral sclerotic foci on both sides of the knee joint. On direct questioning he has also noticed symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia in the last few months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Erdheim-Chester disease
Infiltration of the appendicular skeleton by histiocytes leads to fibrosis and sclerosis which can appear striking on an x-ray. The condition is very similar to Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) and both conditions have been reported across a broad range of patient ages. Usually however LCH presents at around the age of 5-10 whereas ECD peaks in incidence at around 55 years of age. Both diseases are caused by clonal proliferations of one or more lines of histiocytes and there are different cellular markers which can help distinguish between the two diseases pathologically. There is considerable overlap in the clinical and radiological features of both diseases.
Clinically patients with ECD present with all or any of the usual histiocytosis triad of diabetes insipidus, exophthalmos and bone pain. Of these, the most prominent feature is usually bony pain.
X-rays show sclerosis in the metadiaphyseal regions in a bilateral symmetrical pattern but with sparing of the epiphyses. Corticomedullary differentiation becomes blurred and there are also multiple areas of lucency indicating the presence of lytic lesions too.
  Mastocytosis
This disease is also caused by clonal proliferation of a particular cell type however in this case it is of mast cells. Clinically patients may experience symptoms linked to histamine release from the mast cells such as flushing, sweating, diarrhoea and abdominal pains but only around a quarter of patients complain of bony pains. The skeleton can be affected by either focal lesions (usually in the spine) or with diffusely increased density. Other features such as hepatosplenomegaly, and lymph node enlargement (retroperitoneal, mesenteric, periportal) may be present too.
  Metastases
Sclerotic metastases are typical with prostate and breast cancers among others. This should always be considered as a pertinent differential diagnosis however there are not other features in this question to suggest it is correct in this case.
Sclerotic metastases:
Prostate (most common)
Breast (mixed lytic and sclerotic)
Transitional Cell Carcinoma
Lymphoma
Mucinous adenocarcinomas (colon, gastric, ovary)
Medulloblastoma
Neuroblastoma
Carcinoid
  Paget disease
Paget disease is seldom found in patients below the age of 50 but is one of the more common musculoskeletal abnormalities thereafter. It consists of polyostotic, asymmetric disordered bone remodelling where intensive osteoclastic activity leads to multiple lytic lesions before osteoblastic activity results in the formation of sclerotic bone. A variety of imaging findings can be seen with x-ray. 
Lytic phase: During the lytic phase, radiolucency with a ‘flame’ or ‘blade of grass’ shape extends along the diaphysis and osteoporosis circumscripta (large lucent areas of skull) can be found in the skull.
Mixed phase: lytic and sclerotic phenomena
Sclerotic phase: densely sclerotic bone such as the classical ‘ivory vertebra’ can be found.
  Clinically it can be an incidental asymptomatic diagnosis or can present as all or any of:
Elevated ALP with a normal calcium and phosphate
A pathological fracture – although it may be sclerotic, the bone structure is disordered and therefore weaker than normal bone.
Cranial nerve palsies – due to compression at neural foramina
Enlarging head / hat size – due to widening of the diploic spaces (referred to as the Tam O’Shanter sign, whereby the skull takes on the appearance of a the Scottish hat called the Tam O’Shanter)
High output cardiac failure – this is a rare presentation caused by markedly increased bony perfusion
Pain – in the absence of a fracture, it is usually not a painful condition per se but can co-exist with other conditions such as osteoarthritis which may be the cause of the patient’s pain
Radiologically the hallmarks are bony expansion with coarsening of the trabeculae and cortices. On a bone scan active lesions will show increased uptake due to their increased blood flow.
Sarcomatous degeneration of the affected sites into either an osteosarcoma, malignant fibrous histiocytoma or chondrosarcoma carries a poor prognosis and careful study should be made of any known lesions at each imaging opportunity. New soft tissue component formation or new lysis of previously sclerotic bone should raise suspicion.
GPT3_explain: Paget disease is a chronic metabolic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone formation. It is associated with sclerotic foci on X-rays and is a common cause of knee pain in older adults. It can also cause symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia due to its association with hyperparathyroidism.

Qn_Text: A 33-year-old lady presents a few years after a renal transplant with a left sided painful ptosis and a dilated pupil. What is the most likely pathology?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
C: Temporal arteritis with cranial nerve IV palsy
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is an association between adult polycystic kidney disease (APCKD) and berry aneurysms.
The third cranial nerve runs parallel to the posterior communicating artery and dives under the posterior cerebral artery. The association between PCOM or PCA pathology and third nerve palsy signs is a classical one from an exam perspective. Painful ptosis – think PCOM or PCA aneurysm. It will be an ipsilateral pathology because the Oculomotor nerve is post-ganglionic at this point.
Involvement of the pupil also suggests an aneurysm as the pupil is spared in ischaemic third nerve palsies.
Orbital myositis would cause a swollen levator palpebrae.
The fourth cranial nerve supplies superior oblique and would cause diplopia on downward gaze.
A Bell palsy is usually not painful.
GPT3_explain: Bell palsy is the most likely pathology in this case because it is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis and ptosis. Bell palsy is caused by a viral infection that affects the facial nerve, resulting in paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. Additionally, a dilated pupil is a common symptom of Bell palsy.

Qn_Text: A 66-year-old man presents to A+E with severe acute abdominal pains. He is well known to your hospital with a history of both atrial fibrillation and ischaemic heart disease. On examination he has diffuse abdominal tenderness but is not peritonitic. Blood tests performed in A+E show elevated inflammatory markers and a metabolic acidosis with a very high lactate. He undergoes a CT scan which shows thumbprinting of the descending colon with mucosal oedema. The caecum, small bowel and rectum appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Ischaemic colitis
Anything that compromises the vascular supply to the bowl can cause ischaemic colitis. This can be a thrombus, mechanical strangulation or a prolonged period of hypotension (most commonly encountered in the setting of an ITU patient). Mucosal hyperenhancement can be seen on CT as a consequence of increased permeability in the setting of a shocked bowel (other signs of shock include hyperenhancement of the adrenal glands and a slit like configuration to the inferior vena cava). Mucosal necrosis leads to oedema and haemorrhage with sloughing as the dead layer of cells falls away. Necrosis of the submucosal and muscularis layers leads to stricturing. Thumbprinting is a term derived from the appearances of a non-specifically oedematous bowel on a barium study. The same appearance on CT is less suggestive of the classic thumbprint indentations seen on fluoroscopy but the term is still used. Loss of integrity of the mucosa allows gas to enter the mesenteric vessels and thereby the portal venous system. Gas in the periphery of the liver is suggestive of portal venous gas (as opposed to aerobilia) and is a late sign of ischaemic bowel associated with a poor outcome.
The involvement of different areas of the bowel can give a clue as to the affected vessel. The watershed areas are those at the very fringes of supply from the different mesenteric arteries and are the first to be affected in low flow states.
Vascular territories
Watershed areas (splenic flexure and rectosigmoid junction) or the whole bowel
Hypoperfusion states
Caecum to splenic flexure
SMA
Splenic flexure to rectum
IMA
GPT3_explain: I chose number 5: Inferior Mesenteric Artery Thrombus. The CT scan findings of thumbprinting of the descending colon with mucosal oedema are consistent with a diagnosis of mesenteric ischemia, which is most commonly caused by an inferior mesenteric artery thrombus. Superior mesenteric artery thrombus and coeliac axis stricture can cause similar findings, but these are less common causes. Hypotension and internal iliac artery stricture are not likely to cause mesenteric ischemia.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old woman presents to A+E with severe left sided colicky loin-to-groin pain. She undergoes an ultrasound scan which shows left sided hydronephrosis and a hydroureter but fails to demonstrate a stone. Unfortunately the CT scanner is broken. What should you advise next?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Nuclear medicine was an extremely useful tool prior to the advent of cross sectional imaging and it is still very important for use as a problem solving tool in many cases. The key feature of nuclear medicine tests is that they are functional. In this case, in all likelihood, the patient would have received a CT KUB which would have shown a ureteric calculus. However, in patients where even a CT KUB fails to identify the cause of an apparent obstruction it is important to determine if the hydronephrosis and hydroureter really are related to an obstruction and not a feature of long-standing reflux, for example. Given the clinical scenario provided it would not be unreasonable to conclude that the patient is obstructed on the left side, and a MAG3 will be able to confirm this.
  MAG3
Dynamic scan. Images every 2 mins for approximately 20 mins.
MAG3 is a compound which has a high renal extraction rate and can be labelled with Tc99m. It provides an overview of the renal plasma flow. A normal unobstructed kidney shows an initial increase in activity over 2 minutes as the tracer reaches the kidney followed by a slow decline in activity over around 20 minutes as it is filtered. An obstructed system will show a similar initial increase but activity will then not decline. Furosemide can be given to maximise the opportunity to show flow distal to the kidney. MAG3 is a safe agent to use in patients with renal failure.
  Captopril (an ACEi) can be given to diagnose renal artery stenosis as a cause of hypertension since the activity in a patient with renal artery stenosis will decline following administration of Captopril whereas a normal kidney will retain activity.
  Post-micturition images at 20 minutes can help to show the presence of residual bladder volume.
  OIH (Hippuran) - this has largely been replaced by MAG3
  DTPA – differential agent
Dynamic scan. Images at 1.5 second intervals for the first 30 seconds then less at 5 min intervals for 30 mins.
Since DTPA is cleared only via the glomeruli it can be used to measure GFR. In a normal kidney the activity level peaks sharply followed by a decline which is initially rapid and then tapers off. As GFR worsens firstly the initial rapid decline becomes more gradual and with increasingly poor disease the initial peak then becomes diminished too. Ironically for a study used to measure GFR, DTPA is not a good agent for patients with renal failure; it can only be cleared via the glomeruli therefore if there is no glomerular filtration the agent will persist and lead to a high dose. Studies need higher doses than MAG3.
  DMSA – morphology and structure
Static scan. Image once at 2 hours.
DMSA is an excellent agent for evaluating the renal cortex. It is used a lot in the paediatric setting in the investigation of scars following pyelonephritis.
  MIBG scanning (I123-Metaiodobenzylguanidine)
This comes under the broader heading of a guanethidine analogue and can be used to pinpoint catecholamine producing tumours such as phaeochromocytomas or other paragangliomas. The scan can be used to locate an extra-adrenal phaeochromocytoma. The tracer is also taken up by neuroblastomas, carcinoid tumours and medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.
If the CT scan shows morphologically normal adrenal glands then an MRI scan is unlikely to be of any further benefit. A dedicated MRI scan of the adrenal glands with in and out of phase sequences might be useful in the setting of an indeterminate mass; if there is signal dropout within the mass it is likely to be an adenoma.
An adrenal biopsy should 'never' be performed for a suspected phaeochromocytoma. The risk is of provoking catecholamine release and triggering extreme hypertension or a cardiac arrhythmia.
GPT3_explain: Technetium-99m DMSA is the imaging test of choice for evaluating hydronephrosis and hydroureter. It is a non-invasive imaging test that can be used to determine the cause of the patient's condition, such as a blockage, an obstruction, or a congenital anomaly. It can also be used to monitor the effectiveness of treatment.

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by his worried wife after becoming unwell at home. He has neurological signs and an MRI spine is requested which shows abnormalities within the spinal cord. You suspect he may have multiple sclerosis. Which of the following is LEAST consistent with multiple sclerosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
C: High T2 signal affecting 1-2 vertebral levels
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is LEAST consistent with multiple sclerosis.
  Demyelination
Demyelination can occur due to multiple sclerosis, ADEM or as an idiopathic process.
Acute idiopathic transverse myelitis is a specific diagnosis of exclusion. There is inflammation of the spinal cord leading to bilateral motor, sensory and autonomic dysfunction. On imaging there is expansion of the central portion of the cord extending over multiple vertebral levels. The inflamed portion returns high signal on T2 weighted sequences. This occurs most commonly in the thoracic spine and importantly, should involve at least two thirds of the cross-sectional area of the cord at the affected level. This is in contrast to a multiple sclerosis plaque which involves under half of the cross-sectional area of the cord.
Multiple sclerosis can affect the spinal cord. Lesions tend to be smaller usually confined to 1-2 vertebral levels and affecting less than half of the cross-sectional area of the cord. There may be mild focal expansion of the cord, but this is a far less prominent feature than it is with idiopathic transverse myelitis. 90% of patients will have other intracranial lesions. The lesions of MS also return high T2 signal, like their intracranial counterparts. The cervical cord is most commonly affected. Gray matter can be affected but it is white matter plaques which are by far the dominant feature, thus 'sparing' of the gray matter is often used to distinguish MS from ADEM.
ADEM (acute disseminated encephalomyelitis) is an autoimmune condition which occurs days-weeks following a viral infection. It largely affects the white matter of the brain, but the spinal cord can also be affected. Gray matter, particularly the basal ganglia are also often involved. It can occur at any age, but it is usually young children who are affected. Patients usually respond very well to steroid therapy and fortunately, most (90%) cases resolve without any residual deficit. On imaging, the affected areas return high T2 signal.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because high T2 signal affecting 1-2 vertebral levels is not consistent with multiple sclerosis. Multiple sclerosis is typically associated with lesions that involve multiple vertebral levels and parts of the brain and spinal cord.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old man presents with a persistent cough. He also complains of pain in his fingertips. A mass is seen on his CXR so he undergoes a CT chest which shows a well-demarcated pleural based lesion of 5cm which enhances avidly with contrast. No effusions or lymph node enlargement is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Pleural fibroma 
Pleural fibromas are benign fibrous tumours. Unlike their malignant counterpart, the malignant mesothelioma, pleural fibromas do not have an association with prior asbestos exposure. Pleural fibromas tend to be asymptomatic unless large and causing symptoms related to mass effect. There is however a reasonably strong association with hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy. 
On CT the tumours are smooth with contrast enhancement. If seen on a CXR, the presence of an obtuse angle between the bulk of the mass and the chest wall strongly suggests a pleural mass (as opposed to a parenchymal one). Some fibromas can be pedunculated. The presence of haemorrhage or necrosis raises the suspicion of malignancy and although these tumours themselves are benign, around a third of them undergo malignant transformation. Surgical excision, therefore, is the usual management approach.
  Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy (HPOA)
In essence this is a paraneoplastic phenomenon although it can be found in many non-neoplastic circumstances. Subperiosteal new bone formation is seen as a lamellar periosteal reaction on imaging. HPOA is usually described in the distal phalanges in association with clubbing but does also occur in the rest of the appendicular skeleton. Clinically the patients experience a burning pain with swelling and stiffness of any of the affected joints.
HPOA can be caused by the presence of a bronchogenic carcinoma: this is a common scenario of medical school finals exams. Pleural fibromas are also a known cause. Extra-pulmonary causes are less common but do happen.
GPT3_explain: Malignant mesothelioma is the most likely diagnosis in this case due to the patient's age and the presence of a pleural based lesion that is well-demarcated and enhances avidly with contrast. This is classic for malignant mesothelioma, which is most commonly seen in people who have been exposed to asbestos. Sarcoidosis, brown tumour, pleural fibroma, and acromegaly are not typically associated with this presentation.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of APCKD presents to A and E with a ‘worst ever’ headache. She undergoes a CT scan which shows a small subarachnoid haemorrhage. She is managed conservatively and ten days later undergoes an MRI scan for follow up. What will the likely appearance of the subarachnoid haemorrhage be now?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Bright on T1 and bright on T2
B: Bright on T1 and dark on T2
C: Dark on T1 and bright on T2
D: Dark on T1 and dark on T2
E: Isointense on T1 and bright on T2
Explanation:
Explanation:
This question is to do with the imaging characteristics of blood within the brain. We can think of the intracranial space as a closed box as far as oxygen tensions go which means that blood degrades in a predictable fashion and therefore has predictable appearances on T1 and T2 according to the changes in the haemoglobin molecule. There are a few different methods to help remember the changes in appearance, one of which is the table below:
  Timeframe
Name
Haemoglobin
T1
T2
Mnemonic
hours
Hyperacute
  Iso
Bright
→ IBBY
0-2d
Acute
Intracellular deoxyHb
Dark
Dark
→IDDY
3-7d
Early subacute
Intracellular metHb
Bright
Dark
→BIDDY
8-30d
Late subacute
Extracellular metHb
Bright
Bright
→BABY
>30d
Chronic
Intracellular haemosiderin
Dark
Dark rim
→DODO
  In real life and for the 2b exam the important distinction is around the subacute stages.
In that case, by and large, if it is bright on T1 it is subacute and T2 then decides if it is early or late subacute. The timeframes given are also important and can form the basis of 2a exam questions.
  Of the other answers provided therefore:
Bright on T1 and dark on T2 = Early subacute
Dark on T1 and bright on T2 = Chronic
Dark on T1 and dark on T2 = Acute
Isointense on T1 and bright on T2 = Hyperacute
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 2. Dark on T1 and bright on T2. This is because subarachnoid hemorrhages usually appear as dark on T1-weighted images and bright on T2-weighted images due to the high protein content of the blood. Over time, the blood will become more organized and will eventually appear iso-intense on T1-weighted images.

Qn_Text: A 12-year-old boy sustains a head injury with loss of consciousness and is found to have an extra-axial collection on CT. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The classic presentation of an extradural haemorrhage is with an initial head injury causing transient loss of consciousness.
GPT3_explain: Subdural haematoma is the most likely diagnosis in this case because the patient is a 12-year-old boy who sustained a head injury with loss of consciousness, and an extra-axial collection was found on CT. Subdural haematomas occur when a vein is torn between the brain and the dura, causing blood to accumulate in the space between them. This type of head injury is most common in young children and is usually caused by a traumatic event such as a fall or a blow to the head.

Qn_Text: A 53-year-old woman presents to her GP with painless lump in her right cheek region. Although it has been there for 10 months she reports it to be gradually increasing in size, and now measures 1.5cm. She would like it removed before her son’s wedding. On MRI it shows low intensity on T1, and high on T2 with multicystic appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Pleomorphic adenoma is the 80% condition. 80% are in found in the parotid gland, 80% of those are in the superficial lobe. Overall 80% are benign. They are slow growing and usually present as a painless lump. They show low T1 signal and high T2 signal on MRI – think of them as cystic in this regard although their mucoid matrix can give rise to hyperintense areas centrally.
A Warthin tumour is a differential diagnosis for a painless parotid lump but has an association with smokers. Different sources describe different imaging characteristics. A Warthin tumour usually presents as bilateral asymptomatic masses or possibly multiple unilateral masses.
Adenoid cystic carcinoma although also a slow growing process is far more common in the minor salivary glands than in the parotid. A particularly salient feature of this tumour is its propensity for peri-neural spread with paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal nerve seen as a classical feature.
GPT3_explain: I chose Pleomorphic adenoma because it is the most common cause of a painless, slowly growing, well-defined mass in the cheek region. It is a benign tumor that typically has low intensity on T1 and high intensity on T2 with a multicystic appearance, which is what was seen in the MRI of the patient.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the HRCT of a 64-year-old man. He has been experiencing recurrent tachycardia, but this is well controlled on regular medication. The CT shows high attenuation in the liver and bilateral changes in the lower lobes of the lungs. What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Amiodarone therapy
Amiodarone is an anti-arrhythmic drug which contains iodine (am-IOD-arone). Consequently, as it accumulates in the liver, it can cause significant increase in density to the liver on a CT scan.
Around 10% of patients taking Amiodarone can develop lung disease from it. These patients are usually older than 60 and have been taking Amiodarone for around 2-6 months. On an HRCT scan ground glass opacities, reticulations and areas of consolidation can be seen. The constellation of lung changes seen represent a kind of non-specific interstitial pneumonitis as well as an organising pneumonia type of pattern (NSIP and COP).
Around half of patients can develop pleural effusions.
GPT3_explain: The single most likely diagnosis is Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF). IPF is a progressive lung disease characterized by scarring of the lung tissue, which can lead to high attenuation in the liver and bilateral changes in the lower lobes of the lungs. It is more common in people over the age of 50 and is not typically caused by other underlying conditions, such as heart failure or drug-induced lung disease.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: An 82-year-old man attends his GP surgery for straightforward smoking cessation advice. The astute nurse practitioner notices he has bulbous distension at the fingertips with bending of the nails. Plain films demonstrate periosteal reaction affecting the distal phalanges of both hands. No underlying bone lesion can be seen on the plain films. What should the radiologist advise?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy (HPOA)
In essence this is a paraneoplastic phenomenon although it can be found in many non-neoplastic circumstances. Subperiosteal new bone formation is seen as a lamellar periosteal reaction on imaging. HPOA is usually described in the distal phalanges in association with clubbing but does also occur in the rest of the appendicular skeleton. Clinically the patient may experience a burning pain with swelling and stiffness of any of the affected joints.
HPOA can be caused by the presence of a bronchogenic carcinoma: this is a common scenario of medical school finals MCQs. Pleural fibromas are also a known cause. Extra-pulmonary causes are less common but do happen.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because ultrasound scans (USS) are the most effective imaging modality for assessing soft tissue structures such as the distal phalanges of the hands. USS can detect any underlying bone lesions or soft tissue swelling that may be causing the symptoms the patient is experiencing. It is also non-invasive and can be done quickly, making it the most appropriate imaging modality in this case.

3. A question about management, what is the best course of action?

This question falls under the category of a question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 3-year-old boy. The right kidney is grossly abnormal with a mass in the upper pole. You suspect the patient has a multilocular cystic nephroma. Which of the following features would NOT be consistent with this diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which feature is NOT consistent with the diagnosis.
Multilocular cystic nephroma
There were previuosly thought to be two age peaks for this tumour; one at around age 4 which affects mostly boys and one at around age 40 which affects mostly women however more recently immunohistochemical and genetic differences between the tumours affecting each age group have been uncovered. Nevertheless, the radiological features of the two tumour types remain similar. In young boys the most common presentation is of a painless abdominal mass with or without other features such as haematuria and urinary tract infections. On ultrasound there will be a mass of cysts but importantly they will be surrounded by a thick fibrous capsule. Protrusion into the renal pelvis is also a key finding, but this is also seen in some Wilms tumours. There shouldn't be a solid component to this mass but enhancement of the septae separating the cysts may be seen on cross-sectional imaging.
  Renal masses by age
Neonate:
Multicystic dysplastic kidney (second most common neonatal renal mass)
Mesoblastic nephroma (most common SOLID neonatal renal mass)
Nephroblastomatosis (can be a precursor to Wilms tumour)
  Pre-school:
Multilocular cystic nephroma (affects boys, slightly younger than Wilms)
Wilms tumour (most common SOLID mass of childhood)
Lymphoma (can affect teenagers and adults as well)
GPT3_explain: The age of the patient is not consistent with a multilocular cystic nephroma, as this type of tumor is typically seen in children under the age of 10. The other features listed are consistent with a multilocular cystic nephroma, such as the presence of a solid component, the presence of a thick fibrous capsule, and the involvement of the renal pelvis. Additionally, male gender is also a risk factor for this type of tumor.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old man presents with diarrhoea and other symptoms suggestive of malabsorption. A small bowel follow through show thickened jejunal folds with fine micronodularity. There are also some sclerotic bony lesions are also noted on the control film. Which of the following would best fit with these findings?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Fold thickness
Much is made on barium examinations, of the thickness of the folds and whether there is any nodularity. Such features can be helpful in teasing apart the possible diagnoses in similar cases.
Coeliac disease – dilatation without increase in fold thickness
Scleroderma – dilatation without loss of valvulae conniventes, prolonged transit time
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome – dilatation of the proximal small bowel due to hypersecretion
Small bowel lymphoma – fold thickening and lymph node enlargement
Mastocytosis – nodular fold thickening with sclerotic bone lesions
Crohn disease – nodular fold thickening
Whipple disease – thickened folds (+/- microndularity) without dilatation, with normal transit time
  Mastocytosis
Mast cells store histamine (among other things). Where they exist in excess the resultant symptoms fit with excess histamine release. Patients complain of nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, hypotension, flushing and abdominal pain. Asthma-type symptoms can also occur. On imaging hepatosplenomegaly and lymph node enlargement are common. The walls of the small bowel become thickened and malabsorption occurs too. Mastocytosis is also a cause of bony sclerosis.
Causes of bony sclerosis
Metabolic
Hyperthyroidism
Hyperparathyroidism
Congenital
Pyknodysostosis
Osteopetrosis
Malignant
Lymphoma
Leukaemia
Haematological
Sickle cell disease
Myelofibrosis
Mastocytosis
Other
Fluorosis
Paget disease
  Eosinophilic enteropathy
This is a rare condition caused by infiltration of eosinophils into the wall of the small bowel. Patients often suffer from food allergies and experience multiple attacks of abdominal pain, diarrhoea and vomiting in a relapsing/remitting pattern. Blood eosinophil levels are usually raised. On imaging the folds of the small bowel can appear thickened.
Differential diagnosis for lymph nodes of low attenuation
Coeliac disease – cavitating mesenteric lymph node syndrome
Tuberculosis
Whipple disease
Lymphoma
Necrotic metastases
  Coeliac disease
Luminal sensitivity to gluten leads to autoimmune mediated atrophy of villi within the small bowel. Iron deficiency anaemia, malabsorption and deficiency of the fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K) result. Classically on imaging there is jejunisation of the ileum (ie an increased number of ileal folds and a decreased number of jejunal folds) which is a reasonably specific sign to coeliac disease. Importantly however the fold thickness is not increased, in contrast to many of the possible differential diagnoses. On historic fluoroscopic examinations flocculation, segmentation are supposed to be typical and result from hypersecretion of fluid however modern barium preparations are less susceptible to these effects. The moulage sign (complete loss of jejunal folds such that the bowel wall appears smooth) is also quoted. A rare complication is cavitating mesenteric lymph node syndrome where lymph nodes within the small bowel mesentry show low attenuation on CT and characteristically have fat-fluid levels. In such cases the spleen may also be atrophic.
  Scleroderma
Scleroderma is a multi-system connective tissue disease leading to fibrosis and loss of smooth muscle. In the gastrointestinal system this leads to the hidebound sign (similar but different to stacked coin sign which is seen in intramural haematoma where the folds are thickened) where, despite being dilated in calibre, the small bowel still retains the valvulae conniventes which would otherwise be effaced. This is thought to result from fibrosis of the longitudinal layer causing foreshortening along the long axis. In the small bowel there can also be the formation of square-shaped broad-based sacculations (true-diverticulae because they involve all layers of the bowel wall) on the mesenteric border of the bowel is seen owing to uneven atrophy of the smooth muscle there. A prolonged transit time would be ususal. Pseudosacculations (wide-mouthed diverticulae) are found in the colon but this time on the antimesenteric border. (The *only* anti-mesenteric diverticulum of the small bowel is a Meckel's diverticulum.)
  Small bowel lymphoma
Malignancies of the small bowel are rare but lymphoma is the most common of these. Coeliac disease, infection with H. Pylori and AIDs both predispose patients to developing small bowel lymphoma. Perhaps surprisingly patients do not present with obstruction even when the tumour burden is large, similarly neoplastic perforation is not common. Instead patients present with insidious symptoms or haemorrhage. On imaging there is (sometimes extensive) thickening of the bowel wall, often with associated lymph node enlargement.
GPT3_explain: Coeliac disease is the best fit with these findings because it is a condition caused by an autoimmune reaction to gluten, which results in damage to the small intestine. This damage can cause thickening of the jejunal folds and fine micronodularity, as well as sclerotic bony lesions on the control film.

Qn_Text: Which of the following does NOT form part of the portal triad? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The liver lobule is the architectural building block of the liver. Each lobule is approximately hexagonally shaped and consists of plates of hepatocytes radiating outwards from a central vein. The central vein joins to the hepatic vein to drain blood from the liver.
  Running along each corner of the lobule is the portal triad, which consists of the following three structures:
Hepatic artery
Hepatic portal vein
Bile duct
  The portal triad also contains a branch of the vagus nerve (parasympathetic fibres) and lymphatic vessels.
  Between the hepatocyte plates are the liver sinusoids. These are enlarged capillaries through which blood from the hepatic arteries and hepatic portal vein enter into the portal triads before subsequently draining to into the central vein.
      Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of OpenStax College CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because the branch of the vagus nerve does not form part of the portal triad. The portal triad consists of the hepatic artery, the hepatic portal vein, and the bile duct.

3. Multiple choice.

3. Multiple Choice.

Qn_Text: A 48-year-old woman comes to your interventional department for drainage of a diverticular abscess. 5mls of 1% lignocaine is infiltrated and allowed to take effect but the patient continues to complain of pain. How much more lignocaine can safely be given after this assuming the patient is of average weight? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The maximum dose of lignocaine is 3mg/kg.
The average weight of an adult is 70kg for men and 65kg for women giving doses of 210mg or 195mg respectively (i.e. around 200mg).
This relates to 19.5ml of 1% total or 9.75ml of 2%. She has already had 5ml of 1% so there is 14.5ml of 1% left available to give.
GPT3_explain: Lignocaine is an anesthetic that is used to provide pain relief. The maximum safe dose of lignocaine is 4mg/kg. Assuming the patient is of average weight (around 70kg), then the maximum safe dose of lignocaine would be 280mg (4mg/kg x 70kg). Since 1% lignocaine contains 10mg/ml, the maximum safe dose of lignocaine would be 28mls (280mg/10mg/ml). Since the patient has already received 5mls of 1% lignocaine, they can safely receive an additional 10mls, for a total of 15mls.

Qn_Text: You are reporting a CT scan on a baby who had a renal mass discovered on ultrasound. The CT shows it to be a well-defined mass. You suspect this to be a mesoblastic nephroma. Which of the following features would NOT support this diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
B: No involvement of the renal pelvis
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer would NOT support the diagnosis.
Mesoblastic nephroma
This is the most common solid mass in a neonate and 90% of them are diagnosed within the first year of life. Presentation is usually as an abdominal mass. On ultrasound there will be a large hypoechoic renal mass which cannot clearly be separated from the normal renal parenchyma. Cystic spaces can be present due to necrosis. Pertinent negative imaging features of note are the lack of invasion into the collecting system and lack of venous invasion, the latter in particular helps to differentiate it from a Wilms tumour. Both mesoblastic nephroma and nephroblastomatosis show less enhancement post-contrast than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma. Nephroblastomatosis consists of cystic spaces whereas a mesoblastic nephroma is a solid mass which may or may not have cystic spaces.
  Renal masses by age
Neonate:
Multicystic dysplastic kidney (second most common neonatal renal mass)
Mesoblastic nephroma (most common SOLID neonatal renal mass)
Nephroblastomatosis (can be a precursor to Wilms tumour)
  Pre-school:
Multilocular cystic nephroma (affects boys, slightly younger than Wilms)
Wilms tumour (most common SOLID mass of childhood)
Lymphoma (can affect teenagers and adults as well)
GPT3_explain: Mesoblastic nephroma is a type of kidney tumor that is most commonly seen in infants younger than one year. Therefore, age >1 year would not support a diagnosis of mesoblastic nephroma. Other features that would support a diagnosis of mesoblastic nephroma include a well-defined mass, no involvement of the renal pelvis, poor enhancement, and cystic spaces.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old female patient with a heavy smoking history is found to have numerous cystic lung lesions in the upper lobes. The lung volumes are preserved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Histiocytosis (also known as Langerhans cell histiocytosis - LCH)
There are three separate forms of this disease:
Eosinophilic granuloma (70%) – a limited version confined to the skeleton in children or young adults. Clinically presents as fever, raised WCC and ESR with painful bony lesions. In the skull these have a typical ‘beveled edge’ or ‘hole within a hole’ appearance or can be seen as a ‘button sequestrum’. In the spine it is one of the main causes of vertebra plana.
Hand-Schüller-Christian Disease (20%) – classically a triad of destructive bony lesions, diabetes insipidus and exophthalmos. In a quarter of these patients the lungs are involved with cyst formation and spontaneous pneumothoraces possible. Nodule formation, fibrosis and honeycombing is also seen.
Letterer-Siwe Disease (10%) – a fulminant multi-organ variant affecting very young infants
  There is a strong association with smoking for patients who develop pulmonary features of LCH. Heavy smoking causes an accumulation of Langerhans cells and hence, as with other inspiration-related lung diseases, there is a predilection for the upper zones. The Langerhans cells can collect with other cells and become small granulomas seen as small lung nodules. Despite being a type of fibrotic lung disease the lung volumes can be increased (if not normal). Small lung cysts form and there is a risk of spontaneous pneumothorax. There is usually sparing of the costophrenic angles which can be a key finding..
  Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
LAM can go misdiagnosed for many years as emphysema. It occurs exclusively in non-smoking women of childbearing age and quite often a history of spontaneous pneumothorax is given. Radiologically there are numerous small cystic spaces surrounded by normal lung. Nodule formation is not a typical feature, neither is bronchial wall thickening. A chylous pleural effusion (negative Hounsfield units) is reasonably specific. The main differential diagnosis would be histiocytosis which tends to be associated with smoking, classically spares the costophrenic angles and gives small nodules but both can present with spontaneous pneumothorax and give small cysts. The lung volumes in LAM will remain normal whereas they can be increased in Histiocytosis (surprisingly for a fibrotic lung disease).
  Emphysema
Many cystic lung diseases are often misdiagnosed initially as emphysema, largely due to the population prevalence of emphysema. Common things are common.
True lung cysts however have a perceptible wall whereas emphysematous spaces within lung tissue does not.
  Centrilobular emphysema – Caused by smoking. enlargement of the respiratory bronchiole, destruction of the alveolar septa, surrounded by normal lung, distal alveoli are spared. Affects the apical segments of each lobe due to higher ventilation perfusion ratios.
Panacinar emphysema – Caused by alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency. Affects the whole lung with greater severity seen at the bases where there is greater blood flow. Uniform lung destruction.
Paraseptal emphysema – characteristically subpleural. Associated with bullous formation and spontaneous pneumothorax.
  Respiratory Bronchiolitis Interstitial Lung disease (RBILD)
This condition is heavily associated with smoking and can be seen as centrilobular nodules with ground glass opacification – in an exam question setting therefore, look for this trio of findings (heavy smoking + ground glass opacification + centrilobular nodules). Appearances are often very similar to desquamative interstitial pneumonia. Patients can be relatively young.
  Neurofibromatosis
Technically neurofibromatosis (type I) is included in the differential diagnosis for lung cysts (particularly when apical) however the rest of the information provided is insufficient to make this the most likely answer here.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a rare lung disease that primarily affects women of childbearing age and is characterized by cystic lung lesions in the upper lobes, as well as preserved lung volumes. It is often associated with heavy smoking, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Qn_Text: A 12-day-old baby girl with a known VSD has a chest radiograph due to increasing difficulty in breathing. A well-defined segment of increased opacity is demonstrated medially in the left lower zone. She later undergoes cross-sectional imaging which demonstrates a feeding artery arising from the aorta. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Exam questions are often frustrating in that they withhold information that would be readily available to you if you were viewing the scan yourself. For example, if viewing the CT of this abnormality, you would readily assess for the venous drainage pathway which would solve the dilemma.
The answer is extralobar pulmonary sequestration. The presentation for intralobar sequestration is usually in an older child who gets recurrent infections. Extralobar pulmonary sequestration is often seen in neonates and is associated with congenital heart disease. Congenital Lobar Overinflation (CLO - Previously called Congenital Lobar Emphysema) usually affects the upper lobe and would not have systemic arterial supply. Neither would Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation (CCAM). CCAM has no lobar predominance.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because intralobar pulmonary sequestration is a congenital condition that is characterized by a segment of the lung that is supplied by an artery from the aorta, and is not connected to the normal tracheobronchial tree. The chest radiograph in this case demonstrated a well-defined segment of increased opacity in the left lower zone, which is consistent with intralobar pulmonary sequestration. The cross-sectional imaging further supported this diagnosis by demonstrating a feeding artery arising from the aorta.
Cat_Long: This question falls under the category of a question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old man with Marfan syndrome develops sudden onset, severe chest pain. A CT scan is performed, which reveals a diagnosis of aortic dissection. Which SINGLE statement regarding the aorta is true?
A: It runs through a common pericardial sheath with the pulmonary trunk
B: The posterior aortic sinus gives rise to the right coronary artery
C: The aortic arch passes beneath the left main bronchus
D: It initially lies anterior to the pulmonary trunk
E: Its first major branch is the left subclavian artery
Explanation:
Explanation:
The aorta receives oxygenated blood from the lungs and delivers it to the body. It can be divided into three parts:
The ascending aorta
The arch of the aorta
The descending aorta
  The ascending aorta commences at the opening of the aortic valve in the left ventricle of the heart. It runs through a common pericardial sheath with the pulmonary trunk. The ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk twist around each other, with the aorta initially lying posterior to the pulmonary trunk, before twisting to the right and lying anteriorly to it.
  At the root of the ascending aorta, the lumen contains three aortic sinuses. The left aortic sinus contains the origin of the left coronary artery and the right aortic sinus contains the right coronary artery. Together these two arteries supply the heart. The third sinus, which is called the posterior aortic sinus, does not give rise to a coronary artery.
  The aortic arch commences at the point of the pericardial reflection on the aorta, which is posterior to the manubriosternal joint at the level of the second costal cartilage. It passes posterior and to the left, over the left main bronchus and ends at the left side of the body of the 4th thoracic vertebra. Its highest level is the mid point of the manubrium sterni and it is at this level that its three main branches arise:
Brachiocephalic artery, which supplies blood to the brain, head, and right side of the thorax
Left common carotid artery, which supplies blood to the left side of the head and neck
Left subclavian artery, which supplies blood to the left side of the thorax
  The descending aorta commences at the end of the arch of the aorta, which is at the level of the intervertebral disc between the 4th and 5th thoracic vertebrae. The descending aorta, in turn, becomes then thoracic and abdominal aorta.
  The aorta and its three main branches
GPT3_explain: I chose number 5 because the left subclavian artery is the first major branch of the aorta. It branches off of the aortic arch and supplies blood to the left arm. The posterior aortic sinus gives rise to the left coronary artery, the aortic arch passes beneath the right main bronchus, and it runs through a common pericardial sheath with the pulmonary trunk, but these are not the first major branches of the aorta.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old lady is involved in an RTA. She is stabilised at the scene and evacuated via helicopter to the trauma centre where she undergoes an immediate trauma CT. This shows, among lesser injuries, that the left kidney has sustained significant trauma. Which of the following on CT would indicate the most severe renal injury?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
B: Subcapsular haematoma of the left kidney
D: Laceration involving the left renal pelvis
Explanation:
Explanation:
The priorities as far as surgery are concerned are:
Haemostasis
Preserving renal viability
Any injury which threatens either of these is an indication for urgent intervention. A vascular pedicle injury provides a significant threat to the viability of the kidney.
Traumatic injuries to the kidneys are graded according to the depth of parenchymal damage.
  Grade I
Subcapsular haematoma, no laceration
Grade II
<1 cm deep laceration, not involving collecting system (ie no free urine), retroperitoneal renal haematoma
Grade III
>1 cm deep laceration, not involving collecting system
Grade IV
Laceration involving renal pelvis, vascular injury with contained haemorrhage, segmental infarction, expanding haematoma causing renal compression
Grade V
Shattered kidney, vascular avulsion.
Bilateral injuries
Add one grade (i.e bilateral Grade II injuries is a Grade III injury overall).
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3 because a left retroperitoneal haematoma is indicative of the most severe renal injury. This type of haematoma is usually caused by a significant blunt force trauma to the kidney, and it can cause significant damage to the organ, including bleeding, organ rupture, and tissue death. It can also lead to long-term complications, such as infection and organ failure.

Qn_Text: A 60-year-old woman presents with urethral bleeding. She undergoes a CT scan of her abdomen and pelvis with a delayed excretory phase. The CT scan is reported as normal but cystoscopy reveals a urethral mass. Biopsy and histology reveals it is a malignant lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
C: Adenocarcinoma of the gland of Skene
Explanation:
Explanation:
Malignant urethral lesions usually present in the 6th-7th decades and are more common in women than men. Unlike the rest of the urinary tract, where transitional cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy, in the urethra, squamous cell cancer makes up around 70% of malignancy.
GPT3_explain: Transitional cell carcinoma is the most likely diagnosis for a malignant urethral lesion in a 60-year-old woman. Transitional cell carcinoma is the most common type of urethral cancer and is often seen in older women. It is a type of cancer that starts in the cells that line the bladder and urethra. The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with a delayed excretory phase would be normal in this case, as the cancer would not be visible on a CT scan until it has spread to other organs. Cystoscopy is necessary to detect the presence of a urethral mass, which can then be biopsied and histologically confirmed to be a malignant lesion.

Qn_Text: An athletic 14-year-old boy is taken to A+E by his mum after developing a painful right hip. An x-ray demonstrates an irregular shaped bone adjacent to the anterior inferior iliac spine. The avulsion of which muscle is most likely to have caused this injury?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Apophyseal injuries (avulsion fractures) are common in adolescents because the tendons are stronger than the secondary ossification centres. By definition they occur in the unfused skeleton.
Other avulsion fractures do occur in children and adults alike but those in the table all take place at secondary ossification centres around the pelvis.
Of note, in an adult the avulsion of the lesser trochanter suggests a metastasis, not a musculoskeletal injury.
Apophyseal injuries
ASIS
Sartorius
AIIS
Rectus femoris (straight head)
Pubic ramus
Adductors, gracilis
Lesser trochanter
Iliopsoas
Ischial tuberosity
Hamstrings
GPT3_explain: The iliopsoas muscle is the most likely cause of the injury because it is the muscle most associated with hip flexion and is located in the anterior inferior iliac spine. This means that an avulsion of the iliopsoas muscle would result in an irregular shaped bone adjacent to the anterior inferior iliac spine, as seen in the x-ray.

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old woman presents with an uncomfortable swelling at the back of her right knee. On examination you palpate a round, smooth, fluctuant mass within the popliteal fossa. An ultrasound scan confirms that she has a Baker's cyst. Which of the following muscles forms the inferolateral border of the popliteal fossa? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The popliteal fossa is a diamond shaped depression situated at the back of the knee joint. It acts as the main conduit for the neurovascular structures entering and leaving the leg.
  The borders of the popliteal fossa are:
Superomedial border: semimembranosus
Superolateral border: biceps femoris
Inferomedial border: medial head of gastrocnemius
Inferolateral border: lateral head of gastrocnemius and plantaris
  The roof of the popliteal fossa is formed by (from superficial to deep):
Skin
Superficial fascia
Deep (popliteal) fascia
  The floor of the popliteal fossa is formed by:
Popliteal surface of the femur
Capsule of the knee joint
Fascia covering the popliteus muscle
  The contents of the popliteal fossa (from medial to lateral) are:
Popliteal artery
Popliteal vein
Tibial nerve
Common peroneal nerve
  The tibial and common peroneal nerves are the most superficial of the contents of the popliteal fossa. The deepest structure is the popliteal artery. The small saphenous vein pierces the deep fascia to enter the popliteal fossa. The popliteal lymph nodes surround the vessels.
    The popliteal fossa and its contents, with the popliteal lymph nodes in blue (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3 because the medial head of the gastrocnemius is the muscle that forms the inferolateral border of the popliteal fossa. The popliteal fossa is a triangular space located at the back of the knee and is bordered by the medial head of the gastrocnemius, the biceps femoris, and the semimembranosus and semitendinosus muscles. The plantaris muscle is not a border of the popliteal fossa.
