Qn_Text: A 49-year-old woman with obstructive jaundice undergoes an MRCP. There is a smooth stricture in the common hepatic duct with duct dilatation and extrinsic compression from round filling defect in cystic duct. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Mirizzi syndrome
Mirizzi syndrome can present as cholecystitis and occurs when the common hepatic duct is obstructed by the mechanical pressure of a stone within the cystic duct. It follows that patients whose cystic duct happens to insert low in the course of the common hepatic duct are predisposed to this condition.
  Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
Although benign in nature PSC can wreak havoc for patients unfortunate enough to develop it. It is twice as common in men as in women and 70% of patients have a history of inflammatory bowel disease. Bile duct strictures form (particularly at the bifurcation/confluence of ducts) and lead to an obstructive jaundice picture. In between strictures there is dilatation and the combination of the two leads to a string of beads type appearance. The appearance on ERCP or MRCP in some patients can also resemble a tree in winter with pruning of the upstream branches. Outpouchings also form which are either true or pseudo-diverticulae. Hepatic atrophy is present in chronic cases, although the caudate lobe is usually spared. Patients unfortunately have a higher risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma.
  Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
This can be difficult to distinguish from PSC however whereas PSC can involve both intra and extrahepatic ducts, PBC only involves the intrahepatic ducts. It is an autoimmune condition and, like many other autoimmune conditions, patients are typically women in their middle ages. Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are present in the vast majority of patients. On imaging, the secondary cirrhotic effects are most pertinent with caudate lobe hypertrophy and left lobar atrophy. The periportal halo sign as seen on MRI is reasonably specific and relates to fluid accumulation around the portal triad.
  A Klatskin tumour
A Klatskin tumour is an intrahepatic tumour arising at the confluence of the left and right hepatic ducts where they join to form the common hepatic duct. Consequently it obstructs both ducts separately. On MRCP or ERCP this is seen as duct dilatation where the left and right ducts fail to communicate with one another. The location is relevant in identifying this type of tumours since they tend to be aggressive in nature, even for cholangiocarcinomas.
GPT3_explain: Klatskin syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this case since it is characterized by a smooth stricture in the common hepatic duct with duct dilatation and extrinsic compression from a round filling defect in the cystic duct. Klatskin syndrome is caused by a tumor located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts, which can lead to obstruction of the bile ducts and obstructive jaundice.

Qn_Text: A 13-year-old girl complains of pain in her wrist following a fall. An x-ray reveals no fractures but the carpal angle is markedly decreased to around 110o and the proximal carpus is V-shaped. Additionally the distal radio-ulnar joint is dorsally subluxed. With which condition is this deformity LEAST likely to be associated?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The patient has a Madelung deformity. This arises due to a problem with the development of the ulnar side of the distal end of the radius. The distal radioulnar joint subluxes and the ulna displaces dorsally. Owing to growth failure of the distal radius, by comparison the ulna appears lengthened (Positive ulnar variance). The carpal bones become altered in shape from the norm, in particular the lunate appears triangular. The overall appearance is of a V-shape to the radioulnarcarpal joint with angles of <120o considered characteristic.
The Madelung deformity has a number of different aetiologies (Mnemonic = DIGIT):
D = Dysplastic - Ollier disease, osteochondromatosis, achondroplasia, mucopolysaccharidoses, diaphyseal aclasis
I = Idiopathic
G = Genetic - Autosomal dominant.
50% of patients have bilateral deformities. Most common association is Turner syndrome
I = Infection
T = Post-Traumatic
Diaphyseal aclasis can be associated with a Madelung deformity but patients may have a reverse-Madelung (or pseudo-Madelung) deformity instead. Here there is negative ulnar variance due to excessive overgrowth and bowing of the radius with consequential ulnar deviation at the wrist.
  Ulnar variance
Description
Associations
Positive
The ulna is unusually long
Ulnar impaction syndrome
Negative
The ulna is unusually short
Kienboch disease
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Hellerhoff CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose Turner Syndrome because this condition is a chromosomal disorder that affects only females and is not associated with any musculoskeletal deformities. The other conditions listed are all musculoskeletal deformities that can be associated with wrist pain.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 42-year-old builder presents with pain and instability in his wrist. He recalls falling awkwardly whilst carrying heavy materials at work several years ago, since when his wrist has never been the same. Plain radiographs demonstrate what appears to be an old scaphoid fracture. There is a widened scapholunate distance with a scapholunate angle of 70 degrees. What is the best description of this abnormality? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Dorsal Intercalated Segment Instability (DISI)
This occurs in the setting of carpal instability when there is widening of the scapholunate angle to greater than 60 degrees.
  Scaphoid Non-Union Advanced collapse (SNAC)
This occurs following a scaphoid fracture. It is similar to SLAC but there is a normal scapholunate distance, with a scaphoid fracture. Like SLAC, there is radioscaphoid degenerative change, followed by proximal migration of the capitate and eventually dorsal intercalated instability.
  Scaphoid-lunate advanced collapse (SLAC)
This occurs following injury to the scapholunate ligament or secondary to CPPD. It is similar to SNAC but there is scapholunate widening, rather than a scaphoid fracture. Radioscaphoid degenerative changes are an early feature, followed by proximal migration of the capitate and eventually dorsal intercalated instability.
  Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the scaphoid
This is usually secondary to a proximal fracture. The most reliable sign is low T1 signal in the scaphoid.
  Midcarpal dislocation
This occurs in association with triquetral fracture and is very similar to lunate dislocation.
GPT3_explain: Scaphoid Non-Union Advanced collapse (SNAC) is the best description of this abnormality because it is characterized by a widened scapholunate distance with a scapholunate angle of 70 degrees, which is what is seen on the plain radiographs. This condition is caused by an old scaphoid fracture that has not healed properly, leading to instability and pain in the wrist.

Qn_Text: A patient undergoes a CT angiogram for a suspected cerebral artery aneurysm following presentation with a subarachnoid haemorrhage. From which vessel does the anterior choroidal artery arise?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The anterior choroidal artery arises from the internal carotid artery. Another important arterial anatomy fact to remember is the PICA usually arises from the vertebral arteries (70%).
GPT3_explain: The anterior choroidal artery arises from the anterior cerebral artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery. The anterior cerebral artery supplies blood to the medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes of the brain. It also supplies blood to the anterior portion of the corpus callosum and the thalamus.

Qn_Text: A 16-year-old boy with known Familial Adenomatous Polyposis, well differentiated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the colon, and a recent history of sinusitis presents acutely with focal neurology and confusion. On MRI scanning he is found to have a ring enhancing lesion with marked vasogenic oedema. Which of the following will helps establish the diagnosis of an abscess over that of a metastasis for this patient?
C: The histopathology of the known primary
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is a mnemonic for ring enhancing lesions. MAGIC DR (Metastasis, abscess, glioma, infarction, contusion, demyelination, radiation necrosis). Largely however the differential diagnosis is between a metastasis and an abscess.
An abscess tends to show a thin smooth rim of enhancement whereas mitotic lesions often have a thick, irregular margin.
The central liquefied portion of an abscess characteristically (and reasonably reliably) shows restriction in diffusion due to the high viscosity of the pus.
It is possible for hypercellular tumours and their metastases in the paediatric age bracket (such as neuroblastoma, Ewing sarcoma, osteogenic sarcoma and hepatoblastoma) to exhibit restricted diffusion to a greater or lesser extent. This is however, far less reliable a sign than the restriction in diffusion shown by abscesses.
Some studies more recently have shown a broad correlation between cellular differentiation and restriction in diffusion with poorly differentiated tumours returning lower signal on ADC maps (i.e. restricting diffusion).
  Cytotoxic vs vasogenic oedema
Cytotoxic oedema occurs due to hypoxia where the cell membrane ion pumps are no longer able to maintain the concentration gradient. The result is cellular swelling and a concurrent reduction in the extracellular fluid volume. There is restriction in diffusion with cytotoxic oedema. This is usually due to infarction and can affect both the grey and white matter.
Vasogenic oedema occurs due to a breakdown in the blood-brain barrier, of any cause. This can be seen with tumours, trauma or haemorrhage. On imaging the white matter is predominantly affected, with cortical sparing. Vasogenic oedema will respond to steroid therapy, unlike cytotoxic oedema.
GPT3_explain: The presence of vasogenic oedema (option 1) is suggestive of an abscess, but it is not definitive. The histopathology of the known primary (option 2) may be helpful in ruling out a metastasis, but it is not definitive. A thick enhancing wall (option 3), restriction in diffusion (option 4), and the presence of calcification (option 5) are all more suggestive of an abscess than a metastasis, and can help establish the diagnosis. Therefore, the correct answer is 3, 4, and 5.

Qn_Text: An 18-year-old man with known Neurofibromatosis type 1 complains of worsening lumpy skin swellings around the lumbar region. More recently he has noticed worsening weakness and sensory loss in his legs. MRI shows multiple lobulated lesions arising from the lumbosacral plexus bilaterally. These are high on T2 and enhance slightly with contrast. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
NF1 is the ‘peripheral’ version. There are plenty of cerebral features described however NF2 is almost exclusively cerebral and is therefore by comparison the ‘central’ version. There are many and varied skeletal manifestations of NF1. Plexiform neurofibromas are pathognomonic for NF1, despite contrast enhancement not being a particularly classical feature for neurofibromas.
GPT3_explain: Plexiform neurofibroma is the most likely explanation because it is the most common type of neurofibroma seen in patients with Neurofibromatosis type 1. It is characterized by multiple lobulated lesions arising from the lumbosacral plexus bilaterally, which is consistent with the MRI findings. It is also high on T2 and can enhance slightly with contrast, which further supports this diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old woman presents with back discomfort with pain and weakness in her legs. She undergoes an MRI of her lumbar spine for further assessment. The L4/5 vertebral disc is seen to extrude far laterally and efface a nerve root. Which nerve root is most likely to be affected? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
In the cervical spine the nerve roots exit at the spinal cord without needing to traverse (as in the lumbar spine). The exiting nerve root takes the name of the vertebra BELOW the affected disc. A disc protrusion at C3/4 will affect the C4 nerve root. This allows for the extra nerve root at C8 before reaching the thoracic spine. In the thoracic spine the affected level takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level.
In the lumbar spine the exiting nerve root is usually compressed in the neural foramen, whereas the traversing nerve root is compressed usually in the lateral recess. Far lateral bulges affect the exiting nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level). Paracentral bulges affect the traversing nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body BELOW that level).
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. L4 because it is the vertebral disc that is seen to be extruding far laterally and effacing a nerve root. Since the L4/5 vertebral disc is the one that is affected, the nerve root that is most likely to be affected is the L4 nerve root.

Qn_Text: You review a 32-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse. You notice the presence of a series of distended and engorged veins radiating out from his umbilical area. A porto-systemic anastomosis between which veins has caused this appearance? Select ONE answer only.
A: Para-umbilical veins and inferior epigastric vein
B: Para-umbilical veins and right gastric vein
C: Para-umbilical veins and superior epigastric vein
D: Para-umbilical veins and left gastric vein
Explanation:
Explanation:
Caput medusae is the name given to the appearance of distended superficial epigastric veins radiating out from the umbilicus across the abdomen. It is caused by the presence of portal hypertension, usually due to liver failure.
The hepatic portal vein is the major vein of the hepatic portal venous system and carries blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver.
The hepatic portal venous system communicates with the systemic venous system in the following locations:
Oesophageal veins
Para-umbiical veins
Retroperitoneal veins
Rectal veins
When blood flow through the portal system is obstructed, for example due to cirrhosis, thrombosis or the presence of a tumour, pressure rises within the portal system. In these circumstances, portal hypertension develops (a portal venous pressure of >20 mmHg) and these anatomoses become congested and form venous dilatations.
An overview of the main porto-systemic anastomoses and their associated clinical conditions is given in the table below:
  Portal circulation Systemic circulation Clinical condition
Left gastric vein Azygous vein Oesophageal varices
Para-umbilical veins Inferior epigastric vein Caput medusae
Superior rectal vein Middle and inferior rectal veins Haemorrhoids
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 3. Para-umbilical veins and superior epigastric vein. This is because a porto-systemic anastomosis between para-umbilical veins and superior epigastric vein is the most common cause of distended and engorged veins radiating out from the umbilical area in patients with a history of alcohol abuse. This anastomosis is created when the blood flow from the portal vein is diverted to the systemic circulation, resulting in abnormal dilation and engorgement of the veins.

Qn_Text: A 73-year-old lady has a pacemaker inserted for bradycardia refractory to medication. Her post-procedure check x-ray shows an unusual configuration to the pacemaker leads. The leads traverse the cardiac shadow parallel to the left side of the spine, then curve back up and across the midline. There is no pneumothorax. What is the most likely explanation? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Left sided SVC
This is an important but uncommon anomaly. Failure to recognise inadvertent catheterisation of a left sided SVC during pacemaker insertion can lead to arrhythmias.
90% drain into an enlarged coronary sinus
10% drain into the left atrium
  Inter-arterial left main coronary artery
This coronary artery variant is the most significant and likely to cause symptoms. It is often repaired even if not symptomatic, but always repaired if symptomatic as there is an associated with a significant risk of sudden cardiac death. It is known as a 'malignant' course.
  Hemiazygos continuation
This is a congenital anomaly usually consequent on failure of development of the infrahepatic IVC. Instead, blood below this level returns to the heart via a dilated hemiazygos vein which drains into the azygos vein at or above the level of the heart.
    Hemiazygos vein
    PDA - patent ductus arteriosus
A PDA accounts for around one in ten cases of congenital heart disease. In a normal patient the duct will close within hours of birth but in duct-dependant circulations it may stay open for a few days before closing leading to an acute deterioration in the baby (classically around day 5 of life). Prostaglandins can be given to try to re-open the duct, or maintain what patency does exist at the time of presentation. 
If the duct remains open in an otherwise normally formed heart the patient can develop heart failure due to the presence of a left to right shunt, but often patients are asymptomatic.
  Duct dependent lesions:
Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
Severe coarctation
Interrupted arch
Pulmonary atresia
Severe Ebsteins anomaly
TGA (if no VSD)
  Partial anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (PAPVC), scimitar syndrome
A scimitar is a curved sword such as those common in The Middle East from around the 9-10th Century onwards. It lends its name to an anomalous vein draining a hypoplastic lung as seen on CXR. In approximately half of cases the drainage is to the IVC with the remaining half draining to any one of multiple other possibilities. On the CXR the vein appears as a long tubular structure starting in the lower half of the right hemithorax and following a curved path towards the diaphragm. A scimitar vein is one component of PAPVC. The right lung drained by the vein is hypoplastic and consequently the heart is malpositioned (dextro-position) to fill the space. There is also an association with ASD.
GPT3_explain: I chose 2 because left sided SVC is the most likely explanation for an unusual configuration of pacemaker leads that traverse the cardiac shadow parallel to the left side of the spine, then curve back up and across the midline. Left sided SVC is a congenital anomaly in which the superior vena cava (SVC) is located on the left side of the heart instead of the right, and is associated with a malpositioned pacemaker lead.

Qn_Text: A man presents for an ultrasound scan with a left testicular lump. The ultrasound scan demonstrates a 4cm heterogenous mass within the left testicle. Some cystic areas are seen within the mass. The referring clinician reports that the serum hCG is elevated. A chest x-ray shows bilateral hilar enlargement. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cystic areas within a testicular mass are commonly seen in non-seminomatous germ cell tumours. Teratomas, yolk sac tumours, embryonal cell tumours and choriocarcinomas all fall into the category of non-seminomatous germ cell tumours. Of these, embryonal cell tumours make up the vast majority.
Sarcoidosis is part of the differential diagnosis for bilateral testicular masses. Although bilateral hilar lymph node enlargement does fit with sarcoidosis, the elevated hCG does not.
Choriocarcinoma
This is a rare tumour affecting 20-30-year-olds with rapid metastases to lung, liver, GI tract, brain. They often causes haemorrhage in both primary and metastatic lesions. They cause gynaecomastia in 10% of patients due to raised serum hCG.
Lymphoma and leukaemia
Testicular lymphoma is uncommon but important. In men over the age of 60 it is the most common testicular malignancy and in men of any age it is the most common bilateral testicular malignancy (although it is not always bilateral). On ultrasound it appears either as a diffusely hypoechoic and enlarged testicle or as multiple hypoechoic masses.
Testicular leukaemia has very similar appearances to lymphoma and may be difficult to differentiate from it.
Teratoma
This is the second most common tumour in boys under 5. aFP is usually normal. Under ultrasound it appears as a heterogenous complex mass.
Yolk sac tumour
This makes up 80% of childhood testicular tumours. They can often present as testicular enlargement without a focal mass. These metastasize to the lung which is the most common site of recurrent disease.
Embryonal cell tumour
This is the second most common testicular tumour. It is the most aggressive of all testicular tumours with visceral metastases being common and a 5 year survival of 30%.
  In reality, tumours are often mixed histological types in around 35% cases. Testicular tumours can also be diagnosed with a strong pre-test probability based solely on age as detailed in the table below. The role of the radiologist however does not need to be as complex as suggesting the final histological diagnosis. Establishing the presence of a testicular mass is sufficient. Patients should then be referred on to the urology MDT. On ultrasound there will be an intratesticular low reflectivity well-defined mass. Colour doppler flow can be seen within the mass.
  Age at diagnosis Tumour
10s Yolk sac tumour or teratoma
20s and 30s Choriocarcinoma
30s Embryonal cell carcinoma
40s Seminoma
    Testicular tumours © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: Choriocarcinoma is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is associated with elevated hCG levels, which was reported by the referring clinician. Additionally, the presence of bilateral hilar enlargement on the chest x-ray is also consistent with choriocarcinoma. It is an aggressive germ cell tumor that is composed of trophoblastic cells, which can metastasize to the lungs, causing hilar enlargement.

Qn_Text: A 55 female non-smoker is found to have numerous thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. The lung volumes are preserved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
LAM can go misdiagnosed for many years as emphysema. It occurs exclusively in non-smoking women of childbearing age and quite often a history of spontaneous pneumothorax is given. Radiologically there are numerous small cystic spaces surrounded by normal lung. A chylous pleural effusion (negative Hounsfield units) is reasonably specific. The main differential diagnosis would be histiocytosis which tends to be associated with smoking, classically spares the costophrenic angles and gives small nodules but both can present with spontaneous pneumothorax and give small cysts. The lung volumes in LAM will remain normal whereas they can be increased in Histiocytosis (surprisingly for a fibrotic lung disease).
  Histiocytosis (Langerhans cell histiocytosis - LCH)
There are three separate forms of this disease:
Eosinophilic granuloma (70%) – a limited version confined to the skeleton in children or young adults. Clinically presents as fever, raised WCC and ESR with painful bony lesions. In the skull these have a typical ‘beveled edge’ or ‘hole within a hole’ appearance or can be seen as a ‘button sequestrum’. In the spine it is one of the main causes of vertebra plana.
Hand-Schüller-Christian Disease (20%) – classically a triad of destructive bony lesions, diabetes insipidus and exophthalmos. In a quarter of these patients the lungs are involved with cyst formation and spontaneous pneumothoraces possible. Nodule formation, fibrosis and honeycombing are also seen.
Letterer-Siwe Disease (10%) – a fulminant multi-organ variant affecting very young infants
  There is a strong association with smoking for patients who develop pulmonary features of LCH. Heavy smoking causes an accumulation of Langerhans cells and hence, as with other inspiration-related lung diseases, there is a predilection for the upper zones. The Langerhans cells can collect with other cells and become small granulomas seen as small lung nodules. Despite being a type of fibrotic lung disease the lung volumes can be increased. Small lung cysts form and there is a risk of spontaneous pneumothorax. There is usually sparing of the costophrenic angles which can be a key finding..
  Emphysema
Many cystic lung diseases are often misdiagnosed initially as emphysema, largely due to the population prevalence of emphysema.
True lung cysts however have a perceptible wall whereas emphysematous spaces within lung tissue does not.
  Centrilobular emphysema – Caused by smoking. enlargement of the respiratory bronchiole, destruction of the alveolar septa, surrounded by normal lung, distal alveoli are spared. Affects the apical segments of each lobe due to higher ventilation perfusion ratios.
Panacinar emphysema – Caused by alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency. Affects the whole lung with greater severity seen at the bases where there is greater blood flow. Uniform lung destruction.
Paraseptal emphysema – characteristically subpleural. Associated with bullous formation and spontaneous pneumothorax.
  Respiratory Bronchiolitis Interstitial Lung disease (RBILD)
This condition is heavily associated with smoking and can be seen as centrilobular nodules with ground glass opacification. Appearances are often very similar to desquamative interstitial pneumonia. Patients can be relatively young.
  Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) also known as either Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) or cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis (CFA)
This is classically a disease of previously fit middle aged men with a reasonably long (>6month) history of shortness of breath and cough. Volume loss is prevalent and there is a classical apico-basilar gradient meaning that the lower zones are much more affected than the upper zones. Honeycombing is classical, particularly subpleural honeycombing. When secondary to a condition such as rheumatoid arthritis or a drug it is known as usual interstitial pneumonia. Overall the prognosis for this condition is extremely poor; worse than that for many common cancers.
GPT3_explain: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is the most likely diagnosis for a 55 year old female non-smoker with numerous thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma and preserved lung volumes. This is because LAM is a rare lung disease that primarily affects women of reproductive age and is characterized by the growth of smooth muscle-like cells in the lungs and other organs, resulting in cystic destruction of the lung parenchyma. In addition, LAM is typically found in non-smokers, which is why it is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

Qn_Text: A 61-year-old lady with a fatigue and weakness after minimal exertion undergoes a CXR which shows a widened mediastinum. A subsequent CT shows a lobulated 8cm anterior mediastinal mass with pleural deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The ‘5Ts’ of anterior mediastinal masses are a useful aide memoire:
Thymoma
Thyroid tumours
Teratoma
Thoracic aorta
Terrible lymphoma
  Malignant thymoma
These tumours spread by invading the mediastinum and encasing the lung with pleural thickening. Vascular invasion is also seen. There is an association with myasthenia gravis, hence the features of weakness and fatigue symptoms with lid lag and diplopia also commonly described. Pleural deposits are also a good feature to suggest a malignant thymoma over some of the other possible options.
  Hodgkin lymphoma
Hodgkin lymphoma has two age peaks in prevalence, one in the late 20s and one in the late 70s. It can present at any age however. If a histological finding of Reed-Sternberg cells (binucleate white cells) is given there can be no other diagnosis. Hodgkin lymphoma tends to cause anterior mediastinal masses whereas Non-hodgkin lymphoma tends to cause posterior mediastinal masses. Hodgkin lymphoma nodal involvement spreads contiguously from one region to the next. This makes the staging very easy to remember.
Stage I = one nodal group involved
Stage II = two or more nodal groups involved on the same side of the diaphragm
Stage III = nodal groups on either side of the diaphragm
Stage IV = involvement of non-lymphatic structures (e.g. bone or lung)
  Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL)
NHL is 4 times more prevalent than Hodgkin lymphoma. Thoracic lymph node enlargement is common and classically affects the posterior mediastinum. Unlike Hodgkin lymphoma, NHL demonstrates non-contiguous spread and thus the whole neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis should be included in staging imaging.
The following table summarises some of the imaging features separating the two diagnoses:
    Hodgkin lymphoma
Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
Mediastinal nodes
Anterior
Posterior
Spread
Contiguous
Non-contiguous
Predominantly
Thorax
Abdomen
→ Abdominal involvement
Approx 4%
>50%
→ Thoracic involvement
Approx 85%
Approx 50%
  Malignant germ cell tumour
These include seminomas and non-seminomatous (embryonal, yolk sac, choriocarcinoma, mixed cell type) tumours. Generally speaking they affect young adults and an elevated hCG, LDH, or alpha fetoprotein is usually present. The presence of effusions suggests local pleural invasion and may well be seen. Although the presence or absence of calcification is not featured in this question, the lack of calcification is in-keeping with seminomatous tumours.
  Lipoma
Lipomas are usually easily distinguished by their fat content, giving negative Hounsfield units. No Hounsfield units have been provided here but the remainder of the clinical information provided would not be explained by a lipoma.
GPT3_explain: Hodgkin lymphoma is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is the most common cause of a mediastinal mass in adults. It is also the most common cause of a lobulated anterior mediastinal mass, and it is known to cause pleural deposits. Other possible causes of a mediastinal mass include malignant germ cell tumours, lipomas, and malignant thymomas, but these are much less common than Hodgkin lymphoma. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is also a possible diagnosis, but it is less likely than Hodgkin lymphoma in this case.

Qn_Text: An elderly diabetic patient complains of severe right ear pain. She has visible erythema and granulation tissue in the right external auditory canal but it seems her symptoms are far in excess of the findings on examination. She has a 6th nerve palsy, retrobulbar pain and on CT scanning there is fluid in the mastoid air cells, middle ear and ill-defined change in the petrous apex. Which of the following best explains these findings?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Gradenigo syndrome
Gradenigo syndrome refers to the triad of otitis media, retro-orbital pain and abducens nerve palsy which results from an abscess in the aerated petrous apex – petrous apicitis. It is usually caused by either pseudomonas or enterococcus. This particular question does confusingly point towards a concurrent presence of malignant otitis externa however this is not given as an option.
GPT3_explain: Cholesterol granuloma is the most likely explanation for the elderly diabetic patient's findings. The presence of visible erythema and granulation tissue in the right external auditory canal, 6th nerve palsy, retrobulbar pain, and fluid in the mastoid air cells and middle ear suggest that the patient is suffering from a cholesterol granuloma. Cholesterol granulomas are caused by accumulation of cholesterol crystals in the middle ear and mastoid air cells, leading to inflammation and pain. Cholesterol granulomas are common in patients with diabetes, which is why this is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old woman becomes anuric, having initially recovered well, following a cadaveric renal transplant for the management of her polycystic kidney disease. You have been asked to perform an ultrasound scan on the transplanted kidney to confirm a diagnosis of renal vein thrombosis. Which of the following findings would you expect to allow you to make the diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
An increased resistive index is a sensitive finding for the presence of pathology but it is relatively non-specific.
  Renal vein thrombosis
Transplant kidneys are most likely to develop renal vein thrombosis within their first week. Clinically the patient will become anuric with a tender and swollen kidney. Ultrasound is the mainstay of diagnosis and can show thrombus within the renal vein, however the diagnosis is usually made on the basis of the Doppler findings. Since the outflow from the kidney is obstructed the resistive index (the difference in velocity between systole and diastole divided by the systolic velocity) will increase to above 0.7. The resistive index, however, is not specific as it also increases in renal artery stenosis. Furthermore the arterial waveform changes and there may even be reversal of end-diastolic flow in the renal artery. This is seen as inversion of the colour Doppler trace.
  Renal artery stenosis
There are three main aetiologies of renal artery stenosis. The most prevalent is atherosclerosis. Fibromuscular dysplasia is the second most common and is classically given as affecting a relatively young woman with beading (string of beads) of the mid and distal renal arteries seen, for which the management is angioplasty. Finally a small number of cases are secondary to a variety of conditions such as Buerger’s disease, Takayasu’s disease and neurofibromatosis.
The significance of diagnosis of atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis is in avoiding the use of ACE inhibitors. The ASTRAL trial showed that there was no long term benefit of stenting the stenoses over best medical management, although there was still a reduction in the number of episodes of flash pulmonary oedema experienced by the patients.
Slightly different numbers are given in the different sources.
  Signs of renal artery stenosis
Peak systolic velocity (PSV)
>150-180 cm/s
Ratio of peak renal artery velocity to peak aortic velocity (RAR)
>3.5
Resistive Index (RI)
>0.7
Difference in RI between left and right
>5%
Renal-interlobar ratio (RIR)
>5
Pulsus parvus (increased peak) et tardus (late) waveform
-
GPT3_explain: The peak systolic velocity of greater than 150 cm/s is a classic sign of renal vein thrombosis. This is an important finding that allows for the diagnosis of renal vein thrombosis. The other findings, such as increased resistive index, decreased resistive index, tardus-parvus pulse, and spectral Doppler inversion of diastole, may be associated with renal vein thrombosis, but they are not as reliable as peak systolic velocity in diagnosing this condition.

Qn_Text: What is the name given to the line seen on a CXR formed by the interface of the right lung and the posterior mediastinal soft tissue? Select one answer only:
Explanation:
Explanation:
The azygo-oesophageal recess is formed by the interface of the right lung and the mediastinal reflection of the azygos vein.
The anterior junctional line is formed by the meeting of the parietal and visceral pleura anteromedially.
The posterior junctional line is formed by the meeting of the pleural surfaces of the upper lobes behind the oesophagus.
The right paratracheal line is formed by the right wall of the trachea against the right lung.
The right paraspinal stripe is formed by the meeting of the right lung against the posterior mediastinal soft tissue.
GPT3_explain: The posterior junctional line is the line seen on a CXR formed by the interface of the right lung and the posterior mediastinal soft tissue. This line is also referred to as the posterior cardiac line or the right paravertebral line. It is usually seen as a horizontal line between the right lung and the mediastinum and is usually located at the level of the fourth thoracic vertebra.

Qn_Text: An 18-month-old baby girl is brought in by ambulance in acute respiratory distress. Her mother reports she had been unwell with a chest infection for which she had only recently begun a course of antibiotics. A CXR shows a large but well defined mass in the left hemithorax. She is stabilized and taken for a CT scan. This reveals multiple cysts with hypoplasia of the surrounding left lung. The mass is causing contralateral shift of the mediastinum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) – also known as Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM)
Although often an antenatal diagnosis, CPAM should be considered in the investigation of a neonatal respiratory distress. Milder cases can present later when the child develops a LRTI and decompensates. On investigation a cystic mass is discovered. The size of the cysts denotes the type with Type I accounting for half of cases and comprising a smaller number of larger (>20mm) cysts. Type III is more sponge-like with cysts measuring only a couple of mm and Type II is between the two. Where cysts are larger, air-fluid levels may be seen. The malformation can exert a mass effect, causing both hypoplasia of the remainder of the ipsilateral lung as well as contralateral mediastinal shift.
  Congenital lobar overinflation (previously congenital lobar emphysema)
This condition is thought to be caused by underdevelopment of bronchial cartilage in the affected lobe(s). Consequently the bronchus is unable to remain patent during expiration leading to significant air trapping. It is usually the left upper lobe which is affected but approximately 40% of cases involve the left upper lobe; the right middle or the right upper lobes are affected in a further 55% of cases. There is a reasonable male preponderance of approximately 3:1.
On a CXR there is hyperlucency of the affected lobe and often mass effect on the mediastinum leading to contralateral mediastinal shift and thereby respiratory distress.
  Pulmonary interstitial emphysema (PIE)
As the name would suggest, this disease is diagnosed when there is air within the interstitial tissues of the lungs. It is caused by alveolar rupture due to the barotrauma of mechanical ventilation or positive airway pressure. It can be associated with hyaline membrane disease and is prevalent in infants of a low birth weight. Complications such as pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum can be severe and acutely life threatening. Radiographically there is hyperinflation and lucencies in either a cystic pattern or streaks emanating from the hila and following the direction of the bronchi/bronchioles. It is treated with high frequency oscillation ventilation which is less traumatic to the lungs.
  Swyer-James syndrome
In this condition, normal development of the infant lung is impeded by bronchiolitis (viral or mycoplasma) at an early age, with superadded acute airspace destruction. Consequently the affected lobe is small and lucent on the CXR due to air trapping. It is a differential diagnosis for a unilateral lucent hemithorax, along with a pneumothorax, very large pulmonary emboli and causes of decreased chest wall musculature such as Poland syndrome or, historically, polio. In an an exam situation Swyer-James syndrome is usually given as a teenage or young adult patient with a history of recurrent LRTIs. Air trapping, and bronchiectasis can also be described.
  Tension pneumothorax
This must be ruled out for any patient presenting with acute respiratory distress. The presence of lung markings, even if scarce, ought to rule this out although the difference between ‘scarce’ and ‘absent’ is undoubtedly easier to interpret on a real CXR as opposed to a wooly description of one.
GPT3_explain: Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is the most likely diagnosis in this case. CPAM is a congenital disorder characterized by the presence of cysts in the lung tissue. The cysts are typically accompanied by hypoplasia of the surrounding lung tissue, and they can cause contralateral shift of the mediastinum. The other options listed do not typically cause cysts in the lung tissue, and therefore CPAM is the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A baby boy attends his GP surgery for routine immunisations at 12 weeks old. The practice nurse is concerned that the baby's head is an unusual shape and asks the GP to see the baby. She agrees and the baby is referred to the paediatric services at your local hospital. A CT is performed which shows premature fusion of a cranial suture. Which of the following is the most common type of craniosynostosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Craniosynostosis
Premature closure of one or more of the sutures leads to an abnormal shape to the head developing as the brain continues to grow within a confined space. Skull growth will continue perpendicular to the affected suture. Skull x-rays can be performed (Townes, AP and lateral views) but CT scanning offers 3-D reconstruction capabilities and is usually performed prior to any surgery for the purposes of planning.
Of these by far the most common is sagittal craniosynostosis which causes elongation of the skull and is termed scaphocephaly meaning 'boat-like'.
  Suture Age of Closure Craniosynostosis
Metopic (5%) 3-9m Trigonocephaly
Sagittal (50%) 30-40yrs Scaphocephaly
Coronal (20%) 30-40yrs Unilateral = Plagiocephaly
    Bilateral = Brachycephaly
Lambdoid (5%) 30-40yrs Unilateral = Plagiocephaly
    Bilateral = Brachycephaly
All   Oxycephaly or turricephaly
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Xxjamesxx CC BY-SA 3.0
  At birth a suture width of up to 10mm can be normal.
Age Suture width
Birth < 10mm
2 years 3mm
3 years 2mm
  There are a number of conditions which can cause craniosynostosis:
Primary - sporadic or familial
Secondary
Haematological (sickle cell disease, thalassaemia)
Endocrine (hyperthyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, hypercalcaemia, hypophosphataemia)
GPT3_explain: I chose Scaphocephaly because it is the most common type of craniosynostosis, with an estimated incidence of 1 in 2,000 live births. It is caused by premature fusion of the sagittal suture, which runs from front to back along the top of the skull. This results in an abnormally long and narrow head shape.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 29-year-old lady presents with shortness of breath and tachycardia. A full blood count and renal function tests are normal, as is a chest radiograph. The admitting team suspect she may have a pulmonary embolism and the decision is taken to perform a CTPA study, in part due to tracer non-availability at the hospital. The clinical team asks what she should do about breast-feeding her 3-month-old daughter. What should you advise? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
B: She should switch to formula feeding
Explanation:
Explanation:
Considerations during lactation
Less than 1% of injected iodine or gadolinium is excreted into breast milk and less than 1% of this is then absorbed by the baby's intestinal tract. Although these amounts are considered acceptably low as to not necessitate any breast-feeding cessation advice many families are understandably over-cautious. It is accepted that contrast agents are undetectable in blood 24 hours after administration and so any mother wishing to 'pump-and-dump' despite the negligible risks need not do so for longer than a day. Care should, however, be given to counsel the family that it is possible for inadvertent weaning to occur even after short intervals and this should be factored in to any decision made by the family.
Following a nuclear medicine study the risks to the baby are two-fold; firstly from tracer excretion into the breast milk, but also through proximity to the mother during breast-feeding. Recommendations for breast-feeding interruption vary depending on the half-life of the tracer used. For perfusion imaging using technetium (half-life 6 hours) breast milk should be expressed for the first 24 hours following the scan. In theory, it need not be discarded but can safely be bottle-fed to the baby after these 24 hours have elapsed, however in practice many patients none-the-less choose to discard it.
Most tracers simply require adherence to a washout time but of note, the precautions following administration of Gallium-67 based tracers (most commonly used for pyrexia of unknown origin) are much more limiting and, practically speaking, unfortunately lead to complete cessation of breastfeeding. The half-life of Ga-67 is approximately 78 hours. Breastfeeding should, if time allows, be stopped for 2-4 weeks prior to the scan to allow the breast tissue to become less radiosensitive while the tracer circulates within the mother. Where this is an unacceptably long delay for the clinical state of the patient the study can be performed straight away anyway but in either case, milk should also be discarded for at least a further two weeks following the study. Clearly a disruption to breast-feeding of such a long time is far from ideal, even assuming that a patient who is sufficiently unwell as to need a PUO study is able to continue breast-feeding at all, and is likely to lead to complete cessation of breast-feeding. There are other ways to image PUO using Tc99m labelled white blood cells which can be considered.
  Imaging in pregnant patients (for PE)
A pregnant patient suspected to have a pulmonary embolus should undergo a chest x-ray to look for alternative causes of shortness of breath such as a lower respiratory tract infection, pleural effusions or a pneumothorax. In the event that they go on to have a VQ scan a chest radiograph is required for comparison.
Thereafter the patient should undergo bilateral lower limb venous dopplers if they have signs or symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. Around a third of pregnant patients who develop pulmonary emboli will have a deep vein thrombosis and for these patients treatment can be started on the basis of their DVT diagnosis without the need for further imaging. If the patient has no signs or symptoms of a DVT, they should proceed to a VQ scan or a CTPA.
The patient should be counselled that there is a small increase in the absolute risk of the foetus developing a childhood cancer following a maternal VQ scan but also that the absolute risk of maternal breast cancer is reduced compared to a CTPA.
CTPA
CTPA imaging confers a lower dose to the foetus than V/Q scanning, although this effect is diminished in the third trimester as the gravid uterus becomes closer to the field of view.
Unfortunately however, CTPA confers a far greater dose to the breast tissue of the mothers at a time when the tissue is more radiosensitive than it would otherwise be in a non-pregnant woman.
A secondary consideration is the use of iodinated contrast. Iodine crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid. Babies of mothers who have received iodinated contrast during pregnancy should be tested during their first week of life for thyroid suppression although there is little evidence in literature to suggest that many if any infants have developed hypothyroidism following maternal intravenous iodine exposure.
Technical factors to performing a CTPA scan in pregnant patients, if required, are also important to consider. Hyperdynamic circulation can render usual triggering bolus mechanisms suboptimal and raise the possibility of a non-diagnostic study.
  V/Q or Q only scanning
V/Q scanning confers a far lower breast dose to the mother but the dose to the foetus, particularly when small, can be greater owing to tracer accumulation within the solid organs of the mother. The mother should be encouraged to adequately hydrate and void frequently in the subsequent hours/days following a scan.
Many institutes choose to perform perfusion scanning only in pregnant women on the understanding that if the perfusion scan is normal then there is no need to go on to perform the ventilation study. The perfusion scan can also be performed at half the usual dose to further reduce the foetal-dose. Naturally doing so comes with the trade-off of lower sensitivity and specificity.
  Gadolinium in pregnancy
Gadolinium also crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetus into the amniotic fluid. The chelated form of gadolinium in itself poses no risk to the foetus however the free form of gadolinium is teratogenic and the longer the foetus is exposed to the chelated gadolinium administered for the scan, the greater the risk of each molecule of gadolinium becoming dissociated from its chelate. For this reason therefore, gadolinium should only be administered in a patient known to be pregnant, if there is likely to be significant diagnostic benefit from the resultant images.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3 because no breast-feeding interruption is necessary. The CTPA study does not involve any radiation, so there is no need for the mother to stop breast-feeding her daughter. In addition, the CTPA study does not involve any contrast agents, so there is no need for the mother to "pump-and-dump" her breast milk.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about ethical decision making.

3. A question about ethical decision making.

Qn_Text: You are reporting a CT scan of a 63-year-old man who has presented with acute abdominal pain. One of the findings on the scan is of small locules of gas within the bladder. You suspect there may be a colovesical fistula. What is the most common cause of a colovesical fistula?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Diverticular disease is the most common cause of a colovesical fistula and of the inflammatory bowel diseases Crohn disease is more often complicated by fistula formation than is ulcerative colitis.
Gas within the bladder should be obvious on a CT scan. Often this will be for as innocuous a reason as a recent urethral catheterisation but, especially in diabetic patients, it can also be a sign of infection, either emphysematous cystitis or emphysematous pyelonephritis (see below), with a gas-forming organism such as E-coli.
The absence of gas in the bladder does not rule out a fistula and if there is clinical or radiological suspicion the presence of a fistula can be confirmed with a barium enema. Other causes of a colovesical fistula other than those listed as alternative answers include post-radiotherapy complications, abdominal sepsis (such as an appendix abscess), and finally trauma.
  Emphysematous Pyelonephritis
The radiological appearances of this condition are very striking, particularly on CT where streaky or lobulated gas can be seen in the renal parenchyma and perirenal tissues. On ultrasound the gas causes ring-down artefacts and is sometime described as giving a ‘dirty shadowing’ appearance. It is a very important diagnosis to make since it comes with significant morbidity. E-coli is the usual culprit and a history of poorly controlled diabetes is usual. The main differential diagnoses is the far less severe condition of emphysematous pyelitis where e-coli infection is confined to the excretory system and responds well to antibiotic therapy, and the presence of a fistulous connection to the bowel.
GPT3_explain: Diverticular disease is the most common cause of a colovesical fistula. It occurs when a diverticulum (a small sac or pouch) in the large intestine becomes inflamed and breaks through the wall of the bladder, creating a fistula. It is most common in people over the age of 50.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old lady undergoes an MRI to investigate the cause of her chronic headache. On the sagittal T1 weighted sequence, the quadrigeminal cistern is seen to extend above the third ventricle, to the foramen of Monro, but remains bound by the thalamus laterally. Which of the following is the most likely explanation?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cavum septum pellucidum
This is a normal finding in all preterm infants, and common in most term infants, but persists in around 10-20% of adults. It is also known as the 5th ventricle. It is a triangular shaped CSF space in between the anterior horns of the lateral ventricles.
  Cavum vergae
This is a cavity posterior to the columns of fornix. It is essentially a posterior continuation of a cavum septum pellucidum.
  Cavum Velum interpositium
This is present if the quadrigeminal cistern is seen to extend above the third ventricle to the foramen of Monro, but remains bound by the thalamus laterally.
  Holoprosencephaly
This is a developmental abnormality where there is incomplete separation of the two cerebral hemispheres. It can be classified into lobar, semilobar and alobar forms.
Lobar: Nearly normal. Septum pellucidum is absent.
Semilobar:Variable cleavage with a partially formed falx, and a rudimentary third ventricle.
Alobar:The most severe form with no cleavage at all. The falx and third ventricle are absent. The cerebral hemispheres and thalami are fused. There is a large single ‘lateral’ ventricle.
  Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP)
Atrophy of the midbrain produces a characteristic ‘hummingbird’ sign of the brainstem and midbrain (also known at the penguin sign). The size of the midbrain can be compared to that of the pons and a ratio of <0.15 is a reliable sign of PSP.
GPT3_explain: I chose Cavum septum pellucidum as the most likely explanation because it is the most common cause of an enlarged quadrigeminal cistern extending above the third ventricle, while remaining bound by the thalamus laterally. This condition is typically seen in patients with hydrocephalus, which can cause chronic headaches.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about medical ethics.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the coronary arteries is true?
A: The right coronary artery supplies the SA and AV nodes
B: The right coronary artery supplies the entire interventricular septum
C: The left coronary artery supplies the right atrium
D: The left coronary artery arises from the aorta below the left cusp of the aortic valve
E: The right coronary artery is larger than the left
Explanation:
Explanation:
The left coronary artery arises from the aorta above the left cusp of the aortic valve. It supplies the left atrium, left ventricle, intraventricular septum and part of the left branch bundle of His. It is larger than the right coronary artery.
It passes between the left side of the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then bifurcates into the left anterior descending artery (LAD), which is also called the anterior interventricular branch, and the left circumflex artery (LCA). Sometimes an additional artery arises at the bifurcation called the ramus or intermediate artery.
The LAD follows the anterior interventricular groove towards the apex of the heart and then continues to the posterior surface of the heart to anastamose with the posterior interventricular branch.
The LCA follows the anterior atrioventricular groove to the left border of the heart and then proceeds to the posterior surface. It then gives rise to the left marginal branch, which follows the left border of the heart.
The right coronary artery arises above the right cusp of the aortic valve. It supplies the right atrium, the SA and AV nodes and the posterior part of the interventricular septum.
It runs along the right atrioventricular groove before branching. The right marginal artery arises first and then the right coronary artery continues on to the posterior surface of the heart, still running in the right atrioventricular groove. The posterior descending artery (PDA), which is also called the posterior interventricular artery, arises next and then follows the posterior interventricular groove towards the apex of the heart.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Patrick J. Lynch CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the right coronary artery is responsible for supplying the sinoatrial (SA) node and the atrioventricular (AV) node, which are two important structures in the heart that control the heart rate.

Qn_Text: A 53-year-old woman develops a non-tender nodule within the left submandibular gland. Ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic mildly lobulated lesion 1cm in diameter. What is the LEAST likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note the question asks for the LEAST likely option.
The lesion could be a pleomorphic adenoma which are usually found in the parotid gland but the second most common site is the submandibular gland. Warthin tumours on the other hand are almost exclusively found in the parotid gland. A few case reports exist of Warthin tumours in other sites, including the submandibular gland. On the description provided a post-inflammatory sialectatic cavity is not an unreasonable suggestion, neither is an adenoid cystic tumour. It is thought that an intraglandular lymph node has been given as the least likely option since intraglandular lymph nodes are highly unusual in the submandibular gland (far more common in the Parotid gland) and even if found, tend to be barely a few mm in diameter and the question specifies 1cm.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 5 because post-inflammatory sialectatic cavity is the least likely diagnosis. This is because the symptoms described are not consistent with a post-inflammatory sialectatic cavity, which is usually associated with tenderness, swelling, and purulent discharge. The other diagnoses all have a more likely association with the described symptoms.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old diabetic presents with severe ear pain and palsy of the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves. He undergoes a CT scan which shows osteomyelitis of the skull base and is diagnosed with malignant otitis externa. What is the most common cause of this?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Malignant otitis externa
This is an extremely unpleasant condition seen in elderly diabetic patients who present with pain levels disproportionately high compared to the external signs of their disease. Imaging shows osteomyelitis of the skull base, seen better on MRI than on CT. Multiple cranial neuropathies can be present, as can venous sinus thrombosis. It is almost always caused by pseudomonas aeruginosa.
GPT3_explain: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of malignant otitis externa. This bacterium is known to cause skin and ear infections, which can lead to severe pain and damage to the nerves of the ear and face. It is also known to be resistant to many antibiotics, making it difficult to treat.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the management or treatment of a condition.

This question falls under Category 3: A question about the management or treatment of a condition.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old man driving his car at 60mph is involved in a severe road traffic accident and is brought into the Emergency Department. He is too unstable to undergo a CT scan, but a trauma series of radiographs is taken. The CXR shows widening of the superior mediastinum and blurring of the aortic knuckle. The trachea is shifted to the right. What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
An aortic transection is highly likely to be next-to immediately fatal. Formation of a pseudoaneurysm at the transaction site can sometimes contain extravasation but the scenario of a patient surviving long enough to receive even a chest x-ray otherwise seems a little far-fetched but does occur in exceptional circumstances. Disruption to the aortic contour and bilateral pleural effusions are given as signs of aortic transaction. The trachea is shifted to the right by mass effect from the enlarging haematoma around the aorta.
GPT3_explain: The single most likely diagnosis is aortic dissection, because the CXR findings are indicative of this condition. Widening of the superior mediastinum and blurring of the aortic knuckle are both classic signs of aortic dissection, as is tracheal shift to the right. Tension pneumothorax and non-tension pneumothorax can also cause tracheal shift, but the other CXR findings are not indicative of these conditions. Aortic transection may also cause tracheal shift, but the other CXR findings are not indicative of this condition either. Similarly, aortic aneurysm may cause widening of the superior mediastinum, but the other CXR findings are not indicative of this condition.

Qn_Text: A 2-day-old baby boy is brought back to hospital by his parents with vomiting and a distended abdomen. An abdominal radiograph demonstrates two large bubbles of gas with some pockets of distal gas also present scattered throughout the abdomen. What would be the next appropriate step?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The 'double bubble' sign localises the problem to the level of the duodenum. The presence of distal gas makes duodenal atresia highly unlikely. The differential diagnosis is between duodenal web, stenosis or midgut volvulus, all of which would be best investigated with an upper GI contrast study.
GPT3_explain: An abdominal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in this case because it can provide a detailed view of the baby's abdominal organs and can help to identify the source of the distended abdomen and the pockets of gas. It can also help to rule out any other potential causes of the baby's symptoms, such as a blockage or a hernia.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of a procedure, such as how to perform a certain test.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 17-year-old boy suffers trauma to the head after falling over on ice. He is drowsy and mildly confused, but without focal neurology and undergoes a CT head scan. This demonstrates an intracranial 3mm superficial crescentic area of high density at the vertex which crosses the midline. In which compartment does the haematoma lie?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Although extradural haematomas are unlikely to cross the sutures, this can happen and given the falx prevents subdural haematoma from crossing the midline, this must be an extradural haematoma. Subarachnoid blood would be described within the sulci and a creseteric high density at the vertex would not be a usual description for this.
Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a crescentic area of high density is indicative of a subdural haematoma, which is a type of intracranial haemorrhage that occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. Subdural haematomas are typically caused by head trauma, such as a fall, and can cause neurological symptoms such as confusion, drowsiness, and focal neurology.

Qn_Text: A 31-year-old lady who is 18 weeks pregnant with her first pregnancy presents with shortness of breath and tachycardia. Full blood count and renal function tests are normal. The admitting team suspect she may have a pulmonary embolism. Which of the following is INCORRECT? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: The breast dose to the mother from a V/Q scan is usually greater than for a CTPA scan
B: The baby should have a thyroid function test during its first week of life if the patient does have a CTPA
C: Hyperdynamic circulation increases the risk of a non-diagnostic study for pregnant patients
D: Iodine crosses the placenta and is excreted into the amniotic fluid by the foetus
E: The foetal dose from a V/Q scan is usually greater than for a CTPA scan
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which answer is INCORRECT.
A pregnant patient suspected to have a pulmonary embolus should undergo a chest x-ray to look for alternative causes of shortness of breath such as a lower respiratory tract infection, pleural effusions or a pneumothorax. In the event that they go on to have a VQ scan a chest radiograph is required for comparison.
Thereafter the patient should undergo bilateral lower limb venous dopplers if they have signs or symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. Around a third of pregnant patients who develop pulmonary emboli will have a deep vein thrombosis and for these patients treatment can be started on the basis of their DVT diagnosis without the need for further imaging. If the patient has no signs or symptoms of a DVT, they should proceed to a VQ scan or a CTPA.
The patient should be counselled that there is a small increase in the absolute risk of the foetus developing a childhood cancer following a maternal VQ scan but also that the absolute risk of maternal breast cancer is reduced compared to a CTPA.
  CTPA
CTPA imaging confers a lower dose to the foetus than V/Q scanning, although this effect is diminished in the third trimester as the gravid uterus becomes closer to the field of view.
Unfortunately however, CTPA confers a far greater dose to the breast tissue of the mothers at a time when the tissue is more radiosensitive than it would otherwise be in a non-pregnant woman.
A secondary consideration is the use of iodinated contrast. Iodine crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid. Babies of mothers who have received iodinated contrast during pregnancy should be tested during their first week of life for thyroid suppression although there is little evidence in literature to suggest that many if any infants have developed hypothyroidism following maternal intravenous iodine exposure.
Technical factors to performing a CTPA scan in pregnant patients, if required, are also important to consider. Hyperdynamic circulation can render usual triggering bolus mechanisms suboptimal and raise the possibility of a non-diagnostic study.
  V/Q or Q only scanning
V/Q scanning confers a far lower breast dose to the mother but the dose to the foetus, particularly when small, can be greater owing to tracer accumulation within the solid organs of the mother. The mother should be encouraged to adequately hydrate and void frequently in the subsequent hours/days following a scan.
Many institutes choose to perform perfusion scanning only in pregnant women on the understanding that if the perfusion scan is normal then there is no need to go on to perform the ventilation study. The perfusion scan can also be performed at half the usual dose to further reduce the foetal-dose. Naturally doing so comes with the trade-off of lower sensitivity and specificity.
  Gadolinium in pregnancy
Gadolinium also crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetus into the amniotic fluid. The chelated form of gadolinium in itself poses no risk to the foetus however the free form of gadolinium is teratogenic and the longer the foetus is exposed to the chelated gadolinium administered for the scan, the greater the risk of each molecule of gadolinium becoming dissociated from its chelate. For this reason therefore, gadolinium should only be administered in a patient known to be pregnant, if there is likely to be significant diagnostic benefit from the resultant images.
  Considerations during lactation
Less than 1% of injected iodine or gadolinium is excreted into breast milk and less than 1% of this is then absorbed by the baby's intestinal tract. Although these amounts are considered acceptably low as to not necessitate any breast-feeding cessation advice many families are understandably over-cautious. It is accepted that contrast agents are undetectable in blood 24hours after administration and so any mother wishing to 'pump-and-dump' despite the negligible risks need not do so for longer than a day. Care should, however, be given to counsel the family that it is possible for inadvertent weaning to occur even after short intervals and this should be factored in to any decision made by the family.
Following a nuclear medicine study the risks to the baby are two-fold; firstly from tracer excretion into the breast milk, but also through proximity to the mother during breast-feeding. Recommendations for breast-feeding interruption vary depending on the half-life of the tracer used. For perfusion imaging using technetium (half-life 6 hours) breast milk should be expressed for the first 24 hours following the scan. In theory, it need not be discarded but can safely be bottle-fed to the baby after these 24 hours have elapsed, however in practice many patients none-the-less choose to discard it.
Most tracers simply require adherence to a washout time but of note, the precautions following administration of Gallium-67 based tracers (most commonly used for pyrexia of unknown origin) are much more limiting and, practically speaking, unfortunately lead to complete cessation of breastfeeding. The half-life of Ga-67 is approximately 78 hours. Breastfeeding should, if time allows, be stopped for 2-4 weeks prior to the scan to allow the breast tissue to become less radiosensitive while the tracer circulates within the mother. Where this is an unacceptably long delay for the clinical state of the patient the study can be performed straight away anyway but in either case, milk should also be discarded for at least a further two weeks following the study. Clearly a disruption to breast-feeding of such a long time is far from ideal, even assuming that a patient who is sufficiently unwell as to need a PUO study is able to continue breast-feeding at all, and is likely to lead to complete cessation of breast-feeding. There are other ways to image PUO using Tc99m labelled white blood cells which can be considered.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is incorrect. Iodine does not cross the placenta and is not excreted into the amniotic fluid by the foetus. Instead, iodine is absorbed by the placenta and is then filtered out of the mother's bloodstream by the kidneys.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about medical ethics or legal matters.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a case series on the teaching files of cholesteatomas. Which of the following is the area LEAST likely to be involved?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Certainly the ossicles, lateral semicircular canal (Known by some as the Clint Eastwood sign) and lateral epitympanic wall (i.e. scutum) are often involved. Of the ossicles, the long process, lenticular process of the incus and the head of the stapes are commonly involved. The tegmen tympani is the roof of the middle ear and is also often involved. It can be seen superior to the ‘ice cream cone’ on coronal images. The tegmen mastoidium is the roof of the mastoid and is seen laterally to the tegmen tympani.
  There are two types of acquired cholesteatoma:
                Pars flaccid – classically erodes the scutum
                Pars tensa – classically erodes the ossicles
GPT3_explain: The wall of the lateral semicircular canal is not typically involved in cholesteatomas. Cholesteatomas are characterized by the formation of an abnormal keratinized squamous epithelium in the middle ear, which usually involves the tympanic membrane, the middle ear ossicles, and the lateral epitympanic wall. The wall of the lateral semicircular canal is usually not involved in this process.
Cat_Long: This question would fall under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: An MRI neck of a patient with a head and neck tumour is being discussed at the MDT. The tumour is located in the carotid space and is sufficiently large as to be causing mass effect. Which way is the paraphargyngeal space likely to be displaced? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Head and neck anatomy is all about the parapharyngeal space and its relationships. The parapharyngeal space is a small and unobtrusive space itself containing only fat, some branches of the trigeminal nerve and a few vessels but is sat right in the middle of the soft tissues of the neck on each side and as a result gets pushed about when the surrounding spaces are invaded.
The best way to learn which spaces displace the parapharyngeal space which way is to draw it out on rough paper a few times. The following table provides a summary:
  Space Displacement of parapharyngeal space
Masticator Posteromedial
Carotid Anterior
Pharyngeal mucosal Posterolateral
Parotid Anteromedial
Retropharyngeal Anterolateral
GPT3_explain: The parapharyngeal space is located between the lateral pharyngeal wall and the medial surface of the carotid sheath. When a tumour is located in the carotid space, it can cause mass effect, which means that the parapharyngeal space is likely to be displaced medially. This is because the tumour is pushing the parapharyngeal space away from the lateral pharyngeal wall and towards the medial surface of the carotid sheath.

3. A question about clinical management, what is the best course of treatment?

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old West African lady presents with a right Bell palsy and symptoms consistent with diabetes insipidus. Her admission chest x-ray is documented to be abnormal. On MRI there is diffuse meningeal enhancement with nodular enhancement of the spinal cord. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Sarcoidosis
Although only a small percentage of sarcoid patients develop CNS signs these are classical, with multiple cranial neuropathies, meningeal and pituitary involvement.
What separates sarcoid meningitis from tuberculous meningitis which would probably be the best other option is the nodular enhancement.
Both tuberculous and fungal meningitis also affect the basal cisterns and both have the propensity to cause an obstructing hydrocephalus secondary to debris.
Carcinomatous meningitis commonly derives from breast cancer, although lung cancer and melanoma are other possibilities. There is a classic description of ‘zuckerguss’ (sugar coating) where thin areas of subarachnoid enhancement follow the gyral convolutions. Leptomeningeal nodularity is also seen, hence the inclusion here as a possible answer, however the patient demographic fits better with sarcoidosis.
HIV encephalitis causes cognitive problems leading to a dementia. As well as cortical atrophy there can be subtle increases in the T2 signal intensity but meningeal enhancement is not described.
GPT3_explain: Tuberculous meningitis is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common cause of meningitis in West African countries and it is associated with Bell palsy, diabetes insipidus, abnormal chest x-ray, and diffuse meningeal enhancement with nodular enhancement of the spinal cord.

Qn_Text: A 58-year-old man undergoes a ureteroscopy for investigation of a urinary tract malignancy following presentation with haematuria. Which of the following is the LEAST common site of urinary tract malignancy? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely answer.
Transitional carcinoma makes up around 95% of urinary tract cancers in the UK. The vast majority affect the bladder. The renal pelvis is the second most commonly affected site. The ureter is the least common site of malignancy. The lower third is affected in around 75% of cases, followed by the middle third. The proximal third is affected in only around 3% or ureteric malignancies.
GPT3_explain: The renal pelvis is the least common site of urinary tract malignancy. The upper, middle, and lower thirds of the ureter are more commonly affected by malignancies.
