Qn_Text: A 27-year-old man presents with a one month history of headache, nausea and vomiting. He is referred to a neurologist who finds a raised haematocrit and requests and MRI. The MRI scan shows a peripheral left cerebellar hemisphere part cystic and part solid lesion with an enhancing mural nodule, in contact with the pial surface. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
All the answers come within the differential diagnosis for the description of enhancing mural nodules however polycythaemia secondary to erythropoietin secretion as part of a paraneoplastic syndrome is a documented association to haemangioblastomas.
GPT3_explain: Haemangioblastoma is the most likely diagnosis because the MRI scan shows a cystic and solid lesion with an enhancing mural nodule, which is a common presentation of a haemangioblastoma. Haemangioblastomas are tumors that arise from the lining of the blood vessels of the brain and are usually seen in the cerebellum. The raised haematocrit is also suggestive of a haemangioblastoma.

Qn_Text: A new born baby is noted to have a soft swelling on his neck. An ultrasound scan shows a multilocular cystic structure posterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The thyroid and salivary glands appear normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cystic hygroma are usually (but not exclusively) multilocular and are situated in the posterior triangle of the neck.
A second branchial cleft cyst is usually described as being between the submandibular gland and the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
A thyroglossal duct cyst is usually midline or close to midline.
Fibromatosis coli is a fibrotic process which occurs in the sternocleidomastoid muscle and is usually found in the neonatal period following a difficult or instrumental delivery. On ultrasound there is enlargement of the sternocleidomastoid muscle itself but no mass per se. Most cases resolve spontaneously over the ensuing months.
  Neck Masses in Children © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: Second branchial cleft cysts are the most common cause of soft swellings in the neck of a newborn baby. They are usually located posterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and are multilocular cystic structures. Ultrasound scans are often used to confirm the diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A baby boy born at full term is started on phototherapy for presumed physiological jaundice at day 3. Two days later his condition has improved and he is discharged home. On day 16 he is re-referred by the Health Visitor and found to have obstructive jaundice. An ultrasound scan shows his liver is enlarged and echogenic and there is a triangular cord sign in the porta hepatis. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following would be the most likely findings on a HIDA scan?
A: Hepatic activity after 5 minutes and no bowel activity after 24 hours
B: Hepatic activity after 5 minutes and bowel activity present after 24 hours
C: No hepatic activity after 5 minutes with some bowel activity after 24 hours
D: No hepatic activity after 5 minutes and no bowel activity after 24 hours
Explanation:
Explanation:
Biliary atresia
This presents between two weeks and two months of life as an obstructive jaundice picture (i.e. conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia). The extrahepatic bile ducts have become fibrosed and cause obstruction. Initial investigation is usually with ultrasound and an echogenic ‘triangular cord’ structure in the porta hepatitis is considered pathognomic. The gallbladder may be normal, small or non-visualised and therefore contributes little to the diagnosis. Further investigation is often with a HIDA scan. If there is normal activity within the liver (usually after only a few minutes) but there is no visualisation of tracer within the bowel after 24 hours this is considered diagnostic. Phenobarbitol can be given in the days leading up to the scan to increase biliary output.
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because a HIDA scan is used to diagnose obstructive jaundice, which is the condition the baby was found to have in this case. Obstructive jaundice is caused by a blockage in the bile ducts, which prevents the bile from draining from the liver. In this case, the ultrasound showed an enlarged and echogenic liver with a triangular cord sign in the porta hepatis, which is indicative of a blockage. Thus, the most likely finding on a HIDA scan would be no hepatic activity after 5 minutes and no bowel activity after 24 hours, since the bile is unable to drain from the liver.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about diagnosis or management, what is the most likely findings on a HIDA scan?

Qn_Text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents. They report that he fell over the back of their sofa and hit his head. He is examined and x-rays are taken. Which of the following is suggestive of an accidental injury? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
**Please note the question asks for the answer most likely to be caused by an ACCIDENTAL injury**
  Spiral fractures can be caused by both accidental and non-accidental injuries but are more common in adults than children. Significant power is needed to cause a spiral fracture in a child; they are unusual in the setting of a straightforward fall.
  Non-accidental injury
It is the responsibility of all members of the healthcare profession to be alert to the possibility of non-accidental injury. For radiologists, there are specific findings which should alert the reporter to the possibility of non-accidental injury. These include:
Lower limb injuries in a non-ambulant child
Discrepancy between the history and apparent injuries
Delay seeking medical attention
Metaphyseal fractures (corner or bucket-handle)
Multiple fractures of different ages
Scapula fractures
Posterior rib fractures
Sternal fractures
Skull fractures (especially non-parietal, or crossing sutures)
  It is important to appreciate that any fracture (not just the ones listed above) can be caused by non-accidental injury.
A skeletal survey to investigate for the presence of further fractures includes:
Two views of the skull (frontal and lateral)
AP of upper limbs (over multiple films if necessary)
DP of wrist/hand
Lateral of elbow and wrist
AP of lower limbs (over multiple films if necessary)
DP feet
AP ankle
Lateral of ankle and knee
AP abdomen and pelvis
Three views of the chest (frontal and two oblique)
Lateral whole spine
CT head - if younger than 1 year, or older than 1 year with head trauma or abnormal neurology, or older than 2
  Siblings younger than age 2 should also have the same imaging as the index patient.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a displaced occipital fracture is a fracture of the skull that is usually caused by a traumatic event, such as a fall. It is often seen in children who have had an accidental injury, such as a fall from a height or a head injury. In this case, the child fell over the back of the sofa, which could have caused a displaced occipital fracture.
Cat_Long:

Qn_Text: A 14-year-old girl attends for an x-ray. She is worried about a swelling at the tip of her left index finger under the nail and her GP has requested imaging. The x-ray does show a lesion and the girl goes on to have a resection of the terminal phalanx of the left index finger. Histological analysis of the lesion proves it to be avascular. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Subungual exostosis
An exostosis is a bony outgrowth from an otherwise normal bone. Crucially there is cortical and medullary continuity from the parent bone to within the exostosis. They can arise following trauma to the bone and are often found in the adolescent age range.
  Subungual keratoacanthoma
Keratoacanthomas can occur anywhere in on the skin and consist of overgrowth of squamous epithelium with a central area of keratin. Local destruction can sometimes be seen and transformation into a squamous cell carcinoma can also occur. On x-ray a subungual keratoacanthoma will appear as a lucent lesion which, through mass effect only, has eroded the underlying bone but otherwise does not seem to affect the underlying bone (i.e. no sclerosis, no periosteal reaction). The peak demographic is men over the age of 55.
  Glomus tumour
These are benign vascular tumours which arise in patients in their 40s or 50s. They usually present as an exquisitely tender blue/red nodule under the patient’s finger nail. The Hildreth sign is present if the pain is relieved by applying a tourniquet proximal to the lesion. Usually they arise within soft tissue, however occasionally they can be found actually within the terminal phalanx itself where it can be mistaken for an enchondroma.
  Enchondroma
As the name suggests, this is a cartilage forming tumour showing ground-glass matrix and ring or arc calcifications (as with all cartilage forming tumours). Patients are typically young (10-30 years) and the lesions are typically found in the hands (although they can form anywhere in the body, in the hands they are unusual to be found in the terminal phalanges). They are thought to derive from ongoing growth of small foci of cartilage which have become displaced from the growth plate. They can expand the cortex but, unless presenting as a fracture, should be painless and therefore are often an incidental diagnosis. Although they are benign tumours, malignant degeneration to a chondrosarcoma can occur.
  Benign naevus
The colloquial term for this is a mole. A benign subungual naevus would be very rare and any pigmentation of the nail should be treated as a malignant melanoma until proven otherwise.
GPT3_explain: Glomus tumours are the most likely diagnosis for a lesion found under the nail of the finger that is avascular. Glomus tumours are benign, slow-growing tumours that arise from the glomus body, which is a type of blood vessel found in the skin. The tumours are typically painful and can cause swelling and discolouration of the nail.

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old lady is diagnosed with a fibrotic lung condition on HRCT. Which of the following comparisons of IPF and NSIP is NOT correct?
A: Patients with IPF respond well to steroids
B: NSIP patients are approximately 10 years younger than IPF patients
C: IPF is associated with smoking, NSIP is not
D: IPF has apicobasal gradient, NSIP is peripheral
E: IPF has traction bronchiectasis, NSIP has micronodules
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is much overlap between NSIP and IPF but gross trends can be seen which help point towards either diagnosis. Although honeycombing is the go-to feature for IPF, a microcystic version is found with NSIP.
  IPF
  NSIP
Macrocystic honeycombing
↔
GGO
Apicobasilar gradient
↔
Peripheral
Traction bronchiectasis
↔
No nodules
Smoking association
↔
No smoking association
Architectural distortion
↔
Less distortion
Slightly older
↔
Slightly younger
No response with steroids
↔
Responds to steroids
  IPF (Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis) can only be diagnosed in the absence of a precipitating condition such as asbestosis, rheumatoid arthritis, or drug toxicity. Where such exists, the condition is termed UIP (Usual interstitial pneumonia). CFA (Crytpogenic fibrosing alveolitis) is a historic term for the same thing.
There is much overlap in the features of the various different fibrotic lung diseases.
Therefore, look for specific features which are most strongly associated with the different conditions. The table below (despite appearances) simplifies the overall situation significantly and is inadequate for real life radiology but does provide a framework on which to build further understanding of these conditions.
The features in bold are the most prominent in each of the conditions.
  Diagnosis Feature
IPF = UIP = CFA Macrocystic honeycombing, apicobasilar gradient
NSIP Peripheral, associated with CREST/Sjogrens/RA, chemotherapy
COP = BOOP Patchy. Associated with connective tissue diseases, CF, methotrexate, post-transplant
RBILD Smoking, young patients, no bronchiectasis or honeycombing
DIP Smoking, GGO, difficult to tell apart from RBILD
AIP ‘Outpatient ARDS’, spares costophrenic angles
LIP Diffuse pattern, associated with Sjogrens, autoimmune conditions, Hep B, EBV, PCP
  A more detailed description of each condition is listed here with those associated with smoking listed first. There are demographic traits to most of these conditions however for the sake of simplicity these have not been included here.
  Diagnosis Dominant features Location Smoking association? Misc. and associations
IPF

Macrocystic subpleural honeycombing Lower zones ‘apicobasilar gradient’ Yes Prognosis is poor, poorer than many cancers.
RBILD

DIP GGO Peripheral Yes Hard to tell apart from RBILD
NSIP
Ground glass opacification (GGO)

Associated with:
Collagen vasculitides (CREST, -myositis, sjogrens, RA)
Drugs - chemotherapy
HIV

= BOOP

Subsequently traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing in non-dependant lung

GPT3_explain: I chose number 3 because IPF is not responsive to steroids, whereas NSIP is. Steroids are used to reduce inflammation in NSIP, but they are not effective in treating IPF.
Cat_Long: This question falls under basic factual recall regarding anatomy.

Qn_Text: Which of the following ultrasound findings would not be suggestive of renal artery stenosis? Select one answer only.
C: RI difference between the kidneys of >5%
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are three main aetiologies of renal artery stenosis. The most prevalent is atherosclerosis. Fibromuscular dysplasia is the second most common and is classically given as affecting a relatively young woman with beading (string of beads) of the mid and distal renal arteries seen, for which the management is angioplasty. Finally a small number of cases are secondary to a variety of conditions such as Buerger disease, Takayasu disease and neurofibromatosis.
The significance of diagnosis of atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis is in avoiding the use of ACE inhibitors. The ASTRAL trial showed that there was no long term benefit of stenting the stenoses over best medical management, although there was still a reduction in the number of episodes of flash pulmonary oedema experienced by the patients.
There is conflicting literature about the use of resistive index in evaluating for renal artery stenosis in transplant kidneys. The normal value is around 0.7. Some studies have shown figures slightly higher than this (around 0.78) in mild-moderate renal artery stenosis but lower (0.6) in severe renal artery stenosis and in native kidneys studies have shown high resistive indices (above 0.7) to be associated with parenchymal scarring indicating the kidney may respond poorly to revascularisation therapy and resistive index is used to help inform treatment decisions on this basis. It is generally thought not to be a useful marker for diagnosis in renal artery stenosis though, in either native or transplant kidneys.
  Signs of renal artery stenosis
Peak systolic velocity (PSV)
>150-180cm/s
Ratio of peak renal artery velocity to peak aortic velocity (RAR)
>3.5
Difference in RI between left and right
>5%
Renal-interlobar ratio (RIR)
>5
Downstream: Pulsus parvus (reduced peak) et tardus (late) waveform
-
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Increased RAR of >3.5 because renal artery stenosis is typically associated with reduced renal artery resistance (RAR), not increased RAR. An increased RAR would be more suggestive of a renal artery occlusion or other causes of reduced renal perfusion.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: What are the components of the Phemister triad? Select one answer only.
A: Juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, gradual reduction of the joint space
B: Marginal sclerosis, effusion, rapid joint space narrowing
C: Diffuse osteoporosis, chondrocalcinosis, rapid joint space narrowing
D: Diffuse sclerosis, marginal erosions, gradual reduction of the joint space
E: Marginal sclerosis, chondrocalcinosis, gradual reduction of the joint space
Explanation:
Explanation:
Tuberculous spondylitis also known as Pott disease
Around half of patients have no pulmonary disease and spondylitis accounts for around 5% of all infections with tuberculosis. The L1 vertebral body is the most commonly affected level but usually more than one levels is affected. Within the vertebral body it is the anterior aspect which is affected first. This is thought to be due to the subligamentous spread of the bacterium, under the anterior longitudinal ligament. The disc height is usually preserved until relatively late on in the disease which can make the condition very difficult to detect on x-ray since neither periosteal reactions nor reactive sclerosis are likely to be seen either. Calcification to the disc is common though, and virtually pathognomonic when present.
  Phemister triad
Of articular tuberculosis it is the spine which is most commonly affected however the hips and knees can also be affected. The Phemister triad describes three classical features of tuberculous arthropathy which are common to all the joints affected:
Juxta-articular osteoporosis
Marginal erosions
Gradual reduction of the joint space
Differentiating tuberculous spondylitis from pyogenic spondylitis is crucial and there are a number of features which can help.
  Tuberculous discitis
Staphylococcal discitis
Calcification (almost pathognomonic)
No calcification
Involvement of the posterior elements
Posterior elements spared
Insidious onset
More acute onset
Less loss of disc space
More loss of disc space
Gibbus deformity (angular kyphosis)
No gibbus deformity
Multiple levels involved
One level involved
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because it is the correct answer. The Phemister triad consists of marginal sclerosis, chondrocalcinosis, and gradual reduction of the joint space. These three components are the hallmarks of osteoarthritis.

Qn_Text: In the context of breast radiology, what are the stages are involved in a triple assessment? Select one answer only
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Clinical examination, ultrasound and core biopsy
E: Bilateral mammograms and spot compression views
Explanation:
Explanation:
Triple assessment consists of imaging (ultrasound for all women and additional mammography for women over the age of 40), clinical examination and biopsy.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a triple assessment typically involves a combination of imaging techniques such as bilateral mammograms and ultrasound (USS), which are both used to assess the breast for abnormalities. This is often followed by a clinical examination and additional imaging techniques such as MRI or core biopsy if necessary. Spot compression views are typically used to further investigate suspicious areas identified on the mammogram.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man with HIV has an MRI which shows ring enhancing lesions and leptomeningeal enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cerebral tuberculosis
A cerebral tuberculoma would be difficult to differentiate from toxoplasmosis or lymphoma. Classically though they are described as target lesions situated in the corticomedullary regions. They can calcify with treatment which would differentiate them well from other CNS infections. In this particular case the co-existent meningeal enhancement suggests the answer to beTB.
  Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)
This is a JC virus mediated phenomenon which causes asymmetrical patchy white matter changes. These can be bilateral. The testable feature is involvement of the cortical U-fibres which separates it from HIV encephalopathy where the U-fibres are spared. The lack of a mass effect helps differentiate both PML and HIV encephalopathy from toxoplasmosis, cryptococcus and tuberculomas.
  HIV encephalopathy
Separating HIV encephalitis from PML can challenging in real life. HIV encephalitis causes bilateral symmetrical white matter changes, seen as high T2 signal (The T1 sequences can be normal). There is also sparing of the subcortical U-fibres.
  Cryptococcus
This is an opportunistic yeast-like fungus which therefore requires a degree of immunocompromise, typically AIDS. The cryptococcomas are non-enhancing low density lesions in the basal ganglia. These show as high signal on T2 sequences. A granulomatous meningitis can also occur. They can be differentiated from VR spaces on FLAIR where VR spaces will suppress (being CSF in content) whereas the mucoid cryptococcomas will not.
  Toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasmosis is a more common finding in AIDS patients than lymphoma is, by a large margin. On MRI it is seen as multiple ring enhancing lesions, which can show haemorrhage particularly following treatment. One of the stronger differentiators between toxoplasmosis and lymphoma is the SPECT findings. This is sometimes termed ‘hypometabolic’ meaning the lesions do not demonstrate SPECT uptake. The table below gives some general features of the two conditions. There is however considerable overlap in the imaging features despite these broad trends.
    Toxoplasmosis
Lymphoma
Number of lesions
Multiple lesions
Single lesion (can be multiple)
Predilection/involvement of
Basal ganglia
Corpus callosum
DWI
Range of appearances
Restricts
Thallium SPECT
Negative
Avid
MRS choline
Decreased
Increased
MR perfusion
Decreased rCBV
Increased rCBV
GPT3_explain: HIV encephalitis is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is the most common cause of ring-enhancing lesions and leptomeningeal enhancement in HIV-positive patients. HIV encephalitis is an opportunistic infection caused by the virus itself, and it can cause significant neurologic symptoms and cognitive impairment. Other possible diagnoses, such as toxoplasmosis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, cerebral tuberculosis, and cryptococcus, can also cause similar symptoms, but they are less common in HIV-positive patients.

Qn_Text: A 94-year-old lady who underwent a wide local excision for the management of her breast cancer presents with back pain and undergoes an MRI scan. The T6 vertebra is fractured and collapsed. Which of the following is would make an osteoporotic fracture LESS likely than a pathological one?
A: High T2 signal in the pedicles
D: High T1 and intermediate T2 signal of the bone marrow
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are a number of features which can help differentiate between an osteoporotic vertebral collapse and a metastatic one.
  Favours osteoporosis
Favours metastases
Retropulsed bony fragments
Convex posterior cortex
Fluid adjacent to the fractured end plates
Associated soft tissue masses
Multiple compression fractures
Other metastases without compression fractures
Sparing of the marrow signal
Marrow signal abnormalities
  Involvement of the posterior elements of the spine
    Bone marrow on MRI
  T1 T2
Normal bone marrow
High (fatty) Intermediate
Post-Radiotherapy
Very high and homogenous Intermediate (initially high due to oedema)
Haemangioma
High High
Abnormal bone (metastases, myeloma, regeneration)
Low but enhances with Gadolinium High (fluid)
Blastic metastases (prostate, breast, TCC) and myelofibrosis
Low Low
  Metastases
Normally metastatic deposits in the spine lead to low T1 signal and high T2 signal. There should be no signal drop out on fat saturated sequences in contrast to marrow reconversion where although red marrow will experience far less signal dropout than yellow marrow, there will still be some loss in signal owing to the fat content of both types of marrow.
Sclerotic or blastic metastases return little signal on either T1 or T2 weighted sequences. These include prostate, breast or TCC metastases among others.
Breast cancer can cause lytic or sclerotic metastases or a mixed picture.
Lytic metastases are more likely than sclerotic metastases to enhance with contrast. Similarly on DWI imaging, whereas lytic metastases will usually appear hyperintense, sclerotic metastases return little signal since they contain little water.
If there is a diffuse abnormality of the bone marrow it can be difficult to identify but normal bone marrow should not be lower in signal intensity than the muscle on T1 weighted sequences.
GPT3_explain: A high T1 and intermediate T2 signal of the bone marrow is indicative of normal bone marrow, which is generally less likely in a pathological fracture. A pathological fracture is more likely to be associated with low T1 and high T2 signal of the bone marrow, which is indicative of abnormal bone marrow. Retropulsed bony fragments, fluid adjacent to the end-plates, high T2 signal in the pedicles, and multiple compressed levels are all indicative of a pathological fracture.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man presents to his GP with worsening back pain and stiffness. Plain radiographs show some slight sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints bilaterally with small vertebral syndesmophytes in the lumbar spine. He is referred to an orthopaedic consultant who is concerned he may have ankylosing spondylitis and requests an MRI scan. Regarding MRI in ankylosing spondylitis, which of the following is correct? Select ONE answer only.
A: Coronal SIJs - best sequence for the SIJs
B: STIR - best sequence for bony erosions
C: T2 - best sequence for bone marrow abnormalities
D: Axial SIJs - to evaluate facet joints
E: Sagittal spine - to evaluate disc herniation
Explanation:
Explanation:
T1 fat sat - useful for visualisation of bony erosions and new bone formation
T1 fat sat post contrast - useful for detecting bone marrow abnormalities (but so is STIR, so contrast is not an absolute requirement for imaging ankylosing spondylitis).
STIR - useful for detecting bone marrow abnormalities in the SIJs and spine
T2 fat sat - useful for detecting oedema
  Coronal SIJ - ideally this should be taken parallel to the long axis of the sacrum, the better to view the SIJs, both SIJs can be seen on each image for comparison.
Axial SIJ - ideally this should be at 90 degrees to the modified coronal plane and is used to evaluate the ligamentous portion of the SIJs.
Axial spine - useful if co-existing disc herniation present but not ordinarily included otherwise
Sagittal spine - useful to evaluate facet and costovertebral joints
  Ankylosing spondylitis
This disease usually presents in early adulthood with gradual onset of back pain. There is a male preponderance, though it can affect women too. The vast majority (>90%) of patients are HLA-B27 positive. Radiologically the late features are classical with:
Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis
Enthesopathy - calcified tendon insertion sites
Bamboo spine - vertebral syndesmophytes, particularly in the thoracolumbar spine
Dagger sign - spinous process fusion
Erosion, then fusion at the symphysis pubis, costochondral, costovertebral and sternoclavicular joints
Thoracic manifestations: upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis, pericarditis, aortic root dilatation
Early features are far more subtle and require a higher index of suspicion
Enthesopathy - high signal on MRI at tendon insertion sites
Romanus lesions - triangular shaped oedema at the corners of vertebral bodies
Andersson lesions - bony oedema in the vertebral bodies adjacent to the disks.
Oedema in the sacroiliac joints.
  Patients with advanced ankylosing spondylitis are at increased risk of pathological fractures due to fusion. These can be pelvic fractures following a simple fall, or chance fractures of the spine (involving all three columns - in ankylosing spondylitis, these fractures are also sometimes termed chalk-stick or carrot fractures).
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because coronal SIJs are the best sequence for evaluating the sacroiliac joints in ankylosing spondylitis. The coronal plane is most useful for visualizing the SIJs because it provides a direct view of the articular surfaces of the joint and allows for assessment of bony erosions, joint narrowing, and other signs of inflammation. Additionally, the coronal plane is also useful for evaluating the facet joints which can be affected in ankylosing spondylitis.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment?

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old man complaining of chest pain undergoes a CT chest that shows a hilar mass measuring 60HU which demonstrates no enhancement post-contrast. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Carcinoid
These are low-grade lung malignancies with a good prognosis. They are usually central in location (in contrast to the peripheral preferences of hamartomas). Calcification is a common feature in approximately a third of cases which in this question is weakly suggested by the high attenuation. Typically carcinoids are very vascular tumours that enhance avidly, and usually derive their blood supply from the bronchial arteries rather than the pulmonary arteries. Atypical carcinoids can show little enhancement and also tend to be less well rounded and more aggressive in appearance, although that has not been suggested here.
The carcinoid syndrome seen in abdominal carcinoids is far less commonly seen with thoracic carcinoids. Wheezing, on the other hand, can be given in an exam question setting as a feature to point towards endobronchial carcinoid lesions (i.e. mechanical obstruction).
  Lymphoma
Lymphoma would be unlikely owing to the lack of enhancement.
  Duplication cyst
A duplication cyst would have a much lower HU than 60 – it would be expected to be far closer to zero.
  Neurofibroma
Although neurofibromas often show little enhancement on CT post contrast, again 60HU would be too high for most neurofibromas. Additionally a neurofibroma would more usually be described as having an intraspinal element. Dumbbell protrusion through the neural foramina.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because lymphoma is a type of cancer that can present as a hilar mass on a CT chest. Lymphoma is a common cause of a hilar mass, and it is also the most concerning diagnosis due to its potential to spread to other parts of the body. Additionally, the lack of enhancement post-contrast is consistent with a lymphoma diagnosis.

Qn_Text: An 85-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain and is diagnosed with sepsis, CT demonstrates duodenal perforation and retroperitoneal abscess posterior to the pancreas. The patient is deemed unfit for surgery and percutaneous drainage of the abscess is not possible without traversing an intervening organ. Which of the following organs can be considered safe to be traversed with a catheter?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The pancreas, spleen, gallbladder and bowel must never be traversed during percutaneous drainage. The stomach and liver may be safe to traverse in circumstances when other options are unavailable. It is vital to have a normal coagulation profile and the catheter course must be as short as possible away from major ducts and blood vessels.
GPT3_explain: The gallbladder is the safest organ to traverse with a catheter in this situation because it is the least likely to be damaged by the catheter. The pancreas, liver, and spleen are all more delicate organs that could be damaged by the catheter, while the small bowel is more likely to be perforated by the catheter than the gallbladder.

3. A question about the application of knowledge in a clinical context.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 4-month-old baby. There is a solid hypoechoic lesion within the right kidney. You cannot separate the mass from the normal renal parenchyma at the lower pole of the kidney but it is not invading the collecting system or renal vein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Renal masses by age
Neonate
Multicystic dysplastic kidney
Second most common neonatal renal mass
Mesoblastic nephroma
Most common SOLID neonatal renal mass
Nephroblastomatosis
Can be a precursor to WIlms tumour
Pre-school
Nultilocular cystic nephroma
Affects boys, slightly younger than Wilms
Wilms tumour
Most common SOLID mass of childhood
Lymphoma
Can affect teenagers and adults as well
    Mesoblastic nephroma
This is the most common solid mass in a neonate and 90% of them are diagnosed within the first year of life. Presentation is usually as an abdominal mass. On ultrasound there will be a large hypoechoic renal mass which cannot clearly be separated from the normal renal parenchyma. Pertinent negative imaging features of note are the lack of invasion into the collecting system and lack of venous invasion, the latter in particular helps to differentiate it from a WIlms tumour.
  Multicystic dysplastic kidney
A Multicystic Dysplastic kidney is the second most common cause of a neonatal renal mass. The normal renal architecture is entirely replaced by a non-functioning mass of cysts separated from one another by fibrous tissue. The overall appearance is said to resemble a bunch of grapes. If unilateral, the condition can be asymptomatic or can present as recurrent urinary tract infections. The most important distinction to make is from hydronephrosis which is overall the most common cause of a neonatal abdominal mass. In hydronephrosis the apparent 'cysts' will communicate whereas in multicystic dysplastic kidney the cysts are separate from one another.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of ColnKurtz CC BY-SA 4.0
  Multilocular cystic nephroma
There are two age peaks for this tumour; one at around age 4 which affects mostly boys and and one at around age 40 which affects mostly women. In young boys the most common presentation is of a painless abdominal mass with or without other features such as haematuria and urinary tract infections. On ultrasound there will be a mass of cysts but importantly they will be surrounded by a thick fibrous capsule. Protrusion into the renal pelvis is also a key finding, but this is also seen in some WIlms tumours. There shouldn't be a solid component to this mass but enhancement of the septae separating the cysts may be seen on cross-sectional imaging.
  Neuroblastoma
This is the most common solid abdominal mass in infants and second most common in children of all ages (after Wilms tumours). Most are adrenal in location, around a third develop in the retroperitoneum and a fifth are located in the posterior mediastinum. Presentation can be with abdominal pain, a mass, or a fever. Most (95%) secrete catecholamines such as VMA (vanillylmandelic acid – leads to hypertension) or VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptides – leads to watery diarrhoea). There are also a few distinct clinical syndromes which herald the presence of a neuroblastoma.
  Syndrome
Details
Blueberry muffin syndrome
Metastatic cutaneous deposits
Opsomyoclonus
Rapid jerky eye movements and myoclonic jerks of the legs. This occurs in around 2% of neuroblastoma cases but around 50% of patients with opsomyoclonus have a neuroblastoma.
Hutchinson syndrome
Limping due to bony metastases
    On imaging they appear as a very large abdominal mass with or without speckled calcification within in. The kidney can either be invaded or just displaced inferiorly, causing a ‘drooping lily’ appearance on urography (where contrast within the inferiorly displaced renal calyces has the appearance of a lily flower with its head hanging down). Neuroblastomas tend to encase large vessels such as the IVC, as opposed to displacing them as Wilms tumours are prone to doing. Staging is performed with an 123I-MIBG scan (as opposed to a 99mTc-MDP bone scan) and importantly within the staging it is actually stage IVs (disease involving the skin, bone marrow and liver) which has the best prognosis.
  Feature
Neuroblastoma
Wilms tumour
Peak age
2 years
3-4 years
Kidney
Drooping lily sign – displaced downwards, if not invaded.
Claw sign – rim of normal renal tissue extending around the mass
Crosses midline
More common
Less common
Calcification
More common
Regular and stippled
Less common
Curvilinear and phleobliths
IVC
Encases
Displaces and/or invades
  Wilms tumour also known as a nephroblastoma
This is the most common abdominal mass in children under the age of 8. There are reasonably strong associations with renal anomalies, genital anomalies, aniridia and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (although the last of these also has an association with neuroblastoma). Presentation is usually with an abdominal mass and/or pain.
  10% tumour – Wilms
Calcification
Vascular invasion
Bilateral
Lung metastases
Poor histology
  On imaging the masses are usually heterogenous. Cystic areas can often be seen secondary to areas of necrosis. The claw sign occurs when there is a rim of normal renal tissue extending part of the way around the mass. A Wilms tumour is often described as enhancing but less so than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma.
GPT3_explain: Multicystic dysplastic kidney is the most likely diagnosis because it is a common congenital condition in which a mass of cysts form in the kidney. It is usually seen in the lower pole of the kidney and is composed of solid hypoechoic lesions. It does not invade the collecting system or renal vein, which is consistent with the findings in this case.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a CT scan showing a mass invading the foramen ovale. What would be the most likely symptoms related to this?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Atrophy of the muscles of mastication
B: Loss of sensation over the maxilla
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is an anatomy question pertaining to the contents of the foramen ovale which can be remembered with the following mnemonic.
O = otic ganglion
V = V3
A = Accessory meningeal artery
L = Lesser petrosal nerve
E = emissary veins
  The sphenoid bone, with the foramen ovale labelled third from the bottom on the left (from Gray’s Anatomy)
Of these V3 supplies the muscles of mastication and hence invasion of the foramen ovale can be associated with atrophy of these muscles. V2 passes through the foramen rotundum and supplies the skin overlying the maxilla. Anosmia is the word used to describe the inability to smell and in this scenario would imply involvement of the cribriform plate and cranial nerve I. The seventh cranial nerve supplies the stapedius muscle which dampens loud noises.
GPT3_explain: The most likely symptoms related to a mass invading the foramen ovale would be loss of sensation over the maxilla (1), anosmia (2), sensitivity to loud noises (3), atrophy of the muscles of mastication (4), and epistaxis (5).
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old woman presents with an uncomfortable swelling at the back of her right knee. On examination you palpate a round, smooth, fluctuant mass within the popliteal fossa. An ultrasound scan confirms that she has a Baker's cyst. Which of the following is the deepest structure contained within the popliteal fossa? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The popliteal fossa is a diamond shaped depression situated at the back of the knee joint. It acts as the main conduit for the neurovascular structures entering and leaving the leg.
  The borders of the popliteal fossa are:
Superomedial border: semimembranosus
Superolateral border: biceps femoris
Inferomedial border: medial head of gastrocnemius
Inferolateral border: lateral head of gastrocnemius and plantaris
  The roof of the popliteal fossa is formed by (from superficial to deep):
Skin
Superficial fascia
Deep (popliteal) fascia
  The floor of the popliteal fossa is formed by:
Popliteal surface of the femur
Capsule of the knee joint
Fascia covering the popliteus muscle
  The contents of the popliteal fossa (from medial to lateral) are:
Popliteal artery
Popliteal vein
Tibial nerve
Common peroneal nerve
  The tibial and common peroneal nerves are the most superficial of the contents of the popliteal fossa. The deepest structure is the popliteal artery. The small saphenous vein pierces the deep fascia to enter the popliteal fossa. The popliteal lymph nodes surround the vessels.
    The popliteal fossa and its contents, with the popliteal lymph nodes in blue (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: The popliteal artery is the deepest structure contained within the popliteal fossa. It is a continuation of the femoral artery and is the main artery that supplies blood to the lower leg. It is located beneath the other structures in the popliteal fossa, including the popliteal vein, popliteal lymph nodes, tibial nerve, and common peroneal nerve.

Qn_Text: A 10-year-old boy with abdominal pain is diagnosed as having mesenteric adenitis. Which of the following mesenteries crosses the head and body of the pancreas anteriorly? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The mesenteries are double layers of peritoneum in the abdominal cavity that are continuations of the visceral and parietal peritoneum. They enclose the intestines and attach them to the posterior abdominal wall.
The term was originally used only to refer to the small intestine mesentery that suspends the jejunum and ileum. For this reason the small intestine mesentery is sometimes referred to as the mesentery proper.
The term has now been widened to include four main mesenteries:
Small intestine mesentery (mesentery proper)
Transverse mesocolon
Sigmoid mesocolon
Mesoappendix
  The small intestine mesentery is a large, broad, fan-shaped mesentery that is attached to the jejunum and ileum, connecting them to the posterior wall of the abdominal cavity. Superiorly the root of the mesentery is attached to the duodenojejunal junction just to the left of the L2 vertebra. It runs obliquely downwards, from left to right, to attach inferiorly to the ileocaecal junction close to the right sacroiliac joint.
In the region of the root of the small intestine mesentery there are numerous Pacinian corpuscles (encapsulated mechanoreceptors). Traction and tension on the peritoneal folds in the upper abdomen stimulates these mechanoreceptors to produce a drop in blood pressure. This is thought to serve as a protective function by causing reflex contraction of the abdominal wall to aid support of the viscera during extreme movements.
The transverse mesocolon is a broad fold of peritoneum that is attached to the transverse colon and connects it to the posterior abdominal wall. It lies anteriorly across the front of the head and body of the pancreas to enclose the transverse colon. It subdivides the greater sac into the supracolic and infracolic compartments, which lie superior and inferior to the transverse mesocolon respectively.
The sigmoid mesocolon is an inverted V-shaped fold of peritoneum that attaches the sigmoid colon to the pelvic wall. The apex of the V is attached near to the bifurcation of the left common iliac artery. The left limb descends medially to the medial border of the left psoas major muscle and the right limb descends into the pelvis to end anteriorly to the S3 vertebra.
The mesoappendix is a fold of peritoneum around the vermiform appendix. It is attached to the lower end of the small intestine mesentery, near to the ileocaecal juntion. It usually extends to the tip of the appendix.
GPT3_explain: The transverse mesocolon is the mesentery that crosses the head and body of the pancreas anteriorly. It is a fold of the peritoneum that attaches the transverse colon to the posterior wall of the abdomen. It also provides a supportive framework for the pancreas and other organs in the abdomen.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the cardiac MRI scan of a patient who is being investigated for symptoms of heart failure. Changes on his ECG suggest he may have dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following statements regarding cardiac MRI is INCORRECT? Select ONE answer only.
A: Black-blood imaging is particularly useful for suspected cardiac amyloidosis
B: Enhancement at 2 minutes post-contrast could be due to pericarditis
C: On GRE sequences ischaemic areas are seen as bright post-contrast
D: Enhancement at 10 minutes post-contrast could be due to sarcoidosis
E: Enhancement at 2 minutes post-contrast could be due to myocarditis
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cardiac MRI - a brief overview
T2 black blood - used to look at the overall structure and morphology of the heart. Signal from blood within the heart is nulled and appears black in the resultant images. This sequence is susceptible to artefact from abnormal blood flow and is classically difficult to perform in patients with cardiac amyloidosis.
  A small amount of physics for imaging of patients with cardiac amyloidosis
Amyloid deposition leads to fibrosis and, as a general rule, fibrotic processes contain little water. On MRI scans therefore, most fibrotic entities return little signal on any sequence. Additionally, in many patients with amyloid cardiomyopathy, gadolinium washes out of the myocardium far faster than normally occurs. Both these features combine to the extent that the blood within the heart becomes very dark (due to higher than usual concentrations of gadolinium washed out from the myocardium) but at the same time the signal from the myocardium is very low due to the presence of fibrosis. Nulling the signal from the myocardium (to try to better visualise the affected areas of myocardium) therefore becomes difficult since the null point for both the blood pool and the myocardium is almost the same.
  SSFP or FSE - used to look for gross abnormalities in the whole chest, and to plan further cardiac views. Cine-SSFP used to look at ventricle and valve function, volume, mass and ejection fraction. Early post contrast T1 FSE sequences are useful to look for early hyperenhancement which is a sign of inflammation such as myocarditis or pericarditis. First-pass perfusion (can be FSE or GRE) sequences are not essential but can be useful to examine for peri-infarction ischaemia. The ischaemic areas are seen as dark against the enhancement of normal myocardium.
  GRE - used to examine delayed enhancement. Images taken around 15 minutes (10-20mins) after gadolinium is injected. Normal myocardium undergoes a rapid wash-in and wash-out of contrast, but abnormal myocardium has a slower wash-in and wash-out so is still enhancing at this time. Myocardial infarction can be seen as an area of delayed hyperenhancement, classically in a vascular territorial distribution and also classically involving the subendocardium (which is usually spared in non-ischaemic pathology). Delayed hyperenhancement in a pattern typical for ischaemia is highly sensitive for both chronic and acute myocardial infarction.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because enhancement at 10 minutes post-contrast is not typically seen with sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is usually seen as a diffuse pattern of enhancement at 2 minutes post-contrast.

Qn_Text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes an abdominal ultrasound for investigation of intermittent flank pain. Within the left kidney, a 28 mm well-defined and brightly echogenic lesion is seen within the cortex suggestive of a renal angiomyolipoma. Which of the following features is most predictive of spontaneous haemorrhage? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
85% of AMLs over 40 mm will undergo spontaneous haemorrhage. Size remains the single most important predictive factor of AML rupture. Patient with AMLs over 40 mm will frequently be offered prophylactic embolization to avoid this risk of rupture.
GPT3_explain: An angiomyolipoma (AML) is a benign tumor of the kidney composed of fat, smooth muscle, and blood vessels. It is usually an incidental finding on imaging. Spontaneous haemorrhage is a rare but potentially serious complication of AMLs. Studies have shown that the risk of haemorrhage increases with the size of the lesion. In particular, lesions greater than 40 mm in size are associated with a higher risk of haemorrhage, compared to smaller lesions. For this reason, size greater than 40 mm is the most predictive feature of spontaneous haemorrhage.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about applying knowledge to a clinical situation.

3. A question about applying knowledge to a clinical situation.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the HMPAO images from a patient who presented to his GP with a gradual decline in memory. Which of the following findings is correctly matched to its diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: Involvement of the occipital lobes - Lewy body dementia
B: Reduced uptake in the precuneus and cingulate gyrus - Pick disease
C: Reduced uptake of the frontal lobes - Alzheimer's disease
D: Temporoparietal hypoperfusion bilaterally and symmetrically - Vascular dementia
E: Susceptibility artefact bilaterally but asymmetrically - Parkinson's disease
Explanation:
Explanation:
Functional imaging in dementia
Tc99m-HMPAO SPECT and 18F-FDG PET produce very similar patterns when used to image patients with cognitive decline however the latter is considered to have a greater sensitivity and specificity and is therefore preferred.
Two structures bear particular importance in the imaging of dementia; the precuneus and the cingulate gyrus. Both are best appreciated on sagittal views.
Precuneus: The precuneus is located on the medial surface of each hemisphere, in the posterior parietal lobe. It has functions in motor planning, working memory and also connections to the visual pathways.
        The cingulate gyrus: The cinculate gyrus is also located on the medial side of each hemisphere and runs anteroposteriorly just above the corpus callosum. The cingulate gyrus has complex functions to do with learning, emotional response and memory.
        Alzheimer's disease
The radiological findings of this well-known disease are diffuse sulcal and ventricular enlargement. There is a disproportionate effect to the anterior temporal lobes, hippocampi and sylvian fissures with sparing of the sensorimotor and visual cortices, thalami and cerebellum. Functional studies (Tc-HMPAO SPECT or F-18 FDG PET) show reduced uptake in the precuneus, posterior cingulate gyrus, frontal and temporoparietal lobes but with characteristic sparing of the sensorimotor cortex and basal ganglia bilaterally. Importantly there is also sparing of the occipital lobes, which helps differentiate it from Lewy body dementia where the occipital lobes are involved. Other differences between the two conditions are seen with specific dopamine transporter agent imaging techniques
  Lewy body dementia
There is a generalised decrease in cerebral volume (sparing the hippocampi). Temporo-parietal hypoperfusion on HMPAO Tc99m SPECT scanning is indicative of Lewy body dementia. Involvement of the occipital cortex, which is typically spared in Alzheimer’s disease, sets the two apart from one another on PET studies. The cingulate island sign has also been ascribed to Lewy body dementia, where there is preservation of metabolism in the mid-posterior cingulate gyrus. If present, this is said to be specific for Lewy body dementia.
  Vascular dementia
Technically vascular dementia presents as a step-wise decline due to the finite number of small vascular insults that take place. The imaging features should be fairly familiar to candidates from day to day reporting. There are multifocal bilateral white matter changes which can be seen on CT when severe. Inclusion of susceptibility weighted sequences on an MRI scan allows detection of microhaemorrhages suggestive of a parallel diagnosis of cerebral amyloid angiopathy where present.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Lewy body dementia is a type of dementia that is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies in the brain, which are abnormal clumps of proteins that are found in the occipital lobes. This can lead to reduced uptake of the occipital lobes, which is what is seen in the HMPAO images.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 39 year recently arrived from India has a CXR showing apical scarring. A subsequent CT scan shows tree-in-bud features. He also undergoes a cardiac MRI. This shows a 4mm pericardium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Inflammation of the pericardium is termed pericarditis and leads to fibrous thickening. Most commonly this occurs either post-operatively in patients undergoing cardiac surgery or as an idiopathic entity although historically it was tuberculosis which was the most common cause of pericarditis. The diagnosis is predominantly clinical with symptoms such as malaise or dyspnoea and signs such as neck vein distension or paradoxical movement of the JVP. On cross sectional imaging thickening of the pericardium to greater than 2mm can be seen and the fibrosis causes a restriction in distensibility. The right ventricle, being more compliant than the left, becomes flattened and furthermore there can be curvature of the septum towards the left. Elsewhere, if the field of view permits, accessory signs such as pleural effusions and even ascites may be seen.
GPT3_explain: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is the most likely diagnosis because the CXR and CT scan show tree-in-bud features, which are indicative of lymphoma. The cardiac MRI also shows a 4mm pericardium, which is a common sign of lymphoma.

Qn_Text: A 36-year-old man was involved in a car accident where his car was driven at high speed into a wall. He was not wearing a seatbelt and was thrown forwards onto the steering wheel of his car. He has severe bruising over his anterior chest wall and is complaining of chest pain. A chest X-ray reveals a grossly widened mediastinum, deviation of the trachea to the right, and fractures of the first and second ribs. His observations are HR 94, BP 128/73, SaO2 99% on high flow oxygen. At which anatomical site is an injury MOST likely to have occurred in this case? Select ONE answer only.
B: Near the opening of the aortic valve
C: Near the point of origin of the brachiocephalic trunk
D: Near the point of origin of the left subclavian artery
Explanation:
Explanation:
Traumatic aortic rupture is a relatively common cause of sudden death following major trauma, particularly high-speed road traffic accidents (RTAs). Between 15-20% of deaths from RTAs are estimated to be due to this injury. Patients that survive the initial injury can make a full recovery if the aortic rupture is promptly recognized and treated.
Patients that survive tend to have an incomplete laceration near the ligamentum arteriosum of the aorta. Continuity is maintained by an intact adventitial layer or contained mediastinal haematoma that prevents immediate exsanguination and death.
It can be difficult to detect and may go unnoticed as many patients have no specific symptoms and other injuries may also be present clouding the picture.
Findings on chest X-ray can be helpful in making the diagnosis and include the following:
Fractures of 1st and 2nd ribs
Grossly widened mediastinum
Hazy left lung field
Obliteration of aortic knob
Deviation of trachea to the right
Presence of a pleural cap
Elevation and rightward shift of right mainstem bronchus
Depression of left mainstem bronchus
Obliteration of space between pulmonary artery and aorta
Deviation of oesophagus (or NG tube) to the right
  Helical contrast enhanced CT scanning has close to 100% sensitivity and specificity for aorta rupture, however CT scanning should be reserved for patients that are haemodynamically stable.
Treatment is with either primary repair or by resection of the torn segment and replacement with an interposition graft. Endovascular repair is also now an acceptable alternative approach.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the X-ray revealed a grossly widened mediastinum, which indicates that trauma has occurred in the chest area. The widened mediastinum would suggest that the trauma has occurred near the point of origin of the left subclavian artery, as this artery is located in the mediastinum. The fractures of the first and second ribs are also consistent with trauma to this area.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old woman undergoes an MRI scan for staging of her newly diagnosed cervical cancer. Which of the following features would prevent her from receiving fertility preserving surgery?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
C: Tumour within 1.5cm of the internal os
Explanation:
Explanation:
In an ideal world every trainee radiologist would have all the intricacies of staging for all tumour types committed to memory. A qualified subspecialist radiologist could reasonably be expected to be extremely familiar with the staging for cancers within their remit but for the majority of trainees it is simply not practical to memorise each and every staging scheme. As an overall strategy, the most important stages to understand are those which change the management for patients.
  MRI
On MRI a cervical cancer appears as hyperintense soft tissue on T2 and is isointense on T1. There is early enhancement with post-contrast fat saturated T1 sequences.
  Trachelectomy?
A trachelectomy (fertility preserving surgery) involves the removal of the cervix, upper vagina and parametrium. The uterus is ‘closed’ with a purse string suture which is designed to remain patent to allow the passage of menstrual blood. Any subsequent pregnancy should be delivered by caesarean section. Invasion of the cervical stroma does not necessarily preclude a trachelectomy, neither would central necrosis.
For cervical cancer there has recently been a big change in management strategy between stages IB1 (one B one), and IB2 (one B two). It is sometimes possible to preserve fertility for patients with stage I disease whereas once the disease has progressed to stage II fertility preserving surgery is inadequate. Clearly this can have huge implications for the patient if they have not yet completed their family. As surgical and oncological strategies are refined further it may well be that some patients beyond stage IB1 are offered fertility preserving surgery, with counselling regarding the likelihood of recurrence, at the discretion of the individual surgeon. Fortunately, owing to the success of the national screening programme for cervical cancer, the majority of patients have a low stage when they are diagnosed. Stages I and II are detailed below. Stages III and IV have not been included for the sake of brevity.
  Stage
Description
Trachelectomy
Hysterectomy
IA
Preclinical invasion
Yes
Yes
IB
1
Clinically visible lesion <2 cm
Yes
Yes
2
3
Clinically visible lesion 2-4 cm
Clinically visible lesion >4 cm
No
Yes
IIA
Extends into upper third of vagina
No
Yes
IIB
Invasion of the parametrium
No
No
  Hysterectomy?
The next abrupt change in management comes at stage IIB and consequently there is much in the literature on the importance of recognising parametrial invasion. The parametrium is fibrous tissue lateral to the cervix which extends superiorly up to the Fallopian tubes and is bounded inferiorly by the pelvic floor muscles – it lies between the layers of the broad ligament. If the cervical stroma (the smooth muscular layer deep to the epithelium, seen as a hypointense rim on T2w MRI) is intact, the negative predictive value for parametrial invasion is around 95%.
  Lymph nodes
The presence of involved lymph nodes is significant because these can be included in the radiotherapy fields. Regional lymph nodes for cervical cancer are pelvic, iliac and para-aortic nodes whereas inguinal lymph nodes would be considered metastatic (ie M1 in the TNM staging).
Most cervical cancer is squamous cell in origin but some can be adenocarcinoma. The literature is slightly variable regarding trachelectomy for adenocarcinoma however most sources agree that neuroendocrine and sarcomatous varieties of cervical cancer have recurrence rates too great for trachelectomy to be a viable consideration. There is a subtype of adenocarcinoma called minimal deviation adenocarcinoma which is associated with Peutz-Jegher syndrome.
  Summary
Cervical cancer is hyperintense on T2 and isointense on T1. The cervical stroma is seen as a black line on T2.
Stage IB2 cancers are not amenable to trachelectomy – this includes tumours larger than 4cm or with extension into the vagina or parametrium
Stage IIB cancers are not amenable to a hysterectomy – this includes invasion into the parametrium
Inguinal lymph nodes are considered metastatic (para-aortic are considered regional)
Most cervical cancer is squamous cell carcinoma
Peutz-Jegher syndrome is associated with minimal deviation adenocarcinoma
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 5. Squamous cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma is an aggressive type of cancer that is more likely to spread to other parts of the body and is therefore not suitable for fertility preserving surgery.
Cat_Long: This question falls under the category of Clinical Judgement.

Qn_Text: A 14-year-old girl complains of upper back pain and is taken to the GP by her mother. The GP finds a thoracic scoliosis on examination and requests x-rays. The x-rays show a 5mm sclerotic focus in the left pedicle of T8. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Osteoid osteoma
These are small benign tumours but which can be quite symptomatic, classically with pain relieved by aspirin. The majority form in the diaphyses of long bones but the posterior elements of the spine is another classic location.
The radiolucent nidus and symptoms of night pain in a young patient point to either an osteoid osteoma or an osteoblastoma. The final diagnosis comes down to size. <1.5cm is definitely an osteoid osteoma, and >2 cm is definitely an osteoblastoma. There is a nasty grey area somewhere between the two sizes.
On x-ray the radiolucent nidus may not be fully appreciated and the abnormality which is picked up will be the consequential sclerotic solid periosteal reaction. In the spine there may be a painful scoliosis concave towards the lesion as a result of adjacent muscular spasm. CT is used to confirm the diagnosis as the nidus is readily appreciable.
  Osteoblastoma
Osteoblastomas are quite rare, even for bone tumours. To all intent and purposes they can be considered as large osteoid osteomas. They occur in slightly older patients than osteoid osteomas but most patients are still under 30-years-old. Around a third arise in the posterior elements of the spine, sometimes giving a painful scoliosis, a further third can be found in the long bones and roughly the remaining third arise in the small bones of the hands and feet.
  Avascular necrosis - Scheuermann disease
Of the Eponymous avascular necroses, in general any bone can be affected at any age however there are distinct trends for many of them. Some of the prominent conditions are listed below:
  Eponym Bone Age
Kohler Navicular 4-6 years
Panner Capitellum 5-10 years
Sever Calcaneum Young children
Frieberg Metatarsal head (usually 2nd) Teenage women
Scheuermann Vertebral apophyses Children, teenagers
Blount Proximal medial tibial epiphysis Infants, juveniles and adolescents
Kienbock Lunate Young men or middle-aged women
Ahlback Medial femoral condyle (i.e. SONK) Women > 55years
Preiser Scaphoid Any age
GPT3_explain: Osteoid osteoma is the most likely diagnosis as it is the most common cause of thoracic scoliosis in adolescents. It is characterized by a small, well-defined sclerotic focus in the bone, which is what was seen on the x-rays.

Qn_Text: A fair-haired 6-year-old boy undergoes a CT chest for further investigation of recurrent chest infections. This demonstrates lower lobe predominant bronchiectasis. The heart is in the expected position. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia
This predominantly causes bronchiectasis in the middle and lower lobes. Only 50% have Kartagener’s syndrome (A triad of situs inversus, sinusitis and bronchiectasis), hence the normal heart position in the question. Affected men are infertile, and women are subfertile.
  ABPA
This is generally only seen in asthmatics and is characterised by central bronchiectasis particularly in the mid-zones and sometimes upper zones. Centrilobular nodules are also a feature.
  Aspiration
This classically causes lower lobar bronchiectasis, but not in this demographic without mention of risk factors for aspiration in the history.
  Cystic Fibrosis
This is causes bronchiectasis but predominantly affects the upper lobes. Don’t be fooled by the mention of fair hair which is a red-herring in this question.
  Middle Lobe Syndrome
This affects the middle lobe or lingula. Chronic atelectasis arises secondary to airway obstruction from any one of a multitude of different causes (some benign, some malignant) and associated bronchiectasis can develop. Other areas are not usually affected.
GPT3_explain: Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) is the most likely underlying diagnosis because it is the most common cause of bronchiectasis in young children. PCD is caused by a genetic defect of the cilia, which are the tiny hairs in the airways that help to move mucus and other particles out of the lungs. Symptoms of PCD include recurrent chest infections, coughing, and difficulty breathing. A CT chest scan can help to diagnose PCD by showing lower lobe predominant bronchiectasis, which is the most common imaging finding in PCD.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old lady undergoes a colposcopy for an abnormal smear result. The registrar notices some small yellowish lumps on the surface of the cervix. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Anatomy is the key to differentiating between the various female urogenital cysts most of which are, for the most part, asymptomatic incidental findings.
Skene duct cyst
These are retention cysts of the paraurethral ducts and usually they are asymptomatic. On MRI they are seen inferior to the pubic symphysis but lateral to the external urethral meatus. Signal characteristics reflect their cystic nature with high T2 signal but fluid-fluid levels may also be present if there has been intracystic haemorrhage.
Bartholin gland cyst
The bartholin glands secrete lubricating fluid into the inferior third of the vagina. They are found in highest numbers at the posterolateral aspect of the inferior vagina. Although usually asymptomatic, when infected or inflamed a Bartholin gland cyst can present as a painful lump. On MRI they show as high T1 signal owing to the mucoid fluid.
Urethral diverticulum (also known as urethrocele)
Dysuria, dyspareunia and post-void dribbling are classical for this condition. An outpouching of the urethral mucosa protrudes through the smooth muscle. This is seen on MRI as high T2 signal adjacent to or surrounding the urethra. Urinary stasis within the diverticulum predisposes patients to the formation of calculi, which can be seen as low signal on the T2 scan, and adenocarcinoma which will enhance with gadolinium.
Nabothian cyst
Blockage of the mucinous glands on the cervix causes tiny fluid-filled structures to form. These are asymptomatic and appear as small yellow bumps on colposcopy. On MRI they are cystic with high T2 signal and can show high T1 signal owing to their mucein content. They are an incidental finding.
Gartner duct cyst
These are usually found incidentally on MRI scans but can cause dyspareunia. They do not communicate with the urethra and would be unlikely to cause post-void dribbling. They are remnants of the Wolffian ducts and occur superiorly in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. On imaging they appear straightforwardly cystic. For the most part they occur sporadically but they can also be seen in conjunction with renal agenesis or ectopia and are also typical of a rare condition called Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome. This condition causes duplication of all or part of the female genital tract with unilateral haematometrocolpos and ipsilateral renal agenesis.
Ectopic ureter
The ureter normally inserts into the trigone of the bladder but ectopic insertions do occur. If these are below the external urethral sphincter the patient may experience dribbling symptoms however these are likely to have been present from birth. An ectopic ureter may be an isolated diagnosis or may form part of a VACTERL presentation and there is an affiliation to renal duplexity. Vesico-ureteric reflux is also very common since the normal valve mechanism is not present to prevent it. Abnormal ureteric anatomy is well demonstrated either with fluoroscopic studies or a highly T2 weighted sequence on an MRI scan.
      Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Gartner duct cysts are one of the most common causes of small yellowish lumps on the surface of the cervix, and they are generally benign. Cervical cancer is not usually associated with yellowish lumps, and the other options are not typically found on the cervix.

Qn_Text: A 69-year-old lady receiving palliative care for advanced cancer complains of worsening shortness of breath. Her CXR shows new reticular shadowing in the left lower lobe. Which of the following is the LEAST likely primary? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely primary.
  Lymphangitis carcinomatosis is easy to recognize on a scan but can be described in a number of different ways on paper. It occurs when tumour cells, spread via the lymphatics, accumulate in the connective tissues of the lung, in particular the interlobular septa. The classical description is as a smooth thick reticular polygonal network.
A mnemonic for the likely cancers is: Certain Cancers Spread By Plugging The Lymphatics (this is not an exclusive list). Of these Breast accounts for just over half of cases and gastric cancer accounts for most of the remainder.
Cervix
Colon
Stomach
Breast
Pancreas
Thyroid
Larynx (or lung – bronchogenic)
GPT3_explain: Basal cell carcinoma is the least likely primary because it is a type of skin cancer, and is not likely to cause respiratory symptoms or the observed changes on the CXR. The other options are all types of cancers that can metastasize to the lungs and cause respiratory symptoms.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are being asked to review the post-operative images of a 75-year-old man who had an emergency repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm two days previously. The aneurysm repair has normal post-operative appearances but there is a smoothly rounded and oblong dense collection in the subhepatic area. Unfortunately, the images of the CT scan performed at the time of his presentation have not been transferred over to your hospital yet for comparison but the report does not mention anything about it. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Vicarious excretion of water-soluble contrast material does occur via the hepatic route. It can sometimes be seen in cases of renal failure or obstruction and may also occur on CT scans taken 1-2 days after a previous CT scan in otherwise healthy patients.
40% of patients with a popliteal artery aneurysm have and abdominal aortic aneurysm
10% of patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm have a popliteal aneurysm
Patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm are at no increased risk of splenic artery aneurysms. Patients with fibromuscular dysplasia, collagen disorders and some vasculitides are at increased risk of developing visceral artery aneurysms.
GPT3_explain: The most likely explanation for the dense collection in the subhepatic area is a subcapsular haematoma. This is because the CT scan report did not mention anything about it, which suggests that the collection was not present at the time of the scan. A subcapsular haematoma is a common complication of abdominal aortic aneurysm repair and can occur when the aneurysm is repaired in an emergency situation. Additionally, the collection is described as being smoothly rounded and oblong, which is a typical appearance of a subcapsular haematoma. Therefore, the most likely explanation is a subcapsular haematoma.

Qn_Text: A 28-year-old man returns from a business trip abroad and presents with generalised abdominal tenderness and diarrhoea which started while he was away. He is suspected to have infective colitis and he brings with him a CD of a CT scan he had whilst abroad and you are asked to review it. The colonic wall is diffusely low in attenuation with mucosal enhancement and there is a small volume of ascites. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Infective colitis
Infective colitis causes oedematous mural thickening and mural enhancement with the different underlying organism affecting slightly different segments of bowel (albeit with much overlap). Pericolic fat stranding and ascites are variably seen.
Location
Organism
Diffuse involvement of whole colon
CMV and e-coli
Right sided colon
Salmonella and shigella
Left sided colon
Schistosomiasis
Rectosigmoid colon
Gonorrhoea, herpes, Chlamydia (LGV)
GPT3_explain: Shigella is the most likely responsible organism because it is a type of bacteria that is known to cause infective colitis. Symptoms of Shigella infection include abdominal pain, diarrhoea, fever, and nausea. The CT scan findings of a diffusely low attenuation colonic wall with mucosal enhancement and a small volume of ascites are consistent with Shigella infection.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing an x-ray with a colleague. Unfortunately there are no clinical details available at the time. The x-ray shows abnormal lumbar vertebra with posterior scalloping affecting L2-4. You notice that the epiphyses of the iliac crests have fused. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The apophyses of the iliac crests appear around the age of 12 and are usually fused by the age of 15 in girls or 17 in boys.
This precludes Hurler syndrome, as an answer to this question, as Hurler syndrome is usually fatal by this age.
Much is made of the finding of vertebral scalloping. It is caused by pressure effect on the spine either of an abnormal structure (such as a mass) or of the normal CSF pulsations on abnormally soft bone (such as achondroplasia). It can be seen affecting the anterior aspect of the vertebral body, or the posterior aspect within the vertebral canal.
  Vertebral body scalloping
Anterior
Posterior
Retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement (Lymphoma, TB)
Dural ectasia (NF1, connective tissue disorders)
AAA
Intraspinal mass
  Mucopolysaccharidoses
  Achondroplasia
  Acromegaly
GPT3_explain: Scheuermann disease is a disorder of the spine that is characterized by abnormal posterior scalloping of the vertebral bodies, as well as fusion of the epiphyses of the iliac crests. The combination of these two findings on the x-ray is most indicative of Scheuermann disease, making it the most likely explanation.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man presents to his GP with worsening back pain and stiffness. Plain radiographs show some slight sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints bilaterally with small vertebral syndesmophytes in the lumbar spine. He is referred to an orthopaedic consultant who is concerned he may have ankylosing spondylitis and requests an MRI scan. Regarding MRI in ankylosing spondylitis, which of the following is NOT correct? Select ONE answer only.
A: Sagittal SIJs - best sequence for the SIJs
B: Axial spine - to evaluate disc herniation
C: Sagittal spine - to evaluate facet joints
D: STIR - useful for bone marrow abnormalities
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note this question asks which answer is NOT correct.
  T1 fat sat - useful for visualisation of bony erosions and new bone formation
T1 fat sat post contrast - useful for detecting bone marrow abnormalities (but so is STIR, so contrast is not an absolute requirement for imaging ankylosing spondylitis).
STIR - useful for detecting bone marrow abnormalities in the SIJs and spine
T2 fat sat - useful for detecting oedema
  Coronal SIJ - ideally this should be taken parallel to the long axis of the sacrum, the better to view the SIJs, both SIJs can be seen on each image for comparison.
Axial SIJ - ideally this should be at 90 degrees to the modified coronal plane and is used to evaluate the ligamentous portion of the SIJs.
Axial spine - useful if co-existing disc herniation present but not ordinarily included otherwise
Sagittal spine - useful to evaluate facet and costovertebral joints
  Ankylosing spondylitis
This disease usually presents in early adulthood with gradual onset of back pain. There is a male preponderance, though it can affect women too. The vast majority (>90%) of patients are HLA-B27 positive. Radiologically the late features are classical with:
Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis
Enthesopathy - calcified tendon insertion sites
Bamboo spine - vertebral syndesmophytes, particularly in the thoracolumbar spine
Dagger sign - spinous process fusion
Erosion, then fusion at the symphysis pubis, costochondral, costovertebral and sternoclavicular joints
Thoracic manifestations: upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis, pericarditis, aortic root dilatation
Early features are far more subtle and require a higher index of suspicion
Enthesopathy - high signal on MRI at tendon insertion sites
Romanus lesions - triangular shaped oedema at the corners of vertebral bodies
Andersson lesions - bony oedema in the vertebral bodies adjacent to the disks.
Oedema in the sacroiliac joints.
  Patients with advanced ankylosing spondylitis are at increased risk of pathological fractures due to fusion. These can be pelvic fractures following a simple fall, or chance fractures of the spine (involving all three columns - in ankylosing spondylitis, these fractures are also sometimes termed chalk-stick or carrot fractures).
GPT3_explain: STIR is not the best sequence for evaluating bone marrow abnormalities in ankylosing spondylitis. STIR is a T2-weighted sequence that is used to detect areas of increased signal intensity due to inflammation, whereas T1-weighted sequences are more useful for detecting bone marrow abnormalities.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment option?
