Qn_Text: A 58-year-old gentleman presents with a change in bowel habit and weight loss. He has a history of mild asthma and stable angina. Colonoscopy demonstrates a high rectal mass. CT does not identify the presence of any metastatic disease. Rectal MRI is performed to complete local staging. The tumour is easily identifiable and there is no breach of the muscularis mucosa. A fusiform dilatation of the superior rectal vein is demonstrated with subcentimeter, rounded nodes demonstrating restricted diffusion along the vascular pedicle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of the patient? Select ONE answer only.
E: AP resection followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Explanation:
Explanation:
The muscularis mucosa is present only in the upper part of the rectum and is located outside of the lamina propria but inside the muscularis propria. Involvement of the muscularis mucosa therefore means the lamina propria too must also be involved. Involvement of the muscularis propria (and therefore by definition the muscularis mucosa and the lamina propria) in rectal tumours (particularly invasion into the perirectal fat of over 5mm) means neoadjuvant chemo and radiotherapy is necessary prior to resection (T3). Often low grade T3 (T3a and T3b) cancers now are treated with primary surgery (particularly in older patients with a shorter overall anticipated follow-up time).
However, if there is evidence of spread along the vessels (classically fusiform dilatation of the superior rectal vein or micronodularity along the vascular pedicle) then neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is the mainstay of treatment with re-staging after the treatment course.
  Rectal cancer
MRI The muscularis propria is the outer wall of the rectum and shows up as low signal on T2 weighted sequences.
Since the rectum (like the oesophagus) does not have a serosa, once spread beyond the muscularis propria into the mesorectal fat has occurred (ie a T3 tumour), nodal involvement is also feasible. The mesorectal fascia is a thin plane of connective tissue which contains fat, the rectum, local lymph nodes as a distinct anatomical entity and is of paramount importance in rectal cancer management. Spread beyond the mesorectal fascia denotes a T4 tumour. MRI is excellent for local staging of rectal cancer because the mesorectal fascia is seen clearly as a thin black line on T2 weighted sequences and its involvement or lack thereof can be readily discerned. In contrast, the tumour appears as intermediate signal on T2, distorting the normal anatomy.
The fascia is also referred to as the ‘CRM’ which stands for circumferential resection margin and relates to the surgical operation performed for rectal tumours, namely a total mesorectal excision (TME). The proximity of the tumour extent to the CRM is prognostically important; tumours with a >1mm margin before they reach the CRM are far less likely to recur. A <1mm margin is taken as involvement of the CRM.
GPT3_explain: Answer: 5. AP resection followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy. The rectal MRI has identified a fusiform dilatation of the superior rectal vein and subcentimeter, rounded nodes demonstrating restricted diffusion along the vascular pedicle. These findings are suggestive of a locally advanced rectal cancer, and the most appropriate next step in the management of the patient would be an AP resection followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy. This approach is known to be the most effective in treating locally advanced rectal cancer and is the gold standard of care.

Qn_Text: A 50-year-old man is involved in a road traffic accident and is found to have a fracture of his left hip bone on a CT scan. Which of the following bones together form the hip bone? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The two hip bones form part of the bony pelvis and is made up of three parts that start to fuse around the age of 16: the ilium, the pubis and the ischium. Once fused a cup-shaped socket is formed (the acetabulum) that articulates with the head of the femur to form the hip joint.
  The hip bones have three articulations:
Hip joint – with the head of the femur
Sacroiliac joint – between the sacrum and the ilium
Pubic symphysis – between the left and right pubic bones
  The ossification centres of the hip bone (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the hip bone is also known as the coxal bone, and it is formed by the fusion of three bones: the ilium, the ischium, and the pubis. The femur is the bone of the thigh, and it articulates with the hip bone to form the hip joint.

Qn_Text: You are reporting a CT scan on a 64-year-old man who has had intermittent episodes of rectal bleeding. The main finding is of early opacification of the ileocolic vein. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Angiodysplasia
The colon is rich with blood vessels and, with increasing age, there can be some dilatation and dysplasia of these vessels. This usually occurs on the antimesenteric border and can give rise to both mild intermittent bleeding or larger lower gastrointestinal haemorrhages. Angiodysplasia is the most common vascular lesion of the gastrointestinal tract.
The caecum and ascending colon, supplied by the right colic artery, are most frequently affected but angiodysplasia can occur on the rest of the colon or the small bowel too. On an angiogram, a cluster of arterially enhancing vessels may be seen on the antimesenteric border of the bowel but a more frequent finding is that of early opacification of the draining ileocolic vein. The ileocolic vein is also often found to have become dilated and tortuous, remaining opacified in a late venous phase too.
Around 20% of patients have concurrent aortic stenosis.
    The right colic artery from Gray's Anatomy
    Mesenteric angina
Mesenteric angina is a clinical syndrome caused by episodic sup-optimal perfusion of the small or large bowel. This typically occurs in the post-prandial setting when the oxygen requirements of the stomach increase and it 'steals' the blood supply from the stenotic, compromised supply to the rest of the bowel. The radiological findings are akin to a chronic type of mesenteric ischaemia or ischaemic colitis. Chronic ischaemia leads to stricturing and, unlike malignant strictures, these will be smooth in nature. By contrast, the other features listed can all be found in an acute setting.
  Ischaemic colitis
Anything that compromises the vascular supply to the bowl can cause ischaemic colitis. This can be a thrombus, mechanical strangulation or a prolonged period of hypotension (most commonly encountered in the setting of an ITU patient). Mucosal hyperenhancement can be seen on CT as a consequence of increased permeability in the setting of a shocked bowel (other signs of shock include hyperenhancement of the adrenal glands and a slit like configuration to the inferior vena cava). Mucosal necrosis leads to oedema and haemorrhage with sloughing as the dead layer of cells falls away. Necrosis of the submucosal and muscularis layers leads to stricturing. Thumbprinting is a term derived from the appearances of a non-specifically oedematous bowel on a barium study. The same appearance on CT is less suggestive of the classic thumbprint indentations seen on fluoroscopy but the term is still used. Loss of integrity of the mucosa allows gas to enter the mesenteric vessels and thereby the portal venous system. Gas in the periphery of the liver is suggestive of portal venous gas (as opposed to aerobilia) and is a late sign of ischaemic bowel associated with a poor outcome.
The involvement of different areas of the bowel can give a clue as to the affected vessel. The watershed areas are those at the very fringes of supply from the different mesenteric arteries and are the first to be affected in low flow states.
  Crohn's disease
Crohn's disease is characterised by discontinuous (skip lesions) transmural non-caseating granulomatous inflammation. By contrast, ulcerative colitis is characterised by continuous mucosal inflammation. Crohn's disease is usually diagnosed in adolescence or young adulthood and patients present with non-specific abdominal pains, diarrhoea, weight loss and anaemia. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the entire length of the gastrointestinal tract, in contrast to ulcerative colitis which affects only the colon, but owing to the high concentration of lymphoid tissue in the terminal ileum the vast majority of patients will have terminal ileal involvement, in particular thickening of the iliocaecal valve. Aphthous ulceration is common and on endoscopy a cobblestone appearance to the mucosa can be seen where the thickened and oedematous wall is broken up by deep longitudinal fissures. Deep ‘rosethorn’ ulcers can be seen on fluoroscopic studies. Strictures and fistulae characterise the chronic sequela of this disease.
  Ulcerative colitis
Whereas Crohn's disease causes discontinuous transmural inflammation in ulcerative colitis it is a continuous segment of bowel which is affected beginning at the rectum and progressing proximally. Additionally, it is only the mucosa and submucosa which are affected. Patients present with symptoms of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhoea and experience relapses and periods of remission with the disease. In general, the small bowel is spared with the exception of the terminal ileum which can be affected in a so-called ‘backwash ileitis’ manner. On imaging colonic mucosal hyperenhancement can sometimes be seen, along with mucosal oedema (so-called thumbprinting). On fluoroscopic studies pseudopolyps can be seen – these are actually islands of normal mucosa or granulation tissue surrounded on all sides by inflammation. In the chronic phase the colon may become narrower, smooth and featureless as the haustral markings are lost. This is described as a lead-pipe appearance.
GPT3_explain: Angiodysplasia is a condition that is characterized by the presence of abnormal, enlarged and fragile blood vessels in the gastrointestinal tract. Early opacification of the ileocolic vein is a common finding in angiodysplasia, and it is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's age and the intermittent episodes of rectal bleeding.

Qn_Text: An 85-year-old man who has been a lifelong smoker is found to have lymphangitis carcinomatosis on a CT scan. What is the most likely primary?
Explanation:
Explanation:
There are four pieces of information given to us in this question on which to base our answer.
The patient is male
The patient is elderly
The patient is a heavy smoker
The patient has lymphangitis carcinomatosis
Of the cancers listed only pancreatic, lymphoma or adrenal cancers have any association with smoking and of these it is pancreatic cancer which stands out as the most closely associated. The patient is certainly in an appropriate demographic for pancreatic cancer. Furthermore, alongside thyroid cancer, pancreatic cancer is the most widely appreciated of those provided to cause lymphangitis carcinomatosis. The final piece of evidence to consider is that in terms of population statistics pancreatic cancer and lymphoma (non-Hodgkin lymphoma) have the highest incidence among those listed.
Lymphangitis carcinomatosis is easy to recognize on a scan but can be described in a number of different ways on paper. It occurs when tumour cells, spread via the lymphatics, accumulate in the connective tissues of the lung, in particular the interlobular septa. The classical description is as a smooth thick reticular polygonal network.
A mnemonic for the likely cancers is: Certain Cancers Spread By Plugging The Lymphatics (this is not an exclusive list). Of these Breast accounts for just over half of cases and gastric cancer accounts for most of the remainder.
Cervix
Colon
Stomach
Breast
Pancreas
Thyroid
Larynx (or lung – bronchogenic)
GPT3_explain: Lymphangitis carcinomatosis is a condition in which cancer cells spread from a primary tumor to the lymphatic system. In this case, the most likely primary tumor is lymphoma, since the patient is an elderly smoker. Lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, and it is more common in smokers.

Qn_Text: A teaching case is being reviewed which shows an epidural mass extending for the length of 3 vertebral bodies in the thoracic spine. Dumbbell shape extension through the neural foramina is also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The term dumbbell is classically used to describe the appearance of neurofibromas, but the question specifically asks for an epidural lesion. The only epidural lesion in the answers provided is a chordoma, hence this is the correct answer. Around 15% of neurofibromas are extradural and a further 15% have both extradural and intradural components.
  Dumbell lesions of the spinal cord are those which extend from the canal to the paravertebral space via the exit foramina and are a classic finding for the following intradural tumours:
Schwannoma
Neurofibroma
Ganglioneuroma
Neuroblastoma
Meningioma
In the case described the lesion is extradural so the description of ‘dumbbell extension’ is a little stretched. Chordomas are aggressive lesions which tend to grow large and are usually very big at the time of diagnosis. Bony erosion and paravertebral spread is common but this is slightly different from the more benign sounding feature of ‘dumbell extension’. Technically though there is indeed spread from the canal to the paravertebral space through the exit foramina. The information provided in the question is irritatingly (but deliberately) sparse though.
The table below is by no means exhaustive but gives a good grounding on the topic of intra vs extramedullary lesions.
  Intradural, intramedullary
Intradural, extramedullary
Extradural (aka epidural)
Epidermoid
Osteosarcoma
Ependymoma
Osteoblastoma
Astrocytoma
Meningioma
Osteoid osteoma
Haemangioblastoma
Schwannoma
Metastases
Metastases
Neurofibroma*
Chordoma
Cavernous angioma
Paraganglioma
  *Neuofibromas - Around 70% of these are intradural/extramedullary. Of the remaining 30%, half are pure extradural and half are mixed extradural and intradural.
GPT3_explain: Chordoma is the most likely diagnosis for this case because it is a rare, slow-growing malignant tumor that usually occurs in the spine and is characterized by an epidural mass extending for the length of multiple vertebral bodies and dumbbell shape extension through the neural foramina. Chordomas are most commonly found in the sacrum and cervical spine, but can also occur in the thoracic spine.

Qn_Text: The hepatic portal vein is most commonly formed by the union of the splenic vein and which other vein? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The hepatic portal vein is the major vein of the hepatic portal venous system and carries blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver. It carries blood rich in nutrients extracted from food in the gastrointestinal tract and also carries toxins for processing by the liver. It is responsible for roughly 75% of the total blood flow to the liver.
The hepatic portal vein is usually formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein. In some individuals also receives blood from the following veins:
Gastric veins
Cystic veins
Inferior mesenteric vein
Para-umbilical veins
  The hepatic portal vein and its tributaries (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose the answer "2. Superior mesenteric vein" because the hepatic portal vein is formed by the union of the splenic vein and the superior mesenteric vein. The other veins listed are not involved in the formation of the hepatic portal vein.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: The seventh cranial nerve normally supplies all of the following muscles except which of the following? Select one answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The masseter muscle is a muscle of mastication and as such is supplied by the fifth cranial nerve. The anterior belly of diagastric also happens to be supplied by the fifth cranial nerve. The muscles of facial expression include the buccinators, occipitalis and platysma.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 4, Stapedius, because the seventh cranial nerve (facial nerve) does not supply the muscle of stapedius. The facial nerve supplies the muscles of facial expression, posterior belly of digastric, masseter, and stylohyoid, but not the stapedius muscle.

3. A question about a specific laboratory test.

Qn_Text: A 20-year-old man undergoes an x-ray of his right knee which shows a small effusion despite a normal joint space. He goes on to have an MRI. On the MRI there is nodular thickening of the synovium in the suprapatellar space which returns high signal on both T1 and T2 weighted sequences. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Lipoma arborescens
This condition can affect children or adults and is thought to be a reaction to chronic inflammation of the synovium leading to extensive fatty infiltration of the synovium. It is almost always the knee which is affected. Plain radiographs will show only an effusion, which may be large, but on MRI there is frond-like or nodular synovial proliferation which returns fat-signal according to the different sequences used. The signal should be high on T1 and T2 but suppress on fat-saturated sequences. Post-contrast the synovium itself will enhance. Treatment is by synovectomy.
PVNS - Pigmented villonodular synovitis
The classic joint to be affected by PVNS is the knee but it can also occur at other large joints. Usually only one joint is affected in each patient. On x-ray the only sign may be a large joint effusion. Large subchondral cysts can also be seen. On MRI however, the appearances are characteristic. Haemorrhagic proliferation of the synovium in a frond-like villonodular fashion gives rise to the classic low signal 'feathery' sea-anemone-like finding. On susceptibility weighted sequences there is blooming artefact owing to the presence of haemosiderin. Patients are usually middle-aged and treatment is with synovectomy although there is a high rate of recurrence.
If the patient is male, the usual differential diagnosis for PVNS is of haemophilic arthropathy owing to the presence of blood products there too. PVNS appears as a differential diagnosis for subarticular lucent bone lesions due to the formation of large subchondral cysts.
Rheumatoid arthritis
A joint effusion and synovial thickening (which would avidly enhance post-contrast) is a worthy description for rheumatoid arthritis however the high-fatty signal of the synovium is not a feature of rheumatoid arthritis. As the condition develops, patients with rheumatoid arthritis exhibit erosive changes with cartilage loss, bony erosions and marrow oedema.
SAPHO (Synovitis, acne, palmoplantar pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteitis)
This disease is thought to be a variant of psoriatic arthropathy. The cutaneous manifestations may not be apparent at diagnosis (like psoriatic arthropathy) but hyperostosis and osteolysis and ankylosis of the sternocleidomastoid joint is absolutely typical. On a nuclear medicine bone scan, bilateral uptake in the sternoclavicular joints and manubrium is called a ‘bull’s head’ sign. About a third of patients also have spinal disease with paravertebral ossifications and osteosclerosis. Unilateral sacroiliitis may also occur. Appearances can be quite striking on CT. In the knees, ankles and small joints of the hands there may be inflammation of the joints with juxta-articular osteoporosis.
Haemophilic arthropathy
The larger joints are most at risk for this disease, and the knee is particularly classical. On an xray there may only be a joint effusion in early disease but erosions and subchondral cysts develop. In particular there may be widening of the intercondylar notch (for which there is a differential diagnosis of: JIA/RA, Psoriatic arthropathy, TB and haemophilia) due to pannus formation. Also classical is epiphyseal overgrowth secondary to hyperaemia.
On an MRI there may well be nodular deposits on the synovium however the presence of blood degradation products renders these very low in signal on all sequences with blooming artefact present on gradient echo sequences or similar. If a haemarthrosis is present, the signal of the fluid will change depending on the chronicity of the event.
A haemophilic pseudotumour occurs in around 1-2% of patients with haemophilia. The presence of blood degradation products leads to a wide variety of intralesional signal patterns. The lesions are usually surrounded by a low signal haemosiderin rim though. Lesions can arise within bone (intra-osseous) or in soft tissues (usually muscular). Growth and pressure effects on adjacent bone can cause scalloping.
GPT3_explain: SAPHO (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, and osteitis) is a rare disorder characterized by a combination of bone and joint inflammation, skin lesions, and bony overgrowth. The MRI findings of nodular thickening of the synovium in the suprapatellar space with high signal on both T1 and T2 weighted sequences are consistent with a diagnosis of SAPHO.

Qn_Text: An 88-year-old man with a long history of COPD is admitted complaining of acute severe abdominal pain. While waiting to be clerked he begins vomiting and the admitting doctor suspects that he may have a small bowel obstruction. He undergoes a CT scan which shows multiple dilated loops of small bowel and a Spigelian hernia. Which of the following would most accurately describe the radiological findings of this situation?
A: Herniated loop of bowel passing lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle
B: Herniated loop of bowel passing through the Hesselbach triangle
C: Herniated loop of bowel passing medial to the inferior epigastric vein
D: Herniated loop of bowel passing superomedial to the pubic tubercle
E: Herniated loop of bowel passing between pectineus and obturator externus muscles
Explanation:
Explanation:
Abdominal wall hernias
Hernias can occur at any age but are increasingly prevalent with increasing age. Conditions which increase intra-abdominal pressures predispose patients to developing hernias. These might be entities such as constipation or respiratory conditions associated with excess coughing such as COPD.
Hernia
Landmarks
Feature
Femoral
Inferolateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to the femoral vein
More common in women
Direct inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle, medial to the inferior epigastric vein
Through Hesselbach triangle
Indirect inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle and lateral to the inferior epigastric vein
Most common abdominal hernia
Obturator
Between pectineus and obturator externus muscles, through the obturator foramen
Rare
Spigelian
Inferolateral abdominal wall defect, lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle
May be congenital and associated with cryptorchidism
  Indirect inguinal hernias pass through the inguinal canal, taking in both the deep and superficial rings as they do. The deep ring is lateral to the internal epigastric vessels.
Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the conjoint tendon medial to the internal epigastric vessels and enter the scrotal sac through the superficial ring. They pass through the Hesselbach triangle which is composed of the inferior epigastric vessels, rectus abdominus and the inguinal ligament.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because a Spigelian hernia is a hernia that occurs when a loop of intestine passes through the abdominal wall medial to the inferior epigastric vein. The other answers do not accurately describe the radiological findings of this situation.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about management, what is the best course of treatment?

This question falls under category 3: A question about management, what is the best course of treatment?

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old lady presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. A CTPA scan is requested to rule out a pulmonary embolus. This shows an invasive tumour arising from the pericardium. Multiple lung and bone metastasis are also present. The reporting radiologist suggests the pericardial tumour is likely to be a metastasis. What is the most likely origin of the primary?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Cardiac metastasis are thirty times more common than a primary malignancy with the pericardium being the most usual location. The most common situation is from a lung primary, although if the pericardium is affected through local invasion (as opposed to a tumour arising from the pericardium itself), then pleural mesothelioma is more likely. The most common manifestation of pericardial malignancy is a pericardial effusion, followed by pericardial lymphadenopathy.
GPT3_explain: Colorectal cancer is the most likely origin of the primary because it is the most common type of cancer to metastasize to the pericardium. Metastases to the pericardium from other primary sources, such as breast, pleura, lung, and melanoma, are much less common.
Cat_Long: This question would fall under the category of clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old patient presents with upper abdominal pain and raised inflammatory markers. Contrast-enhanced CT demonstrates a subphrenic abscess adjacent to the stomach. CT-guided percutaneous drainage is considered but is difficult to access due to the location and adjacent structures. Which of the following procedural techniques is LEAST beneficial to facilitate drainage?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The Transplenic route of drainage is least likely to be the preferred route due to the risk of non–self-limiting haemorrhage leading to hypotensive shock.
All interventions in the upper abdomen involve the risk of pleural complications. In most cases, pleural transgression cannot be avoided during subphrenic abscess drainage. Therefore, it is essential to monitor the patient closely for pneumothorax following the procedure.
CT gantry tilt and adjusting patient positioning may significantly improve the accessibility to the target area.
In cases of subphrenic abscess Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS), intervention techniques can also be considered to perform puncture and drainage via the transmural route where percutaneous treatment has been difficult. The stomach is most commonly traversed for percutaneous drainage of pancreatic collections and is the preferred route for transmural drainage.
GPT3_explain: Adjusting the CT gantry angle would be the least beneficial technique to facilitate drainage because it would not provide direct access to the abscess. It would only change the angle of the imaging to provide a better view of the abscess, but would not provide a direct route for drainage. Endoscopic transgastric drainage, pleural transgression, and transplenic percutaneous drainage are all direct access techniques that would be more beneficial for drainage.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the chest radiograph of a baby boy born recently. He has developed hypoxia and required admission to the neonatal unit. Which of the following diagnoses is correctly associated with the likely findings on x-ray? Select ONE answer only.
A: Transient tachypnoea of the newborn - prominent hila markings, effusions
B: Hyaline membrane disease - granular, hyperinflated lungs
C: Meconium aspiration - coarse lung markings, hypoinflation
Explanation:
Explanation:
Neonatal Respiratory Distress © Medical Exam Prep
    Of the five main respiratory conditions of the neonate the differential diagnosis can be narrowed based on gestational age. The presence of hyperinflation can also be useful but may not always be present where feasible so should not be used as an absolute discriminator. If present, it is useful.
  Meconium aspiration
Meconium is sticky and causes a chemical pneumonitis in the lungs, seen as patchy consolidation. In addition, small globules of meconium entering bronchi and bronchioles of a decreasing calibre act as a ball-valve mechanism and lead to air trapping; thus the lung volumes of a baby with meconium aspiration may be increased. Air bronchograms are notably absent. The typical baby in a meconium aspiration situation is post-term.
  Transient tachypnoea of the newborn (TTN)
The classical patient for TTN would be a term baby born by caesarean section to a diabetic mother. During normal vaginal delivery the compression of the baby as it descends the birth canal acts to squeeze fluid out from its lungs. This mechanism is all but absent during a caesarean section. Consequently, these babies are born with an excess of retained fluid. The CXR of an affected baby will show bilateral symmetrical air space opacification with air bronchograms, fluid in the fissures and pleural effusions. This peaks in severity at 24hrs but resolves by three days.
  Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD) also known as surfactant deficient disease (SDD)
It is to reduce the likelihood of this disease developing that a woman in pre-term labour will be offered a steroid injection. The steroids help the neonatal lungs to develop faster and increase the likelihood of their being able to produce surfactant once delivered. Where there is surfactant deficiency the alveoli collapse. The CXR will show a granular opacification throughout both lungs which progresses to bilateral ground glass opacification with air bronchograms. If exogenous surfactant is given to the baby there may be asymmetrical improvement in the appearances depending on how much reaches each lung. Of note HMD does not cause pleural effusions. Finally a normal CXR at 6hrs post delivery excludes HMD.
  Neonatal pneumothorax
Usually chest radiographs are performed with the baby lying down. The free gas in the pneumothorax rises to the superior part of the baby and therefore the classical apical contour seen in adult pneumothoraces, is lost. Instead unilateral hyperlucency may be seen and any pleural line should be regarded with extreme suspicion. A deep sulcus sign occurs when the gas collects at the anteroinferior aspect of the thoracic cavity, outlining the costophrenic angle sharply at its most inferior extent. The morbidity and mortality relating to undiagnosed neonatal pneumothorax is such that if there is any doubt further views such as a cross table lateral or a lateral decubitus view should be performed without delay.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because meconium aspiration is a common cause of hypoxia in newborns and is associated with findings of coarse lung markings and hypoinflation on chest radiographs. These findings are consistent with the clinical presentation of hypoxia in this patient.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You review the scans of a 25-year-old male trauma patient with a suspected spinal cord injury. Which of following segmental nerve roots is correctly matched with its corresponding myotome? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The key myotomes are:
C5 – Deltoid
C6 – Wrist extensors
C7 – Elbow extensors
C8 – Finger flexors to middle finger (flexor digitorum profundus)
T1 – Small finger abductors (abductor digiti minimi)
L2 – Hip flexors (Iliopsoas)
L3, L4 – Knee extensors
L4, L5 & S1 – Knee flexion
L5 – Ankle and big toe dorsiflexors
S1 – Ankle plantar flexors
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the C7 nerve root provides innervation to the elbow extensors, which are responsible for extending the elbow joint. The other options are incorrect because the C6 nerve root provides innervation to the deltoid muscle, the C7 nerve root provides innervation to the abductor digiti minimi muscle, the T1 nerve root provides innervation to the flexor digitorum profundus muscle, and the L3 and L4 nerve roots provide innervation to the iliopsoas muscle.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 38-year-old woman presents to A&E with acute left-sided weakness. As part of her initial investigations, she has a CXR which shows a few soft tissue density masses in the left lung. Her only past medical history is of recurrent epistaxis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
In the real world there are many other explanations which could explain this scenario however of the five provided the answer must be something which connects the presence of a lung mass to an acute infarction. Usually the lungs are an excellent filter for micro-emboli however in the presence of a pulmonary AVM (seen as a mass on CXR) these can enter the systemic circulation leading to a CVA. Discounting the epistaxis, breast cancer metastasis would not be an unreasonable differential diagnosis, with the left sided weakness consequent on a cerebral metastasis; certainly breast cancer itself is far more common than Rendu-Osler-Weber syndrome.
  Rendu-Osler-Weber syndrome (also known as hereditary haemorrhagic telangiectasia)
There are three separate vascular manifestations of this syndrome; telangiectasias, AVMs and aneurysms. The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and the vast majority of patients will have a positive family history. Hepatic and pulmonary AVMs are a known association and of patients with a pulmonary AVM or AVMs, the prevalence of Rendu-Osler-Weber syndrome is also reasonably high. Pulmonary AVMs have their own spectrum of complications including:
Paradoxical emboli – TIAs and CVAs
Septic emboli – cerebral abscess
Hypoxia due to shunting
High output cardiac failure
In an exam question setting patients are often described as having epistaxis due to nasal telangiectasia, indeed most patients do suffer from frequent episodes. Cutaneous telangiectasias are also common, particularly affecting the lips as well as the oral mucosa and usually by the age of 40. Older patients in their 50s or 60s may experience GI bleeding secondary to angiodysplasia.
GPT3_explain: Rendu-Osler-Weber syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by recurrent epistaxis (nosebleeds) and the presence of telangiectasias (abnormal dilations of the small blood vessels). It is also associated with an increased risk of arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) in the lungs, which can present as soft tissue density masses on a CXR. Given the patient's history of recurrent epistaxis, this is the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 53-year-old man has AP and lateral radiographs of the right ankle after twisting it whilst playing football. There is no fracture seen, however a central, triangular radiolucent area is seen on the lateral projection in the talar dome. It is well defined with a narrow zone of transition and communicates with the joint space. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Geode
This is a subchondral cyst associated with osteoarthritis which should have communication with the joint space and be present in an older patient.
  Pseudo-cyst of calcaneus
This is a variation of the normal trabecular pattern centrally within the calcaneus. Will not have a crisp edge for this reason. Persistence of thin trabeculae and a visible nutrient foramen are supporting features.
  Unicameral bone cyst
This is a well-defined lesion with thick sclerotic edges and potentially a multiloculated appearance. Absence of calcification within the lesion is a key differentiator from intraosseous lipoma, although if fractured, a fallen fragment sign can be seen.
  Intraosseus lipoma
Calcification within the center of this lesion is a key feature which differentiates it from other lesions of plain film. Fat density on CT or MRI would also be a key differentiator.
  Chondroblastoma
The calcaneus, like the patella, is an epiphyseal equivalent, so any epiphyseal lesions should be considered a possibility in this bone. They usually arise eccentrically in the epiphysis, are lobuated with a thin sclerotic margin.
GPT3_explain: Unicameral bone cyst is a common diagnosis for a well-defined, central, triangular radiolucent area seen on the lateral projection in the talar dome. Unicameral bone cysts are benign lesions that are typically found in the epiphysis of long bones and are filled with fluid. They can communicate with the joint space and can cause pain and swelling. They are usually treated with aspiration and bone grafting.

Qn_Text: A 41-year-old lady undergoes a cardiac MRI with contrast following some non-specific chest pains. The following week she discovers she was pregnant during the scan and her midwife contacts you to ask for advice. Which of the following is correct? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: The risk to the foetus is small
B: When the baby is born it should have a thyroid function test during the first week of life
C: The patient should receive dialysis as soon as feasible
D: Gadolinium does not cross the placenta
E: The gadolinium administered during the scan is teratogenic to the foetus and termination should be considered
Explanation:
Explanation:
Gadolinium in pregnancy
Gadolinium also crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetus into the amniotic fluid. The chelated form of gadolinium in itself poses no risk to the foetus however the free form of gadolinium is teratogenic and the longer the foetus is exposed to the chelated gadolinium administered for the scan, the greater the risk of each molecule of gadolinium becoming dissociated from its chelate. For this reason therefore, gadolinium should only be administered in a patient known to be pregnant, if there is likely to be significant diagnostic benefit from the resultant images.
Gadolinium is undetectable in maternal blood 24 hours following administration.
  Imaging pregnant patients in suspected PE
A pregnant patient suspected to have a pulmonary embolus should undergo a chest x-ray to look for alternative causes of shortness of breath such as a lower respiratory tract infection, pleural effusions or a pneumothorax. In the event that they go on to have a VQ scan a chest radiograph is required for comparison.
Thereafter the patient should undergo bilateral lower limb venous dopplers if they have signs or symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. Around a third of pregnant patients who develop pulmonary emboli will have a deep vein thrombosis and for these patients treatment can be started on the basis of their DVT diagnosis without the need for further imaging. If the patient has no signs or symptoms of a DVT, they should proceed to a VQ scan or a CTPA.
The patient should be counselled that there is a small increase in the absolute risk of the foetus developing a childhood cancer following a maternal VQ scan but also that the absolute risk of maternal breast cancer is reduced compared to a CTPA.
  CTPA
CTPA imaging confers a lower dose to the foetus than V/Q scanning, although this effect is diminished in the third trimester as the gravid uterus becomes closer to the field of view.
Unfortunately however, CTPA confers a far greater dose to the breast tissue of the mothers at a time when the tissue is more radiosensitive than it would otherwise be in a non-pregnant woman.
A secondary consideration is the use of iodinated contrast. Iodine crosses the placenta and is excreted by the foetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid. Babies of mothers who have received iodinated contrast during pregnancy should be tested during their first week of life for thyroid suppression although there is little evidence in literature to suggest that many if any infants have developed hypothyroidism following maternal intravenous iodine exposure.
Technical factors to performing a CTPA scan in pregnant patients, if required, are also important to consider. Hyperdynamic circulation can render usual triggering bolus mechanisms suboptimal and raise the possibility of a non-diagnostic study.
  V/Q or Q only scanning
V/Q scanning confers a far lower breast dose to the mother but the dose to the foetus, particularly when small, can be greater owing to tracer accumulation within the solid organs of the mother. The mother should be encouraged to adequately hydrate and void frequently in the subsequent hours/days following a scan.
Many institutes choose to perform perfusion scanning only in pregnant women on the understanding that if the perfusion scan is normal then there is no need to go on to perform the ventilation study. The perfusion scan can also be performed at half the usual dose to further reduce the foetal-dose. Naturally doing so comes with the trade-off of lower sensitivity and specificity.
  Considerations during lactation
Less than 1% of injected iodine or gadolinium is excreted into breast milk and less than 1% of this is then absorbed by the baby's intestinal tract. Although these amounts are considered acceptably low as to not necessitate any breast-feeding cessation advice many families are understandably over-cautious. It is accepted that contrast agents are undetectable in blood 24hours after administration and so any mother wishing to 'pump-and-dump' despite the negligible risks need not do so for longer than a day. Care should, however, be given to counsel the family that it is possible for inadvertent weaning to occur even after short intervals and this should be factored in to any decision made by the family.
Following a nuclear medicine study the risks to the baby are two-fold; firstly from tracer excretion into the breast milk, but also through proximity to the mother during breast-feeding. Recommendations for breast-feeding interruption vary depending on the half-life of the tracer used. For perfusion imaging using technetium (half-life 6 hours) breast milk should be expressed for the first 24 hours following the scan. In theory, it need not be discarded but can safely be bottle-fed to the baby after these 24 hours have elapsed, however in practice many patients none-the-less choose to discard it.
Most tracers simply require adherence to a washout time but of note, the precautions following administration of Gallium-67 based tracers (most commonly used for pyrexia of unknown origin) are much more limiting and, practically speaking, unfortunately lead to complete cessation of breastfeeding. The half-life of Ga-67 is approximately 78 hours. Breastfeeding should, if time allows, be stopped for 2-4 weeks prior to the scan to allow the breast tissue to become less radiosensitive while the tracer circulates within the mother. Where this is an unacceptably long delay for the clinical state of the patient the study can be performed straight away anyway but in either case, milk should also be discarded for at least a further two weeks following the study. Clearly a disruption to breast-feeding of such a long time is far from ideal, even assuming that a patient who is sufficiently unwell as to need a PUO study is able to continue breast-feeding at all, and is likely to lead to complete cessation of breast-feeding. There are other ways to image PUO using Tc99m labelled white blood cells which can be considered.
GPT3_explain: Gadolinium does not cross the placenta because it is too large of a molecule to pass through the placental barrier. This means that the gadolinium administered during the scan is not likely to reach the foetus and therefore is not likely to cause any teratogenic effects.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about patient management and the best course of action.

Qn_Text: Which area in the bladder is formed by the two ureteral orifices and the urethra? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The urinary bladder is a hollow muscular organ situated at the base of the pelvis. In a normal adult it can accommodate between 300 and 600 mls of urine. A central nervous system response resulting in the perception of fullness and the need to void is usually triggered once the bladder volume reaches around 400 mls.
It is enveloped in extraperitoneal fat and connective tissue and is separated from the pubic symphysis by an anterior prevesical space called the space of Retzius.
The empty bladder is roughly pyramid shaped and has four surfaces:
A superior surface
Two inferolateral surfaces
A posterior surface
  The bladder can be divided into four areas:
The apex – which is located superiorly and points towards the superior edge of the pubic symphysis
The body – the large central portion located between the apex and the fundus
The fundus (base) – which is triangular in shape and located posteroinferiorly
The neck – which is the point where the fundus and inferolateral surfaces converge
  Urine enters the bladder via the ureters, which pierce its lateral aspect of the bladder in an oblique fashion. This creates a valve that prevents the backflow of urine. Urine exits via the urethra, which connects to the urinary meatus.
The trigone of the bladder is a smooth triangular region situated within the fundus of the bladder that is formed by the two ureteral orifices and the urethra.
  The bladder, urethra and penis (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose 1. Trigone because the trigone is the area in the bladder formed by the two ureteral orifices and the urethra. It is triangular in shape and is located at the base of the bladder.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the images of a 76-year-old man who had an MRI scan following an incidental finding of an elevated PSA during pre-op screening for an elective TURP. The scan shows a focus of likely prostate cancer in the left peripheral zone. By which scoring system should this lesion be evaluated? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
PI-RADS (Prostate imaging reporting and data system)
This scoring system (now on its second version) has been introduced to streamline prostate cancer reporting and improve inter-operator variability. The scoring system differs slightly between the transitional zone and the peripheral zone but overall, using a combination of the T2, DWI/ADC and dynamic contrast enhancement lesions are graded 1-5 depending on the likelihood of malignancy.
PRECISE (PC Radiological Estimation of Change in Sequential Evaluation)
The PRECISE guidelines have been proposed as a scoring system for evaluating the follow-up scans when patients are on 'active surveillance' management for their prostate cancer (Moore, et al. Eur Urol. 2017;71(4):648-655).
  1 - Resolution of previous features suspicious on MRI
2 - Reduction in volume and/or conspicuity of previous features suspicious on MRI
3 - Stable MRI appearance: no new focal/diffuse lesions
4 - Significant increase in size and/or conspicuity of features suspicious for prostate cancer
5 - Definitive radiologic stage progression
  PERCIST (Positron emission response criteria in solid tumours)
This is a scoring system used for PET/CT imaging to follow up lesions and determine progression. Below is a simplified summary of the different possible outcomes.
Complete metabolic response (CMR) - resolution of target lesions with no new lesions developing
Partial metabolic response (PMR) - 30% reduction in SUV (corrected for lean body mass) in the target lesions
Stable metabolic disease (SMD) - neither CMR, PMR nor PMD
Progressive metabolic disease (PMD) - >30% increase in SUV (corrected for lean body mass) or new lesions
  RECIST (Response evaluation criteria in solid tumours)
To better develop inter-operator agreement in cancer follow-up imaging the RECIST criteria were developed.
Target lesions are identified on the index staging scan and these lesions are evaluated on subsequent scans against size standards to determine whether there has been overall response to treatment or disease progression. Below is a simplified version of the different possible outcomes.
Disease response
Complete - disappearance of all target lesions
Partial - >30% decrease in the sum of the longest axes of all of the target lesions
Stable disease - grey area between partial response and disease progression
Disease progression - >20% increase in the sum of the longest axes of all of the target lesions
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because the PI-RADS2 scoring system is the most commonly used system for evaluating prostate cancer lesions on MRI scans. The PI-RADS2 scoring system uses a 5-point scale to assess the likelihood of a lesion being prostate cancer, with scores of 1-5 indicating increasing likelihood of a diagnosis of prostate cancer. This system is more accurate than other scoring systems, such as RECIST and PRECISE, which are used to evaluate other types of cancer.

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old-woman is reviewed with an eight-week history of worsening left lower neck pain that radiates out over the trapezius muscle. On examination there is no motor weakness but there is reduced sensation in a cape distribution over the lower neck and upper shoulder girdle. You suspect a diagnosis of cervical radiculopathy. Which interspace is most likely to have been affected in this case? Select ONE answer only.

Explanation:
The following table outlines the classic patterns of cervical radiculopathy:
  Nerve root Interspace Pain distribution Abnormalities
C4 C3-C4

  Reflex – None
C5 C4-C5
Neck
Shoulder

  Sensory – Lateral arm

  Sensory – Lateral forearm, thumb

  Sensory – Dorsal forearm, middle finger

  Sensory – Medial forearm, ulnar digits
  Reflex – None
T1 T1-T2 Ulnar forearm
Motor – Finger instrinsics
  Sensory – Ulnar forearm
  Reflex – None

C3-C4 is the most common interspace affected by cervical radiculopathy, as it is the most commonly compressed nerve root in the cervical spine.

Qn_Text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a fever and a lump on her neck. An ultrasound scan shows a thick-walled unilocular 3cm cyst anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and inferior to the parotid gland. The thyroid and salivary glands appear normal on the scan. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
A second branchial cleft cyst is usually described as being between the submandibular gland and the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
A first branchial cleft cyst is situated in the periparotid region.
A third branchial cleft cyst is situated at the base of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
Cystic hygroma are usually (but not exclusively) multilocular and are situated in the posterior triangle of the neck.
A thyroglossal duct cyst is usually midline or close to midline.
Fibromatosis coli is a fibrotic process which occurs in the sternocleidomastoid muscle and is usually found in the neonatal period following a difficult or instrumental delivery. On ultrasound there is enlargement of the sternocleidomastoid muscle itself but no mass per se. Most cases resolve spontaneously over the ensuing months.
  Neck Masses in Children © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the description of the location of the cyst (anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and inferior to the parotid gland) is consistent with a second branchial cleft cyst. Additionally, the presence of a fever is a common symptom of an infected second branchial cleft cyst, which further supports this diagnosis.

Qn_Text: An athletic 14-year-old boy is taken to A+E by his mum after developing a painful right hip. An x-ray demonstrates an irregular shaped bone adjacent to the ischial tuberosity. The avulsion of which muscle is most likely to have caused this injury?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Apophyseal injuries (avulsion fractures) are common in adolescents because the tendons are stronger than the secondary ossification centres. By definition they occur in the unfused skeleton.
Other avulsion fractures do occur in children and adults alike but those in the table all take place at secondary ossification centres around the pelvis.
Of note, in an adult the avulsion of the lesser trochanter suggests a metastasis, not a musculoskeletal injury.
  Apophyseal injuries
ASIS
Sartorius
AIIS
Rectus femoris (straight head)
Pubic ramus
Adductors, gracilis
Lesser trochanter
Iliopsoas
Ischial tuberosity
Hamstrings
GPT3_explain: The biceps femoris is the most likely muscle to have caused this injury because it is one of the two main muscles that make up the hamstring group, and it attaches to the ischial tuberosity, which is the area where the irregular shaped bone was found in the x-ray. Therefore, it is the most likely muscle to have caused the avulsion injury.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old woman develops rising inflammatory markers on the second day following her hysterectomy. Her surgeon suspects she has a large collection. Which of the following would be best to manage this patient? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
This question is deliberately vague. Although this can be frustrating for the candidate, it is representative of the degree of obscurity found in the exam at times.
CT is the mainstay of investigation for post-operative complications. Without any further suggestion of urinary tract problems, a CT urogram is not currently indicated. If the CT abdomen and pelvis shows features of a possible urinoma then a urographic phase CT could be performed subsequently, if necessary, to confirm damage to the urinary tracts.
An ultrasound guided drain may be useful once the diagnosis has been confirmed however a CT is required to delineate the pathology prior to planning an intervention.
GPT3_explain: Surgery is the best way to manage this patient because it is the most direct way to remove the collection and address the underlying cause of her rising inflammatory markers. Surgery would provide the most definitive diagnosis and treatment of the collection, which is likely causing the patient's symptoms.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical management, what is the best treatment?

Qn_Text: The interlobar arteries divide to form which arteries? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The arterial supply to the kidneys is from the renal arteries, two fast flowing arteries that arise from the abdominal aorta at the L2 vertebral level. As the abdominal aorta is situated slightly to the left of the midline the right renal artery is longer than the left. The kidneys receive approximately 20% of the cardiac output.
After arising from the aorta, the right renal artery passes behind the inferior vena cava, the right renal vein, the head of the pancreas, and the second part of the duodenum as it travels to the kidney. The left renal artery passes behind the left renal vein, the body of the pancreas and the splenic vein as it travels to the kidney. The left renal artery is crossed anteriorly by the inferior mesenteric vein.
The renal arteries then enter the kidney at thehila of the kidneys, which lie approximately in the transpyloric plane at the L1 vertebral level. At the hila the renal arteries divide into four or five segmental branches.
Each segmental branch divides to form the interlobar arteries that are situated on either side of every renal pyramid. These interlobar arteries then undergo further division to form the arcuate arteries.
The interlobular arteries are then given off at right angles from the side of the arcuate arteries, and head into the cortical substance. Once within the cortex a final division takes place with the interlobular arteries dividing to form the efferent arterioles.
In the outer two-thirds of the cortex, the efferent arterioles form the peritubular network. The inner third of the cortex is supplied by long, straight arteries known as the vasa recta.
      Image adapted from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Piotr Michal Jaworski CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose 3 because Interlobar arteries divide to form Interlobular arteries. Interlobular arteries are the arteries that branch off from the interlobar arteries and supply blood to the individual lobules of the kidneys.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old man collapses while playing golf. On arrival in A+E the blood pressure in his arms is found to be different. He is thought to have suffered a stroke and undergoes carotid Doppler study. This shows reversal of flow in his left vertebral artery with biphasic flow in his left axillary and brachial arteries. The right is normal. What is the diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The key to this question is ‘reversal of flow in the vertebral artery’. Subclavian steal syndrome occurs when blood supplying the arm (usually the left arm) travels via the ipsilateral vertebral artery in order to bypass a proximal obstruction of the subclavian artery. The distal subclavian artery ‘steals’ blood from the vertebral artery circulation. This gives rise to two different categories of symptoms:
Arm -  weaker pulses, numbness, paraesthesia, fingertip necrosis
Brain - syncope, ischaemic symptoms
The most likely cause of subclavian steal would be atherosclerosis. Takayasu aortitis can indeed cause subclavian steal but would not be at the top of a differential list without further prompts from the history. Likewise thoracic aortic dissection can also cause steal and would be a reasonable guess but subclavian steal as an answer is more accurate.
Blalock-Taussig surgery is performed in the management of Tetralogy of Fallot and is included as a differential here simply because the subclavian artery is (or used to be, prior to the advent of synthetic grafting) ligated during the procedure.
Similarly complications following repair of an aortic coarctation can also lead to subclavian steal.
GPT3_explain: Coarctation repair complication is the most likely diagnosis in this case, as the symptoms and findings (reversal of flow in the left vertebral artery with biphasic flow in the left axillary and brachial arteries) are consistent with a coarctation repair complication. Coarctation repair is a procedure used to treat a narrowing of the aorta, which can cause blood flow to be restricted or reversed in certain arteries. The reversal of flow in the left vertebral artery, along with the biphasic flow in the left axillary and brachial arteries, indicate that the patient has likely experienced a complication from a previous coarctation repair.

Qn_Text: A 76-year-old man is admitted with acute onset left sided weakness and facial droop. He is suspected to have a right MCA infarction. What would be the best test to demonstrate this acutely?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The available answers in this question are deliberately limited. In some centres CT perfusion is used to detect reversible acute ischaemia but this answer is not given. Unenhanced CT is the first test a patient suspected to have an acute infarction should undergo but this is largely to rule out haemorrhage should the patient be a candidate for thrombolysis therapy. The question, however, actually asks which test should be performed to detect the infarction and hence the answer is DWI. DWI is far superior to an unenhanced CT in confirming the presence of an acute infarction (except in the brainstem and medulla where there is a high false negative rate within the first 24hours). A DAT scan is a nuclear medicine test used in the differential diagnosis of Parkinsonism.
GPT3_explain: CT with visipaque is the best test to demonstrate a right MCA infarction acutely because it is a form of computed tomography (CT) imaging that uses a contrast agent, such as Visipaque, to enhance the visibility of the blood vessels and other structures in the brain. This type of imaging can help identify areas of decreased blood flow in the brain, which can help diagnose a stroke, such as a right MCA infarction.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about management, what is the best treatment?

This question falls under Question 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a patient with only one kidney. She has attended with a sign-language interpreter who explains that she also has abnormalities of her heart, neck and left shoulder. Which of the following is NOT a feature of Klippel-Feil syndrome? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which is NOT a feature of Klippel-Feil syndrome.
A third of cases have sensorineural deafness but bony deformities (and thus conductive deafness) of the middle ear are present in a number of cases too. Congenital ASD is associated with the syndrome, not VSD.
  Klippel-Feil syndrome (different from Klippel-Trenaunay-Weber syndrome: port-wine stains, localised hypertrophy and venous malformations)
Klippel-Feil syndrome is predominantly a segmentation anomaly which arises during foetal development and leads to cervical fusion of two or more vertebral bodies. C2-3 are most commonly involved, accounting for around half of cases. Thereafter C5-6 accounts for a further third and the remainder are made up from fusions at other levels. There are a multitude of associated features, the predominant ones of which include:
Renal abnormalities (of which a third have unilateral renal agenesis) - ⅔
Scoliosis >20o - ½
Sprengel shoulder - ⅓
Deafness (sensorineural) - ⅓
Cervical ribs - ⅕
  The renal anomalies seen include agenesis or dysgenesis, ectopic location, and duplication.
Yet further features of this condition, all present in under 20% of cases include:
Odontoid dysplasia
Hemivertebrae / butterfly vertebrae
Syringomyelia / diastomatomyelia
Ear anomalies (microtia, deformed ossicles etc)
Congenital heart disease (ASD or coarctation)
  Sprengel shoulder
This condition can occur in isolation as well as part of Klippel-Feil syndrome. It is (like Klippel-Feil syndrome) also often associated with renal anomalies. Sprengel shoulder is a congenital abnormality where the scapula (usually, but not exclusively, unilateral) is attached to the cervical vertebra either by a fibrous or osseous connection, and therefore fails to descend into the normal position. The result is elevation and medial rotation of the scapula, which is usually hypoplastic. The condition can be readily appreciated on a plain film although cross-sectional imaging is useful to plan surgical correction if required. If present, the osseous connection between the scapula and the spine is termed an omovertebral bar.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Klippel-Feil syndrome is a condition characterized by the fusion of two or more vertebrae in the neck, which can cause a short neck, low hairline, restricted neck movement, and scoliosis. It does not cause sensorineural or conductive deafness, cervical ribs, VSD, or syringomyelia.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man is suspected to have a traumatic cauda equina following a road traffic accident. He also undergoes an x-ray of his hand. There is generalised osteoporosis and a fracture to the scaphoid but the radiologist also notices hook like osteophytes on the radial aspect of the metacarpal heads. The MRI of his spine is normal but the liver returns very low signal on all sequences. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Haemochromatosis
The primary version of this disease can be inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. Excess dietary iron is absorbed and this accumulates in all tissues of the body leading to various different problems.
Secondary haemochromatosis can arise if patients receive numerous blood transfusions without sufficient chelation to mitigate against the iron overload.
Cirrhosis – the presence of the excess iron in the liver leads to unusual signal properties on an MRI scan. Iron is paramagnetic and causes spin dephasing. T2* and T2 sequences are particularly vulnerable to this effect but lower than expected signal will be seen on all sequences. Importantly the signal from the spleen and bone marrow should be normal. By contrast they will be involved in cases of transfusional siderosis.
Generalised osteoporosis
Hook like osteophytes on the radial aspect of the metacarpal heads – these are highly characteristic
Chondrocalcinosis, particularly affecting the knees
Insulin dependent diabetes
Congestive cardiomyopathy
Skin pigmentation
  Calcium pyrophosphate dehydrate disease (CPPD) also known as pseudogout
CPPD can present in an acute or subacute fashion but is also seen as a chronic cause of joint inflammation. It may be misdiagnosed as simple osteoarthritis owing to its often bilateral and symmetrical distribution but there are also a couple of areas of the body which can be affected in particular, and which would be unusual for isolated degenerative changes.
The patellofemoral joint – joint space loss here can be extremely striking with almost complete preservation of the joint space at the medial and lateral compartments of the knee
Triangular fibrocartilaginous complex of the wrist – calcification
Radiocarpal joints – degenerative changes without involvement of the DIPs and PIPs
  Wilson disease
Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, this disease results from an excess of copper within the body due to the inability of the liver to excrete it. It can present in childhood with cirrhosis but later presentations are more likely to be due to the neuropsychiatric manifestations. Clinically adolescent or adult patients develop tremor and dysarthria due to copper deposition in the lentiform nucleus. The classic diagnostic feature is Kayser-Fleischer pigment rings in the eyes. Radiologically the following features can be seen:
Hepatic manifestations: The liver appears normal on MRI since fatty infiltration effectively cancels out the paramagnetic effects of copper
Musculoskeletal manifestations: Generalised osteoporosis, subarticular cysts, chondrocalcinosis and arthropathy which can mimic CPPD
CNS manifestations: White matter atrophy and T2 hyperintensities predominantly affecting the basal ganglia and thalami. T1 signal is also high in these areas, differentiating it from many of the other basal ganglia disorders. There is a classical feature of ‘sparing of the red nucleus’ leading to an appearance known as the giant panda sign at the level of the pons.
Enteropathic arthropathy
Sacroiliitis and spondylitis are the hallmarks of enteropathic arthropathy. It is an important seronegative spondyloarthropathy. Outside of the axial skeleton, other features common to all seronegative spondyloarthropathies are also found. These include arthritis in the hands and feet, uveitis, and enthesitis (especially calcaneal). Interestingly although it is most commonly discussed in relation to Crohn’s disease and Ulcerative Colitis, only 5 and 10% respectively of patients with these conditions will develop enteropathic arthropathy. By contrast of patients with Whipple disease, around 75-90% of them will suffer from enteropathic arthropathy. Infection with Salmonella, Shigella and Yersinia are also known associations.
  Alkaptonuria also known as ochronosis
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is caused by excessive circulating levels of homogentisic acid (HGA) when the enzyme which would usually degrade it is deficient. HGA has an affinity for collagen and accumulates in the connective tissues throughout the body. In visible light HGA has a blackish colour and thus the disease can be diagnosed in infancy when a baby’s nappies are stained black by the presence of HGA in the urine. By the time patients reach their 20s pigmentation may be visible in their skin, particularly the ears. This is initially a dark yellow colour (hence the term ochronosis, from ‘Ochre’ in Greek meaning a dark yellow colour) but can progress to blue-grey and black.
In imaging chondrocalcinosis is the most prominent feature, with calcification and destruction of the intervertebral discs. Premature osteoarthritic changes to the hands, feet, shoulders, hips and knees will also develop as the collagen deteriorates. Deposition in the heart and kidneys too leads to cardiac and renal failure.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4 because haemochromatosis is the most likely diagnosis. Haemochromatosis is a condition in which there is an excessive accumulation of iron in the body, which can lead to osteoporosis, fractures, and osteophytes. It can also cause low signal on MRI sequences of the liver.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old man is admitted with abdominal and back pain. He thinks he has lost weight over the last few months. His blood results show his ESR to be raised. There is a tender pulsatile mass in his abdomen. He undergoes a CT scan. Which shows the infrarenal aorta to be 6cm in diameter with a rind of homogeneous soft tissue density surrounding it. The radiologist also notes moderate hydronephrosis and proximal hydroureters bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
An aortic aneurysm is simply a dilatation of the aorta. The vast majority of these will be degenerate, caused by longstanding atherosclerosis and hypertension. Connective tissue diseases such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos can predispose to aortic aneurysms at an earlier age. Fusiform aneurysmal dilatation is typical of a degenerate aneurysm.
An inflammatory aneurysm occurs when there is inflammation and fibrosis affecting the wall of the aorta. Fibrotic stricturing of the ureters with consequential hydronephrosis is classical and serves as an excellent differentiator from mycotic or degenerative aneurysms. They also occur in a slightly younger age bracket to degenerative aneurysms. Inflammatory aneurysms are associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis and thereby other IgG4-related diseases.
A mycotic aneurysm occurs when the integrity of the wall of the aorta is compromised by bacterial infection, usually spread from a source elsewhere within the body either haematogenously or by local spread. These aneurysms tend to be more saccular or multilobulated in morphology, reflecting the focal mural compromise. Adjacent soft tissue stranding is present and adjacent gas locules are almost pathognomonic albeit rare. This would be the second most likely diagnosis in this scenario.
A syphilitic aneurysm (also termed Luetic aneurysms), represents tertiary syphilis and therefore has a lag time of anywhere from 5 to 25 years from the initial infection. It occurs when the vasa vasorum supplying the wall of the aorta itself with blood becomes infected with the spirochete Treponema pallidum which causes syphilis. Although there has been a resurgence of syphilis in recent years it should be noted that many of the new cases are likely to be caught and treated long before tertiary syphilis develops.
IgG4 related diseases are one of Radiology’s newest entities. They comprise a constellation of fibrotic conditions affecting virtually every part of the body, mediated by a subclass of Immunoglobulin called IgG4. Where one condition exists others may also be present. The more common of these include:
Orbital pseudotumour
Fibrosing mediastinitis
Reidel thyroiditis
Autoimmune pancreatitis
Sclerosing mesenteritis
Retroperitoneal fibrosis
An elevated ESR and/or CRP is often seen.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the CT scan results indicate that the patient has a pulsatile mass in the abdomen, which is a characteristic of a degenerative aneurysm. Additionally, the radiologist noted moderate hydronephrosis and proximal hydroureters bilaterally, which are common symptoms associated with degenerative aneurysms. Finally, the ESR being raised could suggest an inflammatory process, which is also associated with degenerative aneurysms.

Qn_Text: A 16-year-old man falls at home and sustains a right supraorbital facial laceration. He is reviewed in A&E and facial x-rays are requested at triage. The x-rays show complete opacification of the left maxillary sinus. Which of the following is most likely as a differential diagnosis for this appearance? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
There is a differential diagnosis for opaque maxillary antrum. Wegener’s disease is included in it, but Churg-Strauss is not.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose option 5, Fibrous Dysplasia, as the most likely differential diagnosis for the appearance of complete opacification of the left maxillary sinus. Fibrous dysplasia is a benign bone disorder that results in the replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue. This can lead to the formation of cysts and other abnormalities in the bones of the face, including the maxillary sinus.

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old man complains of worsening leg numbness. On examination he is found to have an absent patella reflex. He is suspected to have a foraminal lumbar disc protrusion. At which level would this be?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is a straightforward anatomy question. In the cervical spine the nerve roots exit above their named vertebral body; thus at the level of C4/5 it is the C5 which will be exiting. This is unlike the lumbar spine where the nerve root exits below its named vertebral body and is explained by the presence of 8 cervical nerve roots with only 7 cervical vertebra.
There is also the concept of the exiting nerve root and the descending nerve root. This applies in particular to disc bulges/protrusions/extrusions and is more pertinent in the lumbar spine. The exiting nerve root at a given level will be one less than the descending nerve root. (ie at L2/3 the exiting nerve will be L2 and the descending nerve will be L3). Central disc pathology affects the descending nerve whereas paramedian or foraminal disc pathology may affect the exiting nerve.
  Level
Exiting nerve root
Descending nerve root
Muscles, reflexes and sensation of exiting root
L1/2
L1
L2
Iliopsoas and hip adductors, anterior thigh sensation
L2/3
L2
L3
Iliopsoas and hip adductors, medial thigh and knee sensation
L3/4
L3
L4
Quadriceps, patella reflex, sensation over knee and shin
L4/5
L4
L5
Dorsiflexion of the foot, ankle eversion, sensation to lateral calf, patella reflex
L5/S1
L5
S1
Hip extension, extension of the big toe, ankle inversion, ankle reflex, sensation to sole of foot
      Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because a foraminal lumbar disc protrusion is a condition where a disc in the lumbar spine (lower back) is bulging and pressing on the nerve root that exits the spine at that level. Since the patient is complaining of worsening leg numbness, it is likely that the disc protrusion is occurring at the L5/S1 level, which is the lowest level of the lumbar spine and is the level where the sciatic nerve, which supplies sensation to the legs, exits the spine.
