Qn_Text: On the ward round of the neonatal intensive care unit, a baby is reviewed. She was born a week ago at 33+4 weeks gestation. She has been receiving mechanical ventilation but her oxygen saturations have deteriorated during the last 24 hours.  A chest x-ray shows slight overinflation with black streaks radiating from the hilum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Of the five main respiratory conditions of the neonate the differential diagnosis can be narrowed based on gestational age.  The presence of hyperinflation can also be useful but may not always be present where feasible so should not be used as an absolute discriminator. If present, it is useful.
    Meconium aspiration
Meconium is sticky and causes a chemical pneumonitis in the lungs, seen as patchy consolidation. In addition small globules of meconium entering bronchi and bronchioles of a decreasing calibre act as a ball-valve mechanism and lead to air trapping; thus the lung volumes of a baby with meconium aspiration may be increased. Air bronchograms are notably absent. The typical baby in a meconium aspiration situation is post-term.
  Transient tachypnoea of the newborn (TTN)
The classical patient for TTN would be a term baby born by caesarean section to a diabetic mother. During normal vaginal delivery the compression of the baby as it descends the birth canal acts to squeeze fluid out from its lungs. This mechanism is all but absent during a caesarean section.  Consequently these babies are born with an excess of retained fluid. The CXR of an affected baby will show bilateral symmetrical air space opacification with air bronchograms, fluid in the fissures and pleural effusions. This peaks in severity at 24hrs but resolves by three days.
  Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD) also known as surfactant deficient disease (SDD)
It is to reduce the likelihood of this disease developing that a woman in pre-term labour will be offered a steroid injection. The steroids help the neonatal lungs to develop faster and increase the likelihood of their being able to produce surfactant once delivered. Where there is surfactant deficiency the alveoli collapse. The CXR will show a granular opacification throughout both lungs which progresses to bilateral ground glass opacification with air bronchograms. If exogenous surfactant is given to the baby there may be asymmetrical improvement in the appearances depending on how much reaches each lung. Of note HMD does not cause pleural effusions. Finally a normal CXR at 6hrs post delivery excludes HMD.
  Pulmonary interstitial emphysema (PIE)
As the name would suggest, this disease is diagnosed when there is air within the interstitial tissues of the lungs. It is caused by alveolar rupture due to the barotrauma of mechanical ventilation or positive airway pressure.  It can be associated with hyaline membrane disease and is prevalent in infants of a low birth weight. Complications such as pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum can be severe and acutely life threatening. Radiographically there is hyperinflation and lucencies in either a cystic pattern or streaks emanating from the hila and following the direction of the bronchi/bronchioles. It is treated with high frequency oscillation ventilation which is less traumatic to the lungs.
  Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
This also occurs due to barotrauma in ventilated neonates but is a more gradual process, occurring later on in the baby’s life; perhaps after a couple of weeks. Typically (but not exclusively) the baby is premature (hence requiring ventilation). It only usually occurs after the baby in question has received ventilation of >21% oxygen for longer than 28 days. The lungs are hyperinflated and what starts off as ground glass opacification becomes complete opacification with air bronchograms in a few days. After 30 days it can be seen as coarse linear lucencies, described as radiating from the hila, with focal emphysematous change. Mikity syndrome has similar features but occurs in term infants who have not received mechanical assistance.
GPT3_explain: I chose Pulmonary interstitial emphysema as the most likely diagnosis because the chest x-ray showed slight overinflation with black streaks radiating from the hilum, which are consistent with the signs of pulmonary interstitial emphysema. The baby was born prematurely and has been receiving mechanical ventilation, which can increase the risk of developing pulmonary interstitial emphysema. Additionally, the baby's oxygen saturations have deteriorated over the last 24 hours, which is another sign of pulmonary interstitial emphysema.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old Jewish man receives a chest radiograph for insurance purposes. The x-ray is performed by a trainee radiographer and the field of view is left too large. There is a serpiginous area of calcification within the left humeral head and the splenic outline is abnormal. Splenomegaly is confirmed on subsequent clinical examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Gaucher disease
This lysosomal storage disease is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion and is around 100 times more common in Ashkenazi Jews than it is in the rest of the population. There is accumulation of glycolipid in macrophage lysosomes. The infantile form is universally lethal before 24 months of age but the adult form may be asymptomatic at diagnosis and is typically diagnosed in young adulthood if not earlier. Hepatosplenomegaly is common and co-existent with thrombocytopaenia and anaemia secondary to bone marrow failure. Osteonecrosis occurs in the femoral or humeral heads leaving serpiginous sclerotic areas or a bone-within-bone appearance. Modelling deformities such as the Erlenmeyer flask deformity (Flared metaphysis + diaphyseal thinning) also occur and are considered characteristic.
  Differential diagnosis for the Erlenmeyer flask deformity
Marrow infiltration
Gaucher disease
Thalassaemia
Sickle Cell disease
Dysplasia
Fibrous dysplasia
Osteopetrosis
Achondroplasia
Ollier disease
  Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI)
A defect on either chromosome 7 or 17 leads to abnormal type 1 collagen. Most cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. An adult with OI is most likely to have either type I or type IV. On imaging there is diffuse undermineralisation of the skeleton and (sometimes extreme) cortical thinning. Once a child with OP has become mobile the soft bones become bowed under the weight of the body. The pressure of the femoral heads on the soft acetabulae leads to acetabular protrusion. Basilar invagination results from pressure of the cervical spine on the base of the skull. Insufficiency fracture of the vertebral bodies lead to a biconcave appearance. OI is a differential diagnosis for multiple wormian bones which persist to adulthood.
  Type
Inheritance
Clinical features
I
AD
Most common form. Normal life expectancy. Presents aged 2-6. Blue sclera, joint laxity, deafness.
II
AR
Often stillborn or perinatal death due to pulmonary hypoplasia.
III
AR
Progressively deforming, fractures at birth in most cases.
IV
AD
Variable severity. Usually shorter in statue, by adulthood, than normal. Normal colour sclera. Usually normal hearing.
  Mucopolysaccharidosis
These are a constellation of lysosomal storage disorders which, with the exception of Hunter syndrome (X-linked) are inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. Mental retardation is common (except in Morquio syndrome). Short, thick fingers with pointing at the proximal end of the metacarpals is classical. Hypoplastic lumbar vertebra is also common, in some cases this extends to vertebra plana, in others there is characteristic ‘beaking’ either of the inferior end plate or centrally.
Morquio syndrome (MPS type IV)– Characterised by normal intelligence with multiple skeletal manifestation which manifest in infancy. Patients usually die in their 30-40s.
Anterior beaking of the vertebral bodies (supposed to be central to each vertebral body and in the upper part of the lumbar spine in particular)
Flared shape to the iliac crests (in contrast to achondroplasia where they are described as tombstone shaped)
Progressive narrowing of the interpedicular distance (similar to achondroplasia)
Atlantoaxial subluxation (often the cause of death)
Short and wide ribs
An increased AP thoracic diameter
Hurler syndrome (MPS type I)– is usually diagnosed in infancy with patients dying before the age of 10
Macrocephaly
Kyphosis +/- gibbus deformity
Small facial bones – gargoylism
Severe cardiac disease (often the cause of death)
Atlantoaxial subluxation
Hunter syndrome (MPS type II)
X-linked recessive
GPT3_explain: Gaucher disease is the most likely diagnosis because it is a disorder of lipid metabolism that results in the accumulation of lipids in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leading to splenomegaly and calcification of the humeral head. Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder that causes bones to be more fragile than normal, but it does not cause splenomegaly or calcification of the humeral head. Morquio syndrome and Hurler syndrome are both lysosomal storage diseases, but they do not typically cause splenomegaly or calcification of the humeral head.

Qn_Text: A 7-year-old girl undergoes a renal tract ultrasound for recurrent urinary tract infections. This demonstrates both kidneys lying centrally in the abdomen, connected by a band of renal tissue. What normal structure limits the superior migration of a horseshoe kidney?
Explanation:
Explanation:
A horseshoe kidney is the most common renal fusion abnormality. It’s associated with multiple complications including susceptibility to trauma, stones, infection and tumours. There is also an associated with Turner syndrome. The IMA prevents further superior migration of the fused kidneys.
Crossed fused ectopia is the next most common renal fusion abnormality. Similar complications are present although there is no increased risk of tumour development.
Eagle Barrett syndrome (prune belly) is a complex malformation with absence of the rectus abdominis, bilateral severe hydroureter/ hydronephrosis, cryptorchidism.
GPT3_explain: The median sacral artery is the structure that limits the superior migration of a horseshoe kidney. This artery is located at the base of the spine and runs along the midline of the body. It provides blood supply to the kidneys and helps to anchor them in place, preventing them from moving too far up the abdomen.

Qn_Text: An 8-year-old girl is tackled during a football training session and is unable to weight-bear. An x-ray in A+E shows a medial malleolar fracture but also a lucent expansile bone lesion in distal tibial metaphysis which has thin sclerotic borders. She goes on to have a nuclear medicine bone scan on which the lesion is shows high uptake. She is subsequently diagnosed with McCune-Albright syndrome. Which of the following would be unusual in this patient? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
This tends to be a condition of childhood-adolescence. It is otherwise rarely seen in patients older than 30. It is a benign condition caused by abnormal osteoblasts and leading to focal replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue. Most cases are monostotic but polyostotic cases occur around 20% of the time. Virtually any bone can be affected although the long bones tend to be more frequently affected in the polyostotic form. That said, fibrous dysplasia is also a typical differential diagnosis for a rib or skull lesion.
Classically the appearances on x-ray or CT is described as 'ground glass' in matrix, and situated within the centre of the bone (i.e. medullary), but often causing bony expansion. Since the bone is abnormal there is an increased risk of fractures but unless there is an acute injury there should not be a periosteal reaction.
On a nuclear medicine bone scan the lesions tend to show increased uptake and this is therefore rarely useful in diagnosing this condition.
Aside from pathological fractures, the condition can also occasionally be complicated by secondary degeneration which would be to osteosarcoma and should be suspected if the patient complains of pain and the growth of a soft tissue mass. This occurs more frequently in patients who have previously been exposed to radiation.
There are a number of eponymous or descriptive terms associated with fibrous dysplasia:
Shepherds crook deformity - coxa varus deformity of the proximal femur. This is usually used to describe the effect of fibrous dysplasia on the proximal femur with chronic bowing and remodelling secondary to microfractures, but the same appearance can occur with conditions such as Paget disease or osteogenesis imperfecta, for the same reasons.
Protrusio acetabuli - fibrous dysplasia is one of a number of things which can cause protrusion of the femoral head into the pelvis due to remodelling of the acetabulum.
Leontiasis ossea - facial involvement causing a specific appearance said to resemble that of a lion. Owing to canal stenosis caused by bony expansion patients can exhibit cranial nerve palsies.
Cherubism - facial (maxilla and mandible) involvement causes a specific appearance said to resemble that of a cherub. Owing to canal stenosis caused by bony expansion patients can exhibit cranial nerve palsies. Cherubism is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.
McCune-Albright syndrome - this almost always only affects girls and consists of a triad of cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (or other endocrine pathology), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia. The cafe-au-lait pigmentation is often on the back and can commonly be seen to respect the midline.
Mazabraud syndrome - this is a very rare condition. Patients present with polyostotic fibrous dysplasia and soft tissue tumours and are at increased risk of malignant degeneration to osteosarcoma.
  Hand-Schüller-Christian Disease – classically a triad of destructive bony lesions, diabetes insipidus and exophthalmos is a type of histiocytosis. In a quarter of these patients the lungs are involved with cyst formation and spontaneous pneumothoraces possible. Nodule formation, fibrosis and honeycombing are also seen.
GPT3_explain: Spontaneous pneumothorax is an unusual symptom of McCune-Albright syndrome and is not typically associated with the disorder. The other symptoms listed (hyperthyroidism, fibrous dysplasia, hyperpigmented patches on her back, and polyostotic lesions) are all common symptoms of McCune-Albright syndrome, so they would not be considered unusual in this patient.

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old man is brought into A+E unconscious. There is no history available. During the course of his treatment he goes on to have an MRI scan which shows high T2/FLAIR signal in the basal ganglia, with corresponding low T1 signal to the same areas. The finding is bilateral and symmetrical. What is the diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
This question draws on the classic differential diagnosis of ‘basal ganglia signal changes’.
  Poisoning
Impairment of mitochondrial function in the highly metabolically active basal ganglia classically causes high T2/FLAIR signal in a bilateral symmetrical fashion but the T1 is usually low in signal. Methanol, cyanide, and carbon monoxide can all cause this. Hopefully the history would be more helpful in establishing the diagnosis than that which has been provided here.
  Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation aka hallervorden-Spatz syndrome
The classic radiological feature which comes up here is the ‘eye of the tiger’ sign where there is low T2 signal in the globus pallidus due to iron accumulation. Confusingly the patient can go on to develop high T2 signal in these areas as gliosis develops. The typical patient will be a young woman with a family history of movement disorders presenting with rigidity or bradykinesia.
  Behcet syndrome
Behcet syndrome is classically described as a triad of oral and genital ulcers associated with one of several ocular manifestations. Its effect on the CNS tends to be as meningoencephalitis or venous sinus thrombosis. In the basal ganglia, in some patients, it can cause lesions with low T1 signal and high T2 signal.
  Toxoplasmosis
Infections derived from intrauterine transmission cause periventricular calcifications affecting the basal ganglia. Otherwise, in AIDS related toxoplasmosis the findings are more of multiple ring enhancing lesions.
Toxoplasmosis is a more common finding in AIDS patients than lymphoma is, by a large margin. On MRI it is seen as multiple ring enhancing lesions, which can show haemorrhage particularly following treatment. One of the stronger differentiators between toxoplasmosis and lymphoma is the SPECT findings. This is sometimes termed ‘hypometabolic’ meaning the lesions do not demonstrate SPECT uptake. The table below gives some general features of the two conditions. There is however considerable overlap in the imaging features despite these broad trends.
    Toxoplasmosis
Lymphoma
Number of lesions
Multiple lesions
Single lesion (can be multiple)
Predilection/involvement of
Basal ganglia
Corpus callosum
DWI
Range of appearances
Restricts
Thallium SPECT
Negative
Avid
MRS choline
Decreased
Increased
MR perfusion
Decreased rCBV
Increased rCBV
  Lymphoma
A ring solitary ring enhancing lesion in the context of an AIDS patient should raise lymphoma as a strong possibility. Multiple lesions can and do occur however, making the distinction from toxoplasmosis challenging. Lymphoma is also part of the differential diagnosis for lesions that cross the corpus callosum and this can be a feature that separates it from toxoplasmosis, although is not a feature of exclusion. Similarly if haemorrhage has been seen associated with the lesion this is more a feature of toxoplasmosis but absence of haemorrhage does not exclude toxoplasmosis.
GPT3_explain: The MRI findings of high T2/FLAIR signal in the basal ganglia, with corresponding low T1 signal to the same areas, is a characteristic of Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation. This is a disorder that is caused by the accumulation of iron in the brain, which can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man with known HIV presents with deteriorating memory problems and word finding difficulties. He undergoes an MRI scan which shows bilateral white matter high signal on T2 and FLAIR in an asymmetric pattern. There is no mass effect. The radiologist notes involvement of the subcortical U-fibres. What is the most likely explanation?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)
This is a JC virus mediated phenomenon which causes asymmetrical patchy white matter changes. These can be bilateral. The testable feature is involvement of the cortical U-fibres which separates it from HIV encephalopathy where the U-fibres are spared. The lack of a mass effect helps differentiate both PML and HIV encephalopathy from toxoplasmosis, cryptococcus and tuberculomas.
    HIV encephalopathy
Separating HIV encephalitis from PML can challenging in real life. HIV encephalitis causes bilateral symmetrical white matter changes, seen as high T2 signal (The T1 sequences can be normal). There is also sparing of the subcortical U-fibres.
  Cryptococcus
This is an opportunistic yeast-like fungus which therefore requires a degree of immunocompromise, typically AIDS. The cryptococcomas are non-enhancing low density lesions in the basal ganglia. These show as high signal on T2 sequences. A granulomatous meningitis can also occur. They can be differentiated from VR spaces on FLAIR where VR spaces will suppress (being CSF in content) whereas the mucoid cryptococcomas will not.
  Toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasmosis is a more common finding in AIDS patients than lymphoma is, by a large margin. On MRI it is seen as multiple ring enhancing lesions, which can show haemorrhage particularly following treatment. One of the stronger differentiators between toxoplasmosis and lymphoma is the SPECT findings. This is sometimes termed ‘hypometabolic’ meaning the lesions do not demonstrate SPECT uptake. The table below gives some general features of the two conditions. There is however considerable overlap in the imaging features despite these broad trends.
    Toxoplasmosis
Lymphoma
Number of lesions
Multiple lesions
Single lesion (can be multiple)
Predilection/involvement of
Basal ganglia
Corpus callosum
DWI
Range of appearances
Restricts
Thallium SPECT
Negative
Avid
MRS choline
Decreased
Increased
MR perfusion
Decreased rCBV
Increased rCBV
  Cerebral tuberculosis
A cerebral tuberculoma would be difficult to differentiate from toxoplasmosis or lymphoma. Classically though they are described as target lesions situated in the corticomedullary regions. They can calcify with treatment which would differentiate them well from other CNS infections.
GPT3_explain: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a rare neurological disorder caused by the JC virus, which is a common virus in the human population. It is most commonly seen in individuals with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The disorder is characterized by the presence of multiple lesions in the white matter of the brain, which can appear as asymmetric high signal on T2 and FLAIR MRI images. The involvement of the subcortical U-fibers is also characteristic of PML. Therefore, the most likely explanation for this patient's MRI findings is PML.

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old man presents with atypical chest pain. Before undergoing a cardiac CT the radiologist checks for contraindications to prescribing gylceryl trinitrate (GTN). Which of the following is NOT a contraindication to GTN?
D: Sildenafil usage within the previous 24 hours
Explanation:
Explanation:
Contraindications to GTN:
Systolic blood pressure <100 mmHg
Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
Sildenafil usage within the previous 24-48 hours
Aortic stenosis
Profound anaemia
  Contraindications to Beta-blocker:
Severe asthma
Acute chest pain
Recent cocaine use
2nd or 3rd degree heart block
  Asthmatics - Generally only brittle asthmatics are contraindicated from having GTN. If they have had previous ITU admissions or recent hospital admissions, beta-blockers should be used with extreme caution.
Heart-block - 1st degree block is acceptable. 2nd and 3rd degree blocks are absolute contraindications.
Sildenafil - use within 48 hours of a cardiac CT is a contraindication to GTN administration, but not beta-blocker administration.
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Sildenafil usage within the previous 24 hours as the correct answer because it is not a contraindication to GTN. In fact, sildenafil is known to interact with GTN in a beneficial way, and is often used in combination with GTN to treat chest pain. The other four conditions are all contraindications to GTN, as GTN can worsen the symptoms of each of these conditions.

Qn_Text: An 8-week-old baby girl, is brought to an urgent care centre by her parents. She is crying inconsolably and has been for the last 12 hours. Her parents report that she has also passed two bloodstained stools during this time. On examination there is a soft mass in the right upper quadrant. She undergoes an ultrasound scan which shows a pseudokidney appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The patient has insussusception. In children the most common cause of this is idiopathic (thought to be lymphoid hyperplasia in Peyer patches), however this has not been listed as an option. The most common lead point in children of this age is a Meckel diverticulum.
  Meckel diverticulum
The rule of 2s is not absolute but does give a guide to some of the pertinent numerical features of this condition. Persistence of the vitelline duct located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum can result in a true diverticulum. Around half of these contain ectopic gastric mucosa secreting acid which causes mucosal ulceration and bleeding.
  99mTc-pertechnetate studies are very sensitive and specific for diverticulae which contain gastric mucosa. The patient should be fasted for at least 4 hours and should not have undergone any barium studies in the preceding 4 days. 20 minutes following tracer injection images are taken which, if positive, show a focus of uptake in the right lower quadrant appearing at the same time as gastric activity does. Cimetidine, which is an H2 blocker, can be given an hour prior to the tracer to improve the quality of the study if necessary.
On mesenteric angiography if a vitelline artery is present (an anomalous end branch artery from the superior mesenteric artery) this is said to be pathognomic of the condition.
The rule of 2s
2% of the population
2cm in length
2-years-old at presentation
2 feet from the ileocaecal valve
  Intussusception
The peristaltic action of the bowel can pick up and invaginate itself and this is known as intussusceptions. It can happen in adults but the majority of patients are children. The usual cause is thought to be patches of lymphoid hyperplasia (Peyer patches) which act as a lead point but for other lead points there is a strong correlation with the age of the child. The table lists some of the prominent causes. There are many others for the children older than 3.
On ultrasound the intussusceptions has a ‘pseudokidney’ appearance when viewed longitudinally and a bulls-eye appearance when viewed in transverse section. Both appearances come about because there are alternating layers of hyperechoic mesenteric fat and hypoechoic bowel wall. When there is anechoic fluid between they layers the intussusceptions is unlikely to be reducible via the pneumatic technique.
On a barium enema the appearances are either of a meniscus or a coiled spring.
The donor loop is termed the intussusceptum and the receiving loop (recipient) is termed the intussuscipiens.
Children (95% of all cases)
Idiopathic
95% (Peyer patches)
Infant <3 months
Meckel diverticulum
3 months – 3 years
Grey area
Child >3 years
Peutz-Jegher syndrome (polyp)
Ectopic pancreas
Henoch-Schonlein purpura
Adults (5% of all cases)
Idiopathic
20%
Adult
Tumour (benign or malignant)
GPT3_explain: Meckel diverticulum is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is the most common cause of intestinal bleeding in 8-week-old infants. The symptoms of Meckel diverticulum include abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools, which are all present in this case. The ultrasound scan finding of a pseudokidney appearance is also highly suggestive of Meckel diverticulum. Furthermore, Meckel diverticulum is a congenital malformation, which is more common in infants than the other potential diagnoses.

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the greater curvature of the stomach is true?
B: It is shorter than the lesser curvature
C: The angular notch is situated half way along it
D: The lesser omentum arises from it
E: It forms the medial border of the stomach
Explanation:
Explanation:
The stomach is a J-shaped digestive organ that lies in the superior aspect of the abdomen between the oesphagus and the duodenum.
It has four main regions:
The cardia – which is around the opening of the oesophagus
The fundus – which is the dilated superior portion lying beneath the left dome of the diaphragm
The body – which is the large central position lying between the fundus and the pylorus
The pylorus – which is the lower portion that facilitates the emptying of its contents into the duodenum
  The medial and lateral borders of the stomach are curved, forming the greater and lesser curvatures of the stomach:
The greater curvature – forms the longer, convex, lateral border of the stomach. The greater omentum arises from it.
The lesser curvature – forms the shorter, concave, medial border of the stomach. The lesser omentum arises from it.
  There is a sharp indentation two-thirds of the way along the lesser curvature called the angular notch. This point marks the junction of the body and the pylorus.
Food boluses enter the stomach via the lower oesophageal sphincter. Once within the stomach protein digesting enzymes, such as pepsin, are released. Hydrochloric acid within the stomach provides a suitably acidic pH for these enzymes to work and also serves to kills bacteria. The food boluses are churned up by peristaltic contractions of the wall and converted into chyme. The passage of chyme into the duodenum is controlled by the pyloric sphincter, which lies between the pylorus and the duodenum.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is the only statement that is true regarding the greater curvature of the stomach. The greater curvature of the stomach is convex in shape, and it forms the medial border of the stomach. The lesser curvature is longer than the greater curvature, the angular notch is situated at the junction of the greater and lesser curvatures, and the lesser omentum arises from the lesser curvature.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old man has a repeat CXR showing a persistent patch of consolidation 4 months after his last xray. The patch is peripheral in location. On a CT scan there is a linear lucency running through an area of ground glass shadowing. He goes on to have a PET CT scan which does not show avidity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) and minimally invasive adenocarcinoma (MIA)
The term bronchalveolar carcinoma (BAC) is historic and shouldn't really be being used. Early on they appear as tiny areas of ground glass opacification (GGO). This then becomes more defined as a small nodule, sometimes still surrounded by a rim of GGO and termed the ‘fried egg’ sign. Air bronchograms can be seen within a small patch of consolidation, such as in this case. Unlike most other types of lung malignancy, PET/CT is often negative for such cases. Also unlike many other types of lung malignancy the incidence of AIS and MIA is higher in non-smokers. It also affects women more commonly than men (despite the demographics given in this question).
  CMV pneumonia 
Infection with CMV is common among AIDS patients but not all cases are diagnosed prior to the autopsy prevalence of over 50%; it does not cause significant morbidity or mortality. When it does manifest radiologically the findings are relatively non-specific with bronchiectasis, nodules and hazy infiltrates seen in a bilateral symmetrical distribution. It is often diagnosed concurrently with Kaposi sarcoma. As a cause of the tree-in-bud appearance it is unusual because the luminal opacification is derived from bronchial wall thickening as opposed to an exogenous substance. Changes are usually widespread; there is no particular predilection for the middle lobe. There can be significant overlap between the appearances of CMV pneumonia and PCP. The main differences to look for would be an apical predominance for PCP (especially in those taking prophylactic pentamidine), and the presence of cysts in PCP.
  Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) also known as Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP)
COP is seen in patients post-infection, post-transplant, with a drug toxicity (chemo or methotrexate among others) or in an idiopathic setting. Patients experience a flu-like illness and a dry cough with worsening dyspnoea dating back over the preceding few months. Patients are often treated initially as a bacterial pneumonia and unsurprisingly there is then no response to antibiotic therapy. On CT there is patchy consolidation or ground glass opacification (GGO) and a third of patients will have pleural effusions or lymph node enlargement.
The reverse halo appearance is synonymous with COP (also known as BOOP – Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia). It is seen as central ground glass opacification surrounded by a ring of consolidation. There are other conditions which can cause this appearance, of which the prominent ones are:
Wegeners granulomatosis
Sarcoidosis
Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia
  Non-specific interstitial pneumonitis (NSIP)
This is sometimes seen as a collection of left-over conditions which do not fit into under the banners of COP or UIP but is a specific entity in its own right. It can occur in association with the collagen vasculitides (Scleroderma, Sjogren syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis and the like). Non-specific symptoms such as shortness of breath with a dry cough gradually worsen over a period of a few months and on HRCT there will be bilateral symmetrical ground glass opacification with microcystic honeycombing. Radiological changes are seen in a more peripheral distribution and the term ‘subpleural sparing’ is often used since the area immediately adjacent to the pleura can be relatively disease free. The architectural distortion is said to be less with NSIP than with IPF (Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis) and the patients tend to be slightly younger. NSIP usually responds well to steroid therapy.
  Eosinophilic pneumonitis
This term includes a number of related conditions.
Simple pulmonary eosinophilia – also known as Loeffler syndrome – The key to the radiological findings in this syndrome is nodules with a ground glass opacification (GGO) halo. These nodules are said to be transient or migratory with resolution in some areas but new development in others as seen on serial scans. Like most other entities which include eosinophilia, patients commonly have an atopic background such as asthma or eczema.
Acute eosinophilic pneumonia – The eosinophils are found in bronchoalveolar lavage as opposed to the blood in this condition. The patients tend to be relatively young adults who present with a short history of a few days of fever and myalgia. HRCT shows patchy GGO in a bilateral distribution. Patients respond well to steroid therapy
Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia – The significance of the HRCT findings of this condition (in the context of an exam question) is that it gives a ‘reversed bat-wing appearance’ (Differential diagnosis: Desquamative interstitial pneumonia, sarcoidosis, resolving pulmonary oedema). Eosinophils are found both in the bronchoalveolar lavage as well as in the blood. Although patients often have an atopic history already, a diagnosis of adult-onset asthma is commonly seen. HRCT findings include bilateral non-segmental consolidation in the peripheries (hence reverse batwing). There is usually a rapid resolution with corticosteroids.
Idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome – this can be diagnosed where there is an absence of any known cause of eosinophilia with evidence of organ dysfunction such as restrictive cardiomyopathy or interstitial pulmonary opacities.
GPT3_explain: Cryptogenic organising pneumonia (COP) is a type of pneumonia that is characterized by a patch of consolidation on a chest X-ray that persists for more than 4 months. The CT scan findings of linear lucency running through an area of ground glass shadowing are consistent with COP. The lack of avidity on the PET CT scan further supports this diagnosis.

Qn_Text: You are reporting a CT abdomen and pelvis of a 68-year-old gentleman which shows a small exophytic mass arising from the lower pole of the right kidney.  You suspect this to be a renal cell carcinoma. There is no renal vein invasion or sign of local spread but you have noticed a mass in the left adrenal gland. It is 3.5cm in diameter and measures -15 Hounsfield Units on the unenhanced images and shows moderate enhancement on the portal venous phase. What should you suggest?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Despite the fact that this lesion has such low Hounsfield Units it demonstrates moderate enhancement and the patient has an existing malignancy.
  Known malignancy
No known malignancy
0-3cm
>80% benign
4-6cm
>70% malignant
>3cm
>80% malignant
>6cm
>80% malignant
  The best test to diagnose this lesion would be a dedicated adrenal CT scan (unenhanced, portal venous and 15 minute delayed phases). This would enable the radiologist to calculate the absolute and relative washout figures for the mass. The theory is that malignant lesions have greater permeability and therefore retain contrast for longer, giving lower washout values. By contrast benign adrenal adenomas will wash out faster, giving higher washout values.
Of the answers given an MRI scan of the adrenals would be best. An adrenal biopsy is invasive should only be sought if the combination of MRI and CT adrenal scans cannot fathom the answer. An MIBG scan is useful to look for an extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma.
  Adrenal adenoma
These present a diagnostic challenge if only to rule out a malignant adrenal mass. Once the diagnosis is confirmed they can then be left alone and do not require any further imaging. The majority are obvious on CT and obviously adenomas. Owing to their high fat content most adenomas show low Hounsfield units (HU) and HU <18 on an unenhanced study has a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity approaching 100%.
In cases where the fat content is insufficient to make the diagnosis an adrenal protocol CT can be performed. This compares the HU on an unenhanced scan, a portal venous phase scan and a 15 minute delayed phase scan. From these values the absolute washout can be calculated by comparing the difference between the two contrast studies with the amount of contrast taken up in the first place (i.e. the difference between the portal venous phase and the unenhanced phase). The relative washout is calculated by comparing the difference between the two contrast studies to just the portal venous phase (i.e. it is relative to the portal venous phase).
An alternative diagnostic strategy which, but for demand management, is better for patients as far as dose preservation is concerned, is an MRI scan. The fat content of adrenal adenomas shows up well as signal loss on out-of-phase imaging and gives a chemical shift artefact in the frequency encoding direction on both gradient echo and spin echo sequences.  On gradient echo sequences due to the chemical shift a black line appears in all directions and is termed the India Ink effect or etching artefact.
  Diagnostic of adrenal adenoma
At least 60% absolute washout
At least 40% relative washout
<18 HU (99% specific)
<37 HU on a delayed scan
India ink effect on GE MRI
Chemical shift on GE and SE MRI
  Adrenal metastasis
This is an important differential diagnosis for a malignant lesion of the adrenal gland. Lung cancer is the most obvious culprit but other cancers do also metastasize to the adrenal glands (Breast, Colorectal, Renal cell, Malignant melanoma, Pancreas). Metastases take on a variety of appearances depending on their cell type but usually retain contrast for longer than adenomas leading to low washout figures. Owing to their neoplastic nature they are however, usually reasonably vascular and therefore show strong enhancement in the portal venous phase (>100HU). On an MRI scan they enhance with gadolinium but importantly fail to show any signal loss on fat suppression sequences.
GPT3_explain: MIBG is a nuclear imaging technique that is used to diagnose and stage adrenal tumors. It is the most accurate imaging technique for the evaluation of adrenal masses and can detect tumors as small as 1 cm in size. MIBG can also be used to distinguish benign from malignant lesions and can detect the presence of metastases.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about a specific clinical scenario.

This question would fall under category 3: A question about a specific clinical scenario.

Qn_Text: A 72-year-old man is undergoing pre-operative assessment prior to a routine TURP procedure for some troublesome lower urinary tract symptoms. When his PSA is found to be markedly elevated he undergoes an MRI scan for further investigation. A 12mm tumour is seen in the left peripheral zone. It returns low signal on the T2 weighted sequences, with very low signal on the ADC map too. Dynamic contrast enhancement analysis reveals a type 3 curve. What is the PIRADS score? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The assessment of peripheral zone and central zone lesions is very different in PIRADS assessment.
Peripheral zone
The highest grade of suspicion for malignancy in the peripheral zone is indicated by the presence of marked restricted diffusion (focal high b-value and corresponding low ADC signal), with a PIRADS 5 lesion being one that is greater than 1.5 cm. PIRADS 3 lesions will show some restricted diffusion but this is far less (subjective analysis) than for PIRADS 4 lesions. Dynamic contrast enhancement is used for assessment of peripheral zone lesions only - differentiating between lesions which show only limited restricted diffusion. If there is dynamic contrast enhancement with a type 3 washout curve, the lesion becomes a PIRADS 4 lesion despite the only limited restriction in diffusion.
Transitional zone
The highest grade of suspicion for transitional zone lesions is reserved for moderate T2 lesion which is lenticular or non-circumscribed and moderately T2 hypointense (PIRADS 5 >1.5 cm).
Three plane T2 imaging is common practice and enables full assessment of the peripheral zone of the prostate, particularly examining for extra-capsular extension, bladder base or seminal vesical invasion. T2 is also the most important sequence for lesions in the transitional zone.
Diffusion weighted imaging is essential for PIRADS calculation and is the first sequence that should be used to evaluate lesions in the peripheral zone. Axial dynamic contrast enhanced imaging (after non-contrast axial T1) is then essential to differentiate between between PIRADS 3 and 4 lesions. The three types of curve are known as type 1-2 curves. Type 3 curves are considered most suspicious for prostate cancer. Just like for breast cancer contrast enhancement curves, in a metabolically active lesion there is usually rapid uptake and rapid washout of contrast, leading to the classical type 3 curve. Type 1 and 2 curves in prostate imaging can also occur in malignant lesions but type 3 curves are the most concerning.
  PIRADS curves © Medical Exam Prep
  The T1 weighted sequences are also useful to check for the presence of any haemorrhagic foci although since most patients now undergo their MRI scan prior to any biopsies being taken this has become far less important.
Interestingly the ADC map is more sensitive for carcinoma of the prostate (in the peripheral zone) than the DWI sequences. A finding of focal low signal on the ADC map may be seen in the absence of a corresponding high DWI focus. In the transitional zone however, the T2 sequences are more sensitive.
GPT3_explain: The PIRADS score for this scenario is 5 because the tumor is 12mm in size and has a type 3 curve on the dynamic contrast enhancement analysis. This indicates that the tumor is highly suspicious for malignancy and has a high likelihood of being cancerous.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the application of knowledge, how to apply a scoring system?

Qn_Text: A 36-year-old woman has a cardiac MRI for investigation of shortness of breath. There was straightening of the interventricular septum, among other findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Inflammation of the pericardium is termed pericarditis and leads to fibrous thickening. Most commonly this occurs either post-operatively in patients undergoing cardiac surgery or as an idiopathic entity although historically it was tuberculosis which was the most common cause of pericarditis. The diagnosis is predominantly clinical with symptoms such as malaise or dyspnoea and signs such as neck vein distension or paradoxical movement of the JVP. On cross sectional imaging thickening of the pericardium to greater than 2mm can be seen and the fibrosis causes a restriction in distensibility. The right ventricle, being more compliant than the left, becomes flattened and furthermore there can be curvature of the septum towards the left. Elsewhere, if the field of view permits, accessory signs such as pleural effusions and even ascites may be seen.
  Pulmonary Emboli
There is some cross-over of the signs and symptoms of pericarditis and a large lobar embolus. On CT, if the embolus is large enough to cause right ventricular strain the septum can sometimes appear bowed with reflux of IV contrast into the hepatic veins.
GPT3_explain: Tricuspid regurgitation is the most likely diagnosis based on the findings of straightening of the interventricular septum on cardiac MRI. Tricuspid regurgitation occurs when the tricuspid valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow backward through the valve and into the right atrium. This can cause shortness of breath, which is the symptom the patient is experiencing. Other possible diagnoses based on the findings on cardiac MRI include Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and pericarditis, but tricuspid regurgitation is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

Qn_Text: A 24-year-old man undergoes a lumbar spine x-ray which shows dense sclerosis to the L4 vertebra. The vertebral body height is preserved, and the discs appear unaffected. Which SINGLE one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Image © Medical Exam Prep
    The ivory vertebra sign denotes dense sclerosis of a solitary vertebra without any change in its size or shape.
  Ivory vertebra differential diagnosis
Paediatric Adult
Lymphoma
Osteosarcoma
Osteoblastoma
Metastatic Ewing sarcoma
Metastatic medulloblastoma
Paget disease
Tuberculous spondylitis
Haemangioma
Prostate/ breast metastatic cancer
GPT3_explain: Ankylosing spondylitis is the most likely diagnosis because it is a type of inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. It commonly leads to the formation of bone spurs (or "sclerosis") on the vertebrae, which is what is seen on the x-ray. The vertebral body height being preserved and the discs appearing unaffected are also consistent with ankylosing spondylitis. The other conditions listed are not typically associated with this type of x-ray finding.

Qn_Text: A 35-year-old man presents with a persistent cough. A CXR shows a 2.5cm mass in the periphery. A CT is suggested which shows a right lower lobe mass which is heterogenous in appearance with a focus of low attenuation measuring -100HU. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Hamartomas have reasonably specific imaging features.
Fat within a thoracic mass is diagnostic of a hamartoma but is only seen in approximately half of cases. In contradistinction to carcinoid tumours, hamartomas tend to be peripherally located whereas carcinoid tumours are often more central. Exceptions to both are reasonably frequent however. Calcification, especially popcorn calcification, is also very classical for hamartomas if present. Cavitation is not a feature often associated with them, but it can be found occasionally. Hamartomas are very similar to the chondromas which form part of the Carney triad (pulmonary chondromas, gastric leiomyosarcomas and extra-adrenal paragangliomas). NB this is different from Carney syndrome (atrial myxoma, facial/buccal pigmentation, sertoli tumours of the testis and multiple other findings).
  Carney Triad
Carney syndrome
Pulmonary chondromas
Atrial myxoma
Gastric leiomyosarcoma (GIST)
Facial/buccal pigmentation
Extra-adrenal paraganglioma
Sertoli tumour of the testis
  Pituitary adenoma
GPT3_explain: Carney syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by the presence of multiple tumors, including myxomas, spotty skin pigmentation, and endocrine overactivity. The CT findings of a heterogenous mass with a focus of low attenuation measuring -100HU are consistent with a myxoma, which is a common tumor associated with Carney syndrome. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Carney syndrome.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old lady is undergoing investigation for infertility. An MRI brain shows a 9mm well defined lesion, which is bright on the T1 weighted sequences, at the junction of the anterior and posterior pituitary. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The giveaway on this question is the location of the lesion; between the anterior and posterior pituitary, even in the absence of any other features which would be noted on the scan but which have not been provided and which would usually be used to eliminated any further doubt as to the diagnosis. Rathke's cleft cyst is mostly hyperbright on T2 although both T1 and T2 signal can vary depending on the exact content of the cyst. The lack of symptoms is also a key feature which points away from several of the other diagnoses given. Microadenomas are below 10mm in size, but 80% return low signal on T1 weighted sequences. Craniopharyngiomas are usually lobulated, often contain cystic and calcified areas. Pathologically the appearance of the cholesterol-rich components gives rise to a classical 'machinary oil' type appearance of craniopharyngiomas.
GPT3_explain: Pituitary microadenoma is the most likely diagnosis because the MRI scan shows a well-defined lesion that is bright on the T1-weighted sequences, which is consistent with a pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenomas are benign tumors that arise from the pituitary gland and can cause infertility. The size of the lesion (9mm) is also consistent with a pituitary microadenoma.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the chest radiograph of a young adult who presented to the Emergency Department with worsening shortness of breath. He has had multiple previous admissions for a longstanding diagnosis of asthma. There is a lucent line extending around the edge of the left lung. What is the SINGLE most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Complications of asthma
The question is to do with the complications of asthma.
Air trapping is a well-known phenomenon in asthma and is seen as flattening of the hemi diaphragms and hypertransradiancy.
Superadded infection can complicate any respiratory condition and asthma is no exception.
ABPA is a known complication of asthma
Pneumothoraces and pneumomediastinum can complicate asthma although the incidence is actually not vastly higher than that in the general population.
  Hypersensitivity pneumonitis classically mimics asthma on a chest radiograph. In a known asthmatic this would be an unusual finding compared to the common complications listed above.
GPT3_explain: Pneumothorax is the most likely explanation for the lucent line extending around the edge of the left lung on the chest radiograph of this patient. A pneumothorax is an accumulation of air or gas in the pleural space, which can cause the lung to collapse. This can be caused by a number of factors, including trauma, asthma, or a spontaneous rupture of a bleb. In this case, the patient has a longstanding diagnosis of asthma, which increases the likelihood that this is the cause of the pneumothorax.
Cat_Long: This question falls under Question about Clinical Judgement, What is the Correct Diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old woman undergoes an ultrasound scan which shows a rounded mass in the right lobe of the liver. She goes on to have an MRI scan with Primovist. In the delayed phase the lesion remains hyperintense compared to the normal liver parenchyma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Gadoxetic acid disodium (Primovist) and gadobentate disodium (MultiHance) are hepatobiliary specific MRI contrast agents. They are taken up by hepatocytes and excreted into the biliary system.
  Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH)
These lesions typically occur in women in late middle age. They are not caused by oral contraceptive use however they do enlarge in response to hormone stimulation. They are composed of hyperplastic hepatocytes and are thought to arise when a small underlying congenital vascular malformation means that an area of the liver receives a better blood supply and therefore grows better, thus they lack a true capsule but can outgrow their blood supply resulting in the classical central fibrous scar which is present in around half of cases. On imaging they do demonstrate mass effect, displacing adjacent vessels, have marked arterial enhancement which fits in with their supposed aetiology. The central scar enhances only on delayed sequences. On MRI they tend to return high signal on T2 weighted sequences. Their appearance on contrast-enhanced ultrasound is interesting; the central scar enhances very early in the arterial phase, branching out in a spoke-wheel type of appearance. During the main arterial phase the lesions enhance strongly before becoming isoechoic in the portal venous phase. On the delayed hepatobiliary phases the lesions are shown to have retained contrast while the adjacent normal liver parenchyma will gradually wash out.  They are the 'only' hepatic lesions to do this (haemangiomas are composed of large vascular channels and usually match the enhancement of hepatic blood vessels. Sometimes the persistent centripetal enhancement arising due to very slow migration of blood through the lesion, is still ongoing during the hepatobiliary phase. This is something of a pseudofinding however, since the filling-in behaviour of th lesion in the previous phases should clearly identify if as a haemangioma, delayed enhancement or otherwise).
Some types of haemangiomata can show enhancement on the delayed phase too but consider that contrast enhanced ultrasound is a dynamic test. For a haemangioma to show enhancement as late as a hepatobiliary phase it will first have enhanced peripherally and then gradually filled in. This contrast behaviour is very different from the central spoke-wheel scar enhancement and subsequent fill-in of an FNH. 
  Time Phase FNH appearance
Arterial phase Around 30s High
Portal venous phase Around 75s Iso
Delayed hepatobiliary phase 20 minutes Higher than the rest of the liver
  Haemangioma
Cavernous hepatic haemangiomas are the most common solid benign liver lesions and the second most common liver lesion overall (after secondary tumours). Pathologically they are composed of large vascular channels in which the blood flows very slowly. They are usually supplied by the hepatic artery which goes some way to explaining their enhancement characteristics. With all contrast studies three different types of enhancement can be seen.
Flash haemangiomas – these show immediate and uniform enhancement which persists on delayed sequences (unlike hypervascular tumours which wash out)
Peripheral nodular enhancement on arterial imaging with complete filling in on delayed images
Peripheral nodular enhancement with incomplete filling in – this usually occurs in giant (>5cm diameter) haemangiomas where the central portion is thrombosed.
  On ultrasound they are usually well-defined hyperechoic compared to normal liver parenchyma. Contrast enhanced ultrasound is coming to the forefront of diagnosis for solitary hepatic lesions, relieving some of the burden of MRI. Haemangiomas show either flash filling or peripheral nodular increased reflectivity followed by a gradual total or near total filling in when microbubble contrast is given.
On MRI the slow flowing blood causes very high signal on T2 weighted images, higher than the spleen and high enough to cause T2 shine through on diffusion weighted images. Conversely although metastases will also show high T2 signal they do not usually outshine the spleen in this regard. Similarly to contrast enhanced ultrasound findings for a haemangioma, the pattern of gradual filling in is replicated with gadolinium-based contrast agents on an MRI scan although on the delayed phase of a hepatobiliary specific contrast agent the lesion will be low in signal as haemangiomas do not contain normal hepatocytes.
Nuclear medicine studies can be useful in the diagnosis of heamangiomata. Sulphur colloid studies will show a photopenic area initially which 1-2hours later shows increased uptake.
  Focal steatosis also known as focal fatty infiltration
The liver plays a small role in fat storage and subtle variation in blood supply and drainage between different areas can lead to variations in the amount of fat in those areas. Focal fatty change is very common and has a geographic appearance on all imaging modalities, with a lack of mass effect (ie preservation of the vascular architecture). It can occur anywhere within the liver but is classically found adjacent to the falciform ligament (i.e. segments II, III and IV). Fat-identifying sequences on MRI can be very useful to cinch the diagnosis with signal drop out on out-of-phase images. Focal fatty sparing on the other hand appears as the inverse of this and on CT will be seen as isoattenuation on a background of a diffusely hypoattenuating liver. On ultrasound the liver will be diffusely hyperechoic when compared to the right kidney, and the spared area will be hypoechoic.
  Hepatic abscess
Liver abscesses can occur in children, for much the same reasons as they arise in adults, although they are far more common in adults. In neonates they may arise as a complication from a misplaced umbilical venous catheter. Pyogenic abscesses result from bacteria accessing the liver via the biliary tree, septicaemia, direct spread, trauma or during a liver procedure. Adult patients are usually in their 60s. Amoebic abscesses occur in slightly younger patients (40s) and tend to result from spread of amoebae from the colon via the portal venous system. On ultrasound abscesses appear as a hypoechoic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement. Internal debris may be apparent. On CT they are usually low in attenuation and may have a rim of enhancing tissue depending on the phase of the contrast. MRI signal characteristics are dependent on the protein content of the pus but usually abscesses return little T1 signal and, owing to their fluid nature, return high signal on T2 weighted sequences. It is said that amoebic abscesses are usually found to be contiguous with the liver capsule.
  Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
Although metastases are the most common cause of malignant hepatic lesions, hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary hepatic malignancy. It usually arises on a background of cirrhosis of any cause. Patients with any of the hepatitis viruses, alcoholic cirrhosis, haemochromatosis, and Wilson disease are all at risk. Carcinogens such as thorotrast and aflatoxin also predispose to HCC formation. Serum alpha fetoprotein levels are often raised, in contrast with cholangiocarcinomas which are one of the main differential diagnoses.
  On imaging HCCs can have a variety of appearances. A large irregular mass with satellite nodules is the most common finding but a diffuse infiltrative version can also occur. Since HCCs derive their blood supply from the hepatic artery they show arterial enhancement on CT with washout on later phases. On ultrasound HCCs tend to be hyperechoic when compared to the rest of the liver and on MRI they show variable signal intensity on both T1 and T2 but arterial enhancement with venous washout can again be seen once Gadolinium has been given. Usually they return slightly higher signal on T2 than the remainder of the liver.
  Fibrolamellar carcinoma of the liver is a specific subtype which occurs in slightly younger patients with otherwise normal livers. It is an echogenic lobulated mass on ultrasound with a central fibrous scar which does not enhance on CT. The lack of enhancement, and sometimes presence of calcification, within the scar separates it from fibrous nodular hyperplasia which is the main differential diagnosis.  On MRI the scar returns low signal on T1 and T2 owing to its fibrous nature.
  Thorotrast is a carcinogenic historic contrast agent used in the 30s and 40s. Its use was abruptly curtailed once it was realised that it is retained indefinitely in the reticuloendothelial system. It causes hepatocellular carcinomas and cholangiocarcinomas but hepatic angiosarcomas are the most frequently quoted related malignancies.
GPT3_explain: I chose 2. Hepatocellular carcinoma as the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common primary malignancy of the liver and is often associated with hypervascularity. The MRI scan with Primovist showed that the lesion remained hyperintense in the delayed phase compared to the normal liver parenchyma, which is a typical finding for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man undergoes a left pneumonectomy for lung cancer. He recovers well post-operatively and is reviewed in clinic six months later. He has been reasonably well but has developed increasing breathlessness more recently. A CXR shows mediastinal shift to the left and a near complete white out of the left hemithorax. What is the most likely explanation? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The patient has developed post-pneumonectomy syndrome. The contralateral lung has hyperexpanded, pushing the mediastinum to the ipsilateral side to surgery and leading to respiratory compromise.
Overall post-pneumonectomy changes are features of volume loss with fluid accumulation in the affected hemithorax. A pleural effusion is therefore an expected finding in post-pneumonectomy patients. A unilateral effusion in patients who haven't had a lung resected would be expected to cause contralateral (not ipsilateral as in the vignette) mediastinal shift, if anything.
As the now empty hemithorax gradually fills with fluid an air-fluid level is to be expected. This should reach approximately half-way up the chest on a CXR by day 4 or day 5 and should reach at least 66%, if not 100%, of the height of the chest on a CXR after a fortnight. Ipsilateral mediastinal shift also usually takes place owing to the volume loss although this is not an absolute finding; Some patients will have no mediastinal shift. Diaphragmatic elevation would be an expected finding, diaphragmatic flattening would not.
Post-operative complications of a pneumonectomy include:
5-10% bronchopulmonary fistula
Contralateral tracheal shift
Reduction in height of the fluid level on sequential films
5% ARDS
5% Pulmonary oedema
<5% empyema
Post-pneumonectomy syndrome
This occurs when hyperexpansion of the remaining lung displaces the heart, with rotation of the heart in an anticlockwise fashion along its long axis.
This develops in the first year and usually affects young adults or children. Patients develop exertional dyspnoea or recurrent infections
GPT3_explain: Mediastinal rotation is the most likely explanation for the patient's symptoms and imaging findings. The pneumonectomy would have resulted in a loss of support for the mediastinum, which would cause it to shift to the left and rotate, resulting in the near complete white out of the left hemithorax seen on the CXR. The rotation of the mediastinum can lead to compression of the pulmonary vessels and airways, resulting in breathlessness.

Qn_Text: A 40-year-old much troubled by abdominal pain is referred for an ultrasound scan of her abdomen as part of a work-up towards a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome. A 4cm liver lesion is noted. It is well-defined and hypoechoic compared to the remainder of the liver. She is brought back to the imaging department for a contrast-enhanced ultrasound scan on which the lesion shows early central contrast enhancement with filling in to become arterially enhanced. On the portal venous phase the lesion is isoechoic to the rest of the liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
This is a classical description of focal nodular hyperplasia.
  Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH)
These lesions typically occur in women in late middle age. They are not caused by oral contraceptive use however they do enlarge in response to hormone stimulation. They are composed of hyperplastic hepatocytes and are thought to arise when a small underlying congenital vascular malformation means that an area of the liver receives a better blood supply and therefore grows better, thus they lack a true capsule but can outgrow their blood supply resulting in the classical central fibrous scar which is present in around half of cases. On imaging they do demonstrate mass effect, displacing adjacent vessels, have marked arterial enhancement which fits in with their supposed aetiology. The central scar enhances only on delayed sequences. On MRI they tend to return high signal on T2 weighted sequences. Their appearance on contrast-enhanced ultrasound is interesting; the central scar enhances very early in the arterial phase, branching out in a spoke-wheel type of appearance. During the main arterial phase the lesions enhance strongly before becoming isoechoic in the portal venous phase.
  Haemangioma
Cavernous hepatic haemangiomas are the most common solid benign liver lesions and the second most common liver lesion overall (after secondary tumours). Pathologically they are composed of large vascular channels in which the blood flows very slowly. They are usually supplied by the hepatic artery which goes some way to explaining their enhancement characteristics. With all contrast studies three different types of enhancement can be seen.
Flash haemangiomas – these show immediate and uniform enhancement which persists on delayed sequences (unlike hypervascular tumours which wash out)
Peripheral nodular enhancement on arterial imaging with complete filling in on delayed images
Peripheral nodular enhancement with incomplete filling in – this usually occurs in giant (>5cm diameter) haemangiomas where the central portion is thrombosed.
On ultrasound they are usually well-defined hyperechoic compared to normal liver parenchyma. Contrast enhanced ultrasound is coming to the forefront of diagnosis for solitary hepatic lesions, relieving some of the burden of MRI. Haemangiomas show either flash filling or peripheral nodular increased reflectivity followed by a gradual total or near total filling in when microbubble contrast is given.
On MRI the slow flowing blood causes very high signal on T2 weighted images, higher than the spleen and high enough to cause T2 shine through on diffusion weighted images. Conversely although metastases will also show high T2 signal they do not usually outshine the spleen in this regard.
Nuclear medicine studies can be useful in the diagnosis of heamangiomata. Sulphur colloid studies will show a photopenic area initially which 1-2hours later shows increased uptake.
  Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
Although metastases are the most common cause of malignant hepatic lesions, hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary hepatic malignancy. It usually arises on a background of cirrhosis of any cause. Patients with any of the hepatitis viruses, alcoholic cirrhosis, haemochromatosis, and Wilson disease are all at risk. Carcinogens such as thorotrast and aflatoxin also predispose to HCC formation. Serum alpha fetoprotein levels are often raised, in contrast with cholangiocarcinomas which are one of the main differential diagnoses.
On imaging HCCs can have a variety of appearances. A large irregular mass with satellite nodules is the most common finding but a diffuse infiltrative version can also occur. Since HCCs derive their blood supply from the hepatic artery they show arterial enhancement on CT with washout on later phases. On ultrasound HCCs tend to be hypoechoic when compared to the rest of the liver and on MRI they show variable signal intensity on both T1 and T2 but arterial enhancement with venous washout can again be seen once Gadolinium has been given.
Fibrolamellar carcinoma of the liver is a specific subtype which occurs in slightly younger patients with otherwise normal livers. It is an echogenic lobulated mass on ultrasound with a central fibrous scar which does not enhance on CT. The lack of enhancement, and sometimes presence of calcification, within the scar separates it from fibrous nodular hyperplasia which is the main differential diagnosis.  On MRI the scar returns low signal on T1 and T2 owing to its fibrous nature.
Thorotrast is a carcinogenic historic contrast agent used in the 30s and 40s. Its use was abruptly curtailed once it was realised that it is retained indefinitely in the reticuloendothelial system. It causes hepatocellular carcinomas and cholangiocarcinomas but hepatic angiosarcomas are the most frequently quoted related malignancies.
  Simple cyst
Hepatic cysts are very common and usually of no consequence. Multiple cysts do occur in the normal population as well as in patients with von Hippel Lindau syndrome or adult polycystic kidney disease. On ultrasound they are well defined, anechoic with posterior acoustic enhancement and no internal vascularity. On MRI they follow water on all sequences. On CT they have Hounsfield Units of 0-10 and do not enhance.
  Focal steatosis also known as focal fatty infiltration
The liver plays a small role in fat storage and subtle variation in blood supply and drainage between different areas can lead to variations in the amount of fat in those areas. Focal fatty change is very common and has a geographic appearance on all imaging modalities, with a lack of mass effect (ie preservation of the vascular architecture). It can occur anywhere within the liver but is classically found adjacent to the falciform ligament (i.e. segments II, III and IV). Fat-identifying sequences on MRI can be very useful to clinch the diagnosis with signal drop out on out-of-phase images.
GPT3_explain: The most likely diagnosis is Haemangioma, as it is the only diagnosis that matches the ultrasound findings. Haemangiomas are well-defined, hypoechoic lesions that show early central contrast enhancement with filling in to become arterially enhanced, and then become isoechoic to the rest of the liver on the portal venous phase.

Qn_Text: A 50-year-old man presents to his GP with weight loss and malaise. His GP refers him urgently to the gastroenterology team at his local hospital since the patient is known to them having had a total colectomy aged 20. He undergoes a CT scan which shows significant dilatation of the pancreatic and common bile ducts. What is the unifying diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Polyposis syndromes – intussusception is a significant risk
  Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)
The polyps in FAP are said to resemble a carpet since they are so numerous. There are invariably colonic adenomatous polyps and around half of patients have stomach hamartomas too and a quarter of patients have duodenal adenomas. Patients usually undergo a prophylactic total colectomy and thereafter the greatest risk is of a periampullary carcinoma.
  Gardner syndrome
This is a subtype of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) and is a triad of colonic polyps, osteomas of the membranous skeleton (skull, maxilla, mandible) and soft tissue tumours such as desmoid tumours of the mesentery, lipomas, fibromas, keloid scarring. Many patients have supernummary teeth and dental caries requiring significant dental work at an early age.
  Cowden syndrome
This is a rare hamartomatous syndrome which is inherited as an autosomal dominant defect on chromosome 10. The polyps are predominantly (but not exclusively) in the rectosigmoid colon. There is an association with fibrocystic disease and fibroadenomas of the breast; around half of patients have breast pathology. There is a specific association with dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma also known as Lhermitte-Duclos disease. Patients with Cowden syndrome also develop skin lesions on the head and face called trichilemmomas which resemble tiny basal cell carcinomas.
  Turcot syndrome
This is a subtype of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)and inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. The polyps are adenomatous and largely colonic. They are subject to the adenoma-carcinoma sequence and thus most patients develop cancer before the reach 40 years of age. Brain tumours are also part of this disease; supratentorial glioblastomas or medulloblastomas. A patient with diarrhoea and seizures would be a typical scenario in which Turcot syndrome is diagnosed.
  Peutz-Jegher syndrome
Around half of cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion but the rest are sporadic mutations to a tumour suppressing gene on chromosome 11.  Innumerable hamartomatous polyps develop throughout the gastrointestinal tract. For a firm diagnosis there should be at least 100 polyps but usually there are far more. In the large bowel the polyps can be larger and more pedunculated, putting the patient at risk of intussusceptions. Patients are also at greater risk of many different cancers (upper GI, ovary, thyroid, testis, pancreas, breast). Mucocutaneous pigmentation is classic.
Syndrome
Inheritance
Typical age at which patients become symptomatic
Features
Familial Adenomatous Polyposis
AD – Ch5
30-40s
  Colonic carpet of polyps
Stomach hamartomas
Duodenal adenomas
Periampullary carcinoma
Desmoid tumours
Gardner syndrome
AD – Ch5
15-30
Colonic polyps, skull osteomas, soft-tissue tumours
Poor dentition.
Turcot syndrome

20s

Seizures – glioblastoma

GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because Peutz-Jegher syndrome is a genetic disorder that is characterized by the presence of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and is associated with dilatation of the pancreatic and common bile ducts. This is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history and the CT scan results.

Qn_Text: An 88-year-old man with a long history of COPD is admitted complaining of acute severe abdominal pain. While waiting to be clerked he begins vomiting and the admitting doctor suspects that he may have a small bowel obstruction. He undergoes a CT scan which shows multiple dilated loops of small bowel and a herniated loop of small bowel passing lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle. Which of the following would most accurately describe this situation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Abdominal wall hernias
Hernias can occur at any age but are increasingly prevalent with increasing age. Conditions which increase intra-abdominal pressures predispose patients to developing hernias. These might be entities such as constipation or respiratory conditions associated with excess coughing such as COPD.
Hernia
Landmarks
Feature
Femoral
Inferolateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to the femoral vein
More common in women
Direct inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle, medial to the inferior epigastric vein
Through Hesselbach triangle
Indirect inguinal
Superolateral to the pubic tubercle and lateral to the inferior epigastric vein
Most common abdominal hernia
Obturator
Between pectineus and obturator externus muscles, through the obturator foramen
Rare
Spigelian
Inferolateral abdominal wall defect, lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle
May be congenital and associated with cryptorchidism
  Indirect inguinal hernias pass through the inguinal canal, taking in both the deep and superficial rings as they do. The deep ring is lateral to the internal epigastric vessels.
Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the conjoint tendon medial to the internal epigastric vessels and enter the scrotal sac through the superficial ring. They pass through the Hesselbach triangle which is composed of the inferior epigastric vessels, rectus abdominus and the inguinal ligament.
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. Spigelian hernia because this type of hernia is caused by a defect or tear in the Spigelian fascia, which is located lateral to the rectus abdominus muscle. This type of hernia is also characterized by multiple dilated loops of small bowel, which is what the CT scan showed.
