Qn_Text: A 55-year-old man who had a valve replacement via a median sternotomy presents one month later acutely feverish and unwell. He undergoes a CT scan of his chest which shows loss of the mediastinal fat planes with gas locules in the mediastinum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Post-operative acute mediastinitis is a known complication which patients should be adequately consented for prior to undergoing thoracic surgery. Unless the question writer has been deliberately vague and unhelpful there should be an obvious history of recent surgery or intervention. Although it occurs in only 1-2% of patients it comes with high morbidity and mortality rates and is therefore important to be able to diagnoses in a timely fashion. Since many patients undergoing cardiothoracic surgery will receive prophylactic antibiotic therapy the presentation of mediastinitis may not manifest prior to discharge from hospital. As a general rule, on CT scans, gas locules within tissue suggests either viscus rupture or fistula formation or infection.
  Boerhaave syndrome
This is oesophageal rupture with consequential extrusion of gastric contents into the pleural spaces and mediastinum. Management is usually surgical initially with many patients suffering a laborious recovery trajectory, often plagued by multitudes of complications lasting many years. Radiographically patients often have a pleural effusion at presentation, moreso on the left than the right. Acute mediastinitis can develop in the wake of an oesophageal rupture.
GPT3_explain: Mediastinitis is the most likely diagnosis in this case because the CT scan shows loss of the mediastinal fat planes with gas locules in the mediastinum. These findings are suggestive of an infection in the mediastinum, which is characteristic of mediastinitis.

Qn_Text: You review an MRI scan of a patient with a suspected spinal cord injury. Which of following spinal nerves is NOT correctly matched with its corresponding dermatome? Select ONE answer only.
A: S1 - The web space between the 1st and 2nd toe
B: L4 – The medial aspect of the calf
Explanation:
Explanation:
The key dermatomes are:
C5 – The area over the deltoid
C6 – The thumb
C7 – The middle finger
C8 – The little finger
T4 – The nipple line
T8 – The xiphisternum
T10 – The umbilicus
T12 – The symphysis pubis
L4 – The medial aspect of the calf
L5 - The web space between the 1st and 2nd toe
S1 – The lateral border of the foot
S3 – The ischial tuberosity area
S4, S5 – The perianal region
GPT3_explain: I chose 3. S1 - The web space between the 1st and 2nd toe as the incorrect answer because the S1 nerve is responsible for innervation of the sole of the foot, not the web space between the 1st and 2nd toe.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: Which SINGLE statement regarding the inferior vena cava is true?
A: It directly receives a tributary from the right gonadal vein
C: It arises as the union of the right and left common iliac veins at the L3 vertebral level
D: It pierces the central tendon of the diaphragm at the T10 vertebral level
E: It drains into the left atrium of the heart
Explanation:
Explanation:
The inferior vena cava carries deoxygenated blood from all of the structures lying below the diaphragm into the right atrium of the heart. It arises as the union of the right and left common iliac veins at the L5 vertebral level.
It ascends upwards in the retroperitoneal space, to the right of the lumbar vertebral bodies and to the right of the aorta. It pierces the central tendon of the diaphragm at the T8 vertebral level to enter the thorax. It then almost immediately enters the pericardium before draining into the right atrium.
The inferior vena cava receives tributaries from:
Common iliac veins (origin at L5) – drain lower limbs and gluteal regions
Lumbar veins (between L1 and L5) – drain the posterior abdominal wall
Right gonadal vein (L2) – drain the right testis/ovary
Renal veins (L1) – drain the kidneys, left adrenal gland, left testis/ovary
Right adrenal vein (L1) – drains the right adrenal gland
Right, middle and left hepatic veins (T8) – drain the liver
Right and left inferior phrenic veins (T8) – drain the diaphragm
  The inferior vena cava, its relations and tributaries (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is the only statement that accurately describes the location of the inferior vena cava. The inferior vena cava is an intraperitoneal structure that arises as the union of the right and left common iliac veins at the L3 vertebral level and pierces the central tendon of the diaphragm at the T10 vertebral level before draining into the left atrium of the heart.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 49-year-old lady presents to her GP with a new left breast lump. She is referred for triple assessment which shows a lobular carcinoma in her left upper outer quadrant. An MRI is performed. Which of the following findings would be most likely to contraindicate wide local excision (WLE)?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: The presence of an additional lesion with enhancement in the LLO quadrant
Explanation:
Explanation:
Separate lesions in separate quadrants of the breast contraindicate wide-local excision. A mastectomy would be the expected management offered in this case. Allergy to contrast or lidocaine would not preclude surgical management. Nodal enhancement would be grounds for further investigation such as ultrasound-guided biopsies but would not on their own contraindicate a WLE.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 3 because an allergy to lidocaine would be a contraindication to performing a wide local excision (WLE) since lidocaine is used in the procedure as a local anesthetic. Other findings, such as enhancement of axillary or internal mammary nodes, the presence of an additional lesion with enhancement in the LLO quadrant, or an allergy to iodinated contrast, would not necessarily be contraindications to performing a WLE.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: The hepatic portal vein is most commonly formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein and which other venous source? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The hepatic portal vein is the major vein of the hepatic portal venous system and carries blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver. It carries blood rich in nutrients extracted from food in the gastrointestinal tract and also carries toxins for processing by the liver. It is responsible for roughly 75% of the total blood flow to the liver.
The hepatic portal vein is usually formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein. In some individuals also receives blood from the following veins:
Gastric veins
Cystic veins
Inferior mesenteric vein
Para-umbilical veins
  The hepatic portal vein and its tributaries (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: I chose 3 because the hepatic portal vein is formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein. The superior mesenteric vein carries blood from the small intestine, while the splenic vein carries blood from the spleen and pancreas. Together, these two veins form the hepatic portal vein, which carries blood from the digestive organs to the liver.
Cat_Long: 1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a CT scan of a 3-year-old girl who has complained of frequent headaches. More recently she has developed neck pain and vomiting. There is an asymmetric mass in the pons which is isodense to the gray matter but the 4th ventricle is flattened posteriorly and there is significant hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The best answer to this question would be a brainstem glioma however this is not listed as an option. However, gliomas encompass astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas and ependymomas or can be a mixture of the three cell types.
Astrocytomas are the most common brain tumour in children. Classically they appear as a posterior fossa cyst with an enhancing mural nodule but about 10% are solid in nature. Solid (uncalcified) components are isodense to gray matter. This differentiates them from a medulloblastoma which will be hyperattenuating. Calcification is reasonably common with astrocytomas and this will obviously appear dense on CT. For the size of the mass there is often surprisingly little adjacent cerebral oedema with an astrocytoma. Any solid component will enhance with contrast.
Medulloblastomas are the most common posterior fossa tumours in children. > 90% appear hyperdense on CT despite the absence of calcification.
Ependymomas also occur in the paediatric cohort. They predominate in the 4th ventricle, and show T1 hypointensity with foci of high T2 signal. They are the ‘toothpaste’ tumour, expanding out through the foramina of Magendie and Luschka.
  Most common paediatric brain tumours according to site:
All Astrocytoma
Posterior fossa Medulloblastoma
Brainstem Brainstem glioma 
Ventricles - lateral Choroid plexus papilloma
Ventricles - 3rd Choroid plexus papilloma = Ependymoma
Ventricles - 4th Ependymoma
GPT3_explain: Ependymoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common type of brain tumor found in children and is often associated with hydrocephalus. The CT scan findings of an asymmetric mass in the pons that is isodense to the gray matter and a flattened fourth ventricle are consistent with ependymoma. Other tumors such as pilocytic astrocytoma, medulloblastoma, lymphoma, and pontine astrocytoma are less likely given the patient's age and the CT scan findings.

Qn_Text: A 58-year-old man taking warfarin for atrial fibrillation attends a pre-assessment clinic prior to a renal biopsy. He received a cadaveric transplant kidney following post-traumatic resection of both of his native kidneys and his renal physician is concerned the transplanted kidney is not functioning adequately. The interventional radiologist is concerned regarding the risk of bleeding for the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate plan for managing this man?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: Stop warfarin 5 days before biopsy, recheck INR on the day
B: stop 24 hrs before biopsy, no vitamin K needed, recheck INR on the day
C: oral vitamin K on the day of the biopsy and recheck INR prior the procedure
D: IV vitamin K on the day of the biopsy
E: Stop warfarin 5 days before biopsy, oral vitamin K on the day of the biopsy
Explanation:
Explanation:
Warfarin therapy is becoming less and less popular with the advent of factor Xa inhibitors which need far less monitoring. Warfarin should be stopped 5 days before a renal biopsy and can be restarted the following day assuming there is no evidence to suggest bleeding. Vitamin K need only be given if a renal procedure cannot wait the requisite 5 days and the effects of warfarin need rapid reversal. Checking the INR on the day of the procedure is standard practice for patients taking warfarin.
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because it is the most conservative approach to managing the patient's anticoagulation prior to the biopsy. This option allows for the warfarin to be stopped 5 days before the biopsy, which gives the patient enough time for their anticoagulation to be reversed. Additionally, this option allows for the INR to be rechecked on the day of the biopsy, which will help to ensure that the patient is not at an increased risk of bleeding. This approach is therefore the safest and most appropriate plan for managing this patient.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best plan of action?

This question falls under question 3: A question about clinical management, what is the best plan of action?

Qn_Text: A 41-year-old man presents with a left Horner syndrome. His MRI shows, among other things, what is describes as ‘T2 crescentic high signal’. To what does this description pertain?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The crescenteric high signal in the question is the ‘sickle sign’ or ‘fried egg’ sign refers to the appearance of T1 fat saturated sequences where a slice transverse through the vessel shows hyperintensity in a crescenteric or circumferential shape to the wall of the affected vessel. Fat saturated T1 sequences may be the most sensitive sequence for cerebral artery dissections but similar findings can still be seen on T2. Unlike large vessel dissections the anatomy here is usually too small to see a dissection flap.
The other classic cause of a Horner syndrome might be an ipsilateral PCOM or PCA aneurysm. A vertebral artery dissection can cause a Horner syndrome due to lateral medullary syndrome. Vertebral artery dissections are most commonly seen in the setting of trauma, and are altogether much rare than internal carotid artery dissections.
GPT3_explain: The description of ‘T2 crescentic high signal’ on the MRI is indicative of subacute subarachnoid haemorrhage, which is a type of bleeding that occurs in the space between the brain and the skull. This type of bleeding can cause a Horner syndrome, which is a condition characterized by a combination of a drooping eyelid, a small pupil, and reduced sweating on the affected side of the face.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the application of knowledge, what is the best treatment? 4. A question about analysis, what is the cause of the condition?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the images of a 76-year-old man with multiple recent UTIs. He has an MRI scan following an incidental finding of an elevated PSA during pre-op screening for an elective TURP. The scan shows an enlarged prostate gland with diffusely low T2 signal affecting the whole gland. What is the most likely explanation? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
E: Squamous cell carcinoma of the prostate
Explanation:
Explanation:
This patient has granulomatous prostatitis. This is an unusual condition which is said to develop following intravesical BCG therapy for bladder cancer. Other possible causes are sarcoidosis or tuberculous prostatitis. Aside from these, more recently purely idiopathic cases have also been noted. In these cases a recent UTI or urethral instrumentation have been implicated. The imaging appearances are reminiscent of a PI-RADS 5/5 prostate cancer and the diagnosis should always be made histologically. Whatever the aetiology, the patient followed up to resolution of imaging abnormalities to ensure a prostate cancer has not been masked.
Squamous cell carcinoma of the prostate accounts for very few prostate cancers. The majority are adenocarcinoma or transitional cell carcinoma.
GPT3_explain: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the most likely explanation for the enlarged prostate gland with diffusely low T2 signal affecting the whole gland seen on the MRI scan. BPH is a common condition in elderly men and is characterized by the enlargement of the prostate and the presence of nodules or nodular tissue in the prostate. BPH can cause urinary tract infections, which could explain the patient's recent UTIs.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old man has a follow up CT for some incidental findings on his trauma workup after a motorbiking accident. There is now a cystic lesion in the spleen which was not there previously. You note that it has an egg-shell type calcification around it.   All the other incidental findings are unchanged in appearance. What is the most likely aetiology of this lesion?
Explanation:
Explanation:
A true cyst must, by definition, have an epithelial lining. False cysts can form in the spleen following trauma and represent the end-stage sequela of a haematoma or infarction within the spleen. Egg-shell calcification is typical of these.
GPT3_explain: The egg-shell type calcification around the cystic lesion is a classic finding of a true cyst. False cysts, sterile splenic abscesses, and lymphoma would not typically present with this type of calcification. Renal cell carcinoma metastasis is also unlikely given the lack of any other changes in the other incidental findings.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A baby born at 41 weeks develops respiratory distress. A CXR shows bilateral diffuse patchy opacities with no air bronchograms visible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Of the five main respiratory conditions of the neonate, the differential diagnosis can be narrowed based on gestational age.  The presence of hyperinflation can also be useful but may not always be present where feasible so should not be used as an absolute discriminator. If present, it is useful
    Meconium aspiration
Meconium is sticky and causes a chemical pneumonitis in the lungs, seen as patchy consolidation. In addition small globules of meconium entering bronchi and bronchioles of a decreasing calibre act as a ball-valve mechanism and lead to air trapping; thus the lung volumes of a baby with meconium aspiration may be increased. Air bronchograms are notably absent.
  Transient tachypnoea of the newborn (TTN)
The classical patient for TTN would be a term baby born by caesarean section to a diabetic mother. During normal vaginal delivery the compression of the baby as it descends the birth canal acts to squeeze fluid out from its lungs. This mechanism is all but absent during a caesarean section.  Consequently these babies are born with an excess of retained fluid. The CXR of an affected baby will show bilateral symmetrical air space opacification with air bronchograms, fluid in the fissures and pleural effusions. This peaks in severity at 24hrs but resolves by three days.
  Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD) also known as surfactant deficient disease (SDD)
It is to reduce the likelihood of this disease developing that a woman in pre-term labour will be offered a steroid injection. The steroids help the neonatal lungs to develop faster and increase the likelihood of their being able to produce surfactant once delivered. Where there is surfactant deficiency the alveoli collapse. The CXR will show a granular opacification throughout both lungs which progresses to bilateral ground glass opacification with air bronchograms. If exogenous surfactant is given to the baby there may be asymmetrical improvement in the appearances depending on how much reaches each lung. Of note HMD does not cause pleural effusions. Finally a normal CXR at 6hrs post delivery excludes HMD.
  Pulmonary interstitial emphysema (PIE)
As the name would suggest, this disease is diagnosed when there is air within the interstitial tissues of the lungs. It is caused by alveolar rupture due to the barotrauma of mechanical ventilation or positive airway pressure.  It can be associated with hyaline membrane disease and is prevalent in infants of a low birth weight. Complications such as pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum can be severe and acutely life threatening. Radiographically there is hyperinflation and lucencies in either a cystic pattern or streaks emanating from the hila and following the direction of the bronchi/bronchioles. It is treated with high frequency oscillation ventilation which is less traumatic to the lungs.
  Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
This also occurs due to barotrauma in ventilated neonates but is a more gradual process, occurring later on in the baby’s life. Typically (but not exclusively) the baby is premature (hence requiring ventilation). It only usually occurs after the baby in question has received ventilation of >21% oxygen for longer than 28 days. The lungs are hyperinflated and what starts off as ground glass opacification becomes complete opacification with air bronchograms in a few days. After 30 days it can be seen as coarse linear lucencies, described as radiating from the hila, with focal emphysematous change. Mikity syndrome has similar features but occurs in term infants who have not received mechanical assistance.
GPT3_explain: Hyaline membrane disease is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is the most common cause of respiratory distress in newborns. It is characterized by bilateral diffuse patchy opacities with no air bronchograms visible, which is what is seen in the CXR. The other options are less likely in this case.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old man presents with right upper quadrant pain. A CT demonstrates a mass with inwards retraction of the liver capsule. What is the LEAST likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note the question asks for the LEAST likely answer.
Retraction of the liver capsule signifies the presence of fibrosis.
  Differential diagnosis for hepatic capsular retraction:
Cholangiocarcinoma
Fibrolamella HCC
Metastases (breast, lung, carcinoid, colorectal)
IgG4 related disease
Iatrogenic/ post-traumatic
Cirrhosis
  In many situations prostate and breast cancer metastases have similar and overlapping features and are considered as equivalents for their respective populations. This is one where that does not hold true. Consider that there are more sub-types of breast cancer than there are of prostate cancer. Not all types of breast cancer cause capsular retraction.
GPT3_explain: Cholangiocarcinoma is a type of cancer that affects the bile ducts. It is not the least likely diagnosis in this case, as the CT scan shows a mass with inward retraction of the liver capsule, which is a common symptom of cholangiocarcinoma. Breast, prostate, colorectal, and fibrolamellar HCC are all less likely diagnoses in this case.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old man who has recently undergone a total colectomy as part of management of his ulcerative colitis, presents with jaundice. An ultrasound is performed by one of your junior colleagues who asks for your assistance. He thinks he has seen some duct dilatation. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
Although benign in nature PSC can wreak havoc for patients unfortunate enough to develop it. It is twice as common in men as in women and 70% of patients have a history of inflammatory bowel disease. Bile duct strictures form (particularly at the bifurcation/confluence of ducts) and lead to an obstructive jaundice picture. In between strictures there is dilatation and the combination of the two leads to a string of beads type appearance. The appearance on ERCP or MRCP in some patients can also resemble a tree in winter with pruning of the upstream branches. Outpouchings also form which are either true or pseudo-diverticulae. Hepatic atrophy is present in chronic cases, although the caudate lobe is usually spared. Patients unfortunately have a higher risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma.
  Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
This can be difficult to distinguish from PSC however whereas PSC can involve both intra and extrahepatic ducts, PBC only involves the intrahepatic ducts. It is an autoimmune condition and, like many other autoimmune conditions, patients are typically women in their middle ages. Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are present in the vast majority of patients. On imaging, the secondary cirrhotic effects are most pertinent with caudate lobe hypertrophy and left lobar atrophy. The periportal halo sign as seen on MRI is reasonably specific and relates to fluid accumulation around the portal triad.
  Choledochal cyst
Reflux of pancreatic enzymes into the common bile duct  leads to weakening of the wall of the common bile duct [CBD] (+/- the common hepatic duct) and thereafter aneurysmal dilatation termed a choledochal cyst. There are five different subtypes. Patients are mostly diagnosed in childhood.  If undiagnosed to adulthood patients present with a triad of episodic jaundice, right upper quadrant pain and a right upper quadrant mass.
Type I – This is by far the most common version. The common bile duct is affected either focally or along its entire length.
Type II – A true diverticulum of the CBD
Type III – Focal dilatation of the CBD contained within the wall of the duodenum. This type is also called a choledochocoele. They present slightly later with most patients being in their 30s at the time of diagnosis and can be seen as a duodenal filling defect on barium follow-through studies.
Type IV – The intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary ducts are affected
Type V – The intraheptic ducts are affected alone. This is termed Caroli disease however there is some discrepancy in the literature as to whether this can be called a type V choledochal cyst or whether it is a separate disease in its own right. Caroli disease (cavernous ectasia of the intrahepatic ducts) can be inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. When present it is quite striking on imaging with saccular dilatation of most of the larger intrahepatic biliary ducts alongside focal strictures giving a beaded appearance. There is an association with medullary sponge kidney and patients are at significantly increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma.
  Cholangiocarcinoma
Any disease which causes chronic biliary inflammation predisposes the patient to developing cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the biliary tree. In particular, inflammatory bowel disease poses a 10 times greater risk. Painless jaundice is the presenting feature in around one in ten patients but mostly patients present more insidiously with abdominal pain or weight loss.
Cholangiocarcinomas can be intra or extrahepatic and a few of the pertinent features of each are listed in the table below.
                   Extrahepatic                  
Intrahepatic
90% (Right > left)
10%
Fluctuating painless jaundice
Painful or painless jaundice, weight loss
Ductal strictures
Satellite nodules
  A Klatskin tumour is an intrahepatic tumour arising at the confluence of the left and right hepatic ducts where they join to form the common hepatic duct. Consequently it obstructs both ducts separately. On MRCP or ERCP this is seen as duct dilatation where the left and right ducts fail to communicate with one another. The location is relevant in identifying this type of tumours since they tend to be aggressive in nature, even for cholangiocarcinomas.
On ultrasound a cholangiocarcinoma can have a variable appearance. Duct dilatation, if present, should be evident. On CT the tumour will be hypodense but can show early rim enhancement with contrast, followed by filling-in leading to homogeneous delayed enhancement by around 15minutes. Thereafter there is washout which, again, begins peripherally. Appearances therefore depend hugely on the phase of the scan. Since cholangiocarcinomas do not derive from hepatocytes they do not take up sulphur colloid and thus will appear cold on a sulphur colloid scan.
  Cholecystitis
When a gallstone becomes lodged in the neck of the gallbladder, chemical irritation from the trapped bile leads to inflammation of the gallbladder. Sometimes this can be felt by the patient as shoulder pain since irritation of the gallbladder is felt via C3, 4 and 5 the dermatomes of which cover the shoulder. Mostly, however, patients complain of right upper quadrant pain. With an accurate history this should be distinguishable from the pain caused by biliary colic, the latter being intermittent in nature and lasting less than six hours per episode.
On ultrasound the earliest signs will be of gallstones in the presence of a sonographic Murphy sign. Clinically Murphy sign is maximal tenderness when palpating over the gallbladder and the addition of ultrasound allows for greater specificity in this regard. The presence of pericholecystic fluid and increasing thickness of the gallbladder wall (>3mm) are also common findings, but come slightly later on. With CT similar findings can be seen with the addition of enhancement of the adjacent liver due to reactive hyperaemia. The presence of gallstones can be easily masked on CT since they are often of equal density to the bile.
Nuclear medicine tests would not usually be part of the index management of cholecystitis however can be used to determine cytic duct patency. Non-visualisation of the gallbladder at four hours following injection of 99mTc-HIDA is reported to be 99% specific in the diagnosis of cholecystitis.
Acalculous cholecystitis can also occur, often in the setting of an already unwell patient on ITU. It will present as generic sepsis and it is usually down to the clinical team to retain a high index of suspicioun. It is thought to be a consequence of low blood flow in the cystic artery.
Emphysematous cholecystitis signifies a gas-producing organism such as Clostridium or E-coli. Appearances are striking on imaging with ring-down or reverberation artefacts on ultrasound and mural gas seen on CT. Patients are typically (but not exclusively) diabetic or suffering from a debilitating condition. Unfortunately the mortality rate is significantly higher than for non-emphysematous cholecystitis.
Mirizzi syndrome can present as cholecystitis and occurs when the common hepatic duct is obstructed by the mechanical pressure of a stone within the cystic duct. It follows that patients whose cystic duct happens to insert low in the course of the common hepatic duct are predisposed to this condition.
GPT3_explain: Sclerosing cholangitis is the most likely diagnosis in this case because it is a condition that can be caused by a total colectomy, which the patient has recently undergone. It is characterized by inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts, which can lead to duct dilatation as seen on ultrasound. Other conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis, cholecystitis, Caroli disease, and cholangiocarcinoma can also lead to jaundice, but they are less likely in this case given the patient's medical history.

Qn_Text: You are performing an outpatient transvaginal ultrasound scan on a 27-year-old lady to assess her recent IUCD. There is a 4 cm irregular collection associated with the right adnexa. The endometrium is slightly thick and you also see a linear hyperreflective area. What is the most likely explanation?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
IUCDs work by thinning the endometrium so the presence of a thick endometrium in addition to the other given finding of a complex adnexal mass must increase the level of suspicion.
  IUCD - Intrauterine contraceptive device
There is an accepted failure rate with all methods of contraception and IUCDs are no exception. Quoted figures vary from source to source but are around 1% or less. Contraceptive failure is most likely to occur within the first 12 months following insertion. The risk of an ectopic location to any co-existent pregnancy is higher than it would be without the presence of an IUCD. On ultrasound the IUCD will be seen as a brightly reflective straight line within the endometrial cavity, posterior acoustic shadowing may also be seen.
  Tuboovarian abscess (TOA)
A TOA can arise as a complication of PID. They therefore share the same aetiology of sexually transmitted infections, IUD insertion or pelvic surgery. They are ususally seen as a complex mass which encompasses the fallopian tube and ovary and it may not even be possible to accurately distinguish the anatomy of the fallopian tube or the exact location of the ovary within the mass. Unlike other pelvic abscesses a TOA usually forms posterior to the uterus, displacing the broad ligament anteriorly. Otherwise, imaging features are common to many other abscesses , namely a complex mass with thick enhancing walls and septae, and the liquid centre of which is low on T1 and high on T2 weighted sequences. They are often bilateral.
  Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
This is a coverall term applied to ascending infection of the genital tract. It encompasses endometriosis, salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, and tubo-ovarian abscesses. Chlamydia and gonorrhoea account of most of the cases and the disease is most prevalent in sexually active young people. Imaging features are those secondary to inflammation with increased vascularity to the endometrium and small volume ascites. Inflammation is also seen on MRI as avid enhancement post contrast. Pelvic inflammatory disease can be complicated by a condition called Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome where there is perihepatitis secondary to PID. 
  Hydrosalpinx - A simple tubular structure with thin enhancing walls
Fluid within the fallopian tube is referred to as a hydrosalpinx. This can occur as a complication of endometriosis or PID and will be seen on imaging as a fluid-filled adnexal structure, distinct from the ovary. The walls are most often thin. On MRI the signal characteristics will depend on the protein content of the fluid but usually they are watery and therefore are low in signal on T1 and high in signal on T2.
  Pyosalpinx -  A tubular structure with thick enhancing walls
A pyosalpinx can be seen within a TOA or can exist as a separate entity in its own right but the presence of a pyosalpinx does not completely stretch to a diagnosis of a TOA. Thick enhancing walls around an identifiably tubular adnexal structure are typical. Signs of surrounding inflammation may be seen too. The content usually has intermediate or high signal on T1 owing to the protein content of the pus and usually high signal on T2.
GPT3_explain: Tubo-ovarian abscess is the most likely explanation because it is the most common cause of an irregular collection associated with the right adnexa that is seen on transvaginal ultrasound scans. The other conditions listed can also cause an irregular collection associated with the right adnexa, but they are less common than tubo-ovarian abscess. The linear hyperreflective area is also consistent with tubo-ovarian abscess, as it is often seen in such cases.

Qn_Text: An 8-year-old boy presents with acute right testicular pain which woke him up during the night. He undergoes an ultrasound which shows both testes to be identical on all parameters. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Testicular torsion
Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency with salvage rates dropping sharply beyond the first six hours. A normal ultrasound scan does not exclude testicular torsion, particularly if performed within the first six hours. Acute unilateral pain beginning at night is a typical history and the peak age range is in either newborn boys or young adolescents (13-16 years). Ultrasound features, if present, are as follows:
Hypoechoic compared to the normal side (after 6 hours)
Heterogenous if there is ischaemic necrosis present (after 24 hours)
Enlarged (after 8 hours)
Absent Doppler signal (incomplete torsion can show flow)
Twisting of the spermatic cord with spiralling vessels
  Missed torsion
Where ultrasound features of heterogeneous testis with increased peri-testicular flow but absent testicular flow are found in a patient with symptoms lasting longer than 24 hours, a missed torsion can be diagnosed.
  Chronic torsion
Beyond around 10 days the testicle becomes small and homogeneously hypoechoic with an enlarged and echogenic epididymis.
  Reversed torsion also known as torsion-detorsion sequence
Increased blood flow within the testicle is either caused by infection or reversed torsion (a testicular tumour can also show increased blood flow).
GPT3_explain: I chose 1. Epididymo-orchitis because it is the most likely diagnosis for an 8-year-old boy presenting with acute right testicular pain which woke him up during the night and an ultrasound which shows both testes to be identical on all parameters. Epididymo-orchitis is an inflammation of the epididymis (a tube that carries sperm) and the testes which can cause pain, swelling, and tenderness. It is a common cause of acute testicular pain and is more common in young boys than adults.

Qn_Text: A 25-year-old woman develops worsening calf pain and swelling. She has been treated for deep vein thrombosis previously but anticoagulation was discontinued following 6 months of treatment. She has no other pro-thrombotic risk factors. A CT is performed and confirms an underlying problem. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
May-Thurner Syndrome
This condition causes recurrent left leg swelling and left sided deep vein thrombosis due to obstruction of the left common iliac vein where it is crossed by the right common iliac artery. The vein is compressed between the right CIA and the spine. Patients can also develop pelvic varicosities and collateral pathways connecting left and right to allow drainage of the pelvic organs via the contralateral side.
GPT3_explain: May-Thurner syndrome is a condition in which the left iliac vein is compressed by the overlying right iliac artery, leading to a clot in the iliac vein. It is a common cause of deep vein thrombosis in young women, and can cause worsening calf pain and swelling. It is also the most likely diagnosis in this case, as the patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis and no other pro-thrombotic risk factors.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing a trauma CT scan of a 16-year-old boy who was involved in a coach crash. He is intubated and ventilated and nothing is known about his past medical history. As well as multiple thoracic abnormalities you also notice that the pancreas seems to be absent. What is the LEAST likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks for the LEAST likely option.
  Cystic fibrosis
An absent finding such as asplenia can be harder to detect than the presence of an abnormality. In cystic fibrosis the pancreatic parenchyma becomes entirely replaced by fatty infiltration to such an extent that it blends almost imperceptibly with the intra-abdominal fat and appears completely absent. Patients suffer from pancreatic failure and require high dose enzyme replacement.
  Pancreatic lipomatous pseudohypertrophy
As the name would suggest, this condition involves fatty replacement of the pancreatic tissue and is a mimic of the findings in cystic fibrosis.
  Shwachman-Diamond syndrome
This very rare syndrome is a differential diagnosis for pancreatic insufficiency. It also causes short stature and aplastic anaemia due to bone marrow dysfunction.
  Retroperitoneal liposarcoma
The finding of a fatty mass in the retroperitoneum should always spark the consideration of a liposarcoma. Most contain some soft tissue components and present as a heterogenous mass whereas in the other differential diagnoses given here the outline of the pancreas is usually just about discernible.
GPT3_explain: Pancreatic Lipomatous Pseudohypertrophy is a rare disorder that affects the pancreas and is usually seen in children and adolescents. This disorder is typically characterized by an enlarged pancreas and fat infiltration of the pancreas, which can cause the pancreas to appear absent on a CT scan. However, this disorder is not associated with trauma and would not be the most likely diagnosis in this case.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: An 84-year-old man with a presentation of progressive memory loss undergoes an 18F-FDG PET study. Reduced metabolism in which of the following areas would suggest a diagnosis of Alzheimers rather than Pick’s disease?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Pick’s disease is also known as Frontotemporal dementia, with these areas most severely affected. The temporoparietal region is classically affected in Alzheimer's, with involvement of the parietal region key for differentiation between the two.
GPT3_explain: The temporal lobes are responsible for memory and language processing, so reduced metabolism in this area would suggest a diagnosis of Alzheimer's rather than Pick's disease. Alzheimer's is characterized by a decline in cognitive abilities, including memory loss, which would be associated with reduced metabolism in the temporal lobes. Pick's disease, on the other hand, is a rare form of dementia that is characterized by personality changes, behavioral disturbances, and a decline in language abilities, but not memory loss. Therefore, reduced metabolism in the temporal lobes would suggest a diagnosis of Alzheimer's rather than Pick's disease.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man presents to his GP with worsening back pain and stiffness. Plain radiographs show some slight sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints bilaterally with small vertebral syndesmophytes in the lumbar spine. He is referred to an orthopaedic consultant who is concerned he may have ankylosing spondylitis and requests an MRI scan. Which sequence would be best to confirm the diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
A: T1 fat sat and STIR, coronal SIJs and sagittal spine
B: T1 fat sat pre and post contrast and STIR, coronal SIJs and sagittal spine
C: T2 fat sat and STIR, axial SIJs and coronal spine
D: T1 fat sat and T2, sagittal SIJs and axial spine
E: T1 fat sat pre and post contrast and T2, axial SIJs and sagittal spine
Explanation:
Explanation:
T1 fat sat - useful for visualisation of bony erosions and new bone formation
T1 fat sat post contrast - useful for detecting bone marrow abnormalities (but so is STIR, so contrast is not an absolute requirement for imaging ankylosing spondylitis).
STIR - useful for detecting bone marrow abnormalities in the SIJs and spine
T2 fat sat - useful for detecting oedema
  Coronal SIJ - ideally this should be taken parallel to the long axis of the sacrum, the better to view the SIJs, both SIJs can be seen on each image for comparison.
Axial SIJ - ideally this should be at 90 degrees to the modified coronal plane and is used to evaluate the ligamentous portion of the SIJs.
Axial spine - useful if co-existing disc herniation present but not ordinarily included otherwise
Sagittal spine - useful to evaluate facet and costovertebral joints
  Ankylosing spondylitis
This disease usually presents in early adulthood with gradual onset of back pain. There is a male preponderance, though it can affect women too. The vast majority (>90%) of patients are HLA-B27 positive. Radiologically the late features are classical with:
Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis
Enthesopathy - calcified tendon insertion sites
Bamboo spine - vertebral syndesmophytes, particularly in the thoracolumbar spine
Dagger sign - spinous process fusion
Erosion, then fusion at the symphysis pubis, costochondral, costovertebral and sternoclavicular joints
Thoracic manifestations: upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis, pericarditis, aortic root dilatation
Early features are far more subtle and require a higher index of suspicion
Enthesopathy - high signal on MRI at tendon insertion sites
Romanus lesions - triangular shaped oedema at the corners of vertebral bodies
Andersson lesions - bony oedema in the vertebral bodies adjacent to the disks.
Oedema in the sacroiliac joints.
  Patients with advanced ankylosing spondylitis are at increased risk of pathological fractures due to fusion. These can be pelvic fractures following a simple fall, or chance fractures of the spine (involving all three columns - in ankylosing spondylitis, these fractures are also sometimes termed chalk-stick or carrot fractures).
GPT3_explain: I chose option 5 because it is the best sequence to confirm a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. T1 fat sat pre and post contrast and T2 sequences are the most sensitive for detecting inflammation and erosions, which are key features of ankylosing spondylitis. Additionally, axial SIJs and sagittal spine sequences are the most appropriate for visualizing the sacroiliac joints and spine, respectively, which are also important for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the interpretation of imaging.

Qn_Text: Ureteric stones are most likely to become lodged in which of the following points? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
A: At the bifurcation of the common iliac arteries
B: At the inferior border of the transverse colon
C: 2 cm distal to the renal hila
D: Near the inferior pole of the kidney
E: At the level of the ischial tuberosities
Explanation:
Explanation:
The ureters are two muscular ducts that carry urine from the kidneys to the urinary bladder. They are usually 25-30 cm long and approximately 3-4 mm in diameter. They lie in the retroperitoneal space.
They arise from the pelvis of the kidney and exit at the hila in the transpyloric plane at the L1 vertebral level. From the hilum they run vertically downwards, passing along the anterior surface of psoas major. They cross the pelvic brim at close to the sacroiliac joints to enter the pelvic cavity. At this point the cross the bifurcation of the common iliac arteries.
Once within the pelvis they turn anteromedially at the level of the ischial spines, to head towards the bladder. Upon reaching the bladder they pierce its lateral aspect in an oblique fashion. This creates a valve that prevents the backflow of urine.
The ureters contain three points of constriction. These are important clinically as the most common sites for kidney stones to become lodged:
At the ureteropelvic junction of the renal pelvis and the ureter
As the ureter crosses the bifurcation of the common iliac arteries to enter the pelvis
At the ureterovesical junction as the ureter obliquely enters the bladder
  The ureter lies in close association with several important abdominopelvic viscera including the appendix, colon and ovaries. This places the ureter at risk from inflammatory, infectious, or malignant processes from these viscera and these can manifest as haematuria, pyuria, fistula, or obstruction. The mass effect of constipation, pregnancy, or ovarian cysts can cause ureteric obstruction.
Sensory input from the ureters travels to the T11-L2 levels of the spinal cord and can be referred to the corresponding dermatomes. Pain from the ureter, for example form ureteric colic, may therefore be referred to the posterior lumbar/flank region or the hypogastrium.
      Image adapted from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Jordi March i Nogué CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the ureteric stone is most likely to become lodged at the narrowest point of the ureter, which is 2 cm distal to the renal hila. The renal hila are the points at which the renal arteries enter the kidneys and the ureter exits the kidneys, so the area 2 cm distal to this point is the narrowest part of the ureter, making it the most likely place for a stone to become lodged.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about interpreting results from a test or investigation.

1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: An 55-year-old man presents for an ultrasound scan with a left testicular lump. The ultrasound scan demonstrates hypoechoic masses in both testicles. Recent routine screening has shown an abnormally elevated PSA. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The differential diagnosis for bilateral testicular masses is reasonably short. Lymphoma is the most likely cause, especially in men aged over 60. Sarcoidosis is also a common cause of this uncommon finding. Leukaemia is difficult to differentiate from lymphoma on imaging alone and the two are usually discussed in tandem. Testicular metastases are themselves rare, but most common in patients over the age of 50 and the primary site is most commonly prostate or lung.
Lymphoma and leukaemia
Testicular lymphoma is uncommon but important. In men over the age of 60 it is the most common testicular malignancy and in men of any age it is the most common bilateral testicular malignancy (although it is not always bilateral). On ultrasound it appears either as a diffusely hypoechoic and enlarged testicle or as multiple hypoechoic masses.
The finding of a germ cell tumour, or bilateral ones, would be unusual at this age, though not impossible.
GPT3_explain: Bilateral germ cell tumours are the most likely diagnosis in this case, as they are the most common testicular tumours in adults and can cause elevated PSA levels. Additionally, the presence of hypoechoic masses on ultrasound scan is often indicative of germ cell tumours.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 17-year-old man has AP and lateral radiographs of the right ankle after twisting it whilst playing lacrosse. No fracture is seen, however a radiolucent lesion is seen within the calcaneus on the lateral projection. It has a thin sclerotic edge and calcification within. There is some endosteal scalloping and a subtle periosteal reaction. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Chondroblastoma
The calcaneus, like the patella, is an epiphyseal equivalent, so any epiphyseal lesions should be considered a possibility in this bone. They usually arise eccentrically in the epiphysis, are lobulated with a thin sclerotic margin.
  Pseudo-cyst of calcaneus
This is a variation of the normal trabecular pattern centrally within the calcaneus. Will not have a crisp edge for this reason. Persistence of thin trabeculae and a visible nutrient foramen are supporting features.
  Unicameral bone cyst
This is a well-defined lesion with thin sclerotic edges and potentially a multiloculated appearance. Absence of calcification within the lesion is a key differentiator from intraosseous lipoma, although if fractured, a fallen fragment sign can be seen.
  Intraosseous lipoma
Calcification within the center of this lesion is a key feature which differentiates it from other lesions of plain film. Fat density on CT or MRI would also be a key differentiator. There should not be a periosteal reaction associated with this lesion, even in the presence of an acute fracture.
  Geode
This is a subchondral cyst associated with osteoarthritis which should have communication with the joint space and be present in an older patient.
GPT3_explain: Unicameral bone cysts are the most likely diagnosis for this radiolucent lesion in the calcaneus. This is because these cysts typically have a thin sclerotic edge, calcification within, endosteal scalloping, and a subtle periosteal reaction, which are all characteristics seen in this case. Other lesions such as intraosseous lipomas, geodes, pseudo-cysts of calcaneus, and chondroblastomas usually have different radiographic features and/or clinical presentations.

Qn_Text: A 45-year-old lady presents with sudden onset right flank pain and bruising which occurred whilst at rest. She denies any history of trauma. Observations carried out in the Emergency department suggest haemodynamic compromise and she is rushed to the CT scanner. The CT scan demonstrates a large right sided perinephric haematoma. A 5 cm fat-dense lesion is also seen within the right kidney. Which of the following syndromes is the most accurate description of this clinical presentation? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Wunderlich syndrome
Spontaneous haemorrhage/rupture is a known complication of AMLs and is termed Wunderlich syndrome. Patients with AMLs larger than 4cm are at particularly increased risk of this. Wunderlich syndrome can occur in the context of Tuberous Sclerosis or in a patient with an isolated large AML. Although Wunderlich syndrome is most commonly caused by an underlying AML, it can also be seen with renal cell carcinoma or vascular malformations.
  Tuberous sclerosis
This condition would explain the presence of a fat containing renal lesion (AML) which is the underlying cause of the haematoma in this case, however it does not describe the main presentation of spontaneous haemorrhage. Not all patients with tuberous sclerosis have AMLs and not all of those with AMLs have large enough ones to rupture, and not all of those with large AMLs experience Wunderlich syndrome. In this question, arguably Tuberous Sclerosis is also a correct answer but in the setting of retroperitoneal haemorrhage, Wunderlich is a more correct/accurate answer.
  Majewski Syndrome
This is a variant of short-rib polydactyly syndrome with no renal associations.
GPT3_explain: I chose Wunderlich Syndrome as the most accurate description of this clinical presentation because it is a condition characterized by a large perinephric hematoma and a fat-dense lesion in the kidney. It is usually caused by a traumatic event, but can also occur spontaneously. Symptoms include sudden onset flank pain, bruising, and haemodynamic compromise.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old man is clinically suspected to have a small bowel carcinoid tumour. What would be the best test to confirm this diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Carcinoid
These tumours are relatively low-grade and slow growing. The small bowel is the most common location for the primary lesion and they are also the most common lesion found in the appendix, though usually the diagnosis is made incidentally when the surgical specimen is examined post appendicectomy. Otherwise, they tend to present insidiously however and therefore are often found to have metastasized by the time of diagnosis. The classical appearance on CT is of a mesenteric soft-tissue density mass containing flecks of calcification and causing a striking desmoplastic reaction in the adjacent mesentry giving it a spiculated appearance. This mass is not the primary tumour but rather a mesenteric metastatic mass. The primary itself may be too small to appreciate with CT but can sometimes be seen as a small arterially enhancing lesion. They can be seen in isolation or in the context of MEN 1 or MEN 2a.
The so-called carcinoid syndrome of flushing, diarrhoea, and bronchospasm occurs when serotonin is released by hepatic metastases into the systemic circulation. Around one in ten patients with a small bowel carcinoid present in this way. Heart failure can also occur due to fibrosis of the tricuspid and pulmonary valves secondary to the excess serotonin levels. On imaging the hepatic metastases are hypervascular, much like the primary lesion would be. There is a direct correlation between the size of the primary lesion and the likelihood of metastasis with 80% of those >20mm in diameter having nodal metastases and around half having hepatic metastases at the time of diagnosis.
Nuclear medicine is useful in the localisation and staging of carcinoid tumours.
111I-Octreotide: This has the highest sensitivity of the two and is taken up by hepatic metastases as well as the primary lesion. It is used for initial staging and for assessing disease response following treatment.
123I-MIBG: This is a useful test for localising the 10% of carcinoid tumours which do not take up Octreotide.
GPT3_explain: Octreotide scan is the best test to confirm a diagnosis of small bowel carcinoid tumour. This scan uses a radioactive form of octreotide, a hormone that is specifically taken up by neuroendocrine tumours, including carcinoid tumours. This allows the radiologist to identify and measure the size of the tumour, as well as detect the presence of metastases. It is a safe, non-invasive test that can provide an accurate diagnosis.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical management, what is the best test to confirm the diagnosis?

Qn_Text: An extremely unwell patient is admitted to ITU after a major trauma incident. He is intubated, stabilised and currently has a GCS of 9. A C-spine injury of both C1 and C2 is strongly suspected owing to the mechanism of his injury. What will your initial C-spine imaging be?
A: CT spine from posterior fossa to T4
C: CT spine from C1 to T1
D: Portable lateral C-spine and CT C-spine
Explanation:
Explanation:
Technically the gold standard for imaging the c-spine in this scenario would be a CT angiogram of the neck, i.e. aortic arch to Circle of Willis. The answers here do not elaborate as to whether contrast has been given however the answer given is the closest to this.
The role of a CT angiogram of the carotids in the setting of trauma is primarily to identify vertebral artery injuries. This is particularly relevant if there are fractures involving the transverse foramen at any level or if there are fractures to both C1 and C2.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2 because a CT scan of the C-spine from C1 to T1 is the most comprehensive imaging study to assess for a C-spine injury in an extremely unwell patient. It provides detailed images of the vertebrae, intervertebral discs, and surrounding soft tissue and can detect fractures, ligamentous disruption, and other signs of injury. In addition, it can help to rule out any other potential causes of the patient's low GCS.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical decision making, what is the best course of action?

This question falls under 3. A question about clinical decision making, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: A 30-year-old man, who is managed by the respiratory physicians for his severe asthma, complains of severe odynophagia. You are asked to perform a barium swallow to aid diagnosis and this demonstrates multiple small ring-like indentations to the mid-oesophagus. The intervening mucosa is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Oesophagitis
Inflammation of the oesophagus usually presents with severe pain on swallowing (odynophagia). There are many different aetiologies but there are a few features which can help separate the differential diagnoses on imaging.
Aetiology
Features
Candidiasis
Immunocompromised patients (including long term steroid therapy)
Upper half of the oesophagus
Irregular, longitudinal plaques with normal mucosa in between
Fulminant candidiasis
Patients with AIDs
Shaggy outline from a pseudomembrane of joined-together plaques
Herpes simplex
Immunocompromised patients
Flu-like symptoms
Multiple small ulcers, each may have a halo of oedema
CMV / HIV oesophagitis
One large ulcer
These two are indistinguishable from one another by appearance
Caustic
Ingestion of corrosive substance
Affects middle and lower thirds
Progression from oedema to ulceration to scarring over days
Barrett oesophagitis
Columnar metaplasia of distal oesophagus in response to reflux
Long strictures
Reticular mucosal pattern
Drug-induced
Ulcers at sites of extrinsic compression in the mid oesophagus
Patients taking medication without enough water immediately prior to going to bed
Idiopathic eosinophilic oesophagitis
History of atopy usually present
Specific ring-like indentations to the oesophagus
  Glycogen acanthosis
This condition is caused by benign age-related squamous hyperplasia but, based on its imaging features, a differential diagnosis for candidiasis. On a barium swallow there will be small rounded white plaques in a random distribution, predominantly affecting the middle and upper oesophagus. Patients are typically middle aged or elderly.
GPT3_explain: Idiopathic eosinophilic oesophagitis is the most likely diagnosis because the barium swallow demonstrated multiple small ring-like indentations to the mid-oesophagus, which is a characteristic symptom of this condition. Additionally, the intervening mucosa was normal, which is also consistent with this diagnosis.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing an MRI of the pelvis. The foveal artery passes through which ligament to supply the head of the femur? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The ligament teres (ligament of the head of the femur) is the only intracapsular ligament of the hip joint. This small ligament originates from the acetabular notch and inserts into the fovea of the femoral head.
It is mainly important not for the stability it provides but instead because it carries the foveal artery, which is a branch of the obturator artery. This artery can become the only blood supply to the femoral head in the case of neck of femur fracture.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because the iliofemoral ligament is the only ligament that the foveal artery passes through to supply the head of the femur. The other ligaments listed are not involved in the foveal artery's pathway.
Cat_Long:
3. A question that requires an understanding of the principles of the subject matter.

1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 78-year-old man presents with an acutely ischaemic left leg and is managed with primary pharmacological recanalization which fails to re-perfuse the leg. He then absconds from the ward but represents after 48 hours as his leg is becoming increasingly painful, and is now mottled in appearance. No pulses can be found below the knee. Which of the following would be the next best option for this gentleman?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Radiology has a significant role to play in the diagnosis of acute limb ischaemia – all centres should be able to perform upper or lower limb CT angiography at all hours of the day or night for truly acute cases, the better to direct subsequent management. Patients receive the best care where Interventional Radiology and Vascular Surgery departments work well together and treatment can be tailored according to the individual patient. There will be patients for whom catheter directed thrombolysis is not feasible and vice versa. Sadly, the initial treatment of either surgery or catheter directed thrombolysis is not always successful and whilst every option should be explored prior to amputation the presence of non-viable tissue precludes further options in this particular case.
GPT3_explain: Amputation is the only option that would provide relief to the patient in this situation. The other options would not provide relief and may even be contraindicated due to the patient's age and the severity of his condition. The patient's leg is already ischemic and mottled and no pulses can be felt below the knee, indicating that the leg is beyond the point of salvage. Amputation is the only option that would provide relief from the pain and prevent further tissue damage.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the management of a particular condition.

This question falls under 3. A question about the management of a particular condition.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing an MRI scan of a patient’s leg to be discussed in the next haematology MDT. The patient has been receiving chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. There are multiple lesions which centrally are isointense on both T1 and T2 to the adjacent bone marrow but which have a dark serpiginous border on the T1 weighted sequences and show a double line sign on the fat suppressed T2 weighted sequence. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Medullary osteonecrosis can be secondary to anything leading to vascular compromise and has the propensity to lead to severe loss or architecture and loss of function, not to mention pain, to the patient. It is an important diagnosis to make. IOn plain film the finding is usually of a lucent area with a sclerotic serpiginous border of granulation tissue. On MRI this serpiginous border returns low signal on T1 and a ‘double-line’ sign on T2 (high signal of granulation tissue surrounded by low signal of sclerosis). Strangely enough, centrally within the infarction the signal retains the characteristics of normal fatty marrow.
Causes of bone infarction
Sickle cell disease
Excess corticosteroid
Pancreatitis
Caisson disease (aka The Bends)
Gaucher disease
Trauma
Leukaemia/lymphoma
  Terminology
Osteonecrosis
Bone death
Bone infarct
Medullary osteonecrosis
Avascular necrosis
Subchondral osteonecrosis
GPT3_explain: The most likely explanation for the MRI findings is that the patient is suffering from leukaemia recurrence. The lesions being isointense on both T1 and T2, and having a dark serpiginous border on the T1 weighted sequences and a double line sign on the fat suppressed T2 weighted sequence are all characteristic of leukaemic recurrence. Additionally, the patient has been receiving chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, which further supports the diagnosis of leukaemia recurrence.

Qn_Text: A baby boy attends his GP surgery for routine immunisations at 12 weeks old. The practice nurse is concerned that the baby's head is an unusual shape and asks the GP to see the baby. She agrees and the baby is referred to the paediatric services at your local hospital. A CT is performed which shows premature fusion of a cranial suture. Which suture is most commonly involved in craniosynostosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Craniosynostosis
Premature closure of one or more of the sutures leads to an abnormal shape to the head developing as the brain continues to grow within a confined space.
Of these by far the most common is sagittal craniosynostosis which causes elongation of the skull and is termed scaphocephaly meaning 'boat-like'.
  Suture Age of Closure Craniosynostosis
Metopic (5%) 3-9m Trigonocephaly
Sagittal (50%) 30-40yrs Scaphocephaly
Coronal (20%) 30-40yrs Unilateral = Plagiocephaly
    Bilateral = Brachycephaly
Lambdoid (5%) 30-40yrs Unilateral = Plagiocephaly
    Bilateral = Brachycephaly
All   Oxycephaly or turricephaly
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Xxjamesxx CC BY-SA 3.0
  There are a number of conditions which can cause craniosynostosis:
Primary - sporadic or familial
Secondary
Haematological (sickle cell disease, thalassaemia)
Endocrine (hyperthyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, hypercalcaemia, hypophosphataemia)
GPT3_explain: The sagittal suture is the most commonly involved suture in craniosynostosis, which is a condition in which one or more of the cranial sutures close prematurely. This can cause an abnormal head shape and can lead to developmental delays and other medical issues. The sagittal suture is located in the middle of the skull, running from front to back, and is the longest of the cranial sutures. It is responsible for allowing the skull to grow in length, so when it closes prematurely, it can cause the head to become abnormally shaped.

Qn_Text: A mother brings her 4 day old baby back to the post-natal ward. She is worried that he is not feeding well and seems more lethargic. He was born at term following induction for prolonged rupture of membranes. A CXR shows bilateral patchy infiltrates with a right sided pleural effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Neonatal pneumonia
Group B strep (GBS) is a beta-haemolytic bacterium known to cause pneumonia in neonates. Factors increasing the risk of developing neonatal GBS pneumonia include:
Prematurity
Long labour
Complicated labour
Prolonged rupture of membranes
GBS is the most common cause of neonatal pneumonia and, unlike other bacteria, causes pleural effusions.
Other causes of neonatal pneumonia are listeria, pneumococci, candida and chlamydia.
  Meconium aspiration
Meconium is sticky and causes a chemical pneumonitis in the lungs, seen as patchy consolidation. In addition small globules of meconium entering bronchi and bronchioles of a decreasing calibre act as a ball-valve mechanism and lead to air trapping; thus the lung volumes of a baby with meconium aspiration may be increased. Air bronchograms are notably absent. The typical baby in a meconium aspiration situation is post-term.
  Transient tachypnoea of the newborn (TTN)
The classical patient for TTN would be a term baby born by caesarean section to a diabetic mother. During normal vaginal delivery the compression of the baby as it descends the birth canal acts to squeeze fluid out from its lungs. This mechanism is all but absent during a caesarean section. Consequently these babies are born with an excess of retained fluid. The CXR of an affected baby will show bilateral symmetrical air space opacification with air bronchograms, fluid in the fissures and pleural effusions. This peaks in severity at 24hrs but resolves by three days.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 1, Streptococcal pneumonia (Group B), as the most likely diagnosis because it is the most common cause of pneumonia in newborns. It is also the most common cause of prolonged rupture of membranes, which is a risk factor in this case. Additionally, the CXR findings of patchy infiltrates and a right sided pleural effusion are consistent with this diagnosis.

Qn_Text: Which of the following structures is drained by the superior mesenteric lymph nodes? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
The abdominal lymph nodes can be broadly divided into pre-aortic and para-aortic groups, depending upon their relationship to the aorta.
The pre-aortic nodes lie anterior to the aorta and lie around the origins of the visceral (anterior) arteries. They drain the gastrointestinal tract and its accessory viscera (liver, spleen and pancreas). These nodes can be further divided into three groups, each lying near to the origins of their respective artery:
Coeliac lymph nodes
Superior mesenteric lymph nodes
Inferior mesenteric lymph nodes
  All of the efferent lymphatics from the pre-aortic nodes drain into the intestinal trunk, which in turn drains into the cisterna chlyi.
The structures drained by each of these groups is summarized in the table below:
Group Structures drained
Coeliac lymph nodes
Stomach
Most of the duodenum
Liver and biliary tree
Pancreas
Spleen
Superior mesenteric lymph nodes
Part of the duodenum
Jejunum and ileum
Caecum and appendix
Ascending colon
Transverse colon
Inferior mesenteric lymph nodes
Descending colon
Sigmoid colon
Upper rectum
  Arrangement of the abdominal lymph nodes (from Gray’s Anatomy)
GPT3_explain: The superior mesenteric lymph nodes drain the lymphatic vessels from the ascending colon, transverse colon, and descending colon. Therefore, the structure that is drained by the superior mesenteric lymph nodes is the descending colon.
