3. A question about problem solving or critical thinking?

1. Basic factual recall

Qn_Text: A 74-year-old lady has been getting worsening hip pain for many months. Her GP suspects it is due to osteoarthritis but requests an x-ray. The x-ray shows an abnormality in the right ilium. The bone appears expanded in parts and there are coarse trabeculations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Paget disease
Paget disease is seldom found in patients below the age of 50 but is one of the more common musculoskeletal abnormalities thereafter. It consists of polyostotic, asymmetric disordered bone remodelling where intensive osteoclastic activity leads to multiple lytic lesions before osteoblastic activity results in the formation of sclerotic bone. A variety of imaging findings can be seen with x-ray.
Lytic phase: During the lytic phase, radiolucency with a ‘flame’ or ‘blade of grass’ shape extends along the diaphysis and osteoporosis circumscripta (large lucent areas of skull) can be found in the skull.
Mixed phase: lytic and sclerotic phenomena
Sclerotic phase: densely sclerotic bone such as the classical ‘ivory vertebra’ can be found.
Clinically it can be an incidental asymptomatic diagnosis or can present as all or any of:
Elevated ALP with a normal calcium and phosphate
A pathological fracture – although it may be sclerotic, the bone structure is disordered and therefore weaker than normal bone.
Cranial nerve palsies – due to compression at neural foramina
Enlarging head / hat size – due to widening of the diploic spaces (referred to as the Tam O’Shanter sign, whereby the skull takes on the appearance of a the Scottish hat called the Tam O’Shanter)
High output cardiac failure – this is a rare presentation caused by markedly increased bony perfusion
Pain – in the absence of a fracture, it is usually not a painful condition per se but can co-exist with other conditions such as osteoarthritis which may be the cause of the patient’s pain
Radiologically the hallmarks are bony expansion with coarsening of the trabeculae and cortices. On a bone scan active lesions will show increased uptake due to their increased blood flow.
Sarcomatous degeneration of the affected sites into either an osteosarcoma, malignant fibrous histiocytoma or chondrosarcoma carries a poor prognosis and careful study should be made of any known lesions at each imaging opportunity. New soft tissue component formation or new lysis of previously sclerotic bone should raise suspicion.
  Hyperparathyroidism
Parathyroid hormone acts to increase calcium levels either by promoting reabsorption in the kidneys or by acting on the osteoclasts of the bones and leads to increased bone resorption. This is seen as generalised osteopenia and cortical thinning, particularly of the subperiosteal bone.
Primary hyperparathyroidism is usually caused by an autonomous adenoma (alternatively parathyroid hyperplasia or a parathyroid carcinoma). Medullary nephrocalcinosis is most commonly caused by primary hyperparathyroidism but does also occur with secondary and tertiary hyperparathyroidism.
Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a hyperplastic response of the parathyroid glands to the high phosphate and low calcium levels which accompany renal osteodystrophy. Soft tissue calcification is very much a feature of renal osteodystrophy. Confusingly the high circulating levels of phosphate in renal osteodystrophy leads to dystrophic mineralisation of trabecular bone which is seen as sclerosis; hence renal osteodystrophy is a cause of generalised increase in bone density despite hyperparathyroidism being a cause of osteopenia.
Tertiary hyperparathyroidism occurs when a patient with secondary hyperparathyroidism (i.e. chronic overstimulation of the parathyroid glands) goes on to develop an autonomous adenoma.
  Osteoporosis
Loss of bone mass is called osteoporosis. It can result from a variety of mechanisms detailed in the table. Serum calcium, phosphate and ALP levels may all be normal in patients with osteoporosis. Loss of bone mass causes the bones to be susceptible to fractures resulting from everyday stress (insufficiency fractures) or as a result of minor trauma. The typical fractures would be a Colles fracture of the wrist or a fractured neck of femur.
Diagnosis is by DEXA (dual energy x-ray absorpitometry) whereby images are taken usually of the spine or femoral neck. By subtracting the two, the density of the bone can be calculated. Patients are scored by comparing their bone density to either age matched normal individuals (Z-score, said to be a more reliable figure) or to young adults (T-score). A T-score of less than -2.5 is considered diagnostic.
The ‘H’ sign or Honda sign is seen on nuclear medicine bone scans. It occurs when there is increased uptake in the sacrum as a result of insufficiency fractures and is often caused by underlying osteoporosis.
  Cause
Example
Congenital
Osteogenesis imperfecta
Idiopathic
So-called age related. Particularly affects elderly women.
Nutritional
Malabsorption, liver disease
Endocrine
Various
Renal failure
Renal osteodystrophy
Mechanical
Immobilisation
Arthritides
Rheumatoid arthritis
Localised
Sudeck dystrophy
  Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI)
A defect on either chromosome 7 or 17 leads to abnormal type 1 collagen. Most cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. An adult with OI is most likely to have either type I or type IV. On imaging there is diffuse undermineralisation of the skeleton and (sometimes extreme) cortical thinning. Once a child with OP has become mobile the soft bones become bowed under the weight of the body. The pressure of the femoral heads on the soft acetabulae leads to acetabular protrusion. Basilar invagination results from pressure of the cervical spine on the base of the skull. Insufficiency fracture of the vertebral bodies lead to a biconcave appearance. OI is a differential diagnosis for multiple wormian bones which persist to adulthood.
  Type
Inheritance
Clinical features
I
AD
Most common form. Normal life expectancy. Presents aged 2-6. Blue sclera, joint laxity, deafness.
II
AR
Often stillborn or perinatal death due to pulmonary hypoplasia.
III
AR
Progressively deforming, fractures at birth in most cases.
IV
AD
Variable severity. Usually shorter in statue, by adulthood, than normal. Normal colour sclera. Usually normal hearing.
GPT3_explain: Paget disease is a disorder of the bone remodeling cycle which results in abnormal bone formation. It is characterized by an increase in bone turnover, leading to increased bone mass, enlarged and deformed bones, and often pain. The x-ray findings of an expanded ilium with coarse trabeculations are consistent with Paget disease, making it the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 43-year-old man presents with a unilateral Horner syndrome. You suspect he may have an internal carotid artery dissection. What is the best investigation to perform?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
On T1w fat saturated images the dissection appears as a crescenteric high signal aka ‘the sickle sign’ or ‘the fried egg’. A slice transverse through the vessel shows hyperintensity in a crescenteric or circumferential shape to the wall of the affected vessel. Fat saturated T1 sequences may be the most sensitive sequence for cerebral artery dissections but similar findings can still be seen on T2. Unlike large vessel dissections the anatomy here is usually too small to see a dissection flap.
The other classic cause of a Horner syndrome might be an ipsilateral PCOM or PCA aneurysm.
On duplex ultrasound a dissection manifests as a thickened hypoechoic vessel wall with a low flow due to the stenotic effect of the dissection flap but in the acute setting ultrasound has largely been superseded by cross-sectional imaging and therefore these findings are more likely to be incidentally picked up in cases where dissection is not suspected.
The main feature of a dissection on a plain CT would be a crescenteric high attenuation rim representing the acute/subacute mural haematoma formed within the false lumen. The remaining true lumen may be narrowed compared to the contralateral side. With such a minimal question there is an argument to suggest that a plain CT to rule out a haemorrhagic stroke would be the most appropriate imaging however this would be an unusual presentation in an unusual age range for this eventuality.
CT angiography does have an excellent sensitivity and specificity in the diagnosis of craniocervical dissections although image interpretation can be hindered by streak artefact from the skull base. Usually in the DGH setting however this is the test that the patient would be most likely to undergo first. That does not, however, mean it is the best test, it is simply a matter of pragmatism that most hospitals would be able to arrange a CTA on a more emergent basis than an MRA.
MRA imaging is more useful in the diagnosis of carotid artery dissection than in vertebral artery dissection but is thought of as the modality of choice.
No investigation would only be pertinent if a mis-diagnosis of Bell palsy had been made.
Overall this is a tricky question. In the real world you could make a case for either CTA or MRA (in the absence of the option of DSA which would be the gold standard). On balance the current trend seems to be that MRA is the best answer to give.
GPT3_explain: CT angiography is the best investigation to perform in a patient with a unilateral Horner syndrome, as it can provide detailed images of the internal carotid artery to assess for a dissection. It is also non-invasive and can provide an accurate diagnosis quickly.

Qn_Text: Which of the following is NOT a secondary sign of an acute rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament? Select one answer only.
B: Buckling of the posterior cruciate ligament
D: Bony contusion to the posterolateral tibia
E: Bony contusion to the lateral femoral condyle
Explanation:
Explanation:
The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is particularly vulnerable to clip injuries and pivot shift injuries. Secondary signs of an ACL tear include:
Anterior translation of the tibia to >5mm
Bowing of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) to <105o
So-called ‘uncovering’ of the lateral meniscus where there is posterior displacement of the posterior horn of the lateral meniscus by at least 3.5mm
Lateral compartment contusions (if pivot shift or clip injury mechanism)
Anterior contusions (if hyperextension mechanism)
Although the medial collateral ligament can also be ruptured during a pivot shift or clip type injury, it is not considered as a secondary sign of ACL rupture.
  Clip injury and pivot shift injury
These two injuries are very similar. Both involve valgus stress on a flexed knee (such as a tackle to the knee during sports). A pivot shift injury also requires external rotation of the tibia. The three main structures most at risk during these injuries are:
Anterior cruciate ligament (especially in a pivot shift injury)
Medial collateral ligament (especially in a clip injury)
Medial meniscus (remember that the medial meniscus is attached to the medial collateral ligament)
If all three are present together it is referred to as the O’Donoghue triad. Since O’Donoghue defined this triad however, it has been discovered that lateral meniscal tears are actually more common with this type of injury than medial meniscus ones.
Bony contusions occur at the side of impact because the proximal tibia and distal femur impact on one another thus:
Lateral tibial plateau (posterolateral in pivot shift injury)
Lateral femoral condyle
GPT3_explain: The correct answer is 5. Medial collateral ligament rupture is not a secondary sign of an acute rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament, as the medial collateral ligament is a separate structure from the anterior cruciate ligament. The other four options are all secondary signs of an acute rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament.
Cat_Long:

Qn_Text: A patient presents with a known history of coronary artery disease presents again with acute chest pain and undergoes Cardiac MRI within 24 hours to investigate if salvageable myocardium is present. A focal wall motion abnormality is demonstrated in the anterolateral wall, but wall thickness remains normal. No invasive treatment is undertaken and follow-up imaging demonstrates resolution of the motion artefact. What is the most accurate description of this pathology?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Stunned myocardium
This gives a wall motion abnormality with high T2 signal. There is normal perfusion on Thallium or sestamibi scanning which is a key differentiating feature against hibernating myocardium. It should be expected to spontaneously resolve, whereas hibernating myocardium will not resolve spontaneously.
  Myocardial scar / Chronic infarct
This is a non-reperfusable myocardial defect (chronic infarct). It gives a wall motion abnormality but would demonstrate thinned myocardium. The T2 signal is low. Scars demonstrate abnormal Thallium perfusion but does not redistribute with delayed thallium, and does not take up FDG.
  Hibernating myocardium
This can be seen as a wall motion abnormality, but also gives abnormal fixed perfusion. Hybernating myocardium redistributes delayed thallium and takes up FDG.
  Focal myocarditis
This classically affects the mid-wall or epicardial (not subendocardial) and does not stay confined to a vascular territory.
GPT3_explain: Hibernating myocardium is the most accurate description of this pathology because it is characterized by a myocardial wall motion abnormality in the absence of a wall thickness abnormality. This is indicative of a reversible myocardial dysfunction due to ischemia, which is typically seen in patients with known coronary artery disease. In this case, follow-up imaging demonstrated the resolution of the motion artefact, further supporting the diagnosis of hibernating myocardium.

Qn_Text: An 85-year-old man undergoes a total hip replacement. Two years later he attends for follow up and complains of some pain and stiffness in the new joint. He undergoes an MRI scan which shows a large mass lesion posterior to the joint. There is marked susceptibility artefact within the lesion. With which kind of prosthesis is this condition associated?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Aseptic lymphocyte-dominated vasculitis associated lesion (ALVAL)
This is a relatively new phenomenon which has been found to result from metal on metal implants. As a consequence of this discovery, the use of such implants has been curtailed to specific circumstances. The condition arises when nanoparticles of the metal are created within the joint by the two surfaces rubbing against one another. The nanoparticles are ingested by macrophages but are toxic to them. The appearance on an MRI is akin to a sterile inflammatory lesion, also referred to as a pseudotumour. Most commonly these appear in a posterior location to the joint.
GPT3_explain: Metal on metal prostheses are associated with this condition because they can cause metal debris to accumulate in the tissue surrounding the joint. This debris can cause inflammation and pain in the joint, as well as the formation of a large mass lesion. The MRI scan is showing the presence of a large mass lesion and marked susceptibility artefact, which is indicative of the presence of metal debris.

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man presents with an acute left third cranial nerve palsy and a headache. A CT scan shows subarachnoid haemorrhage. Most of the blood is concentrated around the quadrigeminal cistern. What is the most likely diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The quadrigeminal cistern sits behind the midbrain, just above the cerebellum. The ambient cisterns run around the posterolateral aspect of the midbrain on either side joining to the interpeduncular cistern and is essentially an extension of the quadrigeminal cistern.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
  The posterior communicating artery (PCom) runs between the internal carotid artery and the posterior cerebral artery. The PComs sit anterior to the midbrain and blood from an aneurysm of the PCom will extend into the interpeduncular cistern, ambient cisterns and thereby to the quadrigeminal cistern.
The third cranial nerve runs parallel to the posterior communicating artery and dives under the posterior cerebral artery. The association between PCOM or PCA pathology and third nerve palsy signs is classical. If a patient has a painful ptosis, a PCOM aneurysm should be considered. It will be an ipsilateral pathology because the Oculomotor nerve is post-ganglionic at this point.
The diagnostic pathway to investigate for intracranial aneurysms following a subarachnoid haemorrhage is:
CT angiogram
Invasive angiogram
Second invasive angiogram after approx 10 days.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because PCom aneurysms are the most common cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage. They are usually located near the quadrigeminal cistern, where the CT scan indicated the blood was concentrated. Other causes of subarachnoid haemorrhage, such as aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery (ACom), internal carotid artery (ICA), posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), and anterior cerebral artery (ACA), are less common causes of subarachnoid haemorrhage.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 64-year-old man is reviewed in clinic 8 years following a partial gastrectomy for a T2N0M0 gastrointestinal stromal tumour. He is experiencing symptoms of dysphagia and early satiety. You have been asked to perform a barium meal to find the cause of the problem. The barium meal shows a mottled filling defect which does not appear to be attached to the gastric wall. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Bezoar
The word bezoar comes from the Persian word for antidote (JK Rowling had a point), and quite apart from their usage in the fictional wizarding world of Harry Potter the term is used to describe concretions of ingested matter which have collected in the stomach or other part of the gastrointestinal tract.
A phytobezoar - this consists of undigested fibrous plant matter
A trichobezoar – this consists of ingested hair and occurs almost exclusively in women, 80% of whom are under the age of 30.
A number of conditions can predispose patients to developing a bezoar; chiefly those which impede passage through the stomach due to either the sheer quantity of ingested matter, the lack of gastric motility or an outright gastric outlet obstruction.
Underlying causes of a bezoar
Poor gastric motility (vagotomy, diabetes, connective tissue disorder)
Vagotomy
Diabetes
Connective tissue disorder
Myotonic dystrophy
Hypothyroidism
Insufficient mechanical or acid/protease action
Gastrectomy
Dental problems
Gastric outlet obstruction
Ulcers
Strictures
  On a fluoroscopic study the bezoar will appear as a large intraluminal filling defect which moves with patient positioning and does not appear to be fixed to the wall at any point. Often on CT the bezoar will be strikingly obvious as a large but smoothly rounded heterogenous mass within the stomach. Locules of gas within the mass are common.
  Bouveret syndrome
This is akin to a gallstone ileus where the level of obstruction is the proximal duodenum and there is consequential gastric outlet obstruction.
  Mirizzi syndrome
Obstruction of the common bile duct by extrinsic compression from a gallstone sitting within the cystic duct is called Mirizzi syndrome.
  Duplication cysts
Around quarter of duplication cysts occur in each of the ileum, oesophagus and colon (of these the ileum is the most common). The remaining quarter includes the stomach, jejunum and duodenum. A barium study may show a filling defect reminiscent of an extrinsic mass and if it is visible on ultrasound it would appear as a rounded or tubular cystic mass. For the most part however the diagnosis can be made on CT or MRI. The thin wall of the cyst may enhance slightly on CT and on MRI they will return high T2 signal, much as would be expected from a cystic structure.
  Stromal tumour also known as GIST (Gastrointestinal stromal tumour)
Particularly when of low staging at resection, these tumours carry an excellent prognosis. Unfortunately around half of patients present with metastatic disease owing to the relatively indolent nature of the primary lesion. Tumour histology is used to guide follow up and newer antibody therapies have also improved outcomes significantly.
70% of GISTs occur in the stomach with most of the remainder being found in the small bowel. Clinical presentation varies slightly with the exact location but dysphagia and early satiety are common, as are sequelae from mucosal ulceration and bleeding. They can occur as a feature of neurofibromatosis type 1 and are also discussed in connection to the Carney triad (Not to be confused with Carney syndrome). On imaging they may be occult or appear as a well-circumscribed submucosal mass. The low attenuation is attributable to central necrosis within the mass. Characteristically however they tend to enlarge extraluminally into the lesser sac, gastrosplenic or gastrohepatic ligaments. Of note, lymph node enlargement is specifically not a feature and an alternative diagnosis should be sought if lymph node enlargement is present.
Carney Triad
Carney syndrome
Pulmonary chondromas
Atrial myxoma
Gastric leiomyosarcoma (GIST)
Facial/buccal pigmentation
Extra-adrenal paraganglioma
Sertoli tumour of the testis
  Pituitary adenoma
GPT3_explain: Phytobezoar is the most likely explanation for the mottled filling defect seen in the barium meal. This is because phytobezoars are composed of indigestible plant material that can accumulate in the stomach, leading to a mottled filling defect.

Qn_Text: A patient presents with visual loss and is found to have a right homonymous hemianopia What is the most likely location of the lesion?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
A superior quadrantanopia arises from a temporal lesion (Meyers loop).
An inferior quadrantanopia arises from a parietal lesion (Dorsal optic radiation).
By the time the tracts reach the occipital lobe they have rejoined and lesions of the occipital cortex cause hemianopias, scotomas or cortical blindness.
      1. Monocular blindness
2. Bitemporal hemianopia
3. Homonymous hemianopia - close to but post-chiasmatic in location, or involving the occipital lobe in such a way as to affect both the superior and inferior optic tracts together.
4. Inferior quadrantonopia - Dorsal optic radiation, parietal lobe
5. Superior quadrantanopia - Meyers loop, temporal lobe
GPT3_explain: The right temporal lobe is the most likely location of the lesion because a homonymous hemianopia indicates that the visual field defect is caused by a lesion in the same side of the brain. Since the patient has a right homonymous hemianopia, the lesion is most likely located in the right temporal lobe.
Cat_Long: This question falls under the category of clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A patient undergoes an MRI for a brain lesion seen on CT. A month later he complains to his GP of pain and itching over his foot and ankle. On examination he has a red indurating rash with paraesthesia. He also mentions being short of breath when lying flat. What is the most likely explanation?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
On balance nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) seems to fit best as the itchiness of the rash described fits better than it does for sarcoid. Dyspnoea has been described in NSF patients but is by no means a prominent feature though. The question writer has however, gone to the trouble of telling us that the patient has had an MRI scan which adds to the weight of evidence for NSF. This would render the brain lesion an incidental finding. On the other hand there is no suggestion that the patient has a poor renal function to predispose him or her to NSF (except possibly a post-iodiniated contrast nephropathy following the CT scan, despite the lack of clarity regarding time frames in this regard).
  NSF
Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a very nasty condition which develops a few weeks or months after a patient has received Gadolinium in patients with acute or chronic renal failure, in particular post liver or kidney transplant patients (NB. hepatorenal syndrome). No particular therapy for it has been found to be effective. Dyspnoea has been described in association with NSF in some literature.
  Sarcoidosis
Erythema nodosum is a well described manifestation of sarcoidosis but is usually described as tender erythematous nodules.
The thoracic manifestations of sarcoid are legion and shortness of breath could well be a symptom.
Neurosarcoid classically affects the cranial nerves but mass lesions can occur.
  SLE
The cutaneous manifestations of SLE are not usually itchy and the brain parenchyma is not often involved (with the exception of haemorrhage or abscess formation), although neuropsychiatric symptoms do occur.
  Whipple disease
Whipple disease causes malabsorption. Tropical sprue also causes malabsorption and is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis but otherwise is unrelated to the scenario described.
  Extrinsic allergic alveolitis
This is a thoracic condition caused by an excessive immune response to an inhaled antigen.
GPT3_explain: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) is a rare disorder that is associated with exposure to gadolinium-based contrast agents used in MRI scans. It is characterized by a red, indurated rash with paraesthesia, as well as shortness of breath when lying flat. It is also associated with pain and itching over the foot and ankle. Therefore, Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is the most likely explanation for the patient's symptoms.

Qn_Text: A 55-year-old man complains to his GP aching in his scrotum. He is referred for an ultrasound scan which shows that, as well as a left sided varicocoele, there are multiple tubular anechoic structures within the left testis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Rete testis ectasia
This is a relatively common finding in men around the age of 60. It is asymptomatic and therefore incidental. The rete testis is the name given to the tubules which collect spermatozoa from the seminiferous tubules and deliver them to the extra-testicular ducts. The normal rete testis is too small to appreciate with ultrasound but when, through age, the distal portion becomes stenosed, there is buildup of fluid within the rete testis. This is then seen as tubular branching anechoic structures within the testis.
  Spermatocoele
A spermatocoele is a focal dilatation of a duct within the head of the epididymis. Since they contain protein debris and spermatozoa, low level echoes can be seen floating within them differentiating them from epididymal cysts. They are essentially an incidental asymptotic finding. 
  Epididymal cyst
A cystic structure within the epididymis is most commonly a simple cyst. They can present as palpable masses or be found incidentally. On ultrasound they behave as you might expect from a cyst, with posterior acoustic enhancement of an anechoic round structure. The main differential diagnosis is a spermatocoele which, unlike a simple cyst, usually contains echogenic material. The latter is usually only found in the epididymal head. 
  Tunica albuginea cyst
The tunica albuginea is a fibrous layer covering the testicle. On ultrasound it appears as the thin echogenic line surrounding the testicle. When cysts form here they are usually palpable as small well-defined lumps a few millimetres in diameter. Appearances on ultrasound usually conform to those expected from any straightforward cyst i.e. An sharply defined anechoic structure with acoustic enhancement posteriorly. They can be uni or multilocular and although they can exert mass effect on the underlying testicle they do not affect the testicular tissue beyond this. They are most commonly located at the anterosuperior or superolateral aspect of the testicle.
  Intratesticular cyst
These are not readily palpable and therefore are seen only as incidental findings. They demonstrate the usual characteristics of any cyst on ultrasound but are located within the testicle itself. They are inconsequential but for their distinction from cystic teratomas. The latter will have solid enhancing components on an MRI scan. Provided, however, there is no ambiguity on ultrasound, no further follow up would be needed for a straightforward intratesticular cyst.
  Seminoma
Germ cell tumours are divided into seminomas and non-seminomatous varieties. They are very common and comprise almost half of all testicular tumours. They can often be found incidentally or subsequent to any trauma which might cause the patient to self-examine and discover a testicular lump. Alternatively they can present as a vague dull scrotal aching sensation with no lump.
Lymphatic drainage is to the retroperitoneum. Para-aortic lymph nodes are therefore regional. Involvement of the internal, external and common iliac nodes however, is considered non-regional. Only if there has been previous scrotal or inguinal surgery disrupting tissue planes are inguinal or external iliac artery nodes considered regional.
They typically are found in patients in their 40s. Testicular tumours can be diagnosed with a strong pre-test probability based solely on age as detailed in the table below. On ultrasound there will be an intratesticular low reflectivity well-defined mass. Colour doppler flow can be seen within the mass.
  Age at diagnosis
Tumour
10s
Yolk sac tumour or teratoma
20s + 30s
Choriocarcinoma
30s
Embryonal cell carcinoma
40s
Seminoma
GPT3_explain: Intratesticular cysts are the most common type of cyst found in the testes, and are typically anechoic, meaning they do not show up on an ultrasound scan. They are usually benign and do not require treatment, though they can cause pain and discomfort.

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the CT scan of a 45-year-old man who previously underwent a splenectomy following a motorbike accident. His CT scan shows features consistent with splenosis. Which of the following best describes the likely findings? Select ONE answer only.
A: Multiple small soft tissue density nodules throughout the abdomen
Explanation:
Explanation:
Splenosis
When there has been trauma to the spleen, tiny fragments can migrate around the peritoneal cavity, attach to structures and grow into larger collections of splenic tissue. On imaging these behave exactly as you would expect the normal spleen to for each modality. They can cause confusion if they are mistaken for peritoneal deposits.
  Labelled RBC scan
During this scan the patient is injected with stannous phosphate which enters the red blood cells and primes them for labelling with technetium. After 20 minutes, 20ml of blood is taken out and combined with Tc99m pertechnetate. The blood is then heated to around 50oC for 35mins and then re-injected. The red blood cells damaged by this process are filtered out of the circulation by any normally functioning splenic tissue within the body. Absence of uptake on imaging is consistent with asplenia.
An alternative scan which can also be performed is a Tc99m sulphur colloid scan.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because splenosis is a condition in which fragments of the spleen are found in other parts of the abdomen after a splenectomy. This can manifest as multiple small soft tissue density nodules throughout the abdomen, which is the most likely finding on the CT scan.

Qn_Text: A 54-year-old male presents with disinhibition and ataxia. An MRI scan demonstrates optic nerve atrophy, subcortical white matter necrosis and hemorrhagic putaminal necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
Methanol poisoning
Optic nerve atrophy, subcortical white matter necrosis and hemorrhagic putaminal necrosis are classical findings.
  Carbon monoxide poisoning
T2 bright signal in the globus pallidus is the usual finding.
  Marchiafava-Bignami syndrome
This is often seen in alcoholic patients. There is swelling and T2 bright signal affecting the corpus callosum, involving the central fibres but sparing the dorsal and ventral fibres. This is known as the sandwich sign.
  Lead toxicity
This does not cause any classical neurological findings, but results in bands of increased density at the metaphyses.
  Iron overload
Iron accumulation in the brain causes signal drop out in the basal ganglia.
GPT3_explain: Marchiafava-Bignami Syndrome is the most likely diagnosis because it is characterized by optic nerve atrophy, subcortical white matter necrosis and hemorrhagic putaminal necrosis, which are all findings seen in the patient's MRI scan. This syndrome is associated with chronic alcoholism, which can also cause disinhibition and ataxia.

Qn_Text: The segmental branches of the renal artery divide to form which arteries? Select ONE answer only.
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
The arterial supply to the kidneys is from the renal arteries, two fast flowing arteries that arise from the abdominal aorta at the L2 vertebral level. As the abdominal aorta is situated slightly to the left of the midline the right renal artery is longer than the left. The kidneys receive approximately 20% of the cardiac output.
After arising from the aorta, the right renal artery passes behind the inferior vena cava, the right renal vein, the head of the pancreas, and the second part of the duodenum as it travels to the kidney. The left renal artery passes behind the left renal vein, the body of the pancreas and the splenic vein as it travels to the kidney. The left renal artery is crossed anteriorly by the inferior mesenteric vein.
The renal arteries then enter the kidney at thehila of the kidneys, which lie approximately in the transpyloric plane at the L1 vertebral level. At the hila the renal arteries divide into four or five segmental branches.
Each segmental branch divides to form the interlobar arteries that are situated on either side of every renal pyramid. These interlobar arteries then undergo further division to form the arcuate arteries.
The interlobular arteries are then given off at right angles from the side of the arcuate arteries, and head into the cortical substance. Once within the cortex a final division takes place with the interlobular arteries dividing to form the efferent arterioles.
In the outer two-thirds of the cortex, the efferent arterioles form the peritubular network. The inner third of the cortex is supplied by long, straight arteries known as the vasa recta.
      Image adapted from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Piotr Michal Jaworski CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Arcuate arteries because the segmental branches of the renal artery divide to form the arcuate arteries, which are the main arteries that supply the renal cortex. The arcuate arteries branch off into the interlobar arteries, which in turn branch off into interlobular arteries, which supply the glomeruli and the renal tubules. The peritubular network is formed by the interlobular arteries and the vasa recta are formed by the interlobular arteries and the arcuate arteries.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about ethical considerations, what is the best course of action?

1. Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: The CT scanner is broken so you are assisting with an aortic arch angiogram. A 6F pigtail catheter is in place. What is the appropriate rate of contrast and volume of contrast?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Although this might seem a little outdated, questions of this type have arisen in the exam and are important to know.
Generally speaking, the smaller the vessel, the slower the rate and the lower the volume.
  Location
Volume (cc)
Rate (cc/s)
Aortic arch
20-30
20
Abdominal aorta
16-25
16-20
Iliac arteries
8-10
6-10
Carotid arteries
7-9
4-6
GPT3_explain: I chose number 4 because it is the most appropriate rate of contrast and volume of contrast for an aortic arch angiogram using a 6F pigtail catheter. The rate of contrast should be between 6cc/s and 10cc/s, and the volume of contrast should be between 8cc and 10cc. This rate and volume of contrast will ensure that the angiogram is performed safely and effectively.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about clinical skills, what is the appropriate rate of contrast and volume of contrast?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the PET-CT scan of a patient with a known lung mass. The scan confirms a thoracic lesion showing avid uptake but there is also avidity in the right vocal cord. Which of the following statements is correct? Select ONE answer only.
A: The primary lung lesion is probably in the AP window
B: There is probably metastatic spread of the lung cancer to the right vocal cord
C: The lung lesion is probably a metastasis from a laryngeal cancer
D: The patient has lung cancer and laryngeal cancer
E: The lung cancer is most likely squamous cell in origin
Explanation:
Explanation:
Focal unilateral vocal cord uptake on a PET-CT scan is more likely to be due to the increased workload of the contralateral vocal cord muscles compensating for ipsilateral paralysis from involvement of the ipsilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve in the chest rather than metastatic infiltration of the contralateral vocal cord itself.
Vocal cord paralysis is a known sign of thoracic malignancy owing to innervation by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
Left - passes through the aortopulmonary window, under the aorta 
Right - passes under the right subclavian artery
  Infiltration of one of these nerves would lead to a unilateral vocal cord palsy. Since the left has a longer thoracic course, it is at greater risk of involvement in a thoracic malignancy. Infiltration may be by the index mass itself, or by an involved lymph node distant from the primary mass.
GPT3_explain: The PET-CT scan is confirming avidity in both the thoracic lesion and the right vocal cord. This indicates that there is likely to be both a lung cancer and a laryngeal cancer present in the patient. The other options are not supported by the imaging evidence and therefore cannot be confirmed.

3. A question about ethical considerations.

Qn_Text: A 70-year-old man with a high Hba1c and poorly controlled hypertension undergoes a CT scan of his head. This shows multiple fluid density spaces in both basal ganglia. A subsequent MRI shows no restriction in diffusion. Which of the following best explains these findings?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
In day to day reporting would be second nature to diagnose these. Both VR spaces and lacunar infarctions could be described in this manner however the history of diabetes and hypertension shifts the balance more towards lacunar infarctions. Chronic infarctions do not restrict diffusion.
  Cryptococcus
This is an opportunistic yeast-like fungus which therefore requires a degree of immunocompromise, typically AIDS. The cryptococcomas are non-enhancing low density lesions in the basal ganglia. A granulomatous meningitis can also occur. They can be differentiated from VR spaces on FLAIR where VR spaces will suppress (being CSF in content) whereas the mucoid cryptococcomas will not.
  Neurocysticercosis
A CNS infection caused by a tapeworm native to low income countries and carried by pigs. Cysts calcify over time. The cysts are classically described as a ‘cyst with a dot’.
  Lyme disease
Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burdorferi which is carried by ticks. Neurological findings are cranial or peripheral neuropathies and meningitis. On MRI there can be areas of high T2 signal and the condition is known as an MS mimic.
GPT3_explain: Lacunar infarcts are small, deep infarcts that occur in the basal ganglia, which is consistent with the CT scan findings of multiple fluid density spaces in both basal ganglia. Additionally, the MRI showed no restriction in diffusion, which further supports the diagnosis of lacunar infarcts. The other options do not explain the findings as well as lacunar infarcts.

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old woman presents with neck discomfort with pain and weakness in her arms and hands. She undergoes an MRI of her cervical spine for further assessment. The C4/C5 vertebral disc is seen to extrude posteriorly and effaces the exiting nerve root. Which nerve root is most likely to be affected? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
In the cervical spine the nerve roots exit at the spinal cord without needing to traverse (as in the lumbar spine). The exiting nerve root takes the name of the vertebra BELOW the affected disc. A disc protrusion at C3/4 will affect the C4 nerve root. This allows for the extra nerve root at C8 before reaching the thoracic spine. In the thoracic spine the affected level takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level.
In the lumbar spine the exiting nerve root is usually compressed in the neural foramen, whereas the traversing nerve root is compressed usually in the lateral recess. Far lateral bulges affect the exiting nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body ABOVE that level). Paracentral bulges affect the traversing nerve root (takes its name from the vertebral body BELOW that level).
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose 1 because the C4/C5 vertebral disc is seen to extrude posteriorly and efface the exiting nerve root. This means that the C4/C5 disc is pressing on the nerve root that exits between the C4 and C5 vertebrae, which would be the C5 nerve root.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the application of knowledge and skills in a clinical setting.

3. A question about the application of knowledge and skills in a clinical setting.

Qn_Text: A 32-year-old lady visits her GP with troubling symptoms of bloating and abdominal distension. Her GP performs a pregnancy test which is negative and refers her urgently for a scan. She undergoes a CT scan which shows extensive ascites as well as deposits causing scalloping of the liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Pseudomyxoma peritonei
Pseudomyxoma peritonei is the term used to denote the peritoneal cavity filled with mucinous fluid secondary to intraperitoneal rupture of a mucinous tumour. Most commonly the original tumour is an appendix mucocoele. Scalloping of the liver by loculated ascites is typical. It is more common in women than men and patients range in age from their 20s to 80s.
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because ovarian cancer is the most common cause of ascites and scalloping of the liver on a CT scan. Other possible causes of ascites and scalloping include cardiac failure, TB peritonitis, mesothelioma, and pseudomyxoma peritonei, but these are all less common than ovarian cancer. Additionally, the patient's age and negative pregnancy test make ovarian cancer even more likely.

Qn_Text: A 40 -year-old woman presents with acute abdominal pain. On examination she is tender and pyrexial. She is pyrexial, with an elevated WCC/CRP. Imaging shows that she has an IUCD which is correctly positioned in the uterus, a right adnexal abscess which is tracking into the psoas, and right sided hydronephrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Actinomycosis
The bacterium actinomyces israelii produces proteases which allows it to cross structures which would otherwise present a barrier to spread of infection. Within the abdominal cavity actinomycosis leads to abscess formation, and fistula development. It is usual for the patient to have previously suffered a ruptured appendix or to be using an IUCD, or other similar entities. In the case of an IUCD, tuboovarian abscesses can form and spread locally to involve the psoas. Extrinsic ureteric compression leads to hydronephrosis.
  Tuberculosis
Abdominal tuberculosis most commonly affects the ileocaecal junction with thickening of the ileocaecal valve and narrowing of the terminal ileum. This can be seen on fluoroscopic examination as the Fleischner sign or umbrella sign where the gaping ileocaecal valve abuts the thin, strictured terminal ileum. Local lymph node enlargement with or without central low attenuation to the lymph nodes may be seen on CT. Multiple different lesions in multiple sites (i.e. skip lesions) is also a feature and a characteristic feature is of elevation of the margins of an ulcer which follow the orientation of lymphoid follicles. In the colon this means the margins are elevated in the transverse plane but in the terminal ileum they are longitudinal. 
The involvement of the ileocaecal valve and the presence of skip lesions means that a key differential diagnosis is Crohn disease. Over half of cases of abdominal tuberculosis will have concurrent ascites whereas this is a relatively rare feature for Crohn disease and can be used as a discriminator.
Specifically relating to the stomach, tuberculosis can cause pyloric stenosis, multiple deep ulcers on the lesser curve, and linitis plastic type narrowing of the antrum.
GPT3_explain: Complicated appendicitis is the most likely diagnosis because the patient has acute abdominal pain, is tender and pyrexial, has an elevated WCC/CRP, and imaging shows a right adnexal abscess that is tracking into the psoas and right sided hydronephrosis. These signs and symptoms are consistent with an appendicitis that has progressed to the point of causing an abscess and hydronephrosis.

Qn_Text: A 15 yr old girl with irregular periods presents with an acute fever and pain and raised βHCG. She denies being sexually active. On USS there is a cystic mass with thick septa on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
Germ Cell tumour
Ovarian germ cell tumours include teratomas, yolk sac tumours, choriocarcinomas and mixed germ cell tumours. Ovarian embryonal carcinoma and dysgerminomas are also germ cell tumours. Approximately 95% of germ cell tumorus are benign teratomas and of the remaining 5% the most common ovarian malignant germ cell tumour is the dysgerminoma. Germ cell tumours make up approximately a quarter of all ovarian tumours and tend to affect young adults or children although can occur at any age. Besides pregnancy and gestational trophoblastic disease, βHCG can also be raised ovarian embryonal carcinoma and dysgerminoma. Embryonal carcinoma can also cause elevation of AFP levels although this would be more classically associated with a Leydig-Sertoli tumour. Embryonal carcinoma can cause menstrual irregularity and any torting ovarian tumour can lead to the acute presentation described. Thick septa as a finding in ovarian masses is strongly linked to malignancy of any nature.
  Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
This is a coverall term applied to ascending infection of the genital tract. It encompasses endometritis, salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, and tubo-ovarian abscesses. Chlamydia and gonorrhoea account of most of the cases and the disease is most prevalent in sexually active young people. Imaging features are those secondary to inflammation with increased vascularity to the endometrium and small volume ascites. Inflammation is also seen on MRI as avid enhancement post contrast. Pelvic inflammatory disease can be complicated by a condition called Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome where there is perihepatitis secondary to PID. 
  Granulosa cell tumours
These oestrogen producing tumours can affect women of any age. The excess oestrogen causes irregular or post menopausal bleeding. They tend to be large and multicystic with thick septations and a sponge-like appearance. Importantly they can be differentiated from epithelial ovarian tumours (e.g. Mucinous cystanedomas) by their lack of a feature described as intracystic papillary projections.
  Dermoid
Teratomas and dermoid cysts have very similar imaging characteristics despite their histological differences. They are usually described interchangeably in literature. Mature teratomas are the most common ovarian neoplasm but are slow growing and usually benign. By contrast immature teratomas are malignant. The presence of fat is a strong indicator for a mature teratoma or a dermoid with the combination of fat, fluid and calcification being highly specific. On MRI the fat will show the usual signal drop-out on gradient echo sequences. Calcification is low in signal on T2. Although benign, dermoids can be complicated by torsion or rupture. Malignant degeneration if it does occur, is to squamous cell carcinoma most commonly.
  Ectopic pregnancy 
Vaginal bleeding is very common in early pregnancy but vaginal bleeding with pain or pain without vaginal bleeding definitely call for an ectopic pregnancy to be excluded. Factors which increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy include:
Previous ectopic 
IVF conception
Previous surgery to the Fallopian tubes
PID
Since most present around 7-8 weeks gestation it is usual that the woman will not yet have had the first routine ultrasound scan, or in many cases, may not yet be aware of the pregnancy at all. Serial serum βHCGs usually fail to double in the usual 48hours for ectopic pregnancies. The exact level of βHCG helps guide the sonographer as to what they can expect to find. An ectopic pregnancy is most commonly located within one or other Fallopian tube. Ultrasound will fail to show an intrauterine pregnancy and the ectopic pregnancy can often be seen as a cystic mass elsewhere. The classic ‘ring of fire’ sign refers to the peripheral colour Doppler flow seen on an ectopic pregnancy although this can also be seen on a normal corpus luteal cyst.
GPT3_explain: Ectopic pregnancy is the most likely diagnosis in this case because the patient is a 15-year-old girl with irregular periods, an acute fever and pain, and a raised βHCG level. Additionally, an ultrasound scan revealed the presence of a cystic mass with thick septa on the left, which is a common symptom of ectopic pregnancy.

Qn_Text: You are performing an ultrasound scan on a 4-year-old boy whose parents are concerned that his stomach has become very large. There is a large mass in the left retroperitoneal space. It is heterogeneous in echotexture. The boy goes onto have a CT scan which shows displacement of the IVC and curvilinear calcification. You suspect he may have a Wilms tumour. Which of the following syndromes does not predispose to Wilms tumour? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is a very rare condition which predisposes to chromophobic RCCs. Patients also suffer from pulmonary cysts (increased risk of spontaneous pneumothorax) and fibrofolliculomas (benign fibrous tumours related to the hair follicles).
Predisposing syndromes for Wilms tumour
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome - macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, visceromegaly, omphalocoele
DRASH syndrome - progressive glomerulonephritis and male pseudohermaphroditism
WAGR syndrome - Wilms tumour, aniridia, GU abnormalities, mental retardation
Perlman syndrome - polyhydramnios, macrocephaly, visceromegaly
Golabi-Behmel syndrome - macrostomia, macroglossia, occular hypertelorism
  Wilms tumour (nephroblastoma)
This is the most common abdominal mass in children under the age of 8. There are reasonably strong associations with renal anomalies, genital anomalies, aniridia and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (although the last of these also has an association with neuroblastoma). Presentation is usually with an abdominal mass and/or pain.
On imaging the masses are usually heterogenous. Cystic areas can often be seen secondary to areas of necrosis. The claw sign occurs when there is a rim of normal renal tissue extending part of the way around the mass. A Wilms tumour is often described as enhancing but less so than the adjacent normal renal parenchyma.
  Renal cell carcinoma
After around the age of 11 the incidence of Wilms tumours and renal cell carcinomas are approximately equal. It can be extremely difficult, nigh on impossible, to tell the two apart on imaging characteristics alone. In general however, renal cell carcinomas are more likely to present with haematuria whereas Wilms tumours, being usually very large, are more likely to present as a large abdominal mass. Both can exhibit calcification, though this is more common in renal cell cancer, and both can invade the renal veins or IVC. Any child diagnosed with a renal cell carcinoma must be screened for von Hippel Lindau syndrome.
GPT3_explain: I chose number 2, Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome, because it does not predispose to Wilms tumour. Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder that is characterized by skin lesions, pulmonary cysts, and an increased risk of kidney cancer. Wilms tumour, however, is not associated with this syndrome.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about applying knowledge to a clinical scenario.

Qn_Text: A 74-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, Contrast enhanced CT demonstrates a large mass arising from the duodenum with foci of necrosis and calcification. The mass is heterogeneously enhancing and does not obstruct the lumen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation:
The duodenum is the most common location for intestinal GIST. It is an endoluminal and exophytic mass; there is often aneurysmal dilatation of the lumen. It demonstrates heterogeneous enhancement with central necrosis, unlike Intestinal lymphoma. Lymphatic spread is rare with GIST.
Intestinal metastases present as intramural masses that can compress or obstruct the lumen. Carcinoid tumours are solitary and enhancing. They are associated with mesenteric metastases with a desmoplastic response. Primary duodenal carcinoma mostly presents with small bowel obstruction.
GPT3_explain: I chose 5. Primary Duodenal Carcinoma because the CT scan findings are most consistent with this diagnosis. The large mass arising from the duodenum with foci of necrosis and calcification, and heterogeneous enhancement are all features of a primary duodenal carcinoma. Other diagnoses, such as intestinal lymphoma, intestinal metastases, and intestinal GIST, would not typically present with these findings. Carcinoid tumors tend to be smaller and less heterogeneously enhancing than a primary duodenal carcinoma.

Qn_Text: You are performing a renal artery doppler on a 65-year-old gentleman with worsening renal failure discovered at his most recent blood pressure medication review. An Captopril 99mTc-MAG3  scan showed a delayed time to peak activity on the left side. The ultrasound shows the left kidney to be smaller than the right and on Doppler insonation the arterial peak velocity reading is higher than normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Subspec: SBA: Genito urinary, Adrenal, Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Breast
Explanation:
Explanation:
Renovascular hypertension
This term is used to denote high blood pressure caused by renal artery stenosis or other renal vascular pathology. It is an important entity which affects around 5% of hypertensives and should be suspected in particularly young patients, those whose hypertension suddenly worsens or in patients who experience a drop in renal function following commencement of an ACE inhibitor.
  Tc99m-MAG3, I131-OIH or Tc99m- DTPA can all be used to show differential activity of the kidneys. This test combined with the use of an ACE inhibitor such as enalapril or captopril can facilitate the diagnosis of renovascular hypertension, including unilateral renal artery stenosis although is less sensitive for cases of bilateral renal artery stenosis. Initially the affected kidney will have a slower time to peak activity than the normal counterpart. On administration of an ACE inhibitor the affected side will show a marked lengthening of the time to peak activity as well as an increase in the transit time (seen as a slow downslope of activity following the peak). This arises since the normal effect of the ACE inhibitor on the unaffected size causes retention of tracer and preservation of activity within the kidney whereas the affected side experiences slow transit of the tracer through the kidney.
  Renin-Angiotensin System
Renin is released by the kidneys in response to low renal perfusion levels. It converts angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I which is then converted to angiotensin II by the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). Angiotensin II is a vasoconstrictor which acts on, among other things, the kidneys causing water retention but at the expense of blood pressure. Thus ACE inhibitors, used extensively to manage high blood pressure, work by preventing renal arteriole vasoconstriction. In patients with renovascular hypertension the renal perfusion pressure is low, not because of an absence of water but because the arterial flow is compromised. Thus the usual mechanism of the renin-angiotensin system serves only to exacerbate the problem by increasing blood pressure further and adding more strain to an already strained system.
  Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of A. Rad CC BY-SA 3.0
  Renal artery stenosis
There are three main aetiologies of renal artery stenosis. The most prevalent is atherosclerosis. Fibromuscular dysplasia is the second most common and is classically given as affecting a relatively young woman with beading (string of beads) of the mid and distal renal arteries seen, for which the management is angioplasty. Finally a small number of cases are secondary to a variety of conditions such as Buerger’s disease, Takayasu’s disease and neurofibromatosis.
The significance of diagnosis of atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis is in avoiding the use of ACE inhibitors. The ASTRAL trial showed that there was no long term benefit of stenting the stenoses over best medical management, although there was still a reduction in the number of episodes of flash pulmonary oedema experienced by the patients.
Slightly different numbers are given in the different sources.
  Signs of renal artery stenosis
Peak systolic velocity (PSV)
>150-180 cm/s
Ratio of peak renal artery velocity to peak aortic velocity (RAR)
>3.5
Resistive Index (RI)
<0.5
Difference in RI between left and right
>5%
Renal-interlobar ratio (RIR)
>5
Pulsus parvus (increased peak) et tardus (late) waveform
-
GPT3_explain: I chose 4. Unilateral renal artery stenosis because the ultrasound showed the left kidney to be smaller than the right and on Doppler insonation the arterial peak velocity reading was higher than normal. This is indicative of a narrowing of the renal artery, which is a hallmark symptom of unilateral renal artery stenosis. The other conditions listed can also cause narrowing of the renal artery, but the combination of the Captopril 99mTc-MAG3 scan and the Doppler insonation reading makes unilateral renal artery stenosis the most likely diagnosis.

Qn_Text: A 34-year-old lady wakes up with unilateral facial nerve paralysis affecting her face. She takes herself to A and E where she is investigated with an MRI head. Which part of the facial nerve is most likely to be affected?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
Explanation:
Explanation:
The question refers to Bells palsy.
The seventh cranial nerve undergoes a number of turns as it crosses through the temporal bone.
The pontine (or Cisternal) segment runs from the pons to the internal auditory meatus. This can enhance Bell palsy.
The Labyrinthine (or meatal) segment runs from the internal auditory meatus to the geniculate ganglion and enhancement is most typically associated with Bells palsy.
The Tympanic portion runs horizontally from the geniculate ganglion. It is also seen to enhance with Bells palsy but since it is known to enhance normally too this is not a distinguishing feature.
The mastoid portion runs vertically (and gives off the nerve to stapedius). It can also enhance normally.
The parotid portion runs distally from the stylomastoid foramen and lies lateral to the retromandibular vein.
GPT3_explain: The geniculate ganglion is the most likely part of the facial nerve to be affected in this case because it is the most proximal segment of the facial nerve. It is located in the temporal bone and is responsible for the motor control of the facial muscles. Therefore, it can be affected by trauma or inflammation, which can lead to unilateral facial nerve paralysis.
Cat_Long: 3. A question about the application of knowledge to a clinical situation.

Qn_Text: You are the duty radiologist at your hospital and a radiographer colleague brings you an x-ray request from a local GP. The request is for bilateral whole leg views of a 16-month-old baby who started walking three months previously but now has bowed legs. The GP has done some blood tests which were all normal. What is the most next most appropriate treatment?
B: AP and frog leg lateral views
Explanation:
Explanation:
Once a child becomes weight bearing, minor bowing of the legs is very common and provided the child is otherwise well and it resolves by around 18 months of age, nothing further need be done.
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because AP and frog leg lateral views are the best way to assess for bowed legs in a 16-month-old baby who has just started walking. These views will provide the most comprehensive assessment of the baby's lower extremities and will allow for the most accurate diagnosis. Additionally, these views can help to rule out any potential underlying causes for the bowed legs, such as Blount's disease or rickets.

Qn_Text: A man is admitted with left sided weakness and facial droop which began 8 hours previously. Which of the following would be a contraindication to thrombolysis with alteplase?
Subspec: SBA: Central Nervous and Head & Neck
A: The fact that this began 8 hours ago
Explanation:
Explanation:
Practices vary locally however the usual quoted time frame is 4.5 hours following onset of symptoms. 8 hours is much beyond this.
A normal CT head is often the case for patients who are thrombolysed. There is a time lag before infarcted tissue becomes radiologically apparent. Loss of the insular ribbon sign refers to loss of grey-white matter differentiation at the insular cortex and is often seen with MCA territory infarctions. It forms part of the assessment of the ASPECTS score whereby 10 specific parts of the MCA territory are reviewed. Patients with more than two of these areas involved who are thrombolysed have been shown to have poorer outcomes than those not thrombolysed so whilst insular ribbon involvement on its own is not a contraindication it can contribute to the overall picture.
GPT3_explain: The normal CT head is a contraindication to thrombolysis with alteplase because it suggests that the patient does not have a clot causing the symptoms. Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent that is used to dissolve clots in the blood vessels, and if there is no clot present, then it would not be beneficial to use this medication.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 1: Basic factual recall, either of basic science, physics, anatomy or regarding a procedure.

Qn_Text: A 3-day-old baby is referred for an ultrasound scan with ambiguous genitalia. The ultrasound demonstrates a normal uterus although the ovaries are not seen. What is the most likely explanation? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)
Normal-appearing adrenal glands does not exclude a diagnosis of CAH however usually the classical appearance for the adrenal glands in a case of CAH is of diffuse enlargement with a so-called 'wrinkled' morphology. The word 'cerebriform' is often used to describe them and compares their appearance to that of the brain. The usual hypoechoic cortex and hyperechoic medulla is still seen but the enlarged gland is folded upon itself giving the wrinkled appearance. The role of ultrasound is also to discern any normal male or female anatomy. The normal uterus can usually be identified, if present, but the ovaries may simply be too small at birth to appreciate. In contrast, the normal testes, where present, should be visible with ultrasound from birth. Females usually present with ambiguous genitalia whereas males can present later with severe electrolyte imbalances.
  Mullerian duct anomalies (MDA)
The two Mullerian ducts form separately then fuse in the first trimester to form all the structures between the upper vagina and the fallopian tubes. The final part of the amalgamation of the two sides is resorption of the central uterine septum.
  Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome also known as EMG syndrome (Exomphalos, Macroglossia, Gigantism)
This curious condition crops up in a number of different radiology circles. It is caused by a mutation on chromosome 11 and leads to a specific set of clinical manifestations, chief among them are the three which give it the alternative name of EMG syndrome. Malrotation of the small intestine is another feature which has a high concordance with this condition.
GPT3_explain: Mullerian duct anomalies are the most likely explanation for an ultrasound scan of a 3-day-old baby with ambiguous genitalia that shows a normal uterus but no ovaries. This is because Mullerian duct anomalies are the most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in newborns and can cause the uterus to be present but the ovaries to be absent.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about a clinical scenario.

3. A question about a clinical scenario.

Qn_Text: You are discussing the management plan for a 65-year-old man with a symptomatic stenosis of the popliteal artery. He is obese with a BMI of 48 but has no other medical problems. Which of the following interventional options is the most suitable?
A: Retrograde access via the superficial femoral artery
B: Antegrade access via the superficial femoral artery
C: Antegrade access via the profunda femoris artery
D: Retrograde access via the profunda femoris artery
E: Retrograde access via the popliteal artery
Explanation:
Explanation:
The correct access should of course be determined on a case by case basis and will take into account various facets such as the patient body habitus, any previous access used and the disease site.
The retrograde approach is easier to perform, and patients usually go on to have a lower rate of post-procedure complications.
Antegrade – straight down the ipsilateral side
Retrograde – contralateral groin, up and over the aortic bifurcation
+ Avoids crossover
- Crossover required
- Harder in patients with a high BMI
+ More suited to patients with a high BMI
- Less operator maneuverability
+ Greater operator maneuverability
- Harder to perform
+ Easier to perform
  The common femoral artery (CFA) is usually the best candidate since it is large and easy to find as it courses over the femoral head. Its proximity to the femoral head facilitates effective compression post-procedure minimizing the risk of complications.
Here use of the CFA is contraindicated (or not given as an option!) the superficial femoral artery (SFA) is the next best option. Owing to its superficial nature it can be an easier target in obese patients. The popliteal artery is a continuation of the SFA so clearly antegrade access via the profunda femoris artery is nonsensical.
Direct popliteal artery access is performed during SFA angioplasty when conventional approaches are not feasible however would be an unusual approach for this case.
GPT3_explain: I chose this option because it is the safest and least invasive method of accessing the popliteal artery. It is important to minimize the risk of complications in this patient due to their age and obesity. By accessing the artery via the superficial femoral artery, the risk of vascular injury is minimized, as the artery is located more superficially and is easier to access. Additionally, this method is less likely to cause damage to the surrounding tissue, which is important for this patient.
Cat_Long: This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 65-year-old man suffers a myocardial infarction and undergoes a primary angioplasty. He is discovered to have a blockage in the left coronary artery. Which SINGLE statement regarding the left coronary artery is true?
A: It supplies part of the bundle of His
B: It bifurcates into the anterior interventricular branch and the left marginal branch
C: It supplies the SA and AV nodes
D: It continues to the apex of the heart as the posterior descending artery
E: It is smaller than the right coronary artery
Explanation:
Explanation:
The left coronary artery arises from the aorta above the left cusp of the aortic valve. It supplies the left atrium, left ventricle, intraventricular septum and part of the left branch bundle of His. It is larger than the right coronary artery.
It passes between the left side of the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then birfucates into the left anterior descending artery (LAD), which is also called the anterior interventricular branch, and the left circumflex artery (LCA). Sometimes an additional artery arises at the bifurcation called the ramus or intermediate artery.
The LAD follows the anterior interventricular groove towards the apex of the heart and then continues to the posterior surface of the heart to anastamose with the posterior interventricular branch.
The LCA follows the anterior interventricular groove to the left border of the heart and then proceeds to the posterior surface. It then gives rise to the left marginal branch, which follows the left border of the heart.
The right coronary artery arises above the right cusp of the aortic valve. It supplies the right atrium, the SA and AV nodes and the posterior part of the interventricular septum.
It runs along the right atrioventricular groove before branching. The right marginal artery arises first and then the right coronary artery continues on to the posterior surface of the heart, still running in the right atrioventricular groove. The posterior descending artery (PDA), which is also called the posterior interventricular artery, arises next and then follows the posterior interventricular groove towards the apex of the heart.
    Image sourced from Wikipedia
Courtesy of Patrick J. Lynch CC BY-SA 3.0
GPT3_explain: I chose number 5 because the left coronary artery is typically smaller than the right coronary artery. The left coronary artery supplies the left ventricle and the interventricular septum, while the right coronary artery supplies the right ventricle and the posterior wall of the left ventricle. The left coronary artery bifurcates into the anterior interventricular branch and the left marginal branch, and it continues to the apex of the heart as the posterior descending artery.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about clinical management, what is the best course of action?

The question falls under Category 3: A question about clinical management, what is the best course of action?

Qn_Text: You are reviewing the images of a patient with sacroiliitis known to have an inflammatory arthritis. Which of the following diagnoses is correctly associated with its usual pattern of sacroiliitis? Select ONE answer only.
A: Bilateral asymmetrical sacroiliitis in psoriatic arthropathy
B: Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis in infective arthropathy
C: Bilateral asymmetrical sacroiliitis in enteropathic arthropathy
D: Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis in chronic reactive arthritis
E: Bilateral asymmetrical sacroiliitis in ankylosing spondylitis
Explanation:
Explanation:
Sacroiliitis in psoriatic arthropathy can be bilateral symmetrical or bilateral asymmetrical though the latter is more common.
  Psoriatic arthropathy
Around a fifth of patients with psoriasis develop arthropathy and it is also possible to suffer from psoriatic arthropathy in the absence of the typical psoriatic cutaneous plaques. Around 80% of patients are HLA-B27 positive.
Importantly, on x-ray there are findings of both erosive changes in addition to productive changes with periosteal new bone formation. The combination of the two contrives to leave a ‘pencil-in-cup’ appearance. The joints can appear fluffy due to the exuberance of new bone formation.
The differential diagnosis for periosteal reactions in the presence of an arthropathy is relatively narrow and very specific:
Psoriatic arthropathy
Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
Reiter syndrome
Infective arthropathy
  Although often classified as a distal arthropathy, preferring the DIPs to the MCPs, psoriatic arthropathy does also affect the spine and SI joints frequently. ‘Sausage digits’ is a term used to describe the diffuse soft tissue swelling which can affect the fingers and toes. Osteoporosis does occur but is a feature of later disease.
  Seronegative arthritides - These are negative for Rheumatoid factor but have a strong association with HLA-B27 positivity.
Ankylosing spondylitis - 95%
Enteropathic arthropathy - 90%
Psoriatic arthritis - 80%
Chronic reactive arthritis - 70%
  Ankylosing spondylitis
This disease usually presents in early adulthood with gradual onset of back pain. There is a male preponderance, though it can affect women too. The vast majority (>90%) of patients are HLA-B27 positive. Radiologically the late features are classical with:
Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis
Enthesopathy - calcified tendon insertion sites
Bamboo spine - vertebral syndesmophytes, particularly in the thoracolumbar spine
Dagger sign - spinous process fusion
Erosion, then fusion at the symphysis pubis, costochondral, costovertebral and sternoclavicular joints
Thoracic manifestations: upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis, pericarditis, aortic root dilatation
  Early features are far more subtle and require a higher index of suspicion.
Enthesopathy - high signal on MRI at tendon insertion sites
Romanus lesions - triangular shaped oedema at the corners of vertebral bodies
Andersson lesions - bony oedema in the vertebral bodies adjacent to the disks.
Oedema in the sacroiliac joints.
  Patients with advanced ankylosing spondylitis are at increased risk of pathological fractures due to fusion. These can be pelvic fractures following a simple fall, or chance fractures of the spine (involving all three columns - in ankylosing spondylitis, these fractures are also sometimes termed chalk-stick or carrot fractures).
  Chronic reactive arthritis
This disease is said to present as a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis/uveitis and urethritis/cervicitis (Can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree) however in reality only around a third of patients present with all three symptoms. Patients are usually aged 16-60 years. It has a reasonably strong male predominance but does occur in women. It can occur following infection with chlamydia, but also with gastrointestinal infections such as salmonella, shigella, campylobacter and yersinia. Most (>2/3rds) of patients are HLA-B27 positive.
Bilateral asymmetrical sacroiliitis
Paravertebral ossification - similar to syndesmophytes but in theory are seen separately from the disc, bridging around it. Most commonly in the thoracolumbar spine.
Enthesopathy - particularly at achilles tendon insertion, interspinous ligaments, and pelvic ligaments.
  Enteropathic arthropathy
This occurs in a subsect of patients with inflammatory or infective bowel disease. Roughly 10-20% of patients with Crohn’s or ulcerative colitis suffer from enteropathic arthropathy. Like chronic reactive arthropathy, it can also occur in the context of salmonella, shigella and yersinia infections. Appearances are very similar to those of ankylosing spondylitis; the two can be very difficult to separate radiologically.
Bilateral symmetrical sacroillitis
Enthesopathy
Vertebral syndesmophytes
Fusion of spinous processes
  Juvenile idiopathic arthritis
This condition used to be termed juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. It is a cluster of similar conditions affecting patients under the age of 16.
The affected joints show:
Effusions
Erosions
Cartilage destruction
  Epiphyseal overgrowth secondary to reactive hyperaemia occurs owing to the immature nature of the skeleton. Premature physeal closure can result in limb length discrepancies in adulthood.
Large joints are typically affected first and the small joints of the hands and feet are affected later on.
  Image © Medical Exam Prep
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because ankylosing spondylitis is a type of arthritis that is known to cause bilateral asymmetrical sacroiliitis. This type of sacroiliitis is characterized by an inflammation of the sacroiliac joint, which is located in the lower back and can cause pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion. Therefore, it is the most likely diagnosis for the patient in the images.
Cat_Long: 2. A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents after they notice acute severe scrotal swelling. The doctor in the department is worried he may have a testicular torsion so arranges an urgent ultrasound scan and review by the surgical team. The ultrasound scan suggests a diagnosis of idiopathic scrotal wall oedema syndrome. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct? Select ONE answer.
C: It is more common in adults than children
E: Scrotal pain is the dominant feature
Explanation:
Explanation:
Acute idiopathic scrotal wall oedema syndrome
This occurs mostly in children under the age of 10 but can occur in adults too and is an important differential diagnosis for acute scrotal pain. It is thought to be a kind of localised hypersensitivity reaction. Scrotal swelling is typical but accompanying pain may or may not be present. Features are usually fairly typical on ultrasound with unilateral scrotal wall oedema (can be bilateral in 10%) and hypervascularity. Reactive hydrocoeles may be present, as with most scrotal pathology. Importantly, the condition requires no surgical input and can be managed conservatively with NSAIDs, avoiding an unnecessary surgery/anaesthetic for the patient when correctly diagnosed.
GPT3_explain: I chose this answer because it is the most accurate statement regarding idiopathic scrotal wall oedema syndrome. This condition is more common in adults than in children, and it does not require surgical drainage, it is not usually bilateral, and scrotal pain is not the dominant feature.
Cat_Long:
3. A question about the management of a patient, what is the best treatment?

This question falls under category 2: A question about clinical judgement, what is the correct diagnosis?

Qn_Text: A 56-year-old man complains to his GP of ongoing abdominal pain for the last few months. Examination is unremarkable, an OGD and colonoscopy are both negative. While awaiting an outpatient CT scan he becomes acutely unwell and is admitted. An inpatient CT is arranged which shows a small bowel lesion that you suspect to be a stromal tumour. Which of the following is LEAST consistent with this diagnosis? Select ONE answer only.
Explanation:
Explanation:
Please note that the question asks which feature is LEAST consistent with the diagnosis.
Stromal tumour also known as GIST (Gastrointestinal stromal tumour)
Particularly when of low staging at resection, these tumours carry an excellent prognosis.
